name: Der Präsident. –
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on the council and Commission statements in preparation for the European Council (19-20 March 2015) (2014/2941(RSP)).

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I am glad to address you today on the forthcoming meeting of the European Council. It will be dedicated to three major topics: the Energy Union, the economy and external relations. They all require adequate attention at the highest political level.  Let me start with the Energy Union. Successful establishment of the European Energy Union with a forward-looking climate change policy is among the most important priorities of the Latvian Presidency. I am very satisfied to see that the energy union enjoys broad support among the Members of the European Parliament, which was reflected, among other things, by the discussion of 25 February 2015 in Parliament’s plenary in Brussels. We followed the debate very attentively and took note of the views expressed.  It is very important to keep the political momentum and to proceed without delay in making the energy union a reality. Over the last months there have been several fruitful and constructive discussions on the energy union at various levels. The first was the Riga Conference of 6 February 2015 and I am very proud that it is in Riga where we started ‘moving away from 28 different national policies to the good European one’, as it was stated by Vice—President Šefčovič. The Council started immediately to work on all the five dimensions of the Energy Union. Let me briefly mention some preliminary views expressed in the Council to give Members an insight. The views expressed in the Council so far will be handed over to the President of the European Council thus contributing to the debate of the European Council.  First, on energy security, solidarity and trust, there were broadly—shared views among Ministers that reducing energy dependency and vulnerability, especially concerning gas supplies, is a priority. There was also general support for bolstering supply diversification strategies of sources, suppliers and routes and reinforcing strategic energy partnerships.  Second, on a fully—integrated European energy market, the Council underlined the necessity for strong and coordinated action to accomplish key infrastructure projects and to increase, reinforce and coordinate cross-border interconnections, as well as underlined the need to fully implement the legislation. Third, on energy efficiency, the Council underscored its importance in support of energy security, competitiveness, decarbonisation and innovation, as well as bringing direct benefits to consumers through lower energy bills.  Fourth, on decarbonising the economy, the views in Council were in favour of using the potential of renewable energy sources more cost-efficiently and sustainably.  Concerning the fifth dimension – research, innovation and competitiveness – the discussions in the Council touched upon funding for research and innovation through Horizon 2020 that should be targeted effectively. Let me be clear that overall there is a common view in the Council that all five dimensions are equally important and interconnected, and they should be mutually reinforcing. The Council expects from the European Council clear political guidelines for further work. The major focus of the March European Council will be on enhancing energy security, reaping the benefits of the internal energy market and pursuing climate diplomacy. Traditionally, the Spring European Council is the economic rendez—vous. The European Council will conclude the first phase of the 2015 European Semester. This reformed and streamlined process requires from the European Council a clear steer to Member States for the preparation of their national reform and stability or convergence programmes. And that is what the European Council will do. The European Semester will also constitute an occasion to have a more general look at the Union’s economic situation. In this context, I welcome the adoption by the Council yesterday of the general approach on the European Fund for Strategic Investments. I reiterate our full readiness to cooperate constructively with you to adopt the legislative act by June, so that the European Fund for Strategic Investments can be fully deployed from mid-2015.  On the economy, the European Council will also discuss the state of play in the negotiations with the United States on TTIP. This is a very timely and important debate which could give further impulse to the process of negotiations. Its economic and geopolitical importance was once again reiterated by the President of the European Council, Mr Tusk, when speaking to President Obama two days ago. I will turn to the European Semester in a more detailed manner during the joint debate in a while. The third topic of this European Council will be external relations. Following the informal meeting of Heads of State and Government on 12 February and following a very fruitful exchange of views at Gymnich Foreign Ministers’ informal meeting, the European Council will discuss the recent developments on the implementation of the latest Minsk Agreement, the situation in Ukraine and relations with Russia. Based on the assessment of the situation, the Council is expected to agree on further steps. This European Council will also give a steer to the preparation of the Eastern Partnership Summit. The Summit will take place in Riga on 21 and 22 May this year. We all want it to be a success. We all see at what cost comes the striving of some of the Eastern Partnership countries to build closer relationships with the European Union. It is paramount that the European Union shows adequate commitment.  The European Council will provide guidance in particular on the objectives of the Summit and on the way forward concerning some issues. Meaningful deliverables and clear vision for the development of the Eastern Partnership in coming years both in the multilateral field and in relations with each individual country are equally important. The Riga Summit should send a strong political message reaffirming the strategic importance and our commitment to the Eastern Partnership Summit. This will also include implementation of the Association Agreements with Georgia, the Republic of Moldova and Ukraine. The Riga Summit should demonstrate the Union’s intention to strengthen, in a differentiated way, relations with each of its six partners based on the level of ambition and the goals to which they aspire in their relations with the European Union. More incentives for the most advanced partners and development of individual bilateral relations with other partners should be considered.  Particular efforts shall be devoted to advance cooperation in such areas as state building, people to people contacts, as well as economics. At the Riga Summit we should achieve progress in the mobility area, as well as use the current window of opportunity to deepen EU relations with Belarus. The Riga Summit should emphasise that the Eastern Partnership has achieved concrete results and it is advancing. Finally, the European Council will have an exchange of views about Libya. We have seen some positive developments as regards the reconciliation talks in Rabat under the good offices of the UN Special Envoy, Bernardino Leon. The Council will continue closely monitoring the situation in order to respond adequately, when appropriate. The situation in Libya will also be discussed in the upcoming Foreign Affairs Council. The situation there is escalating and this has consequences not only for the region, but also for our own security.  We are concerned about the destabilising effect Libya has on the region, as well as illegal migration and terrorist threats that cannot be tackled without addressing the internal situation in the country. The European Council will revert to these issues in more detail in October in the context of a broader discussion on the Southern Neighbourhood. To better manage migration flows it is important to continue to implement the comprehensive approach adopted by the Council on 10 October 2014. The Presidency will continue to closely monitor the situation and will address this issue at the upcoming Justice and Home Affairs Council this week and in June. I thank you very much for your attention and look forward to a very fruitful debate this morning.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the Commission - Mr President, Madam President of the Council, Mr First Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I just want to inform you that the Commission is at work, that it is working with speed and that it is trying to work effectively.  We have submitted to your review and nuanced approval the investment plan, which is important. We have adopted new rules of transparency that we wanted you to draw inspiration from: there is work and effort to be made.  We have published a Green Paper on the Union of Capital Markets, which is an essential union. We presented our first ideas on the energy union, we made decisions on surveillance in the european semester - sometimes disputed, I am not unaware - but reading the decisions in detail, you will see that they read like a poem, they speak for themselves, and so they should be read in full.  We have started the debate on the European migration programme. We have put forward the timetable: in the work programme that was presented, this issue of the migration program was planned to be addressed in July, but in light of recent tragic events, Vice-President Timmermans decided to advance the presentation of the program in May. Finally, we have begun the review of our neighbourhood policies.  I will tell you, if I may, a word about the union of energy. The aim, which should bring us together around this concept of the energy union, is the need to guarantee the energy supply of the European Union. It's about making sure that we stay or become competitive when it comes to energy. It is a matter of not losing sight of our commitments on climate policy.  In fact, in terms of security of supply, our situation is not optimal. We import 53% of the energy we consume and the cost of this import is 400 billion euros a year: we spend more than one billion euros a day by importing energy that we would be better off saving. Our electricity prices are 40% higher than those in the U.S., which, in terms of relative and comparative competitiveness, takes away all the means we would need to be able to operate equally with the United States.  We need to bring the 28 energy markets together in one energy union. It is about taking concrete steps so that we can establish a more integrated, interconnected and secure market. All of this is feasible if we have a strong will to achieve these goals. We saw this a week ago, at a mini-summit in Madrid bringing together President Hollande, the Prime Ministers of Spain and Portugal and the President of the Commission, aiming to open up, from the point of view of energy supply, the Iberian peninsula, which is a real island in this area. At the 2002 European Council in Barcelona, which I was attending as Prime Minister, we agreed on a 10% interconnectivity target. We are a long way from that, but with the decisions taken in Madrid, we are getting closer to that goal. I am impressed by the fact that the three governments involved have set up a working group to monitor the implementation of these decisions. If we had done it in 2002, we would not have to do it now; it is not a question of pouring into the literature, but of acting in a concrete way. That is what we did in Madrid a week ago, and that is what we need to do to put an end to this irrational element in our energy landscape, which is to see 28 energy regulators evolve in parallel, and very often against each other. This waste should be put to an end.  I would like to stress, once again, the need to meet our climate commitments. The Paris summit is approaching by leaps and bounds and we must be prepared to ensure that the targets we have set for ourselves - a 40% reduction - are shared by as many other partners as possible.  This year, the European semester is unique in that again, we have accelerated the procedures. Instead of presenting country-by-country reports in May and June, we have advanced their presentation in February, in order to allow Parliament, the Council and also the social partners, since social dialogue is particularly important, to examine these reports in detail.  I note with satisfaction that the Council of Finance Ministers yesterday unanimously adopted our proposals for the European Investment Fund- which is rare in Europe. Strategic. A year ago, in March 2014, who would have thought that we would be able to ensure that Europe could build on an investment plan that will cover EUR 315 billion?  I also note with satisfaction that Spain, Germany, Italy and France have announced bilateral contributions to the financing of the European Fund for Strategic Investments, which should be congratulated on the countries in question, after inviting all others to do the same. For once, let all other countries imitate France and Germany! Instead of complaining about the overflowing influence of these two countries, other governments should emulate them.  With regard to this fund for strategic investments and this investment plan, I would like to once again call on Parliament to act with consequence and speed. I am well aware of the debates taking place in this House, I am well aware of the attitudes of each other, and I would like to say here, as I have done elsewhere, that the Commission, that is, Europe, without making an equation between the two, needs a solid funding guarantee. We cannot, without the $16 billion, assure investors and everyone else that the investment plan will have a happy future. Therefore, I must strongly stress the absolute need to make a guarantee fund available to the Fund for Strategic Investments, which will cover EUR 16 billion. I do not want to interfere today in the debate, between those who have a natural and understandable penchant for research policies, the volume of which will not be undermined by the Commission's proposal, and those who, in terms of interconnectivity, have ambitions that carry far, and which the fund does not initiate either. However, I would like Parliament to know that we will have to find at all costs a mechanism to put in place a solid guarantee that is not subject to the vagaries of the annual budgetary procedure.  It is very likely, Mr President, that the European Council will have an exchange of views tomorrow on the free trade negotiations that we have had and that we will have with a number of countries. I do not go into the details of this debate, I would just like to say that, at the European Council, I will urge the Heads of State and Government to tell us very clearly. I observe that when we are gathered in the European Council, everyone is in favour of an agreement with the United States, and when everyone is back home, I see, from reading the statements in the national press, that the enthusiasm is waning. There are a few hundred kilometres of distance between Brussels and the different capitals, but it seems that this journey is not only a source of good inspiration but also of a weakening of ambitions; therefore, I would like us to clear this up. On the substance, I have told you everything, but on form, which is only the substance that appears on the surface, I would like governments to clearly state what they want. I would not want Frans Timmermans, who is in charge of the transatlantic partnership in particular, since he is in charge of everything the Commission does and does not do, to find a sudden death on the altar of an agreement which, later on, it would turn out that no one wanted. Therefore, we will ask the Prime Ministers not to be accountable, but to clarify their short- and long-term intentions. The First Vice-President, with his overflowing authority, will inform you, Mr President, of the aspects that concern our neighbourhood policies.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr Timmermans, I would like to thank Mr Timmermans for his work They are not included in the list of speakers. But since we are polite people, we will of course let you talk, in the short ness.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. Mr President, our neighbourhood has changed a great deal in the last ten years. From eastern Ukraine to Libya, the least we can say is that it has become much more unstable. It confronts us with significant challenges that affect the core of many of our interests, including the security of energy supplies and the management of migration flows. Moreover, not all our partners have the same ambitions and aspirations for their relations with the European Union. We face a major geopolitical challenge.  We must take these factors into account when we address the next Eastern Partnership Summit in Riga. It is a question of confirming the specific dimension of this partnership within our neighbourhood policy, but also of reaffirming that this partnership is not directed against anyone. It is an expression of the convergence of interests and values in respect of the right of each partner to freely choose the level of its ambitions in its relations with the European Union.  Every European country has the sovereign right to determine its destiny without submission to other states. The debate in the European Council will no doubt focus on the crisis in Ukraine. This will include taking stock of the implementation of the latest Minsk agreement and developing a strategy that encourages all stakeholders to respect scrupulously what has been agreed. Sanctions against Russia will continue to be part of our strategy. We know that the most difficult elements of the agreement should not be put in place until December, when the existing sanctions come to an end in July and September. The Commission will contribute fully to the implementation of these agreements.  We have resumed trilateral discussions on gas. I hope that the next meeting, by the end of March, will address the issue of Ukraine's gas supply until spring 2016. A few words about Libya. We support the diplomatic efforts of the UN Special Representative, Bernardino Leon, and call for the formation of a government of national unity in Libya.  The Commission strongly believes in the virtues of dialogue. This requires determination and patience, but we must do everything we can to keep the channels of discussion open and not to be drawn into a dangerous spiral of confrontation.

name: Manfred Weber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Presidents, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. I would like to start with the Energy Union, which will be one of the Council's priorities. I am grateful for the commission's ambition to put its first ideas on the table. Europe must become more independent in its energy supply. This is one of the core tasks we have to master. The commission's approach to competition is, of course, the right approach in the field of energy. We need partnerships with other energy producers. For us, the USA is a partner with whom we want to talk more about energy exchange in the future. TTIP is an opportunity to talk to the Americans about energy issues. I fully support the position of our President of the Commission that we need clarity from the Member States on how they stand on TTIP, especially from the management level. We want TTIP to succeed! Secondly, with the case of energy, I would like to say that the implementation of the decisions that have been mentioned so far should actually be the first task that the Council is taking on. It would be exciting if the Commission were to present an audit report on what the Council has promised and what has not been delivered so far. The very example of strengthening the interconnectors between France and Spain is an issue that has been on the table for a long time and, unfortunately, has not been addressed by God. That is why the Council should first take a self-critical approach to these issues. I would like to raise one last point on the energy issue, namely the link with climate protection and climate issues. The European Union is leading the way on this issue globally. We support the European Union in Paris as the leader in climate protection. However, I would also like to say on the part of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats that, despite all the leadership, and all the way forward, we must also look in between to see whether others follow us in the process. We must not lose sight of our competitiveness. The President of the Commission highlighted energy costs in his speech. That is why: yes to ambition, yes to the courage of Europe to go ahead, to go its own way, but these objectives must remain global and realistic. The second point I would like to raise is the concerns about the economic situation in the European Union and, above all, the situation in Greece. The EPP wants the euro area to hold together, the EPP wants Greece to be and remain a strong and stable partner in Europe, in the European Union. The aid that has been confirmed, the extension of the programme by the euro countries, confirms that we Europeans want this. I would like to point out that there has never been such a large majority in the German Bundestag for a programme as in this programme extension. In other words, the parliaments in the euro area, including the Member States, want partnership with Greece. However, we need a Greek partner who works seriously with us. And when we hear that in Brussels the Greek government agrees to extend the programme and then in Greece, in Athens, it is said that there is no longer any programme when the Greek Government in Brussels agrees that it is prepared to continue to accept monitoring in the form of the institution with the new name, and in Greece it is said that there is no more monitoring. , then this is not a serious approach. I hope that the Greek Government will immediately feel that it is a government and will stop being a campaigner. This would be extremely important for further development in this context. Patience, I have to say, is certainly not infinite, and Athens has a great responsibility here. In this overall context, I would like to say what we want to emphasise when deciding on France as the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats: we must not give the impression that there are different procedures for large and small Member States in the European Union. These are the issues that are on the agenda. Finally, I would like to say that, in Minsk, we share the hope that we can secure peace in Ukraine. The focus for us is to maintain unity and, secondly, to look at Ukraine's economic problems. Europe is doing a lot there, but we know that this is not enough. We must do more to help Ukraine economically now. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Εμμανουήλ Γλέζος (
text: GUE/NGL), "blue card" question. I ask Mr Weber to clarify the matter precisely. Is he asking the Greek people to overturn their verdict, yes or no?

name: Manfred Weber (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. We have made agreements with the Greek partners in the past. These agreements have been signed by the democratically legitimate representatives of the Greek people in the past, as have Portugal and Ireland. We have practised the partnership. What the European Union now expects of the Greek Government is that it will implement what is agreed and signed in Brussels at home and explain it to its own citizens. We have to end the double game, then we can also return to a sensible approach. I would like to emphasise once again that everyone, including in our group, wants Greece to remain in the eurozone as a strong and stable partner.

name: Gianni Pittella
text: Mr President, Vice-Presidents, Vice-President vicar, ladies and gentlemen, I will follow the list of Mrs Kalnièa-Lukashevica's proposal with the three points, but first I would like to say very affectionately to Manfred that he is a little recidivist in pointing out non-virtuous countries. The British French is making major reforms, taking courageous and anti-current positions, and it is paradoxical that instead of praising it, it is being criticised. Economy: Investment fund, the Council did well yesterday. Parliament is doing its job with its two rapporteurs, Mr Bullmann and Mr Fernandes. We are not a place to ratify, but we do not want to overturn the proposal either; we want to strengthen it, and parliament's position will therefore be an absolutely constructive position because we want the operation to succeed. It was those who proposed it, we in the Socialist and Democratic Group, who want to defend this great gamble that the Commission and Parliament are making for investment. And we applaud those governments that are contributing – as President Juncker mentioned – Italy, France, Spain and Germany, and we encourage others to bet on this plan. On Greece, we are continuing to work towards an agreement, despite the contradictory positions of the Greek Government. On the energy union, I endorse the things that have been said by President Juncker and Mrs Kalnièa-Lukashevica. Energy union is a very important objective. We must decarbonise Europe and aim for targets to reduce domestic emissions by at least 40 % by 2030, and we can do even more, taking into account certain difficult situations in some regions that affect the industrial sector, to which some positive responses must be given. We must and can reduce energy bills and our dependence on external energy imports. Finally, foreign policy. It is all very well, and rightly so, Minsk, verification, but the centrality today is Libya and on Libya we must strongly support the action that High Representative Mogherini is taking: the meetings, the attempt to find a point of recomposition through the diplomatic route. The talks in Morocco and Algeria are doing well, but we must do so quickly before the country is left to anarchy and disarray. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: John Stuart Agnew (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Pitella, are you aware that if you succeed in decarbonising Europe, our crops will have no natural gas to grow from? We have to have carbon dioxide. What you are suggesting is absolute madness and our agricultural industry is going to suffer heavily if we attempt to bury carbon dioxide in the ground: it is absolutely mad.

name: Gianni Pittella (S&D)
text: Answer to a blue card question. Thank you for giving me the authorship of a proposal, a gamble that is not mine but one of very authoritative personalities from the political, scientific and economic worlds. The collective aim is to reduce carbon emissions, and I believe that this is a shared objective. We must support this idea, support energy from renewable sources and take account of certain situations in which the industrial sector would suffer negative consequences, which must be remedied.

name: Andrzej Duda
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Ladies and gentlemen, Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. I am listening to this discussion and, as far as the Energy Union issue is concerned, one thing is clear, I ask you: it is obvious to the data that we have heard – 53% of the energy we import, it is 40% more expensive than in the United States – that the demand for decarbonisation and the policy towards it, in the direction of renewable energy only in principle, is to put out the fire with petrol, because it will lead to the collapse of the European economy and in terms of prices , which european citizens are paying for electricity today, I assure you that they will not fall, but will increase significantly, not to mention the hundreds of thousands of jobs that we will lose in European industry.  That is why we should have a sensible policy, and the sensible policy in this case is the policy of respecting technological neutrality, of using those energy sources that the Member States have today. And that is where spending, including EU funds, should go in order to leave european countries the opportunity to self-establish themselves, to decide sovereignly to what extent they will be developing. Of course, given the need to develop new technologies, but these technologies are already there, including in terms of burning coal, and at the same time moving towards climate protection, but in a sensible and safe way for the European economy. This is my great call for such action within the Energy Union in the years to come. The Union should be as energy-sovereign as possible, it is obvious, but let us remember that this also means increasing the production of our native energy. And that's the basic point – using the sources you have as much as possible.  And the second point I want to raise is the issue of Ukraine. I regret invariably that the European Union was not directly represented in Minsk. Nevertheless, an agreement was reached. And now an extremely important issue remained, namely the aim of all our efforts to comply with this agreement. Because it cannot be said that the agreement is only partially respected. That cannot be enough for us. No further than the previous night Ukrainian positions were bombed twelve times and not with light weapons, but with heavy weapons of 152 mm caliber, which should not have been there for a long time, and 9 Ukrainian soldiers were wounded.  I call on the Council to have a unanimous policy in this area, unity of the European Union and solidarity. We need to respond to Ukraine's needs, we need the help that Ukraine will expect, which we should decide on together, while showing the strength of the European Union and the disagreement with Russia's imperial policy, which means attacking sovereign and independent countries.

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to make three points on this third European Council of the year.  Firstly on Russia: I think that what you have to try to do in the Council is have unity on the issue of Russia; on the issue of Ukraine. What I see is a mess in the Council, with Mr Orban making an energy deal with Putin outside the Energy Union, and at the same time a Spanish Minister of Foreign Affairs going along with Mr Lavrov and saying that the sanctions are useless and not necessary. That is not the way to handle the European Union and to have a common foreign policy.  I think we need a two—track approach to Russia. On the one hand, like I said in the last debate with Mr Tusk, we need a proactive approach instead of waiting for the next step that Mr Putin will take. What is our strategy for the future? It has to be a strategy where maybe we strengthen sanctions – I think it shall be necessary in the future, unfortunately. But at the same time we also have to come up with a positive package for Russia and for the Russian population, where we make a clear distinction between the Putin regime on the one hand and Russia and the Russian population on the other. This is not a war against Russia; this is not a war against the Russian population, so why not decide on visa liberalisation for young people, for researchers, for businessmen of small and medium—sized companies inside Russia?  That is my first bit. The second is on the Spring Council. First of all, I want to say to Mr Rabbitte that he is right, as regards the semester, that there is the impression that there are two types of countries in the Union – the small countries who have to apply the rules of the Stability Pact and the bigger countries who do not. That is a mistake because we are in fact repeating the mistakes of 2003 and 2004.  That said – and I want to mention this especially for the representation of the Council – it is a Spring Council, it is about creating the most competitive knowledge—based economy in the world – that is the buzzword we always use in the Spring Council. There is one thing you can do in this Council, which is you can take a step in the direction of the digital single market and the telecoms market. You can, in fact, annul and eliminate the bad decision taken a few days ago by the EU ambassadors on roaming charges. That you can do. That should be a huge step in the right direction. India has today a fully digital single market with no roaming charges; with net neutrality. The Americans now have no roaming charges inside their country, they abolished it and at the same time net neutrality has been the key, the rule in use.  Why can we not do that in Europe? I find it a shame that it is at the level of EU ambassadors that a decision is taken to wait until 2018 for the digital single market, because that is the reality. I ask of you one thing. This third European Council will be a big success if, in a few days’ time in this Council, you decide to reverse the decision of the EU ambassadors, you decide not to give in to the interests of a few big telecoms companies in Europe and you decide finally to get rid of the roaming charges and to bring about net neutrality in Europe.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Thank you, Mr Verhofstadt, that was very entertaining and eloquently put as always. You started your speech by pointing out the difficulties with sovereign states and their ambassadors having different views and different priorities when dealing with Russia. Does that not, out of your own words, condemn the whole idea of a common EU foreign policy to the rubbish bin, because there are too many different priorities? It can never work, can it?

name: Guy Verhofstadt (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – I agree with you that, with 28 different diplomacies and 28 different armies, it is not possible. (Heckling) You can continue with your British army – that is no problem for me – but if you look at the world of today, if you look at the empires of India and China, and the United States, and also Russia, you will see that the time is very near when we are going to decide on a European army in the European Union.

name: Gabriele Zimmer
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The debate on the summit so far, which is taking place, has referred to a number of points. I would like to refer essentially to the issue of the Energy Union, as we will also be discussing the European Semester afterwards. I would simply like to make it a little more fundamental, Mr Juncker, because I also had the impression that neither the Council nor the Commission were even further addressing the issues behind the debate on the Energy Union. It is really a question of the fundamental question of whether access to energy supply for people should not be the priority, instead of looking at the issue of price stability and supply stability solely from the point of view of large companies. After all, this also raises the question of democratic control over the availability of energy. I regret that we are not continuing to debate these fundamental issues. Because if we continue to be stuck in this grid as before, nothing will change and questions such as energy poverty – why people suffer from the fact that they do not have enough energy here in the European Union to heat, to wash, to cook – will remain virtually completely hidden and cannot be solved by fine sayings. Mr Juncker, you rightly referred to 53% imports, you also said at another point that it is important to you that the EU should become the number one eu in terms of renewable energy. I believe, however, that what is now being presented in the Council is not aimed in this direction, that it is not aimed at the fact that we can really make a change. It is not ambitious enough to say that we do not want to lose sight of the climate targets. I would like to draw attention to a wider context. Last week, the Chancellor was in the Commission and said that she would be strongly committed to signing TTIP later this year. I would like to draw attention to the fact that there is indeed a link between TTIP and the Energy Union, not least fracking. Neither the Council nor the Commission has talked about fracking today and that fracking is one of the reasons why pressure is being exerted for TTIP to be speeded up. I would like to point out once again that we do not think fracking is appropriate to actually promote energy change and also to say that we are setting ourselves up on a different basis. In Saal in Mecklenburg-Vorpommern, test drilling was discontinued in the summer of last year. To this day, we have no information as to what the reasons for the cancellation of the test funding were. I think there are enough reasons why fracking should be prevented and TTIP removing the barriers to the introduction of fracking. That is my request to you to include this in the recitals. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Dear Colleague, I have seen you start your speech by addressing the Commission and the Council. Do you not think that the Council and the Commission should, however, take more account of what we, the European Parliament, are doing here? Because, after all, we are accountable to European citizens when the Commission or the Council takes the wrong decision.

name: Gabriele Zimmer (GUE/NGL)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I agree with you, of course. However, I must also take note of the fact that the Positions of the European Parliament have often been pushed aside by the Council and the Commission. That is why I have now expressly addressed the two of them to point out once again that at least some of the Members of this Parliament also take a different position.

name: Rebecca Harms
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, Presidents, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Guy Verhofstadt said: This is the third summit this year. I would add that it is another summit which, even though Jean-Claude Juncker has spoken calmly, will be famous for that at some point! – which is taking place again at a time when the European Union is under enormous pressure from centrifugal forces in different directions. Greece is not the most prominent issue on this summit agenda. But everyone here knows that it is not only in Greece that people come home that people talk differently than in Brussels. In Germany, too, I note that people who have commented on Greece in Brussels speak differently at home and, in these discussions, very lightly jeopardise the unity of the European Union. In my opinion, however, there are also increasing centrifugal forces in the debate about the European Union's attitude towards Russia's new and aggressive policy. We have talked about this many times, but it is really clear to me that this debate is also about whether or not we, as Europeans, actually stand up for what we normally associate with European ideas, whether we stand up for the fact that citizens on this continent can choose freedom and democracy outside the European Union. It is a question of whether or not we allow ourselves to be blackmailed by a policy of aggression and lies that currently dominates Moscow. I would like to say it again at this point: especially after this terrible murder of Boris Nemtsov, there can be no question of us making any changes to this idea of sanctions. These sanctions are necessary, not as an educational measure against Putin – I am not deluding myself at all – but these are sanctions, these are changes that are an expression of our self-image of the European Union. The Energy Union is the field brought into play by Donald Tusk in this dispute. Unfortunately, as Gabriele Zimmer and others rightly mentioned in the debates, including in Brussels, it is the case that, with yesterday's ideas once again dominating this Energy Union, we are in danger of putting this project on the wall. Instead of really relying on innovation, on renewable energies, on efficiency and on defining a project for the future for the European Union, we are extending the policy of interests of industries that are not sustainable. This whole debate on nuclear power and new subsidies is probably the best example of this. On Ukraine, we need to do much more, we have to act as a force in Ukraine that really stands for change. A real, well-coordinated task force to help Ukrainians get out of the crisis – that is what we need! And let me warn: I do not believe that former ministers or former commissioners or current members of the Bundestag are in fact the ones who should do a "building Ukraine" consultancy with Ukrainian oligarchs and also publicly funded. These must be people who have real experience in transformation processes in Eastern Europe. These must not be people who want to earn something, but they must be people who really work with the Ukrainians, with civil society, which knows how to change the country.

name: Nigel Farage
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I have been wondering why David Cameron has been slashing our armed forces, will not commit to 2% and is happy for us not to be able to defend our islands. I think Mr Juncker has given us the answer. We are going to do it at an EU level. We are going to have a European army.  When I raised this last year with the Deputy Prime Minister, Liberal Democrat Nick Clegg, he said it was a ‘dangerous fantasy’ to even talk about an EU army. I hope every Liberal Democrat voter has heard Mr Verhofstadt today, the leader of the European Liberals, crying out for militarisation at an EU level. Of course, the truth is that it is already happening. We already have a European Defence Agency; we already have EU battle groups on active service all over the world; we already have an EU navy active against the Somali pirates; and who can forget Eurocorps here in Strasbourg last year virtually goose—stepping that ghastly flag round the courtyard outside? Article 28 of the Lisbon Treaty provides for all of this. Tony Blair was right when he said the European Union is not a project about peace, it is a project about power. I think Mr Juncker is trying to seize on an opportunity. We ourselves in the European Union provoked the conflict through our territorial expansionism in Ukraine. We poked the Russian bear with a stick and, unsurprisingly, Putin reacted, and this is now to be used as an opportunity to build a European army. Mr Verhofstadt, I know that by heckling you increase your hits on YouTube because, otherwise, nobody in Europe wants to listen to you. I think you really ought to let me speak.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr Verhofstadt, I would like to thank Mr Verhofstadt for his I really must ask you to moderate. You may not like the speech. But we, as democrats, are listening to them, too. Now don't interrupt me!

name: Nigel Farage
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, we certainly are democrats; we never shouted you down, but you always try to shout us down. The point I was making is this, the opportunity is being seized and Mr Juncker said we must convey to Russia that we are serious. Who do you think you are kidding, Mr Juncker?  (Laughter from the EFDD Group) We do not want any part of an EU army, and I doubt the rest of the peoples of Europe do either.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr Farage, I would like to thank Mr Farage for Now we have extended your speaking time, and we have brought Mr Verhofstadt back to his senses.  (Laughter) Well, reason is always a question of definition. In my view, you do not belong to the expert group when it all. But I asked Mr Verhofstadt to at least listen to you. I hope he will do so in the future. However, if you honour all the flags in the House, your own and everyone else present here, we are also satisfied.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Farage, what do you think we should do when Russia, for example, is supporting the separatists with very modern armaments? Should the European Union do something to support Ukraine in fighting in eastern Ukraine or do you think that we should wait to fight in western Ukraine for the stability of Europe? Do you not think that together we have to send a clear message of solidarity and unity from the European Union regarding this important subject?

name: Nigel Farage (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – We, through our territorial ambitions, provoked the overthrow of an albeit corrupt, but democratically elected, leader in Ukraine. We have provoked this crisis. Now the question you ask is ‘What do we do from here?’ I was in this Chamber at the time when Libya was attacked. I heard the Liberals and the Greens screaming, frothing at the mouth, for us to bomb Libya: for us to become militarily involved because we believed that would make things better. My view, sir, is that if you look at Afghanistan, if you look at Iraq, if you look at Libya, and if you look at the attempt to back the rebels in Syria – many of whom have now morphed into ISIS – you will see that our recent foreign military interventions have made things worse, not better.

name: Marcel de Graaff (NI).
text: Mr President, the european council's agenda once again shows the situation in Ukraine. I am very concerned about the EU's role in this. President Juncker is belligerently calling for a European army. He sounds just like that other chairman, Chairman Mao, who annexed vulnerable Tibet with his Red Army. Under Juncker, it is becoming increasingly clear that the EU has an aggressive enlargement agenda. But the Commission is making a major error of judgement: Russia is not Tibet. President Putin is not the Dalai Lama. Juncker supports Poroshenko, a war criminal who bombed civilians in Lugansk, and on the same day that Russian opposition leader Nemtsov was assassinated, Mr Poroshenko's main opponent, Mr Chechetov, was found dead. Mr Juncker should not call for a new red army to support the Ukrainian war-hit fighters, but call for a war crimes tribunal in Ukraine, for which Poroshenko is also responsible, in the European Council.

name: Herbert Reul (PPE).
text: Mr President, Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her work and for the time being I want to talk about the Energy Union: I do not think the Commission's proposal is perfect in all parts, but it is interesting and good, because I think it is reasonable that we should turn to reality and consider what we can actually do and change and what we have done. We have taken enough decisions. Perhaps it is time to see whether the decisions are implemented. I find the examples of Spain, Portugal and networks building very interesting. Talking about more networks and the internal market, but not being able to put in place a very concrete project that is disavowing Europe. We have to get it right, then we prove that we are getting something on the line. Mrs Zimmer, to your suggestion that the comments made by the Commission and the President of the Commission on the issue of industry are in the interests of the people – I do not think you are ticking right, sorry! People are interested in cheap prices. You yourself said that if energy prices rise and people can no longer pay for their energy and are sitting in the cold because we have too much energy, then that is a problem! Then we have to think about why energy prices are cheaper in America. You can't devalue that simply by saying that everything they do is wrong. They use their energy sources, e.B. also through fracking. Just saying no doesn't help at all. Taking care of the interests of industry and energy prices also has something to do with people. Because if prices go up too much and jobs are gone, people don't have jobs. And they don't find that interesting at all. So that too is unrealistic! There is a huge opportunity to bring European energy policy together in the networks. Not everyone is playing their game, but they are trying to do more together, including on the issue of promoting renewable energies. Making new programs and wasting money is not particularly intelligent. Using it more effectively in Europe, with a promotion measure for renewable energies, that helps people!

name: Knut Fleckenstein (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Let me just say a few sentences on foreign policy, which will play a role in the European Council. We particularly welcome the fact that, in future, our Eastern Partnership policy should be approached in a much more nuanced way, because it is also necessary. We have the group of those who conclude a trade agreement with us, an association agreement, and already within that group very different partners. We have the Armenian partners entering the Eurasian Economic Union, and we have Azerbaijan, which is looking for a very different form of partnership. The fact that we usually fail according to the motto 'one size fits all' shows here too that we need to be more differentiated than we have done so far. I would also be interested to hear from you after the European Council whether we want to continue to wait for the ruler of Belarus to become a good person before we want to start work in order to change something for the better in a dialogue. Secondly, we assume that the Council will, of course, regard the Minsk agreement and compliance and implementation as a particular priority. It is an EU initiative, even if it has been carried out by two Heads of State, so to speak. In the end, it is important for us that this peaceful process proceeds. Therefore, all parties involved should make every effort to pour little oil on the fire. What the people of Ukraine need is humanitarian aid, and quickly. I do not have the impression that this is happening visibly enough and fast enough, along with all the other things that are important for the construction of this country and for restructuring. As always, it is a give and take. More for more is probably not right in this case in view of the emergency situation, but it is important that we have concrete demands for reform, which are linked to the fact that we continue to support the country economically and financially. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which They are very active this morning with blue cards. First of all, Mr Reul and Mrs Zimmer: Mrs Zimmer drew the blue card very shortly before the end of the post-match period – you were already in the extension. I couldn't see that. I must ask you, given the advanced period, to clarify this perhaps bilaterally. I believe that the party Die Linke and the CDU understand each other so well that they can get it.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: a question asked by raising a blue card. - You talked about foreign policy, but you didn't mention anything about Islamic State. Don't you think that a key issue of the European Council should be the crimes of Islamic State, the investigation of these crimes and the countries that support them, such as the Republic of Turkey?

name: Knut Fleckenstein (S&D)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr President, I am quite right that two minutes of speaking time is absolutely not enough for me. But I cannot deal with every issue in two minutes. That's why I focused on the other. I am sure that this discussion will also take place in the Council in due course.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR).
text: – Mr President, next week the Council will discuss the crisis in Ukraine and the EU’s plans for an energy union. The theme common to these subjects is Russia and the threat it poses. Russia is providing military equipment, financial assistance and troops to the so—called separatists in Ukraine, sparking a conflict in which more than 5 000 people have died. Mr Putin talks peace but, at the same time, his government is doing everything possible to prevent it. As the British Defence Secretary noted, he is behaving like a 1930s tyrant. In these circumstances, we must remain resolute. Should Russia not abide by the latest ceasefire, then we should increase sanctions further. At a time when the solidarity and resolve of the NATO alliance is so vital, it is not helpful, Mr Juncker, Mr Verhofstadt, for you to start fantasising about an EU army. Mr Putin also uses energy policy to threaten us, and here the EU can play a useful role. I welcome the Commission’s plans on the Energy Union. I want a continent—wide single market in both gas and electricity. This will increase competition and lower prices for consumers and businesses, and that will create the growth and jobs we all want. The EU needs to be in a position where it does not matter if Mr Putin turns off the gas taps because we can import as much gas as we need though our liquefied natural gas (LNG) terminals and transport it across the whole continent. That is real energy security. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Fox, it is often stated by the federalists in this place that one advantage of a European Union is that it has kept the peace since 1945. Do you agree with me that Europe is possibly at a more dangerous precipice now than it ever has been since the end of that bloody war?

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – I think the European Community and the European Union have played a role in preserving peace on this continent. But I think the cornerstone of peace in Europe has been NATO, and I emphasise the importance of that military alliance, of our allies in the United States, Canada and Turkey. Talk of an EU army is very dangerous indeed.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, Mr Juncker, energy is not a commodity for profit for the benefit of monopolies and multinationals. It's a basic social good. That is why the energy union must primarily fight energy poverty, ensure equal access for all to cheap energy and promote energy infrastructure and interconnections for the benefit of peoples. These priorities must be set by the European Council.  The United Left will oppose the creation of an energy union that serves private interests and exacerbates inequalities and exclusions. Next, the proposal to inform the Commission in advance of the Member States' energy agreements with third countries, finds us vertically opposed, as it limits the sovereignty of states and degrades their role, but also limits national flexibility in the formulation of efficient multidimensional inter-state energy relations.  The European Council should primarily promote concrete measures to remove the isolation of Member States and promote measures to effectively address problems in energy supply. We must realise that for an energy union to work positively, it must go hand in hand with ending neoliberal austerity policies and promoting a social, development policy.  And a comment about Mr. Weber. Mr Weber, at last respect democracy! Respect the verdict of the Greek people! We don't live in a colonial regime. The Greek people cannot decide to change a policy and want to force them to continue the same destructive policy.

name: David Borrelli (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this European Semester, which ends in its first phase, deserves special attention because it takes place five years after the adoption of the Europe 2020 strategy, but above all in conjunction with the start of quantitative easing. Quantitative easing is a very important, wide-ranging operation with an innovative character in the European institutional and financial context. It is important now that the other institutions support the ecb's efforts. There is only one thing that would not be acceptable now: that nothing should happen and that nothing should change, because then how could we expect private companies to give real and concrete adherence to the objectives of quantitative easing, when we ourselves have not responded adequately to this initiative? Sixty billion a month for at least eighteen months is a fact that has been established and very clear. And it must be clear above all to those who have always been attentive to the accounts, demanding austerity in the name of them. We cannot justify to our citizens the paradox that banks are the recipients of similar figures, while municipalities, even if they have sound balance sheets, cannot spend the money on investments because of the Stability Pact. Those who have been so meticulous in keeping deficit budgets under control, 0.1% more or less, are now showing that they have the same attention to the new and full-bodied possibility that the ECB makes available for growth and show that it has just as much meticulousness to help its impact, to ensure that money really reaches citizens and businesses and that it is not reduced to numbers and figures. , but that we know how to grasp its potential and the ability to do.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI). Mr President, we will deal with the European Semester, the country-specific recommendations, the Stability Pact, which are long-term memoranda with iron discipline, against the needs of the people. Even the powerful France, without a memorandum, was placed under surveillance. Portugal, Ireland and Spain no longer have a memorandum, but they have double supervision, one after the Memorandum and the other within the framework of the European Semester.  Regardless of any differences, anyone who accepts the European Union, the capitalist path of development, accepts their unpopular rules and mechanisms that serve monopolies. All those who claim, like the Greek government, that they will change them in favour of the people by negotiating within the walls, are misleading. The European Union is getting worse, better not. It cannot solve even the most urgent problems of survival of peoples. Only in the struggle for release from it and the shackles of capitalist exploitation is there hope for the people.

name: Andrzej Grzyb (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab As stated here on behalf of the Council, the March Council is primarily an economic council, but It seems to me that there is a strong political component here, because the issue of the Energy Union is not only an economic dimension, but above all a political dimension, which is important for all Member States. We need this strategy, we need energy security, we also need the future shape of energy, it should have both its external dimension but also its own EU energy market. This Union should be built on the principles of solidarity and transparency. We remember those moments when this solidarity was lacking and many Member States, many societies were suffering from energy shortages at the time. Nor can the Energy Union be reduced to a revision of the Security of Gas Supply Regulation. By the way, I will say that at the time there were many doubts as to whether, in the shape that we adopted them, it could function at all. It turned out that we were right, but these regulations are insufficient. Transparency and participation by the European Commission in negotiating and signing energy agreements with third countries will be a key element, but it seems to me that the target model could be jointly negotiating supplies. We know that it is difficult, that many have a different opinion here.  We should be talking about the integration of energy networks and the energy market, the integration of gas networks, but also the development of energy based on own resources. Let us not eliminate what is the strength of the European Union, and therefore also our own resources, including renewable, conventional, but also alternative resources.  The Neighbourhood Policy – Eastern Partnership requires stronger support. I would like this project not to be regarded as a project that goes back to the past, but it is to be a project to build the future, in particular as regards the Eastern Partnership and Ukraine, which we care about, so that it can return to the family of European nations (...).  (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. – I would have liked to have asked the Leader of the Weber Group, but the colleagues of the People's Party say quite a lot about energy union issues. In your ranks is the Fidesz, which is still running the Hungarian government, and just the other day, for 30 years, a convention was signed, which led to the construction of a real, complete nuclear power plant with Russian money for EUR 10 billion, using Russian technology in Hungary. From the point of view of the Energy Union, what does the People's Party think of this?

name: Andrzej Grzyb (PPE)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the "blue card". – Mr President, i would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Schwab The history of Central and Eastern Europe is not in a position to cross the line, nor to the economic links that were concluded at that time. Each Member State, on the other hand, builds its political future on its own priorities. The priority Polish is to build energy independence, we understand that very well. On the other hand, I do not wish to be a reviewer of the conduct of the Hungarian Government. I believe that the Hungarian Government must also act bearing in mind that it is a Member State of the European Union.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would also like to talk today about the Energy Union, one of the three important issues on the Council. When Commissioner Šefčovič presented this, we, as a whole group, warmly welcomed it. After all, we believe that this should be one of the main priorities of this Commission because there are many challenges coming together: climate policy and the many ambitions we have to have there, energy independence - we spend 420 billion a year on energy purchases outside the European Union, an amount that we can better spend in a different way - and of course energy security , also for our citizens.  That plan is a holistic plan, joint plan, and you can't cherry-pick it out. In the previous Council conclusions, attention was paid to the energy union, but there was no mention of energy efficiency, for example, when it is actually one of the backs of that plan, because in energy efficiency all these challenges come together. If we want to meet our climate targets, we can do so by focusing 40% on energy efficiency. And it is also for this reason that in the investment plan that we are working on in Parliament, I, as rapporteur for the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, call for a great deal of attention to energy efficiency. Today, only 5% of the initiatives put forward by the Member States are focused on energy efficiency. That's what I want to turn around. So I urge you to prioritise energy efficiency in the Energy Union.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, Mr Juncker, the troika and the memoranda have turned Greece into a vast social graveyard. 40% of the Greek people live below the poverty line, while the unemployed have reached 1.5 million. Your responsibilities, as former President of the Eurogroup, for this situation are enormous. After all, you yourself acknowledged them in a recent interview. So instead of a change of attitude towards Greece, the sacred alliance of lenders continues its blackmail policy. So, at a time when the European Central Bank is generously spending more than 60 billion euros a month buying government bonds, Draghi is tightening the noose around Greece, causing a dangerous credit suffocation.  Mr Juncker and Mr Weber, you have to make a decision. The Greek people in the elections of 25 January decided to change course and are fighting united to write off the shameful debt and claim German reparations. Mr Juncker, the Greek people no longer accept orders from the international lenders deservedly represented by the Commission.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, colleagues, three weeks ago, the European Commission solemnly announced the creation of an Energy Union. This is as if it were another step towards further federalisation of the European Union. The single currency, the single market, the common energy system are increasingly components of the European Union, which have both pluses and minuses when it comes to the autonomy of states and the well-being of their citizens. In this case, common energy is the big plus that has long been needed by the countries of the European Union. Indeed, individual countries are not able to achieve the independence of energy states individually, the supply of resources at the best prices. The European Union, which speaks with one voice on this issue, is very good. That unity is not only needed as peace today. But I am concerned that, compared to the ambitions, there is too little funding for the creation of the energy infrastructure of the Said Union. The market for goods is usually either cheap or good. Good Energy Union, gentlemen, we will certainly not create cheap ones. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question raised (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Blue card question. – Obviously, Mr Representative, we agree that if, to a 40% extent, the European Union obtains its energy from external sources, then this is also a question of competitiveness. However, I am appalled by what you are saying about federalist objectives. Can't you imagine that this could happen under the current contractual framework without violating national sovereignty?

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: answer to the blue card question. – Thank you very much for your question. As far as federalist ambitions or objectives are concerned, I would like to stress that I am making it clear, concretely, precisely about the union of free European states, and where this can be done without a federalist or other approach, this should be done.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI).
text: Mr President, the Juncker plan to boost growth is likely to fail. With only 21 billion euros of public money, it will not allow the release of 300 billion euros of private funds. And that is fortunate, because this plan would offer private capital benefiting from the financial guarantee of the European Union control of public infrastructure of general interest.  The agreement on trade in services, which I hope will never see the light of day, generalizes the process of compulsory and systematic competition of any public service between private companies. The Commission is trying to complete its work by emptying its meaning of the concept of public service and public interest.  In France, SNCF was an efficient public service. With deregulation, it is slipping more and more into the private sector with increasingly expensive tickets, incomprehensible fares and a shrinking choice of destinations. The Commission is obstinate. It is always the same common thread: stealthily dismantling public services and transferring them to the private sector, sometimes with state money as a bonus. We have a duty to oppose it firmly.

name: Alain Lamassoure (PPE).
text: Mr President, in five years, this is the seventh summit that the Union will devote to energy.  In February 2011, the aim was to develop the European energy market. In June 2012, the aim was to complete this contract. In May 2013, the new energy strategy was launched. In December 2013, the time was right to relaunch this new strategy. In March 2014, the internal energy market was completed. And October 2014 saw the arrival of the new "energy-climate" package. Each time, there was a bubble effect: bubble of ambitions, bubble of objectives. The rhetorical bubble swells. But each time, the Energy Europe is going backwards. For, in the meantime, each country has pursued its selfish national policy. The Union has remained ineffective in the face of Russia's use of gas weapons. It remained unreased in the face of the rapid development of unconventional hydrocarbons, and the emissions market (ETS) collapsed. Thanks to the Commission's proposal, for the first time, the Council is dealing with a comprehensive policy draft. Let us adopt it once and for all and expect the eighth European Energy Council to meet in five years to see the effective implementation of the policy we need.

name: Matthias Groote (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I believe that the Energy Union is not a rhetorical bubble, but an opportunity that we should seize to shape. This is a project that can unite us, bring us forward in the European Union and also secure prosperity. That is why we should do everything we can to ensure that the Energy Union is a clear success. At this point, I think it is important that we as a Parliament are clearly involved here and that things are not organised and regulated in the Context of the Energy Union, but that the whole thing is clearly done in ordinary legislative procedures, that Parliament is involved in every step of the way. That is how it becomes a shoe, and so there is also a very broad legitimacy for the Energy Union, which we absolutely need. I firmly believe that it will be a success with Maro's at the helm.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The current debate on the Council summit shows once again how transverse the European Union's policy really is. While the situation in Ukraine and Russia is under discussion on the Council's agenda, the European Commission, in the person of President Juncker, is calling for the establishment of an EU army in the person of President Juncker, and also says that this EU army should be placed against Russia if necessary. This needs to be explained. Perhaps the President of the Commission, who will take the floor afterwards, can clarify what he thinks of the establishment of an EU army. Are we marching against Russia? I believe that this is absolutely the wrong way to go. We should support peace measures with every fibre of our political work, and we should not pour more oil on the fire. If you look at the current developments in the European Union, where the euro is now almost in par par with the dollar, and Draghi has warned that it will fall to 85%, game over may soon be game over. And you are all well advised to re-develop a Union towards a community of sovereign states that cooperate with each other and which cannot be ensconed by centralism in its room for manoeuvre. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Michael Theurer (ALDE).
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Vilimsky, do you really know the studies carried out in 2007, which show that a common European army could also achieve significantly more security for less money? The EU states spend 50% of the amount that the US spends, but only get 15% military effectiveness. For economic reasons alone, but also for reasons of security policy, it would make sense to consider a common European volunteer army. I think the proposal is very good.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I do not want to take your opinion away from you. We live in a democracy. But I come from a neutral country, and I also fight with every fibre of my political work to maintain this neutrality. I do not want my country, Austria, to be integrated into an international army, which will perhaps also be used as a pawn here and there under the direction of the Americans. Whoever wants to make this euro army should do it, but not with the participation of Austria!

name: Esteban González Pons (PPE).
text: – Mr President, 53% of imported energy is an unsustainable situation for the European Union. We need a European energy market, but we cannot do so if we do not have interconnections like the ones they bet on in Madrid, in March, Spain, France, Portugal, the Commission and also the European Investment Bank. On Russia, it is true that the Minsk Treaty must be supported. And it is also true what has been said: this is not a war against the Russian people. This is a brake on Russian nationalism. And we have to get on with the sanctions. But sanctions don't have to be paid by farmers. The high policy we make from the European institutions and from the countries does not have to be paid for by those below, by those who have the hardest time getting ahead. Farmers, from the countryside, need not pay our policy of skeading Russian expansionism. And I agree, on Libya, with what Mr Timmermans said. Dialogue must be encouraged. Dialogue must be facilitated. But I also say that we must not forget that Libya is at risk of falling into the hands of the Islamic State and that the Islamic State in Iraq is not the same as the Islamic State fifteen minutes' flight from southern Europe. And I take this opportunity, Mr President, to recall that today is European Day for victims of terrorism. And, therefore, ask everyone not to forget the victims, to ask that all crimes be clarified, that all terrorists be stopped, that all gangs be defeated and that their pain should never be forgotten. Because today, European Day of Victims of Terrorism, is the day to remember that if we forget about the victims, terrorists somehow win.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D).
text: Mr President! Dear Juncker! Should the EUROPEAN Union be a strong and independent voice, or should we be under pressure because of our energy dependency? Because Europe is already under pressure from a Russia with a heavy hand on the throttle to Europe. A Russia that does not hold back from sending tanks and soldiers across the border to its European neighbours. We need to get out of that pressure. That is why a green climate and energy union is required. There must be a massive focus on energy efficiency improvements, renewable energy and CO2 reductions. The Energy Union is the key to Europe free from Russian pressure, free from dependence on fossil fuels, but the Commission has yet to come up with concrete answers. Answer what it means to be the world leader in renewable energy, as Juncker promised us to be. When will we have a comprehensive, clear Russia strategy that includes both an energy, security, foreign and trade policy, and preferably in cooperation with NATO, the world's strongest defence alliance, instead of creating a european army of its own?

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: Mr President, Madam President, Mr Vice-President, when it comes to the energy union, it is time to act. But you won't be consistent if you don't give a clear signal about the price of carbon. However, on this very concrete issue, on this step that is before us, at hand, I see in the Council a great reluctance to implement the stability reserve. So, Madam President, if you want this European Council to be useful, including to make the Paris summit a success, we must move faster on what this Parliament is asking you to implement, namely the stability reserve and a clarification to enable long-term investment in the ecological transition in the face of the issue of carbon pricing. With regard to the transatlantic agreement, Jean-Claude Juncker spoke of the contradictions he sees in the behaviour of capitals between their attitude to the European Council and their attitude on their return home. I remember his words here, expressing all his reservations about the workings of investor-state dispute settlement (IRDR) and I would like to see that commitment he made in this house. It seems to us that the strongest supporters of this agreement tell us: "First, when we have defined these standards together, they will become international standards". They also tell us that we have to be demanding. In the negotiations, I do not know how to do it when we are told, on the one hand, that we must be demanding and, on the other hand, that we must reach an agreement at all costs, at full speed. On the other hand, it is on ISDS standards that Europeans must weigh in. They must use this agreement as a lever to deal with this issue in a fundamental way and not allow multinationals to use arbitration to defend their own interests and their sole profit in defiance of democracy.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: – It would be interesting to compare the carrying topics of the European Council in the past and now. The crisis has brought enormous woes to European citizens. On the other hand, finding a way out of the crisis has triggered some positive processes. She connected us even more, or even integrated us. When we talk about the European Union today, we are talking about the Capital Markets Union, about the Banking Union, about the Digital Union, about the Energy Union, that I am not talking about the European Semester, which allows for control of the budget of the Member States. Before the crisis, which I hope we have been through, for the most part, such a unified rumour would not have been possible. I think that this new wave of integration is a sensible response to a crisis that will also increase immunity to different vibrations. Today's debate has shown that there is a sense of need for the European Union to be able to establish itself as a global player only if it also has a united position on security and foreign policy, that is, a coordinated relationship with Putin, Ukraine, TTIP and so on.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S&D). Mr President, we are talking today about energy union and energy security, and of course we all have in mind the European Union's great dependence on Russia and the geopolitical games that are being played there and which, of course, have a negative impact on our family here in the European Union. However, what I want to point out to you and to the Commission, but also to my colleagues, is that we must show our solidarity in practice by tackling this issue as well as by upgrading and recognising the fact that within the European Union we have our own deposits. They are located within the Exclusive Economic Zone of the Republic of Cyprus and if we want to prove that we are a family this paper is in front of us. Do we want to reduce dependence on Russia?
