Let's upgrade our own deposits and confront Erdogan. So we prove that we believe in European values and we are all in the same family.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Mr. President, I want to strongly support the Commission's ambition to create a Single Energy Union by stepping forward. And from all those arguments we've heard here: from the fragmentation of the market, from the need for competitiveness, from the oversupply we have within the European Union, to the dependence on one resourcer and all those other arguments that were very important.  But I want to give Mr. Timmermans and the Commission one suggestion. I want to warn you in a way that the Balkans are full of green renewable energy. The potential of the Balkans is such that we can really produce a lot of green energy relatively cheaply and above all from water sources. In this way, we can help countries that are our candidates or potential candidates to grow economically, and on the other hand we have a close source of great green energy capacity.  Think hard about this idea.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, two telegraph notes on the European Council.  About the energy. What reality has demonstrated, and has been demonstrating with increasing acuity, is the need for public control of this strategic sector, of energy production and distribution. Efficiency, sustainability, the social dimension of energy policy alone will be more than fine words to hide the real increase in the bill of households and businesses and the increase in the fabulous profits of the economic groups that have taken over this sector. Groups that will be the major beneficiaries of the Strategic Investment Plan, as it is drawn. About Ukraine. The proposal by the President of the European Commission on the European army, which I did not want to repeat here today, shows how the deepening of the exploitation and oppression of peoples, which we already knew to be accompanied by the concentration of power in supranational bodies outside their democratic control, is also linked to aggressive and militaristic drive. Now, a project of economic and political colonization, social regression and war, has no future. You will be unappealed.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I can be very brief because having listened very carefully to the contributions of the Members of the European Parliament, it is clear to me that there is a great importance attached to the Energy Union and plans for the Energy Union. I think this is a strong message given by the European Parliament to the European Council.  It is also clear that we are encouraged to pursue our policies of creating European unity in tackling issues such as Ukraine and Libya, and also in our attitude towards Russia. The common thread in all these subjects is a traditional European position, but of the most acute importance today is that when we stand united on this issue we can actually deliver. If we are divided either on the Energy Union or on our foreign relations with other countries, we will open up the opportunity for those who want us to be divided, who want Europe to be weak, to exploit the differences between European nations. I emphatically want to underscore that I cannot imagine that some people here, by being divided, would rather see the way countries are run like Russia by the Russian President than having Europe unite stronger in trying to tackle challenges to our democracy, to the way we have our society.  I truly believe that European unity, both in terms of facing the necessity to create a sustainable society, where we are less dependent on fossil fuels, where we are not in a position to be blackmailed by outside fuel providers, where we are able to create an economy that does not depend as much on fossil fuels and does use more renewable fuel sources, that is a strong contribution to a better life of our citizens, leads to greater stability within our Member States, but especially to a stronger position in the evermore competitive world.

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, this morning’s debate demonstrated a wide convergence of views on where EU priorities lie. This gives us confidence that we are on the right track. I have listened attentively to your views and will transmit them to the President of the European Council. Allow me to make some remarks on what has been discussed this morning. First, there seems to be general agreement between all of us on the need for Energy Union. We do need a real Energy Union. I would strongly agree with the view that we also need to avoid the risk of energy poverty. However, I dare to disagree that the initiatives put forward by the Commission and the Council will not achieve this goal. I believe they will achieve the goal. I believe that if implemented efficiently and effectively, the Energy Union will promote growth and jobs. I am aware that discussion on closer convergence of our energy policies is a challenging one, and while keeping the energy mix a national competence, I am convinced that we can achieve the maximum from the 28 Member States being together. It has considerable strength and its potential should be used to the full extent. As regards energy efficiency, I am happy to confirm that the European Council will look into this issue. Moreover, during the Latvian Presidency, at the informal ministerial meeting, there will be a discussion on heating and cooling.  Developments in the Eastern Neighbourhood are one of the factors also making the creation of this Union more important and urgent. To me, the Energy Union is about enhancing our independence in the energy field. It is about greater solidarity in cases of a potential supply shortage, about a stronger and better interconnected internal market which encourages more competition and thus a better price for consumers. The Energy Union is about strong energy diplomacy. As for Ukraine – so many of you discussed this question – we look forward to the in-depth discussion in the European Council giving comprehensive guidelines for further EU actions aimed at a sustainable political solution with respect to Ukraine’s independence. We should also not forget that other Eastern Partnership countries need our support. I fully share Mr Fleckenstein’s view that there may not be one-size-fits-all solutions. I also agree with Mr Pittella that the situation in Libya requires our closest attention. This is why the European Council will discuss it. It is clear that there will be very crucial debates. The European Council will discuss the situation in Ukraine and relations with Russia, the Energy Union – all the topics that are so crucial for the future of the European Union and that are so crucial in taking account of our responsibility in an international context.  It is clear that Ukraine needs our support in every way that we can deliver it. It is clear that Libya also needs our support and that our citizens await concrete decisions, whether on the Energy Union, economics, external relations or our responsibility. I am sure that the European Council will take very important decisions and that it will take note of the discussions we have had here today. Members have made a lot of very important suggestions and pointed to the very crucial issues that the European Council will debate.

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. The next European Council sets three priorities: external relations, the European semester for growth and employment, and the energy union. On these three priorities, the Council continues to continue to flee further.  Thus, on energy, he proposes to go further in the single market, which he will liberalize more and more. It also engages us in the development of renewable energy at a time when China is unfairly competing with us and killing our industries in this sector.  For jobs and growth, the Union refuses to face reality. The austerity it advocates kills growth and prevents any stimulus through investment. Moreover, the Juncker plan does not meet the necessary needs. It becomes vital to change economic policy by ending the dogma of the single currency and establishing intelligent protectionism. Finally, we must categorically reject TTIP, which will put European peoples even more under the control of multinationals and American desires.  Finally, on the Ukrainian case, it would be in the Union's best interest to ally itself with Russia so as not to systematically align itself with American interests, which are often at odds with European demands.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. – The European Parliament needs to strengthen the European Commission's proposal on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EIE). FEIE is an idea with great potential. There is a general consensus on the idea that this instrument is essential to complement the EI's traditional activity, constrained by the need to maintain a maximum credit rating. So why accept an ambiguous scheme, without legal personality, without clarity about its duration beyond the investments envisaged until 2018, and without compulsory national contributions? Do we not need a permanent, flexible countercyclical instrument to concentrate investment in those States, regions or municipalities that are impaired by their employment rate? We have a golden opportunity to draw up a good regulation from the outset, which is not at odds with rapid approval of it, provided that the Council shows a level of ambition comparable to that of Parliament and the Commission and forever closes these years of European myopia. This requires granting legal personality to the EIE, setting out its indefinite duration, allowing the issuance of debt securities, and setting mandatory national contributions and other stable sources of financing in the regulation, as well as reinvestment of profits.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. I agree with Mr Juncker when he points out, not without humour or diplomacy, the versatility of European heads of state and government on the transatlantic treaty. It is not tolerable for the speeches of the latter to change depending on whether they are in Brussels or in their capital. There are two possible explanations. The first: by supporting TTIP in Brussels, they are lying to the Commission. This is irresponsible, of course, but far less than entrusting the officials of Brussels with the mandate to negotiate on their behalf, and especially in their place, this scoundrel agreement. The second: back home, they lie to their peoples, making them believe that they still have the will and the power to change the course of things.  You are right, Mr Juncker: ask them for clarification, you they are listening while they are deaf to the aspirations of their citizens. It is not to you, it is to their peoples that they lie, driven by the holy fear of the masterful electoral splants that are coming. Our rulers, especially in France, do not only profession lies: they do so in a total absence of political vision and an unfailing submission to interests that are neither those of their nations nor those of a true Europe.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. – I would like to draw the attention of the Commission and the Council to two technical issues. On the one hand, if it has already happened that funds from Horizon 2020 and the Network Finance Facility (CEF) will be transferred to the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) guarantee fund and that we intend to stimulate the economy by lending instead of grants, let us pay attention to the fact that the applicant projects can benefit from both sources in parallel.  My other proposal relates to the enforcement of the Security of Supply Regulation (994/2010). The Security of Supply Regulation lays down strict infrastructure-related principles and rules, such as the N-1 principle or the mandatory two-way traffic control of cross-border capacities until December 2013. I propose that Member States who have not complied with their legal obligation by the deadline and wish to raise funds for an infrastructure development project that has not been implemented now will only be able to obtain support under the CEF or EFSI where justified. We must avoid the fact that it may be worth taking time to implement important energy infrastructure projects. We all know that, with regard to cross-border infrastructures, the Member States are interdependence and the Commission should not be permissive or lenient or rewarding to those who do not do their homework.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. – The strategic framework for the Energy Union, which has just been published by the Commission, will make a major contribution to achieving some of the objectives of the 2030 climate and energy framework, including achieving an economic transition of decarbonisation, making the economy sustainable and combating climate change. It also helps to implement renewable energy and energy efficiency ideas at EU level, which together help to ensure energy security and reduce energy dependency. In my view, one of the main means of implementation of decarbonisation is the effective functioning of the EU ETS. The EU ETS prices in CO2 emissions, thus helping to reduce greenhouse gas emissions cost-effectively and making industry interested. It is also to be welcomed that the new compensation mechanisms under the EU ETS, the proper use of innovation and modernisation funds, the NER400 instrument can significantly help the development of the energy sector, taking into account the priorities of the Energy Union.  However, I think it is important to stress that Member States should be given sufficient flexibility in the choice of decarbonisation measures, taking into account their different economic backgrounds and the energy mix chosen. Finally, with regard to the Paris Protocol, I would like to reiterate that the main objective remains to involve the Contracting Countries as widely as possible and to encourage their commitments. It is also important that these reduction commitments are legally binding at international level.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. - All three topics expected at the next Session of the European Council are extremely current for the future of our continent. The first topic, the European Energy Union has become a priority topic. We urgently need to create all the preconditions for the establishment of a common European energy market. The EU imports 53% of its energy needs and this amounts to around €1 billion per day. The price of electricity in Europe is 40% more expensive than that in the US and this directly brings down European competitiveness. This is especially important in light of the intention to sign TTIP. I expect the European Commission and the European Council to urgently offer all documents in order to take the necessary decisions to establish a European Single Market as soon as possible. Another topic, European development and the launch of investments through the new Strategic Investment Fund, is an absolute priority. Without investment and job creation, there is no European future. That is why I strongly support the creation of a new fund with an initial €315 billion. The third topic, the European Union's foreign policy, contains the creation of the preconditions of the Eastern Partnership for Long-Term Stability at our eu borders today with a European perspective for countries as part of the Eastern Partnership. Also, the catastrophic situation in Libya and all the consequences that this crisis in the Mediterranean brings must be the focus of our foreign policy to the end.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D)
text: in writing. – I fully agree with President Juncker on the need to establish European armed forces, which is vital to strengthen the Diplomacy of the Union, as well as to move forward in the process towards federal Europe. With regard to the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EIE), I believe that the European Parliament needs to strengthen the European Commission's proposal. FEIE is a great idea, with great potential. We all agree that this instrument is essential to complement the traditional activity of the EI, constrained by the need to maintain the highest credit rating. So why should we accept an ambiguous scheme, without legal personality, without clarity about its duration beyond the investments envisaged until 2018 and without compulsory national contributions? Do we not need a permanent, flexible countercyclical instrument to concentrate investment in those States, regions or municipalities whose employment rate is badly deteriorated?

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. - The European Council on 19 and 20 March will focus on the Energy Union, relations with Russia and the situation in Ukraine. The creation of an Energy Union is one of the priorities for the current period in economic policy terms. The cornerstones of the Energy Union are improving energy security, the EU's internal energy market, strengthening the development of renewable energy and increasing energy efficiency. It is also intended to reduce dependence on imports of oil and natural gas and to make energy more affordable in principle. However, the Heads of State or Government will also discuss the general economic situation and provide member states with guidelines for the preparation of their national reforms and stability and convergence programmes. Member States are reluctant to implement the country-specific recommendations, in particular in the implementation of structural reforms. So far, only 22 percent of the most important country-specific recommendations have been implemented. Without the necessary structural reforms in member states, however, the ECB's current monetary policies will fizzle out and the effects of the low euro exchange rate and low oil price will not be sustainable.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. – The fiscal and economic credibility of the EU lies in complying with the rules. Therefore I regret that France has for the third consecutive time failed to do so. I welcome the decision of the Commission to scrutinise further France, but I remind the Commission that a system of fiscal discipline, including penalties, has been established with collective efforts and political will. Everybody without exception has to respect it. The credibility of the euro will depend on each and every Member State meeting their commitments.  The euro area crisis started many years ago with looking away from breaches of the established criteria by the two biggest Member States. This provided a contagious example for the rest to follow on this slippery slope.  I am also alarmed about the Greek rhetoric. Instead of providing a list of measures about conducting crucial reforms, one has to listen to threats and insults towards particular Member States. The result will be undermining the EU as a whole. For me, it is problematic to explain to Estonian people why they should, during the next years, bail out a government that shows so little responsibility towards its own people and for the sacrifices of solidarity by Member States, some of them with a monthly minimum salary of less than EUR 350.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. – The creation of an Energy Union is the only way to achieve Europe's energy independence. The Energy Union guarantees a sustained reduction in energy prices and more efficient energy use. However, it would be worth creating an even more ambitious programme. Europe needs a joint purchase of raw materials to increase our bargaining power with third countries, in particular Russia. Joint action would significantly improve member states' negotiating positions, for example by benefiting from the bargaining power of the EU of 10 million Hungary benefiting from the EU's bargaining power of 500 million. Investing in renewable energies is the key to the growth of our economy. New energy not only creates more jobs than any nuclear power plant investment, but is also the basis for our economic growth. Since 2011, Germany has accounted for almost 400,000 jobs and €17 billion a year in economic output from renewables. Sweden covers more than half of its energy supply from new energy, compared with 30% for Denmark.  The performance of the current Hungarian Government in this area is also devastating: since 2010 it has not been able to increase the share of new energy, and it has recently imposed product charges on solar panels and wind farms. We need a reform similar to the German energy turnaround if we are to see Hungary back among eu-educated people. New energy not only provides economic growth, jobs and cheap energy supply, but also offers serious research opportunities and even protects our environment. Let us take the european renewable energy targets seriously.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. We welcome the news that the Energy Union will be at the centre of the next Meeting of the European Council, on 19 and 20 March. In its five dimensions, it is certainly a priority for the European Union, especially in view of recent events which have led to doubts about security of supply during the winter months.  In particular, it is necessary to create alternative sources by establishing a climate of trust and solidarity between the Member States and to invest heavily in the field of energy efficiency, from which a beneficial side effect could also be achieved in terms of increasing employment.  Finally, we note that the situation in Ukraine remains delicate and unstable and we look to the next European Council for developments, which we hope will include effective monitoring of the Minsk agreements and a discussion on possible further economic support measures for Ukraine.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. - I welcome the fact that the upcoming Meeting of the European Council, among other topics of utmost importance such as the European Semester and relations with Russia, will primarily discuss the Energy Union. I believe that this topic needs to be set very high on the European Union's list of priorities, as a coordinated and coherent approach at Union level will make it easier and more soon to achieve our common, rather ambitious energy goals. In the course of this process, we need to take into account the national circumstances of all Member States, as well as their potential to implement the necessary reforms and provide them with our full support. The political reality is that, in addition to security, energy has also become an oxygen for democracy, so it is the right time to upgrade the political integration of the European Union with that of energy. I also welcome the decision for the Heads of State to also discuss the EU-US trade agreement, as negotiations on this have already progressed quite a bit. Round eight of negotiations are for us and it is high time to discuss this agreement constructively and set frameworks that must be respected if adopted. If we succeed, TTIP has the potential to ensure the creation of highly skilled jobs and enable growth and development on both sides of the Atlantic. Only such TTIP will get my support.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The European Summit is always an event expected and analysed in terms of the messages that flow from it. The outcome of the Summit demonstrates the unity, cohesion and solidarity of the European Union, and this issue raises many discussions and leads to different conclusions and opinions. President Juncker's speech today shows important areas of activity for the European Commission. That's a lot for such a period of action, but the real challenges are still ahead of us.  I would expect a more concrete timetable for the creation of the Energy Union. Because if energy prices in the US are 40% lower than in the EU, what does that say about our competitiveness, especially in the context of the adoption of TTIP? Ambitious climate policy objectives limit our economic development. Does this not require re-analysis and evaluation?

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. – I in turn welcome the approval of the Fund for Strategic Investments by the Finance Ministers. This package, of EUR 315 billion, is a vital breath of fresh air for the Member States which are mainly affected by the crisis and are in a budgetary difficult position. In the case of my country, everyone must recognize that the Greek people have proven with their sacrifices and daily struggle that they deserve a better path for the country, a path out of the crisis, a path of growth and prosperity.  These, after all, are the strategic objectives of the new investment fund. To create new jobs, to support the creation of development infrastructure, to strengthen the sustainability of our economies and to boost the real economy. We should go further by focusing on supporting small and medium-sized enterprises and strengthening the middle class, which for decades has been the backbone of society. At the heart of this effort must be our young people, who are currently facing deadlocks. The EU must rise to the occasion, propose solutions and outlets to national governments, so that we can jointly build a modern, competitive and investment-friendly environment in our countries, with realism and a sense of responsibility.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the joint debate – the report by Dariusz Rosati, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: Annual Growth Survey 2015 (A8-0037/2015) (2014/2221(INI)) – the report by Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: employment and social aspects in the 2015 Annual Growth Survey (A8-0043/2015) (2014/2222(INI)) and – the Ildikó G reportáll-Pelcz, on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: employment and social aspects in the 2015 Annual Growth Survey (A8-0018/2015) (2014/2212(INI))

name: Dariusz Rosati
text: Rapporteur. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Europe needs economic growth. Without a return to sustainable growth, we will not deal with the burden of debt, we will not reduce unemployment, we will not be able to finance important social needs, and above all we will not restore our compatriots' faith in the meaning of a united Europe. We will not restore hope for a better future.  We are all tired of the long-term crisis. Production in the European Union only reached pre-crisis levels last year, in 2008. So we can talk about the lost 6 years. There are different opinions on the causes of this prolonged stagnation. We often hear, also in this House, that the main reason for the economic collapse is budget austerity, that it is they that have led to mass unemployment and a fall in income. We do not share these views. Budget savings were a necessary response to the excessive increase in pre-crisis expenditure, expenditure that led to uncontrolled debt growth. The fundamental cause of the current difficulties has been the irresponsible fiscal policies of governments and the equally irresponsible lending policies of banks in some countries. This could have been avoided, after all, there was no obligation to become indebted.  In 2014, however, there were signs of economic recovery. After a two-year period of decline, gross domestic product in the European Union has increased by 1.6% and is projected by the European Commission to accelerate to 2.1% next year. These figures confirm that difficult fiscal consolidation and structural reforms undertaken in many Member States are producing the desired results. Countries covered by adjustment programmes, such as Ireland and Portugal, have been able to restore their financial credibility and Ireland is the fastest growing economy in the Union. However, the fundamentals of economic growth are still fragile. Further action is urgently needed to strengthen macro-economic stabilisation, job creation, accelerate investment and improve the competitiveness of European economies. Proposals for such measures are contained in a European Commission document entitled 'Annual Growth Analysis'. The Commission proposes an integrated approach to growth based on 3 pillars. These include the Investment Support Programme by the European Fund for Strategic Investments, growth-friendly fiscal consolidation and the necessary structural reforms. The investment pillar is not only aimed at creating a fund with an investment potential of more than EUR 300 billion, but is also intended to be an instrument for building trust among private investors. Growth-friendly fiscal consolidation, on the other hand, aims to strengthen public finances and regain the ability of indebted countries to raise funds on the market. It is also intended to protect public investment, especially in areas such as infrastructure, education and healthcare. Finally, structural reforms aim at modernising European economies: to improve competitiveness through labour market reform, to remove barriers to product and service markets and to create favourable conditions for business, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises. However, not everyone agrees with these proposals. There are ideas to get out of the crisis by continuing to become indebted. In this context, it is proposed to loosen the EU's fiscal rules and halt structural reforms.  Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking We do not agree with these ideas. We consider them frivolous and irresponsible. Their implementation would deepen the crisis and jeopardise the integrity of the euro area. It also raises the obvious question of where the money would come from to finance further debts. We therefore support the Commission's position that these three lines of action should be among the economic policy priorities of the Member States for the coming years as part of the next cycle of country-specific recommendations being prepared. At the same time, we stress that full involvement of the Member States in the implementation of these priorities is necessary. It must not be the case that when it comes to difficult decisions, to difficult reforms, individual governments shift responsibility to Brussels. We expect the national authorities, governments and parliaments of the Member States to fully equate with and be responsible for implementing the reforms. The European Union cannot be treated like a bad policeman. We are all responsible for Europe.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz
text: Artist. – As a rapporter, I would first of all like to thank the shadow auditors for their work and all those who have helped with their amendments to get this form in the report on the internal market within the European Semester. It is almost customary for the European Semesters to be very tight, and that is what we are working on.  As far as the content of the report on internal market governance is concerned, a few comments: My first and most important point is that, in our opinion, the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection believes that it is very important to have a single pillar, a dedicated pillar, in this regard, dealing with single market governance and the internal market part.  The second very important issue is that we wanted to address areas that have added value in the internal market, serve economic growth and focus on job creation. These areas are not invented by us, but the IMCO Commission has studies, these are the latest studies that focus on these key areas. And these are the key areas that we have added to our report.  Overall, we believe that our results so far, which have been in the process of transposing legislation in the internal market, are exaggerated in terms of quantity. And we do not care about how member states transpose these legislation qualitatively. We also believe that the quality of implementation needs to be more focused. We can also imagine sectoral key indicators in this regard, which would show much better the progress we have made. The crisis has clearly highlighted the need to renew the Economic Model of the European Union. This is in order to increase our competitiveness. We have our opportunities, but we haven't used the opportunities yet. For this reason, the European Union must take strong supportive steps to increase cross-border trade, and also to keep up with the changing world and to invest more in digital technology, the digital industry, which is also part of the Juncker Plan.  We believe that repositioning the internal market would in any way contribute to making progress in the area of economic growth and employment, and also to achieving the EU's 2020 strategic goals. This dedicated pillar that I am talking about would clearly deal with the real economy. With the real economy that we need most to stimulate. It is essential that we also set priorities in this regard. We have already had interpretations of the internal market, but the foot of this has not reached the real economy, in order to achieve real results and effective steps, I believe that these should be done, further steps should be taken in this regard.  The governance issue is linked to the same: There is a need to focus more on governance and strong political support to make this happen in the internal market. In other words, the mechanisms that we have put in place really need to be operated, if necessary, then strengthened. I would like to mention a very great sadness, which I find difficult to digest, unfortunately the part on governance in the internal market has not been included in the Annual Growth Survey. I know that I have received the Commission's reply in this regard, but precisely because it is our common goal, I find it difficult to accept it.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, Commissioners, from the Committee on Employment we have tried to make a consensus report that is useful. Useful for underpinning an economic recovery that is still fragile, but above all, a recovery that the vast majority of citizens and businesses do not yet feel. But above all, a constructive and proactive report. Constructive, in order to strengthen this dual objective which we have — and which we share the vast majority of this Parliament - which is to improve the policies designed in the European Union — and implemented by the Member States — to create jobs and reduce inequalities. Create jobs, Commissioners. Create jobs urgently. Create decent employment quickly. Because it is true that we must end this social drama that twenty-five million European citizens live on that demand us not to be complacent, to do everything we have to do to attract investment, to strengthen our industry and to change our productive models, in order to guarantee them their right to access decent work in the European Union. And for this, Commissioners, we propose a number of things for you. First, your investments. We support them in their investment plan, but we remind them that it is a complement. A required add-in, which must also run quickly. They cannot replace previously scheduled investments. They should, in particular, target those regions with the greatest macroeconomic imbalances and higher unemployment rates. And develop into projects that give value, an added value. We ask you, yes, for fiscal responsibility, Mr Rosati, which is one that is compatible with economic growth and employment, which is one that can make use of the greatest flexibility within the Stability and Growth Pact, because the fiscal multiplier effects in the European Union are still too high to be compatible with job creation. But above all, we also ask you to incorporate fiscal responsibility and social responsibility into your Community language. That we cannot turn structural reforms into a mantra where everything is fit. That we have to get more concrete. That the structural reforms we promote in the European Union must first be compatible with economic growth and job creation, because some have had the same pro-cyclical effects as excessive fiscal consolidation. But they have to be compatible with a social model, which is the differential fact of the European Union. Because some structural reforms that have been promoted so far, in the words of the Commission itself, what they have done is, for example, to exclude from basic public services many citizens, for example in the exercise of their right to universal health or quality education. And, above all, broad-spectrum. That it is not only from labour reforms that the competitiveness of the European Union lives. That, in addition to labour reforms that are compatible with non-fragmentation of labour markets and non-wage devaluation, there are also other much-needed reforms, which we look forward to you promoting within the European Semester; energy reforms, internal market reforms, administrative reforms, prosecutors who can make, as I say, a lower workload in the European Union. And a constructive report, Commissioners, to end inequality. I use your own data. 50% of the employment created today in the European Union does not serve to take workers out of labour poverty. Therefore, what we are asking of you is that, in the European Union, the Commission promotes, within its competences — as it did in the past, with wage devaluation — the creation of a framework of sufficient wages, worthy, that allow something as basic as people to live with dignity of their work. You also say that you are concerned about the alarming reduction in the gross disposable income of families and I tell you that this is mainly because we have broken social spending in a very significant way. That we need strong social indicators to assess this impact, in order to avoid, precisely, the increase in inequality due to an excessive increase in the reduction of public spending, mainly in basic social rights. And finally, you're worried about the difference between rents. Between ten per cent higher and ten per cent lower in the European Union, which in some countries has increased sevenfold in recent years. And for that, I tell you that we have to ensure sufficient and dignified automatic stabilisers at the national level, especially in pensions and unemployment benefits, and much more work tax regimes fair and equitable.

name: Zanda
text: Kalniņa-Lukaševica, President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, Vice-President Dombrovskis, Commissioners, rapporteurs and honourable Members, it is a great pleasure for the Latvian Presidency to have this opportunity to discuss with you today the European Semester, which has become, in less than five years, a core process for economic policy coordination in Europe. The economic situation does not look as bleak as it did some time ago, and recent data give cause for moderate optimism, but I believe we all acknowledge that Europe is not yet where it wants to be. The economic recovery is fragile, the legacy of debt weighs heavily on most Member States and the employment situation remains difficult. The European Semester was created in 2010 for Europe to exit the crisis through better coordination of our economic action. This coordination has not always been easy and it still is not. The economies of Member States differ and so do their policy priorities. But with the Semester we have a common framework in which to discuss these policies, and their impact on Europe as a whole, and to agree on the way forward. We are now looking more carefully at the implementation of the policy recommendations issued under the European Semester. Parliament is right to highlight in the resolution that more should be done in that context. The Commission is working closely with each Member State to pursue implementation. The Council is also doing its part, taking a collective look, at ministerial and at expert level, at how the commonly agreed policies are being implemented, exchanging best practices and generating peer pressure. Rebalancing and restructuring our economies cannot be done overnight. That is why we need to stay the course, and I am convinced that our joint efforts will pay off. Turning now more specifically to this year’s Semester and the 2015 Annual Growth Survey: as you may know, the Latvian Presidency has engaged the Council in broad discussions on the Annual Growth Survey. Obviously, the ministers of finance and employment have contributed but we have also debated the Annual Growth Survey in the Competitiveness, Energy and Environment Councils. The Transport Council will address the issue this Friday. This is further proof of the Semester being embedded into our way of conducting economic policy, and more broadly all policies that contribute to growth and jobs. As far as finance ministers are concerned, yesterday in the Ecofin Council, Vice-President Dombrovskis presented the country reports on the economic policies of Member States, prepared as part of the European Semester. The Council had a first exchange of views on them. It will discuss the in-depth reviews in May and the country-specific recommendations for all Member States in June. The Latvian Presidency also decided to link the Council debates on the European Semester to broader sectoral policy initiatives. Taking the example of energy, the Annual Growth Survey was examined by the energy ministers in the same context as the new Energy Union and energy infrastructure proposals. Looking at things from the energy policy perspective, the European Semester is a tool for implementing, for example, the internal energy market. At the same time, the Energy Union is necessary to generate more growth in Europe. What, then, are the results of the Council’s work on the Annual Growth Survey? First, I am pleased to say that the Council fully agrees with the overall approach of the Annual Growth Survey. By this I mean the integrated approach based on three mutually—supportive pillars: investment, structural reforms and fiscal responsibility. Each of these is a necessary ingredient for reaching our growth and jobs objectives. On investment, as you may know, the Council is taking forward the investment plan for Europe diligently. Yesterday, only two months after the Commission presented its proposal, the Ecofin Council adopted a general approach on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) proposal.  For the Presidency it is important to deliver concrete results that can benefit citizens. The Presidency is now ready to negotiate with Parliament and we will do our utmost to find an agreement by this summer, as called for by the European Council. I know this House shares with us the sense of urgency and I hope it will be able to progress swiftly. We look forward to the first trilogue. The great potential of EFSI is obvious. But it is just as obvious that we need to pursue in parallel the other strands of the investment plan. I refer in particular to improving the investment climate and, more generally, the business environment in Europe. One of the most effective ways to do this is to reduce the regulatory burden at both European and national level. But we also have to ensure the necessary regulatory certainty for economic operators. Moreover, we should not look at the EFSI in isolation. EUR 315 billion is a lot of money, but if we can harness synergies between the EFSI and other EU programmes, structural funds and national funding, we will do even better. Lastly, talking about investment, I want to highlight the need for special efforts to facilitate small and medium-sized enterprises’ access to finance, both at the stage of start—ups and also at the critical growth phase. The Council looks forward to the initiatives that the Commission will be taking on the Capital Markets Union. Looking now at the second pillar, structural reforms, these remain as necessary as ever. We must acknowledge that a lot has been done in many Member States, and also that most of the reforms require a long—term perspective. A national education system, for example, cannot be overhauled within a year. Council debates on the Annual Growth Survey are, in fact, a great vehicle for exchanging experiences between Member States on what works on the ground. They also contribute to our collective knowledge on how to prepare reforms in an inclusive way, engaging the relevant stakeholders. The pursuit of the European single market is strongly related to structural reforms at national level. Here the discussions within the Council point to the need to adopt a pragmatic, sector-oriented approach. To be effective, Europe should focus on the sectors with highest potential, in particular the digital economy, energy, transport, telecommunications and services. Under services, retail, business, construction and tourism services are among those that we want to look at as a priority. What emerges from these Council debates is the emphasis on implementation and enforcement of existing single market legislation. Your draft resolution on single market governance shows that our views converge on many issues. Looking now at the last, though not the least, pillar of the Annual Growth Survey, fiscal responsibility, we first have to recognise the significant progress made, since the crisis, in getting our public finances in order. The euro area as a whole now has a neutral fiscal stance and this is no small achievement, considering where we started from. Unfortunately, we cannot rest on our laurels. Public debt, in particular, is an issue that warrants our full attention if we are to safeguard the recovery and also to prepare ourselves to confront any crisis. Hence, the Council insists that all Member States stay on course with fiscal consolidation – but not with any kind of consolidation. It should be differentiated, depending on the fiscal situation of each Member State, and overall it should be growth friendly. In practice this means, for example, giving priority to tax reforms that can generate growth and securing public spending in growth areas such as education and research. Before finishing, I would like to say a few words on ‘digital Europe’. As you may know, it is one of the three priorities of the Latvian Presidency. I see it is also well covered in your resolution. We have used the Council discussions on the Annual Growth Survey to look too at the potential of the digital economy for the EU growth and jobs agenda. It is clear that Europe needs a digital transformation to re-establish its status as a leading player in the global digital economy. Digitisation should cut across all policy fields, from industrial to environmental policies. To digitise Europe, Member States need to reinforce their efforts at national level, but there are also a number of initiatives that we need to pursue at European level. In this regard, the Council also looks forward to the Commission presenting a comprehensive and ambitious Digital Single Market Strategy later this spring. I could continue further on the priorities and considerations of the Council with regard to the Annual Growth Survey or the European Semester in general, and there are a number of other important issues raised in your resolutions that I could address. But I believe it is more important that we now engage in a discussion on the European Semester and where our priorities this year should lie. I thank you very much and I look forward to hearing your views.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice—President of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by thanking the rapporteurs, Mr Rosati, Mr Gáll—Pelcz and Mr Gutiérrez Prieto, as well as the shadow rapporteurs, for their work. The European Semester is our key tool for fostering convergence in Europe’s economic and social policy and making sure that everyone plays their role to bring back jobs. The European Semester will work only if we build a shared understanding of the key economic and social policy challenges. This is why your reports and today’s debates are so important. As highlighted in Parliament’s reports, in spite of an ongoing recovery, the economic situation remains fragile and requires urgent action. We agree that structural, fiscal and monetary policies have to be combined to tackle the current challenges effectively, and that social considerations must enter more explicitly into the formulation of economic policies. I am pleased to see Parliament’s support for the Commission’s economic policy priorities: investment, structural reform and fiscal responsibility. Firstly, we need a coordinated boost to investment. Your support for the investment plan is highly welcome. The Council agreed yesterday on a general approach on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), and we strongly hope that it will be possible to finalise a legislative act by June so that the EFSI can be fully deployed from mid—2015. The fact that several Member States intend to contribute via their national promotional banks is also very good news. Secondly, we need structural reforms. They are needed for competitiveness, for investment, for a better adjustment capacity and, ultimately, to create quality jobs and sustain our social market economies. Labour markets and social systems face heavy fallout from the crisis. Unemployment is still unacceptably high, especially among young people and the long—term unemployed. Inequality and poverty have risen. We must create new jobs without adding to labour market segmentation. Commissioner Thyssen will elaborate on this. Product and services market reforms are also needed in order to stimulate competition and innovation and to reduce prices for customers and costs for businesses. Ambitious reforms are a task not only for Member States but also for the European level. The Commission has, in recent weeks, delivered strategies on the capital markets union and the energy union, and the digital single market will follow soon. The Commission will also put forward a fresh internal market strategy by the end of the year, and Commissioner Bieńkowska will address this in a moment. Thirdly, we need to pursue fiscal responsibility. Without downplaying the achievements so far, most Member States still need to work on their debt sustainability. At the same time, Member States with more fiscal room for manoeuvre have an opportunity to increase their investments. These priorities are translated into country—specific analysis and conclusions in the economic governance package adopted by the Commission at the end of February. The package took into account the Commission’s communication on the best use of flexibility within the Stability and Growth Pact. To make this three—pillar strategy work we must make better use of our system of economic governance. Our common challenge is to stimulate implementation of our policy recommendations in the Member States. To do this we believe that it is important to increase transparency and dialogue, as well as ownership of, and commitment to, the implementation of reforms. As a first step this year, we published the Commission’s country analyses much earlier in the semester cycle. These reports present a clear view on the economic situation and on policy implementation. We now have three months of additional time for discussions and feedback on the analyses before the Commission issues its recommendations in May. My fellow members of the Commission and I, with other Commission representatives, will travel to a number of Member States for discussions with parliamentarians, social partners and governments. Europe needs to re—embark on a path of real economic convergence in terms of growth and jobs and to address social concerns. To get there, Member States must deliver on structural, fiscal and social policies and the EU must strengthen key common policies in fields such as energy, the digital single market and taxation. I look forward to a constructive and fruitful debate with you today.

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the three rapporteurs and to remind you that, for the first time since 2007, the economies of all the EU Member States are expected to grow again in 2015. But the pace of recovery is slow and the social consequences of the crisis are severe. This challenging backdrop requires an ambitious policy agenda. The 2015 Annual Growth Survey and the aligned economic policy agenda marked a new start, one that is based on investment, structural reform and fiscal responsibility, our famous triangle. The proposed EUR 315 billion investment package channelled through the European Fund for Strategic Investment aims to address the problem of weak demand and to stimulate investment in the real economy, where jobs are created. A key aspect of this investment package is to remove barriers for investment, in particular for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), and I am very pleased that my colleague Elzbieta Bieńkowsa is with us today to discuss the European Semester, since a strong single market and product market reform are also necessary to improve the environment for investment. One of the core messages of the 2015 Annual Growth Survey is that reforms supporting the sound functioning of labour markets work. So do reforms improving the effectiveness of social protection systems. These reforms must continue. In both the Commission’s investment initiative and the Annual Growth Survey, employment and social concerns feature as cross—cutting priorities. Together they reflect the Commission’s intention to place greater focus on jobs and growth and the social impact of fiscal and macroeconomic policies. This is a recognition that prolonged employment and social problems act as a drag on growth and social inclusion. This Commission believes that this agenda and its strong focus on social fairness and on the social dimension of reforms will help to build a solid foundation for sustained growth and greater social and economic convergence. The Commission’s publication on 26 February 2015 of a surveillance package, comprising 27 country reports, a euro area report and an accompanying communication, is a second step within the renewed European Semester. You can clearly see the increased consideration that the Commission is giving to employment and social concerns in the country reports. These reports, as you know, form the analytical basis for the country—specific recommendations. Let me also draw your attention to another novelty. The Commission has published the country—specific analysis in a single document for each country, three months in advance. This streamlined and reinforced approach aims to simplify the process, at the same time as increasing joint ownership of it. In practice the Commission has now made an effort to extend the exchanges of views between institutions and stakeholders at national and European level to allow for constructive dialogue with Member States’ parliaments, social partners and civil society. For example, I found the discussion I had with Ministers of Social Affairs and Employment last Monday in the Employment, Social Policy, Health and Consumer Affairs Council (EPSCO) very enriching. Last week the Commission also committed, at a high—level event we organised to promote social dialogue, to ensuring a stronger role for the social partners in the European Semester. This is, of course, also the time for the Parliament to intervene and that is why I find this debate extremely useful today. I am keen to listen to Members and follow the debate now.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, the Single Market is a core part of the European Semester, which is of course a joint exercise between the Commission and the Member States. I can compare the Single Market to a launch pad to get Europe out of the crisis; it will allow us to unlock the investment potential in Europe and, hopefully, create opportunities for our consumers and investors. But, if we are to make the most of it, we need to remove the remaining barriers and bottlenecks. I want to thank very much Ms Gáll-Pelcz, Mr Rosati and Mr Gutiérrez Prieto for their report. It is timely; it covers the most important issues and most urgent tasks. On the Single Market our first priority should be to make existing Single Market rules work to their full potential. We need better implementation – as Ms Gáll-Pelcz said – effective monitoring and stronger enforcement. The Commission has already set up a Single Market governance strategy to promote that. This includes implementation objectives for all legislation – in particular there will be a zero tolerance approach to the Service Directive. There will also be further development of online governance tools, such as Your Europe, SOLVIT and the online Single Market Scoreboard. We also duly stated the conclusions of the parliamentary Cost of Non—Europe report. The European Parliament expressed regrets that the Annual Single Market Integration report was not published this year and there was no sign or Single Market topic in the Annual Growth Survey. Let me be very clear: we are not reducing our efforts. On the contrary, we want to improve the quality and the impact of the reporting; we want to integrate all possible instruments and we are, of course, looking now at how to do this and working very intensively on this. For example, we are looking at streamlining the reports. We are looking at putting more focus on economic indicators because I deeply believe streamlining Single Market governance will help our wider efforts on the Single Market. This year, as was also mentioned, we will launch two major initiatives centred on the Single Market. The first one: the Digital Single Market package, which will be released on 6 May 2015, and then for the end of this year we are planning the Internal Market Strategy. All the proposed actions will be based solid economic grounds and impact assessments. There will be an objective assessment of what works and what does not. I can assure you that we will take the time to ask the right questions and to answer them properly. Let me put a few of them. Is harmonisation in the area of goods as efficient as it should be? Can we improve or even extend the application of the mutual recognition principle in goods and services? How do we address the link between goods and services? How do we tackle the remaining barriers in goods and services? How do we get rid of discrimination over access to goods, services and online content cross—border? How can we get rid of the obstacles to cross—border e—commerce? How do we reduce the administrative burden on our companies to the minimum? These are only some of the questions we need to answer. And we need to do it in partnership with you and the Member States. That is why this debate today is so useful. I really count on our close cooperation in the course of this year and in the course of the whole mandate.

name: Jean Arthuis
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. Mr President, Madam President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and commissioners, ladies and gentlemen, the European semester is the hasty response to the shock of the sovereign debt crisis, particularly in Greece. Crisis resulting from the scandalous absence of eurozone government for ten years.  When states agree to give themselves the same currency, they must ensure that all of their territories are an optimal economic zone. Without convergence of fiscal and social legislation, without coordination of economic policies, without a real government, it is futile to pretend to escape instability and drama.  To give substance to this governance and coordination, I make three recommendations: First, the allocation of a share of unpaid invoices by the European Union into the accounts of the Member States to assess their possible excessive deficit. It is a question of credibility, a prerequisite for trust. We talked about it at length yesterday about the 2016 budget. Secondly, the standardisation of the presentation of states' contributions to the European Union budget in their public accounts. It is a question of consistency and legibility. Finally, the harmonization of the presentation of public accounts and the diligences of their sincerity. The aggregation of all these public accounts would express Europe's true budget and would no doubt facilitate cooperation between governments.

name: Γιώργος Γραμματικάκης
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. Mr President, once again the debate on the European Semester revolves around the crisis. Of course, there was no shortage of efforts and ideas, and we have heard enough today. But the reality, I'm afraid, is painful. As popular wisdom says, our passions have not become lessons. So in the European Union inequality and unemployment are galloping, along with anti-European forces.  So we have no choice, I fear, no more time, no choice. We need to change policy immediately, put a stop to the blind obsession with austerity. This, Mr President, will only be done with real investments in sustainable, green growth, such as renewable energy sources, the circular economy and efficient resource management. The benefits, you all know, will be multiple: creating jobs but also improving competitiveness. Above all, however, improving our health, environment and quality of life.

name: Sofia Ribeiro
text: on behalf of the Ppe Group. – Mr President, for the EPP, the European Semester should be to increase jobs, promote growth and improve investment. These designs should support a market economy model, with strong social concerns, thus ensuring sustainable growth, in order to transmit to the next generation better job opportunities, rather than a heavy legacy, by responsible for debts they have not committed.  That is why we have been committed from the outset to uphold three fundamental pillars: investment, structural reforms and fiscal responsibility.  On employment and social affairs issues, it should not be forgotten that it is only by promoting reproductive investment that we will be stimulating sustainable job creation that enables real investment in human capital, professional mobility, research and innovation, which are essential to expanding the economic potential of the European Union, thereby bringing prosperity to the peoples of Europe. It is essential that we continue to invest in measures to combat youth unemployment, without forgetting long-term unemployment. Young people will be the driver of the leverage of our economy, and Europe, all of us, owes them that.  Urgent measures are needed to enable the balance of professional life with family life, also encouraging training and lifelong learning, as well as dual education. Particular attention must be paid to the outermost regions, to the less developed regions, so that we have real social and territorial cohesion. Member States also have to do their part by eliminating unnecessary administrative burdens and bureaucracy that discourages entrepreneurship, self-employed people, the start-up of micro-enterprises, SMEs, which will be the catalysts for economic growth, innovation, employment and social integration. We must also mobilise all the means to continue in this european prosperity action.

name: Alfred Sant
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I start by congratulating Mr Rosati, our rapporteur on the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, for his fine work. I thank our shadow rapporteurs for their valuable inputs. The analysis and conclusions on the annual growth survey are well in line with the parameters of the Stability and Growth Pact (SGP). However, I must register some unease at aspects of our proceedings. As of now we lack a real understanding as to why the economic performance of national economies has remained so dull, indeed so stagnant. Similarly, we cannot grasp the real reason why the investment gap in the eurozone has remained so significant. True, we see glimmers of growth now and we wish for the best. Rightly, much emphasis is being placed on the flexibility that is presently being read into SGP rules. Over—rigid application of these rules has been counterproductive. Let us hope that flexibility will be applied equally and fairly to all economies and not just the bigger ones. So let me repeat that structural reforms are necessary but, as I said elsewhere, they should not mean an erosion of the European social model. Where structural reforms refer to elimination of monopolies, freer access to the provision of services, curtailment and digitalisation of government bureaucracy, incentivising those who produce, streamlining public procurement practices and the encouragement of public-private partnerships, such reforms should be given full support. Yet, it seems to me that we still do not have a viable approach to tackle regional and national divergences within the eurozone, and they have been increasing. I am uneasy because, having a 19—economy system, working to the model of a quasi—balance in all national budgets is not axiomatically the optimal way to run a currency area. Yes, we have jargon-laden discourse to correct for so-called macroeconomic imbalances, but there is a vagueness about how to implement corrective action on this basis. There still is no valid reply to the question: are country—specific recommendations designed to satisfy eurozone or national priorities? Therefore, I am not too surprised that so many CSRs are ignored by national parliaments and governments. In the absence of a central treasury to regulate transfers between centre and periphery, much of the exercise that we are carrying out now could be compared to that of a circus performer on a high rope, juggling with 19 balls. Of course, in order to succeed, such a juggling operation needs commitment, discipline and a high level of competence.

name: Sampo Terho
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank Mr Rosati for his good cooperation. The economic content of the report has mainly been good, and the author of the report has realised the main problems and solutions of the European economy, mainly correctly. In fact, I could say that we would have liked the final report to have been closer to the rapporteur's original draft. However, there is one point I would like to emphasise. The ECR's vision for the European Semester is that the Semester is advisory. For us, maintaining the independence of the Member States is the basis of all policy, and we refuse to hand over budgetary powers from the Member States to the EU any more than has already happened. Looking to the future, we would really like a few fundamental details relating to the independence of the Member States not to get in the way of the central content of the reports on the European Semester. So what is the sensible content of the advice given to the Member States? ECR will continue to hope for good cooperation, with groups sharing the vision of a free market economy in this ongoing process. Thank you.

name: Nils Torvalds
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I should like to thank Mr Rosati for very honest and good work, and I should also like to thank the rest of the shadows. One of the central words in this debate is ‘austerity’, but this word austerity is at the same time part of a blame game. We tried to use the word austerity just to get rid of our own shortcomings in economic policy. Quite recently there was an article by Ricardo Hausmann about Greece. You can find it in the Project Syndicate, and it is a good read for all those who think that austerity is the main problem here. Ricardo Hausmann is also known for The Atlas of Economic Complexity, and I think that we, as politicians, are very bad at looking at the complexities. We have a complex with complexities and we do not actually like to go into the details. Hausmann’s Atlas of Economic Complexity shows where the problems are. If you take, for instance, Greece then you see that the balance between export and import is not a very good one, and due to globalisation Greece, Portugal and some other countries are gliding down in international competition. They are gliding down as regards possibilities to get into the market, and that is actually the real problem. Therefore, we need a European investment policy. We need an investment policy addressing these profound, deep problems in our economies. If we do not do that, then austerity will be the result, and it is going to be the result because we do not understand what we are actually doing.

name: Presidente. –
text: Because of the dynamics of the debate and the issues that have been considerably lengthened in relation to the votes we will have after the debate, it is not possible to accept blue cards.

name: Miguel Viegas
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, this report, which represents the starting point of the European Semester of the current year, provides the main political guidelines on which national budgets should be built. As expected, he continues to advocate austerity, structural reforms, particularly at the level of the labour market and the privatisation of businesses and public services, calling into question access to social rights gained after decades of struggle. This is totally unacceptable because, in this time of crisis, this economic governance prevents countries from intervening with redistributive policies to help those most in need and to prevent the collapse of aggregate consumption. Economic governance and the European Semester are a way of tassing countries to the neoliberal agendas of the European Union at the service of major economic interests. They prevent countries from being able to sovereignly decide their collective future, forcing them to watch arms tied to the destruction of their economies. We cannot accept this passively and we will do anything to break with this monetary dictatorship.

name: Ernest Urtasun
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I too would like to thank Mr Rosati for his efforts and his cooperation. However, we do not share the substance of the presentation, inter alia, because there is an un critic endorsement of the trio's shaker 'structural reforms, fiscal consolidation and investment', which we believe has failed in recent years as a method of getting Europe out of the serious crisis it is in. Moreover, some of the best data we have right now in some Member States in relation to GDP and having avoided the third recession are simply due to the action of the European Central Bank and also to the fall in the price of oil; in any case, not the shaker that is presented to us in the Annual Growth Study as the only way out. I have to say that structural reforms in most Member States have been socially very damaging and have been a key factor in the problem of devaluation. Competitiveness gains are being highly questioned; for example, in my country right now we are once again in deficit in the trade balance, so the strategy I had designed has not worked. On the other hand, fiscal consolidation, in some cases, has gone too fast and made things worse, and here, of course, we are going to discuss a lot with the rapporteur, Mrs Beres, in the report on the assessment of economic governance, on how all this is adjusted. Because flexibility always applies ex post when it is already inevitable and ex ante is not allowed to give Member States space and scope to deal with a recession situation. And finally, the investment. The Juncker Plan is obviously not a serious plan to encourage investment. We have the European Central Bank doing quantitative easing and a European Investment Bank that has to make an investment plan. And the two plans don't talk to each other. So, we think that's bad news. It seems to me that there must be a change in economic policy and that this is not the solution.

name: Laura Agea
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, my first thanks go to Mr Gutiérrez Prieto for his work and because it shows that, no matter where he sits in this House, when you think about the citizens and look at the citizens, positions do not matter, intentions count. So he deserves an appreciation for the work and for the will to find a share. Of course, the assessment I would like to make is that for the umpteenth time we are being swallowed the purge and immediately afterwards we are given the candy, which means that the taste we have in our mouths is perhaps a little more softened but the result we suffer is exactly the same: because once again you are asking us for structural reforms , once again impose budgetary constraints and fiscal responsibility. When will you allow us to breathe? When will you solve the problem of poverty in our countries? When will you give us the freedom to make real social policies that support our citizens?

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are once again celebrating the ritual of the pointless and damaging debate of the European Semester. Useless, because the coordination of economic policies has not solved any problems; It is harmful, because Europe, by means of absurd measures, dictated by Berlin, written by and to protect the big banks, the big industries, the great economic powers, brings entire States, entire economies, to their knees. An example of all veneto, my region, where the "Eurofollie" since the beginning of the crisis have sent a hundred thousand jobs into smoke and closed, in 2014 alone, over three thousand companies. These are the wonderful results of the European semesters. Let us cancel them and erase these useless rites and erase the Europe of austerity and sacrifice. No more proclamations, no more propaganda, no more lies. Here we must do one thing immediately: change the absurd budgetary parameters laid down in the European Treaties and put citizens and work at the centre of European policies. There are many who ask us this and I will use every minute I have available in here to give a voice to the citizens. Only in this way can a new Europe be born.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE).
text: Mr President, this European semester highlights a positive fact: growth is returning to Europe. However, it is a phenomenon that remains fragile and heterogeneous. It is true that Europe is suffering: it suffers from a lack of investment - the Rosati report says this very well. Investment is still 20% lower than in the pre-crisis period. So it is true that the Juncker investment plan is one of the answers. Of course, we support this plan, but it will only bear fruit if confidence returns. Today, however, we still have SMEs closing their doors, employees who find themselves unemployed, young people leaving Europe for lack of work and, of course, economic insecurity that does not allow companies to invest.  It is time for Europe to regain investor confidence. There is no growth without confidence. And there is no confidence without fiscal consolidation and deleveraging.  I could see the example of Spain, where I visited last week. I have seen that the reforms already undertaken have resulted in lower unemployment and job creation. Not all Member States are in the same situation. France, for example, is a country with many assets: with many resources, it can rely on its extraordinary human capital, dynamic regions and SMEs. But what a waste! For in the absence of sustainable reforms, France is stalling and threatening to drag europe as a whole.  That is why I want the Commission to be firm. France must respect the rules of the Stability and Growth Pact. The Commission, of course, must listen to the people - as we have seen for Greece - but it must not listen to all the sirens. Giving France two more years to implement its reforms is a heavy responsibility: to make future generations bear the burden of debt and delay economic recovery.

name: Maria João Rodrigues (S&D).
text: – Mr President, many thanks to the EU Presidency and to the three Commissioners for coming to talk with us in Parliament. Our message is similar. Of course we want to have real recovery with job creation, but we also want to move to a new growth model which is greener, smarter and with social inclusion. That is why we need a much better policy mix.  Regarding reforms, yes they are needed, but these reforms should be focusing on growth potential, on sustainability and also on reducing social inequalities.  We can be sure that the critical factor to make a real change in the situation will be investment, and investment paving the way for quality jobs. That is why we need these smart rules creating room to invest. I would say that this ‘triangle’ is positive, but it is not enough because we should have a kind of ‘square’.  We need also to support European economic demand, and this requires reducing social inequalities in Europe. I believe that the following priorities should be pushed forward throughout the cycle of the European Semester: the Annual Growth Survey, the country—specific recommendations, the upcoming discussion on the Economic and Employment Guidelines – which has already been presented by the Commission and on which we are preparing our position – and, last but not least, the new phase of the Europe 2020 Strategy.  I would like to conclude by saying something on the word ‘convergence’, because Commissioner Dombrovskis and Commissioner Thyssen underlined this. Indeed, if you want all Member States to have a real opportunity to move in this direction, to use this policy mix, we need to complete and rebalance the Economic and Monetary Union.

name: Anthea McIntyre (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I really welcome the emphasis on reforms and better regulation in the Annual Growth Survey and in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs’ report, and I thank the rapporteur. It is so important we create the right environment to enable businesses to grow and create jobs. This can help us to accelerate the trend of re—shoring – bringing jobs back to Europe. We are seeing this in the UK, and it can happen right across the EU. There can be no one—size—fits—all approach. We do not have a single European social model. Effective policy solutions are best devised by the Member States. In Britain we have 760 000 more small businesses than we had five years ago. The UK is the most entrepreneurial country in Europe. There are 1.85 million more people in work than five years ago. Wages are now rising faster than inflation, and there are more people with the stability and security of a job. This is real growth.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I support the report on Single Market governance, and I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work. However, we do have to admit that the EU Single Market is not fulfilling its full potential. It has to be better monitored if we want to promote growth and jobs. It is very important to develop analytical tools to properly measure the economic and regulatory performance of the Single Market.
