I think that it is very important that the European Semester and the country—specific recommendations reflect the priority sectors in the EU where there is strong potential for growth: first of all, a digital single market, which could generate thousands of jobs; free movement of goods and services, public procurement; ECT.  This morning, the President said that the Commission has fast—tracked the reports on the country—specific recommendations. Now Member States have more time to examine those recommendations. I welcome that. The most important thing is for Member States to better implement EU legislation and international law and commit to structural reforms which are now working. It is time; it is the only way forward.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I must confess that I did not want to, it seems difficult to believe the Commissioner's words, when she says that the proposals that are now presented here in relation to the European Semester are based on impacts and sound economic analyses. I would say: if there is one thing on which they are not based it is on the results and the impacts, because if so there would have to be a total reversal of the recommended policies. Because the results, Commissioner, is that inequalities have increased, that the economies on the periphery are crushed, that debts are unsustainable, that structural reforms are nothing more than adjustment through wages and through the destruction of the social state. Commissioner, no, they did not look at the results or make any solid economic analysis. And that is why the Commission itself has put some of the countries that have been such good pupils under close surveillance, as is the case in Portugal. Commissioner, how are the same policies going to work again now? Commissioner, the problem is austerity.

name: Monika Vana (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I can say from the Greens that we are in favour of a fundamental reform of the European Semester and of strengthening the social dimension, and urgently. On the one hand, it is about the credibility of the European Union when we talk about sustainability, living up to employment and combating poverty. But it is also about the confidence of Europe's citizens after the failed austerity policy. I believe that the focus of recent years solely on competitiveness and economic growth has failed. We need sustainable social reforms here. That is why the adoption of today's report by the Employment and Social Committee on the employment and social aspects of the Annual Growth Survey is so important. It contains concrete proposals on how to invest in social policy and the strengthening of the social dimension of the European Semester, whether through the development of the social criteria that must be treated on an equal footing with macroeconomic separin, or by finally putting the Europe 2020 targets off the rails and finally giving priority to the objectives of poverty reduction, climate protection and also equality between men and women. As previous speakers have said, we need public investment, especially in public and social services. We Greens are strongly in favour of strengthening the democratic dimension of the European Semester, not only for the full co-responsibility and co-determination of the European Parliament, but also, in particular, for the involvement of civil society, as has been discussed many times in this House. For us, the adoption of today's report is a step in the right direction of social and citizen-oriented reform.

name: Patrick O’Flynn (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, for the first time, the self—doubt of the EU political class has transmitted itself publicly, because the motion for debate notes that the euro area, in particular, stands out as an area of unsatisfactory growth. That is because other countries have control over setting their own interest rates and managing their own exchange rates to suit the needs of their economies. In Britain, we have a saying ‘the penny is starting to drop’: well, the euro has certainly started to drop on the international exchanges and, along with quantitative easing, that may help in generating some growth this year. But we all know that once Germany has had enough medicine, the prescription will be stopped for everyone. They used to say that when America sneezed the world caught a cold. Well, in euroland, when Germany stops sneezing the whole of Southern Europe will be left to die of influenza. This currency union has failed. Someone must put it out of its misery.

name: Hans Jansen (NI).
text: Mr President, the situation in the European Union is disastrous. There is little or no economic growth. The debts have never been higher and they are growing by the day. Unemployment is immense, there is no improvement in sight. The European Central Bank has made interest rates extremely low and the money press is putting on the money press, and as a result, the countries that do not want to reform will never do so again.  There is no way out of this situation if we do not change the rules of the game. The euro must be dismantled. Member States must go about their own economic policies. But this Parliament now wants to make an unaffordable welfare state compulsory in all Member States. At whose expense? What we do need is small governments, small debts, low taxes. That alone is the recipe for restoring economic growth. Then we don't need that economic semester that's on the agenda anymore.

name: Burkhard Balz (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The European Semester is an early economic warning system that the Commission and the Member States have at their disposal, but which, in my view, they still make far too little use of. We are therefore also very critical of the fact that the Commission and the Member States are now allowing an extension of the deadline for deficit reduction. Such a decision is difficult to explain to many European citizens. In the end, rules are there to be respected. This must apply equally to small and large Member States. Parliament's opinion, in my view, contains clear messages. We are committed to continuing consolidation, we call for consistent implementation of the country-specific recommendations and we emphasise national ownership. The Black Peter game with the EU institutions is no longer working, as we are currently seeing in the Greek negotiations. We underline the essential need for structural reforms that need to be implemented, and we also make it clear that any investment offensive is not a substitute for reform. We naturally want to boost the European economy. But credibility in economic policy and a consistent commitment to reform are key factors for investors. This is where the European Semester can provide valuable impetus. Above all, the European Semester can also point out any wrongdoing at an early stage. I therefore call on the Member States and the Commission to make greater use of this instrument in the future. The sins of the past, where national aberrations have been dumped on European shoulders, must not happen again.

name: Elisa Ferreira (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioners, ladies and gentlemen, the European budgetary adjustment has not worked. On the contrary, the policies of the last six years have led to large losses of investment and wealth. The fight for unemployment and poverty will take a long time to recover. Today, Europe has become the sick of the world, with anemic growth and historical economic and social inequalities, both within and among its Member States.  In contrast to its predecessor, it must be acknowledged that Jean-Claude Juncker's current European Commission is beginning to show signs of recognising the problem and wanting to advance ways of asolution. They're positive signs, but they're not enough. The change of agenda cannot be just symbolic. The Commission will have to be much more competent in the management of economic governance in the framework of the European Semester. The Commission must put itself at the helm of this economic governance, the recovery agenda, the convergence agenda. The trends of recent years must be urgently reversed.  2015 is, in this sense, a critical year. Citizens must feel this change in their confidence. The components of the agenda are there in the Commission's proposal, but what matters is how they are implemented.  The Group of European Socialists would have liked to have gone further in its recommendations. However, on each of the issues, the position we will be voting on is clear. It is important to recognise the centrality of investment, and the Juncker Fund is a positive step forward. But it will have to contribute not only to relaunching growth, but also to correcting regional employment inequalities. The selection of beneficiary projects should ensure a positive impact on the most devastated regions. With regard to structural reforms, Parliament recommends an urgent review of their content and a careful assessment, not only of their impact on competitiveness, effectively, but also on social and employment. As far as economic governance is in place, fiscal policies must contribute to the recovery. Countries with room for manoeuvre should use it, and countries in the process of adjusting must be able to use the flexibility provided for in the Stability Pact. It is important to protect strategic investment and maintain social cohesion. That's six years of wrong politics. They are provoking rejection reactions from Europe, which is seen in several countries as a serious problem. We must be aware of this reality and act before it is too late.

name: Vicky Ford (ECR).
text: – Mr President, to get sustainable public finances we need jobs and growth to help our businesses be competitive and to increase trade. Too often in the past European legislation has added extra red tape and cost for consumers and it is good that many in this House are recognising the need to change.  The single market is key – businesses need confidence in a level playing field – but we also need better laws and they need to be better implemented and to protect against protectionism. To succeed our single market must also be vibrant and diverse, not a top—down ‘one—size—fits—all’ Communist grey. We do not need ‘one—size—fits—all’ taxes, wages, employment laws; these do not create jobs and I will not support reports that call for them.  The European Semester was meant to be a place to share best practice, to exchange views and give recommendations. It is not about bureaucrats issuing orders or centralised dictates; that will not give people confidence.

name: Enrique Calvet Chambon (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, despite the work I recognise that the rapporteur and many people have done, unfortunately we are faced with a very loose, farcug, omni-thorough, blurred text which leads to confusion without strong recommendations. It certainly includes excellent ideas, such as paragraph 8, which is to call for the European Fund not to be a replacement for investments already made, but to go further; it is followed by paragraph 9 which has nothing to do with the European Semester. I would also like to conclude paragraph 15, which says, within an economic and short-term context — which is what we are talking about in a European Semester — that in order to break imbalances, in a single monetary area and in a market unit, it is also important that areas or countries with a surplus pull the economy. And that's excellent advice. But, next to this, we find a whole series of other concepts, an immense series of other debatable ideas, much more adapted to social policy. I am talking, for example, about the very respectable minimum income, which, of course, I will support at the time. I am talking, for example, about the ways in which deficits are calculated. What it does is create confusion that impoverishes our employment force and impoverishes these important terms, which must also be addressed, in turn, in other legislative texts. Here we also find a red line that the ALDE Group is not going to pass, which is when we turn this role into an ideological debate on economic models or structural practices. On that, if this structural line is not passed, we will vote, although it is not the best of the texts to present to our constituents.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the European Semester is just another piece of the institutional architecture of the European Union that attacks the political and economic sovereignty of countries by imposing budgetary constraints on the national sovereignty bodies themselves. All in the name of one ultimate goal: the stability of the euro.  It is already a general rule that the report of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs of the European Parliament, year after year, tries to square the circle in this process. That is, try to make the impossible seem possible. But the truth is that, no matter how many turns the text goes, no matter how much social word it puts in the text, economic policies that aim to contain countries' spending, cutting into the social functions of the state, privatising public resources, promoting redundancies and making labour costs cheaper – we all say this – these measures cannot simultaneously respond to social objectives. Let us look at what concrete measures the Council and the European Commission put in place on employment. It is said that employment systems are still rigid in many countries, that it is necessary to make derogations from collective procurement, that wages must be aligned with productivity. But it couldn't be any other way. Commissioner Moscovici, on the other, came to say which countries were misbehaving and well-behaved. Mine, Portugal, by chance is already in excessive imbalance, which probably means that it is misbehaved, although it has been well behaved and has implemented all the measures that have now led precisely to the increase in unemployment and the increase in public debt.  And what is this process really different from the Troika? Nobody knows, we don't know, but we all know which parties and political groups support and legitimize this process.

name: Pascal Durand (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, commissioners, the European semester is not an end in itself. It is an instrument for the analysis of public policies that will implement objectives that are at the heart of these public policies. Far from an accounting exercise, this coordination must measure the effects on the ability to revive the economy while reducing inequality. This requires respect for the three pillars of sustainable development: the economy, the social and the environmental.  The report shows that much remains to be done. First, on tax harmonisation, on the elimination of this competition and tax dumping between states. Also in public procurement, to help SMEs, SMALLes, craftsmen through tenders that target not only low costs, but also a more sustainable economy and jobs that cannot be relocated. On the establishment of the Digital Single Market, on the development of more sustainable modes of production and consumption and, finally, on strengthening the protection of consumers and their health, especially the most vulnerable.  Ultimately, beyond our differences, this report on the governance of the single market tries to strike that balance between economic, social and environmental dimensions. That is why, on behalf of the Green Group, we will vote in favour of this report.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the six months of economic policy coordination have been characterised in recent years by a cold accounting severity, a severity with which the European Commission imposes on the Member States the application of rules often inspired by austerity instead of promoting growth. Policy coordination should, on the other hand, provide a strong opportunity for growth and not obligations and must coordinate concrete initiatives aimed at building that single market, in which all consumers are recognised with equal rights and guarantees. This is all the more so in the digital single market, because electronic transactions, particularly cross-border transactions, are becoming increasingly important.  If we want to encourage this activity, online consumers must be guaranteed a level of protection equal to that to which they are accustomed in the traditional market. In this area, which is the engine of growth, the Commission still has a lot of work to do because it has not yet been possible to bring the regulatory framework into line with and coherence. And I will end with a figure: last September's Cecchini study shows that the failure to complete the single market makes us lose EUR 651 billion.

name: Gerolf Annemans (NI).
text: Mr President, we are simply acting as if nothing has happened with the Greek change of power and no lessons are being learned. The euro highway is always going on at full speed, even though , in order to so-called harmonisation, more and more economic factors and powers have to be transferred from the Member States to the European Union in Brussels. The core problem remains undiscussed (because that is part of your euro religion), namely the principle itself of a currency zone for participants who are not equal and which are now trying to force them to become equal.  The price is paid in economic stagnation and especially social dramas in the south of Europe. There is also a lot of frustration between the southern euro countries. Spain and Portugal are not going to stand up, quite rightly, that Greece can renegotiate reform plans in exchange for even more cheap loans, while other ailing countries have not been given that chance. We are not getting out of the fog in terms of the problems with Greece and southern Europe, no, we are only now really heading towards the dense fog with a high speed. The southern crickets fight each other out of the tent and the northern ants, they toiled diligently. European policy is further separate. What an unholy paradox!

name: David Casa (PPE).
text: – Sur President, kollox ma' kollox nista' ninnota b'sodisfazzjon li r-rapport jagťmel enfasi b'saťťitha fuq elementi li huma mmirati li jagťtu nifs lit-tkabbir ekonomiku, il-σolqien tal-impjiegi f'kull strata tal-età u interess partikolari fil-progress soèjali, u dan filwaqt illi jiżi respectt il-mudell soèjali Ewropew. Min-naťa l-oťra, dawn il-prożetti ekonomiżi ambizzjużi ma jistgťux jiżu implimented fi żdan vakwu. Gťandhom jiżu implied a parallellu mal-konsolidazzjoni fiskali u l-użu ta' grad ta' flexibility fil-qasam tar-regulations tal-Patt ta' Stabilità u Tkabbir, b'enfasi partikolari fuq l-investiment soèjali fiσ-σittadin. Dan il-kunèett nemmen illi huwa kruèjali fil-ťolqien tal-impjiegi sostenibbli, inklussivi u ta' kwalità. Nilqa' b'sodisfazzjon partikolari l-miżuri different li żabbret il-Kummissjoni sabiex jiżdied drastikament il-żolqien tal-impjie fi żdan in-negozji ż-żgťar u nispera li dawn il-miżuri jiżu implimented mingťajr dewmien żejjed. Filwaqt li kulťadd huwa tal-fehma li n-negozjanti ż-żgťar huma s-sinsla tal-attività ekonomika tal-Unjoni Ewropea, dawn gťadhom sfortunatament ikunu mxekkla b'piżijiet amministrattivi żejda u burokrazija. Fid-dawl ta' dan kollu, joťroż σar li gťandu jsir aktar sabiex dan is-settur importanti tal-ekonomija jiżi assistit b'investimenti u ťolqien tal-impjiegi. Fl-aťar nett, irrid nirringrazzja lir-rapporteurs u lix-shadows kollha gťax-xogťol important li jagťmlu, b'mod partikolari lil Sofia gťax-xogťol important tagťha.

name: Jutta Steinruck (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the There is a clear link between austerity policies and rising poverty. This has also been confirmed by the independent Annual Growth Survey. Poverty and unemployment in Europe remain at historic highs. Precarious working conditions are almost the norm. European regions are drifting further apart and the imbalance in Europe is growing. Yes, we need structural reforms, but not unilateral labour market reforms at the expense of workers, but reforms that combine sustainable growth with fair, good jobs. The coordination of economic and financial policy does not work. The result: growing Euroscepticism and polemics and incitement. That needs to change. To do this, we need a strong social pillar in the European Semester. Social and employment policy needs exactly the same commitment as fiscal policy. Then we will also move on with a social Europe.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mrs Steinruck, I am very grateful to you for your description of the state of affairs, because what you have said is absolutely right: the effects of European Union policy are devastating for many Member States. Indeed, the coordination of economic and financial policy is not working. But we must also ask why. We have a set of rules that does not work, and I believe it is because equal rights no longer apply to everyone. The European Parliament has created an increasingly complex set of rules on the basis of very simple coordination rules, which has now become so opaque and confusing that the Commission can act and act as it sees fit. Look at the case of France: France has now been resonated for the fourth time. Again and again, both eyes are closed when France violates the rules of the European Semester and the Stability Pact. That is because the eurozone is no longer a stability community. We must ensure that we restore a right that is also applied, so that what is being done is right. This is lacking in the European Union.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI). Mr President, we are talking about the 2015 Annual Growth Survey. The report starts on the grounds that Europe must remain committed to the same model of the social market economy. But this model, gentlemen, has already failed. In those countries that have been implemented, not only has it not secured sustainable economic growth, but is inflating their debt in the interests of lenders. You must understand that this never-before-seen policy leads nowhere. Future generations have nothing to look forward to. No jobs, no economic growth, not even a right to the dream. Just uncertainty and debt. Debts that are not due to them, as they are not responsible for them. The responsibility lies solely with the wrong policies, which you selfishly continue to enforce and support. Greece has a new government that the Greek people trusted with its crisis. Politically we are divided by this government. As Greeks, however, we do not accept your attempt to strangle her and make her your hand, imposing your failed policy with new memoranda and new unpopular measures.  So what do you suggest? More than the medicine of destruction, more reforms, more measures and a small wish list for growth.

name: Andreas Schwab (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I have listened for a long time now, and I believe that it will be difficult to pick up on individual points. It is important to me that we take seriously the pillar of the common market governance, namely single market governance – and I think it is nice that not only Vice-President Dombrovskis, but also Commissioners Thyssen and Bie kowska are here today – that we take seriously the pillar of the common internal market that has been integrated into this European Semester. One thing is clear: as great as the difficulties in the field of social policy and in the macroeconomic view of national budgets may be, there is still considerable potential for growth in the Member States to better implement and apply European law in a uniform manner. Mr President, I would like to say this again: I think we are talking too little about this in this House, because it causes efforts on the part of the Member States, which they do not like to do, and because we do not yet have the strength to carry out appropriate monitoring of the implementation of Member States' acts. But that is actually the core task, because it actually contains real growth. I think that the report by the Committee on the Internal Market, Mr Ildiké Géll-Pelcz, points this out precisely, and I am very grateful to Mr Rosati for making this clear once again. There is considerable potential for growth for all the Member States in the European Union, and it is a pity that we find it so difficult to make better use of this easy-to-achieve objective.

name: Marita Ulvskog (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr For a number of years, the use of concepts such as automatic stabilisers, i.e. investments in public welfare systems that often sustain the vast majority of domestic demand, has been seen as a world-changing area. Now the stabilizers are back on the map and that's good, that's important. We also know that precarious jobs lead to an insecure and precarious economic recovery. Minimum security for Europe's workers will thus continue to be important. Strong and equal partners in the labour market will also be crucial for development. The organisation Oxfam recently presented a report showing that 1% of the world's richest will soon own as much as the remaining 99%. This brings great tension to our societies. Collective bargaining has proven to be a successful way of reducing inequalities in society. We therefore need to strengthen social dialogue. The European Semester must promote, in all its recommendations and instruments, minimum security as well as collective bargaining and their coverage. I therefore take particular note of the fact that both Commissioners, both Mrs Thyssen and Mr Dombrovskis, have mentioned the importance of social dialogue. We expect a lot from it.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Both Mr Rosati and Mr Prieto point to the democratic deficit in their reports. In his report, Mr Rosati calls on the Commission to put forward the necessary proposals to address the issue of democratic accountability in the application and accountability of institutions in economic governance. I do not know how the Commission would achieve this. The governance of the Single Market in the Framework of the European Semester necessarily limits the role of national parliaments in shaping Member States' budgets. This is particularly the case for debtor countries in the euro area and countries outside the euro area dependent on an influx of EU funds. It puts decisions in the hands of anonymous officials or experts, undermines democracy, living only at the level of nation states. So democracy is replaced by technocracy. In my opinion, we should move away from the view that centralisation, putting decisions in the hands of officials, even competent officials, guarantees economic rationality and democracy distorts it.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I want to begin by congratulating Mr Rosati on his report. Even though voters in my constituency do not stop me on the street and talk about macroeconomic imbalances, growth—friendly fiscal consolidation or the European Semester, they do talk to me about this crash that they have gone through, the biggest financial crash in the lifetime of the European Union, and we have to make sure that this crash never comes back.  We have to make sure that the system we put in place for economic governance is strong and robust, and I think it is crucially important that we take some ownership of the decisions that come from this process. I think, as is said in the report, we should have a longer period of time between the publication of the national plans and a debate in the Member State parliament. It is crucially important that Member States take ownership of the country—specific recommendations.  What is shown to be the case in Ireland is that where you restructure radically, where you go through an enormous crash, you can come out the other side with substantially improved growth rates. In those countries that have gone through the biggest shock, we can come out the other side with much more enhanced and restructured economies and we can get more and more people back to work. This is a fundamental part of that process in making sure that we have economies that are fit for purpose.  Finally, can I make this point – in the country—specific recommendations, public sector reform and change of public sector administration is crucial. We should use the EU budget to help countries implement those country—specific recommendations as an incentive to those countries. Many of them have gone through a very difficult period. Finally, can I say this – we have to have the same rules for everyone, big countries and small countries. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Evelyne Gebhardt (S&D).
text: Mr President, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council for his In your speech earlier, you highlighted the importance of the digital single market. I would like to make a special point about this one point. Electronic commerce, investment in broadband infrastructure, the development of digital solutions, data protection, net neutrality and security – these are keywords that must also be discussed in this context, I agree with you. However, this can only be done properly if we really put citizens, consumers and consumers at the centre of the concerns that we have to settle here. If we do not do so, we will not have a future in these areas. This is, of course, also about labour law, about social law, about all the impact that can be had on working life in this area. Dear Presidency, I have one more request: I have heard today that the Council does not want to abolish roaming charges, but is proposing a very strange solution, namely a 5-5-5 solution. I hope this is just a joke, an ulk that I've heard. Because to say that 5 minutes, 5 SMS and 5 megabytes are free of roaming charges, and then you have to pay again – so I think that is simply ridiculous. I very much hope that this is not a proposal from the Council. In any case, the European Parliament will not be able to agree to this.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt (ECR). –
text: Mr President, the single market is the central engine of the European project. It is an important tool to relaunch the economy, to create jobs and to attract investment again. But the single market is far from complete. There are also new challenges in this context that are present, such as the digital single market and the energy market.  That is why it is important that we focus on two things: we need to implement and implement existing legislation and we must ensure the quality of the new legislation, which must be clear, simple and easily applicable . By focusing more on the internal market in the context of the European semester, I hope that these priorities will be a common thread throughout the various policy areas of the European Union.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, let me first pay tribute today, on the European Day of Victims of Terrorism, to all victims in Europe, Spain, and especially in my region, in Navarra. Let the victims of terrorism know that they will always be in my memory. Back to the Semester. I will begin by thanking all the rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs for their work. In my opinion, they have done a more than reasonable job. What happened recently in Greece, with the arrival of the new government and the absence of a risk of economic contagion, shows that today we have instruments that we did not have for a few months now. Therefore, we have to be reasonably satisfied. Because one of these instruments is precisely the European Semester.  But it is not enough, ladies and gentlemen: we must continue to have instruments that allow or encourage governments to continue to make progress in fiscal consolidation processes; but above all, give governments incentives to make reforms. Because reforms, ladies and gentlemen, mean growth. My country, Spain, is an example. Having been one of the most ambitious reform countries, it is now the country that leads the growth of the euro area. Therefore, we know the recipe, we must implement it. But it is not only that, ladies and gentlemen, we must continue to give greater democratic legitimacy to this whole process of economic integration and, ultimately, political integration in which we are immersed, because without legitimacy we will not have the support of the citizens.

name: Presidente. –
text: I would now like to say that we are not going to be in a Benifei, however, I have to make a warning, that unfortunately the sitting is very late for the plenary with the votes and only five speeches will be accepted with regard to catch the eye.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the 2015 Annual Growth Survey has many often positive innovations, such as the introduction of the joint employment report, which this year accompanies the data presented in the social scoreboard. These documents demonstrate the Commission's renewed attention to the employment and social aspects of the European economy. Better late than never, you could add! It is now essential for the European Union to set in motion all its resources in order to resolve the situation described in those documents, especially with regard to unemployment, which jeopardises the European social fabric, the sustainability of economic policy and the single currency and the sustainability of the European project itself. The new approach presented by the Commission and based on the triangle of investment, structural reforms and budgetary responsibility can work if it proves to be geared towards supporting citizens in terms of wealth redistribution, job creation, territorial and social cohesion. The Oxfam report on inequality mentioned by Mrs Ulvskog shows us clear and worrying data. The investment plan we are discussing is creating a great many expectations that should not be disappointed.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE).
text: – Mr President, indeed, the European Semester has become an extremely useful tool in coordinating the economic policies of the Member States. The problems, however, as we know, arise when a number of recommendations agreed between governments and the European Commission are not carried out. One of the reasons why this is happening is that national parliaments do not really engage, from the first stage, in the process of what is called the European Semester, when, in fact, governments present to the European Commission national reform programmes and convergence or stability programmes, as appropriate. That is why national parliaments, when examining draft budgets in the autumn, end up not supporting a number of recommendations that should be reflected in national budgets. That is why I believe that national parliaments must be attracted, involved throughout the European Semester.

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is now shared by all that the main objective we must pursue is that of growth. In order to grow Europe's economies, we need to have an investment-based development plan, we need to abandon the ideology of rigour that has done so much damage, and we also need to have the place where these policies intertwine. That is why the third pillar is very important: the internal market is the place where development policies can actually be given substantial impetus. However, policies must also have some element of connection with each other and of coherence. I am sorry to have to note that the document by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs is in clear contradiction to the document contained by both the IMCO Committee and the EMPL Committee. There are new hypotheses that need to be supported, but to support them we need policies, alas, very different from those that are still indicated in the document that we are going to vote on shortly.

name: Ева Паунова (PPE).
text: – The European Union continues to face one main challenge– rapid recovery and economic growth, as well as tackling high levels of unemployment, especially among young people. This challenge requires coordinated action and responses at all levels and the European Semester in recent years has led to many positive results that have helped us overcome the crisis more quickly. Today, the determination to bring Europe back on the path of growth is stronger than ever. Our efforts must focus on all three pillars of our economic policy and, in particular, on stimulating investment. Measures in this direction are not limited to the Juncker Plan, the changes are much greater. They are related to improving the overall ecosystem of investment and business in the European Union.  Stimulating investment, whether public or private, alongside the untapped potential of the Single Market, especially in the area of network industries, will help improve competitiveness, job creation and growth. The essence of the European Semester is in coordination and synchronisation. They can be effective if we have reliable rules that apply equally to small and large Member States. It is of particular importance that Member States actively promote investment according to the fiscal space at their disposal and continue structural reforms, especially where negative demographic trends and growth are noted.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D).
text: Mr President, Ladies and Gentlemen, Commissioners, representatives of the Council, reforms have been initiated in recent months that put growth and development back at the centre of economic policies. This was also possible thanks to the commitment and determination of the political family of The European Socialists and Democrats.  Only by directly linking economic governance to the real economy will the measures taken in recent months really help to achieve sustainable and sustainable growth. We need to regain internal and international competitiveness, investing again in two directions that only apparently appear to be opposite: quality manufacturing and the new sectors of digital innovation and research. The Single European Market is still a dimension with little-exploited potential, sometimes perceived as far from the needs of society. The report approved by the IMCO Committee points the right direction to take in order for the internal market to be an instrument at the service of citizens, consumers, businesses and institutions, with the common aim of pursuing smart, sustainable and inclusive growth.

name: Esther de Lange (PPE).
text: Mr President, the European economy seems to be slowly improving. Growth is picking up. For me, that's a signal that the course is the right one. A budget that is in order, structural reforms and investments, but in that order and especially not 'or/or', because i hear that too often here 'or one or the other'. No, 'and/and', that is what Europe needs.  Of course, investment is also needed to strengthen our economy, but in such a way that we do not allow deficits and public debt to rise again at a rapid pace. That's a mistake we've made too many times in the past, we haven't used the good years enough to build buffers that we could use in the lean years that followed. We owe it to ourselves not to repeat that mistake and, more importantly, we owe it to our children not to saddle them with unsustainable debts.  And finally, this debate is also about the confidence of European citizens. That confidence is under pressure when they see that France will be given an exception time and time again for achieving the targets. Let us treat countries, small or large, equally.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the governance of the economic market is an essential element to be taken into account in the context of the European semester.  I would like to stress the importance of the new Public Procurement Directive adopted in January 2004 and of which I was the rapporteur in this Parliament. It will undoubtedly improve the governance of the single market if Member States make full use of the various options. I am thinking, in particular, of taking into account qualitative, social and environmental criteria, including the definition of the most economically advantageous offer, which will lead to inclusive growth. As I recall, public procurement accounts for 19% of the Eu's gross domestic product.  This directive also makes it possible to generalise the electronic route during the procurement procedure. We must do everything we can to promote online administration and, more generally, a real digital single market, in which citizens and consumers can take full advantage of the benefits of the digital economy.

name: Tom Vandenkendelaere (PPE).
text: Mr President, it is time we dared to name the European semester for what it really is: an opportunity. Not a tedious straitjacket or test for which we have to succeed every year, no, a real opportunity for the Member States to test their policy plans for their sustainability. The Commission's triangular approach in the annual growth analysis provides the right framework. After all, a sensible policy is a de facto multi-track policy. Investment, structural reforms and fiscal responsibility are all necessary components to create sustainable growth and jobs.  On the basis of this framework of reflection, the Commission is therefore making a very pertinent analysis of Belgium, in which it also calls for debt reduction, an ambitious tax shift, a move away from labour, an urgent approach to school drop-out and the greening of the economy, policy choices to ensure sustainable prosperity.  Finally, I am pleased that the Commission's early timing creates the space for thorough consultation with all actors, including the social partners. I call on all actors to take an active part in this and to seize this opportunity.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I cannot quite share the euphoria of the previous speaker, because that is not the way to go. The European Union is not a casperl theatre! Only 8% of the Commission's recommendations for reform are implemented by the Member States. I therefore say to the Heads of State or Government: be ashamed! There is a lack of sincerity and a lack of seriousness. 43% of the reform measures have been partially implemented and 49% have no progress at all. Ladies and gentlemen, precisely because voluntary budget coordination does not seem to be working properly, we need an EU finance minister, an EU budget policy, an EU economic and social policy and a sanction mechanism against all member states that are unwilling to reform.

name: Verónica Lope Fontagné (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I am pleased to see how employment remains at the heart of the Commission's programme. I strongly support the three pillars on which the guidelines for this year are focused, as they are based on each other. In order for growth, and above all job creation, to be the end result, investment momentum needs to be accompanied by necessary structural reforms and long-term budgetary responsibility. It is essential today that Parliament expresses its voice clearly and forcefully so that our citizens know that, despite the great difficulties they have faced in recent years, they are our main objective, as it is time to prioritise social areas. The data and forecasts that are coming to light in recent months are clear. The recovery is beginning to consolidate and not only is the Union expected to grow and create jobs as a whole in the coming years, but the countries with the greatest problems, as is unfortunately mine, are expected to do so at an even higher rate, as evidenced by the winter forecasts. In fact, at the moment, one in two Europeans in the euro area who are leaving unemployment does so in Spain. However, it is not enough. We will not be able to be satisfied until unemployment is clearly reduced, citizens notice recovery, credit is provided to SMEs or work mobility is improved.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI).
text: Mr President, while fiscal consolidation in the euro area countries is far from over, the European institutions have still not understood that it is the austere corset that prevents any sustainable recovery and parallel reduction in unemployment.  The Commission is relying only on the saving fall of the euro, which until yesterday was supposed to be catastrophic, and the price of oil to keep the economies of European countries out of the water and boost employment. But it may not last. While the unemployment rate, particularly among the youngest and least qualified, has soared in France and the countries of the South, the proposed measures do not hide the disempowerment at the consequences of the actions that the Commission cherishes.  The Youth Employment Initiative and the Youth Guarantee are cauteries on a wooden leg, which do not adequately address key issues such as training and low qualifications for workers. With the unemployment rate in the euro area at 11.5% compared to only 7.3% outside the euro area, the European Union is casting a modest veil on the real debates to be waged on the single currency and on intelligent protectionism.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I use my minute to list the four main causes of this crisis.  One, the different policies pushed by the Member States, which then lead to fiscal dumping and social dumping. The Council is full of hypocrisy and a move should be made. Two, the euro, a fixed exchange rate link between nineteen different countries, which is favouring German exports: 217 billion surpluses, 7 % in 2014 and not the first year. We also apply the rules with the strong and not just with the weak. Depressive fiscal policies that kill and depress weak economies; monetary policies made by the ECB not to support the thousands of micro-enterprises that are failing in some countries but to support strategic plans of banks and lobbies, to do business and share the market. We must be ashamed of these things.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, it is clear that the financial management rules in force in Europe are unrealistic. The Maastricht Treaty requirement for public debt not exceeding 60% of Gross National Product is not met by almost any Member State. The requirements of the Financial Stability Pact which are supposed to complement these objectives are also met only by five Member States. In essence, the European institutions commit national governments to pursuing utopian objectives in order to impose austerity, not as a means of combating over-indebtedness, but rather as a means of bringing about a violent social redistribution by the have-nots at European level. This policy is deadlocked and if it does not change it will destroy, it will derail European unification.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, the European Semester is an institutional way of limiting the national sovereignty of the Member States of the Union. The parliaments of the countries of the Union now lack sovereign rights in shaping national budgets, as the Eurogroup, an unelected body, has made them a tight corset by imposing mercely austerity. At the same time, the Commission and the Eurogroup apply double standards. Thus, while they are treating France and granting it exemptions, at the same time they are continuing to pursue a blackmail policy towards the poor Greek people.  Ladies and gentlemen, the dominant element today in relation to the European Semester is the huge democratic deficit it has created in the name of reducing budget deficits. Thus, through an undemocratic institutional framework, Europe's old political world is trying to chain peoples and impose on them the policy of mercelial austerity, poverty and social exclusion.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the S&D Group has been in the frontline in the struggle for a new flexible approach to economic policies. This report clearly reflects the result of our clear position and our united stand against austerity. The report clearly welcomes the new approach, which focuses on investment and growth in Europe, as opposed to the policies led by the former Barroso Commission. I am especially satisfied by the recognition that the adjustment burden in the EU must be shared between deficit and surplus countries. It is clear that the southern countries of Europe affected by the recession cannot bear the entire cost of the reforms. This report fully expresses the principle of solidarity and balance among Member States by recommending more investment by surplus countries in deficit countries.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, as has already been recognised in the joint employment report, the proportion of NEETs and early school leavers is still dangerously high in the EU. Similarly, structural unemployment has been increasing and labour market matching has worsened in many Member States, resulting in millions of unfilled vacancies, especially in the IT sector. I believe that the Prieto report adequately takes these problems into account and I hope that our calls on the Commission and Member States to set right these imbalances will be duly taken into consideration. The solution lies in education systems that are better adapted to economic needs and that can engage students. Also, in order to improve labour market mobility across sectors, investment must be made in continuous skills development and vocational training. However, in order to secure responsible economic governance, such supportive measures should not be exempt from fiscal and consolidation rules. (Applause)

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice—President of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank you for this very interesting and fruitful debate here today. The Parliament has an important role in the debate on European economic policies and I have carefully taken note of the remarks and points raised today. While we can certainly say that Europe is starting to recover from a deep economic and financial crisis and while we are expecting all 28 EU Member States to have positive economic growth this year, our concern is weak recovery and slow job creation. This is a concern which we need to address through the means of the European macroeconomic policy. While different views and opinions were expressed today during the debate, I am pleased to see that many MEPs largely share our integrated approach on economic policy based on investment, structural reforms and a growth—friendly, fiscally—responsible policy. The Commission welcomes Parliament’s contribution to the European Semester by way of its regular and timely reports, such as those which we have been discussing today. I believe we share the same goals of promoting growth and job creation and I look forward to good cooperation with Parliament in the future as regards European macroeconomic governance.

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President and honourable Members, the debate on the European Semester is an important one and we had here today a very substantial one. The amount of work invested in this process by the Commission, the European Parliament and the Council is clear evidence of this.  Given that the debate is overrunning, I will make only a couple of very short remarks. Concerning the report by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON), prepared by Mr Rosati, I am glad that it supports the three—pillar approach of the Annual Growth Survey and the streamlining of the European Semester. As concerns the report by the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO), the Council shares the view of the need to further deepen the single market. More than 20 years after its creation, the single market is still far from complete. More work should be invested towards achieving this goal.  In response to the remarks made by the rapporteur of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (EMPL), Mr Prieto, I would like to say that the Council does recognise the importance of the social dimension of the European Semester. Only two days ago, the EPSCO Council discussed, among other things, such issues as reducing the tax wage on labour, ensuring an adequate level of social protection, and the need to strengthen efforts to fight poverty, social exclusion and inequality. The conclusions adopted by the EPSCO Council provide an important political orientation to our further work. Let me also mention that the lessons—learned exercises that we have conducted, on the Council side, on previous European Semesters recommend further stepping—up of the involvement of political level representatives, including national parliaments, in the European Semester at the national level. I welcome the work you have done in intensifying the interparliamentary dialogue which facilitates the work of national parliaments in this regard. The European Semester is an evolving tool. We have to keep improving its effectiveness as well as its accountability aspect, while also acknowledging that these go further and that they go together. We look forward to continuing the debate with Parliament on how to improve this Semester and the following ones. The Presidency will put all its energy in ensuring an effective European Semester for 2015. The recommendations that will emerge this summer should reflect our common goals and the main challenges of each country. Most importantly, they should be ‘owned’ by the Member States, who will be responsible for putting them into effect.  I would like to use this opportunity to thank the rapporteurs and the shadow rapporteurs for the hard work. I believe that the discussion is not over. It shall continue at various levels, for example on 13 March the Transport Council will discuss their contribution to the Synthesis Report. Continuous involvement by the European Parliament is very instrumental. Thank you for this debate and the fruitful exchange of views. I shall stop here so as not to delay the voting.

name: Dariusz Rosati
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, let me first express my thanks for the debate we have had in this House: I would like to express my thanks to all the colleagues who participated in the debate and especially to the shadow rapporteurs, with whom I had very fruitful cooperation throughout the whole period of preparing the report. Of course, we did not agree on everything, but I appreciated their readiness to find reasonable compromises. Now, on the debate, I would like to refer briefly to three points. The first is the recurring theme of austerity. Many colleagues complained that austerity is creating ruin in their countries’ social models. Well, let me remind you once again that austerity measures were simply a necessary reaction, a necessary adjustment to the excessive spending in the period before the crisis. All those countries which had irresponsible budget policies had, of course, to make some cuts, and that is nothing to complain about. Those countries which were prudent in their budgetary policies have not had to resort to austerity. The second point I would like to refer to is the social cost involved in these structural reforms. I very much share the view that there have been social costs involved with fiscal consolidation and reforms. Nevertheless, we have to remember that if wages were growing at a pace much higher than productivity before the crisis, then there is a need for those wages to come down. So we should not be surprised that, in some countries, wages and incomes have had to come down, simply in order to stay in line with productivity. Lastly, as to the point about bureaucrats in Brussels who allegedly imposed restrictions on our countries: this is simply not true. All the Member States agreed on the fiscal rules, and the bureaucrats in Brussels are merely responsible for enforcing them.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz
text: Artist. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. Those who were present at the debate are obviously of the same opinion, which I am expressing, that it was very useful and gave us the opportunity to discuss the proposals contained in the report. At the same time, this debate has highlighted the need for further coordination efforts, for example specifically in the area of internal market integration. We have so much legislation in this area, and they are so convoluted that it is difficult to transpose. This transposition is not only a matter of quantity, but also of quality. Therefore, let us not be reluctant to use indicators that are capable of showing quality transposition. On the other hand, the issue of control and governance. It is very important that if we pass legislation, take measures, then everyone should be equal and not equal and equal. You can't be too big not to be subject to the rules. We cannot apply double standards. As far as the key areas are concerned, I have listed a number of these in my report, but I would like to focus on one: this is a question of the digital internal market, which I believe is the most important task ahead of us. However, believe me, fellow Members, that the generations that grew up in front of computers do not understand why we are talking about the digital internal market when this internal market is so fragmented and we are not taking action to do so. Madam Secretary, I don't understand you either. I do not understand how the Bureau may not feel that the abolition of roaming charges is important for us to build this digital internal market. I don't understand why we're pushing it back to 2018. I call on the Commissioner, Mr Vice-President, to take into account our recommendations in the reports for the forth to be drawn up in the following reports.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, thank you all for taking part in this debate. I will recall some data from the European Commission itself: the annual growth rate in the European Union as a whole last year was slightly higher than 0%; in 2014, long-term unemployment rose in the European Union by 4 points. 75% of youth unemployment is now long-term unemployment. One in four households in Europe lives at risk of social exclusion. The question is whether we can be conformists with this data. If there is anyone who believes that with this data we do not have to do more and faster to, precisely, turn around a social reality that becomes unbearable for many European citizens. I agree with the change in the european Commission's line of economic and social policy, but we need it to be more ambitious and fairer. We say yes, that we agree with investment, but that they must go to the regions, to the places where there are the most macroeconomic imbalances and where the highest unemployment rate occurs.  That there has to be fiscal responsibility, but, Mr Rosati, fiscal responsibility - he has told us so to the International Monetary Fund, until the OECD - cannot be excessive austerity. It has to be compatible with economic growth and job creation. That fiscal responsibility must be applied using the greater margins of flexibility established by the Stability and Growth Pact so as not to drown in recession. We need fiscal responsibility but above all, I remember, social responsibility. Social responsibility because structural reforms cannot become a mantra in which everything enters. Social responsibility to end the wage devaluation that has pushed millions of workers today to live below the poverty line because their wages do not allow them to live with dignity. 50% of the employment created today, according to the European Commission, is not employment that can take these workers out of active poverty or labour poverty. Therefore, we have to change. Change to make a society fairer. Change to make economic growth compatible with the European social model we stand for.

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. – According to this year's European economic growth forecasts, the high unemployment rate will continue to be high. This shows that fundamental structural reforms in the economic and social areas are struggling. I support the investment promotion plan put forward by the President of the Commission, but it should not be seen as an alternative to the necessary reforms, but an additional instrument that will allow funds to be allocated to projects with European and economic and social returns. The creation of a single energy market and the promotion of energy independence in EU countries must be accelerated. The creation of an energy union is very important. It would make Member States more competitive and resilient to political pressure from third countries.

name: Guillaume Balas (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Parliament votes on the 2015 annual growth review, a comprehensive analysis document initiating the European semester to coordinate economic policies in Europe.  The division of powers between the various parliamentary committees leaves me dubious. Indeed, the report on employment and social aspects in the annual growth review provides a lucid analysis of the disastrous consequences of the austerity policies that have plagued the peripheral countries of the Union, as well as the accelerated fiscal consolidation measures that have broken the mechanics of recovery.  I welcome the excellent work done by socialist rapporteur Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto, who convinced a majority of parliamentarians to support a plan to combat dumping and tax evasion and to call for an ambitious tax on financial transactions.  On the other hand, the report of the Committee on Economic Affairs takes the opposite of this analysis, referring to the "success" of the troika's programmes in Greece, Portugal and Ireland, while calling on other states to show the same ambition in modernising their economies... The troika's record is disastrous: economic recession, soaring unemployment and a significant increase in debt.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because, when we talk about the impact of structural reforms, we obviously have to take a societal approach. For the Union's economic policies are also ruthless social indicators for disadvantaged groups.  I quote two recent examples provided by Eurostat: (i) 120 million people - one in four Europeans - are at risk of poverty; (ii) more than one in two people with disabilities - or 40 million Europeans - are unemployed, which is a 26% difference from people without disabilities! Clearly, inequality has widened in recent years in the Union as a result of austerity policies, and this must of course be recalled in the European semester report on the coordination of economic policies.  Structural measures can no longer contribute to this human setback. Today, massive investment in job creation and socially blind sanitation must be stopped. Not to mention, of course, the absolute need for a determined fight against fraud and tax evasion, and the necessary tax shift from labour to capital and not to consumption as suggested in the report. For proponents of structural reforms, these are great priorities!

name: Ivo Belet (PPE)
text: Written. – Mr President, the European Semester was set up to make the objectives of Europe 2020 a success. In order to lay the foundations for strong and above all sustainable growth, we must have the ambition to give the Semester not only an economic, but also a full social interpretation. This can be done by investing in employment and social protection and combating social fraud and dumping. It must remain our ambition that every worker has quality work and social protection. A strong social market economy, based on a full-fledged social dialogue, is also the basis for an effective response to the crisis. Social investment and structural reforms are not mutually separate, on the contrary.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – It is futile to discuss the proposed aims for the European Semester in 2015, when the Commission unremittingly refuses to acknowledge the underlying structural and economic problems which the two-pack and six-pack reforms pose. Reading through the aims of the Commission for the 2015 European Semester, the focus is supposedly to avoid economic boom and bust cycles, and aimed at restoring economic growth to the EU. However there is no mention of equitable growth and poverty reduction. It shows a clear disconnect between European bureaucrats and the reality that is facing millions of struggling working families in Ireland and right across the EU.  The primary aim of the European Semester reforms seems to be just to ensure that Member States do not deviate from the economic neo-liberal ideology that it is pushing. It does not leave Member States with flexibility to implement alternative policies, which would be pro-investment, pro-growth, pro-jobs. In effect it is working to deny both Irish and other EU citizens real political choices when electing their governments and is further eroding sovereignty and reducing economic independence.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I support Parliament's strong call for a specific internal market pillar to be set in the European Semester. The aim is to better support the real economy and boost growth and employment. It will also highlight the Digital Single Market, the free movement of goods, services, public procurement and concessions, and the consumer acquis as key areas with the greatest growth potential. As regards the assessment of the integration of the internal market, it proposes the development of an overall indicator to better measure the 'internal market gap' and the regulatory performance of Member States.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. – Europe must implement a responsible policy, focused on investment and the creation of quality jobs, in order to ensure sustainable growth and to leave jobs and not debt to the next generation. The labour market is marked by significant inequalities in working conditions, and it is women who are most at risk of living in poverty or social exclusion after the age of 55. On the other hand, women-run entrepreneurship and SMEs face more problems in gaining access to finance and, as such, viable solutions are needed to overcome these obstacles. We must not forget that poverty reduction is not only one of the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, but also a social responsibility for the Member States, and creating decent and sustainable jobs is the best solution to get out of poverty.

name: Damian Drăghici (S&D)
text: in writing. – Currently, around 25.1% of the EU population is at risk of poverty or social exclusion. I believe that tailored policies need to be developed to support the creation of quality jobs for long-term unemployed people, the unemployed and other groups hit hard by the crisis, such as immigrants, the Roma community and people with disabilities, many of whom face the risk of social exclusion. The proportion of young people who are not in employment and who do not follow any educational or training programmes has remained high among the Roma population.  I believe that promoting employment opportunities for Roma citizens in the Member States through skills and qualifications to combat discrimination, as well as promoting job creation through self-employment and entrepreneurship, can lead to easier integration into the labour market, poverty reduction and adequate social protection. Member States must guarantee access to the labour market for the most vulnerable members of society.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The first lines of the introduction to the Annual Growth Survey 2015 read as follows: ‘Having come through the worst financial and economic crisis in generations, the EU has done a lot to create the foundations for more sound and sustainable growth in the future’. It begs the question – what planet do those people live on? Seven years into this crisis and far from ʽhaving come throughʼ, we have lurched from one emergency to another, with the Commission/Council/various Eurogroups/ECB all combining to come up with one ʽfixʼ after another, many of those fixes then making matters worse, not better. We are still in crisis: the Juncker Plan and the QE programme the latest sure-fire ʽfixesʼ concocted by the institutions. When will you learn? What will it take for you to see that the medicine again being prescribed for us all in this Semester is what is actually killing the patient? It is now as plain as day – austerity and all the neoliberal policies imposed on struggling countries is not working! Please understand, you are dealing with real people, real poverty, real pain; in persevering with these policies you deal out more real poverty, more real pain. This is madness, pure and simple.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. – The coordination of economic policies at EU level must lead to a reduction in regional disparities, job creation in high unemployment areas and an increase in per capita incomes in low-income countries. We cannot talk about an economic and monetary union as long as there are major differences between Member States. I believe that Mr Juncker's investment plan is necessary, but the way in which I am announced is concerned. Without taking into account the specific situation on the ground, without having a geographical distribution of funds, social problems will be created which will have a boomerang effect on Europe. The creation of an investment fund without a concrete mechanism to support SMEs - which are only mentioned in all documents - will lead to a concentration of capital in large companies. Nothing concrete has been done to protect the EU market from unfair competition. I conclude by saying that, in addition to strategies, we need to have concrete measures. There are countries that have citizens living on the edge of poverty. The Commission has a duty to implement the investment programme in such a way as to mitigate the effects of the economic crisis and to increase the standard of living of all citizens of Europe.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. I fully supported the structure of the Gutierrez-Prieto report on employment and social aspects in the analysis of 2015 growth, within the framework of the European Semester. I agree with the rapporteur that the EU's economic and social situation continues to be bleak, due to 1) negative growth rates, which seriously cast doubt on the achievement of the OBJECTIVES of the EU 2020 Strategy, particularly in the eurozone countries; (2) the high proportion of the European population at risk of poverty, unsustainable levels of underemployment and precariousness; (3) the widening of socio-economic imbalances which have widen the gap between the centre and periphery of Europe, to such an extent as to jeopardize the achievement of the convergence of the less developed regions, and with it the fundamental objective of socio-economic and territorial cohesion. It is therefore necessary for the Council and the Commission to focus on the importance of labour market reforms, to expand growth potential, human capital and increase productivity, through measures to support the creation of quality jobs, particularly for the groups most affected by the crisis, the promotion of long-term investment, the inclusion of a gender pillar within the framework of the Europe 2020 strategy , the creation of a European platform for undeclared work.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing – I am pleased that members of the Committee on Budgets have supported nine of my amendments, which are part of the whole resolution that we will be voting on today in the plenary of the European Parliament. Among them, an amendment that, as a matter of principle, changes the way the European budget is financed. The existing system of own resources is complex, unfair and incomprehensible to citizens. The fiscal situation of Member States can be alleviated by means of a new own resources system which will reduce current national contributions based on gross national income. This will save these Member States money and allow them to make consolidation efforts without jeopardising EU funding. That is why, as the Committee on Budgets, we give great importance to the High Level Group on Own Resources and support the debate on the new own resources system, which should lead to a real reform of EU funding while not increasing the tax burden on citizens. I trust that the European Parliament, the Commission and the Council will take appropriate steps to follow up on the final report of that group in order to accelerate the creation and launch of a new era of real resources.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D)
text: Writing. – The conservative-neoliberal economic policy, whose rigid austerity has been pursued at the expense of the citizens, has failed. There can be no effective social policy if economic policy is fundamentally at odds with it. That is why a reorientation of EU economic policy – and thus economic governance – with greater involvement of the social dialogue is imperative for positive developments in the social and economic spheres. The growing investment gap is currently estimated at EUR 230-370 billion. This makes it all the more important that we actively support President Juncker's investment plan, especially Member States with balance sheet surpluses, who need to show more initiative through investment. Public investment, particularly in areas such as services of general interest or social housing, is crucial here and should therefore be excluded from the deficit calculation. In employment policy in particular, we are facing major challenges, which have been drastically exacerbated by the crisis: in 2014, 50% of all new jobs created were fixed-term contracts – social dumping and increasing precarious employment models are just two of the problems that workers face today. Our task in the European Union is to help EU citizens out of the crisis and to relieve them of the burden through progressive economic policies. Macro-social indicators must at last be given the same importance as the macroeconomic criteria in order to alleviate the social crisis.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. – I was very pleased to note that the three reports address a number of issues that really affect the future of Europe. I, too, believe that the extension of the internal market is an instrument that really serves the interests of European citizens. I have said it many times, but I am confirming now that strengthening the digital internal market and supporting education of the right quality and well-functioning is essential to keep the Union competitive. Nevertheless, I would now like to focus on another issue, structural reforms. Nowadays, the best-intentioned structural reform also seems to be a scolding, as on many occasions it has been very flawed to implement them. Structural reforms should only be carried out in a socially balanced form, while protecting citizens at the same time. It should also be underlined here that, in my view, Member States should not only create high-paying but sustainable and high-quality jobs in all respects. Practices based on the exploitation of workers and the worse bargaining power of workers resulting from the economic crisis must be prevented.  Finally, I would like to draw attention once again to the fact that, in addition to tax avoidance, tax evasion and tax provisions that are also against good will, the European Union and the Member States must also combat overtranment. It is unacceptable that there are Member States in Europe that also charge 27% VAT on basic foodstuffs, not to mention additional charges.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. – Seven years after the beginning of the financial crisis, Europeʼs economic recovery is still fragile. With high unemployment rates of nearly 25 million people across the EU, with 75 % of long-term unemployed persons under 35 years old, reinforcement of the employment and social aspects of the European Semester and Annual Growth Survey is fundamental to our economic recovery and social well-being of our citizens.  The current report calls on the EU to shift its policies in the areas of employment and social policy towards growth-led policies which focus on the creation of quality jobs in Europe in sustainable industries. The report also highlights numerous key points in this area, which include among other: reshaping policies to ensure the delivery of the Europe 2020 targets, stepping up the fight against inequality, and introducing a minimum income scheme throughout the EU. The report also refers to the need to take radical measures to combat youth unemployment. In this context, I welcome the request to ensure an adequate budget for the Youth Guarantee in the Multiannual Financial Framework review.  Improving the employment and social conditions of our citizens will allow us to deliver them a fairer and more inclusive socioeconomic reality, thus I welcome the adoption of the report.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. – The 2015 Annual Growth Survey analyses the economic situation more clearly than previous Commission opinions. Weaknesses in financial markets, over-indebtedness or structural deficits are identified. The Commission is desperately calling for change at national level and for responsibility to be taken. Unfortunately, the Commission's praise for the ECB's current balance sheet expansion follows by buying huge quantities of partly dubious securities. The OECD's latest growth report notes a marked decline in the will to reform in the EU. As a result, after the height of the crisis, many governments have shown a high willingness to reform, which then, as a result of the ECB's discharge, has clearly diminished. In addition to expropriating savers, the ECB is above all slowing down the speed of reform and the will to reform in Europe and postponing problems into the future! The Commission's hope that the Member States will tackle fundamental problems in parallel with ECB activity is therefore highly doubtful. The Juncker package is also likely to mask problems in the short term and strengthen the unwillingness to reform. In the meantime, there is often a helpless and resigned accept at European level that a 'lost generation' has arisen, and a clear analysis of the causes is still often refused. This will damage not only the foundations of the eurozone and the European Union, but even the foundations of societies.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D)
text: Written. – With regard to the European semester, one thing is very clear: the need for a social and binding component. After all, in order to meet the targets on poverty reduction, combating inequality and unemployment formulated in the Europe 2020 strategy, Member States need to be encouraged to step up. The European semester with its exclusive focus on binding macroeconomic indicators does not currently do so.
