Member States that score well in macroeconomic terms but at the same time have high (childhood) poverty or inequality are regarded as 'good' pupils, while Member States that are able to produce a worse macroeconomic report but make efforts and achieve results in areas of child poverty, employment for target groups, inequality, women's participation in the labour market, etc. score poorly in the European semester.  It is true that a social scoreboard has been included since 2014, but its non-commitment, including the lack of binding recommendations, does not encourage Member States to implement them. So my plea is simple and clear: put the social indicators at the same level as macroeconomics. This is an important step towards the realisation of a social Union, which is so demanded by the citizens.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D)
text: Writing. The European single market is the Union's greatest economic policy achievement. It provides companies with a 'home market' of 500 million consumers and gives these consumers uniform rights and cross-border protection. The functioning of the Internal Market is an important pillar of the European Semester and a guarantee of growth and competitiveness. The crisis has caused us to experience distortions and distortions of competition in the internal market, and it is to be welcomed that all the major groups have recognised that we cannot leave the internal market to our own devices. The market also needs barriers, regulations and regulation. I support the call in this report for the european semester to introduce an annual 'internal market governance' cycle. The Single Market must also adapt to the realities of the digital age in order to fully exploit the economic and innovative potential of the Digital Single Market. We must also ensure that the social, environmental and consumer protection standards of the internal market cannot be undermined by trade or investment agreements.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: in writing. – In my opinion, economic policy coordination is essential for the EU's economic growth, so I would like to call on the Member States to cooperate more closely, and I would like this cooperation to take place intensively between the European Parliament and national parliaments. I would also like to appeal for a review of the MFF by the new Parliament in order to give it new political legitimacy. In the context of the EU budget, I would like to mention the 2 problems that we have been facing for a long time. One is the failure to respect the principle of budgetary regularity, which, like all national budgets, applies to the EU budget. If we as the EU want to set an example, we must respect this principle. It is not possible that the commitments we have made are not covered by sufficient resources. And the second issue that is plaguing the whole EU is tax evasion. By failing to address this problem in the long term, our budgets are losing significant resources. Here I would like to express my great confidence in the newly established Special Committee of the European Parliament to tackle unfair tax practices. I believe his work will be very rewarding.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. – The European Union and its institutions have been adopting measures and procedures which are considered to be tax-free for an intelligent reading of the Budgetary Treaty. The main measure of these measures has as its main assessment measure their impact on the European Semester, i.e. in the guidelines for Member States' budgetary policy, with a particular focus on the preparation of national budgets for 2016. In this context, in addition to an intelligent reading of the Budgetary Treaty, an intelligent reading of what has been called structural reforms associated with the budgetary procedure is crucial. The European Union has failed in the synergistic link between financial reforms and economic reforms. It is a priority to complete the architecture of the Economic and Financial Union and to extend the spectrum of so-called structural reforms. It is not enough to reform the labour market and reduce the perimeter of public policy intervention to ensure fiscal consolidation, debt reduction and economic and employment growth. Deep reforms are needed in the justice, health, education and economic specialisation systems, not through financial cuts, but through strategic choices and efficient allocation of resources needed for the context to favor growth and jobs. ***

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: Mr President, my motion is also based on articles 11, 12, 186 and Schedule 11 of our regulations.  Indeed, when I arrived in Strasbourg, my colleagues, our assistants and I were stunned to learn from the press that President Schulz was publicly implicating us, just days before the French elections, in the most hostile media, asking his friend, the French Socialist Minister of Justice to prosecute us before the European Office's investigation had even begun... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Presidente. –
text: I am sorry, Mr Gollnisch, I respect your protest, but that is not, under Rule 164, a personal statement. Thank you.

name: President. –
text: We will move to the vote. Mr Gollnisch, you have heard the Vice-President’s ruling. You may make a remark if somebody has made a comment today in the Chamber and on that basis only.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: Madam President, in this case, I am abandoning the motion for personal fact (Article 164) to agree with your interpretation. On the other hand, I ask for the floor for a minute for a motion of order and I can tell you exactly what my motion of order is based on: the relevant articles of the regulation ... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: President. –
text: The next item is the vote.

name: Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I wanted to take advantage of the house being full to recall that today is The European Day of Victims of Terrorism, coinciding with the eleventh of March, when in Spain, in Madrid, these terrible attacks took place. I wanted to tell you simply, and very quickly, that terrorism kills some of us to terrorize us all. And any of us can be victims of terrorism. (Applause)

name: President. –
text: Thank you for that important point.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to make a point of order concerning the racist behaviour of a Member of this House, who called the Roma people 'scum of society' in a television broadcast seen by millions of people. I would like to ask the Presidency of this House whether, under the Rules of Procedure, action can be taken against what I have to call Mr Buonanno who made these statements.

name: President. –
text: Could I clarify for the House ... (Interjection from Mr Gollnisch, protesting about his earlier point of order) Mr Gollnisch, would you please resume your seat. I have something to say and perhaps you would listen with respect. The President has already made an announcement about the television broadcast. He does not have a remit over what is said outside this Chamber and I think that is particularly clear. Thank you for raising the issue, Ms Forenza. Now, colleagues, we can proceed to the vote ... (Interjection from Mr Gollnisch, protesting about his point of order; the National Front Members banged the lids of their desks.) Mr Gollnisch, could I ask you to listen for one moment. I am going to ask the services to clarify directly with you about your issue of a point of order. I am very clear about this point. Would you then please be respectful to the House. (Applause from the National Front) Now, colleagues, I will open the vote.

name: James Carver (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, you gave us the wrong number on that last vote.

name: President. –
text: That concludes the vote. ***

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: Madam President, I note that you have given the floor for motions of order on matters which had nothing to do with Parliament's rules, nothing to do with the debates of this morning, including to impees one of the parliamentarians in this House, and that, while I was telling you very precisely on what point of the regulation I was setting out my motion of order. , you have given me a rather astonishing investigation. So let's get to the fact. When I arrived in Strasbourg, my colleagues, our assistants and I were stunned to learn from the press that President Schulz was publicly implicating us, just days before the French elections, in the most hostile media, asking his friend, the French Socialist Minister of Justice, to prosecute us, even before the investigation of the European Anti-Fraud Office that he had seized. In violation of all the principles of parliamentary law and practice, he did not even deign to hear us before making these accusations public. In violation of Schedule XI relating to internal investigations, including Article 2, paragraph 4, he deliberately breached the confidentiality requirement imposed on him.  In violation of Article 5 of the same schedule, he breached the duty to inform us. In violation of Article 2, paragraph 4, it subjects us to unfair and discriminatory treatment, because if it considered the situation of parliamentary assistant and political responsibilities within a party to be incompatible, it should subject all Members and assistants to investigation, starting with his socialist friends, since a quick and superficial examination has already revealed nine assistants among his political friends holding an important political function. In thirty years of parliamentary life, I have never seen a Speaker of assembly behave in such a biased and partisan manner. (Applause)

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. With the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, an alignment exercise was carried out with Amnibus I and II to ensure that all previous comitology and ad hoc decision-making procedures relating to trade policy are in line with the new system of delegated acts and implementing acts. This Commission proposal is a continuation of this work, with the recasting of Regulation (EC) No 625/2009 on common import rules for certain third countries. In this case, the main change is to remove from the annex countries that are already members of the WTO such as Armenia, Russia, Tajikistan and Vietnam. Since it is a technical report I voted in favour.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Due to the fact that the purpose of this regulation is technical, i.e. to adapt and update the decision-making procedure in this case, I voted in favour.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The Commission proposal concerns the codification and recasting of Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. In the case of the common system of imports from certain third countries, these are mainly necessary technical corrections. As the Committee on Legal Affairs has given a positive opinion, I am voting in favour of its adoption.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. Following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, a corresponding adjustment has been made in the area of trade policy to the comitology and ad hoc decision-making procedures in force up to that time. These have been adapted to the new system of delegated and implementing acts. This was done by Omnibus I (implementing acts) and Omnibus II (delegated acts), which amended some regulations in the field of trade, including Regulation (EC) No 625/2009 of 7 July 2009 on the common regime for imports from certain third countries. In the course of these adjustments, the Commission discovered a number of errors that should be rectified. It was considered necessary to convert the codification into a recast in order to take account of some substantive changes. This is very welcome.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. If there are some positive points in this text, such as reasoned protectionism or safeguards and surveillance measures, this is a timid first step towards protecting our industries and our production. Any brake on ultra-liberalism and blind free trade is to be encouraged as it calls into question a system in which nation states no longer have freedoms.   Nevertheless, there are some weaknesses in this text. There is never any mention of the national level or at least the national freedom to promote domestic products. Considering that the nation-state is the only echelon capable of guaranteeing the economic functioning of a society, I could not vote in favour of this text. Leaving the possibility for the Union to protect European industries is not enough: it is essential to give Member States priority on these issues and to leave them free to carry out their national economic policies.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this because it was a technical amendment.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because it is limited to an outright codification of existing acts, without altering their substance.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on common rules for imports from certain third countries. The purpose of the proposal is to codify existing texts without changing their substance.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. Opposed to this common regime for imports from certain third countries, I logically voted against this report which promotes it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. This is the codification and redesign of the regulation on the common regime for imports from certain third countries. This exercise allows the Commission to rectify several technical errors and the main change in the overhaul concerns the updating of the annex of the regulation, from which the countries that have since become members of the WTO, namely Armenia, Russia, Tajikistan and Vietnam, have been withdrawn.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This report deals with the codification of Regulation (EC) No. 625/2009 of the Council of 17 July 2009 establishing a common export regime. In particular, this report updates the list of states concerned by removing those that have since become members of the WTO.  This regulation certainly introduces more transparency and intelligibility under EU law and recalls the possibilities of monitoring or safeguarding measures against products from a limited number of third countries. Nevertheless, it remains questionable, since it is closely linked to the fact that the Union represents a vast internal market, a free trade area without borders, even as the number of customs barriers in many third countries to EU exports increases. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal concerning codification and recasting (most of them technical corrections) of Regulation (EC) No 625/2009 on the common arrangements applicable to imports from certain third countries. These are not, incidentally, countries that can pose a danger to our production sector.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. For the sake of simplification and clarity of EU law, in order to make it more accessible and understandable to the citizen, I voted in favour of the codification and recasting of Regulation (EC) No 625/2009 on the common regime applicable to imports from certain third countries. This Regulation, which currently applies only to a limited number of countries: Azerbaijan, Belarus, Kazakhstan, North Korea, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan, has been substantially amended through various legislative acts in recent years and, in order to improve clarity and easy understanding of the legislative text, all these provisions should be recast into a new Regulation, respecting the content of the codified texts and making only the relevant formal amendments. As regards the substance, only the Annex to the Regulation is updated to remove the reference to a certain number of third countries that have acceded to the World Trade Organization, namely Armenia, Russia, Tajikistan and Vietnam.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report on common rules for imports from certain third countries. The regulation proposed by the Commission provides for safeguard and surveillance measures which may be applied to imports of products, including coal and steel, but excluding textile products covered by a separate Regulation. The Regulation applies only to a limited number of countries, namely Azerbaijan, Belarus, Kazakhstan, North Korea, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan. The protection measure is rarely used in practice, and as far as supervision is concerned, the last surveillance measure covered steel products and expired on 31 December 2012. The fundamental change in the recast regulation concerns the renewal of the Annex by deleting countries that have now become members of the World Trade Organisation – Armenia, Russia, Tajikistan and Vietnam.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The Commission proposal is limited only to codifying existing acts without changing them significantly, so I support the accompanying resolution.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I consider that the regime of common rules for imports from certain third countries can help improve economic relations with those countries, which can help strengthen the European economy.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. The report discusses the codification of Regulation (EC) 625/2009 of the Council of 17 July 2009 establishing a common export regime. This codification is done on a constant basis without changing the substance of the provisions that will be included in it.  It updates the list of third countries to which the regulation applies, removing those that have since joined the WTO.  If this regulation is questionable, since it reminds us that the European Union represents an internal market without borders, it is a measure of transparency and intelligibility of EU law.  It also recalls the possibility of taking surveillance or safeguarding measures against products from a limited number of third countries under certain conditions which we consider to be far too restrictive.  That is why I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because, following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, a process of alignment has taken place and must ensure that previous committee procedures and ad hoc decision-making on trade policies have aligned with the new regime of delegated and implementing acts. The scope establishes safeguard and surveillance instruments which may be applied to imports of products, including coal and steel, but excluding textiles, which are subject to a separate regulation. This Regulation applies only to a limited number of countries, namely Azerbaijan, Belarus, Kazakhstan, North Korea, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan. The safeguard instrument is rarely used in practice and, as regards surveillance, the last supervisory measure in force, which expired on 31 December 2012, covered steel products. The objective of the reform is to consider updating the Annex with a view to eliminating the countries that have become members of the World Trade Organisation, namely Armenia, Russia, Tajikistan and Vietnam.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal concerns the codification and recasting of Reg. 625/2009 on common arrangements applicable to imports from certain third countries. These are not countries that can pose a danger to our production sectors, so I voted in favour.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. This report aims to adapt legislation relating to the common regime for imports from certain third countries to this new procedure. It is essential that the European Parliament, directly elected by the citizens, be informed at all stages of this procedure and be able to fully enjoy its rights in this area. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have today voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on common rules applicable to imports from certain third countries. Following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, an exercise in alignment took place to ensure that previous decision-making procedures – comitology and ad hoc – in the field of trade policy were in line with the new system of delegated acts and enforcement. The substance of the proposal is therefore largely technical corrections which do not contain any substantial changes.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Due to the fact that the purpose of this regulation is technical, i.e. to adapt and update the decision-making procedure in this case, I voted in favour.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This text constitutes an amendment to Regulation (EC) No 625/2009 concerning imports from certain third countries. This is due to the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, which changed certain procedures and, on this occasion, the Commission introduced some corrections and technical changes.  The proposal refers to imports of products including coal and steel but textile products (which are the subject of a different regulation) are excluded and applies to a limited number of countries: Azerbaijan, Belarus, North Korea, Kazakhstan, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan. The text does not provide for any controversial aspects, and introduces only updates necessary for the proper functioning of the mechanisms; I therefore voted in favour.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which calls for the establishment of a common regime for imports from certain third countries. Of course, proponents of the text can argue that the establishment of such a common regime would increase the transparency and visibility of the rules. However, this measure is done within the framework of the overall project of harmonization of legislation, thus with a view to greater integration, which is a new attack on national sovereignty in terms of trade policy.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The fact that the measure we are examining places quantitative import limits in the textile sector on third countries such as Azerbaijan, Belarus, North Korea, Kazakhstan, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan, favoring and protecting products especially Italian in this sector that have had a drop in sales imposed by the un competitive price with the Asian world due to their lower labour costs.  I welcome the Commission's work to codify an existing regulation dealing with common rules for imports in general from certain third countries. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission's proposal aims to codify an existing regulation dealing with common rules for imports in general from certain third countries. The Regulation applies to imports of textiles not covered by trade agreements or preferences of certain countries: Azerbaijan, Belarus, North Korea, Kazakhstan, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan.  I voted in favour of this regulation because it imposes quantitative restrictions on imports from these countries, in this way protecting Italian products and interests in this sector, which are already severely damaged by trade in Asian products, which are on the market at lower prices thanks to the ongoing social dumping.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr Walesa's report because the proposal in question is limited to a mere codification of existing acts, without any substantial changes. The main change concerns the updating of the Annex, from which countries that are now members of the WTO have been removed, namely Armenia, Russia, Tajikistan and Vietnam.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This proposal seeks to codify an existing Regulation that deals with common rules for imports of textiles originating in third countries and not covered by bilateral agreements, protocols or other arrangements. During trialogue negotiations the Commission did not introduce new elements to the original recast proposal. I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This Commission proposal concerns the codification and recasting of Regulation (EC) No 625/2009 on common arrangements applicable to imports from certain third countries. The proposal lays down safeguard and surveillance instruments applicable to imports of products including coal and steel but excluding textile products, which are the subject of a separate regulation. The regulation applies only to a limited number of countries: Azerbaijan, Belarus, North Korea, Kazakhstan, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan. The safeguard instrument is rarely used in practice; as far as supervision is concerned, the last supervisory measure in force was that concerning steel products and expired on 31 December 2012.   The Commission has proposed an update of the Annex, from which are removed countries that are now members of the World Trade Organisation, namely Armenia, Russia, Tajikistan and Vietnam. Also on the basis of the favourable opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs on this point, I am voting in favour of and voting in favour of the Commission's proposal on common arrangements applicable to imports from certain third countries.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report is a technical proposal that seeks to codify two existing Regulations that deal with common rules on surveillance and safeguard measures regarding common rules for imports from third countries. Due to the fact that this is a technical procedure with the contents of the Regulations being preserved, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on common arrangements applicable to imports from certain third countries. The aim of this proposal is to re-establish Regulation (EC) No 625/2009, which established safeguard and surveillance instruments for imports of products other than textile products, incorporating some substantial, largely technical, amendments. I consider the use of the recast instrument to be fundamental, as it guarantees the clarity and certainty of European legislation, enabling it to keep up with an evolving international environment, as in the case of trade policies. The revision of the Annex provided for the removal of countries that have now become members of the WTO (Armenia, Tajikistan, Russia and Vietnam).

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report focuses on the codification within EU law of Regulation 625/2009 on the common regime for imports from certain third countries, amended under the so-called "omnibus" procedure which has harmonized a number of legislative proposals with the new secondary legislation rules prescribed by the Lisbon Treaty.  The report also proposes an overhaul of the same regulation with the addition of technical amendments, as well as the updating of the annex due to the accession of Armenia, Russia, Tajikistan and Vietnam to the World Trade Organization.  I support this text, which is limited to simple technical changes without any real change in substance. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. In line with the opinion of the parliamentary committee in charge of this report in the European Parliament, I voted in favour of this text, which aims to revise the current regulation on the common regime for imports from certain third countries to the European Union. The main amendment produced by this overhaul is the updating of the annex, from which countries that have become members of the World Trade Organization, such as Armenia, Russia, Tajikistan and Vietnam, have been withdrawn.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. If there are some positive points in this text, such as reasoned protectionism or safeguards and surveillance measures, this is a timid first step towards protecting our industries and our production. Any brake on ultra-liberalism and blind free trade is to be encouraged as it calls into question a system in which nation states no longer have freedom.  Nevertheless, there are some weaknesses in this text. There is never any mention of the national level or at least the national freedom to promote domestic products. Considering that the nation-state is the only echelon capable of guaranteeing the economic functioning of a society, we cannot vote in favour of this text. So I decided to vote against it. Leaving the possibility for the Union to protect European industries is not enough: it is essential to give Member States priority on these issues and to leave them free to carry out their national economic policies.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The purpose of the Commission proposal for a regulation is technical simplification.  The regulation concerns the import of products (with the notable exception of textiles) into the EU from Azerbaijan, Belarus, Kazakhstan, North Korea, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan.  This proposal was necessary to ensure legal clarity, on account of the previous regulation being subject to amendments.  The countries concerned are those that do not belong to the World Trade Organisation (WTO) and are therefore not subject to any preferential treatment, and are not covered by WTO rules, hence the need for a common set of rules governing imports from them in this regulation.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report because I disagree with the globalisation of import rules.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission proposal concerns the codification and recasting of Regulation (EC) No 625/2009 on common arrangements applicable to imports from certain third countries. It lays down safeguard and surveillance instruments applicable to imports of products, including coal and steel. The Regulation applies only to the following countries: Azerbaijan, Belarus, North Korea, Kazakhstan, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan. The main change in the recast concerns the removal of countries that are now wto members, namely Armenia, Russia, Tajikistan and Vietnam. The recast proposal does not contain any substantial changes other than those expressly indicated as such in the proposal itself and, as regards the codification of the unchanged provisions of previous acts with these amendments, the proposal is limited to a mere codification of the existing texts, without changing their substance in any way. Since these are purely technical corrections, I voted in favour.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The content of this diploma is essentially technical, derived from the need to adapt the pre-Lisbon comitology regime to the regimes of delegated acts and implementation in the post-Lisbon under the common rules on imports from third countries, and a new version of the regulation was considered necessary.  It is a technical law regulating the safeguard and supervisory instruments applied to imports of products from a limited number of countries (Azerbaijan, Belarus, Kazakhstan, North Korea, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan (countries that are not full members of the WTO), and the new legal formulation has withdrawn countries that have since joined the epineofe, namely Armenia , Russia, Tajikistan and Vietnam.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission has detected some errors which required correction in Regulation (EC) No 625/2009 on the common regime applicable to imports from certain third countries. The content of these proposals consists mostly of technical corrections.  Safeguard and surveillance instruments are thus defined which can be applied to imports of products, including coal and steel, but excluding textiles, which are the subject of a separate regulation. The Regulation applies only to a limited number of countries, including Azerbaijan, Belarus, Kazakhstan, North Korea, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan. I voted in favour.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report aims to reformulate a set of regulations in the commercial field (Omnibus I and Omnibus II). For the most part, we are dealing with technical corrections aimed at defining safeguard and surveillance tools that can be applied to imports of products, including coal and steel, and to update the Annex. However, it is worth remembering our opposition to the Omnibus I and Omnibus II regulations. Limiting the sovereignty of states in the field of their trade policies. Decisions on trade agreements are therefore imposed taking into account the interests of the major European powers. Although this is an eminently technical report, our vote is inseparable from the principled position set out above.

name: Raffaele Fitto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal to be voted on concerns the simple codification and recasting of Regulation (EC) No 625/2009 on common arrangements applicable to imports from certain third countries. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 The European Commission's proposal concerns the codification and recasting of the Regulation on common rules for imports from third countries. As regards the recast itself, the main change concerning the updating of the Annex concerns countries that have become members of the WTO. As regards the overall report and the proposals themselves, these are mainly technical corrections and the regulation itself applies only to a limited number of countries. Such proposals by the European Commission are also intended to correct some of the errors that currently exist and to ensure that the decision-making procedures in the area of trade policy correspond to the Treaty of Lisbon.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report presented as these are trade agreements with countries that do not undermine our production sector.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am opposed to the globalisation of import rules, so I am voting against the common regime of imports from certain third countries.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This proposal by the Commission sets out safeguard and surveillance instruments which can be applied to import of products, including coal and steel, but excluding textiles, which are subject to a separate regulation.  The regulation only applies to a limited number of countries, namely Azerbaijan, Belarus, Kazakhstan, North Korea, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan. Based on the favourable opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs, I supported adoption of this Commission proposal unamended.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am pleased that this extremely important legislative dossier has been on the agenda for a long time. I welcome the fact that the proposal also contains a number of technical solutions that adequately complement the existing regulatory system. Globalisation has led to a significant increase in trade relations with third countries, and I therefore consider it of the utmost importance that the Union maintains control over imports from third countries with an appropriate regulatory regime. I welcome the fact that the proposal specifically deals with textile imports from third countries with which our trade is not based on a bilateral trade agreement, and for the reasons listed above, I voted positively in favour of this report.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the correction of errors identified in ad hoc decision-making under the trade policy on the common regime applicable to imports from certain third countries after the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon. The report aims to incorporate some background changes because of the need to transform coding into a recast. The text establishes safeguarding and surveillance instruments that can be applied to imports of certain products.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report in order to obtain a new proposal from the Commission that would allow us to have a more harmonised text, so as to simplify the work of many entrepreneurs and consumers who have to consult the applicable import rules.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I would like to thank my colleagues in the Committee on Legal Affairs for the continuous and valuable work of adapting Community legislation to the service of businesses and citizens, as was also the case during this session with the reform of the regulation on common rules applicable to imports from certain third countries. Following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, there have already been numerous legislative alignments to ensure that previous decision-making procedures – comitology and ad hoc – in the field of trade policy were in line with the new system of delegated acts and enforcement. Now, with this proposal, we are establishing safeguard and surveillance instruments applicable to imports of certain important products, including coal and steel.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which concerns a technical matter to undertake codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 517/94 on common rules for imports of textile products from certain third countries not covered by bilateral agreements, protocols or other arrangements, or by other specific Community import rules. The new regulation will supersede the various acts incorporated in it, fully preserving the content of the acts being codified.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report in the interests of clarity and rationality. The purpose of this proposal is to undertake codification of Council Regulation 517/94 on common rules for imports of products from certain third countries not covered by bilateral agreements, protocols or other arrangements, or by other specific Community import rules.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the main changes to common rules for imports from certain third countries. Mainly technical changes were made regarding the countries that have become members of the World Trade Organisation.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report which will facilitate trade with non-WTO countries.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation by Parliament and the Council on common rules for imports from certain third countries, as this does not prejudice the substance of the proposal, but is mainly about technical amendments. In one very important area such as trade policy, it is essential that European Union law is clearer and more accessible to citizens. I believe that codification and recast of this Regulation will contribute to the certainty of rights and reduce the need for research activities when seeking the rules in force.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. If there are some positive points in this text, such as reasoned protectionism or safeguards and surveillance measures, this is a timid first step towards protecting our industries and our production. Any brake on ultra-liberalism and blind free trade is to be encouraged as it calls into question a system in which nation states no longer have freedom.  Nevertheless, there are some weaknesses in this text. There is never any mention of the national level or at least the national freedom to promote domestic products. Considering that the nation-state is the only echelon capable of guaranteeing the economic functioning of a society, we cannot vote in favour of this text. So I decided to vote against it. Leaving the possibility for the Union to protect European industries is not enough: it is essential to give Member States priority on these issues and to leave them free to carry out their national economic policies.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Jaroslaw Walesa's report, which aims to codify an existing regulation on the common regime for imports from certain third countries, particularly with regard to textiles. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the revision of the regulation on the common regime for imports from certain third countries (Azerbaijan, Belarus, North Korea, Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan and Turkmenistan) to the European Union, with the exception of textile products. The overhaul also includes updating the annex to the regulation listing the third countries concerned, from which the countries that have become members of the World Trade Organization, namely Armenia, Russia, Tajikistan and Vietnam, have been withdrawn.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. As this proposal is only a correction of technical problems with import regulations from third countries that have arisen as a result of treaty changes by the EU, I am voting in favour of the motion submitted.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report as it is only a technical proposal that seeks to codify two existing regulations that deal with common rules (on surveillance and safeguard measures).

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am voting in favour of Jarosław Wałęsa's report. The proposal concerns the codification and recasting of Regulation (EC) No 625/2009 on common arrangements applicable to imports from certain third countries. The content of the report is technical and is essentially aimed at codifying and aligning existing texts, not making substantial changes in content.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. The Walesa report proposes to approve regulatory codification of the common regime for imports from certain third countries as part of the EU's trade policy and the harmonisation objectives set out in the Lisbon Treaty. However, I question the legitimacy and effectiveness of the Union's action in this area, which is essentially the responsibility of the Member States according to the interests of their economy. Strengthening the regulatory framework in trade should only be undertaken if these measures are assessed and their impact is clearly studied. Reasons why I voted against this report.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 Report in which the Commission proposes to codify and recast Regulation (EC) No 625/2009 on the common regime applicable to imports from certain third countries, which has been substantially amended through various legislative acts in recent years. This Regulation currently applies only to a limited number of countries: Azerbaijan, Belarus, Kazakhstan, North Korea, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan. Only the Annex to the Regulation is updated to remove the reference to a certain number of third countries that have acceded to the World Trade Organization, namely Armenia, Russia, Tajikistan and Vietnam.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. With the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, an alignment exercise was carried out with Amnibus I and II to ensure that all previous comitology and ad hoc decision-making procedures relating to trade policy are in line with the new system of delegated acts and implementing acts. This Commission proposal is a continuation of this work, with the recasting of Regulation (EC) No 625/2009 on common import rules for certain third countries. In this case, the main change is to remove from the annex countries that are already members of the WTO such as Armenia, Russia, Tajikistan and Vietnam. Since it is a technical report I voted in favour.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. I consider that the amendments that have been imposed, apart from those initially set out in the previous proposal, do not entail any significant change in substance in the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the common regime applicable to imports from certain third countries. These are therefore simple non-substantial changes.  I therefore approve of the proposal based on the amendments recommended by the Legal Services Advisory Group of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour, because that was also the position of our political group. It is of paramount importance that the EU's common trade policy is also implemented vis-à-vis third countries, and the result of the vote confirms this. 643 Members were in for (I am one of them), 32 against and 30 abstentions. That's a great result.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down common rules for imports from certain third countries, because in an arbitrary and discriminatory manner a significant number of Countries of the World Trade Organisation, such as Armenia, Vietnam, Russia and Tajikistan, are arbitrarily and discreetly deleted from the relevant Annex to that Regulation.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report. In terms of the scope of the proposal, it sets out safeguard and surveillance instruments which can be applied to the import of products, including coal and steel but excluding textiles which are subject to a separate regulation. The regulation only applies to a limited number of countries, namely Azerbaijan, Belarus, Kazakhstan, North Korea, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan. The safeguard instrument is rarely used in practice and as regards surveillance, the last surveillance measure was in force on steel products and expired on 31 December 2012.  In terms of what the recast does, the main change concerns updating the annex to remove countries which have now become members of the World Trade Organization, namely Armenia, Russia, Tajikistan and Vietnam.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on common arrangements applicable to imports from certain third countries. The safeguard and control instruments applicable to imports of products such as coal and steel have been implemented. Regulation (EC) No 625/2009 of 7 July 2009 was amended to improve the forecast for common arrangements applicable to imports from certain third countries. The fact that consultations can be held on import conditions, on the economic and commercial situation, on matters relating to the management of trade agreements, makes it possible, together with the possibility for the Commission to examine the volume of imports, their price, the impact on producers and the particular economic system of the countries concerned, to have a guarantee system implemented; this favours the European consumer and makes our market safer.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this proposal concerns the codification and recasting of Regulation (EC) No 625/2009 on common arrangements applicable to imports from certain third countries. Since the content of the Wałęsa report is limited to a mere codification of the existing texts, without making the same substantial changes, I felt it appropriate to put up with it with a vote in favour.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the common regime of imports from certain third countries, as technical problems of import regulations from third countries and the resulting treaty changes by the EU are to be corrected. The import of goods from third countries must be regulated, particularly in technical matters.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Codification consists of grouping normative texts of various natures into collections concerning a given subject with the aim of simplification, clarity and transparency. The purpose of this proposal is to codify Regulation (EC) 625/2009 of the Council of 7 July 2009 relating to the common regime applicable to imports from certain third countries. It is this regulation that authorizes the Commission to amend, suspend or repeal anti-dumping and/or countervailing measures, or to adopt any other specific measure. Opposed to the Commission's control in this area and even if it is only a technical report, I vote against it. These undemocratic technocratic procedures prevent Europe from practising solidarity protectionism, which is the ecological and social emergency of our time.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 We deal here only with a technical issue. This proposal concerns the codification and recast of Regulation (EC) No 625/2009 on the common regime applicable to imports from certain third countries. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report concerns the codification of common rules for imports from certain third countries and the recasting of certain elements of the regulation that concerns these common rules. The major changes were technical corrections and the removal of countries that have become members of the World Trade Organisation. Therefore I voted in favour of this report as codification of European regulations is essential for transparency and citizen involvement in EU decision-making.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. This initiative was welcome in that it simplifies and clarifies Regulation (EC) 625/2009 of the Council establishing a common import regime, which had previously been the subject of many substantial changes.  This new legislation is now more readable and more accessible to the citizen, without the content having really changed it. This decision will therefore have no impact on the current regime.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on common rules for imports from certain third countries (recast). The Report is a technical proposal that seeks to codify two existing regulations that deal with common rules.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal submitted is a largely technical adaptation of an earlier Regulation and its adaptation to changes in some of its points in the meantime.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The report deals with the codification of Regulation (EC) No. 625/2009 of the Council of 17 July 2009 establishing a common import regime. This codification is done on a constant basis without changing the substance of the provisions that will be included in it. It updates the list of third countries to which the regulation applies, removing those that have since joined the WTO.  If this regulation is questionable since it reminds us that the European Union is an internal market without borders, it is a measure of transparency and intelligibility of EU law. It also reiterates the possibility of taking surveillance or safeguarding measures against products from a limited number of third countries.  However, I decided to vote against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the regulation as it will supersede the various acts incorporated in it whilst fully preserving the contents of the acts being codified.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text of codification and revision of the Council's Regulation (EC) No. 625/2009 of 7 July 2009 on the common regime for imports from certain third countries. The main aim is to make some technical changes and to update its annex by removing the countries that have since become members of the WTO.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the Commission's proposal for the codification and recasting of Regulation (EC) No 625/2009 on common arrangements for imports from certain third countries. Indeed, following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, it was necessary to ensure that previous decision-making procedures – comitology and ad hoc – in the field of trade policy were in line with the new system of delegated acts and enforcement. In order to incorporate some substantial changes, it was considered necessary to transform codification into recasting. We would just like to mention here the importance of the safeguard and surveillance instruments applicable to imports of products including coal and steel from Azerbaijan, Belarus, North Korea, Kazakhstan, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text because it proposes beneficial changes to the codification of the Council's regulation establishing a common import regime. It lightens and simplifies the original text, and that is what European legislation must do.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of this proposal is to initiate the codification of the common arrangements applicable to imports in general from certain third countries, which contains rules which have been amended on several occasions. These arrangements apply, by means of quantitative restrictions, to imports of textile products not covered by trade agreements or preferences. In view of the above considerations, and since this is a technical report which does not introduce any innovation in content, but is limited to a mere recast operation, I have decided to accept it with a vote in favour.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted for this report because, through the subject it presents, it once again underlines its importance on the EU agenda. The report shows the common arrangements applicable to imports into the European Union from several third countries. In practice, the European Commission's proposal sets out the safeguard and surveillance instruments that apply to imports of products from various third countries, including coal and steel. Textiles, which are subject to other legislation, shall be excluded. The regulation applies only to certain states, such as Azerbaijan, Belarus, Kazakhstan, North Korea, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan, with countries such as Armenia, Russia, Tajikistan and Vietnam that have become members of the World Trade Organisation being abolished.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: scríofa. ‒ Chaith mise vóta i bhfabhar mar go bhfuil sprioc teicniúil ag an rialachán seo, chun uasdátú agus athchóiriú a dhéanamh ar an bpróiseas cinnteoireachta sa chás seo.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for common rules on imports concerning third countries. In essence, these are technical improvements, but in general, common rules of the game help to increase competitiveness and avoid unfair benefits.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to the Advisory Group of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the Commission's proposal contains no substantial changes other than those expressly indicated as such and, as regards the codification of the unchanged provisions of previous acts and such amendments, the proposal is limited to a mere codification of existing acts without any substantial changes. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ This proposal amends and codifies Regulation 625/2009/EC of the European Parliament and the Council on common rules for imports from certain third countries. The basic act regulates the introduction of protective and supervisory instruments used when importing products, including imports of coal and steel from a limited number of countries such as Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, Belarus, Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan and North Korea. This proposed recast updates the Appendix to the Regulations and removes from the list countries that have since become members of the World Trade Organisation: Armenia, Russia, Tajikistan and Vietnam. The act will not undergo other substanmental changes. Since I expect that such a recast text will contribute to greater legal certainty of the application of the act in relations, both between EU countries and those third countries, as well as between their economic operators in the trade exchange to which the provisions of the Regulation relate, I supported this proposal.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. The report deals with the codification of Regulation (EC) No. 625/2009 of the Council of 17 July 2009 establishing a common import regime. This codification is done on a constant basis without changing the substance of the provisions that will be included in it.  It updates the list of third states to which the regulation applies, removing those that have since joined the WTO.  It is a measure of transparency and intelligibility of EU law.  It also reiterates the possibility of taking surveillance or safeguarding measures against products from a limited number of third countries.  I have decided to vote against it, because this regulation is questionable because it reminds us that the European Union is an internal market without borders, a principle to which I am opposed.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. According to the Advisory Group on the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the Commission proposal does not contain substantive changes other than those mentioned as such in the proposal, and that the proposal, as regards the codification of unchanged provisions of previous acts and those changes, is limited only to codifying existing acts without changing them substantially, I therefore support it.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support the Walese MP's report because it is essential to codify this technical proposal for a regulation that speaks to common rules for imports as a whole, and also on imports of textiles from certain third countries. Following the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, a new act was to be adopted to ensure that previous decisions were in line with the new acts. This was achieved by the Omnibus I and II acts, which amend a number of trade rules, including the Regulation on common rules for imports from certain third countries. The most important modifications were made in terms of being kicked off the list of "third countries" that became members of the World Trade Organization. The Common Commercial Policy should be based on uniform principles, taking into account the specific characteristics of the economic system in third countries. The liberalisation of imports, namely the absence of quantitative restrictions, should therefore constitute the starting point for Union rules, and in the case of protection of the Union's interests, the Commission shall be responsible for adopting safeguards taking into account international obligations.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As we will recall, the Commission's proposal concerns the codification and recasting of Regulation (EC) No 625/2009 on the common arrangements applicable to imports from certain third countries.  With the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, it was necessary to carry out an exercise in alignment in order to allow previous decision-making procedures in the field of trade policy to be in line with the new system of delegated acts and implementing acts;  hence the amendment of a series of regulations in the field of trade concerning the common arrangements applicable to imports from certain third countries.  I agree with the Commission that it considered it appropriate to insert substantial changes to correct certain errors, hence the transformation of codification into recasting. I support the Commission's proposal, which establishes sound safeguard and surveillance instruments applicable to imports of products including coal and steel, the application of which concerns a certain number of countries, with the fair exclusion of those that are members of the World Trade Organisation.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. At a time when trade between the European Union and third countries is important, there is a need to strengthen the rules in place and to update procedures. I voted in favour of changes to the common regime for imports from certain third countries, namely coal and steel. The regulation establishes safeguard and monitoring clauses that apply only to certain countries, namely Azerbaijan, Belarus, Kazakhstan, North Korea, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan.  Another important change is that some countries, namely Armenia, Russia, Tajikistan and Vietnam, have been removed from the annex because they have joined the WTO.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 At its meeting on 10 July 2014, the Advisory Group composed of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission reviewed the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council, by which Regulation (EEC) No 625/2009 of the Council of 7 July 2009 on the common regime applicable to imports from certain third countries is codified. It then concluded, by common agreement, that the proposal underreference does not contain substantive amendments other than those identified therein and that, as regards the codification of the unchanged provisions of the preceding acts with those amendments, the proposal is based on a pure and simple codification of the existing texts, without substantive modifications. I voted, therefore, in favor.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as safeguard and surveillance instruments are defined in this Regulation which can be applied to imports of products, including coal and steel. The Regulation applies only to a limited number of countries, including Azerbaijan, Belarus, Kazakhstan, North Korea, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan. As regards the amendments included in the recast, the main one concerns the updating of the Annex to remove countries which have now become members of the World Trade Organisation, in particular Armenia, Russia, Tajikistan and Vietnam.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since the Committee on Legal Affairs considers that the proposal in question contains no substantive amendments other than those identified as such in the proposal and that it is based on the pure and simple codification of the existing texts, without substantive amendments, there would be no reason to vote against.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. For the sake of simplification and clarity of EU law, in order to make it more accessible and understandable to the citizen, I voted in favour of the codification and recasting of Regulation (EC) No 625/2009 on the common regime applicable to imports from certain third countries. This Regulation, which currently applies only to a limited number of countries: Azerbaijan, Belarus, Kazakhstan, North Korea, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan, has been substantially amended through various legislative acts in recent years and, in order to improve clarity and easy understanding of the legislative text, all these provisions should be recast into a new Regulation, respecting the content of the codified texts and making only the relevant formal amendments. As regards the substance, only the Annex to the Regulation is updated to remove the reference to a certain number of third countries that have acceded to the World Trade Organization, namely Armenia, Russia, Tajikistan and Vietnam.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. This relatively technical proposal aims to codify an existing regulation on the common regime for imports of textile products from certain third countries that are not covered by bilateral agreements, protocols or other arrangements, or by other specific EU import regimes. At present, Belarus and North Korea are the only countries from which the European Union imports textiles that are not covered by specific bilateral agreements, protocols or other regimes, including the Generalised Preference System (GSP) or the "Everything but Arms" (TSA) initiative. The regulation, which had already been amended several times, now provides for the imposition of import restrictions (contingents) on these two countries.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 After 1 December 2009, an exercise in legislative and procedural harmonisation was carried out to ensure that comitology and previous ad hoc decision-making processes in the field of trade policy were in accordance with the new regime of delegated acts and implementing acts provided for in the Treaty of Lisbon. However, during this exercise, some errors that required correction were found. In order to incorporate some substantial changes, it was considered necessary to turn coding into a recast, as is well explained in the Report. As in previous plenary sessions, we have voted today on another report codifying and recasting a European legislation, Regulation (EC) No 624/2009, on the common regime for imports from certain third countries.  As a proposal which, in terms of content, mainly entails technical corrections, it gives my vote in favour of it.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. This report deals with the revision of Regulation (EC) 625/2009 of the Council of 17 July 2009 establishing a common import regime.  This overhaul takes place in the interests of clarity and transparency of the law and follows an expedited procedure in accordance with inter-institutional agreements. It incorporates several substantive amendments to the regulation, which mainly deal with technical corrections. Thus, the main change resulting from the redesign is the updating of the annex, from which the countries that have since become members of the WTO, namely Armenia, Russia, Tajikistan and Vietnam, have been withdrawn.  I supported this text, which is part of the desire to simplify and transparent the law.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission's proposal aims to codify an existing regulation, which has been amended on several occasions. The Regulation applies to imports of textiles not covered by trade agreements or preferences, which in the end are only those from North Korea and Belarus.  The Regulation also imposes quantitative restrictions on imports from these countries. It is important that in international competition the European Union protects European consumers and, to the right extent, European businesses as well.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote in favour because the text establishes safeguard and surveillance instruments applicable to imports of products including coal and steel but excluding textile products. The regulation applies only to a limited number of countries: Azerbaijan, Belarus, North Korea, Kazakhstan, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan because, by exclusion, they are now the only ones in the world with whom we do not have other types of trade agreements in force both within the World Trade Organisation and specific (free trade or partnership). These are not, incidentally, countries that can pose a danger to our production sector.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this purely technical report, which is limited to codifying existing acts, without altering their substance.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (NI)
text: In writing. The European economy already seems far too vulnerable - with an opening rate of 85%, compared to 20% for example in the United States - to further relax the standards for imports from third countries. I therefore voted against it.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on common rules for imports from certain third countries. I welcome the countries which have now joined the WTO and the updating of the annex as a result of this.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Commission's proposal concerns the codification and processing of Regulation (EC) No 2012/2013. 625/2009 on common rules for imports from certain third countries. As regards the scope of the proposal, it lays down safeguard instruments and controls on instruments that can be applied to imports of products including coal and steel, but excluding fabrics subject to a specific regulation. The regulation applies only to a limited number of countries in Azerbaijan, Belarus, Kazakhstan, North Korea, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan. The protective instrument is rarely used in practice, and as far as supervision is concerned, the last monitoring of the measures in force for steel products expired on 31 December 2012. The main change relates to updating removal supplements for countries that have now become members of the World Trade Organization, namely Armenia, Russia, Tajikistan and Vietnam. I would point out that the Advisory Working Group unanimously decided that the proposal does not contain significant changes other than those already established, and that is why I support the report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which will clarify and codify common rules for imports of textile products from certain third countries not covered by bilateral agreements, protocols or other arrangements, or other Community import rules.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I supported the proposal as it makes existing legislation more streamlining in particular without increasing the regulatory burden.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Globalisation of import rules is not moving in the right direction

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. We have ensured that safeguard and monitoring clauses are in place for certain imports, including coal and steel, but not textile products, which are subject to separate regulations. The regulation under consideration also applies only to a limited number of countries, namely Azerbaijan, Belarus, Kazakhstan, North Korea, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan. In fact, the safeguard clause is rarely invoked. As for the monitoring clause, the last measure dealt with steel products and expired on December 31, 2012.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this regulation on common rules for imports from certain third countries: setting rules for imports, based on uniform principles across the EU, and setting simple and identical formalities to be carried out by importers will boost trade with third countries. I support the provision on surveillance and safeguard measures adopted by the Commission: the text provides the Commission with the necessary tools to investigate and ensure EU interests are not endangered, while avoiding unnecessary administrative burdens on importers.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 There are frequent situations where a European legislative act has been amended over the years several times. This puts the European citizen in difficulty, who will ultimately not be able to understand what is the essence of the legislative act and which of the existing amendments is the one in force. The European Commission, with the right to initiate and propose legislative drafts, has always assumed and supported the need for simple and clear legislation so that any European citizen can understand the legislative act and make use of the specific rights conferred on him through it. Clarification of European legislative acts is done through a legislative procedure called codification of legislative acts. The legislative proposal which was the subject of the European Parliament's report aims to codify and reform Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999. Council Regulation (EEC) No 625/2009 of 7 July 2009 on the common arrangements applicable to imports from certain third countries(6). With its vote, the European Parliament gave an opinion in favour of the codification and reform of this regulation.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this technical report without controversial elements, which updates parts of European import legislation.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. With the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, an alignment exercise was carried out with Amnibus I and II to ensure that all previous comitology and ad hoc decision-making procedures relating to trade policy are in line with the new system of delegated acts and implementing acts. This Commission proposal is a continuation of this work, with the recasting of Regulation (EC) No 625/2009 on common import rules for certain third countries. In this case, the main change is to remove from the annex countries that are already members of the WTO such as Armenia, Russia, Tajikistan and Vietnam. Since it is a technical report I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since 1987 all acts should be codified no later than 10 amendments in order to make EU legislation more accessible and easier to understand by the ordinary citizen. In order to ensure the clarity and transparency of the law, it is necessary to codify the rules which have been frequently changed. This cannot be achieved as long as there is a scattering of numerous provisions, amended on several occasions.  This proposal is based on a pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantive amendments.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. The report on the common regime of imports from certain third countries deals with the correction of technical problems of import regulations from third countries and the resulting treaty changes on the part of the EU. I welcome these rules, as the import of goods from third countries must be regulated precisely in technical matters.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted on the report on the proposal for a Regulation on the common regime applicable to imports from certain third countries. After the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, an alignment process took place to ensure that previous committee and ad hoc decision-making procedures on trade policies have aligned with the new regime of delegated and implementing acts. During this exercise, the Commission detected several errors that had to be corrected. The regulation voted today applies only to a limited number of countries, namely Azerbaijan, Belarus, Kazakhstan, North Korea, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report since its purpose was merely to codify and transpose to the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with Montenegro (in force since 2010) the legislative updates made since then affecting the implementation of the Treaty.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This vote concerned codification, which is effectively simplification. On the basis that it is technical and concerned simplification rather than content, I voted in favour.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The proposal merely codifies the existing texts, without modifying their substance, and I am voting in favour of its adoption.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. This is a codification without any substantive amendments to the relevant legal acts, and that is why I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. This stabilisation and association agreement between the European Union and Montenegro has failed to end the important underground economy in the country, where cigarette trafficking is particularly high. This trafficking is the result of an agreement between Montenegro and the Union which asks Montenegro to move away from Serbia. In return, the Union agrees to be lax, particularly on cigarette trafficking.  This codification report is a step towards Montenegro's accession to the Union, which is why I have opposed it.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because it is limited to an outright codification of the existing texts, without altering their substance.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a Stabilisation and Association Agreement for Montenegro. The purpose of the proposal is to codify existing texts without changing their substance.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which aims to prepare for a new enlargement: we have nothing to gain from it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The proposal sets out certain procedures for adopting concrete modalities for the implementation of certain provisions of the Stabilization and Association Agreement with Montenegro. In particular, it provides that fish products originating in Montenegro can be imported into the EU at reduced tariff rates within tariff quotas. It is therefore necessary to establish provisions regulating the management of these tariff quotas.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This report consists of a stabilisation and association agreement for Montenegro's future accession to the European Union. On 29 June 2012, the European Council approved the opening of negotiations for Montenegro's accession to the Union. Unfortunately, Montenegro still has serious problems with corruption, press freedom or the underground economy. To want to enlarge the Union to infinity is a heresy that will not lead in any way to its prosperity. So I voted against this agreement.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the text which, although it does not introduce any change in substance, is a measure against which, on this occasion too, I would like to confirm my firm opposition.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal, as indicated by the Legal Services Advisory Group of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal is limited to a codification of existing acts, without substantial changes, concerning the procedures for the implementation of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and its Member States , on the one hand, and the Republic of Montenegro, on the other hand, and the application of the Interim Agreement between the European Community, on the one hand, and the Republic of Montenegro, on the other.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report on the codification of the rules of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement of the Republic of Montenegro. The Commission attaches great importance to making European Union law simpler and clearer in order to make it more comprehensible and accessible to citizens who have new opportunities and access to the specific rights conferred on them. This objective will not be achieved if many provisions, which have been amended and often substantially amended several times, remain scattered in various acts, and therefore some of them should be sought in the original act and others in subsequent amending acts. Therefore, in order to find the rules in force at a given moment, research work needs to be carried out in comparing the various pieces of legislation.
