text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report as I believe that the existence of EU tariff quotas on agricultural or livestock products significantly restricts free trade.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. The objective of this proposal is to codified Council Regulation (EC) No 774/94 of 29 March 1994 on the opening and management of Community tariff quotas for certain high-quality beef and pork, poultry, wheat and tranquillon, bran, moyuelos and other waste. Such codification must be carried out in full compliance with the procedure for the adoption of EU acts. No substantive amendment has been made and this codification of frequently amended rules is essential for European legislation to be clear and transparent.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I approved the pure and simple codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 774/94 of 29 March 1994 on the opening and management of certain Union tariff quotas for high-quality beef, pigmeat, poultry meat, wheat and mixture of wheat with rye, bran, bran and other waste, which has not undergone any substantial change. This is a technical diploma.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report examines the proposal for a Regulation to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 774/94, on the opening and management of certain Union tariff quotas for high-quality beef, pigmeat, poultry meat, wheat and the mixture of wheat with rye, bran, bran and other waste, and is effectively limited to pure and simple codification, without altering the substance of the acts of the acts objected to. I voted in favour.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. Sad day for farmers, and especially for the farmers of our countries. Instead of taking measures to support our farmers, who are already facing significant difficulties, the European Union prefers to despise the excellence of our agriculture by "facilitating" the importation of so-called high-quality beef, pork, poultry meat and wheat. Proud defender of our farmers, I vote against this text.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The purpose of this report is to codify the Regulation on the opening and management of certain EU tariff quotas for high-quality beef, pigmeat, poultry meat, wheat and the mixture of wheat with rye, bran and other waste. The Commission has decided to ask its services that all acts should be codified no later than 10 amendments in order to make EU legislation more accessible and easier to understand. This objective cannot be achieved as long as there is a scattering of numerous provisions, amended on several occasions, often substantially, which requires a reading of both the original act and the acts amending it. For this reason, and in order to ensure the clarity and transparency of the law, it is necessary to codify the rules which have been frequently changed.   This proposal is based on a pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantive amendments. Regardless of our position of principle on the fundamental issues, given the technical nature of this amendment, we abstained.

name: Raffaele Fitto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal concerns a simple codification of existing texts, without any substantial changes. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 Proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council based on the Interinstitutional Agreement of 20 May 1994 opening and providing for the administration of certain European Union tariff quotas for high quality beef and pigmeat, poultrymeat, wheat and meslin and bran, milling by-products and other residues needed recoding to improve the application of this Regulation.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting negatively on the text even if this is only a process of "codification" of the texts that does not introduce any change in substance, thus reiterating our position of opposition to the substance of the proposal.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report because the existence of Union tariff quotas (proposed) on agricultural or livestock products significantly restricts free trade.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of the proposal as it is a straightforward codification of existing texts without any change in their substance.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted positively in favour of the proposal, which includes the formal amendments to the codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 774/94 of 29 March 1994 on the opening and administration of certain Community tariff quotas for high-quality beef, pigmeat, poultrymeat, wheat and double, dandour, dandour flour and other residues, while preserving the content of its acts. The introduction of single tariff quotas makes it possible to regulate the quantities of goods and products imported by the European Union, taking into account the needs of both domestic producers and consumers. I welcome the fact that the proposal also guarantees the nature, origin and origin of imported products and compliance with the high standards set by the European Union.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report after examining the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council, and to note that this is a proposal which is limited to a pure and simple codification of existing acts, without substantial changes.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On a subject of great interest to citizens such as food, transparency and simplification are two elements of extraordinary importance. With this vote, the European Parliament is codifying the existing texts on Union tariff quotas for high-quality beef, pigmeat, poultrymeat, wheat, rye wheat and bran, stacing and other residues. Thanks to this codification, the regulations will become more coherent systematically and it will be easier and more immediate to consult and communicate them.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. With the vote on Mr Duda's report, supported by the Committee on Legal Affairs, we are taking another step towards the progressive harmonisation of Community rules of the internal market at the service of consumers and the main production categories.  The opinion of the Joint Committee of the Legal Services of the three institutions enables us to proceed quickly and carefully to the adoption of a measure of a technical nature, but extremely important for the development of the internal market. We now have new rules that can more integratedly manage certain EU tariff quotas for important products such as high-quality beef, pigmeat, poultrymeat and wheat.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which concerns codification to take into account changes in the relationship between the EU and Turkey on the subject of agricultural products being imported into the EU.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this proposed regulation. It grants third countries exceptional tariffs which, in addition to facilitating imports and thus competing with our farmers, do not necessarily comply with the health and environmental standards in principle demanded by the European Union. Finally, the European Union has little regard for third countries' respect for the principle of reciprocity with regard to our own exports to their markets.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which is part of a larger group of codification files being votes on. This codification takes into account changes in the relationship between the EU and Turkey on the subject of agricultural products being imported into the EU. The proposal aims to open annual Community tariff quotas for high-quality beef, and for pigmeat, poultrymeat, wheat and meslin, and brans, sharps and other residues, which I support.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation by Parliament and the Council on the opening of certain Union tariff quotas for high-quality beef, for pigmeat, poultry meat, wheat and cohats, and on the management of those quotas, and on the management of those quotas, as I believe that EU law in this area must be as clear and transparent as possible. The European Union must ensure a simpler and more efficient finding and understanding of its legal acts, and codification is heading in this direction.  This proposal guarantees the certainty of rights and reduces the need for research work in the search for the rules in force.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. The codification of developments in the EU tariff quota regulation for high-quality beef, pork, poultry meat, wheat and meteil and sounds, remising and other residues strengthens the regulatory framework opening up the European market to foreign products and is therefore an element of the passivity of EU trade policy. Excessive importation of foodstuffs such as meat is hurting the activity of European producers, whom we must protect, especially in times of crisis and economic recession. So I voted against it.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Andrzej Duda's report on the opening and management of certain EU tariff quotas for high-quality beef, pork, poultry meat, wheat and meteil and sounds, resurables and other residues. It introduces tariff quotas on different products based on the number of tonnes imported and allows the quality of imported products to be monitored.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which codifies the Council's regulation on the opening and management of certain Community tariff quotas for high-quality beef, swine meat, poultry meat, wheat and meteil and sounds, remoulding and other residues. The proposed regulation replaces the various acts incorporated into it. It fully preserves its substance and merely groups it together by making the only formal modifications required by the coding operation itself.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report as it is simply a codification to take into account changes in the relationship between the EU and Turkey on the subject of agricultural products being imported into the EU.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of the Duda report, which aims to codify the regulation opening and operating certain EU tariff quotas, high-quality beef, pigmeat, poultrymeat, wheat, rye wheat, bran and other residues. The proposal is aimed at codifying the existing texts.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. The codification of developments in the EU tariff quota regulation for high-quality beef, pork, poultry meat, wheat and meteil and sounds, remising and other residues is part of the strengthening of the regulatory framework which opens the European market to foreign products and which is one of the elements of the passivity of the Union's trade policy. Excessive importation of foodstuffs such as meat is hurting the activity of European producers, which must be protected, especially in times of crisis. So I voted against it.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this text because it favours the importation of food into the European Union, at a time when our farmers and farmers are already suffering terribly from this unfair competition.

name: Philippe Loiseau (NI)
text: In writing. Against this position. The European Union continues to open its market to non-EU products, while Member States' agricultural production is competing with many products. French farmers are very worried about the increasingly growing competition. We reject any policy that will make this situation worse and this project contributes to the worsening of the fragility of our agriculture.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because this is a pure and simple technical question of the codification of existing acts without substantial changes. This legal amendment adjusts existing legislation without any impact on current legislation.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. Because the proposal makes a simple, non-substantial amendment, based on the recommendations of the Legal Services Advisory Group of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, and therefore does not involve any change in the substantive question, I approve the proposal for a Regulation.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report because the opening of certain EU tariff quotas for high-quality beef, pigmeat, poultry meat, wheat and wheat, as well as bran in general and other residues is, of course, going to harm the austere farmers and farmers of the EU and in particular the countries of the European South.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. Vote against these tariff quotas. This text promotes the importation of food into the European Union, with all the consequences that this can have for European production. Moreover, this text does not contribute anything on the substance.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report as the proposal in question contains a straightforward codification of the existing texts without any change in their substance.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council opening and operating certain Union tariff quotas and meat. We return to the fundamental issue of effective management of food products that are safe for the European market and in accordance with the law with the relevant standards. Nutritious and affordable products, therefore, bearing in mind that the meat sector accounts for about a quarter of total agricultural production.  The objective of improving the quality of products, giving farmers confidence in future income prospects and encouraging more environmentally sustainable farming practices has long been one of the priorities of the CAP (common agricultural policy) and such a contribution increases the security of this market.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of this proposal is to codify the regulation opening and operating certain Union tariff quotas for high-quality beef, pigmeat, poultrymeat, wheat (wheat) and rye and bran, tores and other residues. Since the proposal by the rapporteur, Mr Duda, is limited to a mere simplification of the existing texts, I have decided to welcome their content.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. The domestic producers of high-quality meat and cereal products are not promoted high enough. As long as this fact does not change and domestic producers are promoted to a greater extent, I cannot support a tariff quota regime.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Codification consists of grouping normative texts of various natures into collections concerning a given subject with the aim of simplification, clarity and transparency.  The purpose of this proposal is to codify Regulation (EC) 774/94 of the Council of 29 March 1994 on the opening and management of certain Community tariff quotas for high-quality beef, swine meat, poultry meat, wheat (wheat) and meteil and sounds, re-mouldings and other residues. This regulation delegates to the Commission the power to change the volumes or other conditions of the quota after the Council's decision.  Opposed to the Commission's control in this area and even if it is only a technical report, I vote against it. These undemocratic technocratic procedures prevent Europe from practising solidarity protectionism, which is the ecological and social emergency of our time.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 We deal here only with a technical issue.  The aim of this proposal is to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 774/94 of 29 March 1994 on the opening and management of certain Community tariff quotas for high-quality beef, pigmeat, poultry meat, wheat and mixture of wheat with rye, bran, bran and other waste. The new Regulation will replace the various acts contained therein. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report regarding certain Union tariff quotas for high-quality beef, and for pigmeat, poultrymeat, wheat and meslin, and brans, sharps and other residue, because the consultative working party of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission concluded that the proposed codification of the existing texts is straightforward and presents no change in their substance. It is crucial that agreements that have been amended many times be codified in order to ensure that they are accessible and clear to citizens.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council opening and providing for the administration of certain Union tariff quotas for high-quality beef, and for pigmeat, poultrymeat, wheat and meslin, and brans, sharps and other residues (codification).

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal submitted is to unify the texts of an earlier Council Regulation without any substantive change.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The purpose of the proposal is the constant-law codification of Regulation (EC) 774/94 of the Council of 29 March 1994 opening and managing certain Community tariff quotas for high-quality beef, swine meat, poultry meat, wheat (wheat) and meteil and sounds, re-mouldings and other residues.  It is a measure of simplification and clarification of EU law, as well as improving the accessibility of the law.  This codification follows an agreement on concessions and tariff quotas based on Article 31 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union on certain specific products.  I strongly oppose the free-trade will to grant preferential or zero tariffs on certain quantities of agricultural products, even if this text is merely a codification, without substantial modification of the substance. That is why I am voting against this proposal.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which will take into account the changes in the relationship between the EU and Turkey on the subject of agricultural products being imported into the EU.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the codification of the Council regulation on the opening and management of certain Community tariff quotas for high-quality beef, pork, poultry meat, wheat and meteil and sounds, remoulages and other residues. This regulation has been amended several times and substantially, so that its provisions are now found for one part in the original act and for the rest scattered in the amending acts that followed.  In the interests of clarity and simplification of the law, guaranteeing greater legal certainty and better information for citizens, it was therefore necessary to codify this regulation. This process completely preserves its substance and merely brings together in a legible way the various changes that have been made to it.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this proposal for a regulation opening and operating certain Union tariff quotas and high-quality beef, pigmeat, poultrymeat, wheat (wheat) and rye wheat and bran, statures and other residues, as it is limited to a mere codification of existing texts, without therefore containing any substantial changes to the original agreement.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because the proposal in question is limited to an outright codification of the existing texts, without altering their substance.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. The aim of this proposal is to initiate the codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 774/94 of 29 March 1994 opening and operating certain Union tariff quotas for high-quality beef, pigmeat, poultrymeat, wheat and rye wheat and bran, stail and other residues. Since the proposal by the rapporteur, Mr Duda, as confirmed by the Advisory Group of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, is limited to a mere codification of the existing texts, without making the same substantial changes, I have decided to welcome it. The codification of provisions which have undergone frequent changes over time is necessary if Community legislation is to be fully in line with the principles of clarity and transparency.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report because through this proposal for a regulation 'on the opening and management of certain Union tariff quotas for high quality beef, pork, poultry, wheat, borceag and bran, breezes and other residues', the European Parliament and the Council manage the management of 'these EU tariff quotas'.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the draft tariff quotas for quality beef, pigmeat, poultrymeat, wheat and meslin, and bran, peprede and other residues. No substantive changes will result.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to the Advisory Group of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question is limited to a mere codification of existing texts, without any substantial changes. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. On 1 April 1987, the European Commission ordered that no more than ten amendments to the act must be codified, and this recommendation was endorsed by the European Council in December 1992 in Edinbourgh, and on 20 December 1994 an agreement was adopted between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, which further accelerated the codification process by adopting appropriate legal instruments. Council Regulation 774/94/EC of 29 March 1994 on the opening and provision of certain Union tariff quotas for high-quality beef, pigmeat, poultry meat, wheat and cohats, and sows and other residues has been repeatedly changed. The Regulation regulates the conditions reached during the negotiation of customs concessions under Article XXVIII of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) and agreed during the Uruguayan Round of Multilateral Trade Quota Negotiations. The basic Regulation focused on the opening of annual Union tariff quotas for high quality products. The proposal for a new Regulation will unite the different actions covered by the previous amendments and fully preserve the material content of the act.  Due to the need to apply this regulation properly among the stakeholders to which it has a legal effect, I consider the proposed codification necessary because it contributes to greater legal certainty of the application of the act and therefore I supported this proposal.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. The purpose of the proposal is the constant-law codification of Regulation (EC) 774/94 of the Council of 29 March 1994 opening and managing certain Community tariff quotas for high-quality beef, swine meat, poultry meat, wheat (wheat) and meteil and sounds, re-mouldings and other residues.  It is a measure of simplification and clarification of EU law, as well as improving the accessibility of the law.  This codification follows an agreement on concessions and tariff quotas based on Article 31 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union on certain specific products.  I strongly oppose the free-trade will to grant preferential or zero tariffs on certain quantities of agricultural products, even if this text is merely a codification, without substantial modification of the substance. That is why I am voting against this proposal.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. According to the Advisory Group on legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question is limited only to codifying existing texts without substantive changes. This formal procedure increases the transparency of the process and allows citizens to be fully informed about this topic through simplified rules, so I support it.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support MEP Andrzej Duda's report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on the opening of certain Union tariff quotas for high-quality beef, pigmeat, poultry meat, wheat and cohats and sows and other residues, and the management of those quotas, as the Advisory Group of legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission pointed out that the proposal limits itself to codifying existing texts without substantive changes. The purpose of the proposal is the codification procedure for Regulation No 1000/2013. 774/94 since March 29, 1994, which has changed several times. The new regulation brings together various acts and transmits the content of the acts with the formal amendments necessary for codification, which contributes to transparency and transparency. The European Parliament hereby supports a simplification that will make Union law clearer and more accessible to EU citizens. I welcome the continued efforts of parliament's professional services, the Council and the Commission in codification procedures.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the procedures for managing certain Union tariff quotas and high-quality beef and veal, pigmeat, poultrymeat, wheat and rye and bran, stail and other residues concerns a simple codification of the existing texts, with reference also to the opinion of the Advisory Group of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission of 12/11/2014, and hence my vote in favour.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. As part of the regulations on exports and imports of food products, including high-quality beef, swine meat, poultry meat, wheat (wheat) and meteil and sounds, remising and other residues, the European Parliament has voted on a text on the opening and management of tariff quotas for these products.  I have spoken in favour of this text and stress the importance of legislation in regulating tariff quotas for food products.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 At its meeting on 14 October 2014, the Advisory Group composed of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission reviewed the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council, to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 774/94 of 29 March 1994 on the opening and management of certain Union tariff quotas for high-quality beef, pigmeat, poultry meat, wheat and mixture of wheat with rye, bran, bran and other waste. It then concluded, by common agreement, that the proposal under question should be based on a pure and simple codification of the existing texts, without substantive amendments. I voted, therefore, in favor.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that it is limited only to the correction and codification of existing texts, not altering them substantively.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since the Advisory Group on the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission has delivered a positive opinion and considers that this proposal is limited to the pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantive amendments to the texts, there is no reason to vote against or even to abstain.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council, as indicated by the Legal Services Advisory Group of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, with a view to the codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 774/94, 29 March 1994, concerning the opening and management of certain Community tariff quotas for higher quality beef, pork, poultry meat, wheat, tranquillon, bran, moyuelos and other waste, is limited to a simple codification of existing acts, without substantial modification.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 01/04/1987, the Commission decided to instruct its services to codify all normative acts when there are a maximum of ten amendments. Subsequently, on 20/1994, the Council and the Commission concluded an Interinstitutional Agreement on an accelerated working method with a view to the rapid adoption of codified acts. This proposal aims to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 774/94 of 29 March 1994 on the opening and management of certain Union tariff quotas for high-quality beef, pigmeat, poultry meat, wheat and the mixture of wheat with rye, bran, bran and other waste. I therefore agree with this report that it will ensure greater legal certainty and certainty in this matter.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on the opening and management of certain EU tariff quotas for high-quality beef, pork, poultry meat, wheat and meteil and sounds, swirls and other residues.  This is a commission proposal, which echoes the recommendations of the European Parliament's Legal Services Advisory Group, the Council and the Commission. This proposal is thus limited to an outright codification of existing texts, without altering their substance.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this purely technical report, which is limited to codifying existing acts, without altering their substance.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (NI)
text: In writing. The codified regulation, by opening tariff quotas, facilitates the importation into the European Union of high-quality beef, pork, poultry meat, wheat (wheat) and meteil and sounds, remoulages and other residues. I oppose this in order to preserve the health of consumers and to protect our farmers from social dumping that will end our food independence at risk.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on this report because, although it is presented as a technical issue of pure and simple codification of existing acts and without substantial changes, I am not sure that the technical management of tariff contigates will not have a major impact on producers and producers.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I understand and agree with the codification process, in order to promote greater clarity of the normative acts, resulting from the need to take into account the different amendments they have been subject to in the event that they are more than ten, which have passed through the scrutiny of the ordinary legislative procedure of the respective time in which they occurred. This codification process should not, by its nature, alter the content of the act to which it refers and should be limited to a purely technical procedure, and it is in this spirit that I am voting on this dossier today.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on Union tariff quotas for high-quality beef, and for pigmeat, poultrymeat, wheat and meslin, and brans, sharps and other residues. I welcome the codification to take into account changes in the relationship between the EU and Turkey on the subject of agricultural products being imported into the EU.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the report on the proposal to open Union tariff quotas for high-quality beef, pigmeat, poultry meat, wheat and cob;Tykal and sows and other residues given the importance of consumer protection.  The Greens/ESS Group relentlessly emphasises the importance of the origin of meat as well as other food products, and 90% of consumers in the European Union agree with us. I consider it essential to ensure greater transparency across the food chain and stronger information to Union citizens. This transparency and information provide us with tools to combat food fraud and provide us with the necessary protection.   To protect the common market and domestic producers from over-imports from third countries, the EU must continue to implement a number of measures in the trade sector. Adequate management of quota regimes is necessary to adapt to a better Union market and better trade cooperation with third countries.  In 2014, the Republic of Croatia doubled beef production by 52% compared to 2013, beef imports by 142%, pigmeat by 60% while poultry meat by 44%. I expect further involvement of Croatian businessmen in more transparent trade cooperation with third countries.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. According to the Advisory Group on legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question is limited only to codifying existing texts without substantive changes. On the opening of certain Union tariff quotas for high-quality beef, pigmeat, poultry meat, wheat and cohaesives, and sows and other residues, and on the management of those quotas, the advisory group agreed that the proposal is indeed limited only to codifying existing texts without substantive changes, and I therefore support it.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which will take into account changes in the relationship between the EU and Turkey on the subject of agricultural products imported into the EU, such as high-quality beef, pigmeat, poultry, wheat and meslin, and brans, sharps and other residues.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. – The aim of the proposal is to open annual tariff quotas, whereby the Council regulation must be codified according to the procedure proposed by the Interinstitutional Agreement of 20 December 1994, which requires the accelerated formal codification of legislative texts. The purpose of the proposal is to undertake codification of the Council regulation of 29.3.1994. in the interest of clarity and rationality.  The European Union is in negotiations on customs concessions, relying on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and the Uruguayan Multilateral Trade Negotiations that led to agreements allowing certain annual tariff quotas to be opened for high-quality beef, pigmeat, poultry meat, wheat and cohats, and cons and other residues. In my view, the implementing acts should adopt the rules necessary for the application of the quotas set out in this Regulation, and, where appropriate, provisions guaranteeing the nature, origin and origin of the products, those provisions relating to the recognition of documents allowing those guarantees and provisions on import licence issues and their shelf life.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The existence of Union tariff quotas on agricultural or livestock products significantly restricts free trade.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on provisions for the opening and administration of certain EU tariff quotas for high-quality beef, pork, poultrymeat, wheat and double, dandra, dandra flour and other residues.  The codification procedure had to take into account the negotiations on customs agreements during the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and multilateral trade negotiations, which provide for the opening of annual tariff quotas for the abovementioned products.  An important element is that the Regulation foresames the introduction of a system guaranteeing the nature, origin and origin of the products. To this end, imports under agreed tariff rebatances may be required, if necessary, to produce a certificate of authenticity. The latter endeavour, in line with other EU origin designation efforts, greatly helps consumers and has a clear public health benefit.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the european Parliament and the Council's proposal for a regulation on the opening and management of certain EU tariff quotas for high-quality beef, pork, poultry meat, wheat and meteil and sounds, remoulages and other residues. As a representative of citizens in the areas of consumer protection but also in agriculture, I felt it was important to see a positive vote at the end of this session.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. The Regulation opens tariff quotas and facilitates the importation into the European Union of high-quality beef, pork, poultry meat, wheat and meteil and brans, remoulage and other residues rather than supporting very high-quality national sectors. So I voted AGAINST.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The codification of European legislation facilitates the understanding of European Union legislation. This legislative procedure envisages the clarification of the legislative act, but no substantive amendments to that act can be introduced through it. The European institutions agreed in 1994 to use an accelerated procedure with a view to the rapid adoption of codified acts. The legislative proposal which was the subject of the European Parliament's report concerns the codification of Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999. Council Regulation (EEC) No 774/94 of 29 March 1994 on the opening and management of certain Community tariff quotas for high-quality beef, pigmeat, poultrymeat, wheat, borceag and bran, breezes and other residues. Given that the codification proposal retains the full content of the codified acts and merely regroups them, making only the formal changes required by the coding operation itself and taking into account that the consultative working group of the legal services of the three European institutions recommends supporting this proposal, the European Parliament, by unanimous vote granted, supports the proposal to codify the Regulation.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted favourably on this technical report by the Committee on Legal Affairs on Tariff Tariffs.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel (PPE)
text: in writing. In view of the fact that this proposal has been analysed by the advisory group on the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, and that they have established that the proposal in question is limited to a codification of the existing acts in question, without making substantial amendments to that effect, it is understandable that the rapporteur considers its approval at first reading.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because this is a pure and simple technical question of the codification of existing acts without substantial changes. This legal amendment adjusts existing legislation without any impact on current legislation. It is because this is a technical issue which will have no major impact on producers and producers and I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this report is the codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 774/94 of 29 March 1994 on the opening and management of certain Union tariff quotas for high-quality beef, pigmeat, poultry meat, wheat and mixture of wheat with rye, bran, bran and other waste. Since 1987, all acts should be codified no later than 10 amendments in order to make EU legislation more accessible and easier for ordinary citizens to understand. In order to ensure the clarity and transparency of the law, it is necessary to codify the rules which have been frequently changed. This cannot be achieved as long as there is a scattering of numerous provisions, amended on several occasions.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. As long as domestic producers of high-quality meat and cereal products are not promoted to a greater extent, I cannot support a tariff quota scheme. I voted against this report in this respect.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this Report is the codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 774/94 of 29 March 1994 on the opening and management of certain Union tariff quotas for high-quality beef, pigmeat, poultry meat, wheat and mixture of wheat with rye, bran, bran and other waste. In 1987, the Commission decided to ask its services that all acts should be codified no later than 10 amendments in order to make EU legislation more accessible and easier for ordinary citizens to understand. This objective cannot be achieved as long as there is a scattering of numerous provisions, amended on several occasions, often substantially, which requires a reading of both the original act and the acts amending it. For this reason, it is necessary to code the rules that have been frequently changed.  This proposal is based on a pure and simple codification of the existing texts, without substantive amendments, and we have voted in favour.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because Turkey is an occupying power on the part of the territory of one of the Member States of the European Union, Cyprus. This agreement would therefore allow products from the occupied area to be introduced, recognising it as Turkish territory, in clear violation of the provisions of international law. In addition, the introduction of Turkish agricultural products will have a strong impact on European Mediterranean farmers, lowering prices and making it dependent on international trade for our food. We are committed to international trade that coexists with farmers and allows local agri-food systems that link production and consumption with the territory. It is for these two reasons that I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal on the introduction into the Community of agricultural products originating in Turkey merely constitutes a codification of existing texts, without modifying their substance, and I am voting in favour of its adoption.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. This is a mere codification without any change in the content of the legislation in question, and that is why I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. Turkey has introduced a 100% tax on imported livestock over the past two years, a tax that directly affects French livestock producers.  Today, rising Turkish beef prices are once again making French exports possible, but exports to Turkey are still subject to inspections by Turkish officials of French slaughterhouses. Such conditions are unacceptable, especially since this text provides for the establishment of "a preferential regime applicable to imports (...) turkey" at the expense of European agriculture. So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In line with my previous votes, I intended to vote against this resolution because UKIP MEPs believe that the UK should be in charge of its own system of preferences applicable to imports from Turkey to the UK.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because it is limited to an outright codification of the existing texts, without altering their substance.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on imports into the European Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey. The purpose of the proposal is to codify existing texts without changing their substance.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. Because I am opposed to Turkey's accession to the European Union, which the Eurocrats still hope to impose on the Europeans, and because I am very concerned about the plight of our farmers, I voted against this report.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text because it is an outright codification of the existing texts, without altering their substance.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This report aims to codify Regulation (EC) 779/98 of the Council of 7 April 1998 on the importation into the Community of agricultural products originating in Turkey. Products imported from Turkey therefore benefit from a preferential regime. This regime opens up even more of our markets, hit hard by the crisis, by rising raw material costs, by charges, by unfair competition and by the Russian embargo, to ever more imports from Turkey, countries with lower production costs and more flexible standards. The prerogative of foreign trade and customs barriers must, in my view, fall under the decision of the States and that is why I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the text which, although it does not introduce any change in substance, is a measure against which I would like to confirm my firm opposition on this occasion too.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council, as indicated by the Legal Services Advisory Group of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, with a view to the codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 779/98, 7 April 1998 on the importation into the Community of agricultural products originating in Turkey, repealing Regulation (EEC) No 4115/86 and amending Regulation (EC) No 3010/95, is limited to a simple codification of existing acts, without substantial changes.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which supports the proposal for a codification of the proposal on clarity and rationality of 7 April 1998. Council Regulation (EC) No 779/98 on imports into the European Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey. It should be noted that the Decision of the Association Council of the European Community and Turkey establishes a system of preferences for imports into the European Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey. In addition, where an approximate price is fixed for fishery products, the preferential tariff shall be applied on the basis of that price.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. According to the Advisory Group on legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal is limited only to codifying existing texts without substantive changes. I support the proposal.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, as I did last December in the Committee on Legal Affairs. Indeed, this codification text "established the preferential regime applicable to imports (...) agricultural products originating in Turkey." We must take a clear and frank position on the status, vis-à-vis the European Union, turkey, which we very courteously let hope to join this collective hysteria in vain. Let us dare to tell them that the peoples of Europe do not want their country to be integrated into the European Union. Even the founding fathers of this "thing" did not imagine it. Thus, Robert Schuman's answer, when asked about the borders of this Europe, was unequivocal: "As long as there are churches"... It is important to protect our trade borders, especially in the agricultural sector, because this sector is in great danger in France as in Europe. Let us not give in to the sirens of free trade.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I consider that the import of agricultural products from a neighbouring country such as Turkey is very important for improvement of the competitiveness of the European market. But it should be well regulated.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. The proposal in this case is intended to codify Regulation (EC) 779/98 of the Council of 7 April 1998 relating to the importation into the Community of agricultural products originating in Turkey. This regulation gives imports of Turkish agricultural products a preferential regime. The proposal sets out "the uniform conditions for the implementation of this regime, giving the Commission the powers to carry out".  I strongly dispute any preferential agreement of the Union with Turkey which would result in unfair competition with our farmers, as well as the enforcement competence conferred on the Commission, which does not have to substitute for the Member States in their trade policy towards third countries.  That is why I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the context of a citizens' Europe, the Commission attaches great importance to the simplification and clarity of Union law in order to make it more legible and accessible to the citizen, thereby giving him greater opportunities to make use of the specific rights conferred on him. This cannot be achieved if there are countless changes to the provisions, and these, having been met at least 10 times, are not codified. The codification merely ensures greater legal certainty with regard to the applicable law in relation to a specific issue. I voted in favour of the coding report because it retains the full content of the codified acts, limiting itself to regrouping them, bringing only the changes in the form of the act, which was required by the coding procedure itself.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Simplifying and making EU legislation more accessible is one of the objectives of European lawmakers. Codification serves this purpose and allows a compilation of legislation dealing with the same theme. I voted in favour of the report on the codification of the importation into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the need to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 779/98 of 7 April 1998 on imports into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey. Codification must be carried out in full compliance with the process of adopting Union legislation.  It is essential to simplify and clarify the regulatory environment of the Union, so as to make it simpler, more stable and more predictable for businesses, workers and consumers, since a uniform provision must be adopted to establish the specific implementing rules necessary for the implementation of the import regime for agricultural products originating in Turkey. Ensuring legal certainty applicable to a given subject at a specific time cannot be achieved as long as the regulatory provisions are amended several times, so that they remain scattered. Simplification requires not only a common method, but also a common spirit.  Therefore, in reiterating my vote in favour, I call on the institutions and the Member States to make the necessary effort to simplify the regulatory environment.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as its implementation will provide for greater legal certainty and clarity. This report primarily relates to codification of legal texts. This is important as, if a text is not codified, previous amended versions of it remain in force. Codification is - in a nutshell - simplification.   Any proposal that provides greater legal clarity and transparency should be welcomed as it is the complex nature of such texts which frequently leads to unnecessary legal challenges, often at taxpayers' expense.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The opinion of the legal services of the three Community institutions confirms that this vote aims at a mere codification of the existing texts, without any substantial changes. However, we will monitor future developments in order to protect the interests of our farmers.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which provides for the codification of a preferential regime for the importation of agricultural products from Turkey. Apart from the fact that the European Union is self-sufficient in terms of agricultural production, the unfair competition that Turkish production would impose on our agri-food industry would be contrary to the interests of our fellow citizens. Moreover, we cannot accept the importation of Turkish products even though Turkey has been applying an import ban on some of our products, including beef, since 1996. In this context, it is out of the question to apply a preferential regime beyond reciprocity.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The measure deals with the mere codification without substantial changes of the supervision that the European Union has provided with regard to the import of agricultural products from Turkey, trying to safeguard and protect the products of this sector of the Community especially those of Italy. That is why I voted in favour of the measure

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With reference to Regulation (EC) No 779/98, I welcome the work of regulation and supervision by the Union with regard to the import into the Community of agricultural products originating in Turkey, because this will provide greater protection for Italian products and interests in this sector. Since the resolution is limited to a mere codification of the 1998 regulation, quite rightly without making any substantial changes, I voted in favour of the new text.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr President, this proposal was examined by the Advisory Group on 14 October 2014, which concluded, by common accord, that this proposal is limited to a mere codification of the existing texts, without any substantial changes. I therefore felt it appropriate to vote in favour.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The proposal in question contains a straightforward codification of the existing texts without any change in their substance. I thus voted in favour of the report on codification.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report concerns a proposal on the codification of EU law. It is, in fact, a purely technical procedure, provided for in Article 103 of the Regulation and aimed at verifying that the codification proposal is in fact limited to mere codification, without any substantial changes. Each codification proposal is examined in advance by the legal services of the Commission, the Council and Parliament. The conclusions of this assessment are then sent to the Committee on Legal Affairs for validation and then voted on in plenary for parliament's final approval.  In view of the favourable legal opinions on this matter, I am voting in favour of the report on the import into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This proposal for the codification of the act regarding the import into the European Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey fully preserves the content of said act. Due to the fact that this is a technical procedure with the contents of the regulations being preserved, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I have approved the European Commission's proposal on this report on the main codified provisions on the preferential regime for importing agricultural products from Turkey into the EU. The proposal is limited to a simple codification of existing texts, it does not change their content in any way.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against the proposal to import agricultural products from Turkey into the EU. In particular, I note that Turkey has introduced a 100% tax on imported livestock over the past two years, a tax that directly affects French livestock producers.  Today, the rise in Turkish beef prices makes French exports possible again, but nothing has been done yet, because our exports to Turkey are still subject to inspections by Turkish officials of French slaughterhouses. Such conditions are unacceptable, especially since this text provides for the establishment of "a preferential regime applicable to imports (...) turkey" at the expense of European agriculture.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report deals with the codification within EU law of Regulation 779/98 on the importation of agricultural products from Turkey, which has been substantially amended several times. In particular, the proposed regulation sets out the uniform conditions for the implementation of the regime for importing agricultural products from Turkey into the EU, giving the European Commission enforcement powers.  I support this text as a simple exercise in codifying positive law, without any change in substance. For this reason, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The report concerns codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 779/98 of 7 April 1998 on the import into the Community of agricultural products originating in Turkey. The main provisions codified include Decision No 1/98 of the EC-Turkey Association Council, which establishes the system of preferences applicable to imports into the EU of agricultural products originating in Turkey. It sets out uniform conditions for the implementation of this system and, in the case of products for which EU regulations require a certain import price to be observed, it states that the application of the preferential tariff system will be subject to the that price.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report as I do not wish to contribute to any trade with Turkey, especially with regard to products produced in Greece as well.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal to codify the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on imports into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey. It also follows from this theme how important trade is to the EU economy. The hungarian poultry sector, which has been developing stablely recently, also generates significant revenue from the export of various poultry products. However, the situation has changed radically. Avian influenza has been caused by the migration of wild birds in poultry farms in Füzesgyarmat in Békés county. The Hungarian authorities reacted immediately, completely quarantined the endangered area, where more than 100,000 ducks were destroyed. More broadly, a monitoring zone has been selected. The control of avian influenza is therefore carried out effectively, professionally and in close cooperation with the European Commission. Notwithstanding the above, a number of Far Eastern countries and Russia, which are important for Hungarian poultry exports, have imposed import bans on all Hungarian poultry products. According to the estimates of the trade associations, the loss of turnover in the Hungarian poultry sector will be around EUR 34.5 million over the next three months, and the final damage is even greater. This is a huge loss. That is why I am asking for the assistance of Agriculture Commissioner Phil Hogan to quickly find together the EU crisis management tools that can be used immediately to save Hungarian poultry farmers from even more serious damage.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. The purpose of this proposal is to codified Council Regulation (EC) No 779/98 of 7 April 1998 on the importation into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey, repealing Regulation (EEC) No 4115/86 and amending Regulation (EC) No 3010/95. Regulation (EC) No 779/98 has been substantially amended on a number of occasions and should be codified for the sake of greater rationality and clarity. This codification provides legal certainty with respect to the law applicable in this area and will help to determine the provisions in force.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have approved the pure and simple codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 779/98, of 7 April 1998 on imports into the Community of agricultural products originating in Turkey, which repeals Regulation (EEC) No 4115/86 and amends Regulation (EC) No 3010/95 - the proposal under question is based on a pure and simple codification of existing texts without substantive amendments.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report examines the proposal for a Regulation, by which Council Regulation (EC) No 779/98 is codified, on the import into the Community of agricultural products originating in Turkey, which repeals Regulation (EEC) No 4115/86 and amends Regulation (EC) No 3010/95, has enabled the Advisory Group to conclude by common agreement, and is compending on a pure and simple codification of existing texts without substantive amendments.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. While Turkey is multiplying the bad deeds towards the Member States of the European Union such as Cyprus, its more than murky game is increasingly revealed in Syria, the Erdogan system is compressing, in total indifference, the most basic freedoms, the European Parliament, lying before the Commission, is considering engraving in stone the commercial preference enjoying Turkey. If the Turkish people, who followed the Model of Ataturk making them a people capable of secularism and freedom, remain and always remain a friendly people, there can be no question of granting any satisfaction to the accession process that this deliberation, like many others, aims to advance with a covered face. Moreover, in the context of the current suffering of our farmers, this text is a real provocation. For all this reason, sovereignists and opponents of Euro-globalist federalism oppose such deliberation.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this report is the codification of the Regulation establishing a concession to Turkey in the form of a Community tariff quota for hazelnuts and suspending certain concessions. The Commission has decided to ask its services that all acts should be codified no later than 10 amendments in order to make EU legislation more accessible and easier to understand. This objective cannot be achieved as long as there is a scattering of numerous provisions, amended on several occasions, often substantially, which requires a reading of both the original act and the acts amending it. For this reason, and in order to ensure the clarity and transparency of the law, it is necessary to codify the rules which have been frequently changed.   This proposal is based on a pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantive amendments. Despite the essentially technical nature of this proposal, it weighed on the vote of our group (against), which we are following, the persistence of an illegal occupation by Turkey of part of the territory of Cyprus.

name: Raffaele Fitto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal concerns a simple codification of existing texts, without any substantial changes. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 The proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council based on the Interinstitutional Agreement of 20 May 1994 on imports into the European Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey needed re-codification to improve the application of this Regulation.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting negatively on the text even if this is only a process of "codification" of the texts that does not introduce any change in substance, thus reiterating our position of opposition to the substance of the proposal.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am opposed to any trade with Turkey, especially with regard to products produced in my country, Greece.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of the proposal as it is a straightforward codification of existing texts without any change in their substance.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted positively in favour of this report and consider it of the utmost importance to simplify and make the EU legislation more transparent in order to make it clearer and more accessible to citizens, thus further expanding the possibilities for exercising the rights granted to them. I agree with the codification of the acts which have been amended several times, which is essential for the clarity and transparency of the legislation and for reducing the time needed to compare the considerable research work required to establish the provisions in force with a number of acts, and I agree with the rapporteur's view that codification creates legal certainty.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report after examining the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council, and to find that this is a proposal is limited to a pure and simple codification of existing acts, without substantial changes.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal as it represents a positive and necessary rationalisation of existing legislation on the European market for agricultural products originating in Turkey.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. A few minutes ago, we voted on an important report on the analysis of Turkey's political progress in the accession negotiations with the European Union. I shall not dwell on this report, which deserves to be debated and deepened and which I will therefore deal with in a further statement, but I would like to stress my vote in favour of mr Duda's measure, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs, in which we are going to lay down more certain rules relating to the import into the EU of agricultural products originating in Turkey.  Thanks also to the opinion of the legal services of the three Community institutions, we are merely codifying the existing texts, without any substantial changes, but it is a further step towards deeper commercial integration with Turkey, to the benefit of consumers and businesses.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against the proposal to import agricultural products from Turkey into the EU. In particular, I note that Turkey has introduced a 100% tax on imported livestock over the past two years, a tax that directly affects French farmers.  Today, the rise in Turkish beef prices makes French exports possible again, but nothing has been done yet, as our exports to Turkey are still subject to inspections of French slaughterhouses by Turkish officials.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which is part of a larger group of codification files being votes on. This codification takes into account changes in the relationship between the EU and Turkey on the subject of agricultural products.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation by Parliament and the Council on imports of agricultural products originating in Turkey into the Union, because it is the codification process that contributes to simplifying and explaining EUROPEAN Union law in the context of Citizens' Europe, so that the legal texts of the Union are as clear and transparent as possible. In this context, I support an interinstitutional agreement allowing for an accelerated process of adopting codified acts, and for Commission staff to codify acts after a maximum of ten amendments. In addition, I believe it is important to enable citizens to access their rights without difficulty and to ensure their guarantee.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against the proposal to import agricultural products from Turkey into the EU. In particular, I note that Turkey has introduced a 100% tax on imported livestock over the past two years, a tax that directly affects French farmers.  Today, the rise in Turkish beef prices makes French exports possible again, but nothing has been done yet, because our exports to Turkey are still subject to inspections by Turkish officials of French slaughterhouses. Such conditions are unacceptable, especially since this text provides for the establishment of "a preferential regime applicable to imports (...) turkey" at the expense of European agriculture.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Andrzej Duda's report on the importation of agricultural products from Turkey into the Union. As part of the effort to simplify European law, the aim here is to codify a set of existing provisions on the same subject, in order to integrate them into a single, clearer and simpler text. This report was adopted by a very large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report to codify the Council's regulation on the importation into the EU of agricultural products originating in Turkey. In the interests of clarity and transparency of the law, the procedure known as the formal codification of legislation allows all amendments and revisions to a text to be merged without altering its substance.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report as it is simply a codification to take into account changes in the relationship between the EU and Turkey on the subject of agricultural products.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Why did I vote against the reports today on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on imports into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey, when this is in fact a mere legal codification of the status quo? The reason is quite simple, I wanted to express my solidarity and solidarity with my colleagues in Cyprus. As is widely known, even after three decades of trying to change, the island of Cyprus is still divided into two parts, the Republic of Cyprus and the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus, which is occupied by Turkish troops. In view of this monarchy, and given that the two codified texts also deal with the adjustment of exports from the occupied territory of Cyprus to the EU, I have decided, as an expression of my opposition to the current political situation on this island, which is essentially an occupied EU country, to vote against these reports.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of Andrzej Duda's report because its aim is to codify the regulation on the import into the European Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey. Here, too, the rapporteur's proposal, Mr Beazley, is a good one. Duda, of a technical nature, is limited to a mere codification of the existing texts.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. The package of trade measures and provisions that build a trading space with Turkey, including preferential regimes for the importation of agricultural products from Turkey, is an essential part of the process of political integration into the Union. The codification supported by the report before us contributes to the strengthening and updating of this regulatory framework, which I oppose; that is why I voted against this report.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this text because it confirms the "preferential regime" that Turkey enjoys for importing its agricultural products into the Union.  However, I am against this preferential treatment because it opens the way to unfair competition, of which our farmers would be the victims. Moreover, there is no reason to give gifts to a state that promotes illegal maritime immigration into the Union and is complacent towards the 'Islamic State'.

name: Philippe Loiseau (NI)
text: In writing. Against this report. Once again, the European Union is not listening to the concerns of farmers in the Member States. As a French farmer, I am listening to my colleagues, who are tired of seeing the European market open to agricultural products. The regulation provides for a preferential regime for the importation of agricultural products originating in Turkey. We reject that decision. On the contrary, there is an urgent need to apply strong restrictions on imports in order to protect our agriculture. The European Union has an illogical policy of supporting agriculture that weakens those of the Member States.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because Turkey is an occupying power on the part of the territory of one of the Member States of the European Union, Cyprus. This agreement would therefore allow products from the occupied area to be introduced, recognising it as Turkish territory, in clear violation of the provisions of international law. In addition, the introduction of Turkish agricultural products will have a strong impact on European Mediterranean farmers, lowering prices and making it dependent on international trade for our food. We are committed to international trade that coexists with farmers and allows local agri-food systems that link production and consumption with the territory. It is for these two reasons that I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The codified version of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the importation into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey contains only amendments and recommendations which do not change the substance of the Regulation; I therefore believe that this proposal should be accepted, following the recommendations of the Legal Services Advisory Group of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Turkey has been associated with an EU country since 1963. Relations with Turkey are important for the Union, they must be strengthened in the area of economic cooperation. Agricultural products must enter the EU market on clear rules, which will only facilitate cooperation between the two parties. I, together with 583 Members, supported this decision, even though 112 colleagues were against.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the import into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey, because the import of agricultural products originating in Turkey will irreparably damage the economic interests of Greek and Cypriot farmers who have been impoverished by the Memorandums. Moreover, as Ankara systematically violates international law towards Greece and Cyprus and refuses to comply with the terms and conditions of its pre-accession course, it is obvious that it is not entitled to any favourable treatment of its products by the EU.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. Vote against this regulation. Indeed, this change is a change of form and not of substance, and establishes "the preferential regime applicable to imports (...) agricultural products originating in Turkey." However, we are against this preferential treatment.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report as the proposal in question contains a straightforward codification of the existing texts without any change in their substance.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the import into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey.  Such codification increases the guarantee of clarity and immediate understanding of the provisions, thus contributing to more efficient work. It is important to bear in mind that the existence of the common agricultural policy (CAP) makes it possible in the EU to have controlled and safer products for all citizens, and this is one of the very important EU policies occupying around 34 % of the EU budget. An initiative to make a positive contribution to food safety in important products is therefore to be welcomed.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this proposal concerns the codification of the Regulation on the import by the European Union of agricultural products from Turkey.  Since the proposal by the rapporteur, Mr Duda, is limited to a mere codification of the existing texts, I have decided to support it with a vote in favour.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. I firmly rejected the proposal on imports into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey. Domestic agricultural producers should be spared further burdens.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Codification consists of grouping normative texts of various natures into collections concerning a given subject with the aim of simplification, clarity and transparency.  The purpose of this proposal is to codify Regulation (EC) 779/98 of the Council of 7 April 1998 relating to the importation into the Community of agricultural products originating in Turkey. This regulation establishes a preferential regime for the importation into the EU of agricultural products originating in Turkey and confers enforcement powers on the Commission.   Opposed to the Commission's control in this area and even if it is only a technical report, I vote against it. These undemocratic technocratic procedures prevent Europe from practising solidarity protectionism, which is the ecological and social emergency of our time.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 We deal here only with a technical issue. The purpose of this proposal is to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 779/98 of 7 April 1998 on imports into the Community of agricultural products originating in Turkey, repealing Regulation (EEC) No 4115/86 and amending Regulation (EC) No 3010/95. The new Regulation will replace the various acts contained therein. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report regarding the importation of agricultural products originating in Turkey into the EU because the consultative working party of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission concluded that the proposed codification of the existing texts is straightforward and presents no change in their substance. It is crucial that agreements that have been amended many times be codified in order to ensure that they are accessible and clear to citizens.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the import into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey. The proposal fully preserves the content of the acts being codified.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it aims to simplify Union legislation by codify it. This document makes no substantive amendment to the content concerned, as transcribed in the opinion of the Advisory Group on Legal Services of the European Parliament.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing.
