The proposal in this case is intended to codify Regulation (EC) 779/98 of the Council of 7 April 1998 relating to the importation into the Community of agricultural products originating in Turkey. It gives imports of Turkish agricultural products a preferential regime.  The proposal sets out "the uniform conditions for the implementation of this regime, giving the Commission the powers to carry out".  I formally challenge any preferential agreement with Turkey, as well as any competence of the European Union in the foreign trade of the Member States, which must be theirs.  That is why I voted against this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which will take into account the changes in the relationship between the EU and Turkey on the subject of agricultural products.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the codification of the Council regulation on the importation into the Community of agricultural products originating in Turkey. This regulation has been amended several times and substantially, so that its provisions are now found for one part in the original act and for the rest scattered in the amending acts that followed.  In the interests of clarity and simplification of the law, guaranteeing greater legal certainty and better information for citizens, it was therefore necessary to codify this regulation. This process completely preserves its substance and merely brings together in a legible way the various changes that have been made to it.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this proposal for a regulation on the import into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey, as it is limited to a mere codification of existing texts, without therefore containing any substantial changes to the original agreement.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because the proposal in question is limited to an outright codification of the existing texts, without altering their substance.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this proposal is to initiate the codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 779/98 of 7 April 1998 on imports into the Community of agricultural products originating in Turkey, repealing Regulation (EEC) No 4115/86 and amending Regulation (EC) No 3010/95. Since the proposal by the rapporteur, Mr Duda, is limited to a mere codification of the existing texts, without making the same substantial changes, I felt it appropriate to support it with a vote in favour.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report because, through it, the European Parliament and the Council come to regulate the rules relating to 'import into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey'.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the draft on imports into the EU of agricultural products originating in Turkey. The proposal is limited to the codification of existing legislation without any substantive changes.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Ladies and gentlemen, given that, according to the Advisory Group of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, this proposal is limited to a mere codification of the existing texts, without any substantial changes.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The Regulation on Imports of Agricultural Products originating in Turkey to the Union adopted in 1998 has been repeatedly amended. This procedure, and in the interests of clarity and rationality, on the basis of a Decision of the European Commission of 1 April 1987, endorsed the Recommendations of the European Council confirmed in December 1992. Since 20 December 1994, codifying Council Regulation (EC) No 779/98 of 7 April 1998 and abolishing Regulation (EEC) No 4115/86 and Regulation (EC) No 3010/95.  As Decision No 1/98 of the EC-Turkey Association Council establishes a system of preferences applicable to imports into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey, the proposal for a regulation lays down the unified conditions for the implementation of that system. The proposal for a new Regulation will unite the various amendments that were covered by the previous procedures for amending the basic act, while preserving the material content of the act in full.  Since I have personally always advocated for transparent legal texts, without the need to painstakingly consult their multiple amendments that, often vaguely, run through various acts, which make it difficult for interested parties to navigate and read, and ultimately to apply these acts, I welcome this codification.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. The proposal in this case is intended to codify Regulation (EC) 779/98 of the Council of 7 April 1998 relating to the importation into the Community of agricultural products originating in Turkey. It gives imports of Turkish agricultural products a preferential regime.  The proposal sets out "the uniform conditions for the implementation of this regime, giving the Commission the powers to carry out".  I formally challenge any preferential agreement with Turkey, as well as any competence of the European Union in the foreign trade of the Member States, which must be theirs.  That is why I voted against this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. According to the Advisory Group on legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question is limited only to codifying existing texts without substantive changes. This formal procedure increases the transparency of the process and allows citizens to be fully informed about this topic through simplified rules, so I support it.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support MEP Andrzej Duda's report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on imports of agricultural products originating in Turkey into the Union because an advisory group of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission pointed out that the proposal limits itself to codifying existing texts without substantive changes. The purpose of the proposal is the codification procedure for Regulation No 1000/2013. 779/98 since April 7, 1998, which has changed several times. The new regulation brings together scattered acts and transfers the content of scattered acts into a single act with the formal amendments needed for codification, which contributes to transparency and transparency. The European Parliament hereby supports a simplification that will make Union law clearer and more accessible to EU citizens. I welcome the continued efforts of parliament's professional services, the Council and the Commission in codification procedures.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Again I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the import into the European Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey because, with an opinion of 12/11/2014 of the Advisory Group on Legal Services, this is a mere codification of the existing texts, without major changes

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament recently adopted the revision, the various amendments to the text and the accumulations of different texts regulating imports into the Eu-15 countries of agricultural products originating in Turkey. I have spoken in favour of this administrative provision in order to have a single, simpler and clearer text.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 At its meeting of 14 October 2014, the Advisory Group composed of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, council regulation of 7 April 1998 on imports of agricultural products originating in Turkey, which repeals Regulation (EC) No 779/98 of the Council of 7 April 1998 on imports into the Community of agricultural products originating in Turkey, repealing Regulation (EEC) No 4115/86 and amending Regulation (EC) No 3010/95. It then concluded, by common agreement, that the proposal under question should be based on a pure and simple codification of the existing texts, without substantive amendments. I voted, therefore, in favor.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it is limited to corrections and additions to existing documents, without substantive amendments thereof.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since the Advisory Group on the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission has delivered a positive opinion and considers that this proposal is limited to the pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantive amendments to the texts, there is no reason to vote against or even to abstain.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council, as indicated by the Legal Services Advisory Group of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, with a view to the codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 779/98, 7 April 1998 on the importation into the Community of agricultural products originating in Turkey, repealing Regulation (EEC) No 4115/86 and amending Regulation (EC) No 3010/95, is limited to a simple codification of existing acts, without substantial changes.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this proposal is to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 1506/1998 of 13 July 1998, establishing a concession to Turkey in the form of a Community tariff quota in 1998 for hazelnuts and suspending certain concessions.  In so far as it is a purely technical issue, which aims at the pure and simple codification of existing texts and does not entail major amendments, I decided to give my vote in favour of it.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on the importation into the Eu of agricultural products originating in Turkey.  This is a Commission proposal that echoes the recommendations of the European Parliament's Legal Services Advisory Group, the Council and the Commission. This proposal is thus limited to an outright codification of existing texts, without altering their substance.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote against it because it is a mere process of 'codifying' texts, a formal procedure that does not introduce any change in substance, relating to a measure against which we confirm our position of opposition.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this purely technical report, which is limited to codifying existing acts, without altering their substance.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (NI)
text: In writing. The regulation under codification "established the preferential regime applicable to importation (...) agricultural products originating in Turkey." I oppose Turkey's entry into the EU and do not accept that it should have facilities to export its agricultural materials to our states, thereby endangering local producers.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because Turkey is an occupying power on the part of the territory of one of the Member States of the European Union, Cyprus. This agreement would therefore allow products from the occupied area to be introduced, recognising it as Turkish territory, in clear violation of the provisions of international law. In addition, the introduction of Turkish agricultural products will have a strong impact on European Mediterranean farmers, lowering prices and making it dependent on international trade for our food. We are committed to international trade that coexists with farmers and allows local agri-food systems that link production and consumption with the territory. It is for these two reasons that I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I understand and agree with the codification process, in order to promote greater clarity of the normative acts, resulting from the need to take into account the different amendments they have been subject to in the event that they are more than ten, which have passed through the scrutiny of the ordinary legislative procedure of the respective time in which they occurred. This codification process should not, by its nature, alter the content of the act to which it refers and should be limited to a purely technical procedure, and it is in this spirit that I am voting on this dossier today.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the import into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey. I welcome the codification to take into account changes in the relationship between the EU and Turkey on the subject of agricultural products.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Since, according to the Advisory Group of legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question is limited only to codifying existing texts without substantive changes, and the advisory group, after considering the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on codification of the Council Regulation (EC), is the no. 779/98 of 7 April 1998 on imports of agricultural products originating in Turkey into the Community, repealing Regulation (EEC) No 1999. 4115/86 and amends Regulation (EC) No 4115/86. 3010/95 consensually concluded that the proposal is indeed limited only to codifying existing texts without substantive changes, I support the report matically.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which will take into account changes in the relationship between the EU and Turkey on the subject of agricultural products.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the report for the regulation of concessions relating to imports into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey. The Advisory Group of the LEGAL SERVICE of the EP, the Council and the Commission points out that the proposal contains the formal codification of existing legislative texts without interfering with their content. The Committee on Legal Affairs accepted a report aimed at clarifying and rationalising the codification of the Regulation Council No 1001/2013. 1506/98 of July 1998 established by the Turkey Tariff Quota Community to suspend certain concessions. The aim of the new regulation is to replace the acts without changing the core and as such combine them with official amendments as required by codification in itself.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. From a technical point of view, the codification process is only intended to simplify and better understand legislation. The report explicitly states that there is no amendment to the substance of the Rules of Procedure. However, from a political point of view, there is a problem with the original regulation as Turkey does not recognise the Republic of Cyprus and therefore the Republic of Cyprus is not included in the agreement. In addition, there is no clear reference to the issue of agricultural products originating in the occupied territories. That is why we voted against the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Products produced in Member States of the European Union should be preferred and supported by their third country counterparts

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on imports into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey.  While I consider it important to make eu legislation clear, transparent, easy to interpret and accessible to all, the Regulation is of paramount importance in the functioning of the preferential regime applicable to imports into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey. For example, for products where EU regulations require compliance with a certain import price, the application of the preferential customs system depends on compliance with this price, the follow-up of which is becoming increasingly difficult.  It is therefore essential that the provisions, which have been amended many times, are available in one place in an orderly form.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the european Parliament and the Council's proposal for a regulation on the importation of agricultural products from Turkey into the Eu. I deplore the comments made in debate by extremist elected officials on this issue; making these issues a racist polemic is bad for the issue and for the image of Europe.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. The Regulation establishes a preferential regime for the importation (...) of agricultural products originating in Turkey. I obviously voted AGAINST.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The codification of European legislation facilitates the understanding of European Union legislation. This legislative procedure envisages the clarification of the legislative act, but no substantive amendments to that act can be introduced through it. The European institutions agreed in 1994 to use an accelerated procedure with a view to the rapid adoption of codified acts. The legislative proposal which was the subject of the European Parliament's report concerns the codification of Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999. Council Regulation (EEC) No 779/98 of 7 April 1998 on the importation into the Community of agricultural products originating in Turkey, repealing Regulation (EEC) No 2377/90, Regulation (EC) No 4115/86 and amending Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999 laying down detailed rules for the application of Council Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999 3010/95. Given that the codification proposal retains the content of the codified acts in its entirety and merely groups them together, making only the formal changes required by the codification operation itself and taking into account that the consultative working group of the legal services of the three European institutions recommends supporting this proposal, the European Parliament, by unanimous vote granted, supports the proposal for codification of the regulation.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this unreputed technical report by the Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because Turkey is an occupying power on the part of the territory of one of the Member States of the European Union, Cyprus. This agreement would therefore allow products from the occupied area to be introduced, recognising it as Turkish territory, in clear violation of the provisions of international law. In addition, the introduction of Turkish agricultural products will have a strong impact on European Mediterranean farmers, lowering prices and making it dependent on international trade for our food. We are committed to international trade that coexists with farmers and allows local agri-food systems that link production and consumption with the territory. It is for these two reasons that I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this report is to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 779/98 of 7 April 1998 on imports into the Community of agricultural products originating in Turkey, repealing Regulation (EEC) No 4115/86 and amending Regulation (EC) No 3010/95. Since 1987, all acts should be codified no later than 10 amendments in order to make EU legislation more accessible and easier for ordinary citizens to understand. In order to ensure the clarity and transparency of the law, it is necessary to codify the rules which have been frequently changed. This cannot be achieved as long as there is a scattering of numerous provisions, amended on several occasions.  This proposal is based on a pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantive amendments. However, we draw attention to the fact that Turkey illegally occupies part of cyprus, and we take this opportunity to demand from the EU a firm position of legality in this matter.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. I strongly opposed the regime for the import of agricultural products originating in Turkey into the EU, as I believe that this would place a further burden on domestic agricultural producers, which should be spared them.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this Report is to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 779/98 of 7 April 1998 on imports into the Community of agricultural products originating in Turkey, repealing Regulation (EEC) No 4115/86 and amending Regulation (EC) No 3010/95. In 1987, the Commission decided to ask its services that all acts should be codified no later than 10 amendments in order to make EU legislation more accessible and easier for the citizen to understand. We voted against turkey, a country that illegally occupies part of cyprus, denying the Cypriot people their most basic rights. Furthermore, the original agreement itself does not recognise the Republic of Cyprus and makes it possible for the occupied part of Cyprus to the EU to be illegally exported to the EU.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because this is a technical change in Turkey's agricultural products. Despite its technical nature it involves this country, which is an occupying power on the part of the territory of one of the member states of the European Union, Cyprus. This agreement would therefore allow products from the occupied area to be introduced, recognising it as Turkish territory, in clear violation of the provisions of international law. In addition, the introduction of Turkish agricultural products will have a strong impact on European Mediterranean farmers, lowering prices and making it dependent on international trade for our food. We are committed to international trade that coexists with farmers and allows local agri-food systems that link production and consumption with the territory. It is for these two reasons that I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The proposal concerning the introduction of a concession for Turkey, in the form of a Community tariff quota for 1998, as regards hazelnuts and the suspension of certain concessions, merely constitutes a codification of the existing texts, without modifying their substance, and I am voting in favour of its adoption.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. This is a mere codification without any change in the content of the legislation in question, and that is why I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. It is essential to give priority to local production at the various levels - national, European and then international. The suspension of certain import concessions would promote agricultural production in EU Member States. In addition, Turkey has been implementing a ban on the import of live oxen since 1996, as well as restrictions on the import of beef. While I respect this protectionist decision of a sovereign state, I nevertheless hope that the principle of reciprocity will be applied, and that, in turn, the Member States of the Union can exercise their right to defend their production, and in particular their agriculture. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This vote was to suspend certain concessions currently given to Turkey. To vote in favour would provide implicit acceptance of the current system; to vote against might condone actions by Turkey in breach of an Agreement. Therefore, I intended to abstain as the most logical option.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because it is limited to an outright codification of the existing texts, without altering their substance.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal to suspend certain concessions on imports into the European Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey. The purpose of the proposal is to codify existing texts without changing their substance.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. Turkey has banned the importation of live beef since 1996 and restricts the importation of beef.   I therefore logically voted in favour of this report, which proposes to 'counterbalance the situation with equivalent measures'.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text because it is an outright codification of the existing texts, without altering their substance.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to codify Regulation (EC) No. 1506/98 of the Council of 13 July 1998 suspending certain concessions. Although I challenge the European Union's prerogatives with regard to The Foreign Trade of the Member States, this text wants to impose the principle of reciprocity in our relations with Turkey, which prohibits and restricts the importation of certain categories of live beef and beef from the Union. This point is contrary to paragraph 21 of the codified regulation and I therefore voted in favour of this suspension of concessions.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the text which, although it does not introduce any change in substance, is a measure against which I would like to confirm my firm opposition on this occasion too.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this because, as indicated by the Legal Services Advisory Group of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council, with a view to the codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 1506/98 of 13 July 1998 establishing a concession in favour of Turkey in the form of a Community hazelnut tariff quota for 1998 and suspending certain concessions, is limited to a simple codification of existing acts, without substantial amendments.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which supports the proposal for a codification of the proposal for clarity and rationality of 13 July 1998. Council Regulation (EC) No 1506/98. This Regulation establishes a Community tariff quota for Turkey as a concession for hazelnuts and suspends other concessions. The Decision of the Association Council between the European Community and Turkey provides for the improvement and strengthening of trade preferences for imports into the European Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey. In addition, incentives should be laid down for exports of meat and live animals from the European Union to Turkey.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 The resolution is limited only to codifying existing texts without substanation changes. I support the text.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (NI)
text: In writing. As we joyfully open our borders, "Turkey has been implementing since 1996 an import ban" on live oxen "and restrictions on the import of beef" which are in complete contradiction with the regulation affected by this codification text. Turkey is not living up to its commitments and is applying quantitative restrictions on the import of beef, contrary to the agreement. I therefore voted in favour of these retaliatory measures against actions that penalize our farmers and an entire sector of the agricultural world.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I consider that the import of products from Turkey is positive but must be well regulated and controlled regarding protection of the health of the European citizens.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. The purpose of the proposal is to codify Regulation (EC) No. 1506/98 of the Council of 13 July 1998 suspending certain concessions.  Turkey enforces bans and restrictions on the import of live beef and beef from the European Union.  If this text, which is merely codification, aims to impose on Turkey a principle of reciprocity in its trade relations with the European Union, we challenge the Union with any holding of prerogatives relating to the foreign trade of the Member States.  This report demonstrates, if necessary, that agricultural protectionism is a common practice in many sovereign states, which requires a swift and effective response that the European Union is unable to carry out. That is why it is up to the Member States to enforce the principle of reciprocity. This text goes in the right direction, but I nevertheless voted in favour.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this codification report because it fully preserves the content of the codified acts, limiting itself to regrouping them and making only the changes in the form of the act required by the codification procedure itself.  Decision No 1/2002/EC of 1/98 of the Council on association with Turkey provides for the improvement and strengthening of trade preferences relating to the import into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey and establishes a number of preferential concessions for Union exports for live meat and animal products. Since 1996, Turkey has been banned from importing live bovine animals and restrictions on importing beef. As a result of these measures, exports of the products concerned from the Union to Turkey are blocked. That is why the measure to suspend certain concessions comes as a result of the protection of the Union's commercial interests, which is to be welcomed.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is the approval of a mere process of codification of texts, a formal procedure that does not introduce any change in substance, relating to a measure against which I confirm my position of opposition.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The codification of legislation is a kind of compilation of different European regulations that address the same theme. The aim is to simplify and make European legislation more accessible.  I voted in favour of this report on codifying the suspension of certain concessions relating to the importation into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the need to codify Regulation (EC) No 1506/98 of 13 July 1998 suspending certain concessions relating to imports into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey. Ensuring legal certainty applicable to a given subject becomes a priority in order to successfully implement the Lisbon Strategy. It is therefore essential to simplify and clarify the regulatory environment of the European Union, so as to make it simpler, more stable and more predictable for businesses, workers and, above all, consumers, in order to prevent many provisions from remaining 'scattered'. These objectives cannot be achieved as long as the regulatory provisions are amended several times. Regulation (EC) No 255/2014 of 26 February 2014 amending Council Regulations (EC) No 2008/97, (EC) No 779/98 and Regulation (EC) No 1506/98 on imports of olive oil and other agricultural products from Turkey with regard to delegated powers and implementing powers to be conferred on the Commission. In reiterating what has already been said, I hope that all the institutions and the Member States will make the necessary effort to simplify the regulatory environment.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The dossier aims at the mere codification of existing texts, without introducing any substantial changes, but provides for the suspension of certain concessions relating to the import into the European Union of agricultural products from Turkey, which I consider useful.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which provides for the suspension of certain concessions relating to the importation into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey. Since 1996, Turkey has banned the importation of beef from EU Member States. In this context, it seems normal to suspend the preferential regime terms applicable to imports of Turkish products into the European Union.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The measure provides only for a mere codification of the 1998 Regulation without making any substantial changes to the European Community's need to suspend imports of agricultural products from Turkey, while always without prejudice to any products subject to a specific import regime. For this reason, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With reference to Regulation (EC) No 1506/98, I agree with the need due to the economic crisis to suspend certain concessions relating to the import into the Union of Agricultural Products of Turkey, because this will safeguard Italian products in that sector more, while always saving any products subject to a specific import regime. Since the resolution confines itself to a mere codification of the 1998 regulation, which I can already support, without making any substantial changes, I voted in favour of the new text.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation suspending certain concessions relating to imports into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey, since the Advisory Group concluded by common accord on 14 October that the proposal was limited to a mere codification of the existing texts, without any substantial changes.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒  The proposal in question contains a straightforward codification of the existing texts without any change in their substance. I thus voted in favour of the report on codification.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report concerns a proposal on the codification of EU law. It is, in fact, a purely technical procedure, provided for in Article 103 of the Regulation and aimed at verifying that the codification proposal is in fact limited to mere codification, without any substantial changes.  Each codification proposal is examined in advance by the legal services of the Commission, the Council and Parliament. The conclusions of this assessment are then sent to the Committee on Legal Affairs for validation and then voted on in plenary for parliament's final approval. In view of the favourable legal opinions on this matter, I am voting in favour of the report on the suspension of certain concessions relating to imports into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This proposal deals with the codification of the act on suspending certain concessions on the import into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey. Due to the fact that this is a technical procedure with the contents of the Regulations being preserved I voted in favour of the report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, the aim of which was the simple codification of the regulation on the suspension of certain concessions relating to the importation into the European Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey. The content of the various acts that have been incorporated into this new regulation has been preserved, so this report was no problem, it is a simple administrative manoeuvre.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. I voted for this text for two reasons. The first is that we have to focus on local production, in France for the French, then on the European level, and finally on the international scale. The suspension of certain import concessions would help to promote our agricultural production.  The second is that Turkey has been implementing a ban on the import of live oxen and restrictions on the import of beef since 1996. While I respect this protectionist decision of a sovereign state, I nevertheless hope that the principle of reciprocity will be applied, and that we, in turn, can exercise our rights to defend our production, and especially our agriculture.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report focuses on the codification within EU law of Regulation 1506/98 suspending certain concessions relating to the importation into the EU of agricultural products originating in Turkey. I support this text as a simple exercise in codifying positive law, without any change in substance. For this reason, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report as I do not wish to contribute to any trade with Turkey, especially with regard to products produced in Greece as well.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I approved the pure and simple codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 1506/1998 of 13 July 1998 establishing a concession to Turkey in the form of a Community tariff quota in 1998 for hazelnuts and suspending certain concessions. This is a technical diploma.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report examines a proposal for a Regulation, which codifies Council Regulation (EC) No 1506/1998, which establishes a concession to Turkey in the form of a Community tariff quota in 1998 for hazelnuts and suspending certain concessions, and the proposal is based on a pure and simple codification of existing texts without substantive amendments.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. This resolution is an admission: in addition to the recurring problems caused by the attitude of his government that I have previously mentioned, it must finally be acknowledged that Turkey is not even playing the basic fair play that you would be instead expect of it in terms of trade in general and agricultural in particular. Indeed, Turkey is not the European Commission: it knows how to defend its interests and does not necessarily lie down in front of the oukases of globalism, except when it finds its own advantage. Then I will be charitable: I will vote in favour of this resolution, but let me doubt that it hides your desire to move the accession negotiations forward, and that the pretext of the restrictions here is merely a decoy in the face of your general attitude.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this report is the codification of the Regulation establishing a concession to Turkey in the form of a Community tariff quota for hazelnuts and suspending certain concessions. The Commission has decided to ask its services that all acts should be codified no later than 10 amendments in order to make EU legislation more accessible and easier to understand. This objective cannot be achieved as long as there is a scattering of numerous provisions, amended on several occasions, often substantially, which requires a reading of both the original act and the acts amending it. For this reason, and in order to ensure the clarity and transparency of the law, it is necessary to codify the rules which have been frequently changed.  This proposal is based on a pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantive amendments. Despite the essentially technical nature of this proposal, it weighed on the vote of our group (against), which, like the other report on the import of products originating in Turkey, the persistence of a situation of illegal occupation by Turkey of part of the territory of Cyprus.

name: Raffaele Fitto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal concerns a simple codification of existing texts, without any substantial changes. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 The proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council based on the Interinstitutional Agreement of 20 May 1994 on the suspension of certain concessions concerning imports into the European Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey needed recoding to improve the application of this Regulation.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 As in previous cases I vote negatively on the text even if this is only a process of "codification" of the texts that does not introduce any change in substance, thus reiterating our position of opposition to the substance of the proposal.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am opposed to any trade with Turkey, especially with regard to products produced in my country, Greece.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of the proposal as it is a straightforward codification of existing texts without any change in their substance.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. The proposal represents an amendment to Council Regulation (EC) No 1506/98 of 13 July 1998 establishing a concession in favour of Turkey in the form of a Community hazelnut tariff quota for 1998 and suspending certain concessions.  The proposal is limited to a pure and simple codification of existing acts, without substantial modifications.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Representing this proposal as a complementary codification to the Proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the import into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey already voted on at this session and not entailing any substantial changes, I felt it was right and proper to support it with a vote in favour

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Duda report, which concerns codification to take into account changes in the relationship between the EU and Turkey on the subject of agricultural products.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which takes into account changes in the relationship between the EU and Turkey on the subject of agricultural products. In order to protect the Union's commercial interests, the concessions set out in the annex to the regulation should therefore be suspended.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a regulation by Parliament and the Council on the suspension of certain concessions relating to imports of agricultural products into the Union originating in Turkey, as I consider it an obligation of the European Union to provide its citizens with easy access to legal order acts. The scattering of provisions in various acts leads to the need for swift adoption of codified acts to make the provisions clearer. Codification therefore focuses on simplification that does not change the essential content of acts. This reduces the need for research work to find the rules in place, and ensures a faster and more efficient understanding of EU acts.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. I voted for this text for two reasons. The first is that we have to focus on local production, in France for the French, then on the European level, and finally on the international scale. The suspension of certain import concessions would help to promote our agricultural production.  The second is that Turkey has been implementing a ban on the import of live oxen and restrictions on the import of beef since 1996. While I respect this protectionist decision of a sovereign state, I nevertheless hope that the principle of reciprocity will be applied, and that we, in turn, can exercise our rights to defend our production, and especially our agriculture.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Andrzej Duda's report on the suspension of certain concessions relating to the importation into the Eu of agricultural products originating in Turkey. As part of the effort to simplify European law, the aim here is to codify a set of existing provisions on the same subject, in order to integrate them into a single, clearer and simpler text. This report was adopted by a very large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report to codify the Council's regulation suspending certain concessions relating to the importation into the Eu fare of agricultural products originating in Turkey. In the interests of clarity and transparency of the law, the procedure known as the formal codification of legislation allows all amendments and revisions to a text to be merged without altering its substance.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the proposal as it only contains a straightforward codification of the existing texts without any change in their substance.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of Mr McDerman's report. Andrzej Duda. The aim of the proposal is to start codifying the regulation suspending certain concessions relating to the import into the European Union of agricultural products from Turkey. The text adopted today provides for the codification of existing texts and does not make significant changes in content.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. The codification of the text on the suspension of certain concessions relating to the importation of live animals of the bovine species improves the clarity of the regulatory framework, which ensures a certain balance in trade relations between Turkey and the Eu. I voted in favour of this report, which supports one of the Union's few realistic positions on trade preferences.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: In writing. I voted for this text because it allows retaliation against Turkey, which is guilty of applying quantitative restrictions on the import of our beef.

name: Philippe Loiseau (NI)
text: In writing. In support of this initiative. The aim is to challenge a policy pursued by Turkey concerning a quantitative restriction on the import of beef, which is contrary to the regulation codified in point 21. We support the initiative to replicate this policy. It is time to defend our productions against the unfair practices of countries financed by European funds.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because this is a technical change in Turkey's agricultural products. Despite its technical nature it involves this country, which is an occupying power on the part of the territory of one of the member states of the European Union, Cyprus. This agreement would therefore allow products from the occupied area to be introduced, recognising it as Turkish territory, in clear violation of the provisions of international law. In addition, the introduction of Turkish agricultural products will have a strong impact on European Mediterranean farmers, lowering prices and making it dependent on international trade for our food. We are committed to international trade that coexists with farmers and allows local agri-food systems that link production and consumption with the territory. It is for these two reasons that I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 I approve the codified version of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council suspending certain concessions relating to the importation into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey, since, as I have already pointed out above, these changes and recommendations of the Legal Services Advisory Group of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission , provide only non-substantial amendments, which do not impose any substantial significant changes to the Regulation.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 These concessions should be cancelled. I support it. I voted in favour.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council suspending certain concessions concerning the import into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey, because the report to be adopted suspends the two tariff quotas provided for in Annex 1 to the relevant regulation and allows seamlessly the import of agricultural products originating in Turkey which irreparably affects the economic interests of Greek and Cypriot farmers who have been impoverished by the Memorandums.  Moreover, as Ankara systematically violates international law towards Greece and Cyprus and refuses to comply with the terms and conditions of its pre-accession course, it is obvious that it is not entitled to any favourable treatment of its products by the EU, as promoted by the report to be voted on. On the contrary, the EU had to take drastic restrictive measures against Turkish imports into the Union until Turkey fully complied with its international obligations towards Greece and Cyprus.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. Dominique Martin, on the other hand, voted in favour of this text. Since 1996, Turkey has applied quantitative restrictions on the import of beef. This text will counterbalance these restrictions with equivalent measures, which we support.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report as the proposal in question contains a straightforward codification of the existing texts without any change in their substance.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of this report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council suspending certain concessions relating to imports into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey, because it codifies an EC regulation establishing a concession to Turkey by means of a Community tariff quota, despite the fact that the work is a codification and does not substantially change the text.  I believe that proper control is needed to allow the European authorities more room for manoeuvre, especially in order to encourage compliance with all EU rules on agricultural products that must only be able to enter our countries when they are safe for citizens.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. The proposal to suspend certain concessions on imports into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey received my negative vote, as I do not support the system of concessions in principle.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Codification consists of grouping normative texts of various natures into collections concerning a given subject with the aim of simplification, clarity and transparency.  The purpose of this proposal is to codify Regulation (EC) 1506/98 of the Council of 13 July 1998 establishing a concession, in favour of Turkey, in the form of a Community tariff quota for hazelnuts. It is this regulation that gives the Commission the power to remove the suspension of imports of products originating in Turkey.  Opposed to the Commission's control in this area and even if it is only a technical report, I vote against it. These undemocratic technocratic procedures prevent Europe from practising solidarity protectionism, which is the ecological and social emergency of our time.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 We deal here only with a technical issue. The aim of this proposal is to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 1506/98 of 13 July 1998, which establishes a concession to Turkey in the form of a Community tariff quota in 1998 for hazelnuts and suspends certain concessions. The new Regulation will replace the various acts contained therein.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report regarding the suspension of certain concessions relating to the import into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey because the consultative working party of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission concluded that the proposed codification of the existing texts is straightforward and presents no change in their substance. It is crucial that agreements that have been amended many times be codified in order to ensure that they are accessible and clear to citizens.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on suspending certain concessions relating to the import into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey. The proposal is a straightforward codification of existing texts without any change in their substance.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. On the basis of the Opinion of the Advisory Group on legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, I voted in favour of the codification of this Regulation on the suspension of certain concessions on imports into the Union of agricultural products of Turkish origin.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The purpose of the proposal is to codify Regulation (EC) 1506/98 of the Council of 13 July 1998 suspending certain concessions.  Turkey enforces bans and restrictions on the import of live beef and beef from the European Union.  If this text, which is merely codification, aims to impose on Turkey a principle of reciprocity in its trade relations with the European Union, we challenge the Union with any holding of prerogatives relating to the foreign trade of the Member States.  So I voted for it.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the codification of the European Parliament and Council regulation suspending certain concessions relating to the importation into the Eu with agricultural products originating in Turkey.  This regulation has been amended several times and substantially, so that its provisions are now found for one part in the original act and for the rest scattered in the amending acts that followed.  In the interests of clarity and simplification of the law, guaranteeing greater legal certainty and better information for citizens, it was therefore necessary to codify this regulation. This process completely preserves its substance and merely brings together in a legible way the various changes that have been made to it.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this proposal for a regulation suspending certain concessions relating to imports into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey, as it is limited to a mere codification of existing texts, thus not containing any substantial changes to the original agreement.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union attaches great importance to the simplification, and clear formulation, of Community legislation. However, this desire for clarity cannot be fully realized when the provisions amended remain divided into the form of an original act and acts of amendment. On the basis of the examination of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council codifying Council Regulation (EC) No 1506/98 of 13 July 1998 establishing a concession to Turkey in the form of a Community tariff quota in 1998 for hazelnuts and suspending certain concessions, the Advisory Group concluded by mutual agreement that the proposal was limited to a mere codification of existing texts, without any substantial amendments. In view of the above considerations, I voted in favour of the Duda report, as I believe it is essential to codify the provisions that have undergone frequent changes over time, in the name of the desire to guarantee the clarity and transparency of European legislation.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report because, through it, the European Parliament and the Council come to regulate the rules relating to the 'suspension of certain concessions on imports into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey'.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. It is true that the request must be taken into the credit that it is a codification which, in principle, is capable of increasing the legal certainty and transparency of legislation in the Union. However, I am opposed to the proposal itself, as I see the danger of facilitating the import of agricultural goods from Turkey into the Union. I have therefore voted against the motion.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal to granted Turkey a concession in the form of a Community tariff quota for hazelnuts and suspend certain concessions. The proposal is limited to the codification of existing legislation without any substantive changes.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that, according to the Advisory Group of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question is limited to a mere codification of the existing texts, without any substantial changes, I voted in favour for them.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 The basic text of Council Regulation 1506/98/EC as of 29 March 1994 on the suspension of certain concessions relating to imports into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey governs the suspension of certain concessions due to imbalances in the mutual trade of agricultural products resulting from the application of certain prohibitions on the import of certain agricultural products into Turkey from the EU. Since 1996, Turkey has been applying a ban on imports of live animals (cattle) and has placed restrictions on beef imports from the European Union. In order to protect the Union's trade interests, the provisions of the Regulation took appropriate reciprocal measures and suspended some of the existing concessions.  The Regulation has been amended on several occasions and its codification is necessary. On 1 April 1987, the European Commission ordered that no more than ten amendments to the act must be codified, and this recommendation was endorsed by the European Council in December 1992 in Edinbourgh, and on 20 December 1994 an agreement was adopted between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, which further accelerated the codification process with the adoption of appropriate legal instruments. The proposal for a new Regulation will uniform actions and procedures that have so far been covered by previous amendments and fully preserve the material content of the act.  Due to the need to apply this regulation incorrectly, I consider the proposed codification to be justified.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. The purpose of the proposal is to codify Regulation (EC) 1506/98 of the Council of 13 July 1998 suspending certain concessions.  Turkey enforces bans and restrictions on the import of live beef and beef from the European Union.  If this text, which is merely codification, aims to impose on Turkey a principle of reciprocity in its trade relations with the European Union, we challenge the Union with any holding of prerogatives relating to the foreign trade of the Member States.  So I voted for it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. According to the Advisory Group on legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, this proposal is limited only to codifying existing texts without substantive changes. This formal procedure increases the transparency of the process and allows citizens to be fully informed about this topic through simplified rules, so I support it.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. One of the transparency measures of the Work of the Commission and other institutions of the European Union is to simplify and explain European Union law to make it clearer and more accessible to citizens. In order to achieve this objective, i.e. if the law has to be clear and transparent, the process of codification of frequently changing rules is essential.  The purpose of this proposal is the codification process of Council Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013. 1506/98 of 13 July 1998 on the imposition of a privilege for Turkey in the form of a Community tariff quota for hazelnuts in 1998 and on the suspension of certain benefits. The new regulation will replace various scattered acts, which certainly contributes to transparency and transparency. I therefore support MEP Andrzej Duda's report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on the suspension of certain concessions relating to imports into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey, since, according to the Advisory Group of legal services of the European Parliament and the Council, the proposal is indeed limited only to codifying existing texts without substantive changes.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Again following the opinion of 12/11/2014 of the Advisory Group of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the suspension of certain concessions relating to the import into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey, given that this is a simple codification of the existing texts, without any substantial amendments

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament recently adopted the revision, the various amendments to the text and the accumulations of various texts regulating the suspension of certain concessions relating to imports into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey. I have spoken in favour of this administrative provision in order to have a single, simpler and clearer text.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 At the meeting of 14 October 2014, the Advisory Group composed of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission reviewed the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council, which codifies Council Regulation (EC) No 1506/1998 of 13 July 1998 establishing a concession to Turkey in the form of a Community tariff quota in 1998 for hazelnuts and suspending certain concessions.  It then concluded, by common agreement, that the proposal under question should be based on a pure and simple codification of the existing texts, without substantive amendments. I voted, therefore, in favor.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it only proposes to correct the codification of existing texts, not substantially altering what was previously agreed.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since the Advisory Group on the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission has delivered a positive opinion and considers that this proposal is limited to the pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantive amendments to the texts, there is no reason to vote against or even to abstain.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this because, as indicated by the Legal Services Advisory Group of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council, with a view to the codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 1506/98 of 13 July 1998 establishing a concession in favour of Turkey in the form of a Community hazelnut tariff quota for 1998 and suspending certain concessions, is limited to a simple codification of existing acts, without substantial amendments.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council suspending certain concessions relating to the importation into the Eu of agricultural products originating in Turkey. This is a Commission proposal that echoes the recommendations of the European Parliament's Legal Services Advisory Group, the Council and the Commission. This proposal is thus limited to an outright codification of existing texts, without altering their substance.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote against it because it is a mere process of 'codifying' texts, a formal procedure that does not introduce any change in substance, relating to a measure against which we confirm our position of opposition.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this purely technical report, which is limited to codifying existing acts, without altering their substance.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because this is a technical change in Turkey's agricultural products. Despite its technical nature it involves this country, which is an occupying power on the part of the territory of one of the member states of the European Union, Cyprus. This agreement would therefore allow products from the occupied area to be introduced, recognising it as Turkish territory, in clear violation of the provisions of international law. In addition, the introduction of Turkish agricultural products will have a strong impact on European Mediterranean farmers, lowering prices and making it dependent on international trade for our food. We are committed to international trade that coexists with farmers and allows local agri-food systems that link production and consumption with the territory. It is for these two reasons that I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I understand and agree with the codification process, in order to promote greater clarity of the normative acts, resulting from the need to take into account the different amendments they have been subject to in the event that they are more than ten, which have passed through the scrutiny of the ordinary legislative procedure of the respective time in which they occurred. This codification process should not, by its nature, alter the content of the act to which it refers and should be limited to a purely technical procedure, and it is in this spirit that I am voting on this dossier today.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on suspending certain concessions relating to the import into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey and codification.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Since, according to the Advisory Group of legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question is limited only to codifying existing texts without substantive changes, and since the advisory working group concluded unanimously, on the basis of consideration of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on codifying the Council Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013, the commission will not be able to provide for the provision of the 1506/98 as of 13 July 1998 on the imposition of a privilege for Turkey in the form of a hazelnut tariff quota in 1998 and on the suspension of certain preferences, that the proposal constitutes a direct codification of existing texts without substantive changes, I support this report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Products produced in Member States of the European Union should be preferred and supported by their third country counterparts

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council suspending certain concessions on imports into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey. The Regulation provides for the development and standardisation of trade preferences for imports into the Union of agricultural products originating in Turkey and a number of preferential concessions for EU exports of meat and live animals to Turkey. The revision of the provisions prohibiting trade in live bovine animals and beef to Turkey since 1996 could thus take it to another level. It is also possible to eliminate problems such as the elimination of barriers to preferential exports to Turkey. I believe that the regulation therefore contributes to the protection of the Union's commercial interests. In addition, I believe it is important that EU legislation is clear, transparent, easy to interpret and accessible to all. The above report contributed to this by adopting a simple, consolidated provision.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the european Parliament and the Council's proposed regulation suspending certain concessions relating to the importation of agricultural products from Turkey into the Eu. I can only deplore the words of several extremist elected officials, who still manage, around these themes, to peddle their racist message discrediting the European work.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The codification of European legislation facilitates the understanding of European Union legislation. This legislative procedure envisages the clarification of the legislative act, but no substantive amendments to that act can be introduced through it. The European institutions agreed in 1994 to use an accelerated procedure for the rapid adoption of codified acts. The legislative proposal which was the subject of the European Parliament's report concerns the codification of Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999. Council Regulation (EEC) No 1506/98 of 13 July 1998 laying down a concession to Turkey in the form of a Community tariff quota in 1998 for forest nuts and suspending certain concessions. Given that the codification proposal retains the full content of the codified acts and merely regroups them, making only the formal changes required by the codification operation itself, and bearing in mind that the consultative working group of the legal services of the three European institutions recommends supporting this proposal, the European Parliament, by unanimous vote today, supports the proposal to codify the regulation.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this technical report by the Committee on Legal Affairs which guarantees greater security in the importation of certain agricultural products from Turkey.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because this is a technical change in Turkey's agricultural products. Despite its technical nature it involves this country, which is an occupying power on the part of the territory of one of the member states of the European Union, Cyprus. This agreement would therefore allow products from the occupied area to be introduced, recognising it as Turkish territory, in clear violation of the provisions of international law. In addition, the introduction of Turkish agricultural products will have a strong impact on European Mediterranean farmers, lowering prices and making it dependent on international trade for our food. We are committed to international trade that coexists with farmers and allows local agri-food systems that link production and consumption with the territory. It is for these two reasons that I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this report is to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 779/98 of 7 April 1998 on imports into the Community of agricultural products originating in Turkey, repealing Regulation (EEC) No 4115/86 and amending Regulation (EC) No 3010/95. Since 1987, all acts should be codified no later than 10 amendments in order to make EU legislation more accessible and easier for ordinary citizens to understand. In order to ensure the clarity and transparency of the law, it is necessary to codify the rules which have been frequently changed. This cannot be achieved as long as there is a scattering of numerous provisions, amended on several occasions.  This proposal is based on a pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantive amendments. However, we draw attention to the fact that Turkey illegally occupies part of cyprus, and we take this opportunity to demand from the EU a firm position of legality in this matter.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. I opposed the suspension of certain concessions on imports of agricultural products from Turkey into the Union, as I do not support the system of concessions per se. That is why it is only logical to reject this regulation.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The purpose of this Report is the codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 1506/1998 of 13 July 1998, which establishes a concession to Turkey in the form of a Community tariff quota in 1998 for hazelnuts and suspends certain concessions. In 1987, the Commission decided to ask its services that all acts should be codified no later than 10 amendments in order to make EU legislation more accessible and easier for citizens to understand. This proposal is based on a pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantive amendments. However, we voted against it as this is a negotiation with Turkey involving the territories of Cyprus illegally occupied by those countries, a situation which clearly confronts the rights of the Cypriot people.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution on the amended agreement for the establishment of the General Committee on Mediterranean Fisheries, despite not being in favour of the provisions applicable to fisheries in the CGPM, since the agreement reviews the structure and content of the current one by introducing a clearer explanation of the purpose of the CGPM agreement (defining a clear overall objective of ecological sustainability , social, economic and environmental of marine resources), better defines the functions of the CGPM and creates a well-defined dispute resolution mechanism.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. The CGPM, a regional fisheries management organisation, plays an active role in the development, conservation, development and development of living marine resources in the Mediterranean Sea.  After an evaluation of its performance, a procedure was launched to modify the text of the creation of the CGPM. The new agreement specifies its objectives and functions to enhance its effectiveness.  It sets a clear global objective: to ensure the sustainable use of resources from a biological, social, economic and environmental point of view. It also better defines its functions, with the promotion of joint fisheries management through multi-year management plans, the establishment of restricted fishing areas, and the collection and dissemination of data. It incorporates key elements of the common fisheries policy, such as the goal of maximum sustainable yield, the ecosystem approach and adherence to the precautionary principle, the reduction of releases, and the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. Because the sustainable use of marine biological resources in the Mediterranean and the protection of the marine ecosystems that support them play a vital role in promoting blue growth and sustainable development, I support this agreement.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Agreement establishing the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GEM) entered into force in 1952. EU Member States located in the Mediterranean and Black Sea regions are also parties to this Agreement. In 2013, a process of revising the GHAM agreement was launched.  Among other improvements, the revised Agreement adopts sanctions to address non-compliance by Member States and establishes a mechanism for settling disputes between the Contracting Parties. Taking into account the mutual interest in the development and rational use of living marine resources in the Mediterranean and Black Sea region, I am voting in favour of approving the conclusion of the amended Agreement.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. The effectiveness of this Commission in protecting fisheries resources is not guaranteed. A proposal on certain fishing provisions in the area covered by the CGPM agreement included numerous amendments facilitating the fishing of red coral, a species that is endangered and essential to the Mediterranean ecosystem. However, the project presented here deals with the agreement itself and appears to have the clear objective of a sustainable use of marine biological resources.  We will see to the use of whether this agreement keeps its promises. So I chose to abstain.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because it aims to defend the interests of development and good use of marine biological resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. It is also part of a global vision of conservation and sustainable use of marine biological resources and the protection of marine ecosystems.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to amend the agreement establishing the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (UFJ). The Agreement shall be amended in order to clarify the objectives and functions of the UFK and to increase its effectiveness. The new agreement sets a clear objective of biological, social, economic and environmental sustainability of living marine resources. The UFK's role is also better defined: to promote joint fisheries management through multiannual management plans, to establish restricted fishing areas and to collect and disseminate data. The agreement contains provisions on penalties to be applied in cases where members and non-members fail to comply. In addition, a well-defined dispute settlement mechanism has been established in the event of a dispute between the Contracting Parties.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. Doubts remain about the protection of fisheries resources by this General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean.  For example, last January, a proposal on certain fishing provisions in the area covered by the CGPM agreement included numerous amendments facilitating the fishing of red coral, an endangered species that is essential to the Mediterranean ecosystem. The recommendation on which we had to decide seems more concerned with the sustainable use of marine biological resources.  Remaining skeptical, I preferred to abstain.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. A procedure for amending the text establishing the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (CGPM) was initiated in 2013 after a 2011 report that the objectives and functions of the CGMP needed to be clarified and thus increased its effectiveness. The aim of the European Parliament's vote was to approve the amended agreement. The new agreement sets a clear global objective of ensuring the biological, social, economic and environmental sustainability of marine biological resources. It also provides for sanctions.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. The creation of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (CGPM) dates back to 1919 and has been in force since 1952.
