The Commission's main aim is to promote the development, conservation and management of living marine resources. While these objectives are laudable, I would like to point out that doubts remain about the real protection of fisheries resources by this Commission (e.g. proposal in January to make it easier to fish for red coral, a species that is still endangered). Nevertheless, the recommendation here relates to the agreement itself and appears to be clearly aimed at the sustainable use of marine biological resources. In light of these elements, I abstained.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 The nascent Commission has set the overall objective of biological, social, economic and environmental sustainability of living marine resources for mediterranean fisheries. This noble goal will be pursued with Community regulations that will penalise our fishing and that, in any case, in terms of control and sanctions, will not be fair or enforced by non-EU countries, causing differences in application and commercial disadvantage. For these reasons, I voted against the measure.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. CGPM is one of the so-called regional fisheries management organizations (ORPPs) that aims to promote the development, conservation, rational management and better use of living marine resources, as well as the sustainable development of aquaculture, in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. Following a performance assessment completed in 2011, an amendment to the CGPM Convention was submitted in 2013 to clarify its objectives and functions and strengthen its efficiency. The contracting parties approved the amended version of the Convention at its 38th annual session (19-24 May 2014), which complies with the most modern instruments of the OROPs.  Among the main changes are: a clearer explanation of the purpose and underlying principles of the Convention (the biological, social, economic and environmental sustainability of living marine resources) or the improvement of the definition of the functions of cgPM (promotion of common fisheries management through multiannual management plans, establishment of restricted fishing areas and data collection and dissemination) , as well as sanctioning measures and dispute resolution. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report on the extension of the competence and mandate of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean. The General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (UFJK) is a so-called regional fisheries management organisation whose aim is to promote the development, conservation, rational management and optimal use of living marine resources, as well as the sustainable development of Mediterranean and Black Sea aquaculture. In order to improve its performance, it was decided to better define the functions of the UFK, to establish a well-defined dispute settlement mechanism, to provide for sanctions in the event of non-compliance. The new agreement sets a clear common objective of biological, social, economic and environmental sustainability of living marine resources. In the mutual interest of the European Parliament in the development and proper use of living mediterranean and black sea resources, the European Parliament supports the new agreement on the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Agreement establishing the General Fisheries Commission of the Mediterranean (GFCM), in accordance with the provisions of Article XIV. The FAO Constitution was approved at a session of the FAO Conference in 1949 and entered into force in 1952.  The GFCM is a regional fisheries management organisation (RFMO), which aims to promote the development, conservation and best possible exploitation and rational management of living marine resources, as well as the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. These amendments to the Agreement revised the structure and content of the existing Agreement to bring it in line with the latest RFMO instruments. The amended Agreement is in line with the main objectives of the Common Fisheries Policy.  The aim of the proposal is to conclude a revised GFCM Agreement on behalf of the European Union which I support.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (NI)
text: In writing. I abstained on the amendment of the agreement on the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (CGPM), to which some members of the European Union are also parties. Indeed, a procedure for amending the text of the agreement establishing the CGPM was launched in 2013.  Indeed, I have reservations about the capacity of this Commission to protect fisheries resources. The impact of these amendments will need to be assessed to assess whether the stated objectives are being met.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted yes since I retain important, for the correct development of the fishery market, a Commission for the Mediterranean to regulate fishery activity in a harmonized way.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement on the creation of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean closes a process more than 50 years long, to which the EU joined in 1998 when it was still called the European Community. This is an important agreement born in the framework of the FAO and what we are adopting today is a formal act, but also a substantial one. Since 1 January 2014, a new concept of thinking and experiencing fishing in the EU has been in place.  The common fisheries policy has been reformed to ensure the conservation and exploitation of marine resources in a sustainable way, compatible with the protection of the ecosystem. The agreement that has just been approved is in line with the efforts made by this Parliament to change the way we think about fisheries. It embodies and takes on the principles on which the CFP is based, explicitly providing as a global objective of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean the biological, social, economic and environmental sustainability of living marine resources; The GFCM's functions also include the objective of maximum sustainable yield, the reduction of discards and the fight against illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. The purpose of this recommendation is to accept, on behalf of the European Union, the amended agreement establishing the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (CGPM). The commission aims to promote the management and development of marine resources in the Mediterranean Sea. However, even if the recommendation amends the agreement itself by promoting the sustainable use of fisheries resources, the effectiveness of this committee in protecting marine resources is questionable, as evidenced by the January 2015 proposal favouring the fishing of red coral, a species that is essential to the Mediterranean Sea ecosystem.  That is why I abstained on the vote of this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Agreement establishing the General Commission for Fisheries in the Mediterranean (CGPM), in accordance with the provisions of Article XIV of the FAO Constitution, was approved by the FAO Conference in 1949 and entered into force in 1952. Amendments to this Agreement were approved in 1963, 1976 and 1997. The European Community acceded to the GFC on 16 June 1998 by Decision 98/416/EC. EU Member States opening to the Mediterranean and the Black Sea are also parties to this Agreement. I voted in favour of this recommendation establishing a General Commission for Fisheries in the Mediterranean because the new agreement sets a clear overall objective, which aims at the biological, social, economic and environmental sustainability of living marine resources. Definitions of the terms necessary for the correct interpretation of the agreement are also introduced. Furthermore, the functions of the GFCM, which include the promotion of joint fisheries management through multiannual management plans, the establishment of restricted fishing areas and the collection and dissemination of data, are better shaped. In this context, the new agreement integrates the central elements of the common fisheries policy with regard to the objective of maximum sustainable production, the ecosystem, as well as the objective of cautious approach, reducing discards, combating illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 The nascent committee sets itself the general objective of biological, social, economic, and environmental sustainability of living marine resources for fishing in the Mediterranean, but it will do so on the basis of Community regulations that penalise our fisheries and which, in terms of control and sanctions, are not enforced by non-EU countries, causing differences in application and commercial disadvantage. I abstained.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision on the acceptance, on behalf of the European Union, of the amended agreement on the creation of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean. The amended agreement revises the structure and content of the current agreement to bring it into line with the modern instruments of the Regional Fisheries Management Organisation (ORGP). The main changes introduced are as follows: a clearer explanation of the aims of the agreement on the creation of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM); a better definition of the functions of the GFCM; provisions for the imposition of measures or sanctions in the event of non-compliance by members/non-members; the creation of a well-defined dispute settlement mechanism in the event of conflicts between the Contracting Parties.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it was concerned with the establishment of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean. This is an important procedural matter. It should be noted that I have particular concerns with fishing provisions which are stipulated within the General Fisheries Commission. However, as this report was solely to do with the establishment of this Commission, I voted in favour.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean is a regional fisheries management organisation whose purpose is to promote the development, conservation, rational management and optimum use of living marine resources, as well as the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. I voted in favour because I believe that the conservation and sustainable exploitation of marine resources lives in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea are of prime importance. In addition, sanction measures are now provided for in the event of non-compliance by members/non-members.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I preferred to abstain on this text. Admittedly, the report focuses on a project with clear objectives for the sustainable use of marine biological resources; however, I remain cautious about these good intentions.  Indeed, last January, a proposal on certain provisions relating to fishing in the area covered by the CGPM agreement contained numerous amendments facilitating the fishing of red coral, a species yet threatened and whose disappearance would destabilize the Entire Mediterranean ecosystem. For this reason, I doubt the Commission's ability to make good fisheries decisions, as on many other issues.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The measure we have examined promotes the protection of both the proper exploitation and development of marine resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. The conviction to protect marine ecosystems so that they have an increasingly important role in the growth of areas called blue, also identifying a sustainable growth and to be taken into account also given my island origin. In addition, the provisions for institutions of measures or sanctions in the event of non-compliance by members/non-members are welcome. These premises have encouraged my vote in favour of the measure

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution because it promotes the development and proper exploitation of living marine resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea.  I am convinced that the conservation of marine resources lives in the application area, as well as the protection of marine ecosystems, play an important role in the context of 'blue' growth and sustainable development. I particularly welcome, in the resolution, the provisions for the imposition of measures or sanctions in the event of non-compliance by members.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft Council decision on the acceptance by the European Union of the amended agreement concerning the creation of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM), which aims to promote the conservation, development, common and rational management of fisheries and the optimum use of fishery resources, as well as the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. I support the Eu ropean Union's overall objectives of biological, social, economic and environmental sustainability of marine resources. Only through a more transparent fisheries policy, good governance and the cooperation of specialised companies will it be possible to respond to demand from the European market and, at the same time, to guarantee the protection of the ecosystem and to step up the fight against illegal fishing.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM) is a so-called Regional Fisheries Management Organisation (RFMO) with the aim of overseeing the development, conservation, rational management and best utilisation of resources in the Mediterranean Sea. The Agreement is being amended to clarify the objectives and functions of the GFCM, and strengthen its efficiency. The main changes include a clearer explanation of the purpose of the GFCM Agreement, better defined functions of the GFCM, provisions for the establishment of measures/sanctions to address non-compliance by Members/non-Members and the establishment of a well-defined dispute settlement mechanism. Such measures will play a major role in the context of blue growth and sustainable development. I have thus voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The GFCM is a so-called regional fisheries management organisation whose purpose is to promote the development, conservation, rational management and optimal use of living marine resources, as well as the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean and black sea. The objectives, general principles and functions of the GFCM have been revised and extended to ensure the long-term conservation and sustainable exploitation of living marine resources and their environment. I am voting in favour of safeguarding the common good at sea.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This reports suggests another round of reforms for the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM) which is responsible for the promotion of common fishery management, the establishment of fisheries restricted areas and data collection in the Mediterranean sea. These include a clearer explanation of the purpose of the GFCM Agreement and better defined functions of the GFCM. It also deals with provisions for the establishment of measures/sanctions to address non-compliance by Members/non-Members and the establishment of a well-defined dispute settlement mechanism in case disputes arise between contracting parties. As the report aims at updating the Commission’s operation I have voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean is an organisation whose aim is to promote the development, conservation and development of living marine resources in the Mediterranean and Black Seas. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to extend the functions of this Commission, in order to protect the fisheries resources concerned. This includes the implementation of multi-year management plans, the establishment of restricted fishing areas, and the creation of dispute resolution mechanisms. Acting upstream and in a coordinated manner will ensure the sustainability of marine species, which is one of the major challenges of the coming years in terms of both food security and biodiversity.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. The effectiveness of this Commission in protecting fisheries resources is not guaranteed. A proposal on certain provisions relating to fishing in the area covered by the CGPM agreement contained numerous amendments facilitating the fishing of red coral, a species that is endangered and essential to the Mediterranean ecosystem. However, the project presented here deals with the agreement itself and appears to have the clear objective of a sustainable use of marine biological resources. We will see to the use of whether this agreement keeps its promises. So I chose to abstain.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the mutual interest in the development and proper use of living marine resources in the Mediterranean and black sea and convinced that the conservation and sustainable use of living marine resources in the area of application and the protection of marine ecosystems in which those resources are found play an important role in the context of blue growth and sustainable development.  I agree with the rapporteur's position that recommends that the conclusion of this amended Agreement be approved.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to authorize the conclusion of an amendment to the agreement establishing the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (CGPM) originally established and approved in 1949 by the conference of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO). The amendment in question, approved in May 2014 at the 38th annual session of the CGPM, amends the structure and updates the content of the current agreement to bring it in line with modern fisheries management instruments. Considering that this amendment allows for a better definition of the objectives of the CGPM and its sanctions and dispute settlement regime, as well as introducing elements adopted by the European Union as part of the latest reform of the Common Fisheries Policy, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The General Fisheries Committee for the Mediterranean (GFCM) is a Regional Fisheries Management Organisation (RFMO) and meets annually to discuss maritime issues applicable to the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. Issues covered include management of resources using MSY (maximum sustainable yield), discards and how to tackle IUU (illegal, unreported and unregulated) fishing. This Agreement follows a review of the GFCM and proposes changes which would be in line with the reformed Common Fisheries Policy. The UK is neither affected by the GFCM, nor has direct fishing interests in the Mediterranean. However, I was able to support this Agreement because we support the process of improving the effectiveness and efficiency of the RFMOs

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the new amendments as they provide for a structural improvement of the objectives and general functions of the General Fisheries Commission. The proposed measures are vital for strengthening the control and control mechanisms affecting and protecting Bulgarian waters and fish stocks as well. The new sanctions and dispute resolution mechanisms will provide the Union with an effective tool to address issues such as over-fishing, which endangers many native species, and unregulated and illegal activities that have a negative impact on the environment. The European Parliament's proposals will strengthen policy in this area and help to make the management of fish stocks in the Mediterranean and related waters in an adaptive, responsible and modern way.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this recommendation because, although the proposed amendments do not guarantee the best protection of the marine environment and its resources, they are the result of the negotiations between the Contracting Parties following the recommendations of an assessment completed in 2011, and it is preferable that the powers of the General Committee on Mediterranean Fisheries be well defined for the effective fulfilment of its objectives which are : promote the development, conservation, rational management and better use of living marine resources, as well as the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I stated that I was present at the recommendation because I agree with the need to limit smuggling, as well as with the proper and environmentally friendly management of the biodiversity of the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. I believe, however, that some points need further clarification.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the amendment to the Agreement on the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean, as the text in this area ensures more sustainable fishing of marine fish stocks, better protects marine resources and contributes to the development of fishing methods. It is clear that 30 % of the earth's seas are overfished and that the survival of marine fish stocks could be at risk. Justified steps to maintain marine fish stocks will result in a continuous and significant reduction in the amount of marine fish fish fished. Therefore, the common fisheries policy should pay much more attention to sustainable fish farming, i.e. aquaculture, and in particular freshwater fish farming. A significant number of fish ponds in Hungary are located in Natura 2000 sites. These farms do not pose any threat to the natural assets of these areas. Moreover, in many cases it is precisely because of our closed-system fish ponds that they have created or preserved individual wetland associations. Consequently, freshwater aquaculture should be freed from unduly stringent and unnecessary sustainability standards, which are justified only for sea fishing. Efforts should already be made to clearly define the concept and regulation of freshwater aquaculture.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Industrial fishing is one of the most significant threats to commercial species and those that run into non-selective fishing methods and gear. Despite international commitments, both the main fish stocks and populations of protected species continue to be threatened by fishing.  The impact of industrial fishing on marine habitats and species is even more evident, and dangerous, in the Mediterranean Sea where, in addition to the numerous fleets of the coastal countries, farm-fishing vessels from Asian countries arrive, exploiting the absence of exclusive economic zones (EEz) in the basin and exploiting the wide availability offered by international waters.  The measure presented in plenary concerned the amendment of the Statute of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM) with the identification of a clearer general objective of biological and environmental sustainability of marine resources, the creation of fisheries limitation zones, provisions for the imposition of sanctions in the event of non-compliance by members/non-members and the creation of a dispute settlement mechanism in the event of conflicts between contracting parties.  These decisions provide more effective instruments for better control of fishing activities in the Mediterranean Sea, which is why I voted in favour of their approval.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 THE GFCM is a regional fisheries management organisation that aims to promote the development, conservation, rational management and better use of marine living resources, as well as the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. This Decision was voted by me in favour to enhance the efficiency of the agreement, which was considered in 2011 to be obtained through a process of amending it. One of the most important changes introduced in the new agreement is a "clear global objective of biological, social, economic and environmental sustainability of living marine resources" consistent with my conviction, as a permanent member of the ENVI Commission, of the need to preserve marine ecosystems. Secondly, this agreement establishes, in its new version, "common fisheries management through multiannual management plans, the establishment of fishing restriction areas and the collection and dissemination of data", in addition to the fight against illegal fishing, the search for maximum sustainable yield, blue growth, and a fisheries approach taking into account the ecosystem perspective , including the need, in my view, for the introduction of sanctions and dispute settlement mechanisms.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The General Fisheries Commission of the Mediterranean (GFCM) is a regional fisheries management organisation (ORGP) which aims to promote the development, conservation, rational management and better use of marine living resources, as well as the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. In 2013, a process of amending the GFCM Agreement was initiated which reviewed the structure and content of the current one in order to harmonise it with the modern instruments of the ORGP. The main changes introduced are a clearer explanation of the objectives and principles underlying the GFCM Agreement; a better definition of the functions of the GFCM, in particular the promotion of common fisheries management through multiannual management plans, the establishment of fishing restriction areas and the collection and dissemination of data; penalties against cases of non-compliance by members and non-members and dispute resolution.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. I abstained on this text because, through disillusionment and lies on the part of the Union, our distrust is only growing. The aim of this text is to make sustainable use of marine biological resources in the Mediterranean. However, no credit can be given to the European authorities, who make the Mediterranean not "Mare Nostrum" but a lake open to industrial fishermen from all over the world.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement establishing the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM), established under the FAO in 1949, entered into force in 1952. The European Community became part of the GFCM in 1998. GFCM is a regional fisheries management organisation, which aims to promote conservation, rational management and the best use of marine living resources. The GFCM Contracting Parties have agreed amendments to the agreement, which basically aim to align it with the latest developments in the general ity of regional fisheries management organisations. The main changes introduced concern: - a clearer explanation of the gfcm objectives (biological, economic, social, environmental) and terms that are necessary for a correct interpretation of the Agreement; - a clearer definition of gfcm's functions, which includes the promotion of joint management through multi-annual management plans, establishment of fishing restriction areas, harvesting and dissemination of data; - Establishment of sanctions in cases of non-compliance with the Agreement; - Establishment of dispute mechanisms that may arise between the Contracting Parties. The rapporteur proposes that Parliament adopt these amendments. We voted in favour.

name: Raffaele Fitto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I am convinced that the amendments made to the agreement can promote the development, conservation, rational management and optimum use of marine resources in the Mediterranean.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ Fisheries is one of the most important industries in several Member States of the European Union. For fisheries management, we have a so-called regional organisation (RFMO), which aims, in particular, to promote the development, protection as well as rational management of living marine resources, but also the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. Due to the need to amend and clarify the objectives and functions of the Agreement, as well as to strengthen its effectiveness, the procedure for its amendment has been under way since 2013. The result is a revised structure and content of the previous agreement, as well as alignment with modern RFMO instruments.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I refrain from giving a positive opinion to the agreement given the failure of the common fisheries policy to date. However, the new proposal, with the overall objective of biological, social, economic and environmental sustainability of living marine resources for fishing in the Mediterranean, is nevertheless a step forward.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am present with regard to the establishment of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean, because I initially agree with the need to limit smuggling, as well as with the proper and environmentally friendly management of the biodiversity of the Mediterranean and the Black Sea, but I believe that some points need further clarification.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Considering the mutual interest in the development and the proper utilisation of the living marine resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea and convinced that the conservation and sustainable use of the living marine resources in the Area of Application and the protection of the marine ecosystems in which those resources occur plays a major role in the context of blue growth and sustainable development, I approved the conclusion of the present modified Agreement in the plenary.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted positively in favour of this report, which clarifies the objectives of the GFCM: the development, conservation, best possible use and rational management of living marine resources, as well as the promotion and sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. I welcome the fact that the amended agreement redefines the structure and content of the current agreement in such a way as to bring it into line with the modern instruments of regional fisheries management organisations, and that the agreement also introduces the definitions necessary for a correct interpretation of the agreement. I consider it important to promote common fisheries management, to create areas subject to fishing restrictions in order to conserve our wildlife, to collect, process and disseminate data in a modern and efficient way, and to develop an integrated fisheries policy in the EU, and I therefore support the proposal. I agree with the rapporteur that the development and proper use of the living marine resources of the Mediterranean and the Black Sea is in the common interest and with the conviction that the conservation and sustainable use of living marine resources in the field of application and the protection of marine ecosystems in which these resources occur play an important role in the context of blue growth and sustainable development.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour to clarify the objectives and functions of the CGPM and to strengthen its efficiency. By amending the Convention, a clearer explanation of the purpose of the GCC Convention will be obtained, that is to say, the biological, social, economic and environmental sustainability of living marine resources, and the definition of cgPM's functions, including the promotion of common fisheries management through multiannual management plans, the establishment of restricted fishing areas and the collection and dissemination of data, the imposition of sanctions to address cases of non-compliance with members/non-members and the settlement of disputes, will be improved.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The review of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean, which began in 2013, clarifies its objectives and functions, improving its effectiveness and making it compliant with the modern instruments of regional fisheries management organisations.  For these reasons, I voted in favour of the resolution on the acceptance, on behalf of the European Union, of the amended agreement on the creation of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. Some important studies carried out in 2011 highlighted the need for a thorough revision of the agreement on the creation of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM) to which the European Community acceded in 1998: in order to revitalise the purpose and effectiveness of this cooperation framework, greater clarity of objectives and functions and appropriate adaptations to the modern instruments of regional fisheries management organisations are needed. That is why I supported and voted in favour of the amendments to the agreement that my colleagues in the Committee on Fisheries have introduced. I therefore agree with the principles underlying the amendment of the agreement: improving and optimising the exploitation of the Mediterranean's living marine resources, ensuring careful protection of marine ecosystems, establishing multiannual management plans for common fisheries, establishing maximum sustainable yield targets and the possibility of applying sanctions where Member States deviate from the new regulation of the agreement.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision on the acceptance, on behalf of the European Union, of the amended agreement on the creation of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM), because I am convinced of the need to adapt the 1952 agreement to the changes brought about by the Treaty of Lisbon, in order to modernise the structure of this committee and, above all, to strengthen its role in the conservation of resources in mediterranean fishing areas. , to expand its functions with the aim of ensuring the long-term conservation and sustainable exploitation of living marine resources and the marine environment as a whole. I welcomed the extension of the Commission's functions to include the adoption of multiannual management plans applied in all sub-regions of the geographical area of competence (Mediterranean and Black Sea), in accordance with ecosystem support for fisheries, to ensure that stocks are maintained above levels capable of producing maximum sustainable yield, in any case in line with national plans. , together with the establishment of fishing restriction zones to protect vulnerable ecosystems, including nurseries and breeding grounds.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, given that measures are urgently needed for the conservation of red coral, mitigating the catches of seabirds, sea turtles and cetaceans and regulating the use of gill-nets in the Black Sea.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Recommendation because, although the proposed amendments do not guarantee the best protection of the marine environment and its resources, they are the result of negotiations between Contracting Parties following the recommendations of an assessment completed in 2011, and it is preferable that the powers of the General Committee on Mediterranean Fisheries be well defined for the effective fulfilment of its objectives which are : promote the development, conservation, rational management and better use of living marine resources, as well as the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which contains a number of preferable conservation measures for the Mediterranean – particularly aimed at reducing unintended catches. The proposal covers measures for the conservation of red coral, monk seals, sharks and rays in the GFCM management area, which I support.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text amending the agreement to establish the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (CGPM). The latter, created in 1949, plays an active role in the conservation of fish stocks in the international waters of the Mediterranean Sea. This text will enable better development and sustainable use of marine resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea, as well as increased protection of the marine ecosystems that support these resources.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the new Agreement for the establishment of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean. It sets a clear overall objective of biological, social, economic and environmental sustainability of living marine resources and new definitions that makes this easier to interpret.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report dealing with the Mediterranean. Whilst the new General Fisheries Commission will deal with waters which are not fully within the EU, we should also remember that under the new CFP EU waters should also be managed on a regional basis. I fully subscribe to the notion that Europeʼs seas are best managed by the nations with direct management and economic interests in them.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this Recommendation because, although the proposed amendments do not guarantee the best protection of the marine environment and its resources, they are the result of the negotiations between the Contracting Parties following the recommendations of an assessment completed in 2011, and it is preferable that the powers of the General Committee on Mediterranean Fisheries be well defined for the effective fulfilment of its objectives which are : promote the development, conservation, rational management and better use of living marine resources, as well as the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the council's draft decision to adopt the amended Agreement establishing the General Fisheries Commission in the Mediterranean, as it gives consent to the conclusion of an agreement that will modernise and improve the commission concerned, and strengthen its role in the conservation of marine resources. I believe it is necessary to ensure the sustainable and coordinated exploitation of marine resources and ecosystems, thereby achieving their long-term and balanced conservation. In this context, it is important to clearly justify the overarching objective of the biological social, economic and environmental sustainability of living marine resources, and to better define the competences of the General Commission and the relevant sanctions. This way contributes quality and significantly to the European Union's blue growth strategy.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. A General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean does not appear to be able to effectively protect fisheries resources. For example, numerous amendments to the fishing provisions in the area covered by the CGPM agreement make it easier to fish for red coral, a species in danger of extinction. The project presented to Parliament appears to be aimed at a sustainable and respectful use of marine biological resources. I have chosen to abstain, pending whether the agreement will keep its promises.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Gabriel Mato's report, which proposes to approve the amended agreement to establish the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (an organisation whose aim is to promote the conservation and rational management of fish stocks in the Mediterranean). The amendment of the agreement should clarify the functions and objectives of the CGPM, thereby reinforcing, in my view, the effectiveness of the organization.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report. The General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (CGPM) is a regional fisheries management organisation (ORGP) with the role of promoting the development, conservation, rational management and development of living marine resources, as well as the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean Sea and the Black Sea. The objectives, general principles and functions of the MPC have been revised and expanded to ensure long-term conservation and sustainable use of marine biological resources and their environment.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe that the conservation and sustainable use of living marine resources and the overall protection of the marine ecosystem, to which these resources are found, play an important role in the context of blue development and, more generally, the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean and Black Sea region.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this because the proposals are not mature, but such a Commission is still necessary to protect European fish stocks.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Although the UK is not directly affected by this proposal, the agreement contains a number of preferable conservation measures of red coral, monk seals, sharks and rays, and technical fisheries measures to mitigate the catches of seabirds, sea turtles and cetaceans.

name: Elisabeth Köstinger (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because we must support the rational management and optimal use of living marine resources and the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of this report because it recommends approval of the conclusion of the amended agreement on the creation of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean. The rational management of marine resources and the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea are priorities of the European Union to protect the integrity of the marine heritage, and I therefore support Mr Mato's proposal.  The new agreement complements the basic elements of the common fisheries policy with regard to: the objective of maximum sustainable yield, the ecosystem and precautionary approach, the reduction of discards and the fight against illegal fishing, the modification of measures or sanctions in the event of non-compliance by members/non-members.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. The General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean will be able to take charge of many issues, such as red coral fishing, whose mismanagement has seriously damaged the Mediterranean seabed ecosystem and its fisheries resources. However, the guarantees of the effectiveness of the General Fisheries Commission's action are not sufficient for me to support this report. I therefore wished to abstain on this vote.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. CGPM is one of the so-called regional fisheries management organizations (ORPPs), whose purpose is to promote the development, conservation, rational management and better use of living marine resources, as well as the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. As a result of a performance assessment, it was considered that the Convention should be amended to clarify the objectives and functions of the CGPM and to strengthen its efficiency. The new version revises the structure and content of the current Convention in order to bring it into line with the modern instruments of the OROPs.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution on the amended agreement for the establishment of the General Committee on Mediterranean Fisheries, despite not being in favour of the provisions applicable to fisheries in the CGPM, since the agreement reviews the structure and content of the current one by introducing a clearer explanation of the purpose of the CGPM agreement (defining a clear overall objective of ecological sustainability , social, economic and environmental resources).

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. I consider that the new Convention establishing the General Committee on Fisheries in the Mediterranean contains a clearer explanation of its objective, a better definition of its functions and appropriate changes in sanctions and dispute settlement.  For all this, and due to the great importance of our marine resources and the development of our marine funds and ecosystems, I approve of this proposal, as it promotes a better and sustainable conservation of these.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour, as did 641 mePs.  Against there were only 27 people. The Mediterranean is increasingly in the spotlight of the EP. Fisheries require serious attention from the EU, and this general commission will help to develop the EU's common fisheries policy.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the acceptance, on behalf of the European Union, of the amended Agreement establishing the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean, because the new Agreement sets out a clear overall objective, which concerns the biological, social, economic and environmental sustainability of living marine resources and better defines the tasks of the GFSP , including the promotion of joint fisheries management through multiannual management plans, the designation of restricted fishing areas, and the collection and dissemination of data.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report considering the mutual interest in the development and the proper utilisation of the living marine resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea and convinced that the conservation and sustainable use of the living marine resources in the area of application and the protection of the marine ecosystems in which those resources occur, plays a major role in the context of blue growth and sustainable development.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome this recommendation concerning the draft Council decision on the acceptance, on behalf of the European Union, of the amended agreement on the creation of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean. It is of great importance to work towards a level of sustainable integration of fishing methods, respecting European standards and combating phenomena such as the IUU (Illegal, unreported, unregolated), where the submersible still has too much impact. In addition, taking measures on discards, together with a more effective provision for sanctions, makes it possible to increase quality and promote development, as well as rational management and the optimum use of living marine resources. We support sustainable development.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The conservation, rational management of living marine resources, as well as the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean, and the Black Sea, are priorities for the European Union, as part of the action aimed at protecting the integrity of the natural heritage.  For these reasons, I have decided to support, with a vote in favour, the Mato report, which recommends the approval of the conclusion of the amended agreement on the creation of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report of the Fisheries Committee on the amendment of the Convention establishing the General Committee on Fisheries of the Mediterranean (CGPM) following the decision taken by that regional body at the last annual meeting in May 2013. The new version reviews the structure and content of the current Convention in order to bring it into line with the modern instruments of regional bodies.  Among the main changes made, which I fully support, are: a clearer explanation of the purpose and underlying principles of the CGPM Convention. The new Convention sets out a clear overall objective concerning the biological, social, economic and environmental sustainability of living marine resources. It also integrates new elements of the common fisheries policy, such as maximum sustainable yield, the application of the precautionary principle and the ecosystem-based approach, the reduction of discards and the fight against illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing. Finally, it introduces provisions for the establishment of measures/sanctions with which to address cases of non-compliance of members/non-members.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on the establishment of the General Fisheries Commission in the Mediterranean, as I believe that the creation of such an institution would not bring added value to Europe. In addition, the institutions within the Union should be dismantled rather than strengthened.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The Mediterranean is a shared sea where the peoples of the river and constitute a community of mutual interests. Fishing resources are particularly at risk, particularly due to illegal fishing and pollution. The FAO-issued General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (CGPM) was founded by memorandum of understanding between states in 1952. The European Community joined in 1998. The text specifies the objectives and functions of the CGPM in order to enhance its effectiveness in preserving fisheries resources and combating poaching. I'm voting for.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Agreement establishing the General Fisheries Commission of the Mediterranean (GFCM), in accordance with the provisions of Article XIV of the FAO Constitution, was approved by the FAO Conference in 1949 and entered into force in 1952. The agreement was amendments, which were approved in 1963, 1976 and 1997. The European Community joined the GFCM on 16 June 1998 by Decision 98/416/EC. The Mediterranean and Black Sea States which are members of the EU are also parties to the agreement. THE GFCM is a regional fisheries management organisation (ORGP) that aims to promote the development, conservation, rational management and better use of marine living resources, as well as the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. This agreement has been negotiated since 2013.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of this report because I share the rapporteur’s view that the modified Agreement regarding the establishment of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean will further the development and the proper utilisation of the living marine resources in the area of application.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Agreement for the establishment of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM) was approved by the FAO Conference in 1949 and entered into force in 1952. An amendment of the GFCM Agreement was launched in 2013 and negotiated with the GFCM Contracting Parties. The negotiations were carried out by Member States and the Commission as per their respective areas of competence. I supported the main changes to this Agreement, such as a clearer explanation of the purpose of the GFCM Agreement and better—defined functions of the GFCM.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Agreement establishing the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM) was approved by the FAO Conference in 1949 and entered into force in 1952 and has regularly undergone several amendments. I voted in favour of this report because I understand how fruitful the proposal put forward is to clarify the objectives and principles underlying the CGP Agreement, and a clear overall objective of biological, social, economic and environmental sustainability of living marine resources is established.  I also consider it essential that provisions should be laid down on the establishment of measures/sanctions to deal with cases of non-compliance by members and non-members, as well as that dispute settlement mechanisms may arise between the Contracting Parties should be put in place.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The purpose of this recommendation is to accept, on behalf of the European Union, the amended agreement establishing the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (CGPM). The purpose of this commission is to promote the management and development of marine resources.  However, even if the recommendation amends the agreement itself by promoting the sustainable use of fisheries resources, the effectiveness of this committee in protecting marine resources is questionable, as evidenced by the January 2015 proposal favouring the fishing of red coral, a species that is essential to the Mediterranean Sea ecosystem.  In light of these elements, I abstained.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Although the UK is not directly affected by this proposal, the agreement contains a number of preferable conservation measures for the Mediterranean – particularly aimed at reducing unintended catches.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which authorises the amendment of the agreement to establish the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (CGPM). The CPGM, established in 1949 and joined by the European Union in 1998, aims to promote the development, conservation, rational development and development of living marine resources, as well as the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean Sea and the Black Sea. The amendments to the creation agreement approved by the European Parliament are: clarification of the purpose of the agreement, better definition of the functions of the CGPM, sanctions against parties who do not comply with the agreement, implementation of a dispute settlement system.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM) is a so-called regional fisheries management organisation that aims to promote the development, conservation, rational management and optimal use of living marine resources, as well as the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean and black sea. We welcome an amendment to the agreement of last May 2014, as it finally provides for a more detailed indication of its aims, a better definition of its functions, greater legal clarity regarding the possible use of a system of sanctions and, finally, the creation of a well-defined dispute settlement mechanism in the event of conflicts between the contracting parties. Indeed, we cannot fail to take into account the mutual interest in the development and proper exploitation of marine resources, as well as in the need to protect marine ecosystems that are increasingly sustainable.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this proposal because it calls on the Council to act on the creation of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean by amending some provisions and simplifying others. Thus, the text proposes a better definition of the functions and objective of the CGPM, which will allow for a better sanctions regime.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM) is a regional organisation that promotes the development, conservation, rational management and optimal use of living marine resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. Taking into account the mutual interest in the development and proper exploitation of living marine resources, since 2013 an amendment of the GFCM Agreement has been undertaken in order to clarify its objectives and functions and strengthen its effectiveness. In the light of the above and convinced that the conservation and sustainable exploitation of living marine resources and the protection of marine ecosystems in which these resources are present play an important role in the context of growth and sustainable development, I voted in favour of Mr Mato's report, which calls for parliament to approve it. , of this amended Agreement.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Agreement establishing the General Commission for Fisheries in the Mediterranean (CGPM) entered into force in 1952, and the European Union joined it in 1998 by Decision 98/416/EC. The EU Member States in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea are also parties to this contract. A first amendment to this agreement after the EU's accession to it occurred in 2013, and the Contracting Parties to the GFCM signed this amended document at the 38th Annual Session of the GFCM, which took place in 2014.  I voted for this report because it highlights the main changes contained in the amended agreement including: 1. increasing the biological, social, economic and environmental sustainability of living marine resources, 2. more accurately defining the functions of the GFCM, 3. granting various sanctions in the event of deviation of its members from the rules laid down in it and 4 establishing mechanisms for resolving disputes between its members.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report by my colleague in the Committee on Fisheries, Mr Gabriel Mato, is one of supporting the amendments to the agreement on the General Commission on Fisheries in the Mediterranean (CGPM), to which Romania and Bulgaria are co-signed. The GFCM is a regional organisation with the objective of managing fisheries and marine resources in a sustainable and rational way, as well as the development of aquaculture in the Black Sea and the Mediterranean. I believe that the CGPM, and therefore the agreement amended today, is a very important one for Romania and for the marine resources of our country. That is why I voted in favour of amendments to the original agreement, whereby the GFCM receives a clearer definition and functioning, a dispute resolution mechanism, but also increased powers to sanction misconduct by the signatory States.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. I abstained on the report 'Establishment of the General Fisheries Commission in the Mediterranean'. In theory, the objectives of the common fisheries policy are to guarantee that living aquatic resources are used under economically, ecologically and socially sustainable conditions, applying the precautionary principle and an ecosystem approach. This also applies to areas which go beyond the territorial waters of the Member States and Community waters. Because of some of the wording, I cannot clearly vote in favour of this report and have abstained.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal to amend the Agreement of the Committee on Fisheries in the Mediterranean in order to clarify more clearly the objectives and tasks of the Committee on Fisheries and to make it more efficient. The conservation and sustainable use of living marine resources, together with the protection of the ecosystems that are their habitat, is important for 'blue growth' and sustainable development.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The modified agreement revises the structure and content of the current agreement to bring it into line with modern ORGP tools. For this reason, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ This amendment to the agreement sets a clear overall objective of the biological, social, economic and environmental sustainability of living marine resources and provides new definitions of the terms necessary for the correct interpretation of the Agreement establishing the General Fisheries Commission in the Mediterranean. Better defining the GFCM function includes promoting joint management in fisheries through multiannual management plans, setting up restricted fishing areas and collecting and sharing data. In this regard, the new Agreement covers the fundamental components of the common fisheries policy relating to: ensuring maximum sustainable yield, protecting ecosystems and applying precautionary principles, reducing discards and combating illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. In addition, the amendment to the Agreement adopts provisions for the establishment of measures and sanctions with a view to resolving the non-compliant conduct of non-GFCM parties and sets out a well-defined dispute resolution mechanism if they occur between the parties to the Agreement. Since Croatia is a party to the agreement, I believe that a clearer regulation of these areas will contribute to better implementation of fishing policy aimed at greater sustainability of yields and protection of ecosystems, and at the same time enable better communication of exceptions and needs of specific areas of the Mediterranean such as Croatian islands or islands in the Aegean Sea.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. The creation of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (CGPM) dates back to 1919 and has been in force since 1952. The Commission's main aim is to promote the development, conservation and management of living marine resources. While these objectives are laudable, I would like to point out that doubts remain about the real protection of fisheries resources by this Commission (e.g. proposal in January to make it easier to fish for red coral, a species that is still endangered). Nevertheless, the recommendation here relates to the agreement itself and appears to be clearly aimed at the sustainable use of marine biological resources. In light of these elements, I abstained.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because the protection of the Mediterranean must be a priority for Europe so that the vastness of its resources can also be guaranteed to future generations. The conservation of these resources may be even more effective by making some necessary changes to the agreement on the creation of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean.  The amendments voted on today will make it possible to better define some of the Commission's specific functions for achieving objectives that are important to the Member States, such as the introduction of multiannual plans for the common management of fisheries, through the creation of limitation zones. This will lead to sustainable, eco-systematic and precautionary exploitation of the Mediterranean, reducing the release of waste into the sea and implementing a more concrete fight against illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing.  These objectives can also be achieved through the use of the sanctions provided for in the agreement and the creation of a mechanism for resolving conflicts between the parties.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ GFCM is a regional fisheries management organisation (RFMO), aimed at promoting the development, conservation and best possible exploitation and rational management of living marine resources, as well as the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. The amendment to the GFCM Agreement was initiated in 2013 following a performance audit finalised in 2011, which concluded that the Agreement needed to be amended to clarify the objectives and functions of the GFCM and increase its effectiveness. In this context, the new Agreement covers the core components of the common fisheries policy relating to the objective of maximum sustainable yield, ecosystem and pre-strict approach, reduction of discards and fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. I support the amended Agreement, which is aligned with the main objectives of the Common Fishing Policy. The aim of the proposal is to conclude a revised GFCM Agreement on behalf of the European Union and I hope that in addition to meeting the basic objectives of the common fishing policy, the traditional and cultural specifics of our fishermen will also be taken into account. This primarily applies to small fishermen who are completely marginalized by the existing system, although it is a tradition and lifestyle, not an invasion of ecosystems and profitable activity.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the agreement on the establishment of the General Fisheries Commission of the Mediterranean, primarily because I represent Croatia, a Mediterranean and Adriatic country that has an interest in investing in long-term development, using living marine resources, preserving ecosystems and healthy coexistence between man and nature. I believe that this amendment creates a more convincing and better picture of the agreement itself, as it sets clear goals for biological, social, economic policies of the sea and sustainable development. The very function of the Fisheries Commission, which includes the promotion of joint fisheries management through multiannual plans while establishing protected fishing grounds, is better defined. The agreement covers the basic elements of normal fishing procedures relating to maximum sustainable yield, combating all types of poaching and reducing fish catches. The provision imposes sanctions in the event that Member States do not comply with the agreement. Clear dispute resolution mechanisms between contracting parties are also put in place. The aim of this agreement is primarily to protect "Blue Growth", which is a long-term strategy and support for the sustainable development of the marine and coastal sectors as a whole. Seas are the drivers of the European economy and have great potential for innovation and growth. I therefore reiterate that we should all insist on smart and sustainable growth and development in line with the nature and needs of man.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As we know, the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM) aims to promote the development, conservation, rational management and optimal use of living marine resources, as well as the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. It is right that the agreement should be amended and updated over the years also in order to better identify the functions of the GFCM and legitimise the powers conferred on it.  In this case, the amended agreement correctly wants the new instruments of the Regional Fisheries Management Organisation. I believe that the changes that have been made are relevant, such as establishing the overall objective of the committee, which falls within the scope of the biological environmental sustainability of living marine resources and a clearer definition of the committee's functions with the creation of multiannual management plans for the common fisheries management, the right possibility of sanctions in the event of no compliance on the part of the Member States and , in the event of a conflict between members, the creation of a mechanism for resolving them.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Global warming, safeguarding the planet and sustainable development are now the new challenges facing our societies. The EU is strongly committed to Member States to promote sustainable growth and protect the environment and natural resources. The Union has also mobilised to defend marine resources, which are strongly threatened by intensive fishing. Several marine species are endangered, so it is necessary to react. With this in mind, the EU set up the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (CGPM) in 1949 to promote the development, conservation, rational management and development of marine resources, as well as the sustainable development of aquaculture. The European Parliament voted in favour of changing the structure and organisation of this committee so that it could better meet the current challenges and needs, which is what my region needs. I am pleased to have voted in favour of this text and I believe that the Union must continue to act in this area and preserve our living marine resources in the Mediterranean.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Agreement establishing the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM) was approved by the FAO Conference in 1949 and entered into force in 1952. The European Community joined the GFCM on 16 June 1998. THE GFCM is a Regional Fisheries Management Organisation (ORGP) that aims to promote the development, conservation, rational management and best use of marine living resources, as well as the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. In 2013, following a performance review finalised in 2011, a process of amending the GFCM Agreement was initiated in order to clarify the objectives, functions and efficiency of the GFCM. The amended Agreement reviews the structure and content of the current agreement in order to bring them into line with the modern instruments of THE ORPs, establishing a clear overall objective of biological, social, economic and environmental sustainability of living marine resources. I believe that the conservation and sustainable use of living marine resources and the protection of marine ecosystems play a key role in the context of blue growth and sustainable development, I voted in favour of this resolution, which approves the conclusion of the amended Agreement.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report in that I support the establishment of the General Committee on Mediterranean Fisheries (GFCM), as it is a regional fisheries management organisation (ORGP) which aims to promote the development, conservation, rational management and better use of marine living resources, as well as the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea.  The amendment to the agreement now proposed was negotiated with the Contracting Parties to the GFCM and the Council authorised the Commission to negotiate, on behalf of the Union, matters which fall within the competence of the Union.  I support the need to review the structure and content of the current agreement in order to bring them into line with modern ORGP instruments, including a clearer explanation of the objectives and principles underlying the GFCM Agreement, a better definition of the functions of the GFCM, provisions on sanctions and dispute resolution.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. This is essentially an update of the agreement for more effective conservation and sustainable use of living marine resources in its area of application.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report formally endorses the amended agreement to establish the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (CGPM). The CGPM is a regional fisheries management organisation whose role is to promote the development, conservation, rational management and development of living marine resources, as well as the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean and Black Seas.  The procedure for amending the text of the agreement to create the CGPM was launched in 2013 following a performance evaluation carried out in 2011. The main changes introduced are: a clearer explanation of the purpose of the agreement to create the CGPM, in order to define what a sustainable use of marine biological, social, economic and environmental resources would be; a better definition of the functions of the MPC, which include promoting joint management of the fishery through multi-year management plans, establishing restricted fishing areas, as well as data collection and dissemination, as well as sanctions and dispute resolution mechanisms.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This Recommendation on the acceptance, on behalf of the European Union, of the amendment to the Agreement establishing the General Committee on Fisheries in the Mediterranean has been welcomed and voted in favour because it has made clarifying changes to those which are its objectives and principles linked to the sustainability of marine resources. The amendments also included a better definition of the scope of the FUNCTIONS of the GFCM, sanctioning provisions for cases of non-compliance and a mechanism facilitating dispute resolution.  Like the rapporteur, I believe that these amendments will meet the objective of improving the sustainable use of living marine resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea, as well as ensuring the conservation and protection of marine ecosystems.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. The General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (CGPM) is a regional fisheries management organisation with the role of promoting the development, conservation, rational management and development of living marine resources, as well as the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean Sea and the Black Sea. I supported this report on the procedure for amending the text of the agreement launched in 2013, which aims to clarify the objectives and functions of the CGPM and to strengthen its effectiveness.  In the end, an agreement was reached; it provides a clearer explanation of the purpose of the agreement to create the CGPM (guaranteeing the biological, social, economic and environmental sustainable use of marine biological resources), a better definition of the functions of the CGPM (promoting joint fisheries management through multi-year management plans, establishing restricted fishing areas , as well as data collection and dissemination), provisions for the implementation of sanctions and the establishment of dispute resolution mechanisms.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I have chosen to abstain because the nascent Commission sets itself the general objective of biological, social, economic and environmental sustainability of living marine resources for fishing in the Mediterranean, but will do so on the basis of community regulations that penalise our fisheries and which, in any case, in terms of control and related sanctions, are not enforced by non-EU countries, causing differences in application and commercial disadvantage.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this Recommendation because, although the proposed amendments do not guarantee the best protection of the marine environment and its resources, they are the result of the negotiations between the Contracting Parties following the recommendations of an assessment completed in 2011, and it is preferable that the powers of the General Committee on Mediterranean Fisheries be well defined for the effective fulfilment of its objectives which are : promote the development, conservation, rational management and better use of living marine resources, as well as the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this agreement, which makes the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (CGPM) more effective. The CGPM is a regional fisheries management organisation (ORGP), whose role is to promote the development, conservation, rational management and development of living marine resources, as well as the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean and Black Seas. It brings together 23 countries: Albania, Algeria, Bulgaria, Cyprus, Croatia, Egypt, Spain, France, Greece, Israel, Italy, Lebanon, Libya, Malta, Monaco, Romania, Slovenia, Syria, Tunisia and Turkey, as well as the European Union and Japan. The reform focuses on setting clear objectives to ensure the sustainable use of marine biological resources, a better definition of the functions of the MPC and a review of sanctioning and dispute resolution procedures.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (NI)
text: In writing. Doubts remain that the protection of fisheries resources is a real objective of the Union. Last January, a proposal on certain fishing provisions in the area covered by the CGPM agreement included numerous amendments facilitating the fishing of red coral, an endangered species that is essential to the Mediterranean ecosystem. However, the project presented here deals with the agreement itself and seems to set a clear objective of sustainable use of marine biological resources. I decide to abstain on this text but will remain vigilant about its application.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution on the amended agreement for the establishment of the General Committee on Mediterranean Fisheries, despite not being in favour of the provisions applicable to fisheries in the CGPM, since the agreement reviews the structure and content of the current one by introducing a clearer explanation of the purpose of the CGPM agreement (defining a clear overall objective of ecological sustainability , social, economic and environmental of marine resources), better defines the functions of the CGPM and creates a well-defined dispute resolution mechanism.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With today's vote, we have decided to give our approval to the conclusion by the European Council of the amended agreement on the creation of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM).  The amended agreement, which revises the structure and content of the current agreement to bring it into line with the modern instruments of the HOMDs (Regional Fisheries Management Organisations), will allow a clearer definition of the aims and functions of the GFCM in order to enhance its effectiveness.  I am also sure that the new provisions for the imposition of measures or sanctions in the event of non-compliance by members and non-members, as well as the creation of a well-defined dispute settlement mechanism in the event of conflicts between the contracting parties, will play an important role in ensuring the fair protection and balanced and sustainable exploitation of the marine resources of the Mediterranean sea and the Black Sea.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
