text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a Council Decision is an important document because it clarifies the general principles underlying the Agreement of the General Commission for Fisheries for the Mediterranean, integrating the pillars of sustainable development into the marine environment. The new agreement promotes the common management of fisheries through coordinated plans with the objectives of the principle of ecosystem-based precautionary management, the reduction of discharges, the fight against illegal, unregulated and unreported fishing and the creation of marine protected areas.  I, however, stop by clarifying a concept, so that it is correctly applied in the operationalisation of this document. Maximum sustainable yield is not an objective, but a limit. To this end, the new common fisheries policy states that catch levels must remain adequate so that springs are above the level that promotes maximum sustainable yield. That is, in other words, fishing effort will have to be conservative, i.e. lower than that which promotes maximum sustainable yield.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the proper utilisation of the living marine resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea and I am convinced that the conservation and sustainable use of the living marine resources in the area of application, and the protection of the marine ecosystems in which those resources occur, will play a major role in the context of blue growth and sustainable development.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Amendments to the Agreement of the General Fisheries Commission of the Mediterranean (GFCM) were launched in 2013 and finalised in 2011 following a performance review, which concluded that the agreement should be amended to clarify the objectives and functions of the GFCM and strengthen its effectiveness. Negotiations were conducted between Member States and the Commission as well as in the areas of their competences in accordance with the terms of the mandate. The amended Agreement revises the structure and content of the current one, in order to be adopted in accordance with modern RFMO instruments. The aim of the new Agreement sets a clear Overall Objective of Biological, Social, Economic and Environmental Sustainability of Natural Resources. It also introduces definitions of the terms necessary for the correct interpretation of the Agreement. Better defined functions of the GFCM include promoting joint fisheries management through multiannual management plans, establishing fisheries in restricted areas, and collecting and disseminating data. In this context, the new Agreement integrates the core objectives of the highest sustainable yield, ecosystem, drop reduction, fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing, and therefore I support it.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this proposed regulation because it introduces measures aiming to ensure the conservation of red corals and reduce unintended catches of species in the Mediterranean such as seabirds, sea turtles and cetaceans.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. – On behalf of the European Union, the Commission calls on the Council to take a decision on the approval of the amended treaty establishing the General Fisheries Commission of the Mediterranean, which is known as a regional fishing management organisation with a view to fostering the development, conservation, rational management and best usability of living marine resources and the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. Amendments to the General Commission agreement were launched in 2013 to clarify its objectives and functions and to strengthen its effectiveness. The amended agreement revises the structure and content of the existing one and sets clear targets for biological, environmental, social, economic and environmental sustainability of natural resources. It also integrates the fundamental elements of the Common Fisheries Policy in terms of maximum sustainable yield and the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. Given the shared interest in the development and proper use of living marine resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea, and the conservation and sustainable use of marine resources and the protection of marine ecosystems, it is recommended that Parliament approve the conclusion of this modified agreement which I personally support.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I agree with the proposal as it contributes in particular to making the current agreement more effective and to defining its objectives more clearly.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 There is an absolute need to limit smuggling according to proper and environmentally friendly management of the biodiversity of the Mediterranean and the Black Sea, without ambiguities and gaps.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Council's draft decision on the acceptance, on behalf of the European Union, of the amended agreement to establish the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean, taking into account the mutual interest in the development and proper use of marine biological resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea and convinced that the conservation and sustainable use of marine biological resources in the area of application and the protection of marine ecosystems these resources play a key role in the context of blue growth and sustainable development.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the agreement on the establishment of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean. The European Union joined the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean in 1998 to promote the sustainable development, conservation and rational management of living marine resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. The text set a clearer definition of the overall objective of the organisation in terms of biological, social, economic and environmental sustainability. The new agreement also includes core elements of the Common Fisheries Policy, notably the fight against illegal fishing.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. I approved the amendment to the 1949 agreement establishing the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (CGPM). The commission, which brings together 23 countries around the Mediterranean, aims to organise a sustainable, social, economic and environmental exploitation of marine biological resources in the Mediterranean. While fisheries policy has undergone many changes in 50 years, it was time to update this agreement by incorporating new priorities, such as maximum sustainable yield, the ecosystem approach, the reduction of releases and the fight against illegal fishing.  I support the objectives of the CGPM, which should enable the Mediterranean States to act in a concerted way to tackle the problem of fisheries resources in the Mediterranean. Today, although we have very little data, we know that the situation of Mediterranean fish is catastrophic. According to the Fisheries Scientific, Technical and Economic Committee, 95% of stocks are overfished. The EU will have to impose research programmes and make ambitious management proposals.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. This report calls for the acceptance, on behalf of the European Union, of the amended agreement establishing the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean. Doubts remain about the commission's protection of fisheries resources. Last January, a proposal for certain fishing provisions in the area covered by the CGPM agreement included numerous amendments facilitating the fishing of red coral, an endangered species that is essential to the Mediterranean ecosystem. However, the project presented here deals with the agreement itself and seems to set a clear objective of sustainable use of marine biological resources. We will see to the use of whether this agreement keeps its promises. The entire National Front delegation abstained.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Recommendation because, although the proposed amendments do not guarantee the best protection of the marine environment and its resources, they are the result of negotiations between Contracting Parties following the recommendations of an assessment completed in 2011, and it is preferable that the powers of the General Committee on Mediterranean Fisheries be well defined for the effective fulfilment of its objectives which are : promote the development, conservation, rational management and better use of living marine resources, as well as the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the establishment of the General Committee on Fisheries in the Mediterranean.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel (PPE)
text: in writing. The amendment to the Convention was negotiated with the contracting parties of the General Committee on Fisheries of the Mediterranean (CGPM), and the Commission and the Member States held negotiations in the respective areas of competence in accordance with the mandate established by the Council.  The main changes better explain the Convention of the General Committee on Fisheries of the Mediterranean and the definition of the functions of this entity, as well as the possibility of imposing sanctions and the settlement of disputes.  This amended version of the Convention will contribute to improving the work of the CGPM.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution on the amended agreement for the establishment of the General Committee on Mediterranean Fisheries, despite not being in favour of the provisions applicable to fisheries in the CGPM, since the agreement reviews the structure and content of the current one by introducing a clearer explanation of the purpose of the CGPM agreement (defining a clear overall objective of ecological sustainability , social, economic and environmental of marine resources), better defines the functions of the CGPM and creates a well-defined dispute resolution mechanism.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Agreement establishing the General Fisheries Commission of the Mediterranean (GFCM), in accordance with the provisions of Article XIV of the FAO Constitution, was approved by the FAO Conference in 1949 and entered into force in 1952. The European Community joined the GFCM on 16 June 1998 by Decision 98/416/EC. The Mediterranean and Black Sea States that are members of the EU are also parties to the Agreement. In view of the mutual interest in the development and proper use of living marine resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea, and taking into account the guarantees regarding the conservation and sustainable use of living marine resources in the area of application and the protection of marine ecosystems we have nothing to counter.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. The creation of another institution is reluctant to support rather than expand the institutions within the Union. That is why I abstained from voting.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. The Regional Fisheries Organisation (RFO) is intended to promote the development, conservation, rational management and optimal use of living marine resources, as well as the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean and Black Seas. The conservation and sustainable use of living marine resources within the scope of the Convention and the protection of the relevant marine ecosystems play an important role in blue growth and sustainable development. However, maritime ecosystems are developing across borders. In this area, the EU can indeed create structures to support cooperation between the neighbouring countries. That is why I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the agreement to set up the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean. The amendment to the GFCM agreement was initiated in 2013. Following the 2011 review of the results of the action, it was concluded that the agreement should be amended in order to define its objectives and functions more clearly and to strengthen its effectiveness. The overall objective of this agreement is the biological, social, economic and environmental sustainability of living marine resources.  The main tasks of the committee set up will be the promotion of development, conservation, rational management and the best use of living marine resources, as well as the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. The clear rules governing the dispute settlement mechanism in the event of a dispute settlement mechanism between the parties to the agreement are also important. The new agreement integrates key elements of the common strategy on maximum sustainable fishing, the protection of the ecosystem, the reduction of discards, as well as the fight against illegal and unregulated fishing, which will contribute to strengthening the effectiveness of the common fisheries policy.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report calling for the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of the MEP, firstly since the Member himself agrees with the suspension of the MEP; and secondly because the facts for which he is going to enter the judicial proceedings are not related to his activity as an MEP, but happened during the period when he was president of a Greek football club.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. I abstained on the lifting of Mr Zagorakis' parliamentary immunity. The alleged offence is unrelated to his status as a Member of the European Parliament, but is a matter of his professional activity. Criminal action therefore does not concern an opinion or vote cast by the Member in the course of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament, especially since the proceedings were initiated before he took office as an MEP. The lifting of parliamentary immunity may seem justified, but would require further information to be provided to parliamentarians so that they can make an informed decision.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The alleged offence relates to before Mr Zagorakis’ time as an MEP.  It relates to a substantive allegation.  It would be inappropriate for the European Union to prevent the judicial process; therefore, I voted in favour of waiver of the Parliamentary immunity.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting the immunity of Theodoros Zagorakis, requested by the parliamentarian himself to answer for facts alleged against him during the time when this ex-footballer was president of the PAOK Salonique football club.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This request for the waiver of immunity concerns the indictment of Theodoros Zagorakis for negligent assault and breach of safety obligations in a workplace of an employee of the PAOK football club of which he is president and legal representative. Since the investigation began before the election and had no direct connection to politics or the desire to harm the Member in the political context, I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of Theodoros Zagorakis before the request made by the Supreme Court of Greece in this regard and the investigation carried out in Greece over the last five years, as well as taking into account, moreover, that the accusation made to him is not linked to his exercise as a European parliamentarian but to the exercise of his position as president of a football club.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the Deputy Prosecutor of the Supreme Court of the Hellenic Republic has requested the waiver of the immunity of Mr Theodor Zagorakis, a Member of the European Parliament, in order to take possible legal action in respect of the alleged offence. This member is charged with bodily injury for negligence and for failing to comply with workplace safety rules. This alleged offence is clearly not related to his service as a Member of the European Parliament, but relates to his duties as chairman of the FOOTBALL CLUB PAOK. Furthermore, there is no reason to believe that the process is intended to undermine the activities of a Member (fumus persecutionis), given that the prosecution began several years before the MEP took office. This Decision of Parliament will be referred to the Public Prosecutor's Office of the Supreme Court of Greece.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. The Greek Supreme Court has requested the lifting of Theodoros Zagorakis' parliamentary immunity on the basis of an alleged offence. Indeed, the facts alleged against him are unrelated to his position as an MEP, insofar as they began before his election to the European Parliament and are not of a political nature since they are acts of negligent assault and injury suffered by an employee of the football club of which Mr Zagorakis is the legal representative.  The request to waive immunity for indictment therefore seems to me to be justified and legal. That is why I voted for it.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of waiving immunity.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is a democratic prerequisite that legal process is complied with. Moreover, it serves the interests of all parties that the matter is heard before a court of law where it can be ruled on objectively and impartially.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of waiving Mr Zagorakis' parliamentary immunity following the request of the deputy prosecutor of the Greek Supreme Court. Zakorakis is accused of negligent bodily injury and non-compliance with workplace safety requirements, which have no connection with the position of MEMBER of the European Parliament. The proceedings were also initiated before the beginning of the mandate. The case refers to an accident at work, which occurred in 2010, to an employee of the PAOK football club at the club's stadium in Thessaloniki, of which Zagorakis is president and legal representative.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because the Greek MP, The-doros Zagorakis, is being indicted in his country for negligent assault and breach of workplace safety obligations. However, this alleged offence is unrelated to his status as a Member of the European Parliament: he is not being prosecuted for a political opinion or a vote. Mr Zagorakis is being prosecuted in his capacity as president of the PAOK football club. In this context, it seemed normal to vote in favour of lifting his immunity.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The measure refers to the request by the Public Prosecutor's Office of the Greek Republic for the waiver of European immunity against MEP Theodoros Zagorakis by the European Parliament. From reading the documents, I have been able to verify that the alleged crime in question is outside the exercise of parliamentary duties and therefore affects the personal sphere of a private citizen, contrary to Article 8 of Protocol 7, which refers to the privileges and immunities of Members of the European Parliament.  For the above premise, I voted in favour because I do not believe that there is a fumus persecutionis.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of waiving Therendt's immunity. Mr Zagorakis because the fact under consideration, namely the alleged offence of negligent bodily injury on 13 May 2010 against an employee of the PAOK football club in Thessaloniki, has no connection with his colleague's position as an MEP. On the contrary, the ongoing criminal proceedings, initiated a few years before the start of his term of office, are related to Zagorakis's position as president and legal representative of the club.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Committee on Legal Affairs considered requests for the waiver of immunity of Mr Zagorakis having regard to the complexity of the case, and made a proposal for a reasoned decision which recommended the adoption of the request for the waiver of immunity; thus I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the request of the deputy prosecutor of the Supreme Court of Greece on 19 December 2014, the rapporteur Evelyn Regner asks Parliament to waive the parliamentary immunity of Member Theodoros Zagorakis (PPE). The request for the waiver of parliamentary immunity is part of a criminal investigation in which Zakorakis is charged with the crime of negligent bodily injury and non-compliance with workplace safety requirements. The investigation relates to an occupational injury, which occurred on 13 May 2010, to an employee of the PAOK football club at the club's stadium in Thessaloniki and charged zagorakis as president and legal representative of the club. The alleged offence clearly has no connection to Zagorakis' position as an MEP but is only linked to his position as president of the PAOK football club. Furthermore, there is no reason to assume that the procedure could prejudice the political activity of the Member, given that it was initiated several years before the beginning of the Member's term of office.  For these reasons, I am voting in favour of waiving parliamentary immunity and of conducting the trial of Zakorakis in an ordinary manner.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. The Zagorakis MP who is the subject of criminal proceedings in Greece is not a request to waive immunity motivated by political intentions or regarding freely expressed personal opinions. In order to let the Greek justice system do its job, I voted in favour of lifting the parliamentary immunity of Mr Zagorakis.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The report which will be discussed and adopted on Monday evening in committee will recommend waiving the immunity of Theodoros Zagorakis, who has been accused of bodily harm and infringement of his obligations as an employer by endangering the health and safety of staff by failing to make sure equipment was suitable for use. It specifically concerns allegations that handrails were not fitted to a metal ladder, which resulted in a fall and two arm fractures of an employee. Since the alleged offences do not have a direct or obvious connection with his performance of his duties as a MEP, nor constitute an opinion expressed or a vote cast in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament for the purposes of Article 8 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the EU, the ECR will support the recommendation in the report to waive his immunity.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report as I am in favour of treating MEPs in the same way as other citizens in any case where justice is called for.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. This point deals with the waiver of the immunity of Theodoros Zagorakis, an Mep of the EPP, at the request of the Deputy Prosecutor of the Supreme Court of Justice of Greece and communicated in plenary on 28 January 2015 in the context of procedure E2010/3844 in progress before the Criminal Court of Thessaloniki. In view of the relevant legal provisions, the case-law and the report of the Committee on Legal Affairs, I voted in favour of the waiver of this Member's immunity, in unison with a majority of Members of the European Parliament, whereas Theodoros Zagorakis is accused of breaching the physical integrity and non-compliance with safety standards at work as president of the PAOK football club, and whereas there is no reason to presume that the legal action is to prejudice the political activity of the Member, as it was initiated several years before the beginning of the member's term of office, in line with the recitals of the European Parliament's decision of 11 March 2015.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The aim of this report is to lift parliamentary immunity to Theodoros Zagorakis of the EPP. The deputy is accused of violation of physical integrity and failure to comply with safety standards in the workplace. The lawsuit relates to the work accident suffered in May 2010 by an official of the PAOK football club at the club's stadium in Thessaloniki. Theodoros Zagorakis is a defendant as president and legal representative of the club. The alleged infringement has no manifest relationship with the situation of Theodoros Zagorakis as a Member of the European Parliament and is only related to his duties as president of the PAOK football club. Consequently, the legal action does not concern any opinion or vote expressed in the exercise of your term as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union. Thus, there is no reason to assume that the legal action is to undermine the political activity of the Member, since it was initiated several years before the beginning of the mandate of the Member, so that parliamentary immunity should be lifted. We voted in favour.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of treating MEPs in the same way as other citizens in any case where justice is sought.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted positively in favour of the report on the waiver of the immunity of Theodoros Zagokaris. Since, under the Constitution of the Hellenic Republic, a Member of Parliament cannot be prosecuted during a legislative term without parliament's approval, he cannot be detained or arrested or otherwise restricted in his liberty. I would like to stress that the alleged offence is clearly not related to the position of Theodoros Zagorakis as a Member of the European Parliament, but rather to his position as President of the PAOK football club.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favor of this request for waiver as there is no reason to suspect that the intention underlying the criminal proceedings is to damage a Member’s political activity (fumus persecutionis), given that the prosecution was initiated a number of years before the Member took office.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the waiver of the immunity of Theodoros Zagorakis following the request of the Greek Supreme Court. In this case, there is no reason to suspect that the intention underlying the criminal proceedings is to damage a Member’s political activity.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒I voted for a proposal for a decision by the European Parliament on a request to lift the immunity of Theodoros Zagorakis according to the proposal we received. In accordance with Article 8 Protocol No. 7 On the privileges and immunies of the European Union, in this particular case it is not about expressing an opinion in the performance of the duties of a Member of the European Parliament, but an alleged criminal offence. It is also important to note that prosecutions were launched before Mr Zagorakis became a member of this Parliament.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Evelyn Regner's report on the request by the prosecutor to lift Theodoros Zagorakis' parliamentary immunity at the Greek Supreme Court concerning his indictment for negligent assault and failure to comply with safety obligations following a 2010 work accident at the PAOK football club headed by Mr Zagorakis. This report has been adopted, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the request to lift the immunity of MP Theodoros Zagorakis, sent dated 19 December 2014 by the prosecutor's office to the Greek Supreme Court.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. Since Mr Zagorakis agrees to waive his immunity, I support this move.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the request for the waiver of The honourable Member's parliamentary immunity. Zagorakis, Theodoros. The instrument of parliamentary immunity serves to defend and preserve the Member in the performance of his duties, enabling him to carry out his mandate unconditionally and freely, but these considerations obviously do not occur in cases such as this, where the contested acts and the reasons for the dispute itself do not fall within the activities relating to the parliamentary mandate or the function of a Member.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. The Zagorakis MP who is the subject of criminal proceedings in Greece is not a request to waive immunity motivated by political intentions or regarding freely expressed personal opinions. In order to let the Greek justice system do its job, I voted in favour of lifting the parliamentary immunity of Mr Zagorakis.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report calling for the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of the MEP, because it will allow, as he claims, to investigate and judge the events that took place during the period during which he was president of a Greek football club.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the request to waive the immunity of Theodoros Zagorakis following the positive recommendation of the Committee on Legal Affairs of the European Parliament and the VERY wish of the MEP.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this as there is no reason to suspect that the intention underlying the criminal proceedings is to damage a Member’s political activity (fumus persecutionis), given that the prosecution was initiated a number of years before the Member took office.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the light of Mr Syp.'s request for parliamentary immunity, i.e. the request for parliamentary immunity, i.e. the request for parliamentary immunity, i.e. the request for parliamentary immunity, i Theodoros Zagorakis in the context of a possible investigation into an alleged crime, considering that the principle on which parliamentary immunity is based, provided for in Article 8 of the Protocol, is the freedom of Members to express themselves by representing their constituents on matters of public interest, freely making their comments without being able to be sued before a court or other authority. Whereas the alleged offence has no connection with the position of Theodoros Zagorakis as a Member of the European Parliament, whereas he is in contact with his position as president of the PAOK football club; whereas there is no reason to assume that the procedure depends on the intention to prejudice the political activity of the Member (fumus persecutionis), since it was initiated several years before the beginning of the Member's term of office, I am in favour of waiving immunity

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The deputy prosecutor of the Greek Supreme Court has requested the waiver of the immunity of Theodoros Zagorakis, a Member of the European Parliament, in the context of an investigation into an alleged crime. In view of the fact that Mr Sy would like to see the commission's report on the Theodoros Zagorakis is accused of negligent bodily injury and failure to comply with safety requirements in the workplace, and I am trying to take account of the fact that parliamentary immunity is only applicable in cases where an opinion or a vote is expressed in the exercise of the function of MEP, I have decided to support the Regner report.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. The negligent bodily injury he is accused of is not related to his political activities. That is why I voted in favour of waiving immunity.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The request concerns the lifting of Theodoros Zagorakis' parliamentary immunity. Theodoros Zagorakis, before becoming an EPP MEP, was the director of a football club in Thessaloniki. He is charged with negligence and breach of workplace safety standards as a result of a workplace accident suffered by one of the club's employees in May 2010. Since Theodoros Zagorakis himself is asking for the lifting of his immunity in order to shed light on this case, I cannot oppose it and I vote FOR.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The defence of the independence of the Mandate of the European Parliament is the responsibility of the European Parliament and that independence cannot be called into question. In accordance with Article 8 of the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, members of the European Parliament may not be sought, detained or persecuted for the opinions or votes cast in the performance of their duties. This request is made by the Deputy Prosecutor of the Supreme Court of Justice of Greece who requested the waiver of the immunity of Theodoros Zagorakis, a Member of the European Parliament, in the context of a possible conviction for an alleged offence. Theodoros Zagorakis is accused of violating culpable physical integrity and failure to comply with workplace safety standards. The charge in question is related to the work accident suffered on May 13, 2010 by an official of the paok football club at the club's stadium in Thessaloniki is directed against Theodoros Zagorakis as president and legal representative of the club. Since the alleged infringement has no manifest relationship with the situation of Theodoros Zagorakis as a Member of the European Parliament, I therefore voted in favour of the waiver of parliamentary immunity.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the request for waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Theodoros Zagorakis

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The Greek Supreme Court has requested the lifting of Theodoros Zagorakis' parliamentary immunity for an alleged offence. Indeed, the facts alleged against him are unrelated to his position as an MEP, insofar as they began before his election to the European Parliament and are not of a political nature since they are acts of negligent assault and injury suffered by an employee of the football club of which Mr Zagorakis is a legal representative.  The application to waive immunity for indictment therefore seems to me to be justified and legal. That is why I voted for it.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Mr Zagorakis' request to lift his immunity in the interests of transparency in the activities of all members of our political family, and because that is what the main interested party wishes to go.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Greece's Supreme Court has asked for the waiver of the immunity of Mr Zagorakis, a Member of the European Parliament, who has been charged with negligent bodily injury and non-compliance with workplace safety requirements. The criminal proceedings relate to an injury to an employee of the paok football club, charged to Zagorakis as president and lawyer of the club. In accordance with Article 9 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the EU, Members of the European Parliament shall enjoy on their national territory the same immunities as members of their country and, pursuant to Article 62 of the Greek Constitution, a Member may not be the subject of criminal proceedings, arrest or detention during the parliamentary term without the consent of parliament. In the light of the above, I supported Mr Regner's request to waive immunity because the alleged offence has no connection with Mr Zagorakis' position as a Member of the European Parliament. Instead, he is linked with his position as president of the football club PAOK. Furthermore, there is no reason to assume that the procedure depends on the intention to prejudice the political activity of the Member (fumus persecutionis), since it was initiated several years before the start of the European mandate.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report to lift immunity.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of waiving the immunity of Theodoros Zagorakis, since, first of all, the alleged offence appears to be unrelated to the position of Theodoros Zagorakis as a Member of the European Parliament, but rather to his position as chairman of the PAOK football club. Moreover, this is the only way in which the authorities can clarify the facts in an orderly manner. In addition, the honourable Member himself also voted in favour of waiving immunity.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported Theodoros Zagorakis' request for waiver of immunity because he is in the criminal court pending proceedings in connection with a possible judicial penalty for the alleged crime.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The deputy prosecutor of the Supreme Court of Greece has requested the waiver of the immunity of Theodoros Zagorakis, a Member of the European Parliament, in the context of a possible investigation into an alleged crime. The alleged crime clearly has no connection with the position of Theodoros Zagorakis as a Member of the European Parliament. There is no reason to assume that the proceedings depend on the intention to prejudice the political activity of the Member (fumus persecutionis), since it was initiated several years before the start of the Member's term of office. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. This request for the waiver of immunity concerns the indictment of Theodoros Zagorakis for negligent assault and breach of safety obligations in a workplace of an employee of the PAOK football club of which he is president and legal representative. Since the investigation began before the election and had no direct connection to politics or the desire to harm the Member in the political context, I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I respect the rapporteur's recommendation because, although prosecution is not related to the opinion expressed or the vote to serve as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8 of the EIA, it is not related to the opinion expressed or to vote in the performance of its duties as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8 of the Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunies of the European Union, and the alleged offence is clearly not in any relation to the performance of his or her duties as a Member of the European Parliament, but concerns his function as president of the PAOK football club, there is no reason to assume that the prosecution was initiated with the intention of causing political damage to the member concerned (fumus persecutionis) as it was initiated several years before he became a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported MP Evelyn Regner's report on the request to lift the immunity of fellow MP Theodoros Zagorakis. Parliamentary immunity is a remedy that protects the smooth functioning of Members and thus constitutes a necessary means of protecting parliament's independence. In order to be credible, it is important that parliamentary immunity is solely an instrument of protection against politically motivated persecution. In the case of fellow MEP Theodorus Zagorakis, the Committee on Legal Affairs found that it was not a prosecution brought with the intention of causing political damage to a Member because it was launched a few years before he became an MEP. Since the initiated proceedings have nothing to do with the performance of Theodoros Zagorakis' duties as an MEP, I agree with the unanimous decision of the Committee on Legal Affairs on the waiver of immunity, as the remedy for the protection of citizens' representatives at EU level must not place Members above the law.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In giving my consent to the waiver of Theodoros Zagorakis' immunity, I have strictly adhered to the report of the Legal Affairs Committee of the European Parliament. The crime of which Theodoros Zagorakis is accused predates his election as a Member of the European Parliament, specifically concerns the events that took place in 2010 and is related to his position as president of the paok football club. The criminal proceedings for this crime do not concern any act related to the exercise of Theodoros Zagorakis' mandate as a Member of the European Parliament, and was initiated years before the beginning of his term of office.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this request. The lawsuit relating to the accident at work suffered on May 13, 2010 by an official of the PAOK football club at the club's stadium in Thessaloniki is directed against Theodoros Zagorakis as president and legal representative of the club, so the alleged infringement has no manifest relationship with the situation of Theodoros Zagorakis as a Member of the European Parliament and there is no reason to assume that the lawsuit is aimed at harming the activity member's policy, as it was initiated several years before the start of the Member's term of office.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a matter of Greek internal justice, unrelated to the status of deputy of Theodoros Zagorakis.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of Theodoros Zagorakis before the request made by the Supreme Court of Greece in this regard and the investigation carried out in Greece over the last five years, as well as taking into account, moreover, that the accusation made to him is not linked to his exercise as a European parliamentarian but to the exercise of his position as president of a football club.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting Mr. Theodoros Zagorakis, so that the Greek justice system can do its job, with strict respect for the rights of the defence, concerning the possible sanction of an alleged offence, the prosecutions not intended to harm the political career of the Member concerned, but to shed light on a case of assault that occurred in 2010 in the stadium of the club PAOK in Thessaloniki , of which Mr. Zagorakis is the President.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted to lift Theodoros Zagorakis' immunity in order to let the Greek justice system take its course in a case unrelated to Theodoros Zagorakis' status as a Member of the European Parliament, but rather to his term as president of the PAOK football club.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report calling for the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of the MEP, firstly since the Member himself agrees with the suspension of the MEP; and secondly because the facts for which he is going to enter the judicial proceedings are not related to his activity as an MEP, but happened during the period when he was president of a Greek football club.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Socialists and Democrats Group voted in favour of the request for waiver of the immunity of Theodoros Zagorakis. There is no reason to suspect that the intention underlying the criminal proceedings is to damage the Member’s political activity, given that the prosecution was initiated a number of years before Mr Zagorakis took office.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support the European Parliament's decision lifting Theodoros Zagorakis' immunity, as he is accused of causing bodily harm by inaction and failure to follow workplace safety regulations, and the alleged offence is clearly not in any way related to the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament but in relation to his function as president of paok football club.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. – I supported the report on the basis of a request by the Assistant Public Prosecutor of the Supreme Court in Greece submitted on 19 December 2014, concerning the taking of legal action for the alleged criminal offence of causing bodily harm. Theodoros Zagorakis is accused of inaction inflicting bodily harm on one of the club's employees while serving as president of the Greek football club PAOK.  The European Parliament has decided to vote to lift the immunity of MEP Theodoros Zagorakis. I support this position and vote to waive immunity since the fellow MEP himself has requested it, thereby giving full respect and confidence to the Greek justice system.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 MEPs should be held to account in court when the need to investigate their activities is required, in accordance with existing legal procedures.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted to lift Theodoros Zagorakis' immunity so that he could defend himself in court in his country against the facts alleged against him.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ It is not the intention of this Chamber to damage the image of one of its Members, but as the prosecution of Mr Theodoros Zagorakis began several years before he became an MEP and the indictment refers to a work accident in 2010 when he was president of the football club PAOK, I think there are enough reasons to suspend his immunity in order to be accountable to justice, like any other Greek citizens.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of suspending the immunity of MEP Theodoros Zagorakis.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report calling for the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of the MEP, firstly since the Member himself agrees with the suspension of the MEP; and secondly because the facts for which he is going to enter the judicial proceedings are not related to his activity as an MEP, but happened during the period when he was president of a Greek football club.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The deputy is charged with breach of culpable physical integrity and non-compliance with workplace safety standards and the related lawsuit relates to the work accident suffered on May 13, 2010 by an official of the PAOK football club at the club's stadium in Thessaloniki.  The alleged infringement has no manifest relationship with the situation of Theodoros Zagorakis as a Member of the European Parliament and is only related to his duties as president of the PAOK football club. Consequently, the legal action does not concern any opinion or vote expressed in the exercise of your term as a Member of the European Parliament. Thus, it is considered that there is no reason to assume that the legal action is to undermine the political activity of the Member, since it was initiated several years before the beginning of the mandate of the Member, so that parliamentary immunity should be lifted.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. The negligent bodily injury he is accused of is not related to his political activities. That is why I voted in favour of waiving immunity.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The aim of this report is to lift parliamentary immunity to Theodoros Zagorakis of the EPP. The deputy is accused of violation of physical integrity and failure to comply with safety standards in the workplace. The lawsuit related to the work accident suffered on May 13, 2010 by an official of the PAOK football club at the club's stadium in Thessaloniki. Theodoros Zagorakis is a defendant as president and legal representative of the club. The alleged infringement has no manifest relationship with the situation of Theodoros Zagorakis as a Member of the European Parliament and is only related to his duties as president of the PAOK football club. Consequently, the legal action does not concern any opinion or vote expressed in the exercise of your term as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union. Thus, it is considered that there is no reason to assume that the legal action is to undermine the political activity of the Member, since it was initiated several years before the beginning of the mandate of the Member so that parliamentary immunity should be lifted. We voted for it.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report calling for the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of the MEP concerned in order to deal with a criminal charge for allegedly losing seven documents containing state secrecy under the Law on the Protection of Classified Information when he was Prime Minister of the Republic of Bulgaria.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. I abstained on the lifting of Mr Sergei Stanishev's parliamentary immunity. The case concerning him is not directly related to the performance of his duties as an MEP, especially since he was already the subject of a preparatory instruction before the performance of his duties. The lifting of parliamentary immunity may seem justified, but would require further information to be provided to parliamentarians so that they can make an informed decision.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ As with the previous case, this does not relate to Mr Stanishev’s work as an MEP. I am aware of no clear reason to defend immunity in this case. Therefore I voted in favour of waiving the parliamentary immunity.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the immune lift of Sergei Stanishev, requested by the parliamentarian himself to answer for the disappearance of secret documents during his time as Prime Minister of Bulgaria.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. Sergei Stanishev, when he was Prime Minister of Bulgaria between 2005 and 2009, is accused of losing seven documents containing information constituting state secrets. As the investigation against Mr Stanishev began before his election to the European Parliament and Mr Stanishev had given his written approval for the opening of criminal proceedings against him, I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of Sergei Stanishev's parliamentary immunity in view of the assumption by the Attorney-General of the Republic of Bulgaria of the Office of the Public Prosecutor of the City of Sofia of authorisation to continue the criminal proceedings against Sergei Stanishev that the investigations were initiated prior to the assumption of his duties as AN MEP and that Moreover, the accusation made against him is not linked to his exercise as a European parliamentarian.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the Attorney General of the Republic of Bulgaria has forwarded a request from the Sofia City Prosecutor's Office for authorisation to continue the criminal proceedings initiated against Mr Sergei Stanishev, a Member of the European Parliament. It is alleged that, in his capacity as Prime Minister of the Republic of Bulgaria, he lost seven documents containing classified information which, under the Bulgarian Law on the Protection of Classified Information ('the ACT of the IIA'), constitutes state secrets. In particular, Mr Stanishev is suspected of having transferred these documents in breach of the established rules, since the transmission of documents was not properly recorded in the Register of Classified Information of the Council of Ministers. Prosecutors therefore claim that Mr Stanishev was unable to comply carefully with the procedures for storing, transmitting and distributing documents laid down in the ACT of the AIA and its implementing rules and in the internal rules for the handling of classified information by the Council of Ministers. The European Parliament shall apply its consistent principles in order to decide whether or not to waive the parliamentary immunity. One of the following principles is that immunity is usually waived where the offence does not relate to the duties of a Member, if there is no evidence of fumus persecutionis, i.e. sufficiently serious and clear suspicions that the court has been seised in order to damage the political reputation of the Member concerned.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. The request for the waiver of immunity here concerns Sergei Stanishev. The alleged facts relate to mr Stanishev's time as Prime Minister of Bulgaria. He is accused of misplacing seven documents under state secrecy during the performance of his duties.  As the events occurred before he entered the European Parliament and having no direct connection to his role as an MEP, I voted in favour of the request to lift his parliamentary immunity.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the request for waiver of immunity.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is a democratic prerequisite that legal process is complied with. Moreover, it serves the interests of all parties that the matter is heard before a court of law where it can be ruled on objectively and impartially.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Former Bulgarian Prime Minister Stanishev has been accused of losing documents containing information considered state secrets under Bulgarian law during his duties (between 2005 and 2007). The documents would not have been transmitted in accordance with the applicable legislation as the transfer was not entered in the classified information register of the Council of Ministers. The administrative criminal proceedings which have resulted from this have been interrupted several times as a result of the honourable Member's posts, and I have therefore voted in favour of waiving his immunity in order to allow it to be completed.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which dealt with Sergei Stanishev's request to waive his parliamentary immunity. Mr Stanishev, when he was Prime Minister of Bulgaria, is accused of having lost seven documents during the period between 4 November 2005 and 27 July 2009 containing information constituting state secrets within the meaning of Bulgaria's Classified Information Protection Act. However, in addition to the fact that, in the context of the Bulgarian criminal proceedings against him, Mr Stanishev agreed that his parliamentary immunity should be lifted, the alleged offence has no direct or obvious link to Sergei Stanishev's exercise of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament and does not constitute an opinion or vote cast by him in the exercise of those functions within the meaning of Article 8 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Parliament. European. Finally, Mr Sergei Stanishev was already the subject of a preparatory instruction long before his election to the European Parliament, and this instruction is therefore not related to his duties as an MEP.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The measure refers to the request by the Public Prosecutor's Office of the Bulgarian Republic for the waiver of European immunity against MEP Sergei Stanishev by the European Parliament. From reading the documents, I have been able to verify that the alleged crime in question is outside the exercise of parliamentary duties and therefore affects the personal sphere of a private citizen, contrary to Article 8 of Protocol 7, which refers to the privileges and immunities of Members of the European Parliament.  For the above premise, I voted in favour because I do not believe that there is a fumus persecutionis.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The rapporteur, Andrzej Duda, calls on the European Parliament to waive the parliamentary immunity of Bulgarian MEP Sergei Stanishev (S&D) following the request of the Chief Prosecutor of Bulgaria on 24 November 2014. The request for the waiver of parliamentary immunity is part of a criminal investigation involving Stanisev for disclosing information covered by state secrecy entrusted to him when he was Prime Minister of the Republic of Bulgaria. On the basis of the facts and circumstances described and the evidence gathered in the case, Sergei Stanishev is accused of having lost the abovementioned documents, i.e. he inadvertently lost control over non-compliance with the procedures for safeguarding, transferring and circulating documents defined in the relevant implementing rules and in the internal rules of the Council of Ministers for the processing of classified information. The Member did not oppose the waiver of parliamentary immunity, which was unanimously decided by the Committee on Legal Affairs at its sitting of 9 March. There is therefore no reason to vote against and I am voting in favour of waiving the parliamentary immunity of Member Sergei Stanishev.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. The Mp Stanishev is the subject of criminal proceedings in Bulgaria, this is not a request to waive immunity motivated by political intentions or concerning freely expressed personal opinions. In order to let the Bulgarian judiciary do its job, I voted in favour of lifting the parliamentary immunity of MP Stanishev.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report as I am in favour of treating MEPs in the same way as other citizens in any case where justice is called for.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Sergei Stanishev is accused of having lost, in the performance of his duties as Prime Minister of Bulgaria, 7 documents with information constituting state secrecy and having transmitted them in default of the established rules, since the transfer was not duly recorded in the register of classified information of the Bulgarian Council of Ministers. Sergei Stanishev himself expressed his consent to the initiation of proceedings against himself which began in 2010, but which had to be suspended for taking up his duties as a Member of the National Assembly and subsequently resumed after Stanishev expressed consent to the continuation of the proceedings, which led to the initiation of criminal proceedings of an administrative nature. However, when Sergei Stanishev was elected as a Member of the EP in May 2014, the Court ordered the suspension of the proceedings because of the new type of immunity that the target personality enjoyed. The request for waiver of parliamentary immunity came through the Attorney General of the Republic of Bulgaria. I do not object to that request, since the alleged acts do not have a direct or obvious link with the exercise of the duties of a Member of the EP, nor do they constitute opinions or votes expressed in the performance of his duties as a Member of the EP.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Sergei Stanishev, now a Member of the European Parliament, is alleged to have lost seven documents as Prime Minister of the Republic of Bulgaria in the exercise of his duties as Prime Minister of the Republic of Bulgaria, within the meaning of bulgarian law on the protection of classified information.  Having the view that: - The alleged acts do not have a direct or obvious link with the exercise of the duties of Member of the European Parliament of Sergei Stanishev, nor do they constitute opinions or votes expressed in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union; Investigations prior to the trial of Sergei Stanishev were initiated long before the target became a Member of the European Parliament; - Sergei Stanishev, first as Prime Minister and then as a Member of the National Assembly, made two written statements to the President of the National Assembly, in which he declared that he would call for criminal proceedings against himself; - Parliament has not found any sufficiently serious and reasoned suspicion that, at the origin of the criminal proceedings, it is intended to undermine the political activity of the Member; We voted in favour of this report which considers that parliamentary immunity should be lifted.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of treating MEPs in the same way as other citizens in any case where justice is sought.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the waived immunity of Sergei Stanishev, so I supported the report with a positive vote. In the present case, the Protocol on the privileges and immunities of the European Union applies, according to which Members enjoy immunity for members of their parliament in the territory of their own State, and the Bulgarian Constitution stipulates that the prosecution of members of the Bulgarian Parliament is subject to the prior authorisation of the former. The European Parliament's decision is therefore necessary for the prosecution of Mr Stanishev. On the basis of the evidence, it appears that the alleged offence was committed during Mr Stanishev's time as Bulgarian Prime Minister and only in the context of that office and that preliminary proceedings were started long before Mr Stanishev became an MEP. It follows that the criminal proceedings against Sergei Stanishev are in no way linked to his current position as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this request for waiver as in this case Parliament has found no evidence of fumus persecutionis, that is to say, a sufficiently serious and precise suspicion that the case has been brought with the intention of causing political damage to the Member concerned.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the waiver of the immunity of Sergei Stanishev. In this case, there is no reason to suspect that the intention underlying the criminal proceedings is to damage a Member’s political activity.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a decision by the European Parliament on a request to lift Sergei Stanishev's immunity on the basis of a criminal offence, and the judicial investigation process began before Mr Stanishev became a member of the European Parliament. In addition, Mr Stanishev submitted two statements to the President of the Bulgarian National Assembly agreeing to bring criminal proceedings against him at the time he served as Prime Minister of the Republic of Bulgaria and a member of the National Assembly.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. The request to waive Sergei Stanishev's parliamentary immunity is not motivated by acts in the course of his duties as an MEP. A lifting of immunity would be justifiable if Parliament had more information. That's why I abstained.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Andrzej Duda's report on Sergei Stanishev's request to lift his parliamentary immunity. This procedure, requested by the Member concerned, is a formality in order to enable the judicial authorities to carry out their investigative work. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Sergei Stanishev's request to lift his immunity, submitted on 24 November 2014 by the Attorney General of the Republic of Bulgaria, in connection with the pending legal proceedings before the Sofia City Court.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. Since Mr Stanishev agrees to waive his immunity, I support this move.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. The Mp Stanishev is the subject of criminal proceedings in Bulgaria, this is not a request to waive immunity motivated by political intentions or concerning freely expressed personal opinions. In order to let the Bulgarian judiciary do its job, I voted in favour of lifting the parliamentary immunity of MP Stanishev.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report calling for the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of the MEP concerned in order to deal with a criminal charge for allegedly losing seven documents containing state secrecy under the Law on the Protection of Classified Information when he was Prime Minister of the Republic of Bulgaria.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This story about Sergei Stanisev's immunity has a long history. Sergey Stanisev, my Bulgarian colleague, has been under prosecution since 2009, allegedly for the loss of secret documents. I sympathise with the S&D group's position that immunity should be waived so that the court can establish Sergei Stanisev's innocence as soon as possible. It is a democracy - not to use immunity to hide from the investigation, although it is clear that the case smells of political order. I voted in favour of withdrawing my parliamentary immunity.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the request for the waiver of Sergei Stanishev's parliamentary immunity following the positive recommendation of the Committee on Legal Affairs of the European Parliament.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report as in this case Parliament has found no evidence of fumus persecutionis, that is to say, a sufficiently serious and precise suspicion that the case has been brought with the intention of causing political damage to the Member concerned.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With reference to the request for waiver of Sergei Stanishev's parliamentary immunity, considering the nature of the matter, I am in favour of waiving immunity. What has happened in this particular case is outside the scope of a case relating to duties or expressions of opinion linked to the office of Member of the European Parliament, and therefore eliminates the possibility that Article 8 of the Protocol may apply. Furthermore, Parliament has found no evidence of fumus persecutionis, that is to say, a sufficiently well-founded and precise suspicion that the case brought was aimed at causing political damage to the Member.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Sergei Stanishev has been accused of losing seven documents containing information considered state secrets in the performance of his duties as Prime Minister of the Republic of Bulgaria, between 4 November 2005 and 27 July 2009.  Specifically, Mr Stanishev allegedly forwarded these documents in breach of the rules in force.  In view of the fact that, the alleged crime in question does not have a direct connection with the performance of Sergei Stanishev's duties as a Member of the European Parliament, and does not concern an opinion or a vote expressed in the exercise of his parliamentary prerogatives, I have decided to support the Duda report, which calls, precisely, for the waiver of his immunity.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. The offence against him is obviously (temporarily) not related to his political activities. That is why I voted in favour of waiving immunity.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The request concerns the lifting of the parliamentary immunity of Social Democrat MP Sergei Stanishev. While he was Prime Minister of Bulgaria from 2005 to 2009, he is suspected of having "lost" classified documents classified as "state secret". Since Sergei Stanishev himself is asking for the lifting of his immunity in order to shed light on this case, I cannot oppose it and I vote FOR.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The defence of the independence of the Mandate of the European Parliament is the responsibility of the European Parliament and that independence cannot be called into question. In accordance with Article 8 Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, members of the European Parliament may not be sought, detained or persecuted for the opinions or votes cast in the performance of their duties. The Attorney General of the Republic of Bulgaria has submitted an application for authorisation by the Sofia Public Prosecutor's Office to bring legal proceedings against Sergei Stanishev for the offence of which is provided for in Article 358(1) in conjunction with Article 26(1) of the Bulgarian Penal Code. The alleged acts do not have a direct or obvious link with the exercise of Sergei Stanishev's duties as A Member of the European Parliament, nor do they constitute opinions or votes expressed in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, so I voted in favour of the waiver of parliamentary immunity.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the request for waiver of the immunity of Sergei Stanishev.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The request for the waiver of immunity here concerns Sergei Stanishev. The alleged facts relate to mr Stanishev's time as Prime Minister of Bulgaria. He is accused of misplacing seven documents under state secrecy during the performance of his duties.  Having done so before he entered the European Parliament and having no direct connection to his role as an MEP, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Mr Stanishev's request to lift his immunity in the interests of transparency in the activities of all Members of the European Parliament, and because that is what the main interested party wants to go.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Sergei Stanishev is accused of losing seven documents containing information considered state secrets in the performance of his duties as Prime Minister of the Republic of Bulgaria. This is a criminal offence punishable under Article 358(1) of the Bulgarian Criminal Code. In accordance with Article 9 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the EU, Members of the European Parliament shall enjoy, on their national territory, the same immunities as members of their country and, in accordance with Article 70 of the Bulgarian Constitution, a Member may not be the subject of criminal proceedings, arrest or detention during the parliamentary term without the consent of parliament.  In the light of the above, I have decided to support Mr Duda's request because the alleged crime has no connection with the position of a Member of the European Parliament by Mr Duda. Mr Stanishev. The crime, on the other hand, is linked to his previous position as Prime Minister. Furthermore, there is no reason to assume that the procedure depends on the intention to prejudice the political activity of the Member (fumus persecutionis), since it was initiated several years before the start of the European mandate.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report to lift immunity.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of waiving the immunity of Sergei Stanishev, as this is the only way to prosecute the member's home country with a purposeful purpose. In addition, the honourable Member himself also voted in favour of waiving his immunity.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported sergei Stanishev's request for waiver of immunity because he is in a pending case in Bulgaria.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Whereas the Chief Prosecutor of the Republic of Bulgaria has forwarded the request made by the Sofia Public Prosecutor's Office to authorise the continuation of criminal proceedings against Sergei Stanishev for a crime under Article 358(1), in combination with Article 26(1) of the Bulgarian Criminal Code; that the alleged offence in question does not have a direct or obvious link with the performance of Sergei Stanishev's duties as a Member of the European Parliament and does not concern an opinion or a vote expressed in the performance of his parliamentary duties pursuant to Article 8 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union; That in this case Parliament has found no evidence of fumus persecutionis, that is to say, a sufficiently well-founded and precise suspicion that the case brought was aimed at causing political damage to the Member, I voted in favour.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. Sergei Stanishev is accused of having lost seven documents containing information constituting state secrets while he was Prime Minister of Bulgaria between 2005 and 2009. As the investigation against Mr Stanishev began before his election to the European Parliament and Mr Stanishev had given his written approval for the opening of criminal proceedings against him, I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I respect the rapporteur's recommendation, as the judicial investigation into Sergei Stanishev began long before he became a Member of the European Parliament and taking into account that that criminal procedure is in no way linked to his or her function as a Member of the European Parliament. Although the alleged offence is not directly or manifestly linked to the performance of Sergei Stanishev's duties as a Member of the European Parliament, nor is it concerning the opinion expressed or voting in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8(1) of the EESC. Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunies of the European Union, there is no reason to assume, i.e. sufficiently serious and reasonable doubt, that the proceedings were initiated with the intention of causing political harm to the member concerned (fumus persecutionis).

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported MP Andrzej Duda's report on the request to lift mp Sergei Stanishev's immunity. Parliamentary immunity is a remedy that protects the smooth functioning of Members and thus constitutes a necessary means of protecting parliament's independence. In order to be credible, it is important that parliamentary immunity is solely an instrument of protection against politically motivated persecution. In the case of MEP Sergei Stanishev, the Committee on Legal Affairs found that it was not a prosecution brought with the intention of causing political damage to a Member because it was initiated before becoming a Member of the European Parliament. Since the initiated proceedings have nothing to do with the performance of Sergei Stanishev's duties as an MEP, I agree with the unanimous decision of the Committee on Legal Affairs on the waiver of immunity, as the remedy for the protection of citizens' representatives at EU level must not place Members above the law.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Again, I voted in favour of waiving immunity, because the investigation against Sergei Stanishev was initiated well before the beginning of his term as a Member of the European Parliament and cannot in any way be linked to his position as a Member of the European Parliament.  The indictment relates to a period prior to his election as a Member of the European Parliament, when Sergei Stanishev was Prime Minister of Bulgaria. At that time, Sergei Stanishev had sent the President of the National Assembly two written statements in which he gave his consent to the initiation of criminal proceedings against him in accordance with the constitution of the Republic of Bulgaria.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this request, since the facts occurred before the inauguration of the Member of the European Parliament, since Sergei Stanishev is accused of having lost, in the performance of his duties as Prime Minister of the Republic of Bulgaria, seven documents with information constituting state secrecy within the meaning of the Bulgarian law on the protection of classified information (hereinafter referred to as the 'PIC Law') , the conduct of which constitutes a crime punishable by the Bulgarian Penal Code (violation of information constituting state secrecy and classified information from foreign countries.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. It is a question of Bulgarian internal justice, unrelated to Sergei Stanishev's deputy status.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the withdrawal of parliamentary immunity from Sergei Stanishev in view of the assumption by the Attorney-General of the Republic of Bulgaria of the Office of sofia City of the Public Prosecutor's Office for authorisation to continue the criminal proceedings against Sergei Stanishev, that the investigations were initiated prior to the assumption of his duties as AN MEP and that further, the accusation made against him is not linked to his exercise as a European parliamentarian

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting the immunity of Mr Sergei Stanishev so that the Bulgarian justice system could do its job, with strict respect for the rights of the defence, considering that the alleged offence has no direct or obvious link to the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament. The prosecutions are not intended to damage the political career of the Member concerned, but to shed light on the transmission of documents containing information constituting state secrets when Mr Stanishev was Prime Minister of Bulgaria.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the lifting of Sergei Stanishev's immunity, because the offence he is accused of was committed during his time as Prime Minister of Bulgaria and only in the context of that function. Thus, the criminal proceedings that must be brought against him are not in any way linked to his current mandate as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of the request for waiver of the immunity of Sergei Stanishev. The alleged offence does not have a direct or obvious connection with Mr Stanishev’s performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament. Pre-trial investigations against Sergei Stanishev had already started long before he became a Member of the European Parliament, and the proceedings in question are, therefore, not connected in any way with his position as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. – Sergei Stanishev allegedly lost documents containing information on state secrets and was prosecuted in 2009 with a request for the approval of such proceedings. Mr Stanishev immediately agreed to bring criminal proceedings against him and submitted a written statement accordingly. The criminal proceedings were soon halted when Mr Stanishev became a member of the National Assembly, thereby gaining the right to re-protection with immunity. Mr Stanishev again gave his consent to the criminal proceedings being conducted against him and he went ahead.
