However, when Mr Stanishev was elected as a member of the European Parliament in 2014, the court decided to discontinue the case due to a new type of immunity. Since the judicial investigation into Sergei Stanishev began long before he became a Member of the European Parliament, that criminal proceedings are therefore in no way linked to his function as a Member and that, in the period when he served as Prime Minister and then a member of the National Assembly, he is in accordance with Article 70(2) of the Code of Conduct. Two written statements have been submitted to the President of the National Assembly to the President of the Republic of Bulgaria, which gave his consent to the launch of criminal proceedings against him, I support this report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 MEPs should be held to account in court when the need to investigate their activities is required, in accordance with existing legal procedures.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted to lift Mr Stanishev's immunity so that he could defend himself in court in his country against the facts alleged against him.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of suspending the immunity of MEP Sergei Stanishev.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report calling for the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of the MEP concerned in order to deal with a criminal charge for allegedly losing seven documents containing state secrecy under the Law on the Protection of Classified Information when he was Prime Minister of the Republic of Bulgaria.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Sergei Stanishev is accused of having lost, in the exercise of his duties as Prime Minister of the Republic of Bulgaria, seven documents with information constituting state secrecy.  More specifically, Sergei Stanishev is alleged to have transmitted those documents in default to the established rules, since the transfer was not duly recorded in the register of classified information of the Bulgarian Council of Ministers.  The alleged offence was committed when Sergei Stanishev was prime minister of Bulgaria and only in the context of those duties, and the investigation of the case was initiated long before the target was elected to the post of Member of the European Parliament. It follows that the criminal proceedings brought against Sergei Stanishev are in no way linked to his current mandate as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. The offence against him is obviously (temporarily) not related to his political activities. That is why I voted in favour of waiving immunity.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Sergei Stanishev is accused of having lost, in the performance of his duties as Prime Minister of the Republic of Bulgaria, seven documents with information constituting state secrecy within the meaning of the Bulgarian law on the protection of classified information in the period from 4 November 2005 to 27 July 2009. More specifically, Sergei Stanishev is alleged to have transmitted those documents in default to the established rules, since the transfer was not duly recorded in the register of classified information of the Bulgarian Council of Ministers. Given that the alleged acts do not have a direct or obvious link with the exercise of Sergei Stanishev's duties as A Member of the European Parliament, nor do they constitute opinions or votes expressed in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, we do not oppose the waiver of parliamentary immunity.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL).
text: – A Uachtaráin, staon mé ón vóta seo cé go n-aithním go bhfuil rudaí maithe sa tuarascáil seo cosúil leis an tslí go luaitear an gá atá ann athbhreithniú a dhéanamh ar an gcreat airgeadais ilbhliantúil.  É sin ráite, ní rabhas ábalta tacaíocht a thabhairt dó toisc go gcreidim nach bhfaighimid dea-nuacht ar bith chomh fada is atá an Coimisiún greamaithe sa chreat airgeadais ilbhliantúil atá againn faoi láthair. Tá sé ráite arís is arís eile go bhfuil creat buiséid iomlán difriúil ag teastáil agus go bhfuil athbhreithniú de dhíth. Tá clár infheistithe poiblí láidir uainn, infheistiú a chuirfidh deireadh leis an gcúlú eacnamaíochta; infheistiú a chinnteoidh go dtiocfaidh laghdú ar an mbearna ollmhór atá ann idir na réigiúin is saibhre agus is boichte, agus a chuirfidh le comhtháthú sóisialta agus eacnamaíochta.  Tá neart plé ann faoi láthair faoi phlean Juncker, agus tá sé thar a bheith tábhachtach go dtugaimid cosaint d’infheistíocht phoiblí agus go gcuirimid stop le príobháidiú earnálacha tábhachtacha cosúil le huisce agus fuinneamh sna Ballstáit. Caithfimid tacaíocht a thabhairt do na gnóthaí beaga agus acmhainní a chur ar fáil do chúrsaí taighde, oideachais agus iascaireachta.

name: Morten Messerschmidt (ECR).
text: Madam President! The Danish People's Party and I voted against the Fernández report, and I believe that if the Europeans had been asked, it would also have been a big, resounding and clear 'no'. Why? Yes, not because we are against the fine intentions of employment, entrepreneurship and things like that, but because the only answer when it comes to creating it from this house is more budgets, own resources. You want to be allowed to collect taxes yourself. Despite the fact that there is hardly a European institute, a European political assembly with less popular legitimacy than the European Union, it now insists on coming up with the tool that is probably the most intimidating to the citizen: being able to withdraw tax dollars – or, in your case, tax euros – from the pockets of the citizens themselves. It is not only undemocratic, it is also fundamentally unsympathetic, and that is what is the overarching purpose of this whole report, and then all the fine words about growth and jobs can otherwise come second, therefore a clear 'no' from here.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – I , unlike my previous sayer, supported this report. I believe – also given the majority with which it was adopted – that the vote was entirely justified, because the report credibly describes the situation that arises in the budget section.  I would like to highlight two more points, which I think are quite important, and that is the question of supporting SMEs, as they are also cited in the report. Indeed, it must be stressed that they represent over 90% of all businesses operating in Europe and have undoubtedly also been affected by the crisis.  This role for businesses needs to be linked to the structural and investment funds in the European Union, as they are the main lever of investment spending, so this report must be supported when it mentions this interconnectedness. I'm glad I could support her.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán Lidia Senra Rodríguez Y Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite containing positive points, it does not try to put an end to the austerity policy and the neoliberal nature of many EU policies. The report identifies the deficit that is taking place in the Union budget and requests a payment plan from Member States that can cover it. In addition, the report points to the need to reform the Union's own resources in depth so that resources can be generated through certain taxes, and also calls for a review of the multiannual financial framework to adapt it to current funding needs. That's why I voted against it.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: i scríbhinn. – Staon mé ón vóta seo cé go n-aithním go bhfuil rudaí maithe sa tuarascáil seo cosúil leis an tslí go luaitear an gá atá ann athbhreithniú a dhéanamh ar an gcreat airgeadais ilbhliantúil. Níor chóir dúinn cur leis an ngeilleagar bréagach.  Tá neart plé ann faoi láthair faoi phlean Juncker. Tá sé thar a bheith tábhachtach go dtugaimid cosaint d’infheistíocht phoiblí agus go gcuirimid stop le príobháidiú earnálacha. Caithfimid bogadh ó na polasaithe déine láithreach, agus polasaithe a chur i bhfeidhm a oibríonn ar son na ndaoine seachas ina gcoinne.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The EU budget is an investment budget with a strong leverage and a catalyst for growth, competitiveness and jobs across the Union. It has a positive impact on citizens and it is therefore easier to implement projects and programmes. However, it is impossible to carry out the tasks when the credibility, fairness and soundness of the EU is called into question. The Europe 2020 strategy needs to be relaunched for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth in the European Union.  Unemployment, especially youth unemployment, must be combated. Cross-border transport must be promoted so that Europe can benefit from the diverse skills of its citizens and their educational and employment opportunities are improved, so that the next generations can use this transport without any problems. However, improvements must always be made to ensure that the 2016 budget is improved to the maximum in a wide range of areas.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the general guidelines for the preparation of the 2016 budget. Contrary to what is stated in this report, it will not lead to any leverage since the EU's unpaid debts amount to EUR 30 billion and the first budget item - agriculture - is gradually decreasing, without the European Union planning for future investments.  These general guidelines for the budget point to the financial difficulties that are looming as a result of the Union's policies.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ As a UKIP MEP, I cannot accept many of the principles of the proposed 2016 budget. The Juncker Plan is fundamentally flawed, and there is no attempt to return any financial competence to the Member States – even in cases where the EU funding model has proven to be fundamentally flawed.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the rapporteur's resolution on the general guidelines for the preparation of the 2016 budget, in particular because they underline our strong commitment to full implementation of the joint declarations on payment appropriations and a payment timetable, agreed between Parliament, the Council and the Commission at the end of the 2015 budget procedure. , and I believe that this implementation would demonstrate the real will of the three institutions to find a solution to the problem of unpaid bills.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to define the 2016 commission's budgetary guidelines. The budgetary guidelines are the first document that the EP presents during the annual budgetary procedure and sets out the guidance that the Commission expects the Commission to take when preparing its budget proposal. The multiannual financial framework for 2016 provides for EUR 150.217 billion. This fund is used to address the priority issue. It is important that the EU budget and President Juncker's decision to Juncker's investment plan would contribute to a eur 20 million investment plan. promotion of small and medium-sized enterprises in the EU and the creation of start-ups. I agree that the Commission should find the reasons for the slow implementation of the European Youth Initiative and ensure that it is also financed after 2015. All Member States must be in solidarity and contribute to emergency humanitarian aid and assistance in Ukraine and elsewhere. It is also important that the Commission present as soon as possible a plan to reduce the growing backlog of payments, which has reached an unprecedented EUR 24.7 billion. the amount of EUR 100 million.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which, despite some rather lucid paragraphs on the dysfunctions of the European Union, calls for further increase in the Union's already colossal budget.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The main points of these guidelines for the S and D group are job creation, combating youth unemployment through the funding of the 2016 Youth Employment Initiative, the implementation of the investment plan, asylum and migration policy, research policy, and the full implementation of the clean-up plan agreed at the end of the 2015 budget procedure to end the payments to enable the EU to fulfil its legal obligations in a way that respects third parties.

name: Bas Belder (ECR)
text: Written. According to the rapporteur, the EU budget for 2016 should focus on improving the economy. This is sympathetic, even though the biggest obstacle is the euro and it is the Member States that need to take the most measures for sustainable economic recovery.  However, the budgetary guidelines have such problematic elements that they do not receive my support. The guidelines regard spending too easily as investment, advocating an increase in expenditure and, above all, payments. An incorrect answer to late payment. They also aim to develop special instruments outside the multiannionary financial framework as well as more European sources of income. On the other hand, the opposite is needed: a reduction in the budget, a reduction in financial obligations, respect for the ceilings of the multianne financial framework for all expenditure. In addition, Europe must not receive more 'own resources'. Member State contributions reflect the union's service to the Member States. In addition, the disciplining effects of the Member States at the level of expenditure cannot be missed.  The guidelines are also at odds with the critical review of agencies for necessity, quality and savings. I call on the European Parliament to show a genuine sense of responsibility on these issues. Otherwise, the EP will continue to steer Europe in the wrong direction.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. The general guidelines for the preparation of the 2016 budget presented to us by this report are in line with your deadly ideology for Europe: ever more austerity, ever less public spending and ever more globalism. These guidelines lead the European Union, in the end, to always less growth, ever more unemployment and ever more precariousness.  According to the Commission itself, austerity cost France 4.8 points of GDP between 2011 and 2013 but, under the guise of boosting investment, the Union is putting the peoples of Europe on their knees. The Juncker plan is just another artifice whose hoped-for leverage will surely not be there. Moreover, at the end of 2014, the EU still has 30 billion euros in unpaid bills. So I voted against this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 While containing passages that we can support such as those that deepen the problems of SMEs, the report on the general guidelines for the preparation of the 2016 budget remains problematic and for this reason I did not support it. Let me give you an example: I absolutely do not share the text's uncritical enthusiasm for Commissioner Katainen's strategic investment plan, which will end up draining important resources from other existing and launched programmes, such as Horizon 2020.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted against the guidelines. The report states that "the EU budget is a tool of internal solidarity by supporting economic, social and territorial cohesion, contributing to poverty reduction, promoting social inclusion and helping to minimise disparities in development between Member States." For millions of people in southern Europe in particular who are unemployed and forced into a life of poverty and misery caused by the EU's austerity policies, the report's statement is pure derision. These guidelines start the process of the 2016 budget. My fundamental criticism is that the EU budget is too large and comprehensive. There should be substantial cuts. In principle, I also think it wrong that the European Parliament has power over the budget. The Member States that pay the EU budget should have full decision-making power over Union expenditure.  Other reasons why I am opposed to the EU budget are the costly and environmentally damaging agricultural policy, the incalculable regional and structural funds, where there is widespread fraud, and the investments in Frontex, which means the continued construction of Fortress Europe.  These are some of the reasons why I am voting against the 2016 budget guidelines.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution on the general guidelines for the preparation of the 2016 budget, Section III. This Resolution sets out the main policy priorities for the 2016 budget: job creation, business development and entrepreneurship for sustainable growth in the EU, the implementation of the Investment Plan and the fight against the payment crisis. The Resolution underlines the importance of the Union budget as a tool for creating smart jobs, ensuring inclusive and sustainable growth across the EU, economic, social and territorial cohesion, R&D support, energy transition and interconnections, migration and asylum policy, foreign aid, as well as EU programmes , such as Horizon 2020, COSME or Erasmus+. It also underlines the vital importance of continuing the fight against youth unemployment and the need to ensure the financing of the Youth Employment Initiative from 2016. Finally, the Resolution calls for the full implementation of the joint declaration on a payment plan to end the payment crisis and the problem of unpaid invoices undermining the EU's credibility.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because the European Union budget is essential for job creation and business development and entrepreneurship for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth across the EU. It should be noted that the EU budget is an important contribution to economic, social and territorial cohesion in support of R&D, as well as important for the restructuring of the energy sector and energy interconnection. The EU budget supports EU programmes, including Horizon 2020, the Programme for the Competitiveness of Enterprises and Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (COSME), Erasmus+ and the Youth Employment Initiative, which contribute directly to job creation and employment. The European Parliament therefore expects the Commission to attach great importance to such growth-oriented programmes and measures in the draft budget for 2016 in order to ensure that they are provided with sufficient resources.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: i scríbhinn. – Staon mé ón vóta seo cé go n-aithním go bhfuil rudaí maithe sa tuarascáil seo cosúil leis an tslí go luaitear an gá atá ann athbhreithniú a dhéanamh ar an gcreat airgeadais ilbhliantúil. É sin ráite, ní raibh mé ábalta tacaíocht a thabhairt don tuarascáil toisc go gcreidim nach bhfaighimid dea-nuacht ar bith chomh fada is atá an Coimisiún greamaithe sa chreat airgeadais ilbhliantúil atá againn faoi láthair. Níor chóir dúinn cur leis an ngeilleagar bréagach.  Tá neart plé ann faoi láthair faoi phlean Juncker. Tá sé thar a bheith tábhachtach go dtugaimid cosaint d’infheistíocht phoiblí agus go gcuirimid stop le príobháidiú earnálacha. Caithfimid bogadh ó na polasaithe déine láithreach agus polasaithe a chur i bhfeidhm a oibríonn ar son na ndaoine seachas ina gcoinne.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I agree with the guidelines established for the 2016 budget

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. The budgetary guidelines for 2016 show a clear hypocrisy.  The European Union deplores, on the one hand, the collapse of public investment while it legally organises the austerity that is responsible for it.  On the other hand, the resolution welcomes the implementation of the Juncker Plan, whose leverage of 15 is overestimated. The "Pact for Growth and Jobs" provided for a lever of 6 to finish in reality at 2. It does not propose any new budgetary stimulus and does not meet the need for investment, estimated at 235 billion per year! Moreover, the Committee on the Budget is concerned about the fate of SMEs by touting the COSME programme, while their problem lies more in the economic gloom inherent in the euro area.  Finally, while the Commission is giving lessons in good management, the EU's unpaid payments amounted to 30 billion euros at the end of 2014.  It is high time to give the Member States full use of their fiscal sovereignty and to radically change economic policy so that our economies can return to growth.  I voted against it.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against. I remain sceptical about many passages in the text. I do not agree with the positive investment references made by Commissioner Katainen, which drains resources from important programmes that already exist and are funded by Horizon 2020. The solidarity criteria set out in the text are also not well defined. Furthermore, the work of the High Level Group on Resources chaired by Mario Monti, whose aim is to identify future sources of EU funding, is defined as important.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The budgetary procedure for 2016 has begun and Parliament is setting out its priorities for the year. The emphasis is on entrepreneurship, employment, and investment. We have many goals and we have to give ourselves the means to achieve them. The budget must meet the needs of European citizens and thus help finance all projects that can bring growth and jobs to Europe. We must respect the commitments made to our fellow citizens. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the guidelines for the 2016 budget which stresses that next year's EU budgetary priorities should be to promote growth, supporting job creation, business and entrepreneurship, showing solidarity with countries inside and outside the European Union, putting eu finances in order by addressing, backpaying and , finally, the reform of the Eu ropean Union's resource system.  The EU must promote employment, strengthen the skills of our citizens, support businesses, especially SMEs, and encourage entrepreneurship across the EU. The 2016 budget must have a tangible positive impact on citizens' lives. With regard to the European Youth Initiative, which has the potential to break the negative cycle of unemployment among young people, I call on the Commission to examine the causes of the slow launch of the initiative in the Member States and to guarantee its funding beyond 2015 and especially in 2016.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: i scríbhinn. – Staon mé ón vóta seo cé go athnaím go bhfuil rudaí maithe sa tuairisc seo cosúil leis an slí gur luaitear an gá a bhfuil ann athbhreithniú a dhéanamh den creat airgeadais ilbhliantúil. É sin ráite ní raibh mé ábalta tacaíocht a thabhairt dó toisc go gcreidim nach bhfaighfidh muid dea-nuacht ar bith chomh fhada is atá an Coimisiúin greamaithe sa chreat airgeadais ilbhliantúil atá againn faoi láthair. Tá sé ráite arís is arís eile go bhfuil creat buiséad iomlán difriúil ag taisteáil agus go bhfuil athbhreithniú de dhíth. Tá clár infheistiú poiblí láidir uainn, infheistiú a chuirfidh deireadh leis an cúlú eacnamaíochta. Infheistiú a chinnteoidh go dtiocfaidh laghdú ar an bearna ollmhór atá ann idir na réigiúin is saibhre agus is bochta, agus a chuirfidh le comhtháthú sóisialta is eacnamaíochta. Ní chóir dúinn chuir leis an gheilleagar bréagach.  Tá neart pléigh ann faoi láthair faoi plean Junker. Tá sé thar a bheith tábhachtach go dtugann muid cosaint do infheistíocht poiblí agus go gcuireann muid stop le príobháidiú earnálacha. Caithfidh muid bogadh ó na polasaithe déine láithreach agus polasaithe a chuir i bhfeidhm a oibríonn ar son na ndaoine seachas ina gcoinne.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Employment and support for small and medium-sized enterprises are certainly of paramount importance, and the EU budget is in itself an important investment instrument. However, we do not see any concrete commitments to this effect emerge in the text put to the vote, and they are therefore in danger of remaining a dead letter. It does not seem that the express desire to solve problems accumulated over time - such as unpaid invoices at the end of the financial year, the question of the budgetization of the special instruments of the five-year framework programme and the delay in implementing the new operational programmes within the framework of cohesion policy - are also accompanied by the identification of instruments for achieving concrete results. The Junker plan also seems to be of central importance, given the lack of clear and defined coverage and, in any case, to the detriment of concrete investment programmes such as those in research, transport and smEs.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this report which sets the guidelines for the preparation of the 2016 budget of the European Union. This report is in fact only the acclamation by the European parliamentarians of the submission of national budgets to the Brussels desiderata. In this report, the Union pretends to deplore the collapse of public investment while providing for the legal clauses necessary for the establishment of austerity which, in fact, kills that same public investment. However, the Commission itself acknowledged that austerity cost France 4.8 points of GDP between 2011 and 2013. The estimated investment needs to boost economic activity amount to 235 billion euros per year. It is not by teaching austerity lessons that the economy will be revived, especially when these lessons come from a European Union which, at the end of December 2014, still had 30 billion euros in unpaid debts.

name: Ole Christensen (S&D)
text: Written. We are in favour of the efficient and responsible use of EU funds and we are in favour of better use and prioritisation of EU funds within the existing framework. We are working to create growth, jobs and decent wages in the EU. We are also in favour of investment in, among other things, green conversion, research and infrastructure. That is why we are redistribution of funds from, among other things, the European Union. Horizon 2020 and Connecting Europe Facility deeply problematic. We chose to support the amendment tabled by the Greens on this very fact rather than the GUE's, as the Amendments tabled by the Greens are more constructive and call for funding in other ways, rather than simply condemning the redistribution of funds.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure because the European Union, with this budget, has played a central role in reducing the differences that there are between European regions by encouraging and guaranteeing investment achievements where it is most needed, trying to direct the results to a facilitation on the lives of the citizens of the Member States by encouraging the development of companies with a view to creating new jobs.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the EU budget plays a crucial role in bringing us closer to the EU's objectives, in particular reducing discrepancies between European regions and making investments in the areas where there is greatest need. For these reasons, the budget has a tangible positive impact on people's lives. In particular, I voted in favour of the resolution because I found, between the lines, that a strong emphasis was placed on job creation and business development.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU needs to promote employment, strengthen our citizensʼ skills, support businesses (SMEs in particular) and encourage entrepreneurship across the EU. The EU budget is mostly about investment, with around 94 % of the total budget re-invested. It has a strong leverage effect and acts as a catalyst for growth, competitiveness and job creation. By pooling resources, many important investments with European added-value are made possible.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I congratulate Mr José Manuel Fernandes on his report with the political guidelines for the 2016 budget that he will be responsible in the European Parliament. I share the priority of the 3 E: jobs, business and entrepreneurship. I congratulate you for clearly and unequivocally defining what the priorities for the Community budget should be. I sincerely hope that the Council will not limit financial resources in such a way as to reduce their real meaning. I particularly agree with the emphasis on the serious problem of youth unemployment, support for SMEs, strengthening internal solidarity and social, economic and territorial cohesion. And, Portuguese, I cannot fail to stress the fact that the general rapporteur for the budget and, at the same time, Parliament's rapporteur for the Juncker Plan, is a Portuguese.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU budget, in addition to being an instrument of external solidarity, as it helps to bring emergency aid to countries affected by humanitarian crises, is mainly aimed at supporting the economic, social and territorial cohesion of all Member States. In fact, the European Structural and Investment Funds, which make up the budget mainly, are essential to create jobs first and foremost, especially for young people affected by high unemployment, and to relaunch growth and strengthen the competitiveness and innovation of the more than 20 million SMEs that make up europe's entrepreneurial fabric. I fully agree with Mr Fernandes that we need to resolve definitively and unequivocally the various problems that have accumulated in recent years, namely the recurring problem of unpaid invoices and their repercussions on citizens and local authorities, as well as on the implementation of programmes and funds.  I hope that at the interinstitutional meeting scheduled for 25 March the situation will be taken into stock before proceeding with the preparation of the draft budget for 2016, which will have to be based on real forecasts and needs aimed at achieving objectives and ambitions for the benefit of all Member States.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The report signals the beginning of the budgetary procedure for Parliament and sets the political tone and coveys the main budgetary priorities of Parliament. Such priorities include the creation of employment and the development of enterprises and entrepreneurship for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth across the Union. The report recalls that the EU budget is a tool of internal solidarity in that it supports economic, social and territorial cohesion. The report urges the Commission to give due importance to the priorities set by the Parliament when establishing the draft budget 2016. It also urges the Council to live up to the expectations of its own commitments.  I have thus voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is the first step in the budgetary procedure, which generally set out the priorities of the European budget for 2016. The text is therefore full of good intentions and ideas that we broadly support, including support for innovation and research, SMEs, green growth. There is also a reference to the problem of payments, even if no concrete solutions are proposed to solve the problem. There is also a reference this year to the relationship between the European budget and the investment plan proposed by Juncker.  The report amply emphasises only the positive aspect of the project, but nothing is said about the critical issues, namely that the funds for the EFSI guarantee are taken from important and priority programmes, such as Horizon 2020 and the CEF, without underlining the risk of potential losses of these funds and an increase in the already difficult payment situation. The M5S had tabled a number of amendments to change in particular the section relating to the relationship with EFSI.  Our proposals were rejected in the committee responsible, with the sole support of the GUE, the Greens and part of the ECR. The people's-socialist-liberal bloc was united, and there was broad convergence on the final vote. I am voting against.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU budget is the only item of investment and financing of programmes and projects, which are not feasible. It ensures strategic investments that reduce inequalities in development and macroeconomic data. That's in theory.  In practice, we are faced with the persistence of a phenomenon that is harmful to local economies, such as the exponential growth of the differential between commitments and payments. The budget can only play an active and positive role again if a realignment is restored and only if all previous amounts are paid. The Member States are therefore responsible for the difficulties encountered in implementing the programmes and funds, penalising European citizens, both beneficiaries and businesses, in the first place.  2014 set a record number of unpaid invoices that could pale in the face of the risk that, coinciding with the end of the 2007-2013 schedule, there will be an unprecedented surge in payment requests. The risk of work and programmes being blocked is very high and the solution cannot be – as has been assumed – the disengagement of the sums, but their rationalisation towards the segments that guarantee absorption and positive results.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree with the key points outlined, including the fact that the EU budget is to be considered as a tool to create employment, enterprises, entrepreneurship for sustainable growth in the EU, the European Investment Plan, and the fight against the payment crisis.  I believe in the importance of the principle of additionally in the context of the European Investment Plan and to end the payment crisis, which is contradictory to the European goals set at highest political level and undermines the credibility of the EU. Since the report gives due attention to the need for the 2016 budget to create employment, growth and also foster an entrepreneurial spirit, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. This report on the general guidelines for the preparation of the 2016 budget, endorsed by the European Parliament, sets out the main budgetary priorities that Parliament wants to see taken into account in the development of the 2016 annual budget. By proposing a principled approach to job creation, business development and entrepreneurship, this report is moving in the right direction. These three components are undoubtedly key levers to support and amplify the recovery of growth in Europe. Alongside this reflection on the optimal use of European budgetary resources to promote a return to sustainable growth, the report once again underlines the need to tackle the problem of unpaid bills resolutely.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the Union Structural and Investment Funds account for the bulk of investment expenditure in the Union budget and play a decisive role in creating jobs, boosting economic growth and promoting competitiveness and innovation.  EU cohesion policy has been decisive in supporting public investment in vital economic sectors and has in practice achieved tangible results that can enable Member States and regions to overcome the current crisis and meet the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, and that is why I believe that both the Commission and the Member States must make every possible effort to adopt quickly , in the coming months, the remaining operational programmes so that their implementation reaches "cruise speed" in 2016.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report focuses on the general guidelines for the preparation of the 2016 budget and is the first step in the budget process. I would like to support the main policy, namely, to prioritise employment, business and entrepreneurship, in particular by mobilising the Union's financial programmes, which must be provided with sufficient resources, and the investment plan presented by the European Commission for infrastructure, education and research, as well as support for SMEs and medium-sized enterprises.  The report also raises the sensitive issue of budgetary outstandings accumulated in recent years and, therefore, the issue of meeting the budgetary commitments of the Union and its main contributors, the Member States. Considering that it is necessary for the Commission to propose concrete and sustainable solutions in agreement with the Council and Parliament to solve this recurring problem, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for this report after pushing a number of amendments on key points in this first stage. These included rebalancing towards environmental and solidarity priorities. The Horizon 2020 research programme, COSME, ERASMUS, external and humanitarian aid, energy transition and migration and asylum policies.  As the European Union's budget is essentially an investment budget, we must defend forward-looking guidelines. First, there is the fight against youth unemployment and their employment integration. Then there is the challenge of the energy transition. Finally, there is the issue of investment in the real economy.  The EU budget, due to a lack of own resources, is already a "weak" budget. We must ensure that it is not yet diminished by the cuts to finance the guarantee of the Juncker plan, the bulk of which must be provided by the EIB. Parliament's recommendations must be followed to the letter. This is a lesson I take from the 2015 negotiations - the inter-institutional partnership needs to be tightened, particularly on the issue of unpaid bills for cohesion programmes in the previous period.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I think it is necessary to prioritise investment if we are to boost growth and jobs in Europe.  I note that we are in a good time, since three complementary measures will combine their positive effects during 2016: 1. The ECB's quantitative easing plan: EUR 60 billion per month will be able to move sovereign bonds towards productive assets. In total, a flow of EUR 1,140 billion will be freed up for growth and employment. 2. The Juncker plan and its 315 billion euros: it will reach its cruising speed in 2016. In this regard, I would like to stress that the UNION budget will have to make available to this plan the EUR 8 billion needed to provide the guarantee. 3. The EU budget: this budget is above all an investment budget. As such, it must also stimulate research and innovation. And, in 2016, approved operational programmes will effectively be in the process of being implemented, with their positive effects for growth and employment.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – In the annual budgetary procedures, the European Parliament's first resolution is a statement of intent, defining the main aspects that the reporter and Parliament will try to enforce in their own reading on the budget in September-October. At the same time, it provides guidance to the European Commission on the draft budget. The report puts the 3 'E's' at the heart of the EU budget for 2016: Employment, Enterprise, Entrepreneurship, solidarity within and outside the EU and the creation of a secure Europe. In this context, it stresses that the EU budget contributes to economic, social and territorial cohesion, to support research and development, and to exploiting the potential of energy transitions and interconnection for job creation and growth. The report prioritises the need for resources for the Juncker investment plan. Stresses, however, the complementary nature of the investment plan and the EU budget submitted and their shared commitment to kick-start the economy and stimulate job creation; points out that the EU budget is in itself an important investment instrument with a high profile and mission. The Fidesz-KDNP delegation supports the adoption of the report in line with the position of the People's Party.

name: Diane Dodds (NI)
text: in writing. ‒ As Parliament has its say on the guidelines for the EU budget for 2016, there should be huge emphasis placed on value for money at a time when households, families and businesses face daily pressures as a result of national cuts.   Yet this report does exactly the opposite - it threatens more of the same: targeted budget increases, a reversal of staff and budget cuts, and a continued fascination with a green agenda. And all of this at a time when Europe claims to want to connect with voters and with its citizens. These proposals fail to reflect the burdens hard-felt by taxpayers right across Northern Ireland and the rest of the United Kingdom. They fail to recognise that, for the average person, getting as much back from Europe than they put in, if not more, is the most important thing as to how they view the whole project. But the federalists show little sympathy. This is not democracy - this is a disconnect, and it is time for Members of this House to call it exactly what it is.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ While there are some aspects of the report which would be good for Scotland, such as the emphasis on boosting employment, enterprise and entrepreneurship, it is clear that the European Parliament's agenda has not changed, with a majority still believing in targeted increases to the budget.  For this reason I will vote against. The vote in plenary will be followed by the annual "Spring trilogue" on 30 March. Following the trilogue, the Commission will come forward with a draft budget by the end of May.

name: Anneliese Dodds (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the guidelines for the 2016 budget because I felt that there was insufficient reference within the guidelines to reductions in areas of spending which have consistently failed to promote sustainable economic growth, such as in the Common Agricultural Policy direct subsidy. Although there has been a welcome reorientation of spending towards research and support for young unemployed people, much more needs to be done to focus European spending on measures which will lead to an increase in decent, quality jobs, particularly for young people. There are many examples within the South-East of England of European funding projects promoting sustainable growth, and we should be strongly backing such projects, by removing funding from areas like the CAP and the wasteful second seat of the European Parliament in Strasbourg. I will continue to work with my colleagues within the European Parliament to encourage a reorientation of the EU budget towards growth-promoting areas of expenditure.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We have decided to abstain since the text is quite ambiguous: while on the one hand it recognises that there is a serious shortage of EU funds and reiterates the need to comply with the EU's payment obligations, on the other hand it does not identify the structural causes of this shortage (continuous reductions in commitments under the current MFF) nor does it propose ambitious solutions to end defaults , opening the door to possible cuts in current expenditure by the European institutions under the justification of efficiency. Finally, the European Parliament's recommendation has a weak or no impact on the Commission's preparation of the 2016 budget.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report as cross-border mobility is not a solution to the problem of unemployment because this weakens the already affected countries of the Union by losing their healthy workforce

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 While welcoming and sharing the good intentions that this text seems to carry forward, I can only express my vote against having found some typical inconsistencies between what is set as a goal and the roads that are then voted on to get there; If, for example, there is sensitivity and sensitivity on issues such as the green economy, support for unemployment and small and medium-sized enterprises, how can eur 16 billion be taken away from programmes such as Horizon 2020 and cef to finance Juncker's Investment Plan for Europe?  These are programmes that can or could actually help many European citizens precisely in those areas that the European Commission itself declares fundamental in its guidelines for the 2016 budget, in fact we are talking about research and support for small and medium-sized enterprises in one case and the implementation of physical and digital infrastructure for the CEF, but which are now being significantly damaged.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the guidelines for the preparation of the 2016 budget, Section III, as it stresses what should be the role of the European budget in fostering smart, sustainable and inclusive growth in the European Union, territorial cohesion and competitiveness. The EU budget must also play an important role in providing a funding base for the Juncker growth plan and the EFSI, which aims to relaunch investment in Europe.  I share the position expressed by the resolution which refers to the importance of agencies as an integral part of the EU administration and the need to provide them with an adequate level of resources, under penalty of poor implementation of European policies. This resolution also stresses the need for a new and more serious approach to payment appropriations in the face of the accumulation of late payment of invoices.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. Employment, business and entrepreneurship to promote growth, economic, social and territorial cohesion are priority issues. Both the EU budget and the Juncker Plan should help revive the economy and boost job creation. The existence of a favourable business environment and the development of a culture of entrepreneurship, including decent jobs, could once again give more than 20 million SMEs, which account for 99% of all businesses in the Union, their role as key job creators. EU cohesion policy has been helpful in supporting public investment in vital economic areas. The Community budget should continue to play a crucial role in reducing disparities between Europe's regions by ensuring investment in the areas where it is most needed. This internal solidarity must also be linked to external solidarity, based on the promotion of European values, and respect for the commitments made. The Commission should submit a payment plan to address the recurring problem of outstanding invoices, which at the end of 2014 reached an unprecedented amount of EUR 24.7 billion.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The eu budget-making process is marked by a complex picture in which the voluntarism of speeches – with selfless references to jobs, investment and growth – is not in due match at eu budget level. More specifically, in relation to the 2016 budget and what it tells us (or does not say) this report: - Cuts in horizon 2020, after all the propaganda around science and research, are unacceptable; - The scenario is still that of the "business as usual"; a budget geared towards eu neoliberal and militarist policies. For our part, we are calling for a clear reorientation of expenditure on economic, social and territorial cohesion policies. Policies to combat poverty and social exclusion. A genuine public investment programme, the resources of which amount to at least one per cent of EU GDP. A focus on employment, social progress, environmental protection. A specific programme to compensate countries that are victims of troika policies. A programme that fits a prepared exit from the Euro, from the countries whose permanence has become unsustainable. These were some of the amendments we proposed to the report and which were rejected by the majority. We voted against it.

name: Christofer Fjellner (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 We cannot support the European Parliament's call for a larger EU budget. Instead of prioritising expenditure, the European Parliament requires more budgetary space to be able to live up to political declarations and unpaid bills. Nor can we support the own resources reform that the European Parliament is calling for and which in practice means giving the EU the power to tax. Greater EU budget and tax law are not the solution to Europe's problems. It is structural reforms, deregulation and cutting red tape that strengthen europe's competitiveness and create the conditions for growth and jobs. Nor do we support the fact that certain payments should not be included in the payment ceiling of the EU's multiannual budget. Watering down budgetary requirements hardly create the conditions for growth. Instead, the EU must prioritise spending and focus on results and efficiency. That is why we are voting against the European Parliament's report on the establishment of general guidelines for the establishment of the 2016 budget.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ I very much welcome the fact that the three fundamental points in the budget are employment, business and entrepreneurship for sustainable and inclusive growth in the European Union. This will highlight the potential and added value of the European Union budget for job creation as well as business and business development in all Member States. We will also highlight the contribution of the European Union budget to economic, social and territorial cohesion and its potential for switching energy sources and the interconnection of energy networks for the creation of new jobs and growth. The 2016 budget is also crucial because it should serve as a criterion for the post-election review and revision of the MFF.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report because we do not agree with the positive references on the investment plan presented by Commissioner Katainen (European Fund for Strategic Investments) who, for example, drains resources from important programmes already existing and financed such as Horizon 2020.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report as a whole on the general guidelines for the preparation of the 2016 budget, Section III, because cross-border mobility is not a solution to the problem of unemployment because this weakens the already affected countries of the Union by losing their healthy workforce.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted positively in favour of this report and expressly welcome the priorities for reducing unemployment, developing companies and developing a spirit of entrepreneurship. I believe that a budget based on the pillars set out in the proposal will increase the competitiveness of the EU corporate sector, which is particularly important in relation to globalisation and international trade agreements. I welcome the fact that the report emphasises both the EU's external and internal solidarity and the creation of security in the UNION. I would like to point out that the proposal also aims to address a number of existing and recurring budgetary problems.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. It should be noted that the EU budget is predominantly investment-based, with a strong multiplier effect, and is a catalyst for growth, competitiveness and employment throughout the Union, so it has a positive and tangible impact on citizens' lives. It also plays a vital role: it helps to reduce the differences between the different regions of Europe. However, as a result of the economic and financial crisis, the level of investment in the EU has decreased significantly. The EU budget must fulfil its mission and ensure sufficient budgetary allocation for EU projects.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I supported this report because it establishes as one of the main policy priorities for 2016 that the EU budget is a tool for sustainable growth in the EU. In this context and from our perspective, we will pay particular attention to the fight against youth unemployment and the need to ensure adequate funding for the Youth Guarantee from 2016. In addition, we will work to ensure that priorities for next year's EU budget are not undermined by the need to finance the Investment Plan for Europe. This Plan, which can be a turning point for European investment and for the economy as a whole, must have its own independent financing of the other programmes. In addition, we will continue to work on ending the payment crisis, which is undermining the EU's credibility.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution adopted today by the European Parliament is an important and positive starting point for outlining EU budgetary policies for the year 2016. Indeed, we have asked the Commission to prioritise measures to promote growth, job creation, support for businesses (particularly SMEs) through payments of arrears and the reform of the EU resources system. We have also taken this opportunity to reiterate that the EU is based on principles of cohesion and solidarity that require all EU countries to share fairly the responsibilities arising from the phenomenon of immigration, which must be shared by all EU countries and not only by those directly involved such as Italy. There is no more time and no more excuses: the 2016 budget must be the driving force for the economic recovery of the whole European Union. With today's vote we have taken a first step in this direction, we will continue to work and watch pending the Commission's proposal next May and the subsequent steps in the Council and Parliament.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I would like to thank Mr Fernandes for his important report on the 2016 budget guidelines. I believe that this is a courageous report, which defends Parliament's prerogatives by reiterating some essential political issues that have not yet been resolved in the inter-institutional relationship on the budget. I therefore support the report, of which I would like to highlight a number of passages which, in my opinion, are of some political importance.  Indeed, I agree with what Mr Fernandes said: the EU budget will not be able to achieve its full potential unless the various problems that have accumulated in recent years and which, unfortunately, dominated the budget negotiations last year are resolved definitively and unequivocally. I am thinking in particular of the recurring problem of unpaid invoices at the end of the financial year, the delay in implementing the new operational programmes under cohesion policy. It is right, as the report does, to call for 2015 to be the deadline for finding concrete and sustainable solutions to these outstanding problems. Indeed, I really think it is a cause for reflection that at the end of 2014 the level of suspended payments reached an unprecedented amount of EUR 24.7 billion for cohesion programmes alone in the period 2007-2013: it is a debt that undermines the EU's credibility and runs counter to the EU's growth and employment objectives.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the guidelines for the 2016 budget, given that there was a lack of any real reference to making cuts to ineffective areas of spending, like the CAP direct subsidy for agriculture. What we need is more productive, effective and forward-thinking investment in industries that will secure growth and jobs, in research, and in our young people.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained in the vote on this report as the text is ambiguous: while on the one hand it recognises that there is a serious shortage of EU funds and reiterates the need to comply with the EU's payment obligations, on the other hand it does not identify the structural causes of this scarcity (continuous reductions in the commitments made under the current MFF) nor does it propose ambitious solutions to end the defaults , opening the door to possible cuts in current expenditure by the European institutions under the justification of efficiency. Finally, the European Parliament's recommendation has a weak or no impact on the Commission's preparation of the 2016 budget.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as inefficient budget lines have not been cut and because of the inclusion of a call to make full use of the MFF ceiling, which Labour MEPs believe to be too high.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. Like 484 of my colleagues, I contributed my voice to the report on the general guidelines for the preparation of the 2016 budget. These guidelines represent Parliament's first document in the annual budget procedure and we agree with the general direction, with some inflections that we want to achieve by the time the budget is finalised and some reservations that do not call into question our vote at this stage.  Together with the French Socialist MEPs, we are advocating a rebalancing of priorities for the environment and solidarity. Research programmes, external and humanitarian aid, energy transition, youth employment, and migration and asylum policies need to be particularly highlighted.  Delicate points remain to be resolved in our forth future debates: the first is the payments crisis, which we have a recurring experience with. The second is the issue of the investment plan - this initiative, we have long called for, to boost growth and jobs. However, it should not be at the expense of existing programs. Finally, the reform of the Union's own resources will have to be put in place in order to provide the European Union with a budget worthy of the name.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the general guidelines for the preparation of the 2016 budget. I do support all four focuses: (1) employment, enterprise and entrepreneurship for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth; (2) the Investment Plan; (3) internal and external solidarity; (4) respecting commitments. If the European Union ensures all the goals mentioned above, the economy will grow sustainably.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We abstained in the vote on this report as the text is ambiguous: while on the one hand it recognises that there is a serious shortage of EU funds and reiterates the need to comply with the EU's payment obligations, on the other hand it does not identify the structural causes of this scarcity (continuous reductions in commitments under the current MFF) nor does it propose ambitious solutions to end defaults , opening the door to possible cuts in current expenditure by the European institutions under the justification of efficiency. Finally, the European Parliament's recommendation has a weak or no impact on the Commission's preparation of the 2016 budget.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because of the importance of prioritizing job formation and support for small and medium-sized enterprises that are the engine of employment and training in our society.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the general guidelines for preparing the 2016-Part III budget, as I believe this proposal seeks growth, competitiveness and jobs and represents a kind of investment budget that pays great attention to structural and investment funds. I believe that one of the key things of the EU budget is the focus on reducing the gap between European regions, where it is needed most.  Regional and local authorities within the European Union play the uninteresting role that is essential to achieve comprehensive competitiveness and growth. In this context, the budgetary contribution to territorial, economic and social cohesion, as well as to the innovation and research sectors, is important. It should also be stressed that part of the European budget must necessarily be directed towards small and medium-sized enterprises with more than 20 million within the EU. The year 2016 is of great importance, as eu programmes of the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020 will then be operational, and therefore the Union's political priorities should also be taken into account in order to achieve the objectives set.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the general guidelines for the preparation of the 2016 budget. Contrary to what is stated in this report, it will not lead to any leverage since the EU's unpaid debts amount to EUR 30 billion and the first budget item - agriculture - is gradually decreasing, without the European Union planning for future investments.  These general guidelines for the budget allow us to begin to perceive the financial difficulties that are looming as a result of the Union's policies. And to see that instead of pragmatism, the leaders of the Union prefer to persevere in error and not to change their ways.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague José Manuel Fernandes' report on the general guidelines for the preparation of the 2016 Eu budget. The text highlights the priorities that have traditionally been the European Parliament's: employment, business and entrepreneurship. The report also raises the need to settle the issue of eu year-end unpaid money permanently, for lack of a sufficient budget. The report was adopted by a large majority, with 484 votes in the 180s, 188 against and 36 abstentions, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report on the general guidelines for the preparation of the 2016 budget. The EU budget is above all an investment budget, with a strong leverage. It boosts growth, competitiveness and employment across the EU. It has a positive positive impact on the daily lives of the population, it plays a key role in reducing disparities between European regions and ensuring that investments take place where they are most needed.  The 2016 budget provides for a 3 E plan with jobs, business and entrepreneurship, for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth in the European Union. I welcome this vote.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. Although the text makes perfectly reasonable proposals in some passages, I do not agree on some basic points. This includes, for example.B. the call for more resources for coherence programmes, indirect redistribution at European level, fiscal stimulus and more lax fiscal rules. For these reasons, I cannot support this proposal.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the guidelines as there was a lack of any real reference to making cuts to ineffective areas of spending, like the CAP direct subsidy for agriculture. We need to see more productive, effective and forward-thinking investment in research, in our young people, which will secure growth and jobs. We do need to see less effective areas of spending within the EU budget redirected to projects that deliver real economic and social benefits.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D)
text: Written. We are in favour of the efficient and responsible use of EU funds and we are in favour of better use and prioritisation of EU funds within the existing framework. We are working to create growth, jobs and decent wages in the EU. We are also in favour of investment in, among other things, green conversion, research and infrastructure. That is why we are redistribution of funds from, among other things, the European Union. Horizon 2020 and Connecting Europe Facility deeply problematic. We chose to support the amendment tabled by the Greens on this very fact rather than the GUE's, as the Amendments tabled by the Greens are more constructive and call for funding in other ways, rather than simply condemning the redistribution of funds.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – The report is extremely exaggerated and therefore contains only general guidelines that are completely useless in practice. Instead of repeated phrases to boredom, a number of good amendments have been tabled and supported by me. Unfortunately, it is clear that with this approach, structural structure and economic philosophy, it is not possible to find a way out of the growing crises. In fact, even regional, structural and cohesion funds, designed to reduce the gaps between the different levels of economic development in EU regions, are paid to richer Member States.  The report is completely unacceptable. In this situation, the Community budget should be increased at a time of increasing disparities within the Union. The necessary amounts should come from an increase in contributions from countries with the highest gross national income and the highest per capita income, by adjusting the current unfair system of contribution rates

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of Mr McDerman's report. José Manuel Fernandes on the Guidelines for the EU General Budget for 2016. In view of the forthcoming adoption of the draft budget by the European Commission, Parliament wanted to indicate the priorities to be taken into account in the decision on appropriations. The report calls for strong support for the revival of employment in the EU, the growth of our economy, the development of business and the revival of the business sector, not harming historic EU policies and solidarity between Member States. Mr Fernandes' report therefore emphasises strategic issues and the added value of the European budget, which the European Commission cannot but take into account in view of the presentation of the 2016 DB.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. While the report on the general guidelines for the preparation of the 2016 budget is partly a reminder of the importance of meeting the Union's financial commitments and its multi-year performance targets, it is above all an attempt to justify the aspirations of the Commission's investment plan carried out by President Junker.  However, it turns out that this investment plan is not based on a solid outlook but on the uncertainty of a hypothetical leverage guaranteed by the funds of the EU budget. The chapters of the plan thus reveal target areas where the chances of success and sustainability of targeted investments are reduced.  On the other hand, the choice in particular of the energy or transport sectors and the establishment of vague criteria for eligibility for SME investment reveals, on the one hand, the desire to strengthen the single market in the Union and to open up network industries to competition and, on the other hand, the Commission's trial-and-error economic reasoning, which is very likely to lead to financial mismanagement.  The guidelines for the 2016 budget, as presented in the Fernandes report, are therefore not politically and economically acceptable, and that is why I voted against this text.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 A better balance of EU priorities should be ensured next year. The EU budget should be a tool to create jobs, start-up, support entrepreneurship, which are important for ensuring sustainable growth in the EU, the European Investment Plan and the fight against the payment crisis.

name: Sander Loones (ECR)
text: Written. 'Our first focus must be to take measures for more competitiveness, growth and jobs. We can therefore agree with the important elements in this report that go into this. None of this, however, means that the EU's budget needs to be increased or that the EU's own resources need to be reviewed. In addition, there is our sensitivity to the changes in the budget in terms of the resources for basic research. This requires an overarching vision and debate and will therefore need to receive broad attention when discussing EFSI.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. The report sets out the top policy priorities for the 2016 budget. The key points are: EU budget as a tool to create jobs, businesses and entrepreneurship for sustainable growth in the EU; the Investment Plan; the fight against the payment crisis. The S&D Group's policy priorities have been to ensure a better balance of priorities for next YEAR's EU budget in the context of the Investment Plan for Europe and to end the payment crisis, which undermines the EU's credibility. An agreement has been reached with twelve compromise amendments which includes the key aspects presented by our group.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it does not try to end the austerity policy or discuss the neoliberal nature of many EU policies. Despite some positive points, related to the financing needs of the budget, the absence of clear priorities and sufficient endowment for the EU budget to serve as a real boost to employment and social cohesion motivates our vote against.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The EU budget for 2016 is based on a focus and dedication to the development and growth of employment, especially among young people, which is given priority in our current situation. It will also have support for SMEs, which are currently the most numerous in our business environment, facilitating their access to markets and credit. It also opts for mobilisation, and therefore support for European mobility programmes that promote the growth and development of our skills. As regards the Infrastructure, Education and Research and SMEs Investment Plan, I think it is appropriate, as it aims to reduce the negative effects of the economic and financial crisis. Finally, this budget seeks to achieve solidarity, social integration and the development of the Member States, in order to achieve greater equality between the countries of the Union, together with security measures to ensure their peace of mind. I therefore call on the Commission to draw up the 2016 budget following this line of action to achieve the objectives appointed and support this Resolution on the EU budget for 2016.

name: Olle Ludvigsson (S&D)
text: Written. We Swedish Social Democrats would like to point out that we do not share the report's positive view of the process of reforming the EU's own resources system. We do not want to see any radical reform. We believe that the current system – which is largely based on GNI-related contributions from the Member States – is essentially effective and well-functioning. To change that would be inappropriate.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report because the general guidelines for the preparation of the 2016 budget, Section III – Commission do not address the adverse social and economic consequences of the economic crisis. Thus, although EUR 1.6 trillion has been allocated to save the banks, the EU is filled with armies of unemployed people. Moreover, the troika and memoranda have created a huge humanitarian crisis in Greece, where 40% of the population lives below the poverty line and the unemployed reached 1.5 million. Budget priorities should therefore focus on job creation, entrepreneurship, strengthening social cohesion and solidarity and reducing poverty.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as my national delegation does not believe it is necessary to increase the EU budget for next year and would like to see the EU budget being focused on areas that support jobs and growth.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the report on guidelines for the preparation of the 2006 budget, Section III. One of the first points to start with is job creation and youth employment. The reality of work also leads us to talk about SMEs, which is very important considering the presence of more than 20 million SMEs in Europe, representing 99% of the total. In order to promote active productivity, cross-border mobility must be implemented, giving the various groups the opportunity to find suitable employment. I would also like to stress the importance of combating tax fraud, given the negative repercussions on the economies of the Member States: therefore, to work on a stronger Europe, which is ready to face new challenges.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Job creation, business development and the revitalisation of the sector are crucial challenges for the European Union.  That is why I have decided to support the Fernandes report, which focuses on achieving these objectives.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. I support the report on the general guidelines for the preparation of the 2016 budget prepared by José Manuel Fernandes, which is committed to the recovery of employment, business and entrepreneurship for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth in the European Union. I share with the author of the report that the EU budget is an instrument of internal solidarity by supporting economic, social and territorial cohesion, contributing to the fight against poverty, promoting social inclusion and helping to minimise development differences not only between Member States, but also between their regions. But it is also an instrument of external solidarity that provides emergency assistance in humanitarian and civilian crises by supporting countries that need it, such as Ukraine, and by helping to make the EU the largest donor of development aid, in order to meet the EU's commitments on poverty eradication.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. I voted against this motion for a resolution because I do not consider the guidelines for the 2016 budget to be useful because of the overall constitution. The EU budget is an investment budget and is intended to be a catalyst for growth, competitiveness and jobs across the Union. Despite some sensible approaches, the guidelines as a whole must be rejected. The redistribution of financial resources and the fact that EU countries with extremely questionable economic and financial situations are receiving even more EU funds cannot be supported.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of these guidelines as the European Commission is to put the EU budget back in order by tackling the overdue payments backlog.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report sets out Parliament's guidelines for the preparation of the 2016 EU budget. It continues the velleitarian and hypocritical logic of previous budget reports. It considers it "imperative" that "all commitments" of the 2014-2020 financial framework be "fully respected", even though Parliament has validated budget agreements since 2014 that do not meet these commitments. He calls for the problem of unpaid bills to be "resolved without delay", even though his previous votes in the 2014 and 2015 budgets at a discount will precisely aggravate these unpaid bills. The five paragraphs of this report calling on the Council to "stop being inconsistent" could therefore apply to Parliament itself!

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Economic growth, internal and external solidarity and respect for the commitments made should guide the preparation of the draft EU budget for 2016.  I agree with the priorities set out in this document, which gives the guidelines for the 2016 EU budget. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report stresses the importance of SMEs in the EU, highlighting the fact that there are more than 20 million SMEs in the EU and that they account for 99% of all businesses. It expresses the need to restore a favourable business environment and use the 2016 budget to give SMEs back their role as main job creators in the Union. Therefore I voted in favour of this report as it presents clear guidelines for the 2016 budget, which is expected to directly benefit the EU's citizens and business.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The 2016 budget set out its guidelines: encouraging growth by supporting job creation, business and entrepreneurship, showing solidarity both in the EU and with third countries, and putting European finances in order by tackling arrears of payment and reforming the EU's income system.  The Commission will have to submit a plan to reduce the increasing arrears of payment. It is time for a major reform of the Union's own resources.  We give our full support to the efforts of the Monti Group.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report on the guidelines sets out the main political priorities for the 2016 budget. I fully support the key points of this report, with the EU budget being a tool to create employment, enterprises, entrepreneurship for sustainable growth in the EU, the European Investment Plan, and improving the unemployment situation, and the need to ensure financing of the Youth Employment Initiative as from 2016.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I fully agree that the European Union budget for 2016 should promote economic, social and territorial cohesion, the reduction of development gaps between Member States and regions of the Member States, as well as the fight against poverty and support for social inclusion. At the same time, we must pay particular attention to research and development, including research and development for energy purposes, job creation, the promotion of growth and the improvement of competitiveness and innovation. I agree with the report's findings on the worrying situation of future funding for the Youth Employment Guarantee, which is why I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The budgetary guidelines for 2016 show a clear hypocrisy. Indeed, they consist of agreeing to the implementation of Member States' budgets while moving on the economic consequences. The European Union deplores, on the one hand, the collapse of public investment, while it legally organises the austerity that is responsible for it.  On the other hand, the resolution welcomes the implementation of the Juncker Plan, whose leverage of 15 is overestimated. The "pact for growth and jobs" provided for a lever of 6 to finish in reality at 2... It has no new fiscal stimulus and does not meet the investment need estimated at 235 billion per year! The Budget Committee is concerned about the fate of SMEs by touting the COSME programme, while their problem lies more in the economic gloom inherent in the euro area.  Finally, while the european Union's cold bureaucratic monster is giving lessons in good management, its unpaid bills amounted to 30 billion euros at the end of 2014.  It is high time to give the Member States full use of their budgetary sovereignty! I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the guidelines for 2016 due to the absence of any calls to cut inefficient budget lines and the call to make full use of the MFF ceiling which, overall, is too high.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which sets out the guidelines that the European Union budget should follow in 2016, namely to focus on the '3 E' defended by the European Parliament: jobs, business, entrepreneurship.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
