text: in writing. \u2012 The EU budget represents added value in terms of job creation and business development. Many Community programmes (Horizon 2020, COSME, Erasmus+, Youth Employment Initiative) contribute directly to achieving smart, sustainable and inclusive growth; we therefore call on the Commission to place them at the heart of the draft budget for 2016, in order to ensure that they are provided with the necessary resources. We express our concern about the forthcoming funding of the Youth Employment Initiative and call for an investigation into the causes of delays in the use of this fund. We stress the importance of cross-border mobility in enabling Europe to take advantage of people's variety of professional skills, while at the same time extending training and employment opportunities to all generations. We welcome the Juncker Plan as a first step towards mobilising resources for infrastructure, education and research, in order to compensate for the public and private investment deficit caused by the economic and financial crisis. We reiterate our position in favour of a thorough reform of the EU own resources system, which has shortcomings that could hinder the budgetary negotiations, taking as a basis for discussion the 'first evaluation report' of the High Level Group, chaired by Mario Monti.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this text because it sets out convincing general objectives for the preparation of the 2016 budget, in particular by focusing on the 3 'E' advocates of the European Parliament: employment, business and entrepreneurship. It also welcomes the Juncker plan and welcomes the initiative to create an investment potential of 315 billion euros in infrastructure, education, research and SMEs.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU budget is a strong leveraged investment prospectus that acts as a catalyst for growth, competitiveness and employment across the Union. It facilitates the implementation of programmes and projects that are otherwise difficult or impossible to implement and guarantees strategic investments in works with European added value, pooling resources and allowing economies of scale.  Given that the EU budget has a tangible positive impact on citizens' lives and, given the persistent economic and budgetary constraints at national level, plays a key role in promoting competitiveness and strengthening economic, social and territorial cohesion in the Union, I have decided to support the report as it identifies job creation as a priority for next year. , business development and entrepreneurship.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union budget is a real catalyst for growth, competitiveness and job creation throughout it, helping to improve the daily lives of citizens, but also to try to bridge the gaps between the various geographical regions.  I voted for this report because, through the budget allocated for 2016, the new EU programmes covered by the 2014-2020 financial year will become operational. The establishment of the 2016 budget leads to the relaunch of three main objectives: 'increasing employment, developing businesses, but also entrepreneurship, for smart, sustainable and inclusive economic growth in the European Union'.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The level of investment in the EU has decreased significantly and the development gap between the different regions of the EU has increased due to the economic and financial crisis. We therefore need a balance in setting the EU's budgetary priorities for 2016, as well as the timely identification of areas with demonstrated added value of expenditure at EU level, for which further investment will be needed in the second half of the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020. The European Strategic Investment Fund has the potential to mobilise EUR 315 billion in investments in infrastructure, education and research, as well as sMEs and mid-caps to make up for the shortfall in public and private investment caused by the economic and financial crisis. We underline the additional and complementary nature of the new investment plan and the EU budget. We draw attention to the fact that the EU's financial commitment to the EIB to the creation of this European Strategic Investment Fund must be examined with the utmost care. In conclusion, I voted for the report on the general guidelines for the preparation of the 2016 budget.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. The guidelines for the 2016 budget - Section III contain some useful approaches, but also passages that, for example, give cohesion policy more money. I am also critical of certain relocation plans in the guidelines. That is why I voted against the report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for general guidelines for the preparation of the 2016 European Union budget. The Commission must take due account of all priorities outlined in the draft budget for 2016, so that the relevant EU programmes and actions are allocated the resources necessary to achieve those objectives. It is important that the EU budget is highly leveraged and promotes growth, competitiveness and job creation across the EU.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I believe that the EU's austerity policies should be relaxed. In particular, Member States must have the right to choose the policy that is most appropriate to address existing problems. The Commission should not be given even greater powers in relation to the control of national budgets. The political decisions taken must ensure that Member States benefit, not, in contrast, undermine the availability or quality of their social services and benefits. It is necessary to ensure that structural funds are allocated to those countries that really need them. Another important aspect is the severe lack of funds in the European Union, both at Member State and EU level, and that this can lead to problems in the implementation of some programmes. In this context, all programmes and costs should be carefully analysed in terms of feasibility, productivity and effectiveness. We cannot cut funding for science and innovation.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The JRC voted against the European Parliament's report on the guidelines for the EU budget for 2016, because it is moving in the unpopular direction of strengthening monopolistic groups at the expense of the people. Proposals that refer to the possibility of changing the EU and its character as a union of capital, through negotiations, disorient the peoples. But leaving the euro, coordinated or not, without the people in power, with monopolies in place, does not serve popular interests.  In this context, the JRC also voted against the amendment. These are proposals that call on the people to align themselves with capitalist management alternatives that pre-promote parts of the bourgeoisie to give new impetus to capitalist development. Such proposals deceive and ultimately lead to the subjugation of the people to capital and the perpetuation of their power. With them there is trade, when of hope and when of fear, addressed to the people.  Only, however, can the people with their own and not a foreign flag provide the solution for their benefit and not monopolies: with a strong popular alliance for decommitment from the EU, unilateral debt write-off and socialisation of means of production, with the people in power.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU budget is predominantly an investment budget that acts as a catalyst for growth, competitiveness and employment across the Union and facilitates the implementation of programmes and projects that are otherwise difficult or impossible to implement, enabling economies of scale. This budget plays a crucial role in reducing discrepancies between European regions and in ensuring that investments are made in the areas where there is greatest need. Finally, the EU budget plays a key role in promoting competitiveness and strengthening economic, social and territorial cohesion in the Union. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. The budgetary guidelines for 2016 show a clear hypocrisy. Indeed, they consist of agreeing to the implementation of Member States' budgets while moving on the economic consequences. The European Union deplores, on the one hand, the collapse of public investment, while it legally organises the austerity that is responsible for it.  On the other hand, the resolution welcomes the implementation of the Juncker Plan, whose leverage of 15 is overestimated. The "pact for growth and jobs" provided for a lever of 6 to finish in reality at 2... It has no new fiscal stimulus and does not meet the investment need estimated at 235 billion per year! The Budget Committee is concerned about the fate of SMEs by touting the COSME programme, while their problem lies more in the economic gloom inherent in the euro area.  Finally, while the Union's bureaucratic cold monster is giving lessons in good management, its unpaid debts amount to 30 billion euros in 2014.  It is high time to give the Member States full use of their budgetary sovereignty! I voted against it.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I naturally supported Mr Fernandes' report because I believe that we need to make a qualitative leap forward on the issue of the EU budget. The procedure for approving the budget, but above all the question of own resources, are issues that need to be addressed quickly if we really want to emphasise the added value of the European budget, so that Europe 'walks alone'. Added value to be underlined in the next draft budget for 2016, where the Commission should focus on programmes such as Horizon 2020, COSME, Erasmus+, all geared towards reviving the economy and employment. Particular attention should be paid to the Youth Employment Initiative, which will have to be financed. Another aspect that will need to be addressed urgently by the Commission is the unresolved issue of the accumulation of back payments, which particularly affects the implementation of cohesion policy, which, moreover, is already suffering from delays in launching the new 2014-2020 programming. We therefore expect an ambitious budget proposal and, above all, a constructive approach by the Council so as to make European policies truly effective.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The EU budget is primarily an investment budget with a strong leverage effect that serves as a catalyst for growth, competitiveness and jobs across the Union. Due to continuing economic and budgetary constraints at national level, the EU budget plays a key role in boosting competitiveness and increasing economic, social and territorial cohesion in the Union. A wide range of EU programmes, including Horizon 2020, COSME and Erasmus+, contribute directly to the achievement of the objectives. Thanks to the favourable business environment and the development of entrepreneurial culture in the EU, SMEs could once again take a major role in creating jobs in a Union weakened by the economic crisis. It is good that the largest share of EU budget expenditure is the European Structural and Investment Funds, which are essential for job creation and competitiveness. The EU budget should be a means to foster internal solidarity, as it supports economic, social and territorial cohesion, combats poverty and promotes inclusion in society. The budget is also a means of external solidarity, as it is the EU's largest provider of development aid to countries and people exposed to humanitarian and civilian crises. Finally, I hope that the adoption of this year's budget will not face last year's problem of outstanding bills. Only a balanced and measured budget can enable the full potential of the EU to be realised.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒i2012 I support colleague Jose Manuel Fernandes' report. Further efforts and the provision of funding to combat youth unemployment will boost job creation, business development and entrepreneurship across the Union and facilitate the overcoming of the crisis, which is in line with Europe 2020 targets. The EU budget, as the report underlines, should be the backbone for the formation and potential mobilisation of €315 billion through EFSI with the support of the Commission, which will finance investments in infrastructure, education, research, SMEs, thus making up for the shortfall in public and private investment. Europe is compelled to enhance cooperation between police and judicial authorities, and to improve integration and social cohesion to promote stability and peace, which requires financial support in 2016, I also support the work of the Council, the Commission and Parliament in tackling unpaid bills, which reached €24.7 billion for 2007-2013. The focus of the draft budget should be on programmes and instruments such as Horizon 2020, COSME, Erasmus+ and The Growth-Boosting Youth Employment Initiative. The EU should remain the largest provider of humanitarian, civil and development as is currently the case with Ukraine, so significant resources should be allocated to this end in the budget as a means of external solidarity.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Eu ropean Union budget is one of the key instruments for business development, job creation and sustainable and inclusive GROWTH in the EU, as it is more of a leveraged investment budget that stimulates the various sectors of the economy. For this reason, the Commission must take into account the EU's political and economic priorities when drawing up the budget and must ensure that the relevant EU programmes and actions are provided with the necessary resources to achieve the objectives set.  It is important to remember that the 2016 budget corresponds to the first year of implementation of the provisions of the new Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020 and will serve as a benchmark for the review and review of the MFF. I also believe that it is important, as the report rightly states, to monitor the implementation of the main EU programmes during the current budgetary procedure.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The EU budget is a central tool for defining the main directions the Union should take and the areas on which the eu wants to insist on the economic, social and political levels. The European Parliament has adopted the general guidelines for the preparation of the 2016 budget.  I voted in favour of this text and I support the main points made, namely to promote smart, sustainable and inclusive growth by focusing on employment, SMEs and the integration of young people into the labour market.  I would also like to reaffirm my support for the Structural Funds and investment funds to undertake long-term projects in Europe in key sectors (energy, innovation, transport).  Finally, I welcome the Juncker Commission's investment plan and I believe that it will act, if properly implemented, as a real lever for growth in the Union and will create many jobs.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU budget is predominantly an investment budget, with a strong leverage effect and is a catalyst for growth, competitiveness and employment, and is crucial for the economic, social and territorial cohesion of the Union. This resolution sets out the political priorities for the 2016 budget. It therefore considers it imperative that all commitments contained in the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) be fully respected, so that the EU budget should strike a balance between revenue and expenditure and definitively address certain problems, including unpaid invoices at the end of the year, the budgeting of the MFF special instruments and the delay in implementing the new operational programmes in cohesion policy. It also highlights the support that sits on SMEs and calls for legislative simplification, cutting red tape and the use of available financial instruments. Finally, it reaffirms the need to reform the EU's own resources system, the current shortcomings of which are causing serious deadlocks in budgetary negotiations, and to make every effort to create synergies, not only between the Investment Plan and the EU budget, but also with national budgets. I voted in favour.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it calls for the Union budget for 2016 to focus on reducing unemployment and economic growth by coordinating the implementation of various Union programmes such as Horizon 2020, COSME, Erasmus+ and the Youth Employment Initiative. It is therefore important for the Commission to guide such programmes and instruments for growth within the framework of the draft budget for 2016. At the same time, I also consider it of the utmost importance to establish and implement a sound payment plan to reduce the level of outstanding settlement invoices at the end of the year so that this situation does not call into question the receipt by recipients of the European funds due to them.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. Growth, solidarity and bill payment are the three priorities set out by the European Parliament as part of the policy guidelines for the 2016 budget. This is a response in line with the new European situation introduced by the Juncker Commission, which wants to act in the areas essential for the European future: investment, recovery and job creation. Two points seem very important to me: - to focus on the 20 million SMEs, which represent 99% of businesses in the European Union, and to create the conditions for them to become the main job creators again; - to remedy the slow pace of the European Youth Employment Initiative. The release of one billion euros proposed by the Belgian Commissioner in charge of employment is therefore welcome. Solidarity is the other strong axis of the resolution adopted this lunchtime: economic solidarity by maximising the use of the Structural Funds (33% of the European budget) and by weaving the differences between the regions. Humanitarian solidarity also in terms of the burden of migration flows to be better distributed among EU countries. Finally, it is essential to reduce the arrears of payments that reached the amount of 24.7 billion euros at the end of 2014: paying its creditors is just as important as cleaning up its public finances!

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. We all agree that it should be a primary objective of the EU to take up a path that will lead to the smart, sustainable and inclusive growth of all Member States. Equally important is that this path is based on internal and external solidarity. However, despite all the good theoretical intentions about relaunching the economy and halting unemployment, it will be necessary to translate them into concrete measures that once and for all stop austerity and the consequent social and human crisis. Reality will not change if the way politics does not change.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution on the general guidelines for the preparation of the 2016 budget, Section III. This Resolution sets out the main policy priorities for the 2016 budget: job creation, business and entrepreneurship for sustainable growth in the EU, the implementation of the Investment Plan and the fight against the payment crisis. The Resolution underlines the importance of the Union budget as a tool to create smart jobs and ensure inclusive and sustainable growth across the EU, economic, social and territorial cohesion, R&D support, energy transition and interconnections, migration and asylum policy, foreign aid, as well as EU programmes , such as Horizon 2020, COSME or Erasmus+. It also underlines the vital importance of continuing the fight against youth unemployment and the need to ensure the financing of the Youth Employment Initiative from 2016. Finally, the Resolution calls for the full implementation of the joint declaration on a payment plan to end the payment crisis and the problem of unpaid invoices undermining the EU's credibility.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Encourage growth by supporting job creation, business and entrepreneurship, show solidarity both in the EU and with third countries and... tackling arrears of payment and reforming the Union's own resources system: these are the priorities that the European Parliament yesterday adopted by a large majority (484 votes in support, 188 against and 36 abstentions) for the negotiations on the 2016 budget. On this occasion, the adopted text specifies that the EU budget should form the backbone of Jean-Claude Juncker's investment plan by making available the necessary guarantee fund of 8 billion euros in commitments and payments to provide for the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI).  We also reiterated the commitment to hold at least three inter-institutional payments meetings this year. Because... by the end of 2014, the amount of unpaid bills had reached 24.7 billion euros for the cohesion programmes of 2007-2013 alone.  Finally, we have called - once again - for a fundamental reform of the European Union's funding system. The ball is now in the court of the Commission, which is due to present its draft budget for 2016 at the end of May.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. This report sets out the priorities of the EU budget for 2016. Thus our aim is to encourage growth by supporting job creation, business and entrepreneurship, to increase solidarity with both third countries and within the Union itself and to put European finances in order, including the reform of the Union's own resource system.  European solidarity should be accentuated, in particular, by increasing emergency humanitarian aid and development aid, while supporting the resumption of growth with support for European funds to further encourage the creation of new businesses. Finally, with regard to the reform of the Union's own resources system, the aim is once again to call for in-depth reforms to the resource system that funds the EU budget, which is part of the work of the high-level group on own resources - the Monti Group - which will make its final recommendations by the end of 2016.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote against because I am very sceptical about certain passages in the text: I do not agree with the positive investment references presented by Commissioner Katainen (European Fund for Strategic Investments) which, moreover, drains resources from important programmes that already exist and financed such as Horizon 2020; the solidarity criteria set out in the text are not well defined; The work of the High Level Group on Own Resources chaired by Mario Monti is defined as important, the aim of which is to identify new taxes or levies to finance Union policies.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We abstained in the vote on this report as the text is ambiguous: while on the one hand it recognises that there is a serious shortage of EU funds and reiterates the need to comply with the EU's payment obligations, on the other hand it does not identify the structural causes of this scarcity (continuous reductions in commitments under the current MFF) nor does it propose ambitious solutions to end defaults , opening the door to possible cuts in current expenditure by the European institutions under the justification of efficiency. Finally, the European Parliament's recommendation has a weak or no impact on the Commission's preparation of the 2016 budget.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which lists the priorities of this House in the negotiations on the European budget for 2016. The European Union is in a paradoxical situation: it is not allowed to be in deficit, but nevertheless carries in its balance sheet a backlog of payments which continues to increase and which amounted at the end of 2014 to almost 24.7 billion euros. This is due to the constant lag between commitment credits and payment credits.  Member States are willing to commit European funds for research or infrastructure projects, but refuse to pay the bills. Parliament therefore urges the Council to close this slate and calls for in-depth reforms so that the Union finally has its own resources so that it no longer depends on the annual contributions of the Member States.  Beyond this accounting problem, the report highlights the added value of the European budget in encouraging growth by supporting job creation, business and entrepreneurship, encouraging start-ups, funding the youth employment initiative, promoting territorial cohesion and showing solidarity with third countries.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The procedure for the general budget of the European Union for 2016 will be the subject of many expectations, given the current context of financial constraints and what this budget is expected to provide, in addition to national budgets, in particular with regard to job creation and the creation of conditions for greater competitiveness and growth of economies , based on better knowledge and greater environmental sustainability. The pursuit of these objectives must be accompanied by adequate financial resources and I am concerned about the fall back from the payments of commitments previously made, as seen in the 2015 budget negotiations, and, on the other hand, I hope that the leverage effects under the investment plan will be truly consequential, because this will be the only way we can justify recent budget adjustments.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted against the guidelines for the 2016 budget as there was a lack of any real reference to making cuts to ineffective areas of spending, like the CAP direct subsidy for agriculture. We need to see more productive, effective and forward-thinking investment - investment in industries that will secure growth and jobs, in research, and in our young people. We are working with colleagues here in the European Parliament to drive the European economy forwards and to work towards an EU budget that delivers more positive impacts in the West Midlands. We do need to see less effective areas of spending within the EU budget redirected to projects that deliver real economic and social benefits.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing \ u2012 I voted against. I cannot agree with favouring certain development programmes to the detriment of others. I also share my great doubts about the ad hoc redistribution of Horizon 2020 funds. Moreover, in the future, the planned draft EU budget for 2016 is at least debatable given the lack of effective control mechanisms within the EU and the repeated non-approval of the EU budget by the Court of Auditors.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 It is important that we give a clear signal in the drafting of the 2016 budget of the need for development impulses and that the guarantee for the so-called 'green economy' is a good one. The Juncker Strategic Package was a clear and integral part of this budget.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The effects of the economic and financial crisis are felt in all Member States of the European Union. The level of investment in the EU has fallen significantly and the development gap between different regions in the EU has widened. Unemployment, especially youth unemployment, is a problem for most Member States. I supported this report on the 2016 budget guidance, as it includes measures to recover three main areas: employment, businesses and entrepreneurship. Job creation and business and entrepreneurship development represent smart, sustainable and inclusive growth for the European Union. The EU budget is a means to foster internal solidarity, as it supports economic, social and territorial cohesion, combats poverty and helps reduce inequalities in the development of not only Member States but also their regions. I believe that the 2016 budget guidelines presented in this report have a concrete positive impact on citizens' lives.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the resolution on the guidelines for the 2016 budget as I believe it is not necessary to increase the EU budget next year. Additional money should, rather, be used in areas that support jobs and growth.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - I support this report, as the EU budget serves as a catalyst for growth, competitiveness and jobs across the Union and plays a key role in reducing disparities between European regions and ensuring investment in areas where it is most needed. The budget highlights the recovery of jobs, businesses and entrepreneurship for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth in the European Union. The EU budget is a means to foster internal solidarity, as it supports economic, social and territorial cohesion, combats poverty, promotes inclusion in society and helps reduce inequalities in the development of not only Member States but also their regions. It is also a tool of external solidarity and serves to provide emergency assistance during humanitarian and civilian crises by offering assistance to countries in need, as is the case with Ukraine, and thanks to it, the EU is the largest provider of development assistance to meet the EU's poverty eradication commitments, as confirmed in the European Consensus on Development, and contributes to the global development strategy for the post-2015 period.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: I did not agree with the proposal in writing ‒ as it supports an increase in European Union spending to boost growth and jobs. As can be seen, the promoter of the proposal does not understand that employment is not created by the redistribution of money, but by entrepreneurs who have to be composed of similar projects through higher taxes.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposed guidelines for the creation of the 2016 budget. 2016 will be the year of employment, business and entrepreneurship. I am strongly against the misuse of the debate on the European budget to collect national points. I really wish this year would be different. Let us not forget, the EU budget plays an important role in promoting the competitiveness, economic, social and territorial cohesion of the EU, given its investment nature and, consequently, an important role in confronting and reducing the uncertainty, mistrust and dissatisfaction of EU citizens. That is why I also supported the proposed guidelines for the creation of the European budget for 2016.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 This year's budget report focuses on and supports The Unger Investment Plan and going a step further suggests further liberalising market rules to promote competitiveness. The results of this neoliberal policy have already been lived on. It is what has led to the poverty, unemployment and misery that the people are currently experiencing.  We voted against the budget guidelines because they follow neoliberal policies. This year's report has just all the elements of the EU's neoliberal path. Militarisation, deregulation of market rules, competitiveness as a solution to all the Union's problems, and full support for the Unger package aimed at serving monopolies and increasing the profits of large enterprises.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Cross-border mobility is not a solution to the problem of unemployment, because this weakens the already affected countries of the Union by losing their healthy workforce.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text. It should be noted that the EU budget should form the backbone of this investment plan by making available the necessary guarantee fund of EUR 8 billion in commitments and payments to provide for the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI).  We are told that the contribution from the EU budget should be profitable because of significant leverage. I aspire to believe it, but I remain vigilant. I therefore confirm our willingness to examine with the utmost attention how the European Union's financial commitments to the EIB for the implementation of the EFSI are included in the EU budget!

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the guidelines for the EU budget for 2016, which present our priorities for future negotiations. The text clearly support job creation, but also companies and entrepreneurship, and this is essential, in my view, to create growth in the EU.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I voted against the report on the general guidelines for preparing the 2016 budget. While the report focuses on policies that enable smart and inclusive growth as well as boosting competition for jobs and development and job creation, attention should be focused on investing in visible untapped potential as well as revising the Multiannual Financial Framework, which sets long-term spending priorities.  The ultimate objective of pooling resources is to reduce inequalities between countries in order to enable poorer members to participate equally in the revitalisation of the European economy. This will only be possible if better coordination between national and EU policy is achieved and provides sufficient space and support for innovation and research, the development of better transport and energy routes and ultimately the achievement of a more competitive European economy globally.

name: Giovanni Toti (PPE)
text: in writing. With today's vote, Parliament is once again calling on the European Union to promote employment, strengthen the skills of our citizens, support businesses, especially SMEs, and encourage entrepreneurship in all 28 Member States. The 2016 budget must have a tangible positive impact on citizens' lives.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained in the vote on this report as the text is ambiguous: while on the one hand it recognises that there is a serious shortage of EU funds and reiterates the need to comply with the EU's payment obligations, on the other hand it does not identify the structural causes of this scarcity (continuous reductions in the commitments made under the current MFF) nor does it propose ambitious solutions to end the defaults , opening the door to possible cuts in current expenditure by the European institutions under the justification of efficiency. Finally, the European Parliament's recommendation has a weak or no impact on the Commission's preparation of the 2016 budget.

name: Inese Vaidere (PPE)
text: Writing. – We have identified employment and business promotion as well as support for existing businesses as financial priorities for the 2016 Budget of the European Union. EU support for entrepreneurship is extremely important for stimulating the Latvian economy and boosting the well-being of its citizens. Given the current situation in Ukraine, relations with Russia, as well as the terrorist attacks in Europe, it is very important that the EU spends more on security and defence in next year's budget, especially more financial protection of the external borders. It is also important to devote resources to improving internal security as well as police and judicial cooperation between Member States. It is equally important to find funds from the 2016 budget to pay the bills that have accumulated for projects that have been carried out in the previous programming period. In order for cohesion projects to be able to function successfully, financing areas such as the construction of infrastructure, labour training and the development of cities and regions requires payment for the projects carried out, as well as timely payment of the services provided in the future.  Next year's budget will be very important in the implementation of the European Investment Plan, which aims to raise EUR 315 billion for the European economy. I hope that we will also be able to use the support provided by this fund in Latvia to develop projects in research, innovation, energy efficiency and other sectors.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. We have been saying the same good intentions for years: support for employment and for small and medium-sized enterprises. But the results are difficult to achieve: the resources of the EU budget fail to bring that much-vaunted added value, nor are they a valid leverage effect. A new element is added this year, namely the Juncker plan.  Two years ago we saw the negotiations on the MFF which reduced the EU budget, as requested by the Member States, and now we are looking for a way to review the decisions that have just been taken. The investment plan should use part of the funds earmarked for research and transport as collateral, which should be key elements for european economic recovery, demonstrating that in reality there is no organic and structural vision for the economic growth of all Member States.  My vote against is a condemnation of the schizophrenia of the European budget, which should be a key element of a project but which has in fact become a mere pretext for a European Union that needs to be rethought.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my Parliament Labour Party colleagues I voted against these guidelines because of the absence of any calls to cut inefficient budget lines. I believe we should refocus the EU budget so there can be more investment in programmes which encourage growth and jobs.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. The European Parliament highlighted three major themes in its political approach to the 2016 budget: growth, solidarity and the payment of invoices.  One point also seems to me to be extremely important in this budget, namely the EUR 20 million allocated to SMEs. SMEs in the European Union are the majority of enterprises, which also create the greatest jobs. On the other hand, it is very important that the 2014 backlog of invoice payments by the EU (estimated at EUR 24.7 billion) is eliminated as soon as possible.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. A large majority of the European Parliament (EP) voted in favour of this report on the general guidelines for the preparation of the European Union budget for 2016, while stressing the difficulties posed by the 2014-2020 multi-year budget, which this majority adopted without questioning the Member States' budget cuts. Other problems are raised, such as the consequences of tax evasion and evasion on national budgets, but no real will to change things and propose concrete measures, except to send the ball back to the Council and the Member States by asking them to stop their budgetary inconsistency... The overall approach remains the same. Europe must be put back on track, thanks in particular to the three 'E'es - jobs, businesses and entrepreneurship - and support for the Juncker investment plan, the limits of which are already widely known. At the GUE/NGL, we know that it is only a fundamental challenge to austerity policies that can stop the recession in which the European Union is locked in, by calling for an end to social and fiscal dumping, a policy of reindustrialization, relocation measures, and real support for energy and ecological transitions, capable of creating jobs. I therefore voted against this report in reverse of the measures and decisions to be taken.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The process of drawing up the EU budget is marked by a complex framework where the voluntarism of policies in speeches is not parallel to the contribution of the Member States. About the 2016 budget. We do not understand the cuts in the framework programme for science and research. We reject all funds to fuel the EU's neoliberal and militaristic policies. Rather, we advocate that this expenditure be refocused on social and territorial cohesion policies. Policies to combat poverty and social exclusion that are growing in the eyes of Europe. We would like to see in the 2016 budget a genuine European-wide public investment programme that complements national programmes. To the three E we propose three S: social, solidarity and sustainability.  We also believe that a specific programme is justified to compensate the countries that are victims of troika policies, which, as recognised at the highest level by various personalities, have been disastrous for these economies. In this sense, our amendments are going to be adopted.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. I voted against this motion for a resolution because I do not consider the guidelines for the 2016 budget to be useful because of the overall constitution. Partly because of the redistribution of financial resources, but also because more money is being channelled to EU countries where the economic and financial situation is more than questionable, I consider this budget to be rejected as such, despite some sensible approaches.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my European Parliament Labour Party colleagues I voted against these guidelines because of the absence of any calls to cut inefficient budget lines. I believe we should refocus the EU budget so there can be more investment in programmes which encourage growth and jobs.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The JRC voted against the European Parliament's report on the guidelines for the EU budget for 2016, because it is moving in the unpopular direction of strengthening monopolistic groups at the expense of the people. Proposals that refer to the possibility of changing the EU and its character as a union of capital, through negotiations disorient the peoples. But exiting the euro, coordinated or not, without the people in power, with monopolies in place, does not serve popular interests.  In this context, the JRC also voted against the amendment. These are proposals that call on the people to align themselves with capitalist management alternatives that pre-promote parts of the bourgeoisie to give new impetus to capitalist development. Such proposals deceive and ultimately lead to the subjugation of the people to capital and the perpetuation of their power. With them there is trade when hopes and when fear is addressed to the people.  Only, however, can the people with their own and not a foreign flag provide the solution for their benefit and not monopolies: with a strong popular alliance for decommitment from the EU, unilateral debt write-off and socialisation of means of production, with the people in power.

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution. However, I would like to draw attention to the fact that the 2016 budget should not be a copy of what has been done so far, but should support the investment programme in Europe more broadly. In 2016, the European Fund for Strategic Investments will be operational. For now, the European Commission wants to fund it with EUR 16 billion, hoping that these funds will be increased by the European Central Bank. However, the planned amount of EUR 16 billion is far too low and will not result in a noticeable increase in investments, a significant part of which is to be spent on infrastructure investments. Also in Poland it is planned to build a dozen sections of motorways and railway investments, which will be co-financed by this fund. In my opinion, all the savings in the European Union budget should be directed to the Investment Fund, as it contributes to the recovery of the economy and the creation of new jobs, that is to say, to solving the fundamental social problem in Europe.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We are against cuts in the framework programme for science and research. We reject all funds to fuel the EU's neoliberal and militaristic policies. Rather, we advocate that this expenditure be refocused on social and territorial cohesion policies and policies to combat poverty and social exclusion, the social scourge of various peoples of EU countries. We advocate a specific programme to compensate the countries that are victims of troika policies which, as recognised at the highest level by various personalities, have been disastrous for these economies, so we have tabled amendments to that effect which, unfortunately, have been rejected with the vote against, too, several Portuguese Members. We rejected the overall report.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the general guidelines for the 2016 budget because it emphasises employment, supports the economy and promotes entrepreneurship across the EU. The EU budget can have a strong leverage effect by stimulating growth, competitiveness and innovation and bringing added value in creating new jobs. It plays a key role in reducing disparities between European regions and boosting social cohesion and developing businesses and entrepreneurship for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth across the EU. Around 94% of the EU budget is reinvested in member states, a large proportion through the Structural and Investment Funds, which enables many projects with European added value. EU cohesion policy makes a major contribution to maintaining public investment in key economic areas and has already achieved tangible results that help countries overcome the crisis and achieve the europe 2020 objectives. The guidelines also touch, inter alia, on strengthening the neighbourhood policy and security issues that are important for EU citizens. I hope that the European Commission will take into account Parliament's good proposals when drafting the budget in May.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – I supported this report because I consider the protection of the European Union's financial interests to be an important issue.  We have also made great progress in the Czech Republic, where we have directly put into the criminal law the facts of the damage to the financial interests of the European Union and enforced the criminal liability of legal entities. Here we need cooperation between the institutions of the European Union and the nation states and, say, the judiciary at national level.  The report describes very well how OLAF's work is improving. I welcome olaf's record of more and more possible misuses of European Union funds. It is necessary that this information is not only communicated in some way, but that it is assessed whether it is a criminal activity and, where appropriate, that clear final judgments are handed down in the case of criminal activity. It is also good that the tasks for the Commission are clearly set out here.  I support the report and consider it to be an important matter within the credibility of the European Union.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the figures we have seen tell us that the number of irregularities in 2013 has increased by as much as 17 % compared to last year, and what is most worrying is that the main victim of these infringements is cohesion policy. They are, in short, funds that are directly taken away from the growth and development of our territories and the well-being of our citizens.  It is true that not all recorded infringements, indeed a great many, are fraudulent. Especially in the case of cohesion, irregularities are due to a lack of knowledge of the rules and complicated procedures. So, while I strongly call for zero tolerance in the strict pursuit of those responsible for this fraud, I call with the same force for non-fraudulent infringements to be combated ex ante, through a simplification of rules and procedures and through the training of all those involved in the management and use of cohesion policy funds. It is often this deficiency that prevents, among other things, the very use of funds.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of this annual report, which is an important part of the Treaties. Every year the Commission is asked to bring forward a report on the state of play in terms of the level of fraud that exists across the European Union. One of the obvious examples of fraud, not just in Europe but worldwide, is of course the area of illicit tobacco. The global threat depriving Member States is close to EUR 10 billion every year in terms of lost revenue. Estimates put the potential figure of illegal cigarettes sold on the world market by 2017 at over 628 billion cigarettes. Ireland is a prime target for cigarette smuggling. In Ireland last year OLAF’s Operation REPLICA seized 130 million cigarettes. If there is one key message from this report, it is the need for much closer coordination and cooperation between the revenue service, the customs service and the police and border authorities to make sure we get on top of this problem.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: - Madam President, every year the European Commission publishes a report on the protection of the financial interests of the European Union. The aim is to prevent fraud and encourage sound financial management.  This latest report for 2013 highlighted that negative financial effects have decreased by 17%, but at the same time the number of irregularities and fraud has increased. This may also indicate that the detection system works better, but now it warns us of the need for more effective prevention measures.  I supported this report, which calls for greater cooperation between Member States and the European Commission with a view to increasing transparency and accountability and combating corruption, organised crime, tax avoidance and tax returns in order to reduce as much as possible the negative financial impact of fraud and irregularities.

name: Morten Messerschmidt (ECR).
text: Madam President! It is very rare that I would urge citizens to actually read the reports from the various institutions and agencies of the European Union and so on. But if one institution were to be thrown at, it is precisely the Court of Auditors. When we talk about the fight against fraud and fraud in EU money, there is nothing more obvious. It is absolutely shocking, so bad control of EU money, when a number – not to say everyone – of the EU Member States have to deal with it. What is even more shocking, however, is that the Commission is unable to change its policy, does not have the power to ensure that there is at least the same discipline with EU money – i.e. citizens' money, managed through the European Union – as there is with citizens' money when it is administered through their own countries. Completely ridiculous projects from grandmothers who have to bake cakes, over donkeys travelling around Europe. All in order to create some kind of common feeling in Europe is being funded by these projects, and that is not even the illegal thing. No, the illegal thing is even worse, where the mafia itself has the money, has its hands in the box and draws up billions because the EU is not in control. It's grazing!

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – In this report, which I would like to support, I would like to highlight the issue of fraud, which is implemented in the cohesion policy section.  It is true that the resulting figure is therefore slightly smaller in terms of the sum of the detected, i.e. fraudulent acts in terms of the sum of money, but the number of these individual cases is increasing. I would therefore like to point out here that there has also been a relatively significant misuse of European funds at the level of regional operational programmes in the Czech Republic.  This experience of misuse of funds, when they were not adequately guarded at the level of the regions, led the Czech Republic to change the methodology for drawing in this new period, so that regional operational programmes will no longer work, but will be one national one. I consider this a good example of the fight against fraud.

name: Louis Aliot (NI)
text: In writing. The 2013 Annual Report on the Protection of the Union's Financial Interests reminds us that the fight against fraud, corruption and money laundering must be a priority for institutions and Member States.  However, I abstained on this report because the means put in place to combat fraud in the context of european funds remain insufficient. The report points out that the current lack of results in the fight against fraud is due to the non-application of existing regulations. Some states are singled out because they do not provide accurate data for irregularities in them. There is also an increase in the diversion of aid by some countries.  To remedy cases of fraud, the report calls for the creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, the effectiveness of which remains questionable even as it will undermine the national sovereignty of states.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution on the 2013 Annual Report on the Protection of the EU's Financial Interests – Combating Fraud because it contains important criticisms of current European anti-fraud policy and includes new proposals that are interesting and could contribute to ending this scourge, such as the homogenisation and improvement of fraud control and data collection mechanisms in different States , the assumption of responsibility by the Commission for the withdrawal of fraudulently used European funds, the homogenisation of the definitions of the different offences and the penalties applicable, or transparency measures aimed at knowing details of the entities and projects receiving European funds. Although I reject the proposal for the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office and have a critical opinion on the work done by Eurojust, I believe that these proposals can be an impetus for the fact that the numerous cases of fraud, many of which have been carried out with the complicity of administrations, are actually criminalized in a proportionate and homogeneous manner , when not directly by themselves.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. The fight against fraud, money laundering and corruption must be a priority for the European institutions and member states. In 2013, 1,609 irregularities were reported as fraudulent, representing a total of EUR 309 million in EU funds.  I welcome the fact that several amendments by my colleague Louis Aliot, calling for the use of the European budget in full transparency and in full alignment with the interests of the citizens of the Member States of the Union, have been included in the report. But I regret that the means used to combat fraud in the context of European funds remain insufficient.  The report also calls for the creation of a new supranational body - the European Public Prosecutor's Office - against which I am speaking. For these reasons, I have chosen to abstain on this text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I did not vote against this report, as it recognises the level of financial irregularities and at least some steps are being taken to minimise them. However, I could not vote in favour as much of the problem is structural: it is impossible to eradicate irregularities in this system.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because the fight against fraud, corruption and money laundering within the Union must be a priority for the political action of the Community institutions, and that police and judicial cooperation between Member States is therefore fundamental.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to protect the EU's financial interests and combat fraud. I was rapporteur for the 2010 report on the protection of the EU's financial interests, so this issue is very relevant to me. In 2013, the EU lost around EUR 2 billion as a result of fraud and irregularities. Only 24% of fraud and 70% of irregularities were recovered from Member States. There is no clear framework for member states to implement the recommendations of OLAF investigations relating to fraud and there are no penalties for non-compliance with them. This situation must not be tolerated, and I therefore call on the Commission to take full responsibility for the recovery of funds unduly paid. As I have said many times, another important problem remains the fact that Member States receive huge funds from the EU, but are not obliged to provide comprehensive and comparable data on irregularities when they are used. It is therefore necessary for the Commission to harmonise the principles for reporting fraud.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. Although several amendments tabled by Louis Aliot - calling for the use of the European budget in full transparency and in full alignment with the interests of the citizens of the Union - have been included in this report, I have chosen to abstain because the means put in place to combat fraud in the context of the allocation of European funds remain insufficient. In particular, I deplore the increase in the diversion of aid by newcomers to the Union. And although some proposals are moving in the right direction, I am opposed to the creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, which could constitute a serious obstacle to the judicial sovereignty of our States.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The report clearly demonstrates that the Commission has stepped up its efforts to combat fraud related to its financial interests, but that the problem remains. Cases of spending fraud are even on the rise. In terms of spending, regional development funds are primarily for job creation and social well-being for citizens. As the mayor of a municipality benefiting from these aids, I can testify to their decisive impact in ensuring a better future for our people. We cannot tolerate the diversion of these aids for major social purposes! In terms of revenue, fraud, in addition to the loss of resources it constitutes for the Union, can only feed smuggling, international crime and money laundering. So we can't tolerate it. The fight against corruption also seems essential to me. The latest barometer from the NGO Transparency International reminds us that this scourge is rampant in the Union. The Commission's initiatives can only be encouraged. But also better cooperation between Member States, rapid approval of the proposed PIF directive and the implementation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, which are part of effective cooperation with OLAF and Eurojust.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. The Pirinski report once again demonstrates that the European Union, so quick to criticise, is the victim of numerous frauds and irregularities. Some EUR 309 million has been misappropriated, more than half of it for social cohesion policy alone, notably by eastern European countries such as Romania, Bulgaria, Poland and the Czech Republic. However, Italy is the first in the amount of embezzlement of European funds, with 68.5 million euros embezzled in 2013. Finally, pre-accession funds are also the subject of numerous frauds. If we all agree that the fight against fraud is a priority, because we must have honest and sound management of public accounts, only the Member States must decide to detect them and not a European prosecutor's office. I therefore abstained on this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which calls on the European institutions to cooperate more closely and profitably with national authorities in combating and preventing fraud against European taxpayers and also urges the Commission to reinstate interruptions and suspensions of payments in order to prevent irregularities and the risk of errors in the proper use of EU funds.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted in favour of the report. The report describes the problem of fraud and fraud in the EU. A number of measures are proposed to continue the fight against this criminal activity. That is very positive. It is important that all Member States work hard to put an end to fraud and fraud. I also note that the report proposes continued integration of criminal law and expressed support for the European Public Prosecutor's Office (EPPO). I am critical of these points, but in terms of the whole of the report, it does not change my vote. That is why I am voting in favour of the report.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The report contains optimism-inducing data, such as the reduction in the financial impact of irregularities detected, both non-fraudulent irregularities (38% less than in 2012) and fraudulent ones (21% less) or that for the first time cohesion policy was not the area with the highest number of fraudulent irregularities or that most irregularities detected have been thanks to the control mechanisms provided for in EU law and not through criminal investigations. However, there has been no significant progress in the time it takes to report fraud cases. However, the implementation of the new legal and administrative measures to combat this scourge must be assessed. It is necessary to continue to combat the misuse of public money and to further analyse and propose improvements in fraud detection, prevention and prosecution systems. Moments as delicate as today, when great sacrifices are being demanded from citizens in the form of social cuts and labour precariousness, require that community institutions be at the forefront of the fight against fraud, but also of transparency in the use of public funds. That is why I voted favourably.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the protection of the European Union's financial interests, together with the principle of sound financial management, should be a guarantee that budgetary revenue and expenditure contribute to achieving the EU's priority objectives and objectives and to increasing citizens' confidence. It is very important to assure our citizens that their money is being used transparently, in full compliance with EU objectives and policies and in the interests of EU citizens. Therefore, effective action is needed in the fight against corruption and the use of possible criminal law instruments and other accompanying measures, such as greater transparency and accountability, to combat possible criminal law instruments. It is therefore important that Member States demonstrate strong political will to effectively combat corruption at national and EU level, by adopting effective anti-corruption legislation and continuing to work on existing proposals at EU level. The European Parliament also calls on all Member States to set up their own anti-fraud coordination offices and to entrust them with tangible competences and powers and to allocate sufficient human and financial resources.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Given that fraudulent irregularities in 2013 involved €309 million of EU funding, there is little doubt of the need to fight against fraud and other irregularities. Tá sé tabhachtach caiteachas poiblí a chosaint, go háirithe sa ré déine seo. This is particularly the case now, more than ever, in this era of austerity, particularly given that the Multiannual Financial Framework for 2014-2020 represented the first cut to the EU's seven-year budget in 57 years. I am glad to see some recognition in this report of the need for administrative capacity - in detecting fraudulent activity.  To detect and prevent financial irregularities, Member States and the EU need to adequately invest in training and resourcing people. However, I have serious concerns in relation to the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office and the parameters of its remit. The rationale for the development of EU criminal law is to combat transnational organised crime. The intention is of course to be welcomed, but not at the expense of subjugating the existing judicial systems of individual Member States to the interests of the EU and undermining those systems.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to vote in favour of this report since I agree with its findings and conclusions. Furthermore I strongly believe that the fight against fraud in the European Union is of paramount importance for protecting our financial interests.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. This report shows that fraud is a sad reality in the use of EU funds. For example, almost EUR 309 million has been misappropriated, of which an exorbitant share - EUR 156 million - is part of the social cohesion policy.  The detection of these frauds points the finger mainly at Romania, Bulgaria, the Czech Republic and Poland, which account for almost 40% of the total fraud on the expenditure of European funds, while Italy is at the top of the ranking with almost EUR 68.5 million in embezzlement. Fraud is first and foremost a consequence of the technocratic nature of the Union's institutions, as well as the insufficient administrative capacity of some Member States in the use of European funds.  These fraudulent irregularities also concern non-member countries, including pre-accession aid (Cohesion Fund). While there is a need to strengthen deterrence policies and the fight against fraud, for example by protecting whistleblowers, it is necessary to reject any creation of a European public prosecutor's office, which would jeopardise the principle of subsidiarity in criminal prosecutions. That is why I abstained on this text.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. The text makes a comprehensive analysis of the case studies found in the year in question and calls for greater and better cooperation between the European institutions and the Member States to protect the EU's financial interests.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Every year, the European Commission publishes a report on the protection of the financial interests of the European Union. This report focuses in particular on the measures taken by Member States to neutralise fraud against European funds. In response to this report, the European Parliament is also publishing its own report on the subject. I voted in favour of this report, which highlights the struggle of Member States against corruption.  European funds are created to help Member States, regions and European citizens maximise their potential for growth and job creation, as well as to reduce inequalities within the Union. We must all work for the proper management of these funds at all levels of governance.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the 2013 annual report on the protection of the European Union's financial interests, the main point of which is the fight against fraud. The fight against fraud must, together with the fight against money laundering and corruption, be a priority for the political action of the Community and national institutions. The data of the persistence of these authentic "diseases of the system" are alarming. It is a moral, legal and social defeat that they, in all their nuances, from the violation of the rules for mere irregularities to criminal offences, still afflict and permeate the European system. I am convinced that there is still a need, in the structures and institutions, to unite a united front, and that is why I hope that measures will be taken to further harmonise the approaches and legislation applied in the various Member States. It is desirable, in fact, to strengthen cooperation between the States and the Commission, as well as the simplification of rules and procedures and the overall training of the authorities involved in the management of the funds.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained in this vote. While there were many positive aspects to this report, I have serious concerns in relation to the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office and the parameters of its remit.  The rationale for the development of EU criminal law is to combat transnational organised crime. The intention is of course to be welcomed but not at the expense of subjugating the existing judicial systems of individual Member States to the interests of the EU and undermining those systems. However, the overall intention of this report is to be welcomed, which is the fight against fraud and other irregularities. This is particularly the case now, more than ever, in this era of austerity.  Unfortunately the Multiannual Financial Framework for 2014-2020 represented the first cut to the EU's seven-year budget in 57 years. I am glad to see some recognition in this report of the need for administrative capacity - in detecting fraudulent activity.  To detect and prevent financial irregularities, Member States and the EU need to adequately train and resource people and, in this regard, more needs to be done.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Taking action to prevent fraud, and therefore the misuse of public funds, is certainly a priority, but to achieve this, proactive cooperation is needed between Member States – to which the resolution refers in this regard – and the Commission, which is required to verify the reasons for the high number of frauds in certain States. In this respect, the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, which is responsible for defending the Union's financial interests, will actually help, since cumberful state judicial mechanisms can no longer be an obstacle.  The resolution evokes a positive synergy between the actors involved, in addition to those already mentioned, in particular OLAF (the European office currently responsible for detecting fraud against the Union). The resolution draws particular attention to intervention in the area of fraud linked to the Structural Funds and the European Social Fund, which are in fact the easiest targets for diversion of public money and which should instead be a real resource for citizens.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I preferred to abstain on this report which, if it makes the right diagnosis, is wrong in the remedies to be applied. Indeed, the report reminds us that the fight against fraud, corruption and money laundering must remain a priority for institutions and Member States. On this point, I can only go in the direction of this text. However, when it comes to detecting malfunctions in counterfeiting and smuggling procedures, Member States are singled out as the main culprits, and the solution would once again be "more Europe": the report welcomes the creation of the anti-fraud coordination service (AFCOS). However, what is finally being criticised to the Member States is the reality of their differences, as the report itself admits, the differences in the number of fraudulent irregularities, for example, which are dealt with by Member States according to their particularities. Because I am in favour of a realistic approach, I congratulate my colleague Louis Aliot, who has been able to incorporate in this report amendments favourable for the quality of information of our fellow citizens.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ It is important that the European Parliament take the lead on strengthening measures to combat fraud in the EU budget. Although the total amount of money involved in fraudulent and non-fraudulent irregularities went down, the number of cases went up by 17% in 2013 compared to 2012.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I thought I voted in favour of this measure because, the direction that the Commission wants to take with the two proposals for criminal law instruments, the PIF directive and the regulation establishing the European Public Prosecutor's Office (EP Regulation), I consider them important, since they guarantee more effective investigations and better protection of taxpayers' money throughout the European Area of Freedom, Security and Justice. I am convinced that the fight against fraud, corruption and money laundering within the European Union must be the priority both political and institutional, requiring judicial and law enforcement cooperation. All this in order to increase citizens' confidence by ensuring that their money is used transparently, while fully respecting the objectives and policies of the European Union and the interests of EU citizens

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution because I am convinced that the fight against fraud, corruption and money laundering within the European Union must be a priority both politically and institutionally, requiring judicial and law enforcement cooperation. I believe that this commitment can increase citizens' confidence by guaranteeing that their money is being used transparently, in full compliance with The European Union's policies.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The protection of the EU's financial interests and the Principle of Good Financial Management are basic and fundamental coelars of an organisation of states that is serious and responsible. I believe that any misuse or fraudulent use of Community taxpayers' money harms both the interests of the Member States and the Union as a whole. Although the figures from a statistical point of view are not alarming for a Union of this scale, strong efforts should be made to combat fraud and corruption or any other type of activity harmful to the Union's financial interests, whether in the collection of traditional own resources, or in the detection and reporting of irregularities, in the control of expenditure and in the implementation of the sanctioning measures. Zero policy should be the guiding line! I would like to highlight the first EU anti-corruption report of 2014, which is a special tool for assessing and monitoring the fight against corruption, OLAF's role in monitoring irregular acts and the need for enhanced cooperation between Member States and the Commission in the adoption of measures and means in combating fraud.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because all Ms must make every effort to combat fraud, corruption and any other illegal activity that harms the Union's financial interests, especially in a context such as the current one characterised by serious economic difficulties and insufficient EU budgetary resources. Protecting financial interests means, first and foremost, contributing together to sound financial management aimed at achieving priorities and objectives for the benefit of all, as well as increasing citizens' confidence by ensuring transparent and efficient management of their money. In 2013, some 15 779 irregularities were reported by the EC, of which 14 170 were non-fraudulent and 1 609 fraudulent, for a total amount of around EUR 2.14 billion, of which EUR 1.76 billion related to the areas of expenditure in the EU budget. Not only that, there has also been a slowdown in reports of potential fraudulent irregularities over the past five years, which is also due to a picture of uneven behaviour among Member States such as; different interpretations of the concept of 'fraud' and inability to detect and report 'irregularities/fraud'. We must support anti-fraud strategies, such as the two criminal law proposals aimed at ensuring more effective investigations and the exchange of data between the competent structures of ms.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission is required to produce an annual report on the protection of the EUʼs financial interest, detailing measures taken to counter fraud affecting EU funds. To further protect against irregularities and fraudulent activities, the Commission checks whether national administrative practices are in line with EU rules, and whether the Member States’ control systems are working properly. The Commission also controls whether all substantiating documents are provided and if they comply with EU requirements. In addition, the Commission may carry out on-the-spot checks and inspections to verify Member Statesʼ adherence to the rules. According to the report, an effective action against corruption is possible if criminal law measures are complemented by other measures such as appropriate level of transparency and accountability. I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that Italy is among the countries with the most frauds and given the latest investigations and arrests in Sicily regarding the fraudulent use of EU resources by regional politicians and leaders, I can only vote in favour of this report that indicates the key points of the fight against fraud in 2013.  It calls for greater control and efficiency in the fight against fraud, and I can only agree with that.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The annual report shows that in the area of cohesion policy, reported cases of irregularities have increased by 15%. This is extremely worrying – however partly mitigated by the reduction in the corresponding amounts – which must make us reflect on the instruments for monitoring cohesion policy, particularly in view of the new programming. While it is essential not to lower our guard, but rather to step up controls, concrete action should be taken on two aspects.  On the one hand, on the very system of cohesion policy controls, which is extremely focused on procedural aspects, rather than on achieving objectives.  On the other hand, we need a real change in the bureaucratic and administrative procedures for access to funds which, without sacrificing the efficiency and effectiveness of the control instruments, simplify them. I am convinced that we would have better design and less opportunities for fraud which, all too often, find fertile ground in the folds of articulated and highly designed procedures to such an extent as to facilitate fraudulent activities, rather than curbing them.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which focuses specifically on the fight against fraud particularly when it comes to EU funds. Potential fraudulent irregularities detected in the last five years showed a slow decrease but the number of irregularities not reported as fraudulent has progressively increased. I agree with the call on the Commission to examine in detail what is leading to this.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report looks at the Commission's anti-fraud measures and highlights, in particular, the significant increase in the number of threats resulting from non-compliance and wilful offences or criminal acts.  In the agricultural field, it appears that Member States have now recovered only 15% of the irregular sums collected and that significant gaps remain in budgetary implementation between states. In the last reform of the Common Agricultural Policy, of which I was one of the rapporteurs, it was decided to give Member States greater flexibility in the implementation of agricultural policy, as well as to allow the transfer of funds between the first and second pillars. However, this flexibility must not come at the expense of budget monitoring and evaluation systems.
