I therefore support the idea that the European Commission can align the simplification programme in preparation with dg AGRI's anti-fraud strategy and maintain a necessary balance between simplifying and properly managing EU funds.  For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. At a time when Member States are increasingly being asked to make more efforts on their budgetary capacity, it is essential to optimise the management of European funds. Therefore, the publication of the European Commission's 2013 annual report on the protection of the Financial Interests of the European Union takes on particular importance. For example, the European Parliament, in its own report, is concerned about an overall increase of 17% in the number of irregularities in 2013 compared to the previous year, although their amount has decreased by 36%. The European Parliament's report also notes some concern about the 76% increase in the number of so-called fraudulent irregularities in EU expenditure, as well as an extremely low recovery rate in cases of fraud (23.4%) compared to recent years. The European Commission, in close coordination with the Member States, must propose actions to remedy these shortcomings in the management of European funds for the good of our fellow citizens and in the interests of good management of public funds.

name: Karima Delli (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament adopted a report on 11 March 2015 on protecting the interests of the European Union and combating fraud. I support this report, which encourages the European Commission to quickly propose a legislative proposal on the protection of whistleblowers and provides for a new list of recommendations to combat corruption and fraud more effectively in the Union.  It is essential that the Union protects those people who, by passing on confidential documents, shed light on crucial revelations of public interest. The Commission and the Member States must be aware that transparency remains the best tool to prevent any misuse of EU funds.

name: Diane Dodds (NI)
text: in writing. ‒ It is absolutely right that we should come together to discuss ways in which governments across Europe can detect and deter financial crimes across society.  Illicit trade, smuggling and laundering - which this report is correct to highlight - are crimes which disproportionately impact my constituency, Northern Ireland, given our unique land border with the Republic of Ireland.  And I am delighted to be able to stand before you today in the knowledge that the UK National Crime Agency is now able to operate in Northern Ireland for the betterment of our economy, border communities blighted by these crimes, and our society as a whole. The previous veto on this specialist body working in Northern Ireland was costing the local economy millions of pounds every year - money which lined the pockets of crime gangs with alleged links to republican terrorists.  These national authorities should always have primacy to investigate and prosecute these crimes. However, Europe does have a role to play in terms of ensuring that spending under the EU budget is credible, safe and immune from corruption where possible. Only then can any form of value for money be secured.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The report welcomes the Commission's annual report, which outlines a broad range of legal and administrative measures taken since 2011 to shape a new landscape for the further enhancement of the policy for the protection of the financial interests of the Union. The report states that effective action against corruption is possible if criminal law measures are complemented by other measures such as better transparency and accountability and that Member States must demonstrate political will in countering corruption. The report welcomes the establishment of anti-fraud coordination services (AFCOS) in Member States as bodies which facilitate effective cooperation and exchange of information with OLAF. The report also welcomes the successful outcomes of numerous joint customs operations (JCOs) involving the cooperation of OLAF and Member States with various third-country services.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the protection of the EU's financial interests because, in my view, in times of crisis and overcoming it, it is essential to reduce the number of abuses. Reducing abuse will ensure effective and sustainable development within the Community, which is currently a very important objective. The report noted that it is more important that Member States do not cover up cases of fraud in order to be correct to the institutions. Agriculture is one of the main industries in Bulgaria and access to European funds is vital for producers, but unfortunately there are a large number of frauds and abuses on both national and European scales. It is important to reduce the number of these frauds and to increase the effectiveness of the funds allocated, with the funds being more accessible to small producers, as in Bulgaria a large part of the allocated funds are used by large entrepreneurs. I also note the problems with smuggling, which harms both Bulgarian producers and budget, as well as our Union partners. Once again, I support this report and congratulate you on the good work of the rapporteur.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report as it proposes that the EU clearly define the minimum and higher prison sentences to be imposed on all participating Member States, which is a major blow to the sovereign rights of each Member State

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution because, in the economic difficulties currently facing the Member States and the inadequacy of the EU's budgetary resources, the protection of the European Union's financial interests is of crucial importance; EU funds must be properly managed and used as efficiently as possible. In 2013, the Commission was reported 15,779 irregularities, of which 14,170 were non-fraudulent and 1,609 fraudulent, totalling approximately €2.14 billion, of which almost €1.76 billion related to the areas of expenditure in the EU budget. The number of irregularities reported as fraud in 2013 increased by a full 30% compared to 2012. In 2013, the recovery rate for fraud cases stood at just 23.74%. The Member States and the Commission absolutely must take action to recover sums unduly paid and substantially increase the recovery rate for cases of fraud, which is at a very low level compared to the recovery rate for cases of non-fraudulent irregularities. The Commission, in particular, must take full responsibility for the recovery of amounts unduly disbursed from the EU budget.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Each Member State contributes proportionately to the EU budget, thus representing an expression of unity and deepening of European integration. The protection of financial interests and the principle of good management increase citizens' confidence by ensuring that their money is used transparently. This report presents two proposals strengthening existing measures to combat fraud, corruption, money laundering and other illegal activities that harm the Union's financial interests. It is in this sense that both the Commission and the Member States must make every effort. The report reports that in 2013 15,779 irregularities were reported to the Commission, of which 14,170 were non-fraudulent and 1,609 were fraudulent, involving an overall amount of EUR 2.14 billion, with 98% of traditional own resources being collected without significant problems, representing fraudulent irregularities of 0.29 % of the gross amount of the RPT established (in the amount of EUR 61 million) and non-fraudulent irregularities 1.57 % of THERs (in the amount of EUR 327.4 million).

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Each year, the Commission prepares a report on the protection of the financial interests of the European Union, which includes the latest information on irregularities and cases of suspected fraud reported by member states. This report focuses on the reporting and reporting of non-fraudulent and fraudulent irregularities with regard to expenditure and revenue (from traditional own resources) of the EU budget. We agree with the need to establish a framework for cooperation between the different Member States, which aims to share experiences and best practices. This can be an added value to the fight against corruption at country level. However, we consider it negative that such a measure should be seen as an embryo, serve to promote or fit the more general objective of developing the so-called "area of freedom, security and justice", with a view in particular to harmonisation of justice at EU level. In this way, we reaffirm our reservations about the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, based on Europol, Eurojust and OLAF.

name: Christofer Fjellner (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 The fight against fraud with the EU budget is crucial both for maintaining budgetary discipline and for the credibility of the EU. However, we do not support the call for the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office. This would have far-reaching consequences for Swedish legislation and the exercise of public authority and is not compatible with the principle of subsidiarity. The Swedish Parliament has also reached this conclusion unanimously.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 The protection of the European Union's financial interests is extremely important not only because and in the context of insufficient resources in the European Union budget or the economic problems of the Member States. Up to 321 irregularities reported as fraudulent concerned cohesion policy, and although the amounts involved have been reduced and gradual improvement can be observed in the light of the experience of previous years, cohesion policy is threatened by precisely such cases. We therefore stress the importance of external assistance and controls and call on the Member States to designate the AFCOS and the European Commission to ensure coordination and harmonisation of its activities in all Member States.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the 2013 annual report on the fight against fraud. The analysis carried out calls for greater and better cooperation between the European institutions and the Member States for the protection of the Union's financial interests.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report as a whole on the 2013 Annual Report on the protection of the European Union's financial interests – Combating fraud because it calls for a clear definition of the minimum and maximum prison sentences to be imposed on all participating Member States, which is a major blow to the sovereign rights of each Member State.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. – I voted positively in favour of this report because I consider it of the utmost importance to eliminate the often difficult but significant economic distortions of financial fraud within the European Union. The proposal voted on will help to identify areas at high risk and allow for uniform action against them. I welcome the fact that this year the report has made member states' efforts and progress a top priority, as it is the basis for competence to solve the complex problem so that Member States can recognise their own strengths and weaknesses. I welcome the fact that the new system will allow for more effective cooperation and exchange of information with the European Anti-Fraud Office. I think it is important that the proposal contains a number of practical elements which, through the transparency of accounts, are effective in clamping down on corruption and other financial fraud.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 Combating fraud, corruption, money laundering and other illegal activities affecting the financial interests of the Union and its citizens should continue to be a priority for the EU and all Member States. Faced with the economic and fiscal situation we are experiencing in many EU states, fraud represents a scourge showing the insolidity and lack of civility of companies and citizens who defraud. We must therefore continue to fight with will and constancy against illegal practices that damage Europe's well-being.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The funds used by the EU are the result of the daily work and sacrifices made by millions of European citizens. That is why any fraud or irregularity is an unacceptable betrayal of them, as well as an obstacle to the implementation of the policies necessary to achieve a European Union that is equal to the present and future challenges. With today's vote, we want to say loud and clear that all the necessary measures must be taken to prevent the risk of fraud and to increase the recovery rate of fraud, which stood at 23.74% in 2013, compared with 33.5% in the period 2008-2012. At the same time, we must ensure that all the funds recovered can be used to achieve a lighter and less oppressive tax burden on the lives of all European citizens.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I would like to express my full support for the report on the protection of the European Union's financial interests 'Combating fraud'. I believe it is necessary and right that Europe, home to rights and protections, should also be protected by all measures against all actions aimed at irregularities, corruption, smuggling and money laundering, which seriously threaten the financial interests of consumers, citizens, businesses and administrations.  I therefore agree with the importance of demanding a strengthening of cooperation and the rapid exchange of information between the Commission, the Member States, and the competent national authorities, so as to have a current and up-to-date reference database to help detect transnational fraud, and I confirm my full support for greater transparency in relations with lobbies – as already provided for in the next green light to the register of lobbyists – and for the proposal for an independent European court. responsible for the assessment of fraud offences and capable of protecting the interests of the Union.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Pirinski Report on the fight against fraud because we owe it to our citizens to adopt a strong, unified approach to tackling fraud across all EU Member States. In 2013, EUR 309 million of EU funds was lost to fraud. Fast action is required, including strengthening of the measures already in place, simplification of EU rules and upgrading of the administrative capacities of Member States. When it comes to misusing taxpayersʼ money, we need to adopt a zero-tolerance policy.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report on combating fraud. We think it is very important to have strict control over the use of funds from the European Union and that, as public money, you have to have scrupulous control over it. We think it is a good report, which criticises the role of Member States and stresses that they should put in more measures to detect fraud, as well as to tighten the punishments of fraudsters. Among other things, it proposes to improve transparency with respect to both the beneficiaries of the funds and their use. We attach great importance to the fight against fraud and transparency, especially when it comes to public money, so it seems to us that this report marks a good path to continue working on.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The misuse of EU funds cannot and will not be tolerated. I voted for this report as it calls for a strong, unified approach to tackling fraud across all EU Member States.  There are still different approaches in Member States in detecting and reporting fraudulent and non-fraudulent irregularities and there needs to be a set of common guidelines and indicators in order that Member states can develop a unified and comprehensive ‘information bank’ on irregularities and measures taken.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the protection of the EU’s financial interests – fight against fraud. I do believe that the fight against fraud, corruption and money laundering in the Union must be a priority in order to ensure a sustainable, solid and wealthy society.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Fraud is still too prevalent in the EU and it is imperative that the institutions maintain efforts to clamp down on it.  Parliament has clearly called for the Commission to bring forward legislation to protect whistle—blowers and we will not accept any unnecessary delays.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of the report on combating fraud. We think it is very important to have strict control over the use of funds from the European Union and that, as public money, you have to have scrupulous control over it. We think it is a good report, which criticises the role of Member States and stresses that more measures should be put in place to detect fraud, as well as to tighten the punishments of fraudsters. Among other things, it proposes to improve transparency with respect to both the beneficiaries of the funds and their use. We attach great importance to the fight against fraud and transparency, especially when it comes to public money, so it seems to us that this report marks a good path to continue working on.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because of the need on the part of the European institutions to join forces in the fight against fraud, corruption and money laundering, as well as to protect the interests of citizens, demonstrating full transparency.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the 2013 annual report on the protection of the EU's financial interests: Combating fraud, as it is vital to ensure the proper management and efficient use of EU funds. I fully support the fight against corruption, fraud, money laundering and any other illegal activity to the detriment of the Financial Interests of the Union, the allocation of additional resources to combat such activities, and the principles of accountability and transparency. In this regard, greater and structured coordination between Member States, anti-corruption authorities, managing authorities and the European Commission is needed, as well as the exchange of good practices in order to harmonise the anti-corruption approach. Additional surveillance measures such as control, audit and inspection can certainly strengthen the Financial Interests of the Union with the timely delivery of accurate data by Member States. Quality protection of the EU's financial interests raises citizens' trust in the European institutions and contributes to the fulfilment of the Union's objectives and policies.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. The liberalisation of the capital market, which has been envisaged as part of the Single European Act, has opened loopholes that the Commission now intends to close. From deregulation to control, the snake bites its tail, but deregulation is always one step ahead. For example, I could refer to the practices of McDonald's, which does not pay millions of euros in taxes in Europe through transits through Luxembourg, the Member State of the Union. As recently as Monday, the European Central Bank's quantitative easing programme began, i.e. the purchase of 1,140 billion euros of debt by the central banks of the Eurozone countries. This considerable sum is injected into the financial sphere, hoping that it will then energize the economy, through a cascade phenomenon. I therefore abstained, because, despite relevant amendments, this text does not engage in any substantive criticism of our financial excesses.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of the 2013 Annual Report on Anti-Fraud, a subject on which I have been involved in the REGI Committee. In a context where Member States are experiencing financial difficulties and where the Union's budgetary resources are limited, I believe that the protection of the Union's financial interests is more necessary than ever. As such, I call on the Commission and the Member States to coordinate their action to best combat corruption and fraud of European funds.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the annual report on the protection of the financial interests of the European Union. The protection of the Union's financial interests is of particular importance: in 2013, a total of 15,779 irregularities were reported to the Commission, of which 1,609 were fraudulent, for a total amount of around EUR 2.14 billion. Thus, it is the responsibility of both the Commission and the Member States to do everything possible to combat fraud, corruption and any other type of illegal activity that harms the Union's financial interests.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. The text describes the problem of fraud in EU funds very clearly and raises fundamental questions regarding the review of the use of EU funds. The demands made in the report are a one-way move here and lead to greater control and efficiency in the use of EU funds, as well as in the prosecution of fraudsters. However, since the report explicitly calls for the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, I must abstain, although I support the report's basic message.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report calling for a strict policy of combating fraud and efficient measures to reduce the number of irregularities in the EU budget. We urgently need to strengthen the measures in place to combat cases of fraud and to pursue a policy of zero tolerance. At the same time we highlight the need to upgrade the administrative capacities of Member States and simplify EU rules in order to facilitate better compliance and drastically reduce non-fraudulent irregularities.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With this vote we stress the urgent need to strengthen measures to combat cases of fraud in the European Union. The economic crisis and the consequent contraction of member states' budgets makes the loss to the Union's coffers of hundreds of millions, if not billions, even more intolerable.  That is why, in addition to an important effort to simplify European legislation, which will drastically reduce irregularities, it is important to improve the control and monitoring mechanisms.  Faced with an indictment rate of 54% of the reported cases, it is now clear that we must achieve as soon as possible the creation of a single, strong and independent European Public Prosecutor's Office, capable of prosecuting perpetrators of crimes affecting the financial interests of the Union.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mr De Clercq's report. Georgi Pirinski because, in addition to referring to the principle of transparency and accountability, this document also highlights the importance of anti-fraud coordination between all the Member States of the European Union. The protection of the European Union's financial interests and the fight against fraud are decisive instruments for ensuring the correct and efficient use of European funds, which are important resources for Europe's investments and growth, given also the difficulties of national budgets.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. The fight against fraud in the EU budget presented by the Pirinski report is rightly focused on increasing financial transparency in the allocation of EU funds and controlling the allocation of these resources. The exchange of consolidated information and data is necessary to protect the Union's financial interests.  However, it appears that not all Member States provide the same level of quality information and that the control of funds is failing. The report would therefore have deserved to explore the question of the relevance of the Union's policies and the targets that benefit from the funds allocated.  I abstained on this report, which appears unbalanced and incomplete in its analysis.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 We need to strengthen measures to combat fraud and to pursue a zero-tolerance policy. At the same time, it is necessary to modernise Member States' administrations and simplify EU rules in order to reduce irregularities. Efforts are also needed to improve member states' detection and reporting practices and to introduce common criteria and guidelines for the objective interpretation of those reported.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. The report underlines the importance of the measures taken since 2011, which will enable the development of a new landscape for the protection of the Union's financial interests, and considers that effective action against corruption is possible if criminal law is complemented by other measures, such as greater transparency and accountability. It stresses that it is essential for Member States to demonstrate strong political will in the fight against corruption and stresses the importance of establishing anti-fraud coordination services (AFCOS) in the Member States as bodies to facilitate effective cooperation and exchange of information with OLAF. It invites the Commission to make interruptions and suspensions of payments only as a last resort to prevent irregularities, as it considers that such measures increase the risk of errors due to reduced deadlines for the proper absorption of European funds, and requests that the Commission report on the actual contribution of interruptions and suspensions of payments to the reduction of irregularities and errors.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution on the 2013 Annual Report on the Protection of the EU's Financial Interests – Combating Fraud because it contains important criticisms of current European anti-fraud policy and includes new proposals that are interesting and could contribute to ending this scourge, such as the homogenisation and improvement of fraud control and data collection mechanisms in different States , the assumption of responsibility by the Commission for the withdrawal of fraudulently used European funds, the homogenisation of the definitions of the different offences and the penalties applicable, or transparency measures aimed at knowing details of the entities and projects receiving European funds. Although I reject the proposal for the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office and have a critical opinion on the work done by Eurojust, I believe that these proposals can be an impetus for the fact that the numerous cases of fraud, many of which have been carried out with the complicity of administrations, are actually criminalized in a proportionate and homogeneous manner , when not directly by themselves.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. We are in a situation where fraudulent irregularities affecting Europe's financial interests are a reality, and it must therefore be a priority for us to combat such fraud. In addition, we have numerous data showing us the large number of cases that are taking place in the EU.  I voted in favour of the annual report carried out to combat and protect the Financial Statement of the Union in 2013, because I believe it is a correct and appropriate report. The line of action to follow now is a quick and effective application of this. This will require adequate coordination and cooperation between all Member States and the Commission, while correct regulation and sanctioning of criminal offences in this area.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ any misuse of EU funds means losses not only for individuals but also for the Union and harms the interests of each Member State. For the 2007-2013 programming period, administrative, on-the-spot checks and audit operations resulted in more than 300 % higher detection rates of fraudulent irregularities compared to the previous seven-year period. Nevertheless, the Commission and the Member States must review existing measures and propose a new, effective system to prevent the misuse of funds in the EU. Consideration should be given to strengthening the competence of the European Anti-Fraud Office so that its findings and conclusions are bound by the investigating authorities. Criminal penalties must be enforceable in a timely and expeditious manner in order to increase their effectiveness and preventive action.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the protection of the European Union's financial interests – Combating fraud, because it supports and welcomes the creation of anti-fraud coordination services (AFCOS) in the Member States as required by Article 3(4) of the new OLAF Regulation.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. The text abstained on this text because, although some of our Members' amendments have been adopted, the means used to combat fraud as presented in this report remain insufficient, particularly with regard to the diversion of aid by new entrants.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report which underlines the fact that smuggling of heavily taxed goods causes significant loss of revenue for the budgets of the EU and the Member States, and that direct losses in customs revenue as a result of cigarette smuggling alone are estimated at more than EUR 10 billion a year. It draws attention, moreover, to trafficking in counterfeit goods, which inflicts damage upon both the Member Statesʼ tax authorities and EU companies.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. Ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the protection of the European Union's financial interests – Combating fraud, because it goes towards harmonising the European system for combating fraud and for dialogue and exchange of information between the Member States.  The result of the report shows uneven behaviour on the part of Member States in relation to various interpretations of the concept of fraud and different timings for reporting to the competent bodies. Uniform behaviour on the part of Member States in reporting irregularities to the Commission – OLAF is a necessary condition for effectively combating fraud at European level.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Eu ropean Union budget protects financial interests and, at the same time, provides support for the implementation of Community policies.   It is the European Union's priority to combat fraud, corruption, money laundering and illegal activities that harm its own interests.  I welcomed the report, which refers to the adoption, in 2013, of measures to protect the Community's financial interests, as it highlights the importance of anti-fraud coordination between Member States.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. The EU's priorities and objectives, in addition to the principle of sound financial management, are to be ensured by protecting the EU's financial interests. We welcome the calls for the elimination of irregularities and the fight against fraud. On the other hand, however, this report seeks to demand both OLAF's weak intelligence rate and a European public prosecutor's office. There are both positive and negative points in this report; That is because of this, I abstained.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Every year, Parliament looks at the fight against fraud. This year, the focus is on detecting and reporting irregularities in both the expenditure and revenues of the EU budget. The report notes that in 2013, a total of 15,779 irregularities were reported to the Commission, for a total amount of around EUR 2.14 billion. The report proposes to strengthen the fight against fraud. In particular, it criticises the fact that, in cases of fraudulent irregularities, some Member States limit their action to corrective measures without punishing those responsible. But it is the free wild movement of capital promoted by the Union that contributes greatly to the development of fraud. As long as the fight against fraud stops at the borders of tax havens, it will have little weight. I'm voting FOR.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. The fight against fraud, corruption and any other type of illegal activity harmful to the Union's financial interests is essential for the EU's policies and financial interests to be safeguarded.  Only close collaboration and coordination between the Commission and the Member States will ensure effective protection of the Union's financial interests is therefore imperative to strengthen such collaboration and coordination and make them as effective as possible. The protection of the Union's financial interests requires the same level of vigilance both in terms of resources and expenditure. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it stresses the work that still needs to be done to combat fraud and also takes note of the positive steps that the Commission and Member States have taken to combat fraud. The wide range of legal and administrative measures taken by the Commission since 2011 has enhanced the policy for the protection of the EU’s financial interests. Whilst recognising the measures Member States have taken to detect, evaluate and report financial irregularities, the report stresses the need for an increased exchange of best practices in order to ensure stronger ex-ante coordination and evaluation.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The 2013 Annual Report on the Protection of the EU's Financial Interests, focusing on the evaluation of the fight against fraud, corruption, money laundering and other illegal activities that negatively affect the financial interests of the Union and its citizens, provides welcome information on a wide range of legal and administrative measures taken by the Commission.  Accessible data and statistics show that the effectiveness of legal instruments needs to be further improved. For example, the number of reported fraudulent irregularities increased by up to 30% in 2013 compared to 2012, although their financial impact of EUR 309 million from EU funds decreased by 21%. I find it very worrying that the legal recovery rate in the area of fraud is only around 23%, well below the average rate of 33.5% in the period 2008-2012. I therefore call on the responsible authorities of the Member States, but also the relevant Commission departments, to take a responsible approach to recovering illegally paid funds, including increasing the detection of fraudulent acts.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the annual report for 2013 on the protection of the EU's financial interests - fight against fraud, which notes that the overall trend in detecting and reporting potential fraudulent irregularities in the last five years shows a slow decrease but the number of irregularities not reported as fraudulent has progressively increased.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 An important point in the report, supported by the S&D Group, was the avoidance of overzealousness. The interruption or, where appropriate, suspension of European funds (structural, rural development, direct payments) must be made only as a last resort and after all other reasonable measures to prevent or correct the deficiencies found have been exhausted and proved ineffective or unnecessary. Suspension is the maximum penalty, it should not be "granted" easily.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the report to be important not only for the protection of the Union's primary financial interests, but also for its psychological importance. Solidarity within the Eu, and with it the cohesion of the whole community, will be jeopardised if the eu's resources and the EU's development aid are not managed in a fully transparent manner, without excluding the possibility of fraud. Citizens of the net contributor Member States can be expected not to regret spending part of their taxes on the development of underdeveloped Member States and regions and on strengthening EU cohesion, but this willingness to sacrifice is difficult to expect if there are reasonable suspicions that the money they have paid will be spent lightly or stolen, but in any case will not be used for the purpose for which they have paid it. I consider it particularly important in this matter, in line with the position of my party, the Democratic Coalition, to set up the European Public Prosecutor's Office, which could investigate cases that could harm or harm the EU's financial interests, irrespective of national law enforcement and justice.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. This report shows once again that the Budgetary Organisation of the European Union is an intrinsic source of fraud and error, because of its remoteness and bureaucracy. For example, almost EUR 309 million has been misappropriated, of which an exorbitant share, representing EUR 156 million, has come from the social cohesion policy. The detection of these frauds mainly concerns Romania, Bulgaria, the Czech Republic and Poland, which account for almost 40% of the total fraud on the expenditure of European funds, while Italy is at the top of the ranking, with almost 68.5 million euros of embezzlement.  These fraudulent irregularities also concern non-member countries under pre-accession aid.  If we are to strengthen deterrence policies and the fight against fraud, while also protecting whistleblowers, we must guard against the old fantasy of the European Public Prosecutor's Office which would jeopardise the principle of subsidiarity, including in matters of fraud. It is up to the Member States to detect it and not to a supranational prosecutor's office. So I decided to abstain.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The misuse of EU funds cannot and will not be tolerated. This report calls for a strong and unified approach to tackling fraud across all EU Member States.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the 2013 annual report on the protection of the Union's financial interests and the fight against fraud. In 2013, 15,779 irregularities were reported to the Commission, for a total amount of EUR 2.14 billion. Of these 15,779 irregularities, 1,609, or more than 10%, were fraudulent. The Commission and the Member States, whose diversity of legal and administrative systems complicates the fight against fraud, must strengthen their cooperation in order to further reduce this phenomenon, which harms all European citizens.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The protection of the European Union's financial interests, together with the principle of sound financial management, should be one of our priorities, as the Community budget helps to achieve the Union's policies and objectives and to increase the confidence of European citizens. It is therefore essential for us to make every effort to combat fraud and irregularities. Close cooperation and coordination between the Commission and the Member States are therefore essential. We reiterate our concern that there are still different approaches to detecting and reporting fraudulent and non-fraudulent irregularities; in some cases, uneven interpretations persist when applying the legal framework. It would therefore be appropriate to develop common guidelines and indicators to reduce the gap between the different approaches adopted by the Member States and to prepare a unified and comprehensive database on the irregularities actually committed and on the measures taken, thus providing the authorities with reliable, comparable and centralised data for the implementation of effective corrective measures.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this text because I share the rapporteur's conclusions on the EU-wide record on the fight against fraud in 2013. I welcome the initiatives taken by the European Commission in this area and call on, for Member States that have not yet done so, to set up anti-fraud coordination services in their territories as soon as possible.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Pirinski report, which highlights the wide range of legal and administrative measures taken to protect the Union's financial interests. The report reports that, in 2013, 15 779 irregularities were reported to the European Commission, of which 14 170 were non-fraudulent and 1 609 fraudulent, for a total amount of around EUR 2.14 billion, of which almost EUR 1.76 billion related to the areas of expenditure in the EU budget. More results can only be achieved when these measures are accompanied by other actions concerning transparency and accountability. I also welcome the creation of anti-fraud coordination between Member States.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In 2013, Member States reported 1 609 irregularities as fraudulent, totalling EUR 309 million in EU aid. The number of fraudulent irregularities reported by each Member State continues to vary considerably, which, according to the Committee's report, is due to the fact that Member States use different approaches to fraud detection and, in some cases, do not interpret the legal framework uniformly. However, differences in interpretation can easily support protectionist aid.  With this in mind, I call on the Commission to make greater efforts to ensure a uniform interpretation of the legal framework, which could make the detection of fraudulent irregularities more transparent.  But we mustn't stop here. Although some statistics show that we are becoming more successful in detecting fraud, there is still a lot of money going away without knowing where it lands. In addition to urging uniform regulation, we must also focus on successful initiatives such as the ROMULUK customs operation and continue to support organisations such as the European Anti-Fraud Office. In addition, we are excited to see what the EPPO will be able to do, which, if properly functioning, could at least partially remedy the shortcomings listed above.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report because the fight against fraud, corruption and money laundering must be a priority for all Member States. The report presents a series of concrete data on the evolution, but also on measures to combat this scourge at European level. Thus, it was found that 15,779 irregularities were reported to the European Commission in 2013, of which 14,710 were non-fraudulent and 1,609 were fraudulent, involving AN amount of EUR 2.14 billion. The report also points out that the number of unreported fraudulent irregularities has increased progressively, and this is a concern. The report also reiterates the importance of OLAF in managing this situation and welcomes the establishment of anti-fraud coordination services in the Member States.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Given that fraudulent irregularities in 2013 involved €309 million of EU funding, there is little doubt of the need to fight against fraud and other irregularities. Tá sé tabhachtach caiteachas poiblí a chosaint, go háirithe sa ré déine seo. This is particularly the case now, more than ever, in this era of austerity, particularly given that the Multiannual Financial Framework for 2014-2020 represented the first cut to the EU's seven-year budget in 57 years. I am glad to see some recognition in this report of the need for administrative capacity - in detecting fraudulent activity.  To detect and prevent financial irregularities, Member States and the EU need to adequately invest in training and resourcing people. However, I have serious concerns in relation to the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office and the parameters of its remit. The rationale for the development of EU criminal law is to combat transnational organised crime. The intention is of course to be welcomed, but not at the expense of subjugating the existing judicial systems of individual Member States to the interests of the EU and undermining those systems. For these reasons I abstained.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the 2013 annual report on protecting the EU's financial interests – combating fraud. Protecting the EU's financial interests, together with the principle of sound financial management, should ensure that budgetary revenues and expenditure contribute to achieving EU priorities and objectives and to strengthening citizens' confidence through the guarantee that public money is used in a transparent manner, in full compliance with EU objectives and policies and in the interests of EU citizens. I voted for Amendment 11 urging the Commission to resume the practice of interrupting and suspending payments in order to prevent irregularities and the risk of error with regard to the proper use of EU funds. We call on the Commission to report on the effective merit of these measures to interrupt and suspend payments in reducing irregularities and errors. Given the economic difficulties currently faced by Member States and the insufficient resources in the EU budget, the protection of the European Union's financial interests is particularly important. As Vice-President of the Committee on Budgetary Control, I stress that EU funds must be properly managed and used in the most efficient way possible.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the 2013 Report on the Protection of the European Union's financial interests and the fight against fraud. Both the Commission and the Member States shall be obliged to make every effort to combat fraud, corruption and any other illegal activities detrimental to the financial interests of the Union, in accordance with the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I agree with the report submitted.  It should be noted that some EIB-funded projects were linked to corruption and fraud. This cannot be repeated in the future, such unfair and illegal acts must be prevented. Funding must be transparent and fair. In cases of fraud and corruption, the European Investment Bank should suspend or block any planned or ongoing financing of the project concerned. In addition, the implementation and implementation of projects proposed by Member States relating to the Structural Funds require evaluation through advanced performance audits. I believe that the policy of interruption and suspension of payments is an effective means of preventing fraud and avoiding misuse of EU funds. In view of these aspects, the Commission should report on how interruptions and suspensions of payments actually contribute to reducing the number of irregularities and errors.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The JRC voted against the report on the protection of the EU's financial interests and the fight against fraud against it, because it exploits an existing situation that is being carried, inflated and reproduced by the capitalist exploitation system itself, its own mechanisms (as it admits), to escalate the raid, particularly on taxation, against the working classes.  The report calls for the intensity and tightening of the tax-avoidance of self-employed, small VEDs, adding to the repressive structure of the EU and the European Public Prosecutor's Office, a European Union judicial mechanism, which consolidates criminal prosecution and repression throughout the EU and its Member States. Fraud against public property is reprehensible and must be punished in the strictest possible way, but the EU and its governments not only leave large business groups undisturbed, but legitimise the occupation of popular property by them with "legitimate" tax exemptions, subsidies, concessions, privatisations, immunity for what they commit against workers, with tax havens within and outside the EU based on the very EU "legitimacy" of the freedom of movement of capital guaranteed by all Euro-conditions.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for this report. In 2013, 309 million euros of fraud were uncovered. We urgently need to strengthen measures to combat these practices and support increased administrative capacity to track down these practices. With Parliament's report supporting these proposals, I have given it my support.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Ladies and gentlemen, given that the fight against fraud, corruption and money laundering in the Union must be a priority for the political action of the institutions and that police and judicial cooperation between the Member States is essential to this end. In view of the alarming increase in the number of irregularities reported as fraud in relation to EU expenditure, I voted in favour of them.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. This report shows once again that the Budgetary Organisation of the European Union is an intrinsic source of fraud and error, because of its remoteness and bureaucracy. Nearly 309 million euros have been misappropriated, of which an exorbitant share, representing 156 million euros, comes from the policy of social cohesion. The detection of these frauds mainly concerns Romania, Bulgaria, the Czech Republic and Poland, which account for almost 40% of the total fraud on the expenditure of European funds, while Italy is at the top of the ranking, with almost 68.5 million euros of embezzlement.  These fraudulent irregularities also concern non-member countries under pre-accession aid.  If we are to strengthen deterrence policies and the fight against fraud, while also protecting whistleblowers, we must guard against the old fantasy of the European Public Prosecutor's Office which would jeopardise the principle of subsidiarity, including in matters of fraud. It is up to the Member States to detect it and not to a supranational prosecutor's office. So I decided to abstain.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Given the economic difficulties currently facing Member States and the lack of resources in the EU budget, protecting the financial interests of the European Union is particularly important. In 2013, a total of 15 779 irregularities totalling around EUR 2.14 billion were reported to the Commission, of which around EUR 1.76 billion relates to expenditure of the EU budget, accounting for 1.34 % of all payments and another EUR 380 million accounting for 1.86 % of the grossly collected traditional own resources. The 2013 rate of return for fraud cases was only 23.74%, below the average level of 33.5%. Direct losses in customs revenues caused by cigarette smuggling are estimated at more than EUR 10 billion per year.  It is the obligation of both the Commission and the Member States to do their utmost to combat fraud, corruption and all other forms of illegal activity to the detriment of the Financial Interests of the Union. Protecting the EU's financial interests, together with the principle of sound financial management, should ensure that budget revenues and expenditure contribute to meeting EU priorities and objectives and building greater citizens' trust by convincing them that their money is being used in line with EU objectives and policies and in the interests of EU citizens.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support Pirinski's report because protecting the financial interests of the European Union is particularly important and the financial resources earmarked for the functioning of the EU must be properly managed and used in a fit for purpose. Investigating and reporting financial irregularities and fraud is an essential segment of the fight, and therefore this report has strong implications for further work. Detecting fraud in the COHESION policy segment of the EU budget shows the direction where funding is going in an irregular manner. The new cohesion policy planning control will prevent and reduce the risk of irregularities. In protecting and controlling revenues and expenditures, i.e. combating irregularities in spending financial resources, the most important role is played by the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF), whose further work will greatly reduce financial fraud in the EU. OLAF must be very effective and this will certainly be enhanced through enhanced and independent monitoring. The Commission's strict policy of interruptions and suspensions should also be strongly advocated. Each Member State of the Union has an obligation to appoint an Anti-Fraud Compliance Service by the end of 2014 to strengthen OLAF's cooperation with Member States.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I broadly agree with the content of the report on combating fraud, and I think it is right that the member states' behaviour on reporting fraud to OLAF (European Anti-Fraud Office) should be made homogeneous. The possible measure of rewarding those Member States that perform ly well in this fight can also be a valuable incentive.  We must promote increasingly effective and combat fraud-fighting actions, particularly when we are talking about major transnational fraud. For this reason, I believe that we need a system of efficient exchange of information between the competent authorities of the Member States and increased cooperation with third countries, all with the supervision and coordination of OLAF.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. At a time when European economies are still severely weakened by the economic and financial crisis, it is essential that the Union actively intervene in the fight against financial fraud and corruption.  The European Parliament adopted the 2013 annual report on the protection of financial interests. I have spoken in favour of this report. In particular, this text stresses the Commission's progress in combating fraud and other types of illegal activity. It also sets out the points on which the Commission needs to improve. It is necessary for the Commission to cooperate more with the Member States and to encourage a better understanding and application of financial rules.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution concerns the 2013 Annual Report on the protection of the Financial Interests of the European Union. The protection of the EU's financial interests and the principle of sound financial management should ensure that budgetary revenue and expenditure contribute to achieving the EU's priorities and objectives and increasing citizens' confidence.  According to the Report, 15779 irregularities were reported to the Commission in 2013, of which 1609 were fraudulent, involving an overall amount of EUR 2.14 billion, the recovery rate of which, in cases of fraud, was only 23.74%, below the average of 33.5% in the period 2008-2012.  I am pleased, however, that for the 2007-2013 programming period, administrative checks, on-the-spot inspections and audits have enabled a 63% rate to be achieved for the development of fraudulent irregularities.  Finally, I welcome the encouragement of enhanced cooperation between member states and the Commission and structured coordination between managing authorities and anti-fraud bodies in order to prevent and rectify non-fraudulent irregularities and combat fraud. I voted in favour.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it recognises the introduction of a wide spectrum of legal and administrative measures initiated by the committee since 2011. However, it also recognises that the lack of results in the fight against fraud is due not to the lack of regulation but to the lack of implementation of these measures. It is pressing for the Commission to take responsibility for the recovery of funds owed to the EU and should also improve the recovery process by making it faster, and the detection of these cases is also, on average, too long. The difference in VAT, for example, is continuously high leading to situations of fraud and tax escape. Finally, I believe that the Anti-Fraud Report is a valuable tool in the fight against corruption. The effectiveness of OLAF (European Anti-Fraud Organisation) needs to be urgently improved, and the quality of its recommendations should be examined by the committee overseeing it.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. The fight against fraud plays a central role in the sound management of the Union's financial interests. In 2013, the amount of fraud - alleged or established - directly related to the EU budget amounted to 309.1 million euros according to the annual report. A downward total, of course, but behind which is actually an increase in the number of cases. If all irregularities, fraudulent or not, are taken into account, this amount rises to 2.14 billion euros. This is unacceptable for the European Parliament, which has chosen to take the bull by the horns by adopting a series of anti-fraud measures: strengthening cooperation between the Commission and the Member States, combating smuggling, creating a single database for all registered irregularities, standardising administrative procedures, association of the European Parliament in negotiations on the creation of the European Prosecutor's Office and improving the effectiveness of the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF). At a time when everyone, at all levels of power, is being asked to tighten their belts, it is essential that the Union's financial interests are preserved. That is the signal that MEPs have given today.

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the protection of the EU's financial interests and the fight against fraud, as it calls on the European Commission to quickly propose legislation protecting whistleblowers. Whistleblowers play a fundamental role in our democracies (by revealing information of public interest kept secret) and must therefore be effectively protected throughout Europe.  Whistleblowers are not only bullied, they are also subject to legal proceedings. This is the case of Antoine Deltour, who is currently being prosecuted by the Luxembourg authorities for passing confidential documents to a journalist, thus revealing the "LuxLeaks" scandal.  The report also lists recommendations to tackle fraud and corruption in the EU more effectively. These actions are obviously harmful to European financial interests but also to taxpayers. Transparency and cooperation between states and the Commission are among the prerequisites for an effective fight against malfeasation in the use of EUROPEAN funds.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission and the Member States must work on coordinated action to combat corruption and any other type of fraud or illegal activity that is in any way harmful to the financial interests of the European Union. In the current context, of major economic difficulties faced by Member States, the protection of the Financial Interests of the European Union is of particular importance. It is therefore imperative that EU funds be managed properly and used as efficiently as possible.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The report contains optimism-inducing data, such as reducing the financial impact of detected irregularities, both non-fraudulent ones (38% less than in 2012) and fraudulent ones (21% less), or that for the first time cohesion policy was not the area with the highest number of fraudulent irregularities, or that most of the irregularities detected have been the case thanks to the control mechanisms provided for in EU law and not through criminal investigations. However, there has been no significant progress in the time it takes to report fraud cases. However, the implementation of the new legal and administrative measures to combat this scourge must be assessed. It is necessary to continue to combat the misuse of public money and to further analyse and propose improvements in fraud detection, prevention and prosecution systems. Moments as delicate as today, when great sacrifices are being demanded from citizens in the form of social cuts and labour precariousness, require that the European institutions be at the forefront of the fight against fraud, but also of transparency in the use of public funds. That's why I voted for it.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. The protection of the EU's financial interests and the principle of sound financial management must be the guarantor of a sound and balanced fiscal policy, capable of carrying forward those that are the priorities and objectives of the EU, in a logic of transparency and commitment to the interests of citizens. To this extent, the fight against fraud and corruption is of particular importance, both by the European institutions and by the Member States and in an articulated manner, as a means of better protecting and managing the financial interests of Europeans, within a framework of conformity with the provisions of the Treaty. I also consider it essential, like the rapporteur, that the funds unduly paid from the EU budget are recovered.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this text which provides an overview of the protection of the Union's financial interests and the fight against fraud for 2013.  The report notes that the diversity of legal and administrative systems between Member States complicates the fight against irregularities and fraud.  Among the recommendations that can be implemented is the need to strengthen cooperation and coordination between the Commission and Member States in order for financial interests to be effectively protected. For example, the Commission is being asked to create a mechanism for the exchange of information between the relevant national authorities in order to detect transnational fraud as soon as possible, in the context of the new multi-year financial framework 2014-2020. In this time of financial crisis, we must strengthen our efforts and cooperation to fight fraud.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The fight against fronds is also a problem that has been addressed at Community level. The report pushes for measures to protect the Commission's financial interests, accompanied by other rules that push States towards greater transparency. That is why I voted in favour of Mr De Clercq's report. Mr Pirinski.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote in favour because the text ,drawn up by the Committee on Budgetary Control, makes a fairly comprehensive analysis of the case studies found in the year in question and mentions the need for greater and better cooperation between the European institutions and the Member States to protect the Financial Interests of the Union (especially at this stage of economic constraints for the Member States).

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of the report on combating fraud. We think it is very important to have strict control over the use of funds from the European Union because, as public money, they must be scrupulously monitored. We think it is a good report, which criticises the role of Member States and stresses that they should take more measures to identify fraud, as well as to tighten the punishments of fraudsters. Among other things, it proposes to improve transparency both with regard to the beneficiaries of the funds and the use of them. We attach great importance to the fight against fraud and transparency, especially when it comes to public money, so this report seems to us to mark a good path to continue working on.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which responds to the European Commission's report on fraud affecting the European budget in 2013. The text calls on Member States to do more to recover EU funds lost to fraud, to tighten controls on spending on EU funds and to fight corruption more vigorously. Although 80% of EU funds are managed and spent by Member States, the Commission bears overall responsibility for the expenditure of these funds.  However, the right balance must be struck in some countries, such as France, between the fight against fraud and the discouraging bureaucratic burden of eu-employment rules on access to the European funds.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly supported the European Commission's argument that the increase in the number of frauds in 2013 is primarily an indication of a better system for monitoring and detecting irregularities in the EU. I believe, however, that much progress still needs to be made in order to ensure a uniform interpretation of the concept of 'fraud' and to harmonise olaf's fraud reporting procedures at European level. Only through more structured and effective coordination of member states' anti-fraud actions will we be able to ensure sound management of the funds and thus protect the financial interests of the European Union.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Member States and their authorities should continue their efforts and exchange best practices to ensure better coordination and assessment of cases of abuse. In addition, attention should be paid to the importance of external assistance and control in the fight against irregularities and fraud. There should be a coherent European legal framework to protect the EU's financial interests. Anti-fraud strategies recently developed by the EU are supported in this context. Irregularities, which are considered fraudulent, are often the result of insufficient knowledge of the rules or of overly complex procedures and regulations. It is therefore necessary to provide training to the staff of the bodies involved in the management of cohesion policy funds. Attempts should also be made to simplify the existing rules. In addition to the annual report on the EU's financial interests, the European institutions and Member States could carry out mid-term evaluations to check whether the new regulatory structure of cohesion policy is more preventable and reduces the risk of irregularities. States could also assess the possibility of further simplification of existing rules.  Particular attention should be paid to areas where there are a number of fraudulent irregularities. In this respect, education in the field of fraud prevention and capacity building is of the most important importance, both in public administration, among stakeholders and among civil society organisations. Clear rules should be put in place and their effective application should be pursued, as they are key to effective prevention of abuse.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in support of the annual report for 2013 on the protection of the EU's financial interests, specifically the fight against fraud.  The protection of the financial interests of the EU, together with the principle of sound financial management, should guarantee that budget revenue and expenditure contribute towards the achievement of the EU’s priorities and objectives. Furthermore, it would increase the confidence of citizens by assuring them that their money is being used in a transparent way, in full compliance with the aims and policies of the EU and in the interests of EU citizens.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. – I voted for this report. Regarding the existing economic problems in Member States, the insufficient resources in the EU budget and the importance of maintaining moral standards, there is a need to protect the financial interests of the European Union, and the report emphasises that EU funds must be properly managed and used in the most efficient way possible. However in the case of the call to establish the European Public Prosecutor’s Office, there is a need to underline the subsidiarity of the Member States.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the 2013 EU Annual Report on the Protection of EU Financial Interests, as protecting the EU's financial interests and fighting fraud should ensure that budget revenues and expenditure contribute to meeting eu priorities and objectives, but also to building growing citizens' trust. What should be borne in mind is that effective actions against corruption are only possible if criminal law measures are subjected to measures of greater transparency and accountability. This report showed that in 2013 there were 38% fewer frauds, but the number of reported irregularities increased by sixteen percent compared to the same year. Of particular interest is how cigarettes, as the most and easily trafficked product, have caused significant revenue losses for the BUDGETS of the EU and its Member States. Direct losses in customs revenues caused by cigarette smuggling are estimated at more than 10 billion euros annually. For all of the above, I consider that enhanced cooperation between Member States and the Commission is necessary to ensure appropriate measures to avoid and correct irregularities, and therefore I call on Member States to show strong political will in the fight against corruption.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. The Annual Report underlines that it is the obligation of both the Commission and the Member States to do their utmost to combat all other forms of illegal activity to the detriment of the Union's financial interests, in accordance with the provisions of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. Cooperation and coordination between the Commission and the Member States is essential to ensure effective protection of the Union's financial interests and therefore this cooperation and coordination should be strengthened and made as effective as possible. The protection of the Union's financial interests, in the area of funds and costs, requires an equal level of caution. I welcome the report for the fact that 98% of traditional own resources were raised without significant problems and reported fraudulent irregularities account for 0.29% of gross established traditional own resources (worth EUR 61 million), while non-fraudulent irregularities account for 1.57 % of traditional own resources (worth EUR 327.4 million). This report points to existing work on improving gross national income (GNI) data and issues in the ECA's special report 11/2013 that require shorter, more focused verification of GNI amounts and improved reporting and coordination on results to make the GNI system more reliable in contributed to the calculation of EU revenues.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The misuse of EU funds cannot be tolerated. Therefore I voted in favour of the report calling for a strong, unified approach to tackle fraud across European Union Member States.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - The report helps to identify which areas are most at risk of fraud by enabling more accurate identification of anti-fraud measures both at EU and national level. This year, the report is largely based on Member States' progress in developing national anti-corruption coordination services that had to be established with regard to OLAF regulation. These services aim to work closely with OLAF to jointly fight fraud. The report welcomes the Commission's efforts to protect the Financial Interests of the Union and stresses that the fight against corruption is only possible through better, more accountable and transparent cooperation between all services. I therefore support this report.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: I abstained in writing ‒ I abstained. The European Union's current efforts in the fight against fraud are by no means sufficient and fundamentally more needs to be done to actually increase the efficiency of the management of taxpayers' money.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the 2013 annual report on the protection of the EU's financial interests – the fight against fraud. Each Member State makes a proportionate contribution to the European budget, so all Member States are interested in the promotion of financial interests. It should be noted that it is not only fraud, but a great deal of irregularity also occurs because of the lack of knowledge of the rules and the complexity of the legislation. Therefore, sanctions should also be accompanied by other measures that will equip Member States with the knowledge that they can reduce the number of irregularities not resulting from fraud in the future. I also supported the report because the protection of the EU's financial interests is a very important topic.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 It is clear that MS and, by extension, the EU are facing increased losses of lost revenue from their budgets, thus carrying the burden of the crisis on societies. However, in the report, unfortunately, the report and analysis of the causes and sources of fraud and corruption is rudimentary and the problem essentially focuses on the increased number of irregularities. The ACPL and the Group of the European United Left are very strongly in favour of combating tax evasion and combating fraud in order to improve the state's ability to raise revenue.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The determination of minimum and higher prison sentences planned to be imposed on all participating Member States is a major blow to the sovereign rights of each Member State.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the 2013 Annual Report on the Protection of the European Union's Financial Interests – The Fight Against Fraud. I, too, consider it important that fraud detection be carried out as efficiently and quickly as possible, as this is a legitimate expectation of European citizens. Nevertheless, I would also like to underline that, although one of the very important reasons for VAT fraud or vat avoidance is overtrawing in this area in some Member States. The Commission should also pay particular attention to this when using its powers to support member states' fight against vat losses by all means.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. However, I would like to underline our concern about the threats still to the EU budget, which result from both non-compliance (non-fraudulent irregularities) and wilful offences or criminal acts (fraud). Enhanced cooperation between Member States and the Commission is needed to adopt appropriate and sufficient measures and means to prevent and rectify non-fraudulent irregularities and combat fraud.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The recent LuxLeaks case demonstrated the need to tackle tax fraud in the EU more effectively. I voted in favour of the Commission annual report for 2013 on the protection of the EU's financial interests and urge the Member States to cooperate and coordinate with the Commission on the matter. In 2013, 15 779 irregularities were reported to the Commission, involving about 2.14 billion euros, and I find the growing trend alarming. Many policy sectors are affected by fraud, and I call on the Commission to establish uniform reporting principles in all Member States so as to collect comparable and accurate data.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report on combating fraud. We think it is very important to have strict control over the use of funds from the European Union because, as public money, it must be controlled scrupulously. We think it is a good report, which criticises the role of Member States and stresses that they should put in more measures to detect fraud, as well as to tighten the punishments of fraudsters. Among other things, it proposes to improve transparency with respect to both the beneficiaries of the funds and their use. We attach great importance to the fight against fraud and transparency, especially when it comes to public money, so it seems to us that this report marks a good path to continue working on.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. The report shows that there is still a long way to go to achieve proper protection of the EU's financial interests. In particular, I am referring to the need for a policy of transparency which remains deficient, both as regards the financing provided by the EIB and in the traceability of transactions in European funds. I am pleased that our amendment on the issue of the Mestre Passer-by has been adopted: we want to show that we are at the forefront of those who are fighting for 'healthy' and transparent spending.  The EIB is demonstrating that it does not protect investment from abuse and the tentacles of organised crime. In this respect, I am concerned that the new Junker plan does not seem to take these problems into account, and I would remind you that an appropriate transparency policy can make supervision effective. We call on the Member States to make an additional effort to protect and use transparent European funds, and we call on the Commission to create an effective network of law and protection.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution on the 2013 Annual Report on the Protection of the EU's Financial Interests – Combating Fraud because it contains important criticisms of current European anti-fraud policy and includes new proposals that are interesting and could contribute to ending this scourge, such as the homogenisation and improvement of fraud control and data collection mechanisms in different States , the assumption of responsibility by the Commission for the withdrawal of fraudulently used European funds, the homogenisation of the definitions of the different offences and the penalties applicable, or transparency measures aimed at knowing details of the entities and projects receiving European funds. Although I reject the proposal for the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office and have a critical opinion on the work done by Eurojust, I believe that these proposals can be an impetus for the fact that the numerous cases of fraud, many of which have been carried out with the complicity of administrations, are actually criminalized in a proportionate and homogeneous manner , when not directly by themselves.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 We have stressed the importance of combating fraud and all kinds of irregularities. Anything that can ensure the correct use of EU funds should be valued, as should all measures that improve the collection of EU own revenue. We have seen a decrease in occurrences, although we have an increase in the funds involved. However, the temptation to fall into some sensationalism should be avoided, creating a criminal framework, when in fact and in round numbers, 14 of the 15 000 irregularities have already been regarded as non-fraudulent.
