Only those who walk on the ground have the scale of the complexity of all the application processes for European funds. Assuming that there are fraudulent cases that deserve treatment to be treated, we believe that the figures should give rise to our reflection on ways in which we can improve administrative and bureaucratic contours.  Another very different thing is the European Union's own resources. In this field, the EU, like most countries, is a victim of the globalisation processes it has created and which facilitate all sorts of schemes designed to evade tax payments. Yes, means should be examined, and also a lot of political will to combat this type of crime.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. I believe that the protection of the EU's financial interests and the fight against fraud are worthy of support. On the one hand, it is to be welcomed that irregularities or errors in the proper use of EU funds must be averted. On the other hand, the report mentions both OLAF's weak intelligence rate and the attempt to call for a European public prosecutor. Since the text could have been formulated much more sharply, and on the basis of the facts I have already mentioned, I abstained.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 Sound financial management is intended to guarantee the achievement of the EU's objectives and to reassure EU citizens of the transparent use of the European budget. In view of the economic problems of the Member States, the protection of the EU's financial interests is extremely important. Fraudulent mechanisms caused by non-compliance with the rules by individual Member States, such as the submission of inaccurate data and corruption, pose threats to the EU budget. We must therefore strengthen cooperation between the Member States and the Commission, especially between police and judicial authorities.  The Commission should establish a mechanism for the exchange of information between the national competent institutions in order to allow comparisons of accounting records between Member States in order to detect any transnational fraud.  The Commission should also ensure transparency, for example by providing reliable data on EU funds managed by Member States. In fact, some Member States do not take appropriate action against fraud, they only take corrective measures without investigating a criminal offence or penally sanctioning those responsible.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The JRC voted against the report on the protection of the EU's financial interests and the fight against fraud against it, because it exploits an existing situation that is being carried, inflated and reproduced by the capitalist exploitation system itself, its own mechanisms (as it admits), to escalate the raid, particularly on taxation, against the working classes.  The report calls for the intensity and tightening of the tax-avoidance of self-employed, small VEDs, adding to the repressive structure of the EU and the European Public Prosecutor's Office, a European Union judicial mechanism, which consolidates criminal prosecution and repression throughout the EU and its Member States. Fraud against public property is reprehensible and must be punished in the strictest way, but the EU and its governments not only leave large business groups in a state of crisis, but legitimise the occupation of popular property by them with "legitimate" tax exemptions, subsidies, concessions, privatisations, immunity for what they commit against workers, with tax havens within and outside the EU based on the very EU "legitimacy" of the freedom of movement of capital guaranteed by all Euro-conditions.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Each year, the European Commission makes an own-initiative report on the protection of the Financial Interests of the European Union, which includes the latest information on irregularities and cases of suspected fraud reported by member states. This report places an impact on the reporting and reporting of non-fraudulent and fraudulent irregularities with regard to both expenditure and revenue (from traditional own resources) of the EU budget. We agree that establishing a framework for cooperation between the different Member States, which aims to share experiences and best practices, could be an added value in combating corruption at country level. However, we consider it negative that such a measure should be seen as an embryo, serve to promote or fit the more general objective of developing the so-called "area of freedom, security and justice", namely the harmonisation of justice at European level.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Montenegro has made undoubted progress in the negotiations for accession to the European Union. Sixteen negotiating chapters have now been opened, while those on science and research and education and culture have been provisionally included.  The Montenegrin Government has been proactively involved in the process of regional reconciliation and has the merit of aligning itself with the European Union's foreign and security policy, which is very important, especially in view of the current situation of international terrorist threats. Montenegro must therefore be given the acknowledgeable fact that it has made important improvements, which bode well for the continuation of the negotiations. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – In view of the fact that Montenegro's accession negotiations for EU accession only started in 2012 and that it has opened sixteen of the thirty-five chapters to date and closed two even temporarily, it can be said that they are the most successful candidate in the circle who want to join the European Union. Reform efforts in certain economic areas, and the competitiveness of the small economy, are already bringing positive results in more efficient administrative procedures, and we must continue decisively, and thus the country will also set an example for the other candidate Member States. In Montenegro, too, the fundamental problems that are in fact typical of the countries in this area remain: corruption and organised crime, too little progress in respect of human rights, a lack of independence of media space and justice. These are all areas that are dragging the whole region down. I want a better standard for the people of Montenegro and, therefore, a better life, but that does not mean that they will also have to rise to a certain moral standard in society.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – I supported the proposed report because it rightly assesses Montenegro's progress towards accession to the European Union. Of course, it highlights the weaknesses. They are partly related to freedom of speech, to media ownership. Of course, there are issues that should also be clarified with the Republic of Croatia, but in general Montenegro is the model and the first in the Balkans in the implementation of European norms in practice.  Not to mention that Montenegro has absolute unanimity and absolute agreement with the Common European Policy on the Crisis in Ukraine, with regard to anti-terrorist legislation related to Islamic State. And of course it has to do with its legislation for individuals from its territory who would participate in illegal fighting associated with The Islamic State. That is why I supported this report, and it greatly appreciates Montenegro's progress. Good luck to them.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I supported the adoption of the Resolution on Montenegro's Progress for 2014, as it recognises the efforts made in several segments, but also clearly states the problems facing Montenegro and which need to be further addressed in the coming period. In particular, I would emphasise those parts relating to negotiating chapters 23 and 24 to which Montenegro should be given particular attention, relating to the establishment of the rule of law, the establishment of an effective and impartial judiciary, the fight against corruption, media freedom, the establishment of good public governance and transparency in the financing of political parties, and ensuring that all war criminals are brought to justice and ensure that all victims of war are indemnity. This is primarily where I think about Croatia.  I also believe that the resolution also referred to the necessity of creating an atmosphere of tolerance and inclusion of all national minorities with an emphasis on the need for montenegrin authorities to protect the multinational identity of Boka Kotorska and to strengthen cultural and economic cooperation with neighbouring member states of the European Union.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. The Resolution congratulates Montenegro on the progress made so far and notes that sixteen negotiating chapters have been opened and that two (science and research, education and culture) have already been provisionally closed. It encourages the continuation of accession negotiations on the basis of reforms carried out, particularly in the areas of the rule of law, freedom of expression and the fight against corruption. Our S&D Group tabled amendments on anti-discrimination, the Roma minority, women and children's rights, the rights of persons with disabilities and other social issues. Most of these amendments were adopted or included in the commitments.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because it maintains the line of Parliament's views on the candidate countries, in which a colonial relationship between a rich and powerful centre is reproduced in the face of an impoverished and obedient periphery. The policy of enlargement, as this Resolution demonstrates, consists of a cast of neoliberal proposals and, in this particular case, submission to American interests, since it expressly calls for Montenegro's membership in NATO.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – While there were a number of issues highlighted in this report that I welcome, such as the need to tackle corruption, protect the independence of the judiciary and of the media and the need to tackle impunity in war crimes cases, among others, I believe this report should have been stronger on human rights issues in the country. Although it mentioned issues such as women's rights, gender equality, LGBTI rights etc., it did so briefly and failed to express the importance to society of addressing systemic discrimination in these areas. Significantly, in paragraph 22 the report commends Montenegro's role in the "process of regional reconciliation", while, in the same paragraph, " invites relevant EU Member States to consider accelerating Montenegro's NATO accession process in order to enhance regional stability". I do not believe the expansion of NATO is consistent with either regional reconciliation or regional stability, and I oppose the call for EU Member States to facilitate or encourage NATO expansion. For these reasons I voted against this report.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. The European Union wants to impose its standards and political system on a third state, even though it is not a member. It is not the Union's responsibility to interfere in the internal affairs of a sovereign state, let alone when it is not a member of the Union. The recommendation for propaganda campaigns to "change attitudes" is a significant example of this interference. So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ It is consistent for a UKIP MEP to vote against this report because our philosophy is that the UK should be able to negotiate its own relationship with Montenegro. Such a bespoke agreement would be better than one negotiated for us, compromising over the needs of the 28 European Union countries.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to assess the montenegro's progress report. Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Kosovo, the former Yugoslav Republic and Serbia are the six countries of the Western Balkans applying for EU membership. Of these applicants, two are already negotiating EU membership, both Montenegro and Serbia. Albania and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia have the status of official candidates, while Bosnia and Herzegovina and Kosovo are considered potential candidates. The progress of all these candidates for EU accession varies, with many indicators lagging behind EU members. The main problems are high unemployment rates, corruption and restrictions on freedom of the press.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. Once again, the European Union, which has specialised in moral lessons, which it distributes to the whole world, "urges political actors and civil society to combat widespread hostility against sexual diversity, in particular through measures to educate and inform the public in order to contribute to the evolution of mentalities". This report is also characterized by a deplorable desire to interfere in the Montenegrin legislative process, as well as in foreign policy choices. That is why I voted against Mr Tannock's report.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The proposal sets out certain procedures for adopting concrete modalities for the implementation of certain provisions of the Stabilization and Association Agreement with Montenegro. In particular, it provides that fish products originating in Montenegro can be imported into the EU, within tariff quotas, at reduced customs rates. It is therefore necessary to establish provisions regulating the management of these tariff quotas.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This follow-up report on Montenegro, which is only a progress report, must assess Montenegro's progress towards its future accession to the European Union. 16 chapters have already been validated. Nevertheless, it is undeniable that Montenegro suffers from recurring evils that plague its economy: organized crime, corruption, trafficking... Moreover, attacks on freedom of expression and the media are recurrent in this country, and this report makes a similar observation.  In view of these elements, it is more than urgent that the "eurobenates" simply stop noticing the situation and react by immediately halting the process of Montenegro's accession to the European Union, since Europe no longer has the financial means to welcome new states into its membership. So I voted against that proposal.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the positions defended by the Resolution that partially analyses the lack of progress made by Montenegro as a pre-accession country and for this reason I did not support it with my vote.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I've abstained. However, I see problems with the market-liberal policies imposed on the country by the EU without particular attention to social consequences. I also think it is wrong for the EU to act in favour of Montenegro's accession to NATO.  I would like to underline the importance of giving the people of Montenegro the right to express their views on both the accession process to the EU and on the issue of NATO membership, by referendum. It is the people of Montenegro who should decide for themselves whether or not they want them to belong to the EU and NATO.  That is why I am abstaining on this report.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report congratulating Montenegro on the progress made so far, noting that, provisionally, sixteen negotiating chapters have been opened and two (science and research and education and culture) have been closed. At the same time, accession negotiations are encouraged to continue on the basis of reforms, particularly in the areas of the rule of law, freedom of expression and the fight against corruption. On the other hand, from my group we have draw attention to aspects relating to anti-discrimination measures, Roma minority, women and children's rights, rights of persons with disabilities and other social issues, which have mostly been incorporated into the final text.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, in which the European Parliament evaluates montenegro's progress report for 2014. Parliament welcomes the progress made by Montenegro in implementing reforms aimed at ensuring the independence and efficiency of the judiciary, but calls for substantial reforms in the areas of appointment, promotion and disciplinary procedures of judges and prosecutors. There are concerns about the limited progress made in the fight against corruption, which, despite the considerable financial resources allocated by international donors to public authorities, remains a threat to the proper functioning and stability of democratic institutions, the rule of law and economic development. The European Parliament also stresses the need to improve consultations with civil society organisations in order to increase the transparency of policy-making and legislative implementation and to ensure the openness of these processes. It should also be emphasised that progress in women's rights, gender equality, women's proportions in politics and the labour market and in the fight against domestic violence remains limited. There is therefore an urgent need to accelerate progress in the areas of women's rights, gender equality, women's proportions in politics and the labour market and the fight against domestic violence.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ It is evident that Montenegro is on the right track and this reflects this report. The country has made certain steps forward in the fight against corruption, but it is necessary to ensure greater independence for the judiciary and show political will to systematically investigate, prosecute and punish corruption regardless of the political background and the position of the perpetrators.  The judiciary and prosecution are most effectively fighting corruption when given maximum autonomy and independence from political structures. I say this from the perspective of Croatia, which has shown in recent years that there are no untouchables in front of the judiciary. Eu influence and pressure has been key in this regard. Free and independent media also play a key role in the fight against corruption, as well as the democratisation of society in general. Finally, I call on the Montenegrin government to do more to promote minority rights.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (NI)
text: In writing. Montenegro became a candidate country in 2012. This is the third report for this country. Negotiations may take longer than expected. The Prime Minister even raised the possibility of stopping the talks last November. Two negotiating chapters are closed and ten new chapters are open. For the European Commission, the country continues to meet political conditions. I do not see what the LGBT issue is doing in the debate. In addition, Montenegro has been criticized for its politicized justice and endemic corruption.  I voted against this resolution, which requires Montenegro to adopt a system and policy dictated by Brussels.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ While there were a number of issues highlighted in this report that I welcome, such as the need to tackle corruption, protect the independence of the judiciary and of the media and the need to tackle impunity in war crimes cases, among others, I believe this report should have been stronger on human rights issues in the country. Although it mentioned issues such as women's rights, gender equality, LGBTI rights etc., it did so briefly and failed to express the importance to that society of addressing systemic discrimination in these areas. Significantly, in paragraph 22 the report commends Montenegro's role in the "process of regional reconciliation", while, in the same paragraph, "invites relevant EU Member States to consider accelerating Montenegro's NATO accession process in order to enhance regional stability". I do not believe the expansion of NATO is consistent with either regional reconciliation or regional stability, and I oppose the call for EU Member States to facilitate or encourage NATO expansion. For these reasons I voted against this report.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. The 2014 follow-up report on Montenegro highlights the country's shortcomings in the fight against organised crime, corruption and trafficking of all kinds. Opposed in principle to any further enlargement of the European Union, and noting the deplorable state of freedom of expression and the press in that country, I call for the suspension of the accession process with Montenegro and all the financial payments that result from it.  So I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the 2014 report on Montenegro's progress, because Montenegro has opened negotiating chapters with the European Union and expects that this candidate state will be assessed on its own merits, that any other candidate State, as well as the achievement of accession preparation progress, will be based on increased dialogue with the European Union. This resolution wishes to emphasise that Montenegro has made progress in implementing reforms that guarantee the independence and efficiency of the legal system, but also stresses that there is a polarised internal political climate. In this context, the Montenegrin government could focus on the state's accession agenda to the European Union and commit to a sustainable dialogue for constructive cooperation. Active participation of civil society, as well as active parliamentary scrutiny, are essential to ensure the inclusive nature of the reform process in the negotiations and the European integration process.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. The Resolution congratulates Montenegro on the progress made so far and notes that sixteen negotiating chapters have been opened and that two (science and research, education and culture) have already been provisionally closed. It encourages the continuation of accession negotiations on the basis of reforms carried out, particularly in the areas of the rule of law, freedom of expression and the fight against corruption. Our S&D Group tabled amendments on anti-discrimination, the Roma minority, women and children's rights, the rights of persons with disabilities and other social issues. Most of these amendments were adopted or included in the commitments.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the 2014 progress report on Montenegro because I believe it has made undoubted progress in the negotiations for accession to the European Union.  Sixteen negotiating chapters have now been opened, while those on science and research and education and culture have been provisionally concluded. The Montenegrin Government has also been proactively involved in the process of regional reconciliation and has the merit of aligning itself with the EU's common foreign and security policy, which is very important, especially in view of the current situation of international terrorist threat.  Montenegro must therefore be given the acknowledgeable fact that it has made important improvements which bode well for the continuation of the negotiations. However, I believe that further progress and reform is needed. I am thinking in particular of improving the rule of law, which is a fundamental prerequisite for EU membership and the assumption of its obligations, and the fight against corruption and organised crime.  I would also like to stress that dialogue and constructive cooperation between the government and the opposition in Montenegro must be strengthened in order to make shared progress in the preparations for accession to the European Union.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ While there were a number of issues highlighted in this report that I welcome, such as the need to tackle corruption, protect the independence of the judiciary and of the media and the need to tackle impunity in war crimes cases, among others, I believe this report should have been stronger on human rights issues in the country. Although it mentioned issues such as women's rights, gender equality, LGBTI rights etc., it did so briefly and failed to express the importance to society of addressing systemic discrimination in these areas. Significantly, in paragraph 22 the report commends Montenegro's role in the "process of regional reconciliation", while, in the same paragraph, "invites relevant EU Member States to consider accelerating Montenegro's NATO accession process in order to enhance regional stability". I do not believe the expansion of NATO is consistent with either regional reconciliation or regional stability, and I oppose the call for EU Member States to facilitate or encourage NATO expansion. For these reasons I voted against this report.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Parliament resolution takes stock of the Commission's 2014 progress report on Montenegro. Parliament welcomes the progress made by Montenegro in its accession negotiation process by opening sixteen chapters and provisionally closing two. While commending the legislative progress achieved with regard to the rule of law, the media environment and the fight against corruption, it adds that more needs to be done on the ground. Parliament is concerned that due to the deeply polarised domestic climate the main opposition party has boycotted some parliamentary sessions. In this vein, Parliament encourages sustainable dialogue and constructive cooperation, especially within parliament, and urges all political parties to focus their energy on the country's EU accession. Whilst Parliament commended Montenegro for its pro-active participation and constructive role in regional and international cooperation and regional reconciliation, it is encouraged to address the outstanding bilateral issues with its neighbouring countries as early as possible in the negotiation process. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 As I have already said in this House, I am very much in favour of Montenegro joining the European Union. However, I strongly reiterate that the very strong tourist vocation of the entire Adriatic region must be protected and I hope that the continuation of the accession negotiations will enable us to deal with the environmental issue in practice.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. It was impossible for me to vote in favour of a text which is a real violation of the sovereignty of the Montenegrin people.  Montenegro is thus called to adopt the policies dictated by Brussels, even to the detriment of the national democratic game: "is concerned that the profound polarization of the country has resulted in a boycott of parliamentary work by the opposition, which hinders progress in reform efforts". Montenegrin parliamentarians are therefore asked to obey the commandments of the European Union, and so be it for democratic pluralism. A shameful muzzling that I could only dispute.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The State of Montenegro is currently the country that has provisionally concluded several negotiation procedures with the European Union. The measure before us highlights the efforts that the State of Montenegro has made to achieve reforms in the field of justice, public administration, anti-discrimination and, finally, the cooperation agreement with Eurojust and Europol. In addition, the measure calls for a greater commitment on the part of the State to effectively reform the information sector in view of the lack of communicative transparency. Greater active involvement of civil society calls for the measure. I have chosen to vote in favour of the measure as set out above.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure because it recognises montenegro's efforts and the important reforms already carried out; These including judicial reform, the focus on the organisation of public administration, the anti-discrimination law and the signing of a cooperation agreement with Europol and Eurojust. However, I am aware that serious problems still remain in certain areas that are of crucial importance and for which Montenegro is strongly called upon to remedy them, such as a stable and effective legal system, transparent information, the inclusion of civil society in the decision-making process and a serious commitment against corruption; these are the objectives suggested by the Commission as steps towards the process of rapprochement with the European Union.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I stress the quality and accuracy of Mr Tannock's report on montenegro's developments as a candidate for accession to the European Union. It is indisputable that, in many of the valences, Montenegro is evolving positively, which confirms the value of EU enlargement as a tool to enable economic growth and the consolidation of democracy in the candidate countries. The report also highlights areas of concern, such as limitations on freedom of expression and the media, the poor functioning of various state institutions (such as parliament and the judicial system, among others). Since I maintain a prudent reserve position on further enlargement (I believe that there is still some time left for the EU to digest the latest enlargements), I abstain in its vote.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Commission's report on Montenegro. It recognises the efforts made by the State and the important reforms already carried out; These including judicial reform, the focus on the organisation of public administration, the anti-discrimination law and the signing of a cooperation agreement with Europol and Eurojust. However, serious problems remain in certain areas which the European Union considers to be of crucial importance and for which Montenegro is strongly called upon to remedy them. A stable and effective legal system, transparent information, the inclusion of civil society in the decision-making process and a serious commitment to combating corruption are some of the objectives suggested by the Commission as steps towards the process of rapprochement with the European Union. I also consider the foreign policy aspects included in this report to be very important, especially in view of Montenegro's decision to take part in European, NATO and UN missions. In addition to an increasingly strong alignment with the EU's foreign policy, the country is asked to resolve rapidly the outstanding issues with neighbouring countries in a spirit of good neighbourliness and cooperation, aspects from which the access process cannot ignore.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the progress made in the accession negotiations. The adoption of anti-corruption laws, particularly on lobbying, general administrative procedure, public procurement and amendments to the laws on the prevention of conflicts of interest are important steps toward accession. I am concerned about media freedom and the weak professional and ethical standards among media practitioners in Montenegro. Strong political commitment is essential for the deep and lasting political reforms necessary to strengthen the rule of law.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe that important steps have been taken towards democratisation in Montenegro. The constitutional and legislative framework is moving towards the Community framework. Much effort has been made, but much remains to be done, particularly in the fight against corruption. I believe that it is essential to open up the EEA to the Balkan countries. I welcome what Montenegro has done so far in terms of cooperation with the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution which commends Montenegro on the progress achieved so far, noting that sixteen negotiating chapters have been opened and two provisionally closed. It encourages the continuation of the accession negotiations on the basis of implemented reforms, particularly in the fields of the rule of law, freedom of expression, and the fight against corruption.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This resolution takes note of the European Commission's progress report on progress in the EU enlargement negotiations in Montenegro, which was granted candidate status in 2010. At present, the 2014 follow-up report published by the European Commission shows that sixteen chapters have been opened for negotiation and that two chapters, on science and research, on the one hand, and education and culture, on the other, have been closed. It is necessary for further efforts to be made, as the report clearly shows that this country is still far from meeting all the necessary criteria for accession. This will not be the case for many years. Considering all these elements, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. With this resolution, we wished to encourage Montenegro in its establishment of a rule of law, democratic and with an independent and effective judiciary. We welcomed his proactive role in the region while encouraging him to quickly resolve the conflicts that might exist between the various political parties. The European Union has opened several negotiating chapters for Montenegro's future accession, but at present only two have been provisionally closed, making accession uncertain and very distant.  I would like to reiterate, however, that in line with my campaign promises, I will remain careful that the European Union does not make further enlargements in the coming years. We need a lasting pause in the enlargement of the European Union, it is not negotiable.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. – I am pleased that the European Parliament has adopted a balanced decision on Montenegro. I believe that the document presents realistically the current situation in the country. It contains the shortcomings and problems that Montenegro is facing, such as corruption, organised crime, the sometimes lack of the rule of law, restrictions on freedom of the press, but at the same time it is very important that the decision commends and highlights the positives that the Montenegrin Government has already taken, for example in the area of reforms and legislation, that 16 accession chapters have already been opened to bring their foreign and security policies into line with those of the European Union.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the motion for a resolution because, apart from the fact that the intended enlargement of the EU will exacerbate the economic crisis plaguing the countries of the South, the report favours Montenegro's participation in NATO.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution, which confirms the Commission's comments on Montenegro. In my opinion, Montenegro is on track to join, although they can achieve even better results through sustainable dialogue and constructive cooperation between the government and the opposition. I urge political leaders to stand firm in favour of the reforms required by EU accession. Montenegro is the only country in the region that opens and temporarily closes negotiating chapters with the EU. I agree that this leadership represents greater responsibility both at regional level and in the enlargement process as a whole. I welcome the opening of the 16 chapters and the temporary closure of two.  As regards foreign policy, Montenegro was the only candidate country in the Western Balkans region that fully identified with the UNION's positions and decisions on Ukraine. The country's accession to NATO should be encouraged.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the fact that Montenegro is currently the only country in the region to have opened and provisionally closed negotiating chapters with the EU. However, the country must develop an irreprehensible track record on the rule of law, a fundamental precondition for EU membership, and to fulfil the obligations arising from membership. The continuation of accession negotiations on the basis of the reforms implemented and the concrete results achieved, in particular in the area of the rule of law, the environment surrounding the media and the fight against corruption, is crucial, as well as the strengthening by the Montenegrin government of intrainstitutional coordination and the fight against corruption and organised crime , which are a litmus test for the independence, efficiency and professionalism of the judicial system.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This motion for a resolution presents a wide range of considerations on montenegro's eu integration process. Far beyond the evaluation of the process, the resolution points to a wide range of impositions for membership, which confirm the extent of the interference and loss of sovereignty imposed on countries and peoples in the process of EU membership.  Among others, particular reference should be given to meddling in the economic, judicial and political system, the advanced foreign and security policy guidelines, including the country's membership of NATO, integrated into the militarisation of the EU and the enlargement of influence in the Balkans, among others. Recognizing and respecting the right of each country and of each people to decide sovereignly on whether or not they belong to the European Union, we cannot fail to condemn strongly this unacceptable stance of imposition of models of economic and social organisation, especially since these models that want to be imposed have already revealed to satiety their devastating consequences either from an economic point of view – especially for the weakest and least developed economies – either from the point of view of social view. For these reasons we voted against.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ In the Balkans region, Montenegro is currently the only state that manages to conclude negotiating chapters with the European Union. However, as with the other candidate countries in its history, there are also weaknesses that we have brought to Montenegro in the assessment in question. This is particularly the issue of borders with the Member State of the European Union Croatia, which we are asking to address at the International Court of Justice in The Hague, as well as improving progress in the areas of women's rights, gender equality, women's representation in the labour market, where we call on Montenegro to put in place the necessary measures and make changes. Last but not least, we call on Montenegro to make progress on the environment and climate change by strengthening administrative capacity and promoting an ecological economic model.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report as I do not share the political will behind the proposal.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the motion for a resolution on the 2014 progress report on Montenegro, as, in addition to the fact that the intended enlargement of the EU will exacerbate the economic crisis plaguing the countries of the South, the report favours Montenegro's participation in NATO.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As stated by the Commission, more efforts need to be made by the Montenegrin Government to combat corruption, fight organised crime, ensure transparent elections and reform the judiciary. Moreover, the Montenegrin Government must also ensure that recent attacks on journalists are promptly investigated and that urgent prosecutions follow. However, I believe, considering the progress that Montenegro has made since embarking upon accession negotiations, that these negotiations should not slow down if Montenegro succeeds in acting upon the recommendations of the Commission. I welcome last week’s statement by Prime Minister Milo Đukanović regarding the admission of Montenegro to the NATO alliance, the further progress made by the country in establishing a functioning market economy, and the Commission’s conclusion that Montenegro meets the political criteria for EU membership. All this has to be praised.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. Montenegro is undoubtedly a reference partner for the EU in the Balkan area, and is the only country in the region that has provisionally opened and closed negotiating chapters with the EU. Montenegro has achieved important objectives for the sake of integration into the EU, but it still has a long way to go, so I encourage the authorities of the Republic of Montenegro to continue their work in consolidating the rule of law and basic freedoms.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. The Resolution congratulates Montenegro on the progress made so far and notes that sixteen negotiating chapters have been opened and that two (science and research, education and culture) have already been provisionally closed. It encourages the continuation of accession negotiations on the basis of reforms carried out, particularly in the areas of the rule of law, freedom of expression and the fight against corruption. Our S&D Group tabled amendments on anti-discrimination, the Roma minority, women and children's rights, the rights of persons with disabilities and other social issues. Most of these amendments were adopted or included in the commitments.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. The Resolution congratulates Montenegro on the progress made so far and notes that sixteen negotiating chapters have been opened and that two (science and research, education and culture) have already been provisionally closed. It encourages the continuation of accession negotiations on the basis of reforms carried out, particularly in the areas of the rule of law, freedom of expression and the fight against corruption. Our S&D Group tabled amendments on anti-discrimination, the Roma minority, women and children's rights, the rights of persons with disabilities and other social issues. Most of these amendments were adopted or included in the commitments.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which commends Montenegro on the progress achieved so far. It encourages continuation of the accession negotiations on the basis of reforms implemented, particularly in the fields of the rule of law, freedom of expression, and the fight against corruption.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour, in order to facilitate the development of this country with the help of the European Institutions.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported montenegro's 2014 progress report, as the resolution includes the main preconditions for the further resumption of negotiations, including the main problems that exist in Montenegro in certain areas and are important for EU entry. It is especially important to me that the resolution highlights the question of the future continuation of Montenegro's accession process to NATO with the aim of increasing security in the Adriatic, where all other NATO member states are already. The resolution calls for a negotiated resolution of border issues with the Republic of Croatia, and proposes the International Court of Justice in The Hague in case the dispute is unable to resolve the dispute.  Among other things, the resolution calls for further development of negotiating structures, calls for civil society involvement in the reform process, but also highlights concerns about the division in society that resulted in a boycott of work in parliament by some opposition parties. For Montenegro, continuing public sector reforms, strengthening the capacity of the Ombudsman's Office to combat discrimination, is important. Despite all the problems with the functioning of the judiciary, the development of a new judicial reform strategy in 2014-2018 is important. Progress aimed at ensuring independence and increasing the efficiency of the judiciary should be welcomed. It is also important to highlight Montenegro's policies aimed at greater tolerance and strengthening minority rights.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the 2014 follow-up report on Montenegro. This report takes stock of the accession negotiations between the European Union and Montenegro, pointing to progress but also expressing concerns on certain issues, such as freedom of the press.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the 2014 follow-up report on Montenegro. The report outlines progress in negotiations between the European Union and Montenegro as part of the enlargement policy. A candidate since 2010, Montenegro is the only country in the region to temporarily open and close negotiating chapters with the EU. However, many challenges remain.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the progress achieved by Montenegro on the path to EU accession and encourage continuation of EU- related reforms. Montenegro should now focus on reforms relating to the rule of law, the improvement of public administration and increasing transparency within the political system. I continue to strongly support the aspirations of the Western Balkan countries to engage in European reforms and to become EU members themselves. The process of integration will strengthen the democratic institutions of those countries, modernise their economies and thus improve the lives of citizens. Labour Party Members and the S&D Group will be sure to keep enlargement high on the EU’s political agenda.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – Year after year we read success stories about Montenegro, which has significantly better results than many former Yugoslav regions or Albania. The European Union is constantly in crisis economically, financially and socially, so the two standards are rapidly approaching each other. Of course, it is up to the Montenegrots to see what kind of regional cooperation they are oriented towards, where they want to join. Of course, they still don't know, they're not moving towards their economic ascension, they're moving towards total colonialism.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of the resolution on Montenegro's progress as it reflects the need to encourage accession negotiations on the basis of the results achieved so far. Montenegro has already provisionally closed a number of negotiating chapters with the European Union, and the progress made so far in this process suggests positive aspects for the process of European integration.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. In terms of European Neighbourhood Policy, I voted in favour of the resolution on Montenegro's progress. The 2014 monitoring report for that country demonstrates Montenegro's full alignment with the European Union's common security and defence policy, but also points out that much progress still needs to be made to combat corruption, ensure the independence of the judiciary and guarantee freedom of expression and the media.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the follow-up report on Montenegro, because this resolution wants to impose on Montenegro a system and policy dictated by Brussels, and demonstrates the harmful ideology of continuous enlargement. All this is not in the interest of the citizens of the Member States, nor of those of Montenegro. The objective of bringing Montenegro into NATO is openly stated in paragraph 38 of the resolution. Paragraph 37 "congratulates the Government on the fact that Montenegro, together with Albania, is the only country applying to join the Union in the Western Balkans to have fully brought its legislation into line with the European Union's decisions and positions on the situation in Ukraine."

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it constitutes interference in the internal affairs of a sovereign state. It wants to impose a policy dictated by the European Union.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because it maintains the line of Parliament's views on the candidate countries, in which a colonial relationship between a rich and powerful centre is reproduced in the face of an impoverished and obedient periphery. The policy of enlargement, as this Resolution demonstrates, consists of a cast of neoliberal proposals and, in this particular case, submission to American interests, since it expressly calls for Montenegro's membership in NATO.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The Socialists and Democrats in Parliament welcome the adoption of the reports on Serbia, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (FYROM), Montenegro and Kosovo, and call on the Commission and the Council to show renewed EU commitment to the Western Balkans enlargement process.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on the 2014 progress report on Montenegro, as Greece supports Montenegro's European perspective and has signed a cooperation agreement on the provision of know-how in European Union matters since 2011.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. Voted against this proposal. Indeed, this resolution constitutes interference in the affairs of a third country by requiring Montenegro to adopt a system and policy dictated by the European Union. We are against this overt interference.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report which is concerned about the backlog of cases pending before the Constitutional Court, in particular those relating to the possible systematic violation of human rights, such as the initiative to examine the constitutionality of the Law on Misdemeanours.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the 2014 progress report on Montenegro. There are many positive points, such as the commitment to implement reforms aimed at ensuring the independence and greater efficiency of the judiciary. There are priorities on which serious and constant work is needed: firstly, results with regard to the establishment of the rule of law, which is a fundamental prerequisite for EU membership, as well as an essential condition for the progress of the accession negotiations itself. More efforts are needed to combat war crimes-related impunity seriously. It is also important to emphasise that frequent legislative changes can actually make it difficult to combat organised crime effectively by slowing down the system. Finally, as has rightly been pointed out, we need a greater commitment to women's rights, with a serious fight against domestic violence, to be repressed in every way.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Montenegro is currently the only country in the region that opens and provisionally concludes negotiating chapters with the EU, which I welcome, noting that sixteen chapters have been opened so far, including chapters 23, 24 and 31, and two chapters (science and research, education and culture) have been provisionally closed. However, the motion for a joint resolution is too critical from my point of view – it criticises Montenegro, for example, for the deep polarisation of the domestic political scene, and in other places it meddles in matters that should be purely in the hands of the state, such as possible accession to NATO. We cannot close our eyes to the fact that Montenegro has certain shortcomings, for example, the fight against corruption seems to me to be essential, but I believe that our task should be more to help our partners in Montenegro. I abstained in the final vote.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Montenegro is the only country in the region to have provisionally opened and concluded negotiating chapters with the EU, which is a positive development for the Process of European Integration.  My vote in favour of the resolution reflects the need to encourage the continuation of accession negotiations, on the basis of the results achieved so far.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. Montenegro is part of the European family of nations and therefore, in my opinion, a positive asset. The country's integration into the EU is of enormous importance for the stability of the entire region.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. As a candidate country for EU membership, Montenegro is monitored annually. The Union calls on it to fight discrimination, unemployment, repression of the press and impunity for war crimes. But the stabilization and association agreements for these candidate countries mainly advocate liberalisation and the implementation of austerity plans to stem the rise in public debt. In the case of Montenegro, it is above all the "Russia bashing" that motivates this report submitted to the vote today.  Integration must be strengthened as soon as possible. Montenegrin political forces must "focus on the country's integration into the European Union" and Member States must "actively support Montenegro's accession" to NATO, which is already involved in some of its military operations. The country must continue on its path as the only country in the Western Balkans, together with Albania, "to have fully brought its legislation into line with the decisions and positions of the European Union on the situation in Ukraine".   I vote against it and oppose any further enlargement, especially in this venomous cold war context.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU enlargement process is slow and incorporates a number of rules that have to be respected. Montenegro is currently the only country in the region to have opened and provisionally closed negotiating chapters with the EU, a development that is welcomed. Montenegro's prominent position is an increased responsibility, both at regional level and at the level of the whole enlargement process. We must welcome the progress made by Montenegro and continue to work towards achieving our objectives. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution highlights the positive strides that Montenegro has made to formulate policies that create a climate of tolerance and inclusion for all communities within the country. It also stresses the need to address the outstanding bilateral issues with its neighbours and settle the still pending border demarcation and succession issues with Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Serbia and Kosovo. I therefore voted in favour of this motion as it outlines the advancements made in fulfilling the accession criteria and the work that is yet to be completed.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The adoption of follow-up reports by the European Parliament is an important step in the process of transposing the Community acquis. Indeed, it gives an overview of the elements in line with European Union standards and the efforts that still need to be made to enable accession. The efforts of Montenegro, which applied for membership on 15 December 2008 and was granted candidate status almost two years later, make it one of the most advanced states in the accession process.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ the Commission working document entitled '2014 Progress Report on Montenegro' has provided a wealth of information on Montenegro's positive practices, working continuously on and approaching the negotiating chapters with the EU.  I welcome such progress in the accession negotiations and encourage Montenegro to continue to take a determined and responsible approach to the implementation of the country's reform strategies and action plans. Particular attention must be paid to the fight against corruption, ensuring the independence of the judiciary and fundamental rights and freedoms, particularly in the area of freedom of expression and the media. I voted in favour of the present report, which has taken a balanced assessment of the progress made, while offering advice on areas where improvements need to be made.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the progress achieved by Montenegro on the path to EU accession. Parliament encourages continuation of EU related reforms, and insists on the need to fight corruption more effectively.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Western Balkans and the issue of enlargement is a major moral, political and strategic problem of the European Union. It will not go away, expectations will not go away, our historic experience and commitments will not disappear. It poses crucial, existential questions to the Union itself, to its democratic legitimacy and support among its citizens. I wish I had an answer of my own to this huge conundrum, putting in the balance so many destinies on either side of the equation.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report is realistic and balanced; while taking into account the unquestionable progress made by Montenegro, it faces with ruthless sincerity the problems that remain, and in some cases worsen, such as the situation of the rule of law, on which it rightly considers reforms to be at the heart of the European integration process, the insufficiently effective fight against corruption and organised crime, the limitations of freedom of expression, the deteriorating situation of media freedom, including targeted incidents against journalists and media owners. , shortcomings in the independence of the judicial system, including the uninfluencing of judicial independence, problems with electoral rules, including proportional public funding for all candidates and lack of financial control of political parties, unclear and satisfactory separation of state and parties, and consequently limited progress in politicising public administrations, women's rights, gender equality and the fight against domestic violence and the fact that no serious efforts have been made to end impunity for war crimes.  It is somewhat contradictory, then, that the report encourages the continuation of accession negotiations 'on the basis of reforms and concrete progress in the fight against the rule of law, the media environment and corruption', but I nevertheless voted in favour of its adoption because, in my view, the only way to enforce European values and standards in Montenegro is to continue accession negotiations.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2006 Montenegro declared its independence vis-à-vis the State of Serbia and in 2008 applied for accession to the Union. Four years later the Council approved the opening of negotiations granting Montenegro the status of candidate country.  The Copenhagen criteria have been implemented by montenegro's entities, in particular in their political, economic and social dimension and the implementation of the acquis communautaire. At present, 16 chapters are open, in particular on the free movement of capital; security, defence and foreign policy; financial control; rights in intellectual property, media and the information society; fundamental and judicial rights and justice, freedom and security. The chapter on science, education, culture and research is already closed.  Despite the progress made in the negotiations, there is a fear that political instability could affect the real implementation of the reforms. I would also like to stress that the conditions of freedom of expression and media information must be guaranteed, as it is a cornerstone of a rule of law.  For the above, I vote in favor of the efforts made by Montenegro, its entities and citizens.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The 2014 follow-up report on Montenegro highlights the country's shortcomings in the fight against organised crime, corruption and trafficking, which are poisoning business life. Opposing in principle any further enlargement of the European Union, and noting the otherwise deplorable state of freedom of expression and the press, all accession processes with Montenegro and all the financial payments that result from it must be stopped.  So I voted against it.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the 2014 follow-up report on Montenegro. The resolution provides an update on the status of negotiations with Montenegro as part of its bid to join the European Union. It welcomes the important efforts already made by Montenegro but calls for intensified efforts to strengthen the rule of law.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. Montenegro is currently the only country in the region to have provisionally opened and concluded negotiating chapters with the European Union, which is an important milestone in the stabilisation process in that geographical area. We therefore encourage the continuation of accession negotiations on the basis of the reforms implemented and concrete results, in particular those concerning the rule of law and the fight against corruption. We believe that reforms relating to the rule of law are at the heart of the process of European integration and are an essential condition for the continuation of negotiations, together with the fight against corruption and organised crime, which are the basic condition for the independence, efficiency and professionalism of the judicial system. We reiterate the importance of protecting freedom of expression as one of the EU's fundamental values, as well as the complete independence of the media and journalists.  We express our deep concern at the still modest progress in the areas of women's rights, gender equality, the representation of women in politics and the labour market and the fight against domestic violence. Finally, we encourage the government to implement sustainable economic reforms to stimulate competitiveness, overcome structural weaknesses and generally improve the business environment.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it presents the progress of the dossier of a country applying for membership of the European Union and merely takes stock of the country's progress annually.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The overall objective of enlargement policy is to implement Article 49 of the Treaty on European Union, which offers the prospect of EU membership to all European countries that respect the fundamental values of the Union and are committed to promoting them. This report notes that, although Montenegro is working very well on its way to the European Union, much remains to be done, particularly with regard to the rule of law, the environment, freedom of the press and the fight against corruption. In the light of the above, I welcome Montenegro's commitment to the EU accession process and i am voting in favour of the resolution.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Montenegro is one of the current countries with the status of candidate for accession to the European Union. I voted for this report because it appreciates and encourages the progress that it has made, but also that this country still has to make to become part of the EU. The report reiterates once again some extremely necessary criteria that must be respected and implemented and without which no State can adhere to the EU: fighting corruption, respecting human rights and the rule of law, independence and increasing the efficiency of the judiciary, ensuring freedom of expression, but also gender equality. The report also calls on all NATO members, but especially EU Member States, to actively support Montenegro's accession to this structure as well.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: scríofa. ‒ Cé go raibh neart rudaí maithe sa tuarascáil seo cosúil leis an ngá atá ann dul i ngleic leis an gcaimiléireacht, cosaint a thabhairt do neamhspleáchas na mbreithiúna agus an gá atá ann dul i ngleic le coireanna cogaidh gan baol pionóis, creidim go raibh sé de cheart ag an tuarascáil seo a bheith i bhfad níos láidre ó thaobh ceisteanna faoi chearta an duine de.  Cé go luaitear rudaí cosúil le cearta na mban, comhionannas inscne, cearta daoine atá leispiach, aerach, déghnéasach agus trasinscneach, ní dhéantar go leor trácht orthu agus theip air a léiriú an tábhacht atá ann díriú ar an idirdhealú atá soiléir sa tsochaí seo. Tá sé tábhachtach a aithint i Mír 22 go molann an tuarascáil seo an ról atá imeartha ag Montainéagró sa ‘process of regional reconciliation’ nuair – ag an am céanna san alt céanna – deir sé ‘invites relevant EU Member States to consider accelerating Montenegro’s NATO accession process in order to enhance regional stability’. Ní chreidim go bhfuil forleathnú NATO comhsheasmhach le hathmhuintearas réigiúnach nó le cobhsaíocht réigiúnach agus táim i gcoinne na slí a ghlaoitear ar Bhallstáit AE forleathnú NATO a éascú agus a spreagadh.  Mar gheall ar na fáthanna sin, chaith mise vóta i gcoinne na tuarascála seo.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on montenegro's 2014 progress report. Accession negotiations must be continued on the basis of the reforms implemented and the concrete results achieved, in particular in the areas of the rule of law, the media environment and the fight against corruption.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I welcome montenegro's progress report.  Each enlargement country must have a clear European perspective. Progress towards membership depends on the action taken by each country to meet the criteria set, based on the principle of merit.  It is to be welcomed that progress has been made towards membership, but every effort must continue to be made to implement reforms effectively. There is a need to fundamentally review and strengthen economic governance and implement sustainable economic reforms.  Particular attention should be paid to reforms relating to the rule of law, which is an essential element of the Process of European Integration. It is therefore essential to strengthen democratic institutions and ensure inclusive democratic processes in order to implement fundamental democratic principles and common EU values. It should be noted that progress has been made in implementing reforms aimed at ensuring the independence and efficiency of the judiciary. Consultation mechanisms with civil society organisations have also been improved. However, the problem of impunity in war crimes cases still remains. Moreover, corruption also remains a major problem requiring more effective solutions.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The reports on the accession path of the countries of the Western Balkans, Serbia, Montenegro, Macedonia, call for the ACCELERATION by the EU and their civil governments of unpopular reforms in these countries, which target labour-popular rights, remove any obstacles to the establishment of business groups and their profitability.  The accession process of these countries exacerbates all the problems of workers, intensifies their exploitation for the benefit of monopolies, implicates them in the dangerous imperialist plans of the EU-US-NATO and the competition raging in the wider region for resources of wealth, with unforeseen painful consequences against them.  The peoples of the Balkans have an interest in strengthening and coordinating their fight against the EU and NATO, in every imperialist alliance of capital and the capitalist path of development, opposing their own popular alliance for power, which will pave the way for peace, mutually beneficial cooperation and solidarity, for popular prosperity.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that Montenegro is currently the only country in the region to have provisionally opened and concluded some negotiating chapters with the EU, this represents a positive development; whereas this leading role is seen as an increased responsibility, both in the regional context and in the enlargement process as a whole; that sustainable dialogue and constructive cooperation between the government and the opposition are important in order to make progress in the preparations for accession, but that the issue of freedom of expression and media freedom is still a cause for concern, the European institutions welcome the progress made in the accession negotiations and encourage the continuation of accession negotiations on the basis of the reforms implemented and the concrete results achieved. , in particular those concerning the rule of law, the media environment and the fight against corruption and impunity for war crimes, which are still little fought.  The European Union also urges Montenegro to resolve as soon as possible – within the framework of the accession process – the outstanding bilateral issues with its neighbours, in a constructive and good neighbourly spirit. For all these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am happy that accession negotiations mean that Montenegro has already sixteen opened chapters and that it was able to provisionally close two of them. This is true progress not only for Montenegro but for the European perspective of the region as a whole. Furthermore, I consider the authorities in Montenegro should take decisive action on fighting corruption and engaging in reforming state processes with a clear separation of private and public interests.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. This follow-up report on Montenegro, which is only a progress report, must assess Montenegro's progress towards its future accession to the European Union. 16 chapters have already been validated. Nevertheless, it is undeniable that Montenegro suffers from recurring evils that plague its economy: organized crime, corruption, trafficking ... Moreover, attacks on freedom of expression and the media are recurrent in this country, and this report makes a similar observation.  In view of these elements, it is more than urgent that the "eurobenates" simply stop noticing the situation and react by immediately halting the process of Montenegro's accession to the European Union, since Europe no longer has the financial means to welcome new states into its membership. So I voted against that proposal.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support the latest in a series of progress reports by Montenegro colleague Tannock, who, together with the adopted amendments, correctly presented the areas where Montenegro has prospered, but also those areas whose improvement requires significant efforts. It is certainly worth commending the fact that Montenegro is the country that has made the most progress in the euro integration process of all the candidates with already 16 open negotiating chapters, 2 of which have been temporarily closed. It is also worth commending the adoption of the anti-corruption package adopted last year and supporting their adoption and full implementation, as corruption is one of the main problems facing Montenegro. While attacks on the media and journalists continue, which is reprehensible, it is positive that their numbers have decreased and that all cases of attacks on the media in the last year have been prosecuted. I am also pleased that the report covered a call for Montenegro to find a solution to outstanding bilateral issues with its neighbours as soon as possible, to pay reparations to war victims who have been waiting for it for more than two decades, and to approach constructively addressing remaining succession issues. Once again, I would like to express my support for my colleague Tannock's report on montenegro's Euro-immigration path.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome montenegro's progress in the accession negotiations and the implementation of important reforms that encourage the continuation of negotiations. Among these reforms, there are two of the most important ones, that of public administration, and that of the judicial system to which particular attention must be paid. The efforts made are considerable, but it is good that the Montenegrin authorities are making greater efforts to combat corruption, which is still very much present, and that the system is more transparent in the various sectors. I hope that the Montenegrin Government will implement sustainable economic reforms in order to improve competitiveness and the business environment. I also call on Montenegro to continue the progress made in environmental protection and to develop sustainable energy policies. I also hope that Montenegro will soon join NATO, so that greater security is ensured throughout the Adriatic.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Montenegro, of the other part, of 2010, aims at Montenegro's accession to the EU.  This resolution concerns the 2014 progress report on Montenegro's progress towards achieving such an objective. The report supports the continuation of accession negotiations on the basis of the reforms implemented and the concrete results achieved, in particular in the area of the rule of law, the environment surrounding the media and the fight against corruption.  It also welcomes the progress made in the accession negotiations, noting the opening of sixteen chapters, the provisional closure of two (science and scientific research, education and culture) and the implementation of reforms aimed at ensuring an independent and more efficient judiciary. It also stresses the importance of ensuring that the reform process is inclusive and has the participation of civil society. Finally, it commends the fact that Montenegro has taken a constructive role in regional and international cooperation, as well as in the process of regional reconciliation. I voted in favour.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. In July 2014, European Commission President-elect Jean-Claude Juncker declared in the Chamber that "there will be no further enlargement in the next five years". A common-sense proposal that was high on the agenda of the MR programme during the last European elections. This need to solidify the House of Europe before it is enlarged does not mean that the ongoing negotiations with the countries of the near neighbourhood such as the Western Balkans must stop. These countries need a European perspective, but it must be recognised that both Serbia, Kosovo, Montenegro and Macedonia do not meet European standards today. The difficult economic and social situation in the European Union requires increased vigilance. Added to this is the willingness of European decision-makers to pay much more attention to chapters 23 ("judicial apparatus and fundamental rights") and 24 ("justice, freedom, security"). With regard to Montenegro, the 2014 monitoring report reported serious and persistent dysfunctions: non-compliance with press freedom (the country ranks 114th out of 180), endemic corruption and the absence of an impartial judicial system. A lot for a country that knocks on the door of Europe.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Developments in Montenegro's accession to the European Union are welcomed. However, there is still a long way to go. Rule of Law reforms are now at the heart of the European integration process and prove to be an essential condition for progress in the global integration talks. However, there are other points to be mentioned, namely the importance of transparency in policy and legislation; the importance of freedom of expression on the part of journalists and their media; urgent improvements in the quality of education and improvements in the field of women's rights and gender equality (representation of women in politics and the labour market and combating domestic violence).

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report congratulating Montenegro on the progress made so far, noting that, provisionally, sixteen negotiating chapters have been opened and two (science and research and education and culture) have been closed. At the same time, accession negotiations are encouraged to continue on the basis of reforms, particularly in the areas of the rule of law, freedom of expression and the fight against corruption. On the other hand, from my group we have draw attention to aspects relating to anti-discrimination measures, Roma minority, women and children's rights, rights of persons with disabilities and other social issues, which have mostly been incorporated into the final text.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this text, which provides an overview of Montenegro's progress in reforms in 2014. Some progress has been made, including Montenegro's alignment with the European Union's common security and defence policy. On the other hand, the country must continue its efforts on certain weaknesses. Progress remains to be made in the fight against corruption, the independence of the judiciary and the guarantee of freedom of expression and the media. The text also highlights the lack of real action in the fight against impunity in war crimes cases. It is therefore necessary for Montenegro to continue its efforts to bring itself in line with the values defended by the European Union and to concentrate its efforts on the rule of law.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Negotiations with Montenegro on its accession to the EU were opened following the request for annexation. Many steps have been taken by Montenegro, but there are still some gaps to be filled. Much progress has also been made in the area of regional cooperation. It is important to work closely with a country so geographically close to ours, which could soon be a resource, for Italy and for Europe.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which welcomes Montenegro's progress in the negotiation process for EU membership, but calls for ambitious measures to combat corruption, ensure the independence of the judiciary and guarantee freedom of expression and the media.  This follow-up report does not, however, prejudge Montenegro's rapid accession to the European Union.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because it maintains the line of Parliament's views on the candidate countries, in which a colonial relationship between a rich and powerful centre is reproduced in the face of an impoverished and obedient periphery. The policy of enlargement, as this Resolution demonstrates, consists of a cast of neoliberal proposals and, in this particular case, submission to American interests, since it expressly calls for Montenegro's membership in NATO.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE)
