text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Montenegro has made significant progress recently towards bringing its political and economic system closer to EU standards, and out of the 36 negotiating chapters, 16 have already been opened. Although numerous deficits have been identified in many areas, Montenegro is taking action in their regard, as evidenced by the adoption of legislation to prevent corruption. It should not be forgotten, however, that the very establishment of a right is not everything, because it is necessary to implement it and to record concrete results on the ground. Another key area from the point of view of EU standards is the guarantee of freedom of expression and the media and the decisive fight against the persecution of journalists. Montenegro will need strong political will to bring about a change in this situation. We are making progress in implementing this important standard for the functioning of a democratic state, but it cannot yet be said that the problem has been averted. Montenegro's additional problem is the political world's dependence on business, which is not conducive to a proper perception of the real situation of its citizens. Social problems include high unemployment of 19% and poverty among the employed as well. It is therefore necessary to combat social inequalities, to support and expand the production base, to protect the environment and to improve the labour market. The situation of persons with disabilities also needs to be further improved.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the 2014 Progress Report on Montenegro along with the Socialists and Democrats Group.  The progress report highlights that Montenegro has opened sixteen chapters in accession negotiations and has already provisionally closed two. This is real progress in the enlargement process. Reforms are still necessary in areas such as the rule of law, public administration and discrimination against women and LGBTI community members. S&D presented amendments on issues such as anti-discrimination, rights of vulnerable members of society and other social issues with most being adopted or considered in the compromises.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. Montenegro started negotiations with the European Union in 2012 and plays a leading role in European integration in the Western Balkans and I supported the positive development of its Stabilisation and Association Agreement. Assessing the progress of the negotiations is a major incentive to make further efforts to address remaining problems that hinder its path to EU membership, concerning the judiciary, corruption, human rights violations and media independence. Montenegro needs to demonstrate a strong initiative in achieving common regional interests by actively engaging in the development of the Adriatic-Ionian Strategy. Through the Strategy, states are working together to improve the region in the tourism sectors, better transport connectivity, job creation and increasing standards in the region.  Montenegro needs to be actively involved in developing regional energy policy and more strongly encourage the linking of energy systems in Southeast Europe. Good connectivity and the development of renewable energy sources are the basis on which Montenegro can successfully develop its economy and strengthen its own energy security.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Progress Report of Montenegro is very well written and balanced, covering and highlighting all relevant aspects such as corruption, organised crime, the judiciary, freedom of the media and expression, minority rights, gender equality and foreign policy. I welcome the progress that has been made so far and show Montenegro's serious commitment to improving the situation in the country. I welcome the resumption of negotiations on the basis of the improvements and reforms made so far, which reflect concrete results, especially in the area of the rule of law. Otherwise, I am concerned about the economic situation of the country and the unemployment rate. This is certainly a problem that will need to be paid a lot of attention in the years to come. It should be borne in mind that if the economic situation in the country improves, then crime and corruption will also be reduced, in combination with appropriate laws. The country needs to be made attractive to foreign investors and to enable existing companies to continue to operate successfully. I am pleased and welcome montenegro's progress, and I am sure that they will remain on this good track in the future, as they are focused and have a clearly defined objective. I therefore voted in favour of supporting the resolution on Montenegro's progress made in 2014.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 Enlargement of the EU means an increase in the area of peace and stability for the Western Balkans in this area of Europe. It is important that we give Montenegro a clear signal that it is welcome in the future as a full member of the European family.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this report because it encourages the government to implement sustainable economic reforms, including legal provisions on competition mechanisms, fostering competitiveness and overcoming structural shortcomings, addressing large informal sectors, and improving the business environment in general. I believe that transparent action on the totalitarian past, including the opening of secret service archives, is a step forward towards democratisation, accountability and institutional strength. It is also important for Montenegro to resolve the remaining bilateral issues with its neighbours in a constructive and good neighbourly manner as soon as possible in the accession process. In particular, I welcome the call on the Montenegrin authorities to protect national minorities, the multinational character of The Bay of Kotor, and to encourage its cooperation with the Republic of Croatia and other EU members.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report indicating the progress made by Montenegro in regards its accession to the European Union and measures still to be taken. While real progress is being made, reforms need to be made in areas such as the rule of law, public administration and discrimination against women and LGBTI community members.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the report and welcome the progress made in the pre-accession negotiations and support the efforts made in the areas of the rule of law, media freedom and the fight against corruption, as well as the Commission's emphasis on public administration reform. I express particular satisfaction because all amendments of the Croatian EPP delegation are included in the text of the Resolution, either as a compromise or as an independent one.  In order to preserve good-social relations, we will continue to insist on resolving outstanding bilateral issues at an early stage of accession negotiations, as the Resolution states, among other things. In particular, I emphasise the European Parliament's call on Montenegro to resolve border issues quickly and efficiently, and here I particularly emphasise the border at Prevlaca, and to preserve the multinational identity of Boka Kotorska.  I am particularly pleased that the resolution included an amendment concerning fair reparations to montenegrin concentration camp inmates, so I call on the authorities to implement the conclusions of the Report and to adequately, promptly and fairly compensate Croatian concentration camp inmates in Montenegro, but also to implement the property sucency of the former JNA.   I must point out that the fact that no serious efforts have been made to punish war crimes so far is important to conduct effective investigations without delay, while on the other hand Montenegro can count on The Republic of Croatia's support on the European path using its experience in negotiations.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I supported the proposal, as I welcome Montenegro's progress. Montenegro's reform efforts are beneficial not only for Montenegro itself, but better functioning of its economy will also help all its trading partners, including the European Union.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I supported the resolution on Montenegro's progress for 2014, which leads to the Western Balkans as a candidate country. Montenegro must strengthen the area of the rule of law, especially when it comes to combating corruption at high levels. Further efforts are needed to implement constitutional reforms, and citizens' trust in the institutions must be strengthened. Montenegro must strengthen transparency and improve the business environment. A well-functioning public administration has a direct impact on the government's ability to provide public services. It also contributes to growth and competitiveness. Freedom of expression and freedom of foundation is one of the fundamental values of the European agenda. There is still a lot of work to be done in this area.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported today's resolution on montenegro's progress report, mainly because I believe that there is no alternative for this country other than membership of the European Union. If Montenegro has an interest in this membership, we need to support it in its efforts by clearly identifying the conditions necessary for admission to the EU and clearly assessing what still needs to be done by Montenegro. Only sufficiently implemented reforms will allow Montenegro's future effective existence within the European Union. The same applies to other countries in the so-called Western Balkans.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 In the text there are several problematic points with which we disagree. Initially there is a strong call for economic reforms within the framework of neoliberal economic policy. The report then calls for an acceleration of Montenegro's NATO accession process and urges Montenegro's participation in military missions. We do not oppose Montenegro's desire to join the EU, but we cannot vote in favour of a report that is a hymn to NATO's action, neoliberal austerity policies and military interventions.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Any enlargement of the EU will exacerbate the economic crisis plaguing the countries of the South, without succeeding in improving the living conditions of its respective citizens.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the 2014 report on montenegro's achievements, which showed that Montenegro had made significant progress in its integration with the EU.  The motion rightly lists areas such as the fight against corruption, freedom of expression and freedom of the press and the independence of the judiciary, where further significant progress is needed. The active participation of civil society should also be supported in each of these reform processes.  I also particularly welcome the mention of encouraging the country's future membership of NATO. This is also important because all the countries in the region are already members of the organisation and montenegro's accession would further strengthen the security of the region.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. Each candidate country is judged on its own merits and on the fact that future progress will be focused on the effective implementation of the country's reform strategies and action plans.  Sustainable dialogue and constructive cooperation between the government and the opposition are important to make progress in the preparations for accession and to ensure citizens' confidence in the electoral process and in state institutions. All political forces should remain focused on the country's accession process to the European Union.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report which encourages the continuation of accession negotiations on the basis of the reforms implemented and concrete results. In my point of view, the reforms linked to the rule of law are at the centre of the integration process and the Montenegro must continue to work on these aspects.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am of the opinion that the European integration of the Western Balkans is one of the key challenges that the EU will confront in the coming years. Even though Montenegro still has a long road to achieve full membership of the EU, it has to be recognised that it is making efforts to improve its standards in many fields, and particularly on the rule of law. Moreover, the peaceful and democratic way in which Montenegro achieved independence through a referendum, should be taken into consideration as good model to solve territorial disputes.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. Once again, a report that requires Montenegro to adopt a regime and political system dictated by the European Union, which poses as a schoolteacher who would distribute the good and bad points. Parliamentarians are dictating to the Parliament of Montenegro how they should conduct their political and legislative work! We are AGAINST this odious interference in the national affairs of other sovereign states.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. The Resolution congratulates Montenegro on the progress made so far and notes that sixteen negotiating chapters have been opened and that two (science and research, education and culture) have already been provisionally closed. It encourages the continuation of accession negotiations on the basis of reforms carried out, particularly in the areas of the rule of law, freedom of expression and the fight against corruption. Our S&D Group tabled amendments on anti-discrimination, the Roma minority, women and children's rights, the rights of persons with disabilities and other social issues. Most of these amendments were adopted or included in the commitments.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because it maintains the line of Parliament's views on the candidate countries, in which a colonial relationship between a rich and powerful centre is reproduced in the face of an impoverished and obedient periphery. The policy of enlargement, as this Resolution demonstrates, consists of a cast of neoliberal proposals and, in this particular case, submission to American interests, since it expressly calls for Montenegro's membership in NATO.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 We respect the sovereign will of the people of the Republic of Montenegro, in particular in deciding to join the EU or not. However, we see in this report another exercise of seduction that no longer lives to tie this country more to the neoliberal and militaristic agenda of the EU and NATO. With possible membership, it will once again be the people who suffer the consequences of this enlargement which corresponds to an insatiable desire of the EU to expand its market, while ensuring and expanding its military control over that area of Europe.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. Montenegro is part of the European family of nations and therefore, in my opinion, a positive asset. The country's integration into the EU is of enormous importance for the stability of the entire region.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I am against the enlargement of the EU. In this respect, I do not agree with the appropriate preparation. This attitude will not change until the EU and its institutions are fundamentally renewed and reformed and we are once again developing the EU as a federation of sovereign states and not as a federation of states.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the 2014 progress report on Montenegro, as the country has made significant strides in recent years and made substantial progress during accession negotiations. The EP must support this effort, which strengthens stability, security and democracy in the region.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The reports on the accession path of the countries of the Western Balkans, Serbia, Montenegro, Macedonia, call for the ACCELERATION by the EU and their civil governments of unpopular reforms in these countries, which target labour-popular rights, remove any obstacles to the establishment of business groups and their profitability.  The accession process of these countries exacerbates all the problems of workers, intensifies their exploitation for the benefit of monopolies, implicates them in the dangerous imperialist plans of the EU-US-NATO and the competition raging in the wider region for resources of wealth, with unforeseen painful consequences against them.  The peoples of the Balkans have an interest in strengthening and coordinating their fight against the EU and NATO, in every imperialist alliance of capital and the capitalist path of development, opposing their own popular alliance for power, which will pave the way for peace, mutually beneficial cooperation and solidarity, for popular prosperity.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I consider this report on Montenegro's progress to be positive. I am glad that the prospect of Montenegro's EU membership has contributed to new reforms and overall development in this country. I firmly believe that it will continue in this direction, which is why I personally strongly support its future accession to the EU.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This motion for a resolution presents a wide range of recitals on montenegro's integration process into the EU. In addition to the evaluation of the process, it points to a wide range of impositions for membership, which confirm the extent of the interference and loss of sovereignty imposed on countries and peoples in the process of EU membership.  We highlight the interference in the economic, judicial and political system, in the advanced foreign and security policy guidelines, including the country's membership of NATO integrated into the militarisation of the EU and the enlargement of influence in the Balkans, among others. We consider unacceptable the manor attitude with which the recitals and conditions required to satisfy the precepts relating to the integration of the country are unacceptable, removing from the peoples the legitimate right to decide their future, where they are part, the free and sovereign choice of EU membership, but also of economic and social development strategies. For these reasons we voted against.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the progress report on Montenegro because I believe that it has in a balanced way underlined both the progress already made by the candidate country and those that are still lacking to complete the process. In particular, while anti-discrimination legislation has been almost fully aligned with the Acquis communautaire, efforts are still needed to adequately protect women's rights and gender equality, especially in the labour market. More attention should also be paid to the fight against corruption, which continues to be a cause for concern both for the proper functioning of the rule of law and for economic development and the ability to attract investment. Finally, it is important that real freedom of expression is guaranteed in Montenegro, especially for journalists and the media in general, which is a prerequisite for any democratic country.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the 2014 report on Montenegro's progress towards the EU by Charles Tannock, because it is right for Parliament to highlight the positive aspects of the process, while highlighting the country's still-present problems, such as the lack of respect for media freedom, the lack of rule of law, ubifiastion corruption and lack of parliamentary activity. Montenegro is the fastest approach to the European Union and is the only country in the region to open 16 chapters in negotiations with the EU, including Chapter No 24 on the rule of law. It has even closed two chapters (including education and culture). I believe that the pro-European and pro-democracy mindset will win and that Montenegro will successfully complete its rapprochement with the European Union.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D).
text: Madam President, I support this report because it sends two important political messages. The first is to unfairly block Macedonia from opening accession negotiations because of its bilateral dispute with Greece. This is the ninth consecutive time the European Council has called for the start of negotiations and there is no indication that next year will be any different. Another thing is the regression of democracy, freedom of expression and media and political culture in Macedonia.  Accusations by a leading opposition politician that the prime minister and the government are illegally eavesdropping on large numbers of citizens are serious and are ringing alarm bells. If a small part of the accusations are correct, it will give momentum to those who want to stop Macedonia's European progress. The situation in which the Prime Minister announces the prosecution of opposition leaders in a personal address on state television is politically extremely dangerous and has no place in a democratic state.  I call on the Macedonian government to allow an impartial and objective investigation into the wiretapping allegations, and if they prove correct, accept political responsibility.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – I voted in favour of the resolution on the progress report of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia because, in my opinion, it identifies well the situation in a country that is by no means rosy, and at the same time encourages the country in an appropriate way to move faster accession negotiations. I believe that the dispute with Greece over the name of a country that has been one of the main barriers to accession for many years... in the EU's accession process, it is easy to resolve as soon as possible and no longer affect the start of negotiations. That the current political situation in Makeda.... That he's... Yes, the current political situation in Macedonia is extremely unstable, but delaying the start of negotiations can only lead the country into more chaos. However, both the European Parliament and the rest of the EU institutions cannot and cannot allow themselves to do so in the interests of the desire for stability throughout the region and for the approximation of European values to this area. I believe that Macedonian politics, both the government and the opposition, must immediately start a dialogue that will resolve the country's current instability.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – I also supported this report with the clear knowledge that we are sending an extremely important message to the government in Skopje, and it is that bilateral relations must be resolved, that the treaty of good neighbourliness and friendship between Bulgaria and Macedonia must be concluded, that the practice of speech hatred towards Bulgaria and the Bulgarian media in Skopje must be terminated, that the rights of all citizens in the Republic of Macedonia must be recognised to be united on their own national basis and principle and to their native language.  For the first time, a European Parliament document mentions the citizens of Macedonia with a Bulgarian national consciousness. This is extremely important to me and I hope that this message will be clearly heard by the government in Skopje. This is the only obligation and guarantee of this government to be able to continue on its path of European integration, knowing that it must use all European rules and practices.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I welcome the solidarity we have shown towards Macedonia and with this resolution called on the European Commission and the Council, after 9 consecutive failures, to find a solution in order to formally open negotiations for Macedonia, and continue to resolve the bilateral dispute in parallel with Macedonian harmonisation with European legislation. Macedonia has been waiting 10 years for the opening of negotiations due to the bilateral name dispute with Greece, which is discouraging for the Macedonian people and puts into question the success of the methodology of the negotiation process so far. A successful example of solving bilateral problems within the negotiation process as Croatia had is an example of good practice that we should also use in the case of the Republic of Macedonia. Once again, I call on the European Council and the Commission to actively use good examples from past negotiations and urgently find a way to open negotiations for Macedonia, as Macedonia deserves it given its high level of preparedness.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. This report reiterates the call on the Council, without further delay, to set the start date of the accession negotiations and states that bilateral issues should not be an obstacle to the official opening of the negotiations. Most importantly, Parliament is seriously concerned about the worsening relations between the Government and the opposition, especially in relation to the recent announcement of charges against the opposition leader by the prime minister, and any illegal surveillance is condemned.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because it maintains the line of Parliament's views on the applicant countries, in which a colonial relationship between a rich and powerful centre and an impoverished and obedient periphery is reproduced. In the case of the report put to the vote, there is also a need for States wishing to join the Union to maintain good relations with their members, which is not complied with by the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. The dispute around the country's name is a condition for starting negotiations for accession. However, the Resolution calls for the start of them before agreement is reached on the matter. For this reason, I decided to vote against it.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I abstained on the 2014 Progress Report on Macedonia as I feel there are contradictory aspects to it. The report calls for the authorities and civil society to overcome ethnic and identity divisions in Macedonia. I welcome this. In Ireland we are still working towards national reconciliation and respect for all our identities. Recently at our annual party conference, the Sinn Féin Chairperson, speaking about the Irish peace process, said: "There should be a fearless resolve to dismantle barriers and build bridges by all sides. Those who want to push the Peace Process backwards, and directly or implicitly oppose reconciliation should be challenged, without fear or favour." Unfortunately the report also calls for Macedonia's accession to NATO. I believe the expansion of NATO is contrary to the spirit of peace and reconciliation. Hence my abstention.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. This report is a continuation of other reports on Eastern European states. There are many interferences in the internal affairs of a sovereign state, whether on social issues, with the consideration of LGBT coterie demands, or in foreign policy, particularly in its relations with Greece. I logically voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I do not support the accession of Macedonia to the European Union, and therefore voted against this resolution.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to evaluate the 2014 progress report of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Kosovo, the former Yugoslav Republic and Serbia are the six countries of the Western Balkans applying for EU membership. Of these applicants, two are already negotiating membership of the European Union, Montenegro and Serbia. Albania and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia have the status of official candidates, while Bosnia and Herzegovina and Kosovo are considered potential candidates. The progress of all these candidates for EU accession varies, with many indicators lagging behind EU members. The main problems are high unemployment rates, corruption and restrictions on freedom of the press.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which is once again characterized by an unbearable desire to interfere motivated by an ideology that is not mine.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. This is the annual follow-up report on Macedonia as part of its application for membership. The European Parliament recalls that the Council is preventing the country from reaching the next stage of the accession process because of the unresolved conflict with Greece over its name. Nevertheless, Parliament calls on the Council, for the 9th consecutive time, to set a date for the start of negotiations in order to speed up the reforms related to the acquis. The European Parliament welcomes the electoral reforms and welcomes the advanced level of harmonisation at the legislative level. Nevertheless, it expressed grave concern at the political and financial pressures that threaten the independence of the media and called for the anti-discrimination law to be brought into line with the UNION's acquis, as the law does not prohibit discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This 2014 follow-up report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, which is again very ideologically oriented, advocates genuine interference in the legislative process and calls for the promotion of the European Union worthy of Soviet propaganda.  This is not surprising since the Union, which is equal to itself, intends to subject States and peoples to its dictatorship of single thought and to its globalist ideology. It even calls on Macedonia to "condemn all forms of nationalism; calls for a proactive defence of a multi-ethnic and multi-faith, tolerant society where everyone has a place." Quite a program! Finally, it no longer hesitates to interfere in its foreign policy by indicating the directions it must take, especially with Greece. So I voted against this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the positions defended by the Resolution which partially analyses the lack of progress made by the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia as a pre-accession country and for this reason I did not support it with my vote.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I've dropped my voice.  However, I believe that FYROM should be allowed to start negotiating with the EU, and that a country's name is its own matter to decide. The report calls for FYROM to bring its economic and foreign policy into line with the EU, i think that is wrong.  In principle, I believe that the people of FYROM should be given the right to express their opinion on the accession process to the EU, by means of a referendum. It is up to the people of FYROM to decide for themselves whether they want the country to belong to the EU. That is why I am abstaining on this report.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which reiterates, for the ninth consecutive time, its call on the Council to set, without further delay, a start date for accession negotiations with the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, while considering that bilateral issues should not be an obstacle to the official opening of the negotiations. In the report, Parliament condemns any illegal surveillance and expresses serious concern about the progressive deterioration of relations between government and opposition, especially in relation to the Recent Announcement of Charges against the Leader of the Opposition by the Prime Minister.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, in which the European Parliament evaluates the progress report for the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia in 2014. Parliament believes that the authorities and civil society should take appropriate measures to achieve historical reconciliation in order to eliminate the mutual and internal exclusion between different ethnic and national groups, including Bulgarian citizens. Welcomes, however, the fact that a legal and institutional framework is already in place to combat organised crime and that many police operations against organised criminal groups have been successfully carried out, in particular by cutting off international routes for drug trafficking and smuggling of migrants. However, it still regrets that there is insufficient cooperation with civil society organisations and public stakeholders in the development of legislation. Such cooperation should be based on the government's genuine willingness to consult with various stakeholders, both in legislative and policy-making.

name: Mario Borghezio (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 Taking into account the unresolved dispute with Greece regarding the name issue, the very high level of corruption, the freedom of the press constantly in danger, the strong presence of organized crime, the lack of transparency at all levels, the growing unemployment and also considering that the European Commission does not foresee any new membership of the European Union for the next 5 years , I voted against this resolution.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, whose ideological orientation is regrettable. Once again, the European Union is setting itself up as a lecturer. There is a serious dispute between a Member State, Greece, and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. We cannot interfere in the conduct of this country's foreign policy. And the report states that "bilateral problems cannot be invoked with the aim of hindering the accession process". We must not interfere in the internal legislative process of this country by calling for "the compliance of the law against discrimination with the acquis of the Union". I do not understand the appropriateness of the preciseness of the report which "condemns all forms of nationalism; calls for a proactive defence of a multi-ethnic and multi-faith, tolerant society where everyone has a place."

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on the 2014 Progress Report on Macedonia as I feel there are contradictory aspects to it. The report calls for the authorities and civil society to overcome ethnic and identity divisions in Macedonia. I welcome this. In Ireland we are still working towards national reconciliation and respect for all our identities. Recently at our annual party conference, the Sinn Féin Chairperson, speaking about the Irish peace process, said: "There should be a fearless resolve to dismantle barriers and build bridges by all sides. Those who want to push the Peace Process backwards, and directly or implicitly oppose reconciliation should be challenged, without fear or favour." Unfortunately the report also calls for Macedonia's accession to NATO. I believe the expansion of NATO is contrary to the spirit of peace and reconciliation. Hence my abstention.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. Very ideologically oriented, the report calls for the European Union's scandalous interference in Macedonia's internal legislative process and in its external relations, particularly with Greece.  The report "condemns all forms of nationalism; calls for a proactive defence of a multi-ethnic and multi-faith, tolerant society where everyone has a place." He therefore advocates a Macedonia under European infusion, permeable to the Union's propaganda. It is in the interest of Macedonians to refuse these multiple interferences that threaten their sovereignty and identity.  That is why I voted against this outrageous text.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. This report reiterates the call on the Council, without further delay, to set a date for the start of accession negotiations and states that bilateral issues should not be an obstacle to the official opening of the negotiations. Most importantly, Parliament is seriously concerned about the worsening relations between the Government and the opposition, especially in relation to the recent announcement of charges against the opposition leader by the prime minister, and any illegal surveillance is condemned.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the 2014 report on the progress made by the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.  In view of the fact that the European Parliament has repeatedly called for the opening of accession negotiations with the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia and that further delays in the opening of negotiations could have a negative impact in the country on the EU's reform processes and credibility in the region, the report called on the Council to set a date for the opening of negotiations as soon as possible so as not to lose momentum and to promote related reforms, thereby helping to consolidate the process of democratisation initiated by the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is important.  The opening of accession negotiations can only have a positive impact on efforts to continue the much-needed reforms linked to the rule of law, the independence of the judiciary and the fight against corruption.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on the 2014 Progress Report on Macedonia as I feel there are contradictory aspects to it. The report calls for the authorities and civil society to overcome ethnic and identity divisions in Macedonia. I welcome this. In Ireland we are still working towards national reconciliation and respect for all our identities. Recently at our annual party conference, the Sinn Féin Chairperson, speaking about the Irish peace process, said: "There should be a fearless resolve to dismantle barriers and build bridges by all sides. Those who want to push the Peace Process backwards, and directly or implicitly oppose reconciliation should be challenged, without fear or favour." Unfortunately the report also calls for Macedonia's accession to NATO. I believe the expansion of NATO is contrary to the spirit of peace and reconciliation. Hence my abstention.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution concerns the Commission's 2014 Progress Report on the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.  Parliament called once again for the opening of accession negotiations with the country, citing the fact that further delays in opening negotiations might have a negative impact on the reform processes in the country and the credibility of the EU in the region. It further added that bilateral issues should not hinder the accession process and calls on the Council once again to set a date for the start of the accession negotiations. The resolution further recalls the commitment of Member States to return to the name issue in 2015 with a view to the opening of accession negotiations. This could also hasten the implementation of much- needed reforms, especially on the rule of law, independence of the judiciary and the fight against corruption. Parliament expressed its serious concern at the worsening of relations between the government and the opposition, particularly the recent accusations and counter-accusations of wrongdoing. Parliament calls for an independent investigation to take place into all allegations and surveillance carried out. I voted in favour.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 As I have already been able to say during the debate, I am in favour of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia joining the European Union because it is an historic necessity. Nonetheless, the EU's commitment to the naming issue needs to be more proactive: this issue needs to be addressed in depth in parallel with accession so as not to create yet another source of instability in the Balkan region.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this very ideologically oriented report. It advocates real interference in the legislative process, with, for example, the injunction made to Macedonia to pass a pro-LGBT law. Eurocrats are also seeking to dictate to the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia the direction its foreign policy should take. Thus its relations with Greece and the dispute between them concerning the name chosen by the former Yugoslav Republic. Finally, this report is a real propaganda in favour of multiculturalism: "condemns all forms of nationalism; calls for a proactive defence of a multi-ethnic and multi-faith society." Macedonia, like many countries of the former Soviet bloc, is also at risk of finding itself under a new yoke, the UERSS, which places states under infusion and issues its "good practices" in defiance of the independence of the peoples.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Negotiations between the Eu ropean Union and Macedonia must be provided for on a peremptory period, as this measure provides. The promotion of the reforms envisaged in the acquis must be called upon to consolidate the integration process. The unresolved situation between the State of Greece and the State of Macedonia with regard to the so-called designation must not stand in the way of the integration process.  The commitment required of the Macedonian State is to remedy the high rate of corruption and the pressure exerted by the political sector on the independence of the media, crucial points which I believe are essential for full integration. Increasing the efficiency of the judgments of the courts, of the Macedonian State after judicial reforms, must be taken into account positively.  For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of the measure.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure because I agree with the call for a date to be set as soon as possible for the start of negotiations between the EU and the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, so as not to lose momentum and to promote reforms linked to the acquis and to consolidate the democratisation process.  I believe that the unresolved issue with Greece regarding the name should not be an obstacle to the start of negotiations because it is a bilateral issue, although it should be resolved before the end of the accession process. I welcome the high level of legislative alignment and the increased efficiency of Macedonian courts as a result of judicial reforms. However, I am aware that serious problems still remain in certain areas of crucial importance, such as media independence from political pressure and a serious commitment to corruption. These are the objectives suggested by the Commission as steps towards the process of rapprochement with the European Union.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I stress the quality and accuracy of Mr Vajgl's report on the development of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia as a candidate for eu union entry. It is indisputable that, in many of the valences, FYROM is evolving positively, which confirms the value of EU enlargement as a tool to enable economic growth and the consolidation of democracy in the candidate countries. The report highlights many areas where FYROM is still a long way from Community standards, but still puts pressure on the Council to start accession negotiations. Since I maintain a prudent reserve position on further enlargement (I believe that there is still some time left for the EU to digest the latest enlargements), I abstain in its vote.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the 2014 progress report by the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia because, while sensitive issues relating to media freedom, freedom of expression and the independence of the judiciary remain, and despite the need to note a political stalemate caused by the absolute lack of cooperation between the government and the opposition, Macedonia is aligning itself with the requirements for being part of the European Union. I also believe, in line with the position expressed by the Commission, that the issues highlighted above do not constitute an obstacle to the opening of negotiations, and that the opening of these negotiations can have a positive influence both on the process of reforms necessary for the country and on the current situation of political tension.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia has made further progress in improving its ability to take on the obligations of EU membership The country has completed the bulk of its reforms as regards the judicial system and the public administration and has made progress since becoming a candidate country in 2005, but the independence and competence of courts also needs to be further enhanced and more focus placed on the quality of justice provided to citizens. Recent developments brought about strong accusations between government and opposition and worsened the tense political situation.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted positively on the 2014 progress report on Macedonia because I believe that as an EU candidate for almost 10 years and as the most advanced country in terms of alignment with the European acquis, negotiations must be conducted as soon as possible. The Balkans must be part of this European Union and we must help them to ensure that this happens. Bilateral questions about the name dispute, between Greece and Macedonia, must in no way hinder Macedonia's accession negotiations with the European Union.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report reiterates for the ninth consecutive time its call on the Council to set a date for the start of accession negotiations without further delay and that bilateral issues should not represent an obstacle to the official opening of the negotiations. However the report also states that the Parliament is seriously concerned by the worsening of the relations between the government and the opposition, particularly with regard to recent announcement of charges against the opposition leader by the Prime Minister. While agreeing with S&D’s call for all political actors in the former Yugolsav Republic of Macedonia to engage in constructive dialogue I have voted in favour of this report which encourages the enlargement process.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This resolution takes note of the European Commission's progress report on progress in the negotiations to extend the European Union to the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. For the sixth year in a row, the report recommends the opening of accession negotiations with Macedonia, which was granted candidate status in 2005.  The European Parliament calls for the Council of Ministers to set a start date for negotiations and stresses that ongoing bilateral disputes in the region should not be an obstacle to opening negotiations.  At present, it is clear that Macedonia is still far from meeting all the necessary criteria for accession and it is necessary for Macedonia to undertake reforms, particularly in the area of freedom and independence of the media, as well as to protect freedom of expression and the independence of the judiciary. It is essential that Macedonia complies with European standards in this area if it is to be considered a credible candidate country. Considering all these elements, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. Every year, the European Commission reports on the progress made by the candidate countries, or potentially potentially so. This resolution thus reflects the Commission's recommendations on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.  I voted in favour of this resolution, which lists the policies in which the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia must evolve to meet European criteria, such as media freedom, the independence of the judiciary and freedom of expression.  However, this resolution does not constitute a passport to integration within the European Union, since no negotiating chapter has been opened to date. I am convinced that the European Union must take a lasting break from the enlargement process.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the parliamentary decision on FYROM. I consider it very important that we have adopted a document containing the positives that have been achieved, but in order for the country to develop, it points to the shortages and mistakes that FYROM still has to work on. I find it regrettable that the accession process has been delayed so long. This is certainly a bad signal for a country facing internal political tensions. It is crucial that the country moves out of this stagnant state as soon as possible and moves more strongly towards the euro integration process, which is what we should be helping here in the European Parliament.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. This text interferes with the legislative process of a third country, Macedonia, by calling for laws to be passed in favour of sexual minorities. It gives guidance to the State on how it should conduct its foreign policy, particularly vis-à-vis Greece. Finally, he is authoritarian in calling for "the proactive defence of a multi-ethnic and multi-faith, tolerant society".  This report is a pure product of the pro-European Union ideology, far from the daily reality of the citizens, which is why I voted against it.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU accession process for the FYROM is currently at an impasse.  There has also been no breakthrough in the long- running dispute with Greece, which dates back to the breakup of Yugoslavia in 1991.  FYROM applied to join the EU in 2004. In March 2012, a High-Level Accession Dialogue started with the EU offering new opportunities on EU-related priorities of benefit to the country's social and economic development, including the rule of law.   The report calls for fresh efforts to resolve the main issues, and warns of the risks of conflict in the Balkans.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the motion for a resolution because, contrary to what is proposed in the progress report, the resolution of the name must not be limited to bilateral level and independent of skopje's accession path.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, as Macedonia has been an EU candidate country for nine years, and I agree with Parliament's repeated calls for the Council to set a date for the opening of accession negotiations. Bilateral disputes have no place in a country's integration into the EU, and further delays in the opening of negotiations are increasing and unpredictable costs for the country and regional stability. Furthermore, the credibility of the European Union's enlargement policy is at stake. Macedonia is the most effective candidate country in alignment with the EU acquis and the start of accession negotiations can only have a positive impact on the resolution of bilateral disputes. I agree with the finding that all candidate and potential candidate countries should be dealt with on their own merits during the integration process.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia has been a candidate for EU membership for nine years and, according to reports, is prepared to negotiate with the EU. The Council has blocked the move to the next stage of the accession process due to the unresolved dispute over the country's name with Greece which should not constitute an obstacle to accession negotiations with the European Union. I believe it is important for the Council to set a date without delay for the start of the accession negotiations, so as not to lose momentum, to support the reforms related to the acquis and to strengthen the democratisation process. Bilateral issues cannot be an obstacle to the launch of the support talks, but should nevertheless be resolved before the end of the action process. It is essential for me that both governments take concrete steps to find a mutually acceptable solution.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. This report is a perfect illustration of the European Union's deep contempt for the people. Thus, the report calls on a sovereign country to "bring the anti-discrimination law into line with the ACQUIS of the Union, as this law does not prohibit discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation".  If it is to impose "marriage for all" by the European Union, I will address you in return this word from Chateaubriand, by analogy: "If I were to be imposed the Charter by Europe, I would go to Be Turkish in Constantinople"...

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This motion for a resolution presents a wide range of considerations on the process of integrating the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia into the EU. Far beyond the evaluation of the process, it points to a wide range of impositions for membership, which confirm the extent of the interference and loss of sovereignty imposed on countries and peoples in the process of EU membership.  Among others, particular reference should be made to the economic, judicial and political system, in the advanced foreign and security policy guidelines, including the country's membership of NATO, integrated into the militarisation of the EU and the enlargement of influence in the Balkans, among others. Recognizing and respecting the right of each country and of each people to decide sovereignly on whether or not they belong to the European Union, we cannot fail to condemn strongly this unacceptable stance of imposition of models of economic and social organisation, especially since these models that want to be imposed have already revealed to satiety their devastating consequences either from an economic point of view – especially for the weakest and least developed economies – either from the point of view of social view. For these reasons we voted against.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the 2014 Progress Report of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia commemorates the ninth consecutive time to set a date for the opening of accession negotiations without further delay, in particular with a view to supporting reforms and strengthening the democratisation process. The problem of the name of a country, which is a bilateral problem, must not be an obstacle to the opening of accession negotiations. We therefore call on the Government of Macedonia and Greece to take concrete measures towards accepting and adopting a mutually acceptable solution. Member States have committed themselves to returning to this issue in 2015 in order to start accession negotiations. The European Union must be more actively involved in the name issue itself in order to reach a solution. We welcome the fact that the European Union's agenda remains a strategic priority for the country, but we call for a reversal of policies and practices that could constitute an obstacle to its European future.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report as I do not share the political will behind the proposal.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the 2014 progress report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, because the resolution of the name must not be limited to bilateral level and independent of Skopje's accession path.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. As a candidate State to join the EU, we must note the country's efforts to include the acquis communautaire in its law. However, there are issues that must be resolved before its entry into the EU, such as the country's name, as well as internal political tensions, respect for separation of powers, anti-corruption, respect for freedom of expression etc. I encourage the Government of the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia to continue working on the consolidation of the rule of law and basic freedoms.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. This report reiterates the call on the Council, without further delay, to set a start date for accession negotiations and states that bilateral issues should not be an obstacle to the official opening of the negotiations. Most importantly, Parliament is seriously concerned about the worsening relations between the Government and the opposition, especially in relation to the recent announcement of charges against the opposition leader by the prime minister, and any illegal surveillance is condemned.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. This report reiterates the call on the Council, without further delay, to set a date for the start of accession negotiations and states that bilateral issues should not be an obstacle to the official opening of the negotiations. Most importantly, the European Parliament is seriously concerned about the worsening relations between the Government and the opposition, especially in relation to the recent announcement of charges against the leader of the opposition by the prime minister, and any illegal surveillance is condemned.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (FYROM) because it is high time for the Council to make progress on setting a date for the start of accession negotiations. Starting negotiations will be crucial in helping FYROM achieve the necessary reforms in the fields of the rule of law, independence of judicial power and the fight against corruption. This can only be achieved however, if the current deadlock between political forces in the country is solved. Therefore I urge the Commission and High Representative Mogherini to work with all parties in FYROM to facilitate internal dialogue.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against the Resolution on the view that international matters relating to the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia must be resolved before the opening of the negotiating partnership process to the European Union. In particular, we consider that bilateral neighbourhood issues with States already members of the European Union have not yet been resolved.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (FYROM) because it encourages FYROM to continue efforts to reform the rule of law and the fight against corruption in the country.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against the Resolution on the view that international affairs relating to the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia must be resolved before the opening of the negotiating partnership process to the European Union. In particular, we consider that bilateral neighbourhood issues with States already members of the European Union have not yet been resolved.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted to accept the progress report of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia for 2014, as I agree with the allegations in the adopted Resolution. In particular, I would like to highlight the need to establish the start of negotiations. I also believe that the name should not be an obstacle in the accession process, and negotiations can only improve the resolution of bilateral issues. Bilateral issues must not be an obstacle in the European accession process. Furthermore, I would highlight the problem of the country's polarising climate, deteriorating relations between the opposition and the ruling ones. I also condemn the unlawful oversight and call for an independent investigation, respecting the principles of impartiality, taking into account the fundamental principle of freedom of expression.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. This text interferes with the legislative process of a third country, Macedonia, by calling for laws to be passed in favour of sexual minorities. It gives guidance to the State on how it should conduct its foreign policy, particularly vis-à-vis Greece. Finally, he is authoritarian in calling for "the proactive defence of a multi-ethnic and multi-faith, tolerant society".  This report is a pure product of the pro-European Union ideology, far from the daily reality of the citizens, which is why I voted against it.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the 2014 follow-up report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. While substantial progress seems to be needed on freedom of expression, freedom of the press or the independence of the judiciary, I believe it is important not to slow down the momentum of reform and the process of democratization in the country.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the 2014 follow-up report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, which has been a candidate since 2005. The report outlines progress in negotiations between the European Union and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia as part of the enlargement policy. The start of negotiations with the European Union can only have a positive influence on the country's efforts to comply with EU rules. While also being a source of new necessary reforms, with regard to the rule of law, the independence of power and the fight against corruption.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I continue to support setting a date for EU accession talks to begin. I am, however, concerned about the impact which the current political crisis in the country is having on the prospects for realising that aim. I welcome the report's call for an independent investigation into all allegations and unauthorised surveillance, with full respect for the principles of transparency, impartiality and presumption of innocence. All political actors should engage in constructive dialogue.  I continue to strongly support the aspirations of the Western Balkan countries to engage in European reforms and to become EU members themselves. The process of integration will strengthen the democratic institutions of these countries, modernise their economies and thus improve the lives of citizens. Labour Party Members and the S&D Group will be sure to keep enlargement high on the EU’s political agenda.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – As before, an essential element of the resolution is the fact that a country that has not been able to find a name acceptable to the EU for more than 20 years has been given a given. Moreover, the state and the legal economy can only be described with negatives. At the same time, there is a European Union, the functioning of which is dissatisfied with the way most of its citizens operate, its money is unstable, its unemployment is rising stable and its development is sustained by the fact that the newly acceding countries are being forced into colonial ranks by multinational companies from the old Member States. It's hard for a thinker to get a workable plan out of this, so it's good for everyone to be able to join as soon as their GDP reaches the EU average

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of the resolution on the progress made by the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, and calls on the new High Representative, Federica Mogherini, to develop initiatives aimed at overcoming the deadlock in the European integration process.  The Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia has been a candidate for nine years to join the European Union, showing compliance with the requirements of the acquis communautaire, so I hope that we can move in the direction indicated in the resolution.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of a resolution on the follow-up report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. This text encourages constructive cooperation between the European Union and FYROM, but reminds us that much progress still needs to be made.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. National Front MPs voted against the resolution on the follow-up report on the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. This is, as is the case with all follow-up reports in the context of the enlargement policy, a very ideologically oriented text. In the federalist concept, the enlargement of the European Union is an end in itself, whereas the vast majority of voters in most Member States no longer want this policy of continuous enlargement. The Vaigl report is a typical example of the authoritarianism of the European Union. He advocates a Macedonia under European infusion, as well as very active pro-EU propaganda, notably by condemning "all forms of nationalism" and calling for the "voluntary defence of a multi-ethnic and multi-faith society".

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it constitutes interference in the internal affairs of a sovereign state. It wants to impose a policy dictated by the European Union.

name: Philippe Loiseau (NI)
text: In writing. Vote against. We are still opposed to the desire for enlargement. The report further proves the clear interference of the European Union, as is the case for all candidate countries.  There is interference in the country's policy on the recognition of sexual orientations but also in the area of diplomacy, in this case for that country with Greece. The European Union imposes its vision of the "ideal" society in its eyes for this country: multi-ethnic, multi-faith, in line with European practices.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because it maintains the line of Parliament's views on the applicant countries, in which a colonial relationship between a rich and powerful centre and an impoverished and obedient periphery is reproduced. In the case of the report put to the vote, there is also a need for States wishing to join the Union to maintain good relations with their members, which is not complied with by the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. The dispute around the country's name is a condition for starting negotiations for accession. However, the Resolution calls for the start of them before agreement is reached on the matter. For this reason, I decided to vote against it.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal which encourages the country to continue to consolidate reforms and change policies and practices that could still hinder its European future and to ensure progress towards the implementation of the priorities of EU-related reform, also in the context of the high-level dialogue on accession.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The Socialists and Democrats in Parliament welcome the adoption of the reports on Serbia, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (FYROM), Montenegro and Kosovo, and call on the Commission and the Council to show renewed EU commitment to the Western Balkans enlargement process.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the motion for a resolution, because Skopje continues its provocative attitude towards Greece, with skopje's altruism expressed by the counterfeiting of history and the burning of the name of our Macedonia. Also, Greece does not recognize the education of Skopje. The Greek people will not accept the burning of the name of our Macedonia from Skopje. Nor will the name of Skopje accept a complex name by any geographical designation. I am strongly opposed to any future accession of Skopje to the European Union. After all, the dead ends of this process can also be ascertained by the report we have discussed and which I am certainly voting against.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. Vote against. This resolution calls for ideological and authoritarian interference in the legislative affairs and foreign policy of another country.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report which welcomes the fact that the EU agenda remains the country’s strategic priority; encourages the country to further consolidate reforms and to reverse policies and practices which could still constitute obstacles for its European future, and to secure progress in the implementation of EU-related reform priorities, including in the context of the High-Level Accession Dialogue.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia has been an EU candidate country for nine years and is the most advanced country in terms of alignment with the acquis; and is certainly ready to start accession negotiations with the EU. Unfortunately, there is still an unresolved dispute with Greece over the name. The motion for a joint resolution contains a number of positive elements from my point of view, but the bulk of it is again expressed on the purely internal issues of each country, such as the absence of a constructive and inclusive dialogue between the government and the opposition, and the post-election boycott by the opposition, as well as the call for all NATO members to actively support the country's accession to NATO. These are matters on which I have a different opinion. However, since, of course, I do not reject EU enlargement and in no way oppose aid to Macedonia as our partner, I abstained in the final vote

name: n/a
text: in writing. \u2012 The frustration of macedonian public opinion about the stalling of the process of European integration risks exacerbating national problems, and internal tensions. That is why I have decided to support the progress report by the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, which calls on the new High Representative to develop initiatives to break this deadlock.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. The existing problem of Macedonia with the Albanian minority can become the next source of conflict in the Balkans.  Although Macedonia is part of the European family of nations, the deficits in the fight against corruption must first be reduced.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This resolution pushes for the start of negotiations for the accession to the European Union of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (FYROM), as internationally used at the United Nations, ignoring Greece's positions in the Council which opposes the name and the country's nationalist policy.  The resolution supports the current Atlanticist government. Good recommendations on freedom of expression, transparency or other rights should not be used as an excuse for this resolution to be strong. The European mirage of these countries will quickly turn into a nightmare when they see the first effects of the structural reforms demanded even before possible integration.  FYROM is the most advanced candidate country in terms of alignment with the Union's market economy policy and is already one of the poorest countries in the EU's neighbourhood. The unemployment rate is 30%, and the minimum wage is equivalent to 130 euros. The only answer given by the Union is the market economy and liberalisation. I vote against any enlargement under these conditions.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia has been the candidate country for EU membership for nine years, and is also the most advanced country in terms of alignment with the acquis.  Despite the difficulties in continuing with the enlargement policy, we must congratulate the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia on the developments it has shown. The Council should seek to find a date to restart negotiations in the near future. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution highlights the positive strides that the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia has made to reduce unemployment. It also outlines the positive work that has been done in the field of regional cooperation and states that it has no outstanding border issues with its neighbours. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution as it outlines the advancements made in fulfilling the accession criteria and the goals that have yet to be achieved.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, which has been a candidate for membership of the European Union since 16 December 2005, is the most advanced country in terms of alignment with the Community acquis. However, efforts are still needed in many areas, including corruption, the environment, the independence of the judiciary and political stability.  The report, of course, is to encourage the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia to continue its progress, but above all to provide it with support to enable it to overcome the political impasse in which it is currently in.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Progress Report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia reiterates for the ninth consecutive time that the Council should set a date for the start of accession negotiations without further delay and that bilateral issues should not represent an obstacle to the official opening of the negotiations. I fully support the call on all political actors to engage in constructive dialogue.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Western Balkans and the issue of enlargement is a major moral, political and strategic problem for the European Union. It will not go away, expectations will not go away, and our historic experience and commitments will not disappear. It poses crucial, existential questions for the Union itself, its democratic legitimacy and support among its citizens. I wish I had an answer of my own to this huge conundrum, putting in the balance so many destinies on either side of the equation.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report rightly points out that, despite the problems in the country, including those relating to the rule of law, corruption, organised crime, judicial independence, media and freedom of expression, Macedonia has been an EU candidate country for nine years. The opening of accession negotiations, despite the Commission's recommendation six times and parliament's nine calls, could not take place only because the Council resisted this because of the bilateral historical dispute with Greece over the country's name.  In my view, this situation is untenable and I share the reportman's view that this is a major disappointment to the public in Macedonia, undermines the CREDIBILITY of the EU in their eyes and may also undermine the results of democratisation so far.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia since its independence in 1991 has faced some opposition from the Greek side, in particular as to its nomenclature.  In 2004, macedonia's FYROM applied for membership of the Union, achieving candidate status in 2005. However, negotiations have not yet begun to date.  I am in favour of this report which calls for negotiations to begin as soon as possible. The country faces problems of political instability and violations of freedom of expression, the media, the independence of the judiciary that can be solved with the support of the Union. Despite the controversy I believe it is extremely important that we support the political, social and economic development of the people of the FYROM.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. This 2014 follow-up report on Macedonia shows unheard-of propaganda. It is scandalously interfering both in its foreign policy, by dictating the conduct to be taken with Greece in particular, but also on the internal level, since it requires compliance with the acquis of the European Union of a whole section of Macedonian legislation, all in a speech promoting the European Union. In short, the arrogance of the Union that is reverberant is in line with the globalist logic. So I decided to vote against it.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the 2014 follow-up report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (FYROM). The resolution provides an update on the status of negotiations with FYROM as part of its bid for EU membership. It notes that FYROM, a candidate for nine years, is the most advanced country in terms of alignment with the Community acquis, even though corruption and organised crime remain at a worrying level.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia has been a candidate for the EU for nine years and is the most advanced country in terms of alignment with the acquis communautaire. In view of the progress made, we believe that the country is ready to negotiate its accession, and we therefore call on the Council to launch all the procedures laid down. Indeed, we as a Parliament have repeatedly called for negotiations to start, believing that further delays could have a negative impact on the reform processes in the country and on the EU's credibility in the region. While we recognise the existence of the unresolved dispute with Greece over the naming issue, we are convinced that bilateral issues should not be an obstacle to negotiations. The lack of progress in the process of European integration could increase the costs to regional stability and credibility of the EU, as well as lead to a decline in the country's democratic norms. We are also concerned about the continuing deterioration of relations between the government and the opposition, particularly with regard to the recent exchange of allegations of criminal offences. We therefore call on all parties to ensure sustainable political cooperation, to lay the foundations for constructive dialogue, which is essential for the democratic development of the country and the pursuit of the European agenda.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it presents the progress of the dossier of a country applying for membership of the European Union and merely takes stock of the country's progress annually.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to support the resolution because I believe that the time has come for the Council to give the green light to the opening of EU accession negotiations and for the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia and Greece finally to find, through the mediation of the High Representative for Foreign Policy, a mutually acceptable solution on the controversial issue of the name 'Macedonia'.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 FYRM is one of the countries that is ready to start negotiations with the EU and i voted therefore for this report.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: scríofa. ‒ Staon mé ón vóta seo mar cheap mé go raibh gnéithe frithráiteach le fáil ann.  Iarrann an tuarascáil seo ar na húdaráis agus ar an tsochaí shibhialta deireadh a chur leis an deighilt eitneach agus féiniúlachta sa Mhacadóin, agus cuirim fáilte roimhe seo.
