In Éirinn táimid fós ag obair i dtreo an athmhuintearais náisiúnta agus chun meas ar gach féiniúlacht a bhaint amach. Le déanaí ag ár gcomhdháil náisiúnta agus é ag labhairt faoin bPróiseas Síochána in Éirinn, dúirt Cathaoirleach Shinn Féin: ‘There should be a fearless resolve to dismantle barriers and build bridges by all sides. Those who want to push the Peace Process backwards, and directly, or implicitly oppose reconciliation should be challenged, without fear or favour.’ Is trua mór é go n-iarrann an tuarascáil seo ar an Macadóin aontachas a dhéanamh le NATO áfach. Creidim go dtéann forleathnú NATO díreach i gcoinne na síochána agus an athmhuintearais agus mar sin staon mé ón vóta seo.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report as it notes in general the efforts made by Macedonia to reform and improve its legislation and practices in line with its European vocation. It is unfortunate that the name issue is still persists to this day and we deeply believe that it is high time to solve it and allow Macedonia a full way into the EU in the future.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on the progress report of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia for 2014. Accession negotiations must be started immediately in order not to lose momentum and to accelerate reforms relating to the EU acquis and to strengthen the democratisation process. Delaying the start of accession talks will complicate the internal situation of this country.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The reports on the accession path of the countries of the Western Balkans, Serbia, Montenegro, Macedonia, call for the ACCELERATION by the EU and their civil governments of unpopular reforms in these countries, which target labour-popular rights, remove any obstacles to the establishment of business groups and their profitability.  The accession process of these countries exacerbates all the problems of workers, intensifies their exploitation for the benefit of monopolies, implicates them in the dangerous imperialist plans of the EU-US-NATO and the competition raging in the wider region for resources of wealth, with unforeseen painful consequences against them.  The peoples of the Balkans have an interest in strengthening and coordinating their fight against the EU and NATO, in every imperialist alliance of capital and the capitalist path of development, opposing their own popular alliance for power, which will pave the way for peace, mutually beneficial cooperation and solidarity, for popular prosperity.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia has been a candidate for the EU for nine years and is the most advanced country in terms of alignment with the acquis and that, for the sixth time in a row, the Commission has recommended that the Council start negotiations; that the country is ready to negotiate with the EU; Whereas the rule of law, freedom of the media, regional cooperation and good neighbourly relations are essential criteria for the EU enlargement process and considering that corruption and organised crime are still a serious problem; reiterating for the third time in a row its request to the Council to set a date for the start of negotiations as soon as possible so as not to lose momentum and to promote reforms linked to the acquis strongly encourages the authorities and civil society to take appropriate measures for historical reconciliation in order to bridge the gap between and within the various ethnic groups; Noting that the EU programme remains a strategic priority of the country, reforms and the reversal of policies that could still hamper its European future are being called for, I voted in favour.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ It is of the utmost importance that accession negotiations with the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia start as soon as possible. The EU will start losing its credibility and transformational power in the region if accession negotiations are systematically blocked by bilateral issues, which are much easier to solve with the launch of accession negotiations. There is no added value in further postponing the opening of negotiations, which are the best way to continue the Macedonian reform process. The dispute between the government and the main opposition parties is damaging for the functioning of democracy and also has a negative effect on the EU accession process and the general standing of the country. In this regard, the Joint Parliamentary Commitee (JPO) I co-chair is an important tool for exchanging views,  enhancing dialogue and political culture, promoting better understanding and ultimately forging political commitments which would improve the accession process. Therefore, I really hope that Macedonian leaders both in government and in the opposition find a political agreement in order to ensure that the parliament is fully represented and inter alia help in restoring the full functioning of the JPC.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. This 2014 follow-up report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, which is again very ideologically oriented, advocates genuine interference in the legislative process and calls for the promotion of the European Union worthy of Soviet propaganda. This is not surprising since the Union, which is equal to itself, intends to subject States and peoples to its dictatorship of single thought and to its globalist ideology. It even calls on Macedonia to "condemn all forms of nationalism; calls for a proactive defence of a multi-ethnic and multi-faith, tolerant society where everyone has a place." Quite a program! Finally, it no longer hesitates to interfere in its foreign policy by indicating the directions it must take, especially with Greece. So I voted against this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support colleague Vajgla's report, his first, which presented the situation in Macedonia and all the problems they face in a comprehensive and realistic way. It is unacceptable that for the ninth time negotiations have been called for without any result. The current situation of blockade is damaging Macedonia, but it can have serious implications for the entire region. Turkey and Iceland are clear examples of how the European Union project has lost momentum on the periphery. The European Union needs to know what it wants with the Area of the Western Balkans located in its inner courtyard. This is especially true for Macedonia, which, along with Bosnia and Herzegovina, urgently needs a new approach. Its citizens are pro-European, but Macedonia must first sort out its affairs on home soil, such as the latest affair about the eavesdropping of thousands of citizens, in order to make more convincing arguments to their friends in Europe, among whom I certainly am, that we can jointly end a blockade that has been going on too long.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia has been an EU candidate country for nine years and is the most advanced country in terms of alignment with the acquis, so I strongly support the text of the resolution, which again, for the ninth year in a row, calls on the Council to set a date for the start of accession negotiations without further delay, despite the still unexplained name of the country. I am also glad that the European Parliament has adopted my proposed recommendation that "the EU should develop a more active participation in the process of finding an acceptable format for the country name and that the new Vice-President of the Commission, the High Representative, should cooperate with the UN Special Representative on these issues in this regard." While many of the country's reforms have been successfully implemented or have already been completed, it is impossible to close our eyes to the deteriorating relations between the government and opposition since last year's elections, the accusations of the opposition leader and the prime minister's counter-accusations, and the likely manipulation of the media in this context. Independent examination of all allegations and respect for the presumption of innocence is the basis of the rule of law, and this must be respected by any country that is serious about EU membership.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is in a good position in terms of alignment with the acquis communautaire, I believe that now is the time to start negotiations with the EU.  With this in mind, the country should further consolidate reforms and commit itself to ensuring progress in implementing the EU-related priority reforms. In order to make progress, however, there must be a better political climate and political parties must improve their relations and a constructive dialogue must be established in order to ensure political stability. I also hope that a solution will be found to the bilateral issue of naming.  With this in mind, relations with neighbouring countries should be improved, with an interpretation of objective history, better attitudes of the population towards their neighbours and better reconciliation between the various ethnic groups.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Macedonia's European integration is still hampered by a bilateral problem with Greece, which not only denies the country recognition of its name, but also complicates the opening of accession talks with the European Union. I would like to take this opportunity to support the position of both the Commission and the European Parliament, with both of these institutions repeatedly proposing that Macedonia be given the opportunity to start the accession process. Of course, the country faces some problems, but it is Europe's future that may motivate it to improve the rule of law, the quality of public administration, or combat corruption. The 2014 progress report mentions the achievements and shortcomings that accompany Macedonia's journey to the Union and therefore deserves our support. I believe that the slogan of Macedonia's approach to the Union, which, with reference to macedonian national symbols and Union symbols, also reads 'The sun is a star' will soon come true.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. The former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia has been a candidate country for EU membership for nine years and is also the most advanced country in terms of acquis alignment. This resolution reiterates the Commission's recommendation to the Council for the opening of negotiations with a view to the accession of that country to the EU.  I welcome the high level of alignment with the legislative acquis and the improvement of efficiency and professionalism of the courts resulting from comprehensive judicial reforms and record the positive developments in the implementation of the 2011-2015 anti-corruption programmes by the candidate country.  I also welcome the fact that the country has maintained an active and constructive attitude in the field of regional cooperation and that there is no pending border dispute with neighbouring countries. Furthermore, I believe that the issue of the name of the country raised by Greece, being a bilateral issue, cannot be an obstacle to the launch of the support talks. Finally, I would remind you that the delay in opening these negotiations can have a negative impact on the reform processes in the country, exacerbate internal tensions and affect the EU's credibility in the region. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. I supported this resolution as it calls on the Council to set a date for the start of accession negotiations without delay, so as not to lose the momentum presented by Macedonia, to support reforms and to strengthen the democratisation process. I also argue that the issue of the name of the country cannot constitute an obstacle to the launch of the association talks, but should nevertheless be resolved before the end of the application process. Even if the support does not take place quickly, it is important that the candidate countries can initiate structural reforms that will allow them to bring european designs and principles closer together.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. In July 2014, European Commission President-elect Jean-Claude Juncker declared in the Chamber that "there will be no further enlargement in the next five years". A common-sense proposal that was high on the agenda of the MR programme during the last European elections. This need to solidify the House of Europe before it is enlarged does not mean that the ongoing negotiations with the countries of the near neighbourhood such as the Western Balkans must stop. These countries need a European perspective, but it must be recognised that both Serbia, Kosovo, Montenegro and Macedonia do not meet European standards today. In particular, European decision-makers are willing to pay much more attention to chapters 23 ("judicial apparatus and fundamental rights") and 24 ("justice, freedom, security"). With regard to the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, which was granted candidate status in December 2005, we are well aware that the Council is preventing macedonia from entering the next stage of the accession process because of the unresolved conflict over its name with Greece. But other problems remain: the independence of the judiciary, the fight against corruption, and the list is not exhaustive.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. It is important that a date for the start of Macedonia's accession negotiations to the European Union be set without delay, as member states have committed themselves to returning to this issue in 2015 in order to open accession negotiations. However, Macedonia has yet to address some gaps in its internal policy. It is imperative that the government pursues a policy of strengthening media pluralism and diversity of opinions. The high rate of child poverty and the lack of capacity of the institutions responsible for implementing policies and strategic actions in this area are also worrying.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which reiterates, for the ninth time in a row, the call on the Council, without further delay, to set a date for the start of accession negotiations with the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia while considering that bilateral issues should not be an obstacle to the official opening of the negotiations. In the report, Parliament condemns any illegal surveillance and expresses serious concern about the progressive deterioration of relations between the Government and the opposition, especially in relation to the recent announcement of charges against the leader of the opposition by the prime minister.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The resolution voted this afternoon relates to the last follow-up report published by the European Commission in October 2014, and the conclusions of the European Council in December 2014. In its report, the EU executive recommended, for the sixth year in a row, the opening of accession negotiations with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.  The text of the European Parliament's resolution expresses some concerns. In particular, concerning media freedom, freedom of expression and the independence of the judiciary, areas in which the authorities are being called upon to consolidate the necessary reforms. Recent events have led to serious accusations between the government and the opposition and further degraded the already tense political situation in the country. The resolution also deplores the lack of a political culture and constructive political dialogue and calls for independent investigations and checks.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this text, which refers to the progress made by the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia in 2014 on reforms.  Some concerns are expressed in this report, including media freedom, freedom of expression and the independence of the judiciary, for which the necessary reforms are called for to be consolidated. In addition, recent events have led to serious accusations between the government and the opposition, degrading the political situation in the country.  Finally, the lack of constructive political dialogue is regrettable and remains a concern.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution reiterates the need to set a date for the open of negotiations, while highlighting the lack of a political culture and the restriction of certain fundamental freedoms. Through the negotiations, the EU hopes to stimulate Macedonia towards a necessary path of democratisation for the good of the whole continent.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against the resolution in considering that international affairs relating to the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia must be resolved before opening the negotiating partnership process to the European Union. In particular, we consider that there are still bilateral neighbourhood issues with states already members of the European Union that have not yet been resolved.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls on the Council to finally set a date to start accession negotiations with the Republic of Macedonia and break the deadlock on the question of its name, which is poisoning relations between Greece and the "former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia". Indeed, Greece vetoes the accession process because of its opposition to the use of the name "Macedonia" by this neighbouring country, for historical, political and geographical reasons.  Parliament calls on the Commission to present initiatives to renew the dialogue and relaunch the negotiations so as not to threaten the country's reform and democratisation process, as well as its European aspirations. This follow-up report does not prejudge Macedonia's rapid accession to the European Union.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (NI)
text: In writing. This report constitutes a marked interference in Macedonian politics. The report calls on Macedonia to change its codes of law as well as its relations with certain states such as Greece. We are here a long way from the spirit and letter of the Copenhagen criteria. This interference motivates my opposition to the text.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because it maintains the line of Parliament's views on the applicant countries, in which a colonial relationship between a rich and powerful centre and an impoverished and obedient periphery is reproduced. In the case of the report put to the vote, there is also a need for States wishing to join the Union to maintain good relations with their members, which is not complied with by the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. The dispute around the country's name is a condition for starting negotiations for accession. However, the Resolution calls for the start of them before agreement is reached on the matter. That's why I voted against it.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Overall, the country has achieved a high level of alignment with the European acquis, but there are specific concerns about the politicisation of state institutions. A significant problem here is the political crisis manifested in the escalation of the conflict between the government and opposition parties. It is therefore difficult to imagine further progress in the country's integration into the EU without a constructive internal political dialogue. It should also not be forgotten that, before the Ukrainian conflict, the last armed conflict took place in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. Furthermore, the political crisis in the country may undermine the accession negotiations, which is why it is now so important to ensure that the agreement reached in March 2013 is met.  The country's long-term interests require well-functioning institutions, which is not helped by the growing criticism from the opposition and political opponents blaming the government for further shortcomings. While the evidence surrounding the accusations cannot be ignored, it is also important to be aware of the country's complicated history. Nevertheless, there is a credibility deficit, the improvement of which requires the country to make appropriate binding declarations.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs supported the motion for a resolution on the progress report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. The report reiterates its call on the Council to set a date for the start of accession negotiations without further delay. Bilateral issues should not represent an obstacle to the official opening of the negotiations.  It also emphasises the ongoing need for reform in the country in areas such as civil society engagement, the civil service and freedom of expression.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I voted in favour because I believe in the continuation of a high-level accession dialogue that can help the quality of the reform process in the country.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the Resolution on The Progress of Macedonia, which has been a candidate for MEMBERSHIP in the European Union for nine years, given the fact that it has made significant progress in aligning legislation with the European Union. She demonstrated her readiness for the EU accession process by improving business conditions as a leader in the Western Balkans region, with progress also made in the labour market and the unemployment rate falling from 29% to 27.9%. Macedonia is also the first country in the region to prepare a document from the National Climate Change Plan, listing climate change adaptation and reduction measures in each sector. I believe that the problem of a name opposed by Greece should not delay the launch of negotiations, on the contrary, neighbouring countries should not be a threat to each other, and there are much more important issues that should be a priority. Despite the assessment of progress, social inequality and poverty rates rose, while the lowest level of media freedom in the region was recorded, dropping from 34th place to 117th place. Croatia gives its full support to Macedonia in European integration, with which it has maintained co-operation and good relations for years, and the prosperity and stability of the country is not only in the Croatian interest, but also in the interest of its neighbours and the whole of Europe.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The resolution on the 2014 progress report of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is well written and balanced. It covers all the important aspects that have been highlighted in the report, which is why I voted in favour of the resolution. The former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia has been among the candidates for accession to the EU for nine years and has made the most progress in aligning with the acquis. It should be stressed that for the last eight years the European Parliament has consistently called for the opening of accession negotiations with that country, and any further postponing the start of negotiations could have a negative impact on the country's reform processes and the EU's credibility in the region. Despite the enormous progress the country has made in recent years, corruption and organised crime remain a major problem, and freedom of expression and media independence are also under threat. The polarised political climate in the country is also worrying. Therefore, the government must respect the role of parliament and provide sufficient time and opportunities for consultation, including on constitutional changes, to allow for smooth and independent parliamentary scrutiny. Unfortunately, there is no cooperation with civil society organisations and public stakeholders in the drafting of legislation. Civil society organisations can make an important contribution to raising public awareness of the accession process and help make it more transparent, more accountable and inclusive.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ I welcome the progress macedonia has made. We are ready to share with him our experience of the reform process. EU enlargement has proved to be a success story, and I am sure that it should continue to the Countries of the Western Balkans.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support this report and welcome the fact that the state continues positive developments in improving business conditions and its shift from 31st place in 2013 to 30th place in the World Bank rankings in 2014. However, it is common for contractual obligations to be carried out with difficulties and that frequent legal changes that occur without proper consultation constitute serious obstacles to creating a business environment. At the same time, I would stress the importance of making progress on labour law and strengthening social dialogue, and that the business environment needs to be further improved by supporting SMEs, reducing differences between regions and linking research and development institutions with the entrepreneurial and employment sectors. I welcome the stable flow of foreign direct investment that has diversified exports. It is noted that 80% of total FDI comes from EU companies, and that the exchange of services and goods with the EU has increased further. I emphasise the importance of attracting foreign investment and believe that the stalemate in the EU accession process could be an obstacle to deeper economic integration. I therefore welcome the opening of negotiations with Macedonia as soon as possible.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as, for the ninth consecutive time, it calls on the Council to set a date for the start of FYROM's accession negotiations. Furthermore, the report calls for more active engagement on the country's name issue and draws attention to the ongoing need for reform in areas such as civil society engagement, the civil service and freedom of expression.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. – Concerns have been raised about media freedom, freedom of expression and the independence of the judiciary, where authorities are instructed to strengthen the necessary reforms. The resolution expresses concern over the lack of political culture and constructive political dialogue due to strong accusations between the government and the opposition. It calls on the government and all political parties to work to improve relations in order to maintain political stability, establish sustainable constructive political cooperation and accelerate the implementation of the European agenda. Recalls that the foundations of democracy are based on compromises, stresses the need to improve the transparency of the accession process and participation in it, stresses that the issue of post-election boycott should be addressed in a spirit of shared responsibility of the government and the opposition towards the smooth work of parliament, calls on the VP/HIGH Representative to work with all parties to improve political dialogue. It also condemns any form of unlawful surveillance and calls for allegations to be made public and reported, calls for an independent investigation into the surveillance carried out and any allegations of this, while respecting the principles of transparency, impartiality and presumptions of non-compliance, reiterates the importance of adhering to the fundamental principle of freedom of expression, and calls on all political participants to engage in constructive dialogue in order to maintain a focus on the strategic priorities of the country and its citizens. That's why I support this report.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I supported the resolution on the progress of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia for 2014. I welcome the fact that bringing the European Union closer remains a strategic priority for Macedonia. There have been repeated political crises between the government and the opposition in the country. Constructive and inclusive dialogue is needed. The government and the opposition must show sufficient political responsibility and constructive dialogue so that they can resolve all outstanding issues and step up efforts to reform the country. It is also necessary to establish appropriate control mechanisms and to correct errors in the area of judicial independence.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The resolution emphasises the difference in name and essentially calls for Greece's objections to be bypassed in order to start negotiations immediately. It calls, in fact, on all NATO states to support Macedonia's accession to the Alliance.  The resolution also calls for negotiations on EU membership to begin and for the name issue to be resolved before they are concluded. We, from a principled point of principle, argue that the problem of naming must be seen within the framework of international law and under the auspices of the UN in order to find a commonly accepted solution before the start of negotiations. We recognise the term Macedonia in Macedonia, but only as a geographical concept as opposed to the way the Macedonian leadership perceives it. We therefore support a commonly accepted solution that states exclusively geographical definition, away from nationalisms that divide peoples. By avoiding nationalist propaganda, we are in favour of an attempt at a commonly accepted peaceful solution. That is why we voted against the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This report tends to repeal all UN, European Council and Parliament resolutions on the name issue, which is unacceptable.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the 2014 report on the progress made by the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, inter alia, because it rightly calls on the Council to set a date for the opening of accession negotiations. It is very important for the stability of the region that the momentum and commitment to reforms remain in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, since, as the motion emphasises, the country is the most effective candidate country in terms of alignment with the ACQUIS. I also welcome the fact that the motion urges the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia to join NATO in order to ensure stability in the region.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ As a long friend of Macedonia it is disappointing that negotiations are still to be opened, particularly bearing in mind its strong and existing alignment with the acquis. As noted in the resolution, this is now the ninth time Parliament has called upon the Council to open negotiations. The Thessaloniki Agenda states that all Western Balkan countries have a European Union perspective and Macedonia should prove no exception. I welcome therefore the resolution’s call for the High Representative to support the UN’s Special Representative, Matthew Nimetz, in finding a mutually acceptable solution to the unresolved name issue, and its reference that bilateral issues should not prevent the accession process of potential members. This issue aside I welcome the calls regarding potential NATO membership. However, I do think it necessary to remind Macedonia of its commitments concerning Chapter 31 of the acquis and therefore note its failure to join in applying EU-wide sanctions against Russia. Many reforms will be needed before Macedonia can join the EU, especially considering recent allegations of electoral malpractice and corruption, but it is difficult to encourage these whilst the accession process remains stalled. I hope therefore that next year I will be able to welcome the opening of negotiations.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. It is sad, even ridiculous, that this is our 9th request to the Council to set without further delay a date for the start of accession negotiations, so as not to break the momentum, to accelerate the reforms linked to the acquis and to strengthen the process of democratisation. It should be remembered that the dispute over the country's designation, which is a bilateral issue, cannot be an obstacle to the opening of negotiations, although it must be resolved before the end of the accession process.  We share the Commission's view that the inability of the parties to reach a compromise after nearly twenty years of mediation discussions has a direct and negative impact on the European aspirations of the country and its people. We call on both governments to take concrete steps to identify a solution acceptable to both parties. Let us reiterate the importance and need for a constructive approach to problems with neighbouring countries on these bilateral issues.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which calls on the Council to set a date without further delay for the start of accession negotiations for the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. Such a decision would help to accelerate the reforms in the country and to strengthen the process of democratisation.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ 2014 Progress report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. The former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia has been a candidate for EU membership for nine years and is the most advanced country in terms of adaptation. During the last eight years the European Parliament has repeatedly demanded the opening of accession negotiations with the country and that further delay of these negotiations could have a negative impact on the country’s reform process and the credibility of the EU in the region, but the Council locks due to unresolved issues with Greece. These issues should not be an obstacle to the official opening of accession negotiations, but should be addressed as soon as possible so that history, culture, education and promotion of European values, to support initiatives in favour of democratic changes, is also a reality in Macedonia. I have given my support to this motion because I believe that a good agreement between all parties will benefit everyone.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. This is a new report that is very ideologically oriented, in line with other reports on the Eastern States. The European Parliament advocates real interference in the legislative process.  There is also interference in the direction of the country's external relations, particularly in its relations with Greece. The report therefore advocates a Macedonia under European infusion, as well as a very active pro-European Union propaganda. I voted AGAINST.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against the Resolution on the view that international matters relating to the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia must be resolved before the opening of the negotiating partnership process to the European Union. In particular, we consider that bilateral neighbourhood issues with States already members of the European Union have not yet been resolved.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on developments in Macedonia's accession to the EU.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. This report reiterates the call on the Council, without further delay, to set a date for the start of accession negotiations and states that bilateral issues should not be an obstacle to the official opening of the negotiations. Most importantly, the European Parliament is seriously concerned about the worsening relations between the Government and the opposition, especially in relation to the recent announcement of charges against the leader of the opposition by the prime minister, and any illegal surveillance is condemned.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because it maintains the line of Parliament's views on the applicant countries, in which a colonial relationship between a rich and powerful centre and impoverished and obedient periphery is reproduced. In the case of the report put to the vote, there is also a need for States wishing to join the Union to maintain good relations with their members, which is not complied with by the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. The dispute around the country's name is a condition for starting negotiations for accession. However, the Resolution calls for the start of them before agreement is reached on the matter. For this reason, I decided to vote against it.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. European Commission President Juncker had announced at the start of his mandate that there would be no enlargement of the Union for the first five years. This does not, of course, mean that negotiations with candidate countries are not continuing, especially since such negotiations can easily drag on for 10 years. The Balkan countries (Serbia, Kosovo, the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia and Montenegro) are continuing to negotiate and are certainly not meeting European requirements to become members today. There are also many problems of corruption, human rights and the rule of law in the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. It is up to the EU to continue to step up this pressure for reform so that the country meets the standards at some point and can possibly become a member of the EU.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We respect the sovereign will of the people of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, in particular in deciding to join the EU or not. However, we see in this report another exercise of seduction that no longer lives to tie this country more to the neoliberal and militaristic agenda of the EU and NATO. With possible support, it will once again be the people who suffer the consequences of this enlargement which corresponds to an insatiable desire of the EU to expand its market, while ensuring and expanding its military control over that area of Europe.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. The existing problem of Macedonia with the Albanian minority can become the next source of conflict in the Balkans. Although Macedonia is part of the European family of nations, the deficits in the fight against corruption must first be reduced.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I am against the enlargement of the EU. In this respect, I do not agree with the appropriate preparation. This attitude will not change until the EU and its institutions are fundamentally renewed and reformed and we are once again developing the EU as a federation of sovereign states and not as a federation of states.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted against Macedonia's Progress report, as once again Parliament is sending the wrong signals to the candidate country. While everyone recognises that the situation in Macedonia has deteriorated in recent years, the resolution calls for the opening of negotiations, even blaming Greece for the name issue. It needs to be made clear to everyone. The country's own government and its intransigence both at home and in relations with its neighbours are solely responsible for the situation in Macedonia. As far as the name issue is concerned, only two things: Firstly, the name issue is not bilateral, as some argue. It is international, as the United Nations has explicitly acknowledged. Secondly, no Greek government will agree to the opening of accession negotiations unless this issue has been resolved beforehand. Hiding problems "under the carpet" has been clearly proven to be a failed practice. To appeal to Greece, because it exercises a perfectly legitimate right, is at least hypocritical, especially when in the past other countries have refused enlargements on matters of much lesser importance. In the name of 'supposed stability', we will not accept any distortion of our history.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The reports on the accession path of the countries of the Western Balkans, Serbia, Montenegro, Macedonia, call for the ACCELERATION by the EU and their civil governments of unpopular reforms in these countries, which target labour-popular rights, remove any obstacles to the establishment of business groups and their profitability.  The accession process of these countries exacerbates all the problems of workers, intensifies their exploitation for the benefit of monopolies, implicates them in the dangerous imperialist plans of the EU-US-NATO and the competition raging in the wider region for resources of wealth, with unforeseen painful consequences against them.  The peoples of the Balkans have an interest in strengthening and coordinating their fight against the EU and NATO, in every imperialist alliance of capital and the capitalist path of development, opposing their own popular alliance for power, which will pave the way for peace, mutually beneficial cooperation and solidarity, for popular prosperity.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is one of the candidate countries whose future accession to the EU is highly controversial, I am of the opinion that we must not leave bilateral disputes at the forefront of this debate. Macedonia's future is in the EU and the EU must start accession negotiations as soon as possible.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This motion for a resolution presents a wide range of recitals on the process of integrating the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia into the EU. In addition to the evaluation of the process, it points to a wide range of impositions for membership, which confirm the extent of the interference and loss of sovereignty imposed on countries and peoples in the process of EU membership. We highlight the meddling in the negotiation with Greece in defining the country's name, in the economic, judicial and political system, in the advanced foreign and security policy guidelines, including the country's membership of NATO integrated into the militarisation of the EU and the widening of influence in the Balkan region, among others. We consider unacceptable the manor attitude with which the recitals and conditions required to satisfy the precepts relating to the integration of the country are unacceptable, removing from the peoples the legitimate right to decide their future, where they are part, the free and sovereign choice of EU membership, but also of economic and social development strategies. For these reasons we voted against.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – As a member of the cooperation delegation with Serbia, I welcome this report, which describes the progress made by Serbia in a number of areas over the last year.  On the other hand, I consider the report to be balanced, because it also draws attention to the problems that are still being pursued by Serbia. As a person who has dealt with the judiciary at his national level, I am particularly interested in those points that touch on judicial reforms, police reforms and the fight against corruption. It is clear that even as Serbia seeks to reform the judiciary, there is still much to improve on the road to the rule of law. It is good that this call is clearly explicitly stated in the report that without Serbia being a clear rule of law, it is difficult to become a member of the European Union.  I think that we should help Serbia in this matter, because the reform of the state, the police and the judiciary are among the most difficult, and all the new Member States that used to belong to the post-communist bloc were waiting for these reforms, and those who want to enter will be waiting for them.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – I was very happy to support the resolution on Serbia's progress. It speaks of the great efforts of the Serbian Government to ensure that both through the reform programme, with better relations in the region, as well as with the rest... progress in the functioning of the rule of law respects europe's values. I believe that the people of Serbia deserve europe to stand in solidarity with them and that they develop a country as soon as possible to the point where it is able to join the European Union. The efforts of the current government, as well as the great enthusiasm of the Serbian people to take the pro-European path, must be upgraded with this European solidarity, as well as with pre-accession assistance and other instruments, to prepare Serbia for EU entry as soon as possible. I wish them every success along the way.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – I have also supported this report, but we must send a clear message to the Government in Belgrade that, on its path to European integration, it must respect the rights of every national minority on its territory recognised by the Republic of Serbia itself, the rights of every national minority to be taught in native language, to have textbooks in their native language , to speak his native language. We are talking about the Bulgarian national minority in the western Bulgarian outskirts, which is recognized by Serbia, but so far absolute setbacks and severe problems are made to this minority to be able to study their native Bulgarian language and use Bulgarian textbooks. This must be our clear message to Serbia on the otherwise acceptable, otherwise legitimate, otherwise normal path to its European integration.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I supported rapporteur David McAllister's 2014 Resolution on Serbia's Progress Report, as its key message is that Serbia needs to be helped to implement reforms to continue its European path.  In my view, the European Commission, which has a duty to take care of the protection of the rule of law, should also play an important role in this. The rapporteur took into question most of the amendments that I submitted with my colleagues from the Croatian EPP delegation, highlighting in particular the issue of the status of the Croatian national minority in Vojvodina and the problem of missing persons. I am also pleased that our colleagues in the European Parliament have begun to understand how problematic the Law on the Organization and Competence of State Organs in the War Crimes Procedure is, by which Serbia abuses the principle of universal jurisdiction, as evidenced by the amendment of the author of the resolution that was adopted today and thus made this issue international.  In serbia's case, the European Commission can no longer push problems under the rug, but must start solving them. I therefore call on them once again to seriously learn the disputed Law and ask Serbia to abolish Articles 2 and 3 of that Law. It is also necessary to enable the transfer of Veljko Maric to Croatia and allow him a fair trial.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – In historical, cultural and economic terms, Serbia, like the other Western Balkan countries, is part of Europe. Therefore, with the country's accession to the European Union, this natural state will only be confirmed. The Serbian Government is aware that only the settlement of the situation of indigenous minorities in the territory of the country and reconciliation with neighbouring countries and peoples can bring lasting development to the much-suffering Serbian society. I support the motion, which encourages Serbia to prepare a specific action plan on the situation of national minorities. The settlement of the minority situation in the Western Balkans is not necessary because of the European Union, it should not be a mandatory task to be carried out under external pressure, but should be an expression of an internal need that can steer the process towards normality. We hope that Serbia will be able to set an example for many EU Member States, as experience has shown that some Member States, Romania and Slovakia, for example, are experiencing a setback in this area.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – I must say that in monitoring Serbia in the process of moving closer to European integration, it is important to note that Serbia has made great strides in various areas in recent years, including reforms, including justice, on reforms that are important for meeting the conditions for accession to the European Union. It is true, however, that some external circumstances were not particularly favourable to them. I am talking, of course, about the floods that have affected Serbia and some other countries. And I think that in a situation where Serbia is also economic, I think it is also necessary to look at challenges in this area, which can lead Serbia to european integration more quickly. And I think it is very important to emphasise the role of neighbouring countries and their relations. And I think that just when we are talking about Serbia, it is also necessary to be so much in solidarity that Serbia is helped in this and, of course, that it is not hindered.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. The report welcomes the formal start of accession negotiations on 21 January 2014 at the first Summit of the EU-Serbian Intergovernmental Coordination Group and commends the good implementation of the EU-Serbia Stabilisation and Association Agreement. However, the report also draws attention to the country's problems, such as freedom of the press, deteriorating conditions for freedom of expression, lack of transparency in the financing of political parties and election campaigns. The report also invites Serbia, inter alia, to make greater efforts to ensure equal representation of women in political and public life, to improve the situation of Roma and to ensure the consistent implementation throughout the country of legislation on the protection of minorities.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because it maintains the line of Parliament's views on the applicant countries, in which a colonial relationship between a rich and powerful centre and an impoverished and obedient periphery is reproduced. In this particular case, in addition to meddling in the internal affairs of the State to press for the Neoliberal agenda of the European Union, Serbia is asked to recognize the self-proclaimed Republic of Kosovo to 'facilitate' its accession.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – There are some positives in this progress report for Serbia, particularly calls for enhancing human rights, children's rights, fundamental freedoms, respect for cultural and linguistic diversity, justice and reconciliation. These recommendations are all important issues that need to be dealt with in a post-conflict society such as Serbia. In Ireland's experience, the Good Friday Agreement commits signatories to delivering an Irish Language Act and a Bill of Rights for the north and a Charter of Human Rights for All-Ireland. We are still fighting for the implementation of these. So I welcome enhancing human rights protections in Serbia. However, I am concerned by calls for "structural economic reforms" and "fiscal consolidation". In Ireland's experience these so-called reforms, at the behest of the EU, have caused much hardship, particularly to the most vulnerable. On this basis I abstained.

name: Lucy Anderson (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The contribution of the European Parliament to the 2014 progress report on Serbia underlines the agreement of most members with the decision of the European Council to launch accession negotiations. The many amendments to this resolution tabled this year led to a balanced result. I was therefore pleased to vote for the resolution. I am particularly supportive of the points in the resolution recalling that the EU has placed the rule of law at the centre of our enlargement policy. In addition, I fully support the calls for further early action in the area of ensuring judicial independence and protecting fundamental rights in Serbia, including trade union, equalities and minorities’ rights, and free speech. While recognising and welcoming efforts made by Serbia aiming to restructure public administration, I was glad that my own amendment reinforcing the importance of workers’ rights and the significance of public sector employment for Serbian citizens and their wellbeing was incorporated into the final text. Furthermore, it is important that we agreed on wording urging the Serbian Government to ensure an accessible education system and prioritise the provision of work and training opportunities for young people.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I strongly support the European perspective of all Western Balkan countries since the political enlargement of the EU strengthens stability and democracy in this region. That is why I am voting in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the 2014 progress report on Serbia.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. In addition to the progress that Serbia has already made, there are still problems in some areas that make it difficult to join the EU. That is why I welcome Parliament's resolution on this matter.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. This report is very ideologically oriented, in the sense of a vassalisation of the countries of Eastern Europe to NATO. Paragraph 11, in particular, is an injunction asking Serbia to "harmonize its foreign policy towards Russia". I voted in favour of an amendment to remove this paragraph. This report is deeply opposed to the principle of state sovereignty, so I voted against it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I do not support the accession of Serbia to the European Union, and therefore voted against this resolution.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to assess the serbia's progress report. Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Kosovo, the former Yugoslav Republic and Serbia are the six countries of the Western Balkans applying for EU membership. Of these applicants, two are already negotiating membership of the European Union, Montenegro and Serbia. Albania and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia have the status of official candidates, while Bosnia and Herzegovina and Kosovo are considered potential candidates. The progress of all these candidates for EU accession varies, with many indicators lagging behind EU members. The main problems are high unemployment rates, corruption and restrictions on freedom of the press.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which in particular urges Serbia to "harmonize its foreign and security policy with that of the European Union, including policy towards Russia" and promotes the vassalisation of European countries to NATO.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. This is the annual follow-up report on Serbia, as part of its application for membership. The European Parliament welcomes the official opening of accession negotiations on 21 January 2014. He welcomes the successful implementation of the EU-Serbia Stabilisation and Association Agreement. In particular, Parliament welcomes Serbia's participation in the normalization process with Kosovo. It calls on the country to harmonize its foreign policy with that of the European Union, including with regard to Russia, and encourages it to cooperate more with the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia. Parliament welcomes the political effort to combat corruption, but expressed concern about the deteriorating conditions for the exercise of freedom of expression in Serbia.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. Again, this motion for a resolution, which follows on from the 2014 follow-up report on Serbia, requires submission to the Europeanist dogma. In view of the enlargement of the Union and the possible accession of Serbia, Serbia is required to harmonize its foreign and security policy with EU policy, particularly vis-à-vis Russia.  There is still time for these States to back down in their desire to join the European Union, at the risk of being completely divested of their legislative, budgetary and perhaps monetary sovereignty in the long term. I have therefore spoken out against this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the positions supported in the resolution which partially analyses the little progress made by Serbia as a pre-accession country and for this reason I did not support it with my vote.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I've abstained. However, I see problems with the market-liberal policies imposed on the country by the EU without particular attention to social consequences. I also think it is wrong that the EU requires foreign policy adjustments. In principle, I believe that the people of Serbia should be given the right to express their opinion on the accession process to the European Union, by referendum. It is up to the people of Serbia to decide for themselves whether or not they want the country to belong to the EUROPEAN Union. That is why I am abstaining on this report.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report welcoming the formal start of accession negotiations with Serbia on 21 January 2014 at the first Summit of the EU-Serbian Intergovernmental Coordination Group and commending the successful implementation of the EU-Serbia Stabilisation and Association Agreement. However, attention is paid to the country's problems, such as freedom of the press, deteriorating conditions for freedom of expression, and lack of transparency in the financing of political parties and election campaigns. It should be noted that Serbia is invited to make a greater effort to ensure equal representation of women in political and public life, to improve the situation of Roma and to ensure the consistent implementation throughout the country of legislation on the protection of minorities.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, in which the European Parliament evaluates Serbia's progress report for 2014. The European Parliament welcomes the commitment demonstrated by the Serbian Government to the Process of European Integration and calls on Serbia to undertake systemic, social and economic reforms with determination and no need for a mandate. It should be underlined that the careful implementation of legislation and policies remains a key indicator of the successful integration process and that Serbia should therefore improve the planning, coordination and monitoring of new legislation and policies. Parliament stresses that Serbia has ratified the core International Labour Organisation conventions in the field of labour rights, as well as the revised European Social Charter. However, despite constitutional guarantees, labour and trade union rights are still limited, and Serbia should continue to strengthen these rights. The European Parliament also calls on the Serbian authorities throughout the country to undertake structural economic reforms to promote economic growth, improve the business and investment environment, ensure balanced socio-economic development in all regions, combat high unemployment and poverty, fiscal consolidation and combat corruption, which is still a major threat to the business environment.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 David McAllister's decision on Serbia was adopted by the European Parliament as a balanced, realistic document. It also includes serbia's shortcomings, areas where the country needs to perform better, but at the same time it does not forget to praise the effective reform measures of the Serbian Government so far. Hungary, and personally, it is crucial for me that minority issues are also given a worthy place in the text of the decision. The decision is a significant step in further encouraging the country to be part of a large family of European peoples. With the coordinated amendments of the Fidesz delegation, the report was able to better highlight certain issues and send a more positive message about Serbia overall. Hungary interested in serbia being an EU member as soon as possible. In addition to foreign policy, security policy and economic interests, good neighbourly relations between the two countries have developed rapidly over the past few years. It is also essential to further improve the realisation of minority rights. This is also important to me personally, because as a person of Transcarpathian origin, I am aware that the future of Hungarian communities living beyond the country's borders depends largely on this. I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly support the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the report on Serbia's recent progress towards EU membership. In recent months we have received positive and encouraging signals, progress that is heading in the right direction but needs further input from the Serbian Government in order to be consolidated. Two sensitive fronts are the fight against corruption and organised crime. The dialogue between Belgrade and Pristina remains of fundamental importance, and in this respect we hope that all the standardisation agreements already reached between the two parties will be implemented quickly in order to further facilitate Serbia's accession to the EU.  We believe that it is only through the joint efforts of all regional actors that Serbia will be able to strengthen its economic, social and democratic development. The protection and implementation of human rights and fundamental freedoms at all levels of Serbian society and in accordance with European and international values are in this sense a priority and fully supported and monitored by the S&D Group.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (NI)
text: In writing. Serbia now has candidate status. Twenty-eight chapters of negotiations have been opened. Once again, the European Parliament is asking itself as a lesson-giver: "great efforts" would still be needed. We allow ourselves to interfere in Serbia's delicate relations with its neighbours, by imposing the normalization of relations with Kosovo. Moreover, it is also questionable whether Serbia should be invited to "harmonize its foreign and security policy with that of the European Union, including policy towards Russia". So I voted against it.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ There are some positives in this Progress Report for Serbia, particularly calls for enhancing human rights, children's rights, fundamental freedoms, respect for cultural and linguistic diversity, justice and reconciliation. These recommendations are all important issues that need to be dealt with in a post-conflict society such as Serbia. In Ireland's experience the Good Friday Agreement commits signatories to delivering an Irish Language Act and a Bill of Rights for the north and Charter of Human Rights for All-Ireland. We are still fighting for the implementation of these. So I welcome such recommendations. However I am concerned by calls for "structural economic reforms" and "fiscal consolidation". In Ireland's experience these so-called reforms, at the behest of the EU, have caused much hardship particularly to the most vulnerable. On this basis I abstained.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. The 2014 follow-up report on Serbia shows a desire to encircle Russia by submitting The countries of Eastern Europe to the European dogma (notably through the enlargement policy). There are intolerable demands in areas where the European Union has no jurisdiction. Indeed, the European Union calls on Serbia to harmonize its foreign and security policy with its own, including with regard to Russia. This is a blackmail at accession, which reflects a move to vassalize the countries of the European Union to NATO. Opposing any further enlargement and defending Serbia's sovereignty, I voted against this motion for a resolution.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained, I do not share the openly critical positions towards the pro-Russian policies of the Serbs.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. The report welcomes the formal start of accession negotiations on 21 January 2014 at the first Summit of the EU-Serbian Intergovernmental Coordination Group and commends the good implementation of the EU-Serbia Stabilisation and Association Agreement. However, the report also draws attention to the country's problems, such as freedom of the press, deteriorating conditions for freedom of expression, lack of transparency in the financing of political parties and election campaigns. The report also invites Serbia, inter alia, to make greater efforts to ensure equal representation of women in political and public life, to improve the situation of Roma and to ensure the consistent implementation throughout the country of legislation on the protection of minorities.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the 2014 report on Serbia's progress. Indeed, the new Serbian Government has shown that it wants to engage fully in the process of European integration and that it wants to tackle decisively and directly the systemic and socio-economic reforms necessary to continue along the path of change and rapprochement with European standards.  The negotiations between the EU and Serbia are already having positive effects, such as progress towards normalising relations with Kosovo, improving regional cooperation policy and establishing closer relations with the EU. Serbia is a key country on the Balkan chessboard and its entry into the European Union is therefore to be considered strategic. I therefore hope that the Belgrade Government will resolutely continue the process of integration that has begun and will be able to put in place the courageous choices necessary to complete it.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ There are some positives in this Progress Report for Serbia, particularly calls for enhancing human rights, children's rights, fundamental freedoms, respect for cultural and linguistic diversity, justice and reconciliation. These recommendations are all important issues that need to be dealt with in a post conflict society such as Serbia. In Ireland's experience the Good Friday Agreement commits signatories to delivering an Irish Language Act and a Bill of Rights for the north and Charter of Human Rights for All-Ireland. We are still fighting for the implementation of these. So I welcome such recommendations. However I am concerned by calls for "structural economic reforms" and "fiscal consolidation". In Ireland's experience these so-called reforms, at the behest of the EU, have caused much hardship particularly to the most vulnerable. On this basis I abstained.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ In its resolution, Parliament welcomed the opening of the accession negotiation process with Serbia. It welcomes the commitment shown by the Serbian Government to the European integration process. On the other hand, progress is still lacking as regards the rule of law. Parliament welcomed Serbia's efforts in the normalisation process with Kosovo. Further efforts are needed to align its foreign and security policy with that of the EU, to fully implement bilateral agreements with neighbouring countries and to address its open bilateral issues in a pragmatic way. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Council of 28 June 2013 finally decided to start accession negotiations with Serbia. As I was able to recall during the debate, we call for Serbia's efforts in the search for missing persons to be strengthened. Twelve thousand families have not known the fate of their loved ones for more than 20 years. I hope that the Serbian authorities will have the will to open the various archives to deal with this issue, which remains a wound still bleeding in the heart of the countries of the former Yugoslavia.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. Another report that testifies to the european Union's mad race for enlargement in recent years.  I voted against this text, which also violates Serbia's independence, with injunctions such as 'invites Serbia to harmonize its foreign and security policy with that of the European Union'. However, foreign policy is supposed to be one of the regal prerogatives of any nation-state! To ask the States aspiring to join the Union to align their policy with its own is therefore to admit the federalist aim of the European Union, in defiance of the treaties, in defiance of the will of the peoples who have, on numerous occasions, expressed their desire to remain sovereign. What is behind all the texts concerning relations with the countries of Eastern Europe and are currently being voted on in Parliament is a desire to encircle Russia by the vassalisation of its strategic partners.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Serbian Government's commitment to the Process of European Integration, highlighted in this measure, which calls on the Serbian State to cope with socio-economic and structural reforms, is commendable and rewarding. The success of integration takes place with a complete change in both policies and legislation.  An improvement in the rule of law is the process that the Serbian State is facing decisively and resolutions that are certainly important for a final result. I also believe that Serbia is a fundamental state for its strategic economic and trade relationship with Russia, given the close relationship between the two states. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of the measure.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure, as it welcomes the commitment shown by the new Serbian Government to the process of European integration and calls on Serbia to tackle systemic and socio-economic reforms decisively and directly. I believe that Serbia can play a key role in EU-Russia relations, thanks to the traditionally strong economic, social and cultural ties that exist between the two countries. I am convinced that the full implementation of legislation and policies remains a key indicator of a successful integration process; that is why I believe that Serbia must improve the planning, coordination and monitoring of the implementation of the new rules and policies; In particular, Serbia must make further progress with regard to the rule of law.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I stress the quality and accuracy of Mr McAllister's report on the development of Serbia as a candidate for membership of the European Union. It is indisputable that, in many of the valences, Serbia is evolving positively, which confirms the value of EU enlargement as a tool to enable economic growth, the maintenance of peace and the consolidation of democracy in the candidate countries. The report also highlights areas of concern, such as the treatment of ethnic and religious minorities, the urgent reform of the judicial sector, the need to adopt legislation that is derailed, the relationship with neighbouring states such as Kosovo and better cooperation with the International Criminal Court. Since I maintain a prudent reserve position on further enlargement (I believe that there is still some time left for the EU to digest the latest enlargements), I abstain in its vote.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Commission's 2014 progress report on Serbia's progress because, while I still see significant critical issues relating to child protection regulations, education systems, media access and freedom of religion by linguistic minorities, and despite the fact that it still has to comply fully with the European Union's foreign policy and security policy , account must be taken of the efforts and systematic and socio-economic approach adopted by the Serbian Government, in particular in the reform of justice and public administration.  The Republic of Serbia is also to be welcomed for its commitment to dialogue with Kosovo, although the report shows a delay in implementing the agreements. I believe, in line with the position expressed by the Council and the Commission, that the above issues do not constitute an obstacle to the progress of the negotiation process for Serbia's accession to the EU.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the fact that Serbia continues to sufficiently meet the political criteria of accession to the EU. Early parliamentary elections in March confirmed the European integration aspirations of the country and that EU accession remains the main goal of the new government. First steps were taken in the implementation of the national strategies on judicial reform and the fight against corruption. The legal framework for the protection of minorities is broadly in place but its consistent implementation across the country needs to be ensured, notably in the areas of education, use of languages, and access to the media and to religious services in minority languages. I support the report which calls on Serbia to ensure consistent implementation across the country of legislation on protection of minorities.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe that Serbia is making considerable efforts towards alignment with European democratic standards. Important progress has been made: social and economic reforms augur well. However, much remains to be done, especially in the fight against corruption and with full respect for minorities. I welcome the efforts made to normalise relations with Kosovo. We must facilitate the integration of balkan countries into the European Union.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which welcomes the formal beginning of accession talks which took place on 21 January 2014 at the first EU-Serbia Intergovernmental Conference and commends the smooth implementation of the EU-Serbia Stabilisation and Association Agreement. However, the report also draws attention to problems in the country, such as media freedom, deteriorating conditions for freedom of expression, lack of transparency in the funding of political parties and election campaigns. The report also invites Serbia, among other things, to make further efforts to guarantee equal representation of women in political and public life, to improve the situation of the Roma and to ensure consistent implementation across the country of legislation on protection of minorities.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This resolution takes note of the European Commission's progress report on progress in the EU's enlargement negotiations with Serbia. Following his new candidate status, granted in 2012, the first exchanges for membership took place on 21 January 2014. In this context, Serbia has committed itself to reforms, with priority in chapters 23 and 24 on the judicial system, fundamental rights, freedom and security.  The resolution also reiterates the need for Serbia to normalise its relations with Kosovo (Chapter 35 of the negotiations) and stresses that this progress must be made in parallel with the overall negotiations. Serbia is also encouraged to align its foreign policy positions with that of the European Union, particularly vis-à-vis Russia.  Finally, Parliament calls on Serbia to do more to protect minorities. It is therefore clear that new efforts must be made towards accession, which cannot therefore take place for many years to come. Considering all these elements, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. This resolution underlines the need for Serbia to implement comprehensive economic and social reforms in order to become a strong partner of the European Union. To this end, the establishment of a rule of law with an independent judiciary is crucial. Initial exchanges have taken place on Serbia's eventual accession to the European Union, but this accession remains conditional on the normalization of relations with Kosovo, and is not expected to materialize for several years. I believe that, in line with the promises we made to our constituents in May 2014, the process of enlargement of the European Union must take a lasting break, in the interests of all.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – David McAllister's decision on Serbia was adopted by the European Parliament as a balanced, realistic document. It also shows Serbia's shortcomings and flaws, areas where the country needs to perform better, but at the same time does not forget to praise the effective reform measures taken by the Serbian Government over the past year. This is very important because it helps Serbia to remain on the European path. Moreover, Hungary, minority issues were also given a worthy place in the text of the decision. In doing so, we have helped to make sure that the rights of indigenous national minorities are fully protected and not violated.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. This report is very ideologically oriented, in the sense of a vassalisation of the countries of Eastern Europe to NATO. Paragraph 11, in particular, is an injunction asking Serbia to "harmonize its foreign policy towards Russia". I voted in favour of an amendment to remove this paragraph. This report is deeply opposed to the principle of state sovereignty, so I voted against it.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Relations between the European Union and Serbia are gradually improving, with the formal beginning of accession talks having taken place in January 2014. A comprehensive contractual framework between both sides entered into force the previous September. The report positively assesses recent parliamentary elections, and the "smooth implementation" of the EU-Serbia Stabilisation and Association Agreement, which the rapporteur says provides the general framework for Serbia and the EU to intensify their cooperation. There are also calls for further steps to reform political and judicial structures, improve economic policy, and improve the treatment of minority groups.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the motion for a resolution because, apart from the fact that the intended enlargement of the EU will exacerbate the economic crisis plaguing the countries of the South, the report favours Serbia's participation in NATO.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution because the European Union aims to promote peace, stability and economic development in the Western Balkans and to provide a credible prospect of EU integration. I would also like to draw attention to the fact that, for the first time in the history of the European Parliament, the interests of Serbia and Vojvodina are reflected in this resolution from the point of view of Vojvodina. The document also praises the election of the National Minority Councils on 26 October 2014.
