In Serbia, the Law on National Councils of 2009 allowed, among other things, the establishment of an institutional system guaranteeing the cultural autonomy of minorities in Vojvodina, the first of the Hungarian-dinged areas of the Carpathian Basin. I welcome the Serbian commitment to integration and the high level of preparedness shown by the previous Serbian Government even at the start of the accession negotiations. Fortunately, the new government also prioritises European integration. The European Commission must learn the lessons from the drag of the Croatian accession negotiations and start with the two most difficult chapters, chapter 23 (Justice and Fundamental Rights) and Chapter 24 (Justice, Freedom and Security). I consider it important to reach an agreement with Kosovo at the Brussels meeting in February, which was a sensitive issue in the normalisation of relations between the two countries, since Serbia cannot start the substantive part of the accession negotiations until it has fulfilled the points of the Brussels Treaty.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. Serbia has been making progress in the process of European integration and efforts to meet the Copenhagen criteria and the conditions set out in the Stabilisation and Association Process. I would like to highlight the fact that you have taken important steps in favour of normalising relations with Kosovo. The positive assessment by international observers of the legislative elections is another point in favour of the Serbian government. I believe that it is time for Serbia to take a decisive approach to systemic and socio-economic reforms and to strictly implement the legislation and policies that make it a rule of law.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. The European Union is doomed to lose; how can a system survive by humiliating a country in this way? Thus, this report calls on Serbia, which, I recall, has a democratically elected government and, unlike some countries, respects the will of its people, "to harmonize its foreign and security policy with that of the European Union, including the policy towards Russia". If there is one recommendation we can make to Serbia, it is to follow Iceland's example by withdrawing its application for membership of the European Union.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This motion for a resolution presents a wide range of considerations on serbia's eu integration process. Far beyond the evaluation of the process, it points to a wide range of constraints towards membership, which confirm the extent of the interference and loss of sovereignty imposed on countries and peoples in the process of EU membership.  We highlight the interference in that country's relationship with the Serbian province of Kosovo, or in the relationship with the ICC, the intrusions into the country's economic, judicial and political system, the advanced foreign and security policy guidelines, including the country's membership of NATO, integrated into the militarisation of the EU and the extension of influence in the Balkan region, among others. We consider unacceptable the manor stance with which the recitals and conditions required to satisfy the precepts relating to the integration of the country are unacceptable, removing from the peoples the legitimate right to decide their future, where they are registered, the free and sovereign choice of EU membership, but also the strategies of economic and social development. For these reasons we voted against.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ In the report, we agree to start accession talks of January 2014 between the European Union and Serbia. We consider Serbia to be one of the most important countries in the Balkans region and welcome the progress that has been made. The Serbian Government has shown its determination to address systemic and socio-economic reforms in the interests of the European integration process. The opening of the negotiating chapters should take into account developments but also the political context of relations between Serbia and the European Union, in particular for Chapters 23 and 24. We also insist that Chapter 35 should be clearly defined as regards relations with Kosovo.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report because, unlike other reports, it remains objective in relation to the Serbian question.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the motion for a resolution on the 2014 progress report on Serbia, as the intended enlargement of the EU will exacerbate the economic crisis plaguing the countries of the South, without improving the living conditions of Serbs.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe we need to be aware that work lies ahead for Serbia: improvements are very much needed with regard to the rights of minorities, freedom of the media, the lack of transparency in funding of political parties, equal representation of men and women, corruption etc.  I believe that, in our negotiations with all the candidate countris, we must keep our European priorities and values clear in our minds:  the goal of achieving stability in the region is very important but we cannot forfeit our support for and defence of the exercise of democratic rights and freedoms in the Balkans.  I support this process. At the same time I believe that we must take a clear political position.  It is time for us to show that no state that wishes to join the EU can avoid complying with all fundamental European Union democratic values.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. Serbia is confident of entering the European Union in the medium term, so it must continue to work on the consolidation of the rule of law, as well as on the structural and economic reforms necessary to improve the country's situation. Similarly, while we welcome progress between the parties, the problem between Serbia and Kosovo continues to be perpetrated: we must continue to call for a peaceful solution to end this political conflict.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. The report welcomes the formal start of accession negotiations on 21 January 2014 at the first Summit of the EU-Serbian Intergovernmental Coordination Group and commends the good implementation of the EU-Serbia Stabilisation and Association Agreement. However, the report also draws attention to the country's problems, such as freedom of the press, deteriorating conditions for freedom of expression, lack of transparency in the financing of political parties and election campaigns. The report also invites Serbia, inter alia, to make greater efforts to ensure equal representation of women in political and public life, to improve the situation of Roma and to ensure the consistent implementation throughout the country of legislation on the protection of minorities.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. The report welcomes the formal start of accession negotiations on 21 January 2014 at the first Summit of the EU-Serbian Intergovernmental Coordination Group and commends the good implementation of the EU-Serbia Stabilisation and Association Agreement. However, the report also draws attention to the country's problems, such as freedom of the press, deteriorating conditions for freedom of expression, lack of transparency in the financing of political parties and election campaigns. The report also invites Serbia, inter alia, to make greater efforts to ensure equal representation of women in political and public life, to improve the situation of Roma and to ensure the consistent implementation throughout the country of legislation on the protection of minorities.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. This is the first time that the European Parliament has formally expressed its views on Serbia's progress towards EU membership. The Council's formal decision to open negotiations came in fact in the second half of 2013 and only a few weeks ago the Commission was able to produce the first monitoring report on the ongoing negotiations. This is therefore an exciting time: unfortunately, many of us vividly remember the atrocities and crimes committed only 20 years ago during the Balkan conflict.  A conflict that seemed to cut off the hope of reconciliation and full reunification in this region of the continent, a war that created a black hole in the heart of Europe and which today, after much effort, seems to be far from memory. Serbia's place is in the European Union, to which it belongs for deep cultural, historical and spiritual ties. Membership of the EU is, however, primarily a political act, which is why I agree with and support Mr McAllister's careful report, which highlights the steps to be taken on a number of crucial points, such as the reform of administration and justice, the protection of minorities and the detection of the many acts and crimes committed during the recent conflict.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the 2014 Progress Report on Serbia seeing that, while praise is due for the smooth implementation of the EU-Serbia Stabilisation and Association Agreement, significant obstacles remain on Serbiaʼs path to the EU.  These include media freedom, deteriorating conditions for freedom of expression and a lack of transparency in the funding of political parties and election campaigns. In particular, Serbia urgently needs to make headway on ensuring equal representation of women in political and public life, improving the situation of the Roma and ensuring consistent implementation across the country of legislation on protection of minorities.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. "U2012 We have therefore abstained, despite considering that Serbia's process of integration into the EU can be positive for its people, the Resolution has a language with which Serbia is still being accused, subjectively and arbitrarily, of past developments.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the 2014 Progress Report on Serbia, which calls on Serbia to work more closely with neighbouring countries and to promote a culture of freedom and openness.  While significant obstacles remain in relation to Serbiaʼs path to accession to the EU, including protection for freedom of expression and freedom of the press as well as a lack of transparency in relation to political funding and election campaigns, this report highlights the positive steps which have already been taken and points to what can be done to make Serbia a more free and open society

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We have therefore abstained, despite considering that the process of integrating Serbia into the EU can be positive for its people, the Resolution uses language that continues to accuse Serbia of past developments subjectively and arbitrarily.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I support Serbia's 2014 progress report, as it realistically presents political and socio-economic processes in the process of joining the European Union. Accession negotiations opened in early 2014. The implementation of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement has improved and a commitment to European integration is visible. It is important to create preconditions for opening negotiating chapters 23 and 24 as soon as possible, as well as Serbia's engagement in building good-social relations with Kosovo, and co-operation in the fight against criminal groups. Given developments in the 1990s, Serbia needs to continue co-operation with the International Criminal Court, boost co-operation with Croatia and other countries to collect missing persons data. Cooperation with easuing countries should continue, bilateral relations should be improved and bilateral issues addressed. Progress has been made in the judiciary through the implementation of the 2013-2018 Strategic and Action Plan for Judicial Reform. What matters is that the resolution highlights the issue of Vojvodina. It is important that vojvodina's autonomy must not be narrowed and in this regard the Resolution calls for the adoption of a law on the jurisdiction and financing of AP Vojvodina. As a convinced regionalist and connoisseur of Vojvodina, participant and promoter of cooperation, and carrier of the idea by which multilingualism in Vojvodina has spread to citizens of Croatian nationality, I expect that in the future all aspects of contemporary European regionalism will be applied.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. This report, motivated by ideology and not geopolitical interests or reality, seeks NATO's control of Eastern European foreign policy. Serbia is the order to harmonize its foreign policy towards Russia with that of the European Union. I voted in favour of the amendment removing this paragraph, but against this report which opposes the principle of state sovereignty.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the follow-up report on Serbia. I agree with the report's recommendations on socio-economic reforms and in favour of the rule of law.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the 2014 follow-up report on Serbia, which was granted candidate status in 2012. The European Council on 28 June 2013 decided to start accession negotiations with Serbia. For example, it has made a great deal of progress in several areas in order to comply with the Union's requirements. However, many challenges remain.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. Serbia's accession to the EU is an opportunity and an asset for the Union, as Serbia can also play a bridge and mediating role with Russia. A fair and balanced report on Serbia's progress in bringing it to the EU, which I have absolute support for.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. I commend the Serbian Government for its efforts to align with the EU legislation in its pre-accession process. Nevertheless, I recommend that the Serbian Government not use its urgency procedure too much and that it give enough time for the various actors in society to consult and discuss various items of legislation.  I regret the statement by the Serbian Government that it would never agree with sanctions against Russia. I call on the Serbian Government to bring its values and aims into line with EU foreign policy. Russia is an aggressor violating the borders of its neighbouring country and conducting hybrid war against Ukraine. Undermining the European stand against an aggressor would undermine the whole European project, and I am sure that that is not the aim of Serbia.   I am also greatly worried about the situation regarding freedom of media and expression. Media ownership has to be transparent. Any attempts to influence independent media and censor critical voices are not in line with democratic values and cannot be tolerated. I call on the Serbian authorities to seriously tackle the matter of freedom of media and expression and ensure compliance with European democratic values.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I congratulate Serbia on the progress achieved on its path to the EU. However, a lot of work lies ahead on issues such as media freedom, deteriorating conditions for freedom of expression, and lack of transparency in the funding of political parties and election campaigns. Serbia should also make further efforts to guarantee gender equality and protect the rights of minority groups.  I continue to strongly support the aspirations of the Western Balkan countries to engage in European reforms and to become EU members themselves. The process of integration will strengthen the democratic institutions of these countries, modernise their economies and thus improve the lives of citizens. Labour Party Members and the S&D Group will be sure to keep enlargement high on the EU’s political agenda.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of the resolution on serbia's progress, which expresses the importance of improving the implementation of the EU-Serbia Stabilisation and Association Agreement. The Authorities of Serbia and Kosovo are also called upon to step up cooperation in order to combat the criminal networks responsible for the control and exploitation of irregular migrants.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on Serbia's progress since the establishment of the new government and its constructive approach to its relationship with neighbouring countries. It also reiterates that Serbia needs to take more concrete action to reform its judicial system and increase transparency about media ownership.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the follow-up report on Serbia. This resolution is a catalogue of interference in Serbian policy, particularly in social, economic, institutional and energy matters. Moreover, the European Union seems to have the vocation to be an arbiter of relations between Serbia and Kosovo, when that is not its role. The Union's interference in Serbia's foreign policy is more than suspect, as it is very clearly aimed at bringing the country into the sphere of influence of the United States and NATO. This relentless desire to isolate Russia from its allies will one day backfire on the European Union and its member states.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it constitutes interference in the internal affairs of a sovereign state. It wants to impose a policy dictated by the European Union.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because it maintains the line of Parliament's views on the applicant countries, in which a colonial relationship between a rich and powerful centre and an impoverished and obedient periphery is reproduced. In this particular case, in addition to meddling in the internal affairs of the State to press for the Neoliberal agenda of the European Union, Serbia is asked to recognize the self-proclaimed Republic of Kosovo to 'facilitate' its accession.

name: Peter Lundgren (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ While I believe it is important to demonstrate that the foreign policy actions taken by Russia with regard to its neighbouring European countries are completely unacceptable, nevertheless I cannot support an amendment which calls for Serbia to align its foreign and security policies with that of the EU. I strongly oppose the notion that the EU should be a foreign policy actor in itself, let alone increase its sphere of influence into non-Member States, which is why I choose to abstain on this vote.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Socialists and Democrats in Parliament welcome the adoption of the reports on Serbia, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (FYROM), Montenegro and Kosovo, and call on the Commission and the Council to show renewed EU commitment to the Western Balkans enlargement process. I voted in favour with my colleagues from my political group.

name: Ramona Nicole Mănescu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report for the following reasons: I welcome the progress made in implementing the EU-Serbia Stabilisation and Association Agreement, the commitment shown by the Serbian Government in relation to the European integration process, and I believe that legislation needs to be implemented rigorously and consistently across the country. In this respect, it is necessary to implement legislation on education, use of the national language, access to the media and religious services in minority languages and representation of minorities in local, regional and national parliament bodies. I encourage Serbia's commitment to the development of a concrete action plan on the position of national minorities in the action plan for Chapter 23 negotiation. I am sure that Serbia's presence within the EU's borders will lead to stability and prosperity for both Serbia's and European citizens, and good management of the relationship with minorities will support the accession process.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on the 2014 progress report on Serbia, as Greece supports Serbia's European path and has concluded cooperation agreements since 2010 aimed at strengthening and accelerating its accession path.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. Dominique Martin opposed this text, which, without concealment, calls on Serbia to align its foreign and security policy with that of the European Union. Another proof of eu interference, which is necessary in the relations of other countries.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this Report which calls on Serbia to intensify its cooperation with neighbouring countries and to strengthen its efforts in the search for missing persons, and to fully share all relevant data. It urges the Serbian authorities, in this regard, to open up the archives of the Yugoslav People’s Army in order to establish the truth of past tragic events and obtain information. Furthermore it urges the authorities to open up and facilitate transparent access to those archives that concern former republics of Yugoslavia and to the documents of the former intelligence agency (UDBA), including by providing them to the respective governments.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the joint resolution adopted today on Serbia, I welcome a number of elements, such as the finding that a recently published report by the European Court of Auditors concluded that funding from the Instrument for Pre-Access Structural Policies (IPA), together with other forms of support for Serbia, has helped to implement social and economic reforms. Unfortunately, however, there are also passages in the resolution that are unacceptable to me, such as calls for Serbia to make greater efforts to align its foreign and security policy with the EU's foreign and security policy, including its policy towards Russia, or the regret that Serbia did not join the Council's decisions to introduce restrictive measures against Russia when called upon to do so. However, we must recognise the traditionally strong economic, social and cultural links that exist between the two countries. I believe that Serbia, as the OSCE's presiding state in 2015, will support all means in this capacity to step up efforts to peacefully resolve the current conflicts in the area where the OSCE operates; and I am sure that it will play a positive role in this respect. Since, of course, I do not oppose EU enlargement, on the contrary, I believe that Serbia needs to be helped as our partner, I abstained in the final vote on the resolution.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Serbia has made a lot of progress in recent years, making itself the protagonist of a normalization in relations with Kosovo.  I therefore voted in favour of the resolution on Serbia, which expresses the importance of improving the implementation of the EU-Serbia Stabilisation and Association Agreement, and calls on the Authorities of Serbia and Kosovo to step up cooperation in order to combat and dismantle the criminal networks responsible for the control and exploitation of irregular migrants.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. I believe that we should all congratulate ourselves on the commitment made by the Government of Serbia to the EU integration process, as well as its constructive attitude in relations with neighbours.  From the European Parliament, however, we would like to ask through this resolution, which I have my support, that this whole accession process be more inclusive and transparent. Serbia, as stated in the Resolution of this House, must also do more to reform the judiciary, increase the transparency of media ownership and strengthen its unity to align its foreign and security policy with that of the EU, particularly when it comes to Russia. The Serbian Government must make an effort to ensure that the accession process can move forward appropriately for all, introducing all the reforms and improvements that will facilitate this path.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. The motion for a resolution on the 2014 progress report on Serbia received my positive vote. Serbia is not only a part of Europe, but also an important partner of the European Union. In the accession negotiations, Serbia is called, inter alia, to align its foreign and security policy with that of the EU, to strengthen its cooperation with neighbouring countries and to step up cooperation with Kosovo in order to crack down on criminal networks. Long-term integration of the country into the EU, with the conditions for accession, is not only the right one, but also the logical path that this country and the EU must take.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The Stabilization and Association Agreement signed with Serbia prepares Serbia for future membership, including neoliberal reforms, in cooperation with the IMF. The European Union therefore observes the reform programme every year in its agreements with the Balkans. The Commission calls on Serbia to ensure "fiscal consolidation" as well as a "restructuring" of public suppliers, and to continue liberalisations, as recently in the electricity or telecommunications sector. The resolution therefore congratulates the government on its 'European commitment'. It reflects intensely on Kosovo, but ignores the disastrous economic and social situation, compounded by European demands. As with the other texts on the Western Balkans, the resolution also calls on Belgrade to harmonize its policy towards Russia with that of the European Union, which the government has already refused.  I vote against any enlargement process under these conditions.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. Serbia has been taking important steps to normalise relations with Kosovo, resulting in the signing of the First Agreement on the Principles of Standardisation of 19 April 2013. It has also made efforts to sufficiently meet the political criteria and conditions of the Stabilisation and Association Process. As a rule, the eu-to-eu support effort is an important driver in the countries interested in being part of the EU, hopefully that is also Serbia's motivation. We look forward to the negotiations, as well as the positive developments of Serbia in the various matters under scrutiny. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution highlights the efforts that Serbia has undertaken to fight corruption, and the further implementation of the recommendations of the Group of States against Corruption. The resolution also stresses the urgent work needed to deal with all pending issues between Serbia and Kosovo. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution as it outlines the advancements made in fulfilling the accession criteria and the goals that have yet to be achieved.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the opening of the first Chapters in the EU enlargement negotiations with this important player in the Western Balkans this year. However, it should also be underlined that a lot of work lies ahead.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Western Balkans and the issue of enlargement is a major moral, political and strategic problem of the European Union. It will not go away, expectations will not go away, our historic experience and commitments will not disappear. It poses crucial, existential questions to the Union itself, to its democratic legitimacy and support among its citizens. I wish I had an answer of my own to this huge conundrum, putting in the balance so many destinies on either side of the equation. That is why I have voted in favour of the report.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Apart from Serbian policy on Russia, the report reports significant progress in most important areas, in this regard it is particularly important to have a positive perception of the conduct of an early election by international observers. As a result, I consider the report worthy of support.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Western Balkans region has five candidate countries. Serbia formalised its membership in 2009 and in 2012 it was granted candidate country status. However, it was not until 2014 that formal negotiations for accession began at the 1st Intergovernmental Conference.  The European Parliament underlines some concerns about the slow progress of reforms needed to establish a rule of law. It therefore considers that in the first phase the chapters on Fundamental and Judicial Rights and the dimension of Justice, Freedom and Security should be opened. At the same time, I would like to stress that it is important to apply legislation that protects minorities, both in access to education and in the right to use their languages. Another fact to be highlighted, by the negative, is serbia's alignment with Russian foreign policy, which goes against the line followed by the Union.  Finally, I would like to underline the efforts of serbia's entities in the stabilisation process with neighbouring Kosovo, a sign of the country's maturity. I believe that the strengthening of relations between the two countries must accompany both negotiation processes.  I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The 2014 follow-up report on Serbia shows a desire to encircle Serbia by submitting The countries of Eastern Europe to the European dogma (notably through the enlargement policy). There are intolerable demands in areas where the European Union has no jurisdiction. Indeed, the European Union calls on Serbia to harmonize its foreign and security policy with that of the Union, including (and above all) russia. This is a blackmail for accession and a move to vassalize the countries of the European Union to NATO. Opposing any further enlargement, I voted against it.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the 2014 follow-up report on Serbia. The resolution provides an update on the state of negotiations with Serbia as part of its bid to join the European Union. The resolution stresses that Serbia has taken important steps to normalise its relations with Kosovo, but that the EU-Serbia Stabilisation and Association Agreement needs to be better implemented.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the recent start of accession negotiations with Serbia, stressing the progress made and the commitment shown by the new government to the process of European integration. We call for every effort to be made to implement the planned systemic and socio-economic reforms; we welcome the efforts made in the standardisation process with Kosovo and strongly encourage the Serbian authorities to play a constructive role in this context, as well as in the development of good neighbourly relations and cross-border cooperation.  We note, in fact, that corruption and organised crime are rampant in the region, which are also an obstacle to serbia's democratic, social and economic development. We therefore believe that a regional strategy and enhanced cooperation between all the countries in the region are essential to address these issues more effectively.  We call for further commitment to the promotion and protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms, respect for minorities at all levels of Serbian society, without discrimination and in accordance with European and international standards. We encourage the Serbian authorities to make progress in ensuring equal representation of women in political and public life.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it presents the progress of the dossier of a country applying for membership of the European Union and merely takes stock of that country's progress.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to support the resolution on Serbia's progress during 2014. This resolution welcomes the start of the accession talks on 21 January 2014 and the commitment shown by the Serbian Government towards the Process of European Integration. However, further progress is being made on the road to reform, in the process of normalising relations with Kosovo, in aligning its foreign and security policy and in legislation on the protection of minorities. Finally, Serbia is encouraged to conclude bilateral agreements with its neighbours.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Serbia began EU accession negotiations on 21 January 2014. The European Union, through its institutions, appreciates the Serbian Government's efforts to align itself with the EU's requirements, imposed on all states that want to be part of it.  I voted for this resolution which insists on the progress made by Serbia, which currently also holds the OSCE Presidency, on the road to accession, but also on the measures still needed, such as the promotion of democracy, the rights of national minorities (Vlachs, Romanians, Vlasi), the protection and application of human rights at all levels of Serbian society, without discrimination and in accordance with European standards.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: scríofa. ‒ Tá rudaí dearfacha sa tuarascáil seo go háirithe an tslí go gcuirtear béim ar neartú a dhéanamh ar chearta an duine, ar chearta leanaí, ar chearta saoirsí, ar an meas ar éagsúlacht chultúrtha agus éagsúlacht teangacha, ar cheartas agus ar athmhuintearas. Tá na moltaí seo go léir thar a bheith tábhachtach agus caithfear dul i ngleic leo uilig i sochaí i ndiaidh coinbhleachta cosúil leis an tSeirbia.  In Éirinn, agus le Comhaontú Aoine an Chéasta, tá gealltanas ann ó na sínitheoirí Acht na Gaeilge, Bille na gCeart don Tuaisceart agus Cairt um Chearta an Duine don tír ar fad a chur cun tosaigh. Táimid fós ag troid i gcomhair fheidhmiú na rudaí seo. Mar sin cuirim fáilte roimh na moltaí atá sa tuarascáil seo.  É sin ráite, táim buartha faoin tslí a bhfuil an tuarascáil seo ag lorg ‘structural economic reforms’ agus ‘fiscal consolidation’. In Éirinn, is iomaí rud diúltach atá déanta ag na ‘leasuithe’ seo ar na daoine leochaileacha inár sochaí. Tá an-chuid damáiste agus fulaingt cruthaithe acu. Mar sin, staon mé ón vóta seo.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The normalisation of relations between Serbia and Kosovo is an example of the strong positive effects of the European Union's perspective. Although early elections in both Serbia and Kosovo have slowed the pace of negotiations between the two countries, countries should move forward with improving relations and, in a timely manner, to continue to fully implement all agreements already concluded. Serbia should make greater efforts to bring its foreign and security policy, including its policy towards Russia, into line with that of the EU. For example, Serbia did not follow the call for restrictive measures imposed on Russia by EU decisions, as well as joint military exercises with Russia.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I welcome serbia's progress report. It is very important that the country strictly adheres to the democratic rules of the game. The enlargement of the EU should be based on a coordinated policy. European integration is a continuous and dynamic process. It is therefore essential that it reflects the general changes that are taking place in the EU. It is to be welcomed that Serbia has made clear progress towards meeting the conditions of the Stabilisation and Association Process. However, it is essential that systemic, social and economic reforms continue to be carried out with determination and without a challenge. In particular, structural economic reforms need to be implemented in order to stimulate economic growth and improve the business and investment environment. In addition, the legal framework must be strengthened and uniform compliance with the law is ensured.  Serbia needs to accelerate progress in the field of energy. In this context, it is essential that the Commission support the Serbian Government's efforts to reduce the country's dependence on imported energy and to increase the diversity of energy resources.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that Serbia is making important progress in meeting the Copenhagen criteria and thus meeting the conditionalities of the stabilisation and association process; however, there are still many gaps that the country must remedy in order to pass the entrance examination. Considerable progress has been made in the normalisation and legal framework of relations with Kosovo. The new government seems to be motivated to work actively on the EU accession project and its actions are mainly geared towards this objective. Significant was the government's decision to authorise the Pride Parade, which took place without major incidents. Nevertheless, Serbia lags far behind in a number of areas.  Working more actively in the fight against crime, illegal migration, respect for environmental standards, strengthening the rule of law, protecting minorities and tackling systemic and socio-economic reforms are just some of the main challenges facing the Belgrade Government. The will seems to be there, the European need to integrate the former Yugoslavia countries as well. I am convinced that Serbia will be able to play an important role in the dialogue with its north-east neighbourhood in the future.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The reports on the accession path of the countries of the Western Balkans, Serbia, Montenegro, Macedonia, call for the ACCELERATION by the EU and their civil governments of unpopular reforms in these countries, which target labour-popular rights, remove any obstacles to the establishment of business groups and their profitability.  The accession process of these countries exacerbates all the problems of workers, intensifies their exploitation for the benefit of monopolies, implicates them in the dangerous imperialist plans of the EU-US-NATO and the competition raging in the wider region for resources of wealth, with unforeseen painful consequences against them.  The peoples of the Balkans have an interest in strengthening and coordinating their fight against the EU and NATO, in every imperialist alliance of capital and the capitalist path of development, opposing their own popular alliance for power, which will pave the way for peace, mutually beneficial cooperation and solidarity, for popular prosperity.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering that the European Council of 28 June 2013 decided to open accession negotiations with Serbia; that the first Intergovernmental Conference (IGC) took place on 21 January 2014; that in its 2014 progress report on Serbia's tasks, the Commission reports on serbia's progress towards European integration, assessing its commitment to meeting the Copenhagen criteria and the conditionality of the Stabilisation and Association Process; that good neighbourly relations are a key element of the positive European integration of any country and that bilateral issues must be addressed in the accession process in accordance with the negotiating framework, in a constructive and good neighbourly spirit; taking into account the EU's global interests and values; that important steps have been taken in the process of historical reconciliation between Serbia and its neighbours; stressing the progress made and the importance of improving the implementation of the EU-Serbia Stabilisation and Association Agreement (ASA); stresses that the ASA provides the general framework for Serbia and the EU to step up their cooperation, Pho voted in favour.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I consider Serbia’s integration process in the Western Balkans could play a decisive role in the European perspective of the region. It is a country with general well-preparedness and positive engagement. Serbia should continue on its way of enhancing the rule of law and progress in the normalisation process with Kosovo. Due to personal reasons, I was not able to vote, but I welcome the efforts made by Serbia so far in the European integration process.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. Again, this motion for a resolution, which follows on from the 2014 follow-up report on Serbia, requires submission to the Europeanist dogma. In view of the enlargement of the Union and the possible accession of Serbia, Serbia is required to harmonize its foreign and security policy with EU policy, particularly vis-à-vis Russia. There is still time for these States to back down in their desire to join the European Union, at the risk of being completely divested of their legislative, budgetary and perhaps monetary sovereignty in the long term. I have therefore spoken out against this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. I support this report by my colleague McAllister, his first on Serbia's annual progress on its European path. Serbia has a serious opportunity to actively coordinate and improve many areas of the internal political set-up through active politics, as part of membership negotiations with the EU, but much more than in previous periods to contribute to regional stability in the Western Balkans. It is the Western Balkans today that are not devoid of political, economic, social and security risks. As for the human rights compliance complex, it will also be best tested in Serbia in the position of minority communities. It is progress in this area that will help better understand Serbia and neighbouring states. Any country that today has European ambitions, in addition to adopting a general legal heritage, must also respect a common foreign and security policy. That is why opening negotiating chapter 31 as early as possible would be the right message at a time when the European Union is spreading through the Balkans.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome Serbia's efforts and commitment to the Process of European Integration, and for this reason, Serbia must carry out the necessary systemic and socio-economic reforms in a comprehensive manner.  That is why Serbia must improve the planning, monitoring and coordination of the EU's new rules and policies, which remains the key factor in a successful integration process. With a view to improving relations with Kosovo, I welcome the good improvement in relations achieved in the dialogue between the prime ministers of the two countries, with a view to initiating a process of normalisation with Kosovo.  I stress that it is important for the two countries to commit themselves to intensifying cooperation between them in order to combat and dismantle the criminal networks that are responsible for the exploitation and trafficking of migrants from Kosovo to certain EU Member States, via Serbia.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The Serbian government has made a lot of progress in negotiations with the European Union. However, the Commission and Parliament encourage Serbia to continue its efforts in the area of the rule of law and the reform of the judicial system. In addition, Serbia should intensify its efforts to harmonize its foreign and security policy with that of the Union, including policy towards Russia.  The European Parliament adopted the 2014 monitoring report on Serbia's progress. I support the reforms undertaken by this country. However, I reaffirm my wish to establish a moratorium of 5 to 10 years for any new membership.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Council of 28 June 2013 decided to start accession negotiations with Serbia, with the first intergovernmental conference (IIC) taking place on 21 January 2014. This resolution concerns the 2014 Monitoring Report on Serbia, which is intended to analyse the progress made by serbia in the process of European integration, assessing its efforts to meet the Copenhagen criteria and the conditions laid down in the Stabilisation and Association Process. I see that Serbia must improve the planning, coordination and control of the implementation of new legislation and new policies. In the same way, structural reforms in the socio-economic field need to be pursued in order to combat corruption and organised crime. I welcome the constructive approach taken by the Serbian government in relations with neighbouring countries, which has made substantial progress, both in terms of regional cooperation and rapprochement with the EU. Finally, it should be noted the work of independent regulatory bodies and their contribution to improving the legal framework and accountability of state institutions in the defence of the rule of law. I voted in favour.

name: Miloslav Ransdorf (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. – On the resolution on Serbia's progress in eu integration, I abstained because some points seem very contentious to me. Above all, these are parts of Kosovo, because Security Council Resolution 1244 still applies. Kosovo's declaration of independence was unilateral and has so far only been recognised in the international community by a minority of UN member states. Furthermore, Serbia cannot be prescribed the relationship with a non-EU country, the Russian Federation. The Russian Federation is a key partner of Serbia's foreign trade, especially in the field of raw materials and energy. It is a natural outlet for Serbian food products. I also find it unacceptable to prescribe to Serbia to limit its investment in coal, especially after Serbian mines have been flooded with water, and this has caused significant damage to Serbian energy. Although Serbia has done a lot in the area of small hydropower plants and therefore in renewables, it cannot be dictated what its energy mix should be. It should be taken into account that Serbia is the central economy of the Balkans and without its stabilisation the Balkans as a whole cannot be stabilised.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. In July 2014, European Commission President-elect Jean-Claude Juncker declared in the Chamber that "there will be no further enlargement in the next five years". A common-sense proposal that was high on the agenda of the MR programme during the last European elections. This need to solidify the House of Europe before it is enlarged does not mean that the ongoing negotiations with the countries of the near neighbourhood such as the Western Balkans must stop. These countries need a European perspective, but it must be recognised that both Serbia, Kosovo, Montenegro and Macedonia do not meet European standards today. In particular, European decision-makers are willing to pay much more attention to chapters 23 ("judicial apparatus and fundamental rights") and 24 ("justice, freedom, security"). With regard to Serbia, in addition to the normalization of its relations with Kosovo through the agreement reached on 19 April 2013, significant progress is to be made, such as the commitment made by the new Serbian government to the Process of European Integration. But clearly Serbia needs to make further progress in its priority reform, namely the rule of law, at the heart of the Union's enlargement policy.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the work carried out by Serbia in the framework of the work carried out for the process of joining the European Union. The commitment shown to EU integration shows that the guidelines pointed out by the different European entities have been taken into account. Important measures taken by Serbia in normalising relations with Kosovo and other neighbouring countries should be highlighted.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it welcomes the formal start of the accession negotiations which took place on 21 January 2014 at the first Summit of the EU-Serbian Intergovernmental Coordination Group and commends the successful implementation of the EU-Serbian Stabilisation and Association Agreement. However, attention is paid to the country's problems, such as freedom of the press, deteriorating conditions for freedom of expression, and lack of transparency in the financing of political parties and election campaigns. It should be noted that Serbia is invited to make greater efforts to ensure equal representation of women in political and public life, to improve the situation of Roma and to ensure the consistent implementation throughout the country of legislation on the protection of minorities.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. In this report yesterday, we called on Serbia to redouble its efforts to harmonize its foreign and security policy with that of the European Union, including its policy towards Russia.  In this resolution, we particularly regretted that Serbia had not aligned itself, when invited, with the Council's decisions introducing restrictive measures against Moscow, at a time when Serbia is in a position to play an extremely important role in EU-Russia relations.  We also called for Belgrade to make progress in systemic and socio-economic reforms, as well as in its judicial system and the rule of law. We also called for the opening of the negotiating chapters to take into account technical developments and the political climate in relations between Serbia and the European Union.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this text, which refers to the progress made by the Yugoslav Republic of Serbia in 2014 on reforms.  Progress has been made, thanks in particular to the Serbian government's commitment and constructive approach to neighbouring countries by building a stable dialogue with Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia and Croatia.  On the other hand, systemic and socio-economic reforms are expected, as well as progress in the independence of the judiciary and greater transparency regarding media ownership.  It is important that the Yugoslav Republic of Serbia continues on this path and continue its political, economic and social reforms.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 An open and constructive dialogue with Serbia is even more necessary today, especially in view of its relations with Russia, which are not aligned with European positions. A number of problems remain to be resolved, some linked to the presence of minorities and relations with Kosovo.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We abstained in the vote because, despite considering that Serbia's process of integration into the EU can be positive for its people, the Resolution has a language with which Serbia is still being accused, subjectively and arbitrarily, of past developments.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which welcomes Serbia's efforts, the new Serbian government's commitment to the European integration process and its constructive approach to relations with neighbouring countries, in particular with Kosovo, following the agreement reached under the aegis of the High Representative on 19 April 2013. However, much progress remains to be made to assert the rule of law, reform the judicial system, increase media transparency and intensify coordination of European and Serbian foreign policies, particularly vis-à-vis Russia.  This follow-up report does not prejudge Serbia's rapid accession to the European Union.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (NI)
text: In writing. The report calls on Serbia to "comply" with the "foreign policy" of the European Union. It therefore calls on Serbia to renounce its historical, cultural and strategic community with Russia. The Union therefore demands the vassalisation of new entrants and not the recognition of their specificities. I am opposed to this interference.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because it maintains the line of Parliament's views on the applicant countries, in which a colonial relationship between a rich and powerful centre and an impoverished and obedient periphery is reproduced.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 Serbia is an important country in its region because of its stability and it is to be hoped that it will live up to its hopes. The country is the main economy in the Balkans and without its active participation efforts to normalize relations in the region would be very difficult. In view of this, assistance to Serbia should also be considered, e.g. in the context of flood recovery, and possible cooperation on energy and the promotion of renewable sources. If such cooperation is in place, not only Serbia, but also its neighbours, can benefit, while increasing links and energy security in the region. The process of change in Serbia requires the opening of further chapters in the negotiation process with the EU, but the most important thing now is the continuation of the reforms that have started. Despite visible progress, it cannot be ruled out that there will be distortions, as in the case of a difficult initial period in the implementation of social reforms. Efforts should also be made to address the problems of abuse of power, but for this it will be necessary to involve and appropriate the state. The EU should also ensure that changes taking place in Serbia take place on a democratic path and not under any pressure from third countries, and such freedom should be guaranteed here.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of the resolution on the progress report on Serbia. The report welcomes the formal beginning of accession talks which began on 21  January 2014.  It draws attention to certain problems in the country yet to be overcome including media freedom, deteriorating conditions for freedom of expression and lack of transparency in the funding of political parties. Serbia must make an effort to address these challenges. It is hoped that accession talks will continue progressing smoothly.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: I abstained in writing ‒ given that I respect the official position of the Slovak Republic with respect to the Republic of Serbia.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the EP resolution on Serbia's progress report, which showed its commitment and readiness for EU membership in the new phase of the road to the European Union. Serbia received €1.2 billion in EU support from 2007 to 2013, which would boost its administrative capacity, but only 32 percent of citizens still have a positive attitude towards the EU. In addition to progress in reforms of public administration, the judiciary and the fight against corruption, Serbia needs to show a stronger commitment to regional co-operation by taking over the OSCE presidency. The duration of the negotiations will depend on the ability to resolve the most important chapters, concerning the rule of law, economic governance and active and constructive engagement around Kosovo and the normalisation of their relations.  Serbia needs reforms to attract as much quality investment as possible, but the economic situation was further hampered by catastrophic floods last year that have seen major damage. Serbia has significant economic potential in the development of waste management, as well as in the construction and development of green energy policy. Of particular concern is the over-reliance on coal as a major source of energy in the energy structure.  Emphasis should be placed on effectively resolving border disputes with neighbours and implementing all international treaties on minority rights. There are over 50,000 Croats living in Serbia whose cultural and minority rights need to be further supported and strengthened.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 I welcome the progress made by Serbia. We are ready to share with him our experience of the reform process. EU enlargement has proved to be a success story, and I am sure that it should continue to the Countries of the Western Balkans.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported Serbia's 2014 progress report. David McAllister, and I believe serbia must continue implementing reforms on the road to the European Union. It is essential that Serbia adequately adopts measures to combat corruption and organised crime, ensures the independence of the media, and that human and minority rights and fundamental freedoms are promoted and protected. I call on Serbia to more decisively align its foreign and security policy with that of the EU, especially when it comes to policy towards Russia. It is also very important that Serbia steps up co-operation with neighbouring countries and makes a step forward in resolving the issue of missing persons. To ensure the legal certainty of EU citizens, Serbia must also harmonise its Law on the Organisation and Competence of State Bodies in War Crimes Proceedings.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report as I welcome Serbia’s accession talks, but also believe we need to draw attention to problems and challenges the country is still facing in regard to media freedom, equal representation of women in political and public life, lack of transparency in the funding of political parties and election campaigns and deteriorating conditions for freedom of expression.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. – I support this report and the process of European integration, which is also in the interest of the Republic of Croatia, but with clearly set criteria and treatment of the EU that will not differ from what Croatia had in the negotiations. Only by truth, dealing with the past and respecting common values can we contribute to better relations. I point out that the Croatian EPP delegation has tabled a number of amendments to the report on Serbia's progress as those who are pushing Serbia to more efficiently establish cooperation to provide data in order to quickly find missing persons from the Homeland War. Also, the text of the report was an invitation to Serbian authorities to open JNA archives and open and access the UDBA archives to establish the truth about the past and tragic events. I expect that serbian authorities will implement bilateral agreements in accordance with the text of the report that oblige them to have Croat representation in the Serbian National Assembly, given the poor status of national minorities in Vojvodina, among which are many Croats. There are still many issues from the return of alienated cultural goods through the disputed law on Universal Jurisdiction of Serbia to the Danube border, so we will also articulate in the future the key issues raised during the Serbian aggression against Croatia with the aim of establishing better neighbourly relations and reconciliation. Most importantly, the acceptance of amendments urging Serbia to review the Law on War Crimes Jurisdiction committed on the territory of the former Yugoslavia.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ i supported serbia's resolution on progress for 2014. I welcome this report, which describes the progress made in the previous year. The report is balanced because it also draws attention to the problems that the country has. It is necessary to provide additional measures for a truly independent justice and an even greater fight against corruption and organised crime. Despite the great effort, this area still needs to be improved. And this call is clearly stated in this report. If Serbia does not become the right rule of law, it cannot become a member of the EU. We must therefore help Serbia to carry out reforms in the area of justice.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 In the report there are positive references to the need to safeguard freedom of speech, enhance transparency and safeguard minority rights as well as labour rights.  However, we cannot overlook the way kosovo is presented as an independent state in the report. The report also criticises Serbia for conducting joint exercises with Russia and calls for the alignment of Serbia's foreign policy with EU foreign policy, including policy towards Russia. Finally, the call for Serbia to carry out structural economic reforms, e.g. privatisations and other neoliberal austerity prescriptions, is particularly negative.  For these reasons, we abstained. We do not oppose the will of the people for a closer relationship with the EU. However, we cannot support interventions in the conduct of countries' foreign policy and also the imposition of economic models that have proven to have destroyed the peoples of Europe.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The intended enlargement of the EU will exacerbate the economic crisis plaguing the countries of the South, without succeeding in improving the living conditions of Serbs.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 With the adoption of the David McAllister Progress Report on Serbia, the European Parliament acknowledged the serbian government's efforts to implement reforms in the light of European values, while highlighting the necessary steps to be taken. From a Hungarian point of view, it is a special achievement that we were able to represent the rights of historical minorities beyond the border, and thus hungarians in Serbia, in a dign fitting manner with our amendments tabled by the FIDESZ delegation of the People's Party.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of this report, taking into account the fact that the success and credibility of the Serbian accession process is a key issue for the democratisation, long-term stability and economic development of the entire Balkan region in accordance with European standards. I think it is right that the report confirms the efforts and achievements of the new Serbian Government so far, but at the same time provides sufficient weight and detail on the tasks facing Belgrade and the EU's expectations at this stage of the accession negotiation process. I have considered two important aspects with particular weight: 1: Russian aggression against Ukraine has once again highlighted the importance of a single and coherent European foreign policy, and the report recalls for a reason that candidate countries are also expected to adapt to our common foreign and security policy. We cannot allow Belgrade – or any current and future Member State – to articulate and shape its Russian relations in the face of common EU interests. In the current situation, the EU has a legitimate expectation that the Serbian Government will join the sanctions.  2. The report rightly points out that an open, constructive neighbourhood policy and the guarantee and fulfillment of the rights of minorities are particularly important for long-term peace and stability in the Balkans. In this context, I think it is important that, in the case of Serbia, the report recalls the special and delicate situation of Vojvodina and its (mostly Hungarian) minorities.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ 2014 marked the opening of negotiations between Serbia and the EU, with the first Inter-governmental conference taking place in January of last year. This is a welcome step forward, which I hope will add momentum to enacting the comprehensive actions plans that have been set out, particularly regarding Chapters 23 and 24. I am pleased to note that the process of normalising relations with Kosovo is continuing, which is particularly important in the negotiations bearing in mind the added conditions of Chapter 35. As rapporteur for Montenegro I would like to raise attention to the recent commitment between Serbia and Montenegro to increase co-operation regarding security and policing. Agreements have been reached on opening up further border crossings, with increased border security co-operation, as well as working together to fight cross-border organised crime and corruption. The continuing links with United Russia, the high-profile visit of President Putin in late October 2014 and the failure to join in the European-wide sanctions against Russia do remain of concern, however. 2014 marks only the beginning of negotiations and there is a long road ahead. Nevertheless, Serbia remains politically committed to EU membership and has set out an ambitious road-map to achieving it.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. The opening of the negotiating chapters as soon as possible, taking into account technical developments and the political climate of relations between Serbia and the European Union, is in the European DNA itself.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ If I welcome the new Serbian Government’s commitment to the European integration process, the country must make progress in its systemic and socio-economic reforms, and also as regards its judicial system and the rule of law. This is the reason why by voting for this report I call on Serbia to redouble its efforts on the path of European integration.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ Serbia's progress on the road to joining the European Union is important for Croatia, but also for other European countries. I have no doubt that serbia's stabilisation process shows technical progress in a number of areas, but I must express regret over the lack of co-operation in many outstanding bilateral issues, as well as the Unwillingness of the Serbian Government to implement bilateral agreements with neighbouring countries. I regret, in particular, that no amendment has been adopted that anuses Serbia's law of exclusive jurisdiction that has wrongfully imprisoned Croatian citizen Veljko Maric. Consistent implementation of the EU acquis must be a priority, but I believe that the adoption of certain legal frameworks must at the same time adopt and respect the fundamental values of the Union. First of all, I mean respect for the fundamental rights of citizens, which unfortunately this report has not touched on and the forgotten Bunjevčki Croats who are on the margins of society and represent a group of populations threatened in the exercise of their rights.  I am particularly concerned about passivity in punishing war crimes, solving the problem of missing persons and the lack of desire to reclaim cultural treasures that were alienated in the Homeland War in a peaceful and civilized way, because I think it is necessary to make further progress in Serbia, so I voted against this report.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ We have to make a joint effort to leave the past behind and look to the future together, in peace and freedom, which is full of opportunities for all. We must recognise the efforts of Serbia to normalise relations with Kosovo. There must be the necessary legal framework to ensure the protection of minorities with regard to access to education, the media and especially regarding the use of language. I agree to meetings between the EU and Serbia being intensified because I am convinced that European values will bring them prosperity.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. This report announces a new commitment to enlargement with the thinly veiled aim of encircling Serbia by the submission of the countries of Eastern Europe. Injunctions such as: "invite Serbia to harmonize its foreign and security policy with that of the European Union, including policy towards Russia". This is a vassalisation of the countries of Europe to the NATO system. I voted AGAINST.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. "U2012 We have therefore abstained, despite considering that Serbia's process of integration into the EU can be positive for its people, the Resolution has a language with which Serbia is still being accused, subjectively and arbitrarily, of past developments.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Report on the evolution of Serbia's accession to the EU.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. The report welcomes the formal start of accession negotiations on 21 January 2014 at the first Summit of the EU-Serbian Intergovernmental Coordination Group and commends the good implementation of the EU-Serbia Stabilisation and Association Agreement. However, the report also draws attention to the country's problems, such as freedom of the press, deteriorating conditions for freedom of expression, lack of transparency in the financing of political parties and election campaigns. The report also invites Serbia, inter alia, to make greater efforts to ensure equal representation of women in political and public life, to improve the situation of Roma and to ensure the consistent implementation throughout the country of legislation on the protection of minorities

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because it maintains the line of Parliament's views on the applicant countries, in which a colonial relationship between a rich and powerful centre and an impoverished and obedient periphery is reproduced. In this particular case, in addition to meddling in the internal affairs of the State to press for the Neoliberal agenda of the European Union, Serbia is asked to recognize the self-proclaimed Republic of Kosovo to 'facilitate' its accession.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'From my interest in Kosovo, it is normal for me to follow developments in Serbia closely. Like Kosovo, Serbia also has a long-term prospect of possible eu membership. After the restart of the talks with Kosovo, one major stumbling block has already been removed in this rapprochement with the EU. But like Kosovo, Serbia, which has already come a meaningful way in terms of reforms, must also pay more attention to restoring the rule of law. The EU will focus more on reforms to the legal system, human rights, justice and security. This report has therefore received my full support.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We respect the sovereign will of the people of Serbia, in particular in deciding to join the EU or not. However, we see in this report another exercise of seduction that no longer lives to tie this country more to the neoliberal and militaristic agenda of the EU and NATO. With possible membership, it will once again be the people who suffer the consequences of this enlargement which corresponds to an insatiable desire of the EU to expand its market, while ensuring and expanding its military control over that area of Europe.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. Serbia is not only a part of Europe but also an important partner of the European Union. Long-term integration of the country into the EU, with the appropriate conditions for accession, is not only the right one, but also the logical path that this country and the EU must take. Since my Member State, Austria, would also benefit greatly from this accession, subject to the appropriate conditions, I voted in favour of this motion.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I do not agree with the motion for a resolution on the 2014 progress report on Serbia. Serbia is required to move closer to the acquis communautaire by adapting its national rules and reshaping its social coexistence. But the European Union is at an impasse of over-regulation, centralisation and unification. Serbia's supposed advances are therefore catching up in the wrong direction. If the direction is not correct, any speed is the wrong one. In this respect, it must be stressed that the omission is not due to Serbia, but rather to the European Union. It should not currently accept any other members. Before enlargement is possible, the dream of a free Europe must be redreamed. Once the foundations for a free, united Europe have been re-established, the enlargement process can be resumed.

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against amendment 4 of this text. While I believe it is important to demonstrate that the foreign policy actions taken by Russia with regard to its neighbouring European countries are completely unacceptable, nevertheless I cannot support an amendment which calls for Serbia to align its foreign and security policies with that of the EU. I strongly oppose the notion that the EU should be a foreign policy actor in itself, let alone increase its sphere of influence into non-Member States, which is why I choose to abstain on this vote.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the decision of the European Parliament adopted today on the progress made so far in Serbia's accession to the European Union. I voted in favour of this decision and I specifically appreciate that the reporter has also taken note of the rights of national minorities, such as the right to use the mother tongue, the right to education and the media in the mother tongue, and the right to representation at local, regional administrative and parliamentary level.  At the same time, I welcome the emphasis on the return of ecclesiastical and religious community property confiscated from national minorities by the former Communist regime as a recommendation, and the document specifically emphasises that without them religious freedom cannot be ensured in Serbia.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the 2014 progress report on Serbia and I too welcome the start of accession negotiations launched last year. Serbia has made significant progress in recent years and this deserves our respect and support. The opening of new chapters must continue as progress in reforms in the country continues. Of course, and there are areas where more needs to be done, but I am convinced that Serbia has made substantial progress to date and we must all reward these efforts.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The reports on the accession path of the countries of the Western Balkans, Serbia, Montenegro, Macedonia, call for the ACCELERATION by the EU and their civil governments of unpopular reforms in these countries, which target labour-popular rights, remove any obstacles to the establishment of business groups and their profitability.  The accession process of these countries exacerbates all the problems of workers, intensifies their exploitation for the benefit of monopolies, implicates them in the dangerous imperialist plans of the EU-US-NATO and the competition raging in the wider region for resources of wealth, with unforeseen painful consequences against them.  The peoples of the Balkans have an interest in strengthening and coordinating their fight against the EU and NATO, in every imperialist alliance of capital and the capitalist path of development, opposing their own popular alliance for power, which will pave the way for peace, mutually beneficial cooperation and solidarity, for popular prosperity.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Serbia is a country with many problems that it is trying to solve and, in my opinion, is making considerable progress. However, one problem that worries us the most, Kosovo, is still unresolved. Both sides must fulfil their commitments, and close cooperation with the EU can do them a great deal of good.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This motion for a resolution presents a wide range of recitals on serbia's eu integration process. Well beyond the evaluation of the process, it points to a wide range of conditionalities for membership, which confirm the extent of the interference and loss of sovereignty imposed on countries and peoples in the process of EU membership.  We highlight the interference in that country's relationship with the Serbian province of Kosovo, or in the relationship with the ICC, the intrusions into the country's economic, judicial and political system, the advanced foreign and security policy guidelines, including the country's membership of NATO integrated into the militarisation of the EU and the widening of influence in the Balkan region, among others. We consider unacceptable the manor stance with which the recitals and conditions required to satisfy the precepts relating to the integration of the country are unacceptable, removing from the peoples the legitimate right to decide their future, where they are registered, the free and sovereign choice of EU membership, but also the strategies of economic and social development. For these reasons we voted against.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – I voted in favour of the resolution on the kosovo integration process, as it represents a good overview of the past years, but at the same time draws attention to the major shortcomings and problems that Kosovo still faces and needs to change. The obvious fact we have seen lately is that people clearly do not see the future in their country. This is due to the inaction of a number of subsystems that are clearly not working in the country. But the exodus problem is just one of the last ones that have been ed out, and those... and clearly indicate that the country is in an alarming state, which is already affecting countries in the EU. Both those who live geographically close, as well as those to which the poor population is run by criminal gangs that give desperate people false hopes. In Slovenia, too, there are many impoverished people in Kosovo who do not see the future at home and testify to the difficult situation that ruled there.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – I also supported this report because the rapporteur, Mrs Lunacek, had made an absolutely righteous reflection of the events in Kosovo. Of course, there are an awful lot of problems with organised crime, drug trafficking, the dire economic situation, the fact that many people are forced to leave Kosovo.  Of course, in this report we also recommended the protection of the rights to self-determination and the use of native language of national minorities, including those of foresters, and this is the path that this country should follow if it wants to be part of the European family despite the problems. I appreciate Mrs. Lunacek's efforts. They're going in the right direction. That's why I supported this report.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this text is unacceptable because it simply does not take into account the interests and dismay of the Serbs, so dear to Victor Hugo.  He proposes to treat Kosovo as a solved problem. Kosovo would be a normalizing state, where Serbs and Albanians would coexist better and better. We are in denial of reality, in line with the absurd ideology that has prevailed for decades in the region, inspired by the American governments and the European Union.  The reality is that the European Union has been wrong about this issue since the break-up of Yugoslavia. The European Union has recognised the legitimacy of the terrorist organisation UCK and now recognises an institutionalised mafia as a state. Today, some see this state as a potential candidate for the European Union, as if European funds, policy frameworks and free trade could alter the deep determinisms of a complex region.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
