text: – I supported this Resolution on Kosovo because the will of freely expressed people, their possibilities for well-being and the integration of diversity as the basis of peace and stability are part of the founding values of the Union.  Kosovo's history refutes the ideas about sovereignty, identity and fundamental rights handled by these ancient nation-states, which still do not understand that we need a true federal Europe. A common space capable of dealing together with global challenges. A space that must be based on the free adherence of all the identities that form it, of all those who feel its citizens. A space in which the imposition of such sensitive issues as a national identity is the result of blindness for those who continue to believe that their territorial integrity—another concept to be reviewed—is above the will of individuals.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report as it continues along the lines of Parliament's positions on the applicant countries, in which a colonial relationship between a rich and powerful centre is reproduced in the face of an impoverished and obedient periphery. In this case, a positive vote is equivalent to the endorsement of the Atlantic Alliance's policy in the Balkans, imposed through illegal wars in order to divide the peoples of the former Yugoslavia and reposition the United States in Europe. The motion for a Resolution was a call on the authorities of the self-proclaimed Republic of Kosovo to consolidate the state attributes that have been equipped in recent years, which is why I voted against it.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – There were a number of positive aspects to the 2014 Progress report on Kosovo. The text outlines a number of current social and economic issues facing Kosovo including poverty, ethnic division and need for reconciliation, unemployment, minority rights and the social exclusion of or discrimination against women, the LGBT community, etc. However, the report also calls for ‘structural economic reforms’ and further liberalisation of its market which I believe would be damaging for Kosovo and its people, as it has been for many other countries in Europe and beyond. On this basis I abstained.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I strongly support the European perspective of the Western Balkans since the EU's enlargement policy strengthens stability and democracy in this region, which is why it must continue.  However, I believe that the European Parliament resolution should take into account the fact that five EU Member States, including Greece, have not recognised Kosovo as a state. That is why I voted to abstain in the final vote.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The European Parliament welcomes participation in the fight against terrorism and progress in gender equality and women's rights. It was also noted that progress has been made in meeting the requirements of the Visa Liberalisation Roadmap.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. This text marks a desire to integrate into the European Union a territory that is not recognised by some of the members of the UN Security Council. Five EU member states, including Spain, are challenging the independence of the territory. It is obviously not possible, in this diplomatic context, to start any negotiations towards possible integration into the European Union. The hostile policy towards the Orthodox Serb minority of the Pristina authorities is also evident. I naturally voted against this text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I do not support the accession of Kosovo to the European Union, and therefore voted against this resolution.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to assess the kosovo's European integration process. Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Kosovo, the former Yugoslav Republic and Serbia are the six countries of the Western Balkans applying for EU membership. Of these applicants, two are already negotiating membership of the European Union, Montenegro and Serbia. Albania and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia have the status of official candidates, while Bosnia and Herzegovina and Kosovo are considered potential candidates. The progress of all these candidates for EU accession varies, with many indicators lagging behind EU members. The main problems are high unemployment rates, corruption and restrictions on freedom of the press.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. Continuing a crazy logic of continued enlargement of the European Union, the Eurocrats now want to integrate a territory whose independence has not been recognised by all the members of the UN Security Council, or even by five of the Member States of the Union. For me, the Region of Kosovo-Metochia remains the cradle of Serbia.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Parliament welcomes the establishment of a parliament and the appointment of a government that marks the end of a six-month political impasse, but is concerned about the possible impact of the appointment of people with troubled pasts. The new government will have to strengthen the rule of law, as well as fight corruption, unemployment and organized criminalization. Parliament stresses that the establishment of the Special Court, as well as its cooperation with the Special Court, should be a priority and will enable Kosovo to face its past.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution on Kosovo's European integration process is again ideologically oriented. Moreover, this territory is not yet recognised by the UN Security Council, or even by five of the Member States of the European Union. In committee, several amendments had been tabled to deal with the ever-increasing interference of the Union. Moreover, while it is so quick to give lessons on human rights, how can the Eu consider integrating a territory where, between 1999 and 2004, of the 235,000 Serbs, Gypsies, Goranis and Turks expelled from Kosovo after the Kumanovo Accords, only 12,000 were able to return, 1,200 Serbs were murdered, 2,300 were kidnapped , more than 150 churches and monasteries were destroyed and 40,000 houses burned or destroyed with explosives? So I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not share the positions defended by the Resolution which partially analyses the lack of progress made by Kosovo as a pre-accession country and for this reason I did not support it with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The text welcomes the end of political stagnation after the months following the elections in Kosovo, with the establishment of the Assembly and the appointment of the new Government, emphasizing the urgency of addressing the strengthening of the rule of law and the judicial system, the fight against corruption and organized crime, unemployment, as well as structural economic reforms and sustainable development. The Socialist amendments, which are mostly included in the final text, concern the rule of law, the fight against terrorism and radicalisation; lack of transparency in the media and the importance of media freedom and independence; the role of women in government and the fight against discrimination against LGBT people; EULEX's role and the need for a comprehensive and in-depth analysis in order to assess the overall effectiveness of the mission; or, finally, strengthening relations with neighbors as an element of stabilization of the region. We abstained from what we consider inadequate call to recognise Kosovo's independence from the remaining Member States, including Spain.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this resolution, which discusses the process of European integration of Kosovo. Despite some progress made, Kosovo still has difficulty in implementing legislation on the protection of ethnic minorities and cultural rights. In this area, it is therefore necessary to make continuous efforts in this area in relation to the amendment of the law, including a provision on the rights of national minorities, in order to avoid direct and indirect discrimination. The European Parliament is concerned about the high unemployment rate, especially among young people, and discrimination on grounds of sex in the labour market. It should be noted that progress in the area of property rights remains slow and undermines long-term economic growth. Parliament considers that accession to international and regional organisations and mechanisms should be a priority for Kosovo, and therefore calls for the strengthening of relations with Kosovo and its representation in regional organisations, international agencies and bodies such as the Council of Europe, as well as in cultural and heritage institutions, with full membership status. It is also important to improve its representation in European and international media organisations so that Kosovo artists can participate in all international cultural events.

name: Mario Borghezio (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 Taking into account the persistent shortcomings of the judicial system, the high level of corruption, the strong presence of organised crime also involved in trafficking in human beings, the lack of protection of minorities and discrimination against women in particular, the lack of transparency in media funding and the shortcomings in labour market conditions, including rising unemployment; Also considering that the European Commission does not envisage any new membership of the European Union for the next 5 years, I voted against this resolution.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒Mr. President, I support this Statement, as well as the process of further integration of Kosovo while fulfilling all the obligations and responsibilities it entails. The rule of law, the fight against terrorism, the independence and transparency of the media, the role of women in the Government, as well as the decisive "NO" to discrimination against LGBT communities, are just some of the tasks on which those responsible must work even more decisively in implementing reforms of a country recognised by 23 of the EU's 28 Member States so far.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. The question of a stagnation of The Kosovo integration process can be asked. I can only express serious doubts about Pristina's efforts. Thus, this latest report encourages it to breathe new life into the reforms and notes that the normalization of relations with Serbia is taking a step forward. But many problems continue to arise, such as the fight against organized crime, corruption and a mass exodus of the population due to endemic unemployment, which hinder democratic development and the establishment of the rule of law. In addition, the report notes that anti-corruption action is totally ineffective because of "low political support". Here again, ideology takes precedence over reason: it is not relevant to start the process of accession, in the name of a dogmatic desire for continuous enlargement, of a territory which is not even unanimously recognised by the United Nations Security Council and which, moreover, is not recognised by five of the Member States of the European Union. In addition, it should be demanded that the country respect the Serb and Orthodox minority, which is still the victim of vexation on the territory of Kosovo.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ There were a number of positive aspects in this report on Kosovo. The text outlines a number of current social and economic issues facing Kosovo including poverty, ethnic division and need for reconciliation, unemployment, minority rights and the social exclusion of,  or discrimination against, women, the LGBT community, etc. However, the report also calls for ‘structural economic reforms’ and further liberalisation of its market, which I believe would be damaging for Kosovo and its people, as it has been for many other countries in Europe and beyond. On this basis I abstained.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. The report on Kosovo's European integration process is ideologically very oriented. The European Union wants to integrate a state that is not recognised as such by either five of the Member States of the European Union or by the entire UN Security Council.  But above all, how can the European Union envisage the integration of Kosovo, when multiple human rights violations have been committed and are still committed by the current government? As such, I would like to point out that of the 235,000 Serbs, Gypsies, Goranis and Turks expelled from Kosovo between 1999 and 2004, only 12,000 of them were able to return to their land.  This report testifies to the degree of vassalisation of the European Union to NATO's interests.     Naturally, I objected to the adoption of this text.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against, Kosovo still seems a long way from EU standards and does not, in my opinion, integrate the basic requirements of cultural and historical unity with Europe.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the Kosovo European Integration Process which calls on your government to make progress in reforms in order to provide its citizens with a better future. Seven years after the declaration of independence, Kosovo still faces many challenges: poor economic prospects, high unemployment and insufficient efforts to combat corruption and organised crime, slow progress on the rule of law and media freedom. The new government elected in December 2014 does not meet expectations of change, more jobs and a better health and education system. I therefore hope that the Government of Kosovo will make an effort to carry out the necessary reforms.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ There were a number of positive aspects in this report on Kosovo. The text outlines a number of current social and economic issues facing Kosovo including poverty, ethnic division and need for reconciliation, unemployment, minority rights and the social exclusion of,  or discrimination against, women, the LGBT community, etc. However, the report also calls for ‘structural economic reforms’ and further liberalisation of its market, which I believe would be damaging for Kosovo and its people, as it has been for many other countries in Europe and beyond. On this basis I abstained..

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Parliament resolution welcomes the end of the political stalemate following the elections. The new government is being encouraged to continue on its European path. Parliament highlights in its resolution a number of areas that remain of deep concern, these being the independence, accountability, impartiality and efficiency of judges and prosecutors, the prison system and the performance of the rule of law sector in general. Parliament welcomed the meetings taking place between Serbia and Kosovo. On the other hand, it called on both sides to  fully implement the agreements reached by both sides. Another element of serious concern are the allegations of corruption made concerning the EULEX in Kosovo. Parliament believes that this mission has played an important role in Kosovo, and it has still a role to play. It welcomed the prompt reaction by the VP/HR to appoint an independent expert to probe into the allegations. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today, 110 of the 193 UN member states, including 23 of the 28 EU Member States, recognise Kosovo's independence. Mrs Ulrike Lunacek's report does not keep quiet about the various problems facing the country: a situation that is still critical and difficult from a political and economic point of view and with still very high rates of corruption and crime. I therefore believe that Serbia and Kosovo must continue along the path of accession in parallel and we will work with them to ensure that this track is straight.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I refused to vote in favour of this text, which promotes the European integration of a territory whose independence is still not recognised by two member states of the UN Security Council or five of the Member States of the European Union. It is also to combat the ideological vision defended by the European Union that I tabled in the AFET committee 21 amendments on this dogmatic text. How can we claim to defend human rights and consider integrating into the Union a territory governed by authorities who have committed ethnic cleansing of Serb and Orthodox minorities? Moreover, as the Dick Marty report, written by the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe in 2011, showed, Kosovo is a narco-state, where trafficking of all kinds is rampant: drug trafficking, arms trafficking, but also human organs. Despite this, Mrs Lunacek, author of this report, and the other parliamentarians who voted for this text, want to start the visa liberalisation process and gargle with the association agreement between the European Union and Kosovo, which was signed in July 2014. This is further proof that ideology in the European Parliament is stronger than reality.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The process of integrating kosovo state is an indispensable and positive action. The establishment of the new government and the formation of the new Parliamentary Assembly six months after the elections require urgent democratic and transparent action on reforms. The reforms of justice, sustainable development and economic development are central and immediate, operating in the clarity and maximum participation of civil society.  The measure highlights the regulatory shortcomings of protection for both women and children and ethnic minorities. It also points out the urgent need to combat the crime that is the architects of terrorism and illegal immigration. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the measure.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on kosovo's European integration process, because this measure underlines the importance of the formation of the Parliamentary Assembly and the constitution of the government six months after the elections. However, there are countless aspects for which I believe reforms are urgently needed: I am thinking in particular of justice reform, economic reform and the promotion of sustainable development. I also believe that there is a need for greater inclusion of civil society in the decision-making process in Kosovo and that there is a lack of serious recognition of ethnic minorities. I particularly welcome the resolution's urgent call for the fight against criminal organisations, the main vectors of illegal immigration and terrorism.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I stress the quality and accuracy of Mrs Lunacek's report on the evolution of Kosovo as a candidate for eu union. It is indisputable that, in many of the valences, Kosovo is evolving positively, which confirms the value of EU enlargement as a tool to enable economic growth and the consolidation of democracy in the candidate countries. The report highlights, however, several areas of concern, some expected in view of the small size of the State and the fragility of its institutions. Since I maintain a prudent reserve position on further enlargement (I believe that there is still some time left for the EU to digest the latest enlargements), I abstain in its vote.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on kosovo's European integration process. It welcomes the formation of the parliamentary assembly and the formation of the government six months after the elections, but there are countless aspects for which reforms are urgently needed. In particular, reference is made to justice reform, economic reform and the promotion of sustainable development, calls for greater transparency and inclusion of civil society in the decision-making process; The serious shortcomings in the recognition of ethnic minorities, and in the protection of women and children, are also highlighted.  I welcome the urgent need to combat criminal organisations, which are the main vectors of illegal immigration and terrorism. Equally welcome is the call for a rapid remedy for high unemployment, a factor of social hardship that drives people to leave their country. In order to carry out the necessary reforms as soon as possible, this document encourages European countries that have not yet done so to recognise the Kosovan State, to cooperate and to establish trade relations with it and rightly calls for the renewal of the mandate of the Special Representative for Kosovo.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The motion for a resolution welcomes the end of the six-month political stalemate that followed the elections, with the constitution of the Assembly and the appointment of the new government. It encourages the new government to continue its European course and urges it to pursue steps to strengthen and affirm the rule of law. The resolution also stresses the need for urgent actions aimed at fighting the criminal groups that are making irregular migration possible. Whereas the resolution welcomes the progress achieved on women’s rights and gender equality it calls for measures to strongly address the challenges and problems regarding domestic violence and gender-based violence. It also expresses concern at the lack of any significant progress in fighting high-level corruption and organised crime and calls upon the authorities to redress the situation. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the EP's position on kosovo's European integration process. A number of critical points have been raised that deserve attention, including the lack of effectiveness in the fight against corruption and the need for legislative frame-work that guarantees freedom of the press, as well as diversifying energy sources and developing renewable energy sources.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution which welcomes the end of the six-month political stalemate that followed the elections. It stresses the urgency for the new government to pursue the necessary reforms with commitment and determination, and notably strengthening the rule of law and the judiciary, the fight against corruption and organised crime, unemployment, structural economic reforms, and sustainable development. Concerns still remain regarding the independence, accountability and impartiality of judges and prosecutors.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. The current Resolution of the European Parliament provides an update on the progress of Kosovo's European integration process, including the formation of the Parliamentary Assembly following the parliamentary elections and the recent establishment of a new government. Nevertheless, the resolution calls on Kosovo to undertake reforms in the independence, impartiality and efficiency of its judicial system, to launch a reform of its prison system and to improve the overall performance of the rule of law. The resolution also refers to accusations of corruption having targeted some of its members of the European Mission in Kosovo (EULEX) and welcomes the decision of the Vice-President of the European Commission, Federica Mogherini, to launch an investigation. Pending the outcome of this investigation, it is important to remember that the EULEX mission has a key role to play in Kosovo's European integration process. Considering all these elements, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. This resolution aims to encourage Kosovo in its process of normalizing political life, following the appointment of a new government and the formation of its national assembly. I voted in favour of this text, which calls for important reforms in all sectors, particularly in the area of justice and the independence of judges. With regard to membership of the European Union, it is still largely hypothetical, given the progress still to be made, and because the European Union must stop expanding in the coming years if it is to complete the integration of the countries that have recently joined it. On the other hand, concerns persist about the growing number of Citizens of Kosovo leaving their country for Eu Member States. I will remain vigilant on this issue in the coming months.

name: Luis de Grandes Pascual (PPE)
text: in writing. In my own name and right and representing the Spanish delegation of the PPE Group as Secretary-General, we would like to state, in relation to the Resolution on the Process of European Integration of Kosovo, that the negative meaning of our vote is due to the fact that the Resolution treats Kosovo as if it were an ordinary independent State, recognized by the entire international community. This is not the case, to the point that five Member States of the European Union, including Spain, have not recognised it.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. This text is unacceptable because it simply does not take into account the interests and dismay of the Serbs.  It proposes to treat Kosovo as a problem solved in advance thanks to the good European policies of the last two decades and years to come: Kosovo would be a state, in the process of normalization, where Serbs and Albanians would coexist peacefully. We are in denial of reality, in line with the absurd ideology that has prevailed for decades in the region through the action of the United States and the European Union. The reality is that the Union has been straying on this issue since the decomposition of Yugoslavia, in particular by recognising the legitimacy of the terrorist organisation UCK. Today, Kosovo is seen as a potential candidate for the Union, as if European funds, policy frameworks and free trade could alter the deep determinisms of a complex region.  Therefore, I voted against this report.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The report is concerned about the recent allegations of corruption within EULEX and welcomes the reaction by the VP/HR Mogherini to appoint an independent expert to probe into the handling of such allegations. The report takes note of the progress made by Kosovo in fulfilling the requirements of the visa liberalisation roadmap. It notes with concern the high unemployment rates. Finally the report regrets that due to the election events in both countries, the pace of high-level negotiations between Kosovo and Serbia has slowed down.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the motion for a resolution because, apart from the fact that the desired enlargement of the EU will exacerbate the economic crisis plaguing the countries of the South, we are opposed to the recognition of Kosovo.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution, as the European Union must continue to send a strong and clear signal in support of the integration process in the Western Balkans. I consider it essential that the five EU Member States that have not yet done so recognise kosovo's independence. I welcome the end of the six-month domestic political crisis following the elections and the appointment of the Government of Kosovo. I agree that the new government must take action in the fight against corruption and organised crime at all levels. I am pleased that progress has also been made in the organisational part of the judiciary. I consider it important to reach an agreement at the February meeting in Brussels on the composition of the court in northern Kosovo, which was a sensitive subject, as it was one of the cornerstones of the 2013 agreement. Under the current agreement, the Serbian and Kosovo Prime Ministers have agreed on an ethnic balance between judges and prosecutors in northern Kosovo. In my opinion, this is a great success, because a few years ago it would have been inconceivable that there would be equal numbers of Albanian and Serbian legal professionals in the judiciary. Kosovo is committed to normalising its relations with Serbia, which they need, as the country is in the process of stabilisation and association agreement.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution which supports the process of democratisation, state-building and economic development in Kosovo, within the framework of good relations between kosovo and the EU.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. Seven years after its independence, Kosovo still faces many challenges such as weak economic prospects, high unemployment or recognition of its independence. It is the only country in the Western Balkans whose citizens cannot travel freely within the EU and is therefore not a full member of the international community. The report also argues that Parliament should continue to push for visa liberalisation with Kosovo, something tangible that citizens understand and feel their effects on the first person. I would like to appeal to the Kosovo government to strengthen the fight against corruption and organised crime and to continue a constructive dialogue between Pristina and Belgrade, as well as progress in the rule of law and freedom of the press.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. As my colleague Aymeric Chauprade, a recognised geopolitician, rightly pointed out in the Committee on Foreign Affairs, Kosovo is not unanimously recognised by the UN Security Council, or even by five of the Member States of the European Union. This "up-to-the-boutiste" desire to integrate Kosovo is an illustration of the European Union's adventurous foreign policy. There will come a time when history will judge what happened in Kosovo. I am voting against this text.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 First of all, it should be recalled that the unilateral declaration of independence of the Serbian province of Kosovo was a serious and unacceptable precedent in the context of the violation of international law. Remember that this independence is still not recognised by many countries, including some that are part of the EU, while weighing the strong pressures of the latter to recognise. This was a process that undoubtedly contributed and contributed to the instability of the Balkan region. This is a stark example of interference and the instrumental nature of EU and US foreign policies in defending their geostrategic interests, disregarding and affronting fundamental rights of peoples. An example that casts bare contradictions in the EU's discourse on the defence of border maintenance.  They're reasons for our vote against.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report as it is not objective and I do not share the political will behind the proposal.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the motion for a resolution on kosovo's European integration process, because, apart from the fact that the desired enlargement of the EU will exacerbate the economic crisis plaguing the countries of the South, I am opposed to the recognition of Kosovo.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the resolution approved in the Committee on Foreign Affairs and I believe it is a positive step forward. More efforts need to be made to strengthen the rule of law and the judiciary to combat corruption and organised crime, to reduce unemployment, enact structural economic reforms and promote sustainable development. I strongly support the amendments made by our Group: the focus on the importance of transparent media, the role of women in government and progress in the negotiations with Serbia. We, from Romania, are following these negotiations very closely and we are going to take them into account.  We need to increase cooperation in the fight against terrorism and radicalisation. We need, regarding the role of EULEX, to have a broad and deep analysis in order to assess the overall effectiveness of the mission. A call for full transparency is crucial for the credibility of the European institutions.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. We must celebrate the progress made in Kosovo, while being aware of the enormous challenges ahead. The consolidation of the rule of law in all its forms and dimensions should be one of the priorities of the Government of Kosovo. Structural economic reforms and sustainable development should also be promoted through the creation of a regulatory framework and incentives for economic development. The EU must support Kosovo in fulfilling its obligations and overcoming its recent past, as well as in achieving the results of the Belgrade-Pristina dialogue.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. Just over 15 years ago, European public opinion was appalled at the outbreak of a new conflict within the continent. Today, Kosovo, after an uninterrupted series of tensions and historical sedimentations of nationalist rivalries, finally seems, albeit slowly, to move towards a path of pacification, also thanks to the intervention and help of Europe. The Lunacek report – which I fully supported – has the merit of fully reconstructing the state of the political situation in Kosovo and of indicating the crucial elements on which European action must focus in order to contribute to further democratic progress in the country.  The electoral events of recent months have led to a slowdown in the pace of negotiations between Kosovo and Serbia, which is, of course, the main scenario to be analysed in order to assess the young Balkan country's progress towards democracy and peace. The report notes this situation but also welcomes the resumption of talks between Belgrade and Pristina in February 2015 in Brussels. I hope that the European Parliament's report will be able to urge the new Government of Kosovo to continue along the European path, implementing a number of priority issues, including the strengthening and affirmation of the rule of law, the definition of a judicial model based on the principles of independence, professionalism and effectiveness, and a systematic and effective fight against corruption and organised crime.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on the European Integration Process of Kosovo because it is crucial that we send out a clear signal to the effect that, following the resolution of a six-month political stalemate, the government now urgently needs to achieve step change in strengthening the rule of law and the judiciary, eradicating corruption and organised crime, strengthening employment, and laying strong foundations for structural economic reforms and sustainable development. Deeply concerned about the recent allegations of corruption against EULEX, I also urge the independent expert appointed by VP/HR Mogherini to carry out investigations on this matter in full transparency.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Kosovo was militarily occupied by NATO under the pretext of a humanitarian alibi in 1998. However, United Nations Security Council Resolution 1244 of 10 June 1999 states that Kosovo is an autonomous province of Serbia. In 2008 Kosovo unilaterally declared its independence, therefore violating international law. Since then there has been a persecution and criminalization of the Serbs, the destruction of their historical monuments has been carried out, important corruption scandals have been detected, it has been linked with organ trafficking, drug trafficking and jihadism to senior leaders who were part of the ELK (typified by international organizations as a terrorist organization).  It can be said that the state is a kind of U.S.-backed narco-state as there is a key military base for U.S. interests in the region. As a result, Kosovo's process of integrating into the EU would mean the recognition of Kosovo, contrary to international law, and would further undermine tensions in the region by hampering reconciliation and stability. That is why we voted against this resolution.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which looks at the political stalemate that has followed its recent elections. The report highlights the need for the new government to carry out necessary reforms such as strengthening the rule of law and fighting against corruption and organised crime in the country.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome Parliament’s call for all the EU’s Member States to recognise Kosovo’s independence. The EU is a union of independent states and national self-determination is a fundamental right. Countries which continue to ignore Kosovo’s independence show a lack of respect for the democratic wishes of that country’s people.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Kosovo was militarily occupied by NATO, under the guise of a humanitarian alibi, in 1998. However, United Nations Security Council Resolution 1244 of 10 June 1999 states that Kosovo is an autonomous province of Serbia. In 2008 Kosovo unilaterally declared its independence, therefore violating international law. Since then there has been a persecution and criminalization of the Serbs, the destruction of their historical monuments has been carried out, important corruption scandals have been detected, it has been linked with organ trafficking, drug trafficking and jihadism to senior leaders who were part of the ELK (typified by international organizations as a terrorist organization).  It can be said that the state is a kind of U.S.-backed narco-state as there is a key military base for U.S. interests in the region. As a result, Kosovo's process of integrating into the EU would mean the recognition of Kosovo, contrary to international law, and would further undermine tensions in the region by hampering reconciliation and stability. That is why we voted against this resolution.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. My vote is negative because Spain does not recognize Kosovo as an independent country.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the report on Kosovo's European integration process, as I consider the issue important for stability in Southeast Europe and for making progress on a number of issues that are important for Kosovo and thus for the wider region. In this regard, the fight against corruption and organised crime and Kosovo's participation in the fight against terrorism are primarily important. Urgent action should be taken against criminal groups, greater tolerance in society and respect for human rights should be built, and cooperation with civil society organisations in particular those dealing with women's rights and LGBT groups should be increased. There are concerns about the issues of judicial independence and effectiveness. The resolution highlights the problem of respecting Monuments of Serbian and Orthodox heritage and the heritage of other peoples. It is important to point out that the Stabilisation and Association Agreement was initialled in 2014. In this regard, it is important for the Council to take the necessary decisions necessary for the use of the EU programme. I commend the proposal to extend the mandate of the EU Special Envoy for Kosovo after the end of the current mandate. The key to kosovo's continued integration is the resumption of Serbia-Kosovo meetings and respect for the agreements reached between the two sides.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. This text is unacceptable because it simply does not take into account the interests and dismay of the Serbs.  It proposes to treat Kosovo as a problem solved in advance thanks to the good European policies of the last two decades and years to come: Kosovo would be a state, in the process of normalization, where Serbs and Albanians would coexist better and better. We are in denial of reality, in line with the absurd ideology that has prevailed for decades in the region because of the United States and the European Union. The reality is that the Union has been wrong about this issue since the decomposition of Yugoslavia. The Union has recognised the legitimacy of the terrorist organisation UCK, and now recognises an institutionalised mafia as a state.  Today, we see this 'state' as a potential candidate for the European Union, as if European funds, policy frameworks and free trade could change the deep determinisms of a complex region.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the Kosovo integration process. I support the continuation of reforms in this country and share the rapporteur's concerns, particularly on the question of the independence of judges.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. Negotiations on a stabilization and association agreement with Kosovo were concluded and the agreement was signed in July 2014. Kosovo has made significant efforts to meet the EU's accession criteria. This sends a positive signal to all the countries of the Union, which shows that Europe has not ceased to be attractive.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. The economic and political situation in Kosovo is a disaster. The country is experiencing one of the largest waves of emigration in terms of the total population, the government is not advancing economic or political reform, and it is managing the country as if it were privately owned. For this reason, I cannot support the report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support the European integration process of Kosovo. Kosovo’s authorities have to pursue the necessary reforms with commitment, and strengthen the rule of law, the fight against corruption, discrimination, unemployment, and structural economic reforms for the benefit of citizens. I continue to strongly support the aspirations of the Western Balkan countries to engage in European reforms and to become EU members themselves. The process of integration will strengthen the democratic institutions of these countries, modernise their economies and thus improve the lives of citizens. Labour Party Members and the S&D Group will be sure to keep enlargement high on the EU’s political agenda.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 11 March 2015, we voted in the European Parliament on a motion for a resolution tabled by the Council and the Commission on the European integration process in the case of Kosovo. First of all, I would like to say that I have never agreed with the international recognition of the Republic of Kosovo as an independent and sovereign entity in the relations of international law. I believe that kosovo's declaration of independence has proved wrong and the opening of the Pandora's box, which should have remained closed forever, and as such is perceived by the main actors at the time who pushed for kosovo's recognition. In my opinion, this was then a flagrant violation of the fundamental principles and principles on which public international law is based, and this decision by some states indirectly resulted in several tragic situations in international relations, in particular in relation to events in Ukraine, Scotland or Catalonia. By bending the international community to the breaking of the fundamental rules of public international law, it has set a very dangerous precedent for everyone else, who is currently being abused. That is why I voted against the motion for this resolution.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – The recommendation provides a long list of negatives that characterise kosovo's public conditions. As is known, the EU took note in 2008 but did not recognise kosovo's declaration of independence. He left it up to the Member States to act. To date, the EU's 5 member states (Spain, Cyprus, Greece, Romania and Slovakia) do not recognise Kosovo.  Recent events in thinking people have raised many questions about how some peoples may have the right to independence, even where they have settled and why others who have lived on their land as indigenous peoples for thousands of years do not have the right to do so.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of the resolution on kosovo's European integration process as it urges the new government to continue its activities by continuing its rapprochement with the EU, stressing the need to make further efforts to up assert the rule of law in Kosovo.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on Kosovo, which underlines the urgency and absolute need for Kosovo to pursue structural reforms. The text calls on the Government of Kosovo to make the rule of law, the independence of the judiciary and the implementation of effective anti-corruption measures its top priorities.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. I, like the other Members of the National Front, voted against the follow-up report on Kosovo, because we want to integrate into the European Union, in the name of an ideological will for continuous enlargement, a country that is not even recognised by five current Member States. The report highlights the absence of any significant progress in the fight against high-crime and organised crime in Kosovo. It reports links between organized crime and members of the public administration. He is also concerned about the extent of illegal possession of firearms, and the rise of radicalization among some young people, some of whom join jihadist movements in Iraq and Syria. Let us be clear: it is not in the interests of the Member States to give a prospect of accession to a country like Kosovo.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this text because it wants to integrate Kosovo into the European Union, even though it is a state whose existence is recognised by only 23 of the 28 Member States of the Union. Furthermore, I am opposed in principle to any further membership of the Union.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report as it continues along the lines of Parliament's positions on the applicant countries, in which a colonial relationship between a rich and powerful centre is reproduced in the face of an impoverished and obedient periphery. In this case, a positive vote is equivalent to the endorsement of the Atlantic Alliance's policy in the Balkans, imposed through illegal wars in order to divide the peoples of the former Yugoslavia and reposition the United States in Europe. The motion for a Resolution was a call on the authorities of the self-proclaimed Republic of Kosovo to consolidate the state attributes that have been equipped in recent years, which is why I voted against it.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. I agree with my colleague, shadow reporter and S&D MEP Pier Antonio Panzeri, that Kosovo needs to deliver on strengthening the rule of law, including the independence of the judiciary, the fight against organised crime and corruption, and reforms in their public administration. Socioeconomic developments have to be carefully dealt with. Kosovoʼs authorities have to responsibly outline a vision and provide Kosovoʼs citizens with a perspective of tangible economic improvement.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the motion for a resolution because Greece does not even recognise Kosovo's education. In addition, the action of extremist Islamic elements in Kosovo raises strong concerns in the region. There have already been mass arrests of suspects for involvement in combat operations in Iraq and Syria. The revival of Albanian nationalism is particularly worrying, as Tirana is pushing Kosovo forward with the redeeming idea of Greater Albania demanding a change of borders in Balkan territories belonging to Greece.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. Dominique Martin voted against this proposal without hesitation. This proposal to integrate Kosovo is a consequence of the European Union's obsession with integration, even though the territory of Kosovo is not unanimously recognised by the UN Security Council and within the Union only 23 out of 28 Member States officially recognise Kosovo.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 I had to reject the joint resolution dealing with Kosovo and therefore voted against it. I still believe that the unilateral proclamation of an independent Kosovo in 2008 was a gross violation of international law and a counterproductive step in terms of eu objectives and policies in the Western Balkans. The situation in Kosovo is not yet fully stabilised, there are criminal organisations that allow illegal migration to take place, corruption, organised crime, illicit arms trafficking are on the rise, and the high unemployment rate – around 30% – is also worrying. Relations with Serbia, of course, are very problematic, where dialogue between them is only very slow. In short, there are more than enough problems in the area. I could not support the resolution.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report which expresses concern at the lack of any significant progress in fighting high-level corruption and organised crime, a significant obstacle in the way of Kosovo’s democratic, social and economic development. It stresses the need for a clear signal from the government that Kosovo is systematically tackling corruption at all levels and fighting organised crime and calls for further steps to prevent any possible link between organised crime and people within the public administration. It is also concerned about widespread illegal ownership of firearms and calls on the Kosovar Government to initiate programmes to collect such firearms. It calls on Kosovo to cooperate with the EU expert group on arms trafficking and with neighbouring countries in taking preventive action, and calls for the EU to provide every form of technical assistance required for that purpose.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 23 of the 28 Member States of the European Union have recognised kosovo's independence. According to what was concluded during the EU Election Observation Mission, the last legislative elections were held within the country on the basis of transparency and inclusion.  I voted in favour of the resolution because it urges the new Kosovar Government to continue on its European path. At the same time, it adequately stresses the importance of affirming the rule of law within the country.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. The status of the Serbs in Kosovo must be clarified and the Serbs on the ground must be protected. In addition, the persecution and destruction of Serbian culture in Kosovo must finally be stopped.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. For Ukraine, the European Union's enthusiasm for the principle of border inviolability and territorial integrity is overwhelming. When it comes to Kosovo's independence, these principles have been and are put in brackets. This resolution does not respect the UN resolution or the opinion of the five EU Member States which have not recognised Kosovo's independence. In fact, it participates in the general enthusiasm for the militarization of the region, not denouncing the Kosovar government's desire to create an army, nor the extension of the joint mission with NATO forces on the ground. The resolution calls for following the structural economic reforms envisaged in the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with the Union.  There is no answer to the increasing migration to the Balkans since the break-up of Yugoslavia, when one third of the local population is unemployed. The report simply notes "the absence of any significant progress" in the fight against corruption and organised crime, even though Kosovo has been the largest recipient of European aid per capita in the world. I'm voting against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have always been and continue to be a critic of how Kosovo's independence has been recognised. I therefore follow with interest this process of integration that I hope will not make the same mistakes of the past.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution outlines the steps that Kosovo still needs to achieve in the integration process. The author highlights the need for the Kosovo authorities to live up to their responsibility to respect, conserve and protect Serbian, as well as all other, cultural and religious monuments, which form part of the common European cultural and historical heritage. The report also calls on the Vice-President / High Representative and the Member States to extend the mandate of the EU Special Representative for Kosovo beyond 28 February 2015. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of this resolution on the Kosovo integration process, which is part of the European Union's actions in the region. Indeed, the latter works to enable the normalization of Kosovo's relations with its neighbours. I also support the European Parliament's call for a thorough and full investigation into the recent allegations of corruption within the EULEX mission.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution, which is a balanced text that welcomes the end of the six-month political stalemate that followed the elections, with the constitution of the Assembly and the appointment of the new government. I support the European integration process of Kosovo. However, Kosovo’s authorities have to pursue the necessary reforms with commitment, and notably strengthen the rule of law, the fight against corruption, discrimination and unemployment, and structural economic reforms.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Kosovo is one of the neuralgic points of the Balkans and europe as a whole, due to the many problems mentioned in the report, so it is particularly important that the country's integration into Europe is progressing in as many areas as possible and as quickly as possible. The steps that have been praised or proposed in this report can, in my view, be effective in helping to do so.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Kosovo unilaterally declared its independence in 2008, following the failure of international negotiations. Several countries such as Portugal, France, Germany and the United States recognized it as a sovereign state. However, countries such as Spain, Russia that consider Kosovo part of Serbia still remain.  For the above reasons Kosovo is only a potential candidate for the Union. However, the Union has been supporting its economic and social development through not only financial aid, but also through EULEX's presence in the territory, with the aim of implementing reforms to achieve a rule of law and the presence of the Union's Special Representative in Kosovo.  Kosovo has been gradually implementing some reforms. However, there are still elements in the judicial sphere that undermine the implementation of a rule of law, namely the full independence, transparency, impartiality and efficiency of judges and judges.  It is now important to investigate the alleged cases of corruption within EULEX, so that there can be concrete clarifications. On the other hand, the dialogue between Pristina and Belgrade should continue to maintain stability in the region.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The report on Kosovo's European integration process is ideologically very oriented. There is a desire of the European Union to integrate Kosovo, a state which is not even unanimously recognised by the UN Security Council, or even by all the Member States of the European Union, into an infinite enlargement process.  Several amendments have been tabled in committee in an attempt to rectify his overt dogmatism and interference. How can the Union teach lessons on human rights and minority rights on the whole world and do everything possible to bring Kosovo into its midst, where, between 1999 and 2004, of the 235,000 Serbs, Gypsies, Goranis and Turks expelled from Kosovo, only 12,000 were able to return?  I therefore objected to the adoption of this text.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the process of European integration of Kosovo. Kosovo's independence is recognized by 110 of the 193 UN member countries, as well as 23 out of 28 European Union countries. The resolution recalls that the EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement was signed in July 2014, that the parliamentary elections in May and June 2014 were transparent and well organised, as were the municipal elections that preceded them. Nevertheless, it also stresses that much progress still needs to be made in strengthening the rule of law.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the end of the political stalemate that lasted about six months after the last elections, with the constitution of this House and the appointment of the new government, which we call for to continue on the European path through measures to strengthen the rule of law, the definition of a judicial model based on the principles of independence, professionalism and effectiveness, as well as a systematic and effective fight against corruption and organised crime at all levels.  Despite the progress made in the legislation governing the judicial system and its organisation, there are still strong concerns about the independence, accountability, impartiality of judges and prosecutors, as well as the functioning of the Judicial Council, the prison system and the protection of the rule of law. We agree that further efforts must be made to prepare for the full transfer of responsibilities from the European EULEX mission to Kosovo. In this regard, we express our deep concern at the recent allegations of corruption within EULEX and therefore welcome the Rapid Reaction of the High Representative to appoint an independent expert to investigate in depth the follow-up to these allegations. We therefore call for the full transparency of these investigations and call on all parties involved to cooperate fully to ensure that they are concluded quickly.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it presents the progress of the dossier of a country applying for membership of the European Union and merely takes stock of that country's progress.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution because I believe that European integration is the key to stabilising Kosovo and the region as a whole. Today's vote, by a large majority, is a sign of great confidence in that country. Seven years after the declaration of independence, Kosovo still faces many political, economic and social challenges. It is therefore extremely urgent and essential that Kosovo continues to implement the reforms necessary to continue on the European road.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained in the vote on the European integration process of Kosovo in accordance with Romania's official position on this subject.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: scríofa. ‒ Bhí cúpla rud dearfach faoin tuarascáil seo ar an gCosaiv. Léirigh an téacs seo cúpla ceist eacnamaíochta agus sóisialta sa Chosaiv, cosúil leis an mbochtanas, deighilt eitneach agus an gá atá ann don athmhuintearas, dífhostaíocht, cearta na mionlach agus eisiamh sóisialta nó idirdhealú in aghaidh na mban agus an phobail LADT. É sin ráite, tá an tuarascáil seo ag lorg ‘structural economic reforms’ agus tuilleadh léirscaoileadh den mhargadh rud a chreidim a bheadh dainséarach don Chosaiv agus do na daoine ann díreach cosúil leis an tslí a raibh sé dainséarach do thíortha eile san Eoraip agus cinnte, ar fud an domhain. Mar gheall air sin staon mé ón vóta seo.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The normalisation of relations between Serbia and Kosovo is an example of the strong positive effects of the European Union's perspective. Although early elections in both Serbia and Kosovo have slowed the pace of negotiations between the two countries, countries should move forward with improving relations and, in a timely manner, to continue to fully implement all agreements already concluded. The recognition of Kosovo's sovereignty by the five EU Member States that have not yet done so would also contribute to the normalisation of relations between Belgrade and Pristina.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution.  Progress in the transposition of EU norms is an essential criterion for assessing the candidate's readiness to open formal accession negotiations. Kosovo is to be resolute in pursuing European objectives and actively addressing a wide range of priority issues, including actions to strengthen and confirm the rule of law and to establish a model for judicial authorities. Every state must respect human rights, the principles of freedom, democracy and legitimacy.  However, despite some progress made, the Kosovo authorities should step up their efforts to combat unemployment in a systematic and effective manner, to promote structural economic reforms and sustainable development, to create a regulatory framework and incentives for small and medium-sized enterprises, and urgent action is needed to combat criminal groups and high-level corruption.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The EU's "Stability and Association Agreement with Kosovo" is part of the EU-US-NATO imperialist plans, the use and upgrading of this Euro-Atlantic protectorate in the Western Balkans region and the wider region, increasing the risks to peoples.  The permanent presence of EULEX, the EU's largest police force in the region, only guarantees the continuation of poverty, misery and exploitation, as demonstrated by its interconnection with business groups, organised crime and corruption rings, a self-evident consequence of the imperialist intervention of the EU and its NATO and US allies.  The European Parliament seeks to take a more active role in lobbying for the recognition of the Euro-Nato protectorate by EU Member States that have not yet done so, as well as for its full and unconditional recognition by Serbia, under the agreement imposed by the EU's "gun to the head", under blackmail and pressure to continue Serbia's EU accession process , serving part of Serbia's bourgeoisie.  It is further proof that the choice and commitments of the urban classes in the process of closer association and in the PROCESS of EU accession only ing new ills for the peoples of the Balkans.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that negotiations for the EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement (ASA) were completed in May 2014 and that the ASA was initialled in July 2014; that each (potential) candidate country will be judged on its own merits and that the speed and quality of the necessary reforms set the timetable for accession; welcoming the end of the six-month political stalemate that followed the elections, with the constitution of the Assembly and the appointment of the new government; expressing concern about the appointment of persons who are the subject of controversy, whose background could be called into question; deploring the unnecessarily high number of ministers and deputy ministers in the new government, with their budgetary implications, as well as the small number of women among ministers; urging the new government to continue along the European path and stressing that it is committed to pursuing with determination, including through a legislative framework, a number of the country's priority issues; I welcome the progressive strengthening and greater coordination between civil society organisations of the progress made in the legislation governing the judicial system and its organisation.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the fact that Kosovo has been able to overcome critical differences and that the government is engaged in progressing the country towards the EU and advancing in the European spirit. I regret I was not able to vote on the resolution, due to absence.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the adoption of a resolution on the Report on the Kosovo European Integration Process recognised by the Republic of Croatia in March 2008. I welcome the establishment of a dialogue between the authorities of the Republic of Serbia and Kosovo and any effort to respect and normalise relations with each other, as confirmed by the first agreement on the principles governing the normalisation of relations, signed by Prime Ministers Hasim Thaҫi and Ivica Dacic on 19 April 2013, as well as the Action Plan for Implementation from 22 May 2013.   In this regard, I also consider it important to call on the Report to sign a co-operation agreement between the Serbian and Kosovo authorities with a view to containing and dismantling criminal networks that control, exploit and smuggle irregular migrants from Kosovo through Serbia to individual EU member states.  The resolution also lists all critical areas where Kosovo still has to make efforts to improve democratic processes and continue to work for the country's stability. In particular, I underline efforts to combat corruption and organised crime at all levels, the establishment of a functioning judiciary and the rule of law, the adoption of effective and comprehensive legislation and an institutional framework for the media. Also, Kosovo needs to make efforts related to economic progress, poverty eradication, and ensuring higher employment in the country.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution on Kosovo's European integration process is again ideologically oriented. Moreover, this territory is not yet recognised by the UN Security Council, as well as by five of the Member States of the European Union. In committee, several amendments had been tabled to deal with the ever-increasing interference of the Union. Moreover, while it is so quick to give lessons on human rights, how can the Eu consider integrating a territory where, between 1999 and 2004, of the 235,000 Serbs, Gypsies, Goranis and Turks expelled from Kosovo after the Kumanovo Accords, only 12,000 were able to return, 1,200 Serbs were murdered, 2,300 were kidnapped , more than 150 churches and monasteries were destroyed and 40,000 houses burned or destroyed with explosives. So I voted against it.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 After six months of deadlock, the Assembly was finally established in Kosovo and a government was appointed. I voted in favour of this resolution because it is right that the Kosovan nation should now feel the support of the European Union, even though 5 of the 28 Member States have not yet recognised its independence, and I would encourage them to do so.  Kosovo must implement the reforms with strength and commitment, so that the process of European integration can take place quickly. In order to allow this, the Kosovo authorities must strengthen the rule of law and the judicial system, make it independent and impartial so that it can guarantee its citizens. It is also absolutely essential that we have an effective fight against corruption, discrimination, particularly against women, and unemployment, focusing on structural economic reforms and sustainable development.  To avoid, by means of prevention, any radicalisation that may result in forms of terrorism, guaranteeing transparency in the media and freedom of the press. I am also very pleased with the decision taken by the High Representative for the appointment of a legal expert to clarify EULEX's role in the alleged corruption allegations.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. As head of the European Parliament's delegation to Kosovo, I welcome my colleague Lunaček's report, which had to cover the extraordinary dynamics of events in Europe's youngest country. Particular attention in European terms was caused by large-level migs of "asylum seekers" from Kosovo, which resulted from backwardness, but also a lack of perspective on the vast work of the population. This is an opportunity for the new Kosovo authorities, as well as the European institutions, to change the situation for the better as quickly as possible.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the Report on kosovo's European integration process after the end of the six-month political blockade that followed the elections, followed by the constitution of the Assembly and the appointment of a new government. The new government is encouraged to continue on its European path. Implementing reforms is the most important task along the way. Problems adhesion to the judiciary, especially in the fight against corruption and organised crime, must be first on the reform list. The alignment of legislation with the European acquis must guarantee the rule of law and the functioning of the acquis. All allegations of organised crime must be transparently investigated and independently prosecuted. Ensuring judicial independence, increasing employment and preserving existing jobs lead Kosovo towards the society of economically prosperous countries and will attract potential investors. The inability to find a job is an urgent call to initiate structural economic reforms to reduce the unemployment rate, which by the way is the highest in Europe. Europe's Kosovo is certainly a guarantor of stability in Southeast Europe. It is also important to mention relations with neighbouring Serbia that are progressing according to the latest indications. Serbia and Kosovo must continue to co-operate, respecting the agreements already reached and develop new ones through dialogue.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the fact that the new government was recently appointed in Kosovo and the Assembly was established after the long standoff after the elections. I hope that the new government will implement the necessary reforms with commitment and determination and without further delay, it is important that the rule of law, an independent, professional and effective judicial model and a systematic fight against organised crime and corruption are strengthened.  If Kosovo is to aim for European integration, this House must also adopt a new regulation in line with European best practice. I also believe that it is a priority for the authorities in Serbia and Kosovo to try to establish cooperation agreements to combat and dismantle the criminal networks responsible for controlling and exploiting irregular migrants as well as for the trafficking of migrants from Kosovo to certain EU Member States via Serbia.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Kosovo still faces a number of challenges of its international recognition. The fact remains that even five EU Member States still do not recognise this state. However, even in this situation, it is necessary and pragmatic for the Union to communicate and cooperate with Kosovo in a number of areas. In doing so, it is necessary to monitor respect for the rights of minorities, not only serbs, but also smaller groups such as roma, Kosovan Egyptians or Askals. Of course, the level of corruption or the state of the economy and the rule of law remain a problem in Kosovo. Cooperation with Kosovo is also important because there are cases of radicalisation and attempts to leave islamist extremists in Syria and Iraq. The report presented on the situation of the Union's contacts with Kosovo is, in my opinion, balanced and therefore deserves support.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As in previous years, I voted against the Lunacek Report on the European integration process of Kosovo. And that is not because I do not want a better future for the people of Kosovo, but because, as has happened in previous years, the position of member states that do not recognise Kosovo is not taken into account. The call to these states, in paragraph 20, to proceed with this recognition is in flagrant contradiction both with the fact that state recognition is a national competence and with the idea of neutrality with regard to Kosovo's status, which underpins European policies on this issue.  Moreover, this year, the Lunacek Report establishes an unacceptable link between the recognition of Kosovo and the process of normalising relations with Serbia. It is clear that the two processes are distinct and are also managed at institutional level separately. If recognition is solely within the Member States, the process of normalising relations with Serbia is a bilateral one, managed by the European External Action Service.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. The negotiations on the STABILISATION AND Association Agreement between the EU and Kosovo were concluded in May 2014. This resolution welcomes the end of the six months of political deadlock following the elections, encourages the new government to continue on the path of European integration and reports on progress in this area. Progress has been made in the law on the judicial system and its organisation. However, there are still strong concerns about the independence, accountability, impartiality and efficiency of judges and prosecutors and the functioning of the Kosovo Judicial Council.  It should also be noted the allegations of corruption concerning EULEX, which highlight the lack of significant progress in the fight against high-level corruption and organised crime. In any case, it is important to encourage the new Government to continue on the European path and to welcome its commitment to pursue a series of reforms with the aim of strengthening and affirming the rule of law, the independence of the judiciary and the fight against corruption and organised crime at all levels. I voted in favour.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because we must praise the end of the six months of political deadlock that followed the elections, with the constitution of the Assembly and the appointment of the new Government. However, there are still some concerns about the new government, with the budgetary implications arising from the unnecessarily high number of ministers and deputy ministers, as well as the small number of women in the executive. The new government must be encouraged to pursue the necessary reforms with commitment and determination in order to align this country with the European principles necessary for its full integration.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. In July 2014, European Commission President-elect Jean-Claude Juncker declared in the Chamber that "there will be no further enlargement in the next five years". A common-sense proposal that was high on the agenda of the MR programme during the last European elections. This need to solidify the House of Europe before it is enlarged does not mean that the ongoing negotiations with the countries of the near neighbourhood such as the Western Balkans must stop. These countries need a European perspective, but it must be recognised that both Serbia, Kosovo, Montenegro and Macedonia do not meet European standards today. With regard to Kosovo in particular, the economic and social situation is serious: an unemployment rate of 35%, which reaches more than 55% among young people, and widespread corruption at all levels of society. Without any prospect, between 30,000 and 50,000 Kosovars have left the country in the past two months, an exodus not seen since the 1999 war. The European Union must therefore set itself first and foremost as a priority to help the Kosovars build a future in their country.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although a new government has been appointed for Kosovo, I express my concern at the unnecessarily high number of ministers and deputy ministers in the new government, given the budgetary implications arising therefrom. It is also worrying the small number of women in ministers' positions. The increase in the number of women in this position could serve as a positive incentive for society at large. It is important that this new government also gives a clear signal that it is fighting corruption and tax fraud, a very present problem in Kosovo.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The text celebrates the end of political stagnation after the months following the elections in Kosovo, with the establishment of the Assembly and the appointment of the new Government, emphasizing the urgency of addressing the strengthening of the rule of law and the judicial system, the fight against corruption and organized crime, unemployment, as well as structural economic reforms and sustainable development. The Socialist amendments, mostly included in the final text, concern the rule of law, the fight against terrorism and radicalisation; lack of transparency in the media, and the importance of media freedom and independence; the role of women in government and the fight against discrimination for LGBT people; EULEX's role and the need for a comprehensive and in-depth analysis in order to assess the overall effectiveness of the mission; or strengthening relations with neighbors as an element of stabilization of the region. We abstained because we consider the call to recognise Kosovo's independence to the remaining Member States, including Spain, inappropriate.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. We voted yesterday on a resolution calling on the Council to adopt "as soon as possible, and by mid-2015 at the latest" the decision to sign and conclude the stabilisation and association agreement between the European Union and Kosovo, an agreement signed in July 2014. The text of the resolution stresses that this decision would result from "a powerful motivation to implement and institutionalize reforms" and that the agreement would give Kosovo "new opportunities to consolidate relations with its neighbours and contribute to the stabilization of the region".  We also welcomed the appointment of a new government and called on the government to implement reforms, including strengthening and consolidating the rule of law, establishing a judicial system based on the principles of independence, professionalism and efficiency, the systematic and effective fight against corruption and organised crime, and economic and social reforms.  In addition, we have once again encouraged Spain, Greece, Cyprus, Romania and Slovakia, which have not yet recognised Kosovo, to do so, believing that this would further contribute to the normalization of relations between Kosovo and Serbia.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. Kosovo has encountered political stability difficulties in recent times, with a six-month political stalemate and the appointment of a new government; In this sense, it is extremely urgent and essential to continue the necessary reforms and to continue to spread our European values.
