Thus, Kosovo must make progress in the rule of law, the independence of the judiciary and the fight against corruption and organised crime. At the international level, Kosovo must continue to deepen the Belgrade-Pristina dialogue and normalize its relations with Serbia over the long term.  I voted in favour of this resolution to support Kosovo's efforts and encourage its future reforms.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Stabilising the entire Balkan region is of strategic and economic importance for the whole of the European Union. The case of Kososvo is one of the most difficult, if we consider that not all Member States have recognized this. The recent corruption scandal involving EULEX reaffirms the need to engage even more in that area.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Kosovo was militarily occupied by NATO, under the guise of a humanitarian alibi, in 1998. However, United Nations Security Council Resolution 1244 of 10 June 1999 states that Kosovo is an autonomous province of Serbia. In 2008 Kosovo unilaterally declared its independence, therefore violating international law. Since then there has been persecution and criminalization of the Serbs, their historical monuments have been destroyed, major corruption scandals have been detected and senior leaders who were part of the ELK (typified by international organizations as a terrorist organization) have been linked to organ trafficking, drug trafficking and jihadism.  It can be said that the state is a kind of U.S.-backed narco-state as there is a key military base for U.S. interests in the region. As a result, Kosovo's process of integrating into the EU would mean the recognition of Kosovo, contrary to international law, and would further undermine tensions in the region by hampering reconciliation and stability. That is why we voted against this resolution.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which is alarmed by the political and economic situation in Kosovo: a new and largest government composed of people who are not unanimous, high poverty and unemployment, endemic corruption and no significant progress in the fight against organised crime. The report calls for closer dialogue with the European Union to promote the necessary reforms. This report does not prejudge Kosovo's rapid accession to the European Union.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (NI)
text: In writing. Kosovo's independence is not recognised by five of the Member States of the European Union. This entity was guilty of a policy of ethnic cleansing against Serbs present in this territory, which constitutes the historical heart of Serbia. Between 1999 and 2004, of the 235,000 Serbs, Gypsies, Goranis and Turks expelled from Kosovo after the Kumanovo Accords, only 12,000 were able to return, 1,200 Serbs were murdered, 2,300 kidnapped, more than 150 churches and monasteries were destroyed and 40,000 houses burned or destroyed with explosives. We must also stress that Kosovo is a hub for trafficking into Europe. I voted against it.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report as it continues along the lines of Parliament's positions on the applicant countries, in which a colonial relationship between a rich and powerful centre is reproduced in the face of an impoverished and obedient periphery.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Socialist and Democrat MEPs strongly support the European integration process of Kosovo and therefore voted in favour of the resolution. The new government in Kosovo must urgently pursue the necessary reforms on the rule of law, corruption, employment etc. with commitment and determination. To date, 23 out of 28 Member States have recognised Kosovo’s independence, and this resolution encourages the remaining five Member States to proceed with the recognition of Kosovo. Strengthening relations with its neighbours should be seen as a method to advance stabilisation in the region.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: I abstained in writing ‒ given that I respect the official position of the Slovak Republic towards the territory of Kosovo.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the motion for a resolution on Kosovo's European integration process, seeing it as an incentive to implement reforms necessary to meet obligations under the Stabilisation and Association Agreement. Although Kosovo declared its independence from Serbia in 2008, five member states did not recognise its status as a state: Greece, Spain, Slovakia, Cyprus and Romania.  The Kosovo government should make efforts to curb corruption and organised crime and establish the rule of law and the protection of minorities. The economic situation in which the state finds itself creates a feeling of hopelessness and strong depression in the population. The high unemployment rate is over 30%, of which more than 55% are young people. Almost five percent of the population, i.e. 90,000 people have emigrated illegally to the European Union and will be returned after the asylum deadline. Their survival will depend entirely on a state that is not ready for their return.  Relying on lignite as a major source of energy does not ensure Kosovo's sustainable development in the future. Instead of building new power plants, renovation of old ones is needed, which will bring much-needed short-term positive effects and harness the potential of renewable energy sources.       A strong financial burden is the absence of an area code, an internet domain, as well as participation in the system of green cards of insurance companies. It is necessary to address the IMF and plan the budget and guarantee allocated funds.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I support the European Parliament resolution on the process of integrating Kosovo into the European Union, which is why I voted in favour of its adoption in plenary on 11 March 2015. The authorities and residents of the Republic of Kosovo have achieved important political, administrative and economic reforms. Nevertheless, much remains to be done to strengthen the rule of law, which is the cornerstone of long-term development, democracy and the social market economy. In addition, Kosovo has strengthened its capacity to address the priorities of the integration process in the European Union by follow-up to the short-term priorities identified in the feasibility study and by preparing for the negotiations on a Stabilisation and Association Agreement with the EU. Kosovo has changed and adopted important legislation, including laws on asylum, party financing and trafficking in human beings, as part of the visa liberalisation dialogue. Despite good progress, further efforts are still needed to address the challenges of the European Reform Programme under the Stabilisation and Association Agreement, in particular in priority areas such as the rule of law, the judiciary, public administration, electoral reform and human and fundamental rights. However, I am confident that Kosovo will continue to successfully cope with the progress and improvements in the country in the coming years.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ I am aware that the basic condition for continuing Kosovo's European path is its agreement and dispute settlement with Serbia. Kosovo's approach to the European Union is the best precondition for stabilising the region. The expansion of dialogue between governments in Belgrade and Pristina is the hope that one day the two parts of the former Yugoslavia will meet again in a united Europe. This time of your own free will and as equal partners.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support the proposal for a resolution on Kosovo's European integration process. By ending the six-month political stalemate and appointing a new government, Kosovo can move decisively to implement the necessary reforms and continue on its path to Europe. Kosovo's progress is slowly being seen in certain areas, but the key is to implement reforms itself. The new government needs to focus on addressing a number of priority issues, such as minority rights, strengthening and upholding the rule of law, media independence and public administration reform. Of course, I encourage the Kosovo government to send us a clear sign that Kosovo is systematically fighting organised crime and corruption at all levels, because this is the area where progress is expected.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as I welcome the end of Kosovo’s six-month political stalemate following the elections, and also support the call for the new government to pursue necessary reforms that will strengthen the rule of law and judiciary, fight against organised crime and corruption. Furthermore, I support the resolution’s encouragement for all EU Member States to recognise Kosovo’s independence.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. – I welcome the end of the six-month political stalemate that followed the elections and the convening of the Assembly and the appointment of a new government. I encourage the new government to focus on addressing priority issues, measures to strengthen and uphold the rule of law, establishing a model of justice based on the principles of independence, expertise and efficiency, and systematic and effective fight against corruption and organised crime at all levels. While political turmoil and street protests over poverty, unemployment and corruption are ongoing in Kosovo, according to available data, around 20,000 people leave the country every month in search of a better life in one of the Western members of the European Union, with a large number entering the European Union illegally. That is why I call on the authorities of Serbia and Kosovo to adopt co-operation agreements that would control and dismantle the criminal networks they control, exploit and smuggle migrants from Kosovo through Serbia towards the EU. I also support Kosovo's involvement in the fight against terrorism, given changes to Kosovo's penal code to take tough measures against foreign fighters and actions taken by authorities to hand over to justice those involved in recruiting young people to access extremist groups.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on the process of integrating Kosovo into the European Union, which is balanced and objective. It clearly points to the structural problems in Kosovo with regard to the economy and the rule of law, but it also shows the way forward. This is a clear signal that Kosovo's future is in Europe. The citizens of Kosovo deserve concrete results and solve the biggest problems. Particular attention should be paid to improving the rule of law, judicial independence and strengthening the fight against corruption. It should be made clear that the main responsibility for progress is on the part of Kosovo. The main institutions, the political summit and civil society must play their part and contribute to a faster path to the European Union.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Any enlargement of the EU will exacerbate the economic crisis plaguing the countries of the South, without succeeding in improving the living conditions of its respective citizens

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. In this regard, I would like to point out that Kossovo works very closely with the various Member States, including asylum claims on unfounded or even abusive claims through deterrence campaigns.  Kosovo is the last Balkan country whose nationals need a visa to travel to the Schengen area. I have asked the Commission for a clear position on the subject.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which calls on the new government to set up reforms for the development of the country and develop its integration process. In particular the new government must strengthen the rule of law, reinforce the judicial system and fight against corruption and organised crime.

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. It is necessary to urge States that have not done so to recognize Kosovo as a State. The European Union must participate in peacemaking and reconciliation in the Balkans by recognizing and negotiating the political actors that have resulted from the political processes of the region. That is why I voted in favour of the report on the Kosovo European integration process.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I am pleased with Kosovo's progress because any effort to reform, regardless of the European integration process, results in a better state of society and a better life for citizens. I believe this is in the interest of the European Union and the Kosovo authorities and therefore I do not expect turbulence in our relations. Kosovo's progress towards EU membership will definitely be marked by relations with Serbia. We are currently in an absurd situation where we are negotiating membership with a country that does not recognise its southern neighbour while at the same time fostering a European perspective of that neighbour that not all Member States have recognised either. I believe that the insistence on the recognition of Kosovo by members who have not done so so far and by Serbia is a question of credibility, and therefore I take the opportunity to call on all actors in this process to clearly and unequivocally determine themses according to Kosovo's statehood and European future.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Whereas 110 of the 193 Member States of the United Nations recognize Kosovo’s independence, including 23 of the 28 Member States of the EU and knowing that each candidate country will be judged on its own merits and that the speed and quality of the necessary reforms determines the timing of EU membership. I agree with this motion to encourage the new government to follow the European course and pursue firmly, even through a legal framework, a number of priority issues, including the consolidation and validation of the rule of law. I welcome the progress made on issues such as women’s rights and gender equality, the coalition against terrorism, the Stabilisation and Association Agreement in July 2014, which provides for enhanced political dialogue, greater trade integration and new forms cooperation. Finally, I think that the Member States that still don not recognize Kosovo, should act as soon as possible in order to establish diplomatic relations with this new European state.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. It is inconceivable to vote for this highly ideologically oriented report. In essence, the European Union would like to integrate within it, in the name of an ideological will for continuous enlargement, a territory that is not even unanimously recognised by the United Nations Security Council or by five of the Member States of the European Union. I am opposed to Kosovo's integration into the Union. I voted AGAINST.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Kosovo was militarily occupied by NATO under the pretext of a humanitarian alibi in 1998. However, United Nations Security Council Resolution 1244 of 10 June 1999 states that Kosovo is an autonomous province of Serbia. In 2008 Kosovo unilaterally declared its independence, therefore violating international law. Since then there has been a persecution and criminalization of the Serbs, the destruction of their historical monuments has been carried out, important corruption scandals have been detected, it has been linked with organ trafficking, drug trafficking and jihadism to senior leaders who were part of the ELK (typified by international organizations as a terrorist organization).  It can be said that the state is a kind of U.S.-backed narco-state as there is a key military base for U.S. interests in the region. As a result, Kosovo's process of integrating into the EU would mean the recognition of Kosovo, contrary to international law, and would further undermine tensions in the region by hampering reconciliation and stability. That is why we voted against this resolution.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report as it continues along the lines of Parliament's positions on the applicant countries, in which a colonial relationship between a rich and powerful centre is reproduced in the face of an impoverished and obedient periphery. In this case, a positive vote is equivalent to the endorsement of the Atlantic Alliance's policy in the Balkans, imposed through illegal wars in order to divide the peoples of the former Yugoslavia and reposition the United States in Europe. The motion for a Resolution was a call on the authorities of the self-proclaimed Republic of Kosovo to consolidate the state attributes that have been equipped in recent years, which is why I voted against it.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'As shadow rapporteur, I have coordinated the Liberal Group's position on this issue. Kosovo's European integration process has been restarted after a few months of silence. Kosovo and Serbia have restarted their talks and Kosovo is gradually moving back into the European Union. There is still a lot of work to be done on fighting corruption, improving the rule of law and building a viable economy. I am pleased, also on behalf of my group, that progress is being made and have supported this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We respect the sovereign will of the people of Kosovo, particularly in deciding to join the EU or not. However, we see in this report another exercise of seduction that no longer lives to tie this country more to the neoliberal and militaristic agenda of the EU and NATO. With possible support, it will once again be the people who suffer the consequences of this enlargement which corresponds to an insatiable desire of the EU to expand its market, while ensuring and expanding its military control over that area of Europe.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. The status of the Serbs in Kosovo must be clarified and the Serbs on the ground must be protected. In addition, the persecution and destruction of Serbian culture in Kosovo must finally be stopped.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I do not agree with the motion for a resolution on the process of European integration of Kosovo. Kosovo is required to move closer to the acquis communautaire in the run-up to negotiations on a Stabilisation and Association Agreement by adapting its national rules and reshaping its social coexistence. But the European Union is at an impasse of over-regulation, delusion of centralisation and unification. Kosovo's supposed progress is therefore catching up in the wrong direction. If the direction is not correct, any speed is the wrong one. In this respect, it must be stressed that the omission is not the fault of Kosovo, but rather of the European Union. It should not currently accept any other members. Before enlargement is possible, the dream of a free Europe must be redreamed. Once the foundations for a free, united Europe have been re-established, the enlargement process can be resumed.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 European Parliament decision on Kosovo, which was adopted today by the Plenum, objectively analyses the steps taken by this country in the process of edcra with the European Union. With this decision, the European Parliament shows its support for the Republic of Kosovo and encourages the Government of Pristina to continue to follow the European line. I voted in favour of this decision and I also welcome the fact that the text of the document contains recommendations to the Kosovo authorities on the necessary investments in the education system of ethnic communities and disadvantaged communities.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The EU's "Stability and Association Agreement with Kosovo" is part of the EU-US-NATO imperialist plans, the use and upgrading of this Euro-Atlantic protectorate in the Western Balkans region and the wider region, increasing the risks to peoples.  The permanent presence of EULEX, the EU's largest police force in the region, only guarantees the continuation of poverty, misery and exploitation, as demonstrated by its interconnection with business groups, organised crime and corruption rings, a self-evident consequence of the imperialist intervention of the EU and its NATO and US allies.  The European Parliament seeks to take a more active role in lobbying for the recognition of the Euro-Nato protectorate by EU Member States that have not yet done so, as well as for its full and unconditional recognition by Serbia, under the agreement imposed by the EU's "gun to the head", under blackmail and pressure to continue Serbia's EU accession process , serving part of Serbia's bourgeoisie.  It is further proof that the choice and commitments of the urban classes in the process of closer association and in the PROCESS of EU accession only ing new ills for the peoples of the Balkans.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This motion for a resolution presents a wide range of recitals on the process of kosovo's integration into the EU. It is imperative to recall that the unilateral declaration of independence of the Serbian province of Kosovo was an unacceptable precedent in international law, which is still not recognised by many countries, particularly among those in the EU. This situation undoubtedly contributes to the instability of the Balkan region and which is a glaring example of the interference and loss of sovereignty that the process of European integration and the external policies of the EU and the US impose on the peoples. That puts the indisputable contradictions in the EU's discourse on the defence of border maintenance raw.  For these reasons we voted against.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of this report because we must all admit that the recovery that we all expected, unfortunately, has not arrived. Let us now hope that the European Commission's forecasts are real. The three priorities identified are acceptable: investment, structural reforms and budgetary consolidation will certainly help the recovery. It is important to stress, however, that flexibility cannot be lacking in this context. Budgetary interventions must not affect growth or even be an impediment or investment in research, education and training. Small and medium-sized enterprises, one of the largest resources for the market, still face many difficulties in accessing credit and finance. Levels of social protection are minimal in many countries and are a long way from being standardised. The Structural Funds are not always spent or even lost.  Expecting growth was therefore naïve: the good thing is, however, that we now know where to start again and, above all, what to correct.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I supported this report too as it welcomes the Commission’s new approach to economic policy, with focus on growth and investment.  The report for me also insists on reforms that are very important, and which are required from Member States, that they must be socially—balanced and growth friendly and that the surplus countries must do more to re—launch growth in Europe. However, I believe in the future that the European Commission should also take into account the reforms made by Member States to tackle tax fraud and tax evasion and give credits to these Member States in the same way as Member States who reduce their excessive deficit get credits.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: - Madam President, the three pillars on which growth is based, are structural reforms, fiscal consolidation and investment. Investing in education, research and development, fostering innovation, modernisation, a cheaper energy source are important for achieving productivity and competitiveness. Investments are falling because there is no confidence and no hope of recovery, no willingness to take risks, entrepreneurs are over-indebted, financial markets are fragmented. The investment gap can and must be bridged by targeted public investments and the opening of favourable sources of financing to entrepreneurs. This report shows that determined and courageous governments and states can look to the future with optimism, and that is why I am pleased that the report is overwhelmingly supported in Parliament today.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the economic crisis still has many consequences that slow down the European Union's economic recovery, although a recovery is expected for 2015 and a further improvement for 2016. However, these improvements can only be achieved on the basis of three pillars proposed in the 2015 Annual Growth Survey: relaunching investment, accelerating structural reforms and pursuing responsible fiscal consolidation conducive to growth. This is linked, however, to the need for the European Union to increase its global competitiveness by increasing and planning investment in innovation and development and by improving the market for goods and services. Finally, I agree with the emphasis in the report on measures to increase the efficiency of public administration and those aimed at improving the labour market, paying particular attention to youth unemployment, the sad scourge of our time. The report does this, and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Morten Messerschmidt (ECR).
text: Madam President! I voted against this report. It is not because I as such disagree with the figures or believe that the content as such can be discussed, but because the perspective is completely wrong. It completely overlooks the fact that growth in the world is significantly greater than it is in Europe. Growth in Europe is significantly higher than it is in the EU and growth in the EU is significantly higher than it is in the Euro zone. Ergo, there's something tear-wringing- raging wrong in the Eurozone. The European Union will not emerge from recession until we put an end to the foolish idea that we can conduct a common exchange rate with such different economies. There is only one way to save it: either to abandon democracy, so greeks and Germans, and what do I know can no longer choose their own fiscal policy, or convince northern Europeans to finance southern Europeans forever. Neither thing is going to happen. That is why the whole project should be scrapped, and only then can we see growth again in Europe.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: - Madam President, thank you for the floor. I reject the report on the European Semester on principle. In the run-up to the financial crisis, President Nicolas Sarkozy announced the need to create a European economic government that should function as a real government. This wording was found by many to be strong, so it was dressed in disguise, thus resulting in closer economic coordination and the European Semester under discussion. In essence, the Union requires national governments to specify what should be included in their financial economic plan. At the end of the semester, it will be clear whether or not the Union will accept this. It should be made clear: the European Semester is the pre-regulation and approval of member states' budgets, thereby limiting the sovereign right of national parliaments to budget.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it positively sanctions the neoliberal orientation of the economic governance framework. The annual prospective study is the European Commission's economic study that starts the entire European Semester process. This study develops a very limited monetarist analysis, which does not take into account eer the social effects of austerity policies or differences in the productive structures of EU Member States. On the basis of this limited analysis, austerity recommendations to Member States will be justified, deepening the effects of the crisis. This report does not in any way condemn the way in which this study is drawn up and that is why I have decided to vote against it.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. I welcome the promotion of investment, the acceleration of structural reforms and the pursuit of responsible, growth-friendly fiscal consolidation. I support the Commission's proposals to improve the European Semester by streamlining existing procedures, including the timetable, as well as strengthening competitiveness and the internal market.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. The coordination of economic policies does not seek to combine the different national objectives to define common strategies in certain key sectors, but tends to strengthen the internal market. The latter appears to be the central concern of the proposed text, whose incantations can only aim at the convergence of the Union's economies and regulatory harmonisation. The European Semester is an economic plan that does not meet the needs of the Member States, which only meets supranational political objectives and is proving to be both ineffective and contrary to the sovereignty of the Member States, which is why I voted against this text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I do not believe that the European Semester process is sufficiently democratic, and in any event as a UKIP MEP I should vote against for reasons of principle.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the European semester, because this practice is a first step towards vital economic coordination for the euro area. The result will be the creation of an economic government of the euro area.

name: Guillaume Balas (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the European semester for the coordination of economic policies: annual review of growth 2015. Beyond the few details made on how the European Investment Fund works, this text bears the seal of a classic liberal philosophy: hailing the "success" of the troika's programmes in Greece, Portugal and Ireland, this resolution calls on the other Member States of the European Union to show the same ambition in modernising their economies...  The troika's record is disastrous: economic recession, soaring unemployment and a significant increase in debt. I believe that continuing on the path of austerity and the dismantling of social protection systems further inflates the European economy in the rut of the crisis.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a European Semester for economic policy coordination: employment and social aspects. According to this year's European economic growth forecasts, high unemployment rates will continue to remain high, indicating that fundamental structural reforms in the economic and social areas are struggling. I support the investment promotion plan put forward by the President of the Commission, but it should not be seen as an alternative to the necessary reforms, but an additional instrument that will allow funds to be allocated to projects with European and economic and social returns. The creation of a single energy market and the promotion of energy independence in EU countries must be accelerated. The creation of an energy union is essential and will make Member States more competitive and resilient to political pressure from third countries.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which is just a series of incantations on the 'European Semester for the Coordination of Economic Policies' and which I consider above all to be an ineffective shackle and contrary to the sovereignty of our States.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which calls for structural reforms without taking into account the social impact on European citizens. It is clear that Member States must make budgetary efforts, but these must not be achieved without continuing to make productive investments and without guaranteeing sustainable jobs.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This report on the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination, with the 2015 Annual Growth Review, is a perfect illustration of European hypocrisy. Thus, the report calls for more investment and deplores the lack of public support, but soon forgets that the Union and the budgetary demands of Brussels forcing states to ever more austerity and reduce public spending is in total contradiction with the guidelines advocated by this text. Worse, the eurozone countries are doing worse than those outside. Unemployment is 11.5% in the euro area compared to 7.3% outside, and GDP is 2% lower than in 2008 in the euro area but 4.5% higher outside. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this text, which insists on reaffirming the usefulness of the European Semester for the coordination of economic policies, which is denied by the facts, by 25 million unemployed and 5 million young people who do not have a job. The citizens can no longer be puppets of this Europe where financial lobbies and Germany have taken the place of democracy. They are tired of paying for the crazy power games of a ruling class which, instead of taxing the citizens and glorifying the European Semester, should only admit that the EURO has failed and that the treaties need to be rewritten.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which calls for reforms to create a new entrepreneurial environment that promotes new businesses, new investments and innovations that ensure a possible return on investment, as a key factor in attracting financial capital to the European economy. Furthermore, increased investment financing requires a well-functioning financial system in which stability is improved and existing cross-border institutions can facilitate liquidity and market formation, in particular for small and medium-sized enterprises. The European Parliament welcomes the Investment Plan for Europe as an important tool for increasing private and public investment. It should be noted that the plan aims to encourage additional investment, develop new projects, attract investors and restore our citizens' confidence in Europe. In order to do so, Parliament calls for the european Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) resources to be used in such a way that funds are spent on projects with economic returns or with a positive social cost-benefit ratio. The European Parliament therefore calls on the Member States to actively support the Investment Plan and to contribute to the EFSI by complementing the funds provided by the EU budget and the EIB in order to encourage and encourage investment in the private sector.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the coordination of economic policies, which effectively highlights the favourable elements of recent months and the many problems still to be addressed in order to return to growth. Among the signs that bode well for economic recovery, we can certainly consider the significant reduction in the price of oil, the rebalancing of the value of the euro and the policies finally put in place by the ECB. In Europe, the integration of targeted investment with national structural reforms is the strategy we are pursuing. The communication on flexibility and the constant work for the final implementation of the Strategic Investment Fund are key tools to support Member States to make public investments on the one hand and to support the private sector to overcome the limited risk appetite on the other. In addition to the investment plan, in order to start again, we need to be competitive again: reforms must guarantee real and sustainable growth. Improving and simplifying the rules in the business context are priorities in this respect, as is the need to modernise education systems in order to allow the skills of tomorrow's workers to be effectively matched by the demands of the labour market.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒The rapporteur underlines the importance of a strategic approach in planning European economic growth. The objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy must be put at the heart of all documents and must be systematically addressed. Many Member States are losing share of the global economy and these are problems that the Union must address.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. The above report provides a rather lucid picture of the economic and social situation in the euro area. Growth is very low and unemployment is at record levels at almost 11.5% of the labour force. In addition, the EU is trying to tackle the risks of deflation by proposing the resumption of investment at European level and structural reforms for employment. In a context of cuts in Member States' national budgets, coupled with the maintenance of the single currency, these policies will not achieve the desired results. Moreover, neither the youth guarantee nor the introduction of a European minimum income will help to achieve social convergence between Member States. No, the solutions are elsewhere and call for the Union to engage in a genuine aggiornamento of ultra-liberal economic policies that have been pursued for too many years. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The slowdown in economic growth in 2014 demonstrates that the Union economy is facing the long-running effects of the recession and the recovery is hampered by short-term cyclical phenomena that reveal structural problems that need to be addressed. We need better coordination of economic policies in order to avoid transitional measures that could influence growth in the long term. A functioning single market is conditional on an integrated economy, which has the capacity to manage its own resources effectively by harnessing the economic potential of the Member States. I was in favour of this report because I believe that boosting investment is the key to economic recovery, and restoring confidence would help to strengthen a more attractive economic climate for investors. The Juncker Commission's ambitious initiative plays an important role in increasing the profitability of public investment and spending responsibility. By attracting private capital in public investment, the European Fund for Strategic Investments is an instrument for coordinating investment policies at European level.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against. The report supports the Commission's three-pillar approach (relaunching investment, structural reforms, austerity), which is like wanting to cure influenza by inoculating other pathogenic viruses in the disease. Some examples of the proposed cure: institutionalising the troika, a common European corporation tax to combat tax fraud, cross-border and cross-sectoral mobility of workers and more immigrants to promote growth.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the annual growth review for 2015 as part of the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination.  The economic and financial crisis of 2008 highlighted the need to coordinate the economic policies of Member States. We have indeed seen that when a country is put in trouble, it is the Union as a whole that suffers the consequences. Of course, it is not only Greece or Spain that I point the finger at here, but also Belgium, Italy and France. This report highlights the importance of respecting the rules set out in the Stability and Growth Pact, as well as implementing appropriate structural reforms as proposed by the Commission in the country recommendations. This is the prerequisite for a lasting recovery of the economies of our countries. We must be flexible, but only within the rules of the pact.  At the same time, I welcome the new European economic strategy, which is divided into three pillars: fiscal responsibility, structural reforms and investment.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination, and in particular on the 2015 Annual Growth Survey, because recovery needs to be strengthened if growth and jobs are to be substantially increased in the medium term. The euro area is still grappling with the consequences of an exceptionally long period of economic decline that began in 2008. This dramatic situation is due in particular to the lack of investment caused by low confidence, low demand expectations, high indebtedness, the lack of measures to promote productive public investment, low demand expectations of austerity measures seeking to correct overspending, a lack of adequate financing capacity and the fact that in many cases Member States and the EU do not take appropriate action to address these factors. The investment plan for Europe is an essential instrument for recovery. I therefore call on the Member States to actively support this plan and to contribute to the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), complementing the amounts provided by the EU budget and the EIB, in order to encourage the private sector to invest.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒  I voted against this report as it is futile to discuss the proposed aims for the European Semester in 2015, when the European Commission unremittingly refuses to acknowledge the underlying structural and economic problems which the two-pack and six-pack reforms pose, specifically failing to address the need for wide-scale investment in employment and social investment.  Reading through the aims of the Commission for the 2015 European Semester, the focus is supposedly to avoid economic boom and bust cycles, and aimed at restoring economic growth to the EU.  However there is no mention of equitable growth and poverty reduction. It shows a clear disconnect between European bureaucrats and the reality that is facing millions of struggling working families in Ireland and right across the EU. The European semester reforms’ primary aim seems to be just to ensure that Member States do not deviate from the economic neo-liberal ideology that it is pushing. It does not leave Member State with flexibility to implement alternative policies, which would be pro-investment, pro-growth, pro-jobs. In effect it is working to deny both Irish and other EU citizens real political choices when electing their governments and is further eroding sovereignty and reducing economic independence.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained in the split vote on part 1 of paragraph 29, because while we cannot support calls for the EU to interfere in the tax and criminal law of Member States, we of course do not oppose cracking down on tax fraud and illegal activity.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This is one of the two reports drafted by Parliament concerning the European Semester for economic policy coordination on the Annual Growth Survey 2015. As part of the annual European Semester cycle, the Commission published its Annual Growth Survey 2015 (AGS) on 28 November 2014. I voted in favour of the report as it supports the three-pillar approach proposed by the Commission: fiscal discipline, structural reforms and investments.  The report notes that, although Member States which went through an adjustment programme are now slowly recovering from the crisis, their recovery is still very fragile. The report also mentions that what is needed now is a stronger focus on growth-enhancing investments, particularly in relation to SMEs, and the continuous commitment of Member States to deliver on their commitment to complete the single market. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The policy coordination envisaged on the basis of the European Semester should aim to promote growth and, to this end, the effective completion of the single market and the protection of workers and consumers is a priority. The approach taken during the six months has not made it possible to make considerable progress in this direction, so much so that dumping - both social and fiscal - remains a major problem. In addition, depressive fiscal policies and the ECB's actions, which have no tangible impact on the thousands of micro-enterprises in crisis, have not offset the situation. It is important to make it clear that there is an absolute need for a reversal of the trend, european citizens have the right to effective and concrete responses to the crisis, and I have therefore voted against this report.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which welcomes the fact that the European Semester is a genuine system for monitoring national economic policies.  Under the pretext of coordinating national economic policies - in order to meet the long-term growth targets set out in the Europe 2020 strategy - the European Commission once again allows itself to distribute the good and bad points in terms of economic strategy, without any consideration of the specifics of each national economy.  The designated growth targets are thus unrealistic in view of the fiscal consolidation obligations imposed on Member States, which are far too restrictive in a context of crisis.

name: Ole Christensen (S&D)
text: Written. The Commission is already very active today when it comes to ensuring and enforcing the free movement of people, services and capital. Although the right to freedom of movement is one of the cornerstones of European cooperation, it should be stressed that it is sometimes necessary to weigh this up against other considerations. At present, Member States have the opportunity to take appropriate measures to enforce the working and employment conditions applicable in individual labour markets. That is the way it should be in the future. Similarly, individual Member States are allowed to ensure that social security systems are not abused.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The measure promotes economic recovery and a return to more sustainable growth levels based on three important pillars such as the revival of investment, budgetary consolidation seen from the point of view of accountability and the acceleration of structural reforms. It is clear that the recovery is still weak and needs to be strengthened if growth and jobs are to increase substantially in the medium term. The measure is satisfactory and I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the economic recovery is still too weak and that it needs to be strengthened if growth and jobs are to increase substantially in the medium term. I take note of the Commission's 2015 Annual Growth Survey, which works to promote a return to stronger levels of growth and to strengthen the recovery. I support the approach based on three main pillars (relaunching investment, speeding up structural reforms and pursuing responsible budgetary consolidation). For these reasons, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite the slowdown in the EU's economic recovery in 2014, the European Commission expects a recovery in 2015 and strengthened in the following year 2016. I share the view that the EU economy as a whole needs to boost its activity on the world stage through a range of measures ranging from increased competition, the Investment plan for Europe, support for SMEs, promotion of a single energy market, structural reforms in a number of Member States and budgetary responsibility. I regret that at institutional level the amount of outstanding invoices amounts to EUR 24.7 billion and the principle of budgetary truth is called into question, due to the discrepancy between payments and commitments and the treaty which does not allow deficit in the European budget to be violated.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination, which deals with the annual growth survey for 2015 for the regions below. This report, part of a package of 3 reports on the European Semester, highlights that the lack of investment is determined, on the one hand, by the high level of indebtedness and risk aversion of the private sector, and on the other by the fragmentation of the financial markets and the low demand expectations of austerity measures, which aim to contain expenditure.  In this context, the Commission's financial programming should stimulate investment and encourage new investors. In addition, the progressive process of structural reforms undertaken by the Member States has allowed a stabilisation of capital markets and has led to a reduction in the number of countries subject to the excessive deficit procedure to 11 in 2014 compared to 24 in 2011. These assumptions imply little optimism for the future. The European strategy, based on fiscal adjustment, structural reforms and increased investment in growth, appears to be in line with the need to relaunch the microeconomies of the Member States and the European macroeconomics.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The 2015 Annual Growth Survey focuses on putting Europe firmly back on a path of sustainable job creation and economic growth. To give a common direction and steer national approaches, the Commission recommends three main pillars for the EUʼs economic and social policy in 2015: fiscal adjustment, structural reforms and growth enhancing investments. I agree with the objectives of the report, since the global economic and financial crisis, the EU has been suffering from low levels of investment. Collective and coordinated efforts at European level are needed for economic recovery. Investments are needed to modernise welfare systems, fund education, research and innovation.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 As every year, the European Parliament presents an own-initiative report analysing the aspects of the text on the Analysis of Growth. The text voted on in the ECON Committee is very critical and makes no substantial contribution to the formulation of the next report.  In particular, the text is too pleased with the measures taken after the crisis and does not recognise that austerity measures have choked growth and social cohesion, as well as being based on an overly optimistic approach to the prospects for future growth. Furthermore, there is no marked reference to the measures needed to return to growth, apart from the few references to the internal market, labour, social policies and the fight against tax evasion and avoidance. In committee, after long and difficult negotiations with the rapporteur, the text was slightly amended but not to such an extent that it was acceptable. No amendments proposed by the M5S have been included in the compromises. I can only vote against it.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which welcomes the Commission’s new approach to economic policy with focus on growth and investment. It is also insists that reforms required from Member States must be socially balanced and growth-friendly and that surplus countries must do more to re-launch growth in Europe. I voted for the report as both its content and the new European Semester itself focus on jobs, growth and investment... elements which I truly believe should be the foundation of re-launching Europe.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the euro area is still struggling with the effects of the particularly long economic recession after 2008 and that the recovery is still fragile and should be strengthened in order to generate much stronger growth and much more jobs in the medium term. I believe that it is necessary to ensure that short-term and long-term policies reinforce each other, and I also believe that reforms need to be carried out that facilitate a new entrepreneurial environment, stimulate the creation of new businesses and the development of new investments and innovations, with investment profits that could be achieved as a vital factor in attracting financial capital to the European economy.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report presents the annual growth review in 2015 as part of the European semester. From these figures, it is clear that the Union is still grappling with the consequences of an unusually long economic crisis. If the recovery remains fragile, it must be consolidated by a long-term strategy based on investment stimulus, accelerated structural reforms and responsible growth-oriented fiscal consolidation. I am convinced that there is also a need to strengthen the coordination of national policies in order to gradually reduce the internal and external macroeconomic imbalances of member states, including large trade surpluses. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The European semester, set up in 2010 for greater convergence of Member States' fiscal and economic policies, traditionally begins with the annual growth review. This exercise helps to define the economic priorities of the European Union. As part of the 2015 Annual Growth Review, the European Commission has set three priorities: boosting investment, renewed commitment to structural reforms and responsible and growth-friendly fiscal consolidation measures. In particular, I wished to welcome the three-priority approach and support the call for a special scheme for SMEs as part of the EUR 315 billion investment plan proposed by the European Commission.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: in writing. – The European Semester – AGS Growth Survey 2015 is extremely important for Europe as a tool for economic policy coordination and governance.  I voted in favour because I believe a good balance has been achieved.  At macro level the report reflects my position on the need for structural reforms in the EU, the modernisation of economies and the continuation of fiscal consolidation. It also calls for the tax burden on labour to be reduced and for wages to be brought into line with productivity. Another important position cautioning against protectionist tendencies and restriction of the four freedoms has been adopted as well. The report furthermore recognises that the investment gap can be bridged by targeting significantly higher levels of investments in private companies and in European business. It promotes a well-functioning financial system where increased stability and existing cross border institutions can facilitate liquidity and market making, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises. Last but not least, it highlights the fact that the Member States and the Commission have not yet delivered on their commitment to complete the single market, especially the single market for services and the digital economy. This is what I believe our priority must be next.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European semester frames the economic and budgetary policies of the Member States. It is a tool for common economic governance, and as such is a further step towards greater integration of the euro area. This coordination at European level must give priority to growth and jobs, cohesion and investment, and ensure a macroeconomic rebalancing of the euro area. In order to make this process better, it is of course necessary that the European Parliament be more involved, but also our national parliaments.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. The coordination of economic policies as presented in the European semester does not seek to combine the different national objectives to define common strategies in certain key sectors, but tends to strengthen the internal market. The latter appears to be the central concern of the proposed text, whose incantations can only seek convergence of the Union's economies and regulatory harmonisation. The European semester is an economic plan that does not meet the needs of the Member States and only meets supranational political objectives, which is why I voted against this text.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The report is the European Parliament's response to the Annual Growth Survey, which is the Commission's analysis of the EU's priorities for growth for the year ahead.  It stresses that the most important priorities are Member States’ competitiveness and reduced unemployment and stresses that low GDP, low inflation and high unemployment should all be urgently addressed. More controversial elements of the report concern calls for the Commission to address fiscal consolidation and promote increasing convergence. There are statements that the European Monetary Union is 'far from complete' and the Commission is reminded of its obligations and commitments to enhance economic and budgetary coordination. The report then asks the Commission to put forward proposals for the completion of the EMU, which should be based on the Community method.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Dear Colleagues, I voted against Mr Rosati's report because it is essential for me and my colleagues from the European Conservatives and Reformists to protect the sovereignty of the Member States and to oppose the further conferral of competences on the European institutions. I fully support the idea of coordination between the economic, social and financial policies of the Member States, but here, among other things, it is about national budgets and the role that the European Semester plays. Initially, we had hoped that through the European Semester Member States would be consulted on their budgetary policy, but subsequently it turned out that the European Commission had become a controlling body that could oblige Member States to conduct one or another budgetary policy. This is completely contrary to our views, as, on the one hand, the national budget is an essential element of any sovereign state and, on the other hand, it is unacceptable for an undemocratic institution to take decisions of this nature that directly affect member states and its citizens.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report as the European Semester process is undemocratic and violates the right of each Member State and its people to decide their policies according to their economic and social situation, as well as their rights and aspirations.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on paragraph 29, split 1, because, while we cannot support calls for the EU to interfere in the tax and criminal law of Member States, we of course do not oppose cracking down on tax fraud and illegal activity.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. This own-initiative report takes into account that, in 2014, economic recovery slowed down. It also reiterates the three pillars on which growth must be based: relaunching investment, speeding up structural reforms and pursuing responsible and growth-friendly budgetary consolidation. However, it is a source of optimism.  This does not seem to me to be an analysis that reflects the reality of the situation. The report welcomes the EUR 315 billion of the Juncker plan when, in reality, it has not yet been understood how the famous multiplier will materialise, which, for every euro invested, will be able to generate 15 billion. It also praises the Commission's 2015 Annual Growth Survey as if the Commission could boast excellent results when, immediately afterwards, it laments the loss of global market share by Member States and loss of competitiveness.  I believe that, in order to increase global competitiveness, it is necessary to restore public confidence, with policies that focus on innovation and that keep labour costs in line with productivity, solving the problem of youth unemployment so as not to further exacerbate social distress in the years to come. I voted against because I do not believe that asking the Member States to make additional efforts under these conditions, without combining them with appropriate measures for growth, is the right way to go.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Report on the Annual Growth Survey for 2015, an instrument that should enable member states to take specific measures and define recommendations for a return to higher growth levels, based on the three pillars on which we need to continue working: the promotion of investment, the implementation of structural reforms and the continuation of fiscal consolidation. The resolution also notes the very low level of implementation of country-specific recommendations and supports the simplification measures now proposed, with the purpose of reversing this trend and resulting in a loss of competitiveness on the part of the European economy.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. Despite the slowdown in the ECONOMIC recovery in the EU, the outlook for 2015 is projected to be a recovery that will be more significant in 2016. However, unemployment is still at high levels. The report also reports a decrease in the level of investment by €470,000, but highlights europe's considerable effort to respond to the sovereign debt crisis. Recovery is fragile and should be strengthened in the medium term in order to respond to cyclical problems in the short term, as well as long-term structural problems. The Commission has been making an effort to promote a return to higher growth levels supported by promoting investment, accelerating structural reforms and pursuing responsible fiscal consolidation in favour of growth.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the prospective annual growth study because it recognises that, together with the reforms for increasing productivity and competitiveness, it is necessary to accompany the pace of fiscal adjustment with the growth rate of Member States' gross domestic product, as well as to implement the Investment Plan for Europe. This is the European Parliament's first report on the so-called European Semester for economic policy coordination which is adopted after the election of the new Commission, and it follows the turn in European public policies which we Socialists have long demanded.  However, I believe that the EU's economic policy should not only rest on these three pillars (reforms, gradual fiscal consolidation and investments), but should be added to the fiscal pillar (automatic exchange of information, harmonisation of corporation tax) and the social pillar. In this sense, reforms cannot be synonymous with cuts to the welfare state, but should be conceived as instruments to improve worker productivity, increase the accumulation of human capital, increase per capita income, and reduce social and territorial inequalities.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the Annual Growth Survey (2015) represents the starting point of the European Semester procedure and the whole "economic governance" process. This report provides major policy guidelines on which national budgets should be built – otherwise their countries are faced with sanctioning procedures if these guidelines are not accepted. Here we continue to advocate "austerity" and "structural reforms", particularly in the labour market and the privatisation of businesses and public services, which guarantee access to social rights gained after decades of struggle. We are facing a setback of civilizational dimension. The so-called Economic Governance and the European Semester – supported by the sacrosanct alliance between the right and social democracy – are a way of linking national states to the neoliberal agenda of the European Union at the service of great capital. They seek to prevent countries from being able to sovereignly decide their collective future, forcing them to watch their economies in arms tied. Obviously we voted against it.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the euro area is still struggling with the consequences of the long economic downturn caused by the post-2008 economic crisis. The recovery of the economy and the economy is very fragile and needs to be strengthened if we are to ensure more growth and jobs. This could help to ensure an approach based on the three main pillars of supporting investment, promoting the responsibility of growth-promoting fiscal consolidation and accelerating structural reforms. We should also incorporate this approach into the forthcoming recommendations for individual Member States. At the same time, however, we also need simplification of existing procedures to improve the European Semester and greater involvement of national parliaments in order to strengthen accountability at national level as well.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am strongly opposed to yet another report which supports the Commission's approach to economic policies which are, for us, unsuccessful.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the European Semester for the coordination of economic policies: Annual Growth Survey 2015. The European Semester process is undemocratic and violates the right of each Member State and its people to decide their policies according to their economic and social situation, as well as their rights and aspirations. I do not want any more structural reforms aimed at weakening the south.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The S&D group has been at the forefront of the struggle for a new, flexible approach to economic policies.  This report clearly reflects the result of our pressures and our united stand against austerity. The report clearly welcomes the new approach, which focuses on investment and growth in Europe as opposed to the policies pursued by the former Barroso Commission.  I am especially satisfied with the recognition that adjustment burden in the EU must be shared between deficit and surplus countries.  It is clear that the southern countries of Europe affected by this dramatic recession cannot bear the entire costs of reforms.  This report fully expresses the principle of solidarity and balance among Member States by recommending more investment by surplus countries in deficit countries.  It respects the European rules that the position of surplus countries must also be addressed by the European Commission.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. It is a fact that the EU's economic recovery is not consolidated, and that in many of the Member States the fiscal and labour market situation is very worrying. 2015 and 2016 may be the key years for Europe's exit from the crisis, so we must continue to encourage investment, accelerate structural reforms and pursue budgetary consolidation that promotes responsible growth. Similarly, we must continue to bet on the integration of the single market, to increase the competitiveness of the European economy and to improve performance through innovation. SMEs must be a priority at both European and state level, as they are the basis of the European economy and a source of occupation for millions of citizens.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. Mr Rosati's report is an important text, which I voted for whole, not least because it comes at a decisive time for the economic recovery of the European Union. A few months after the start of the parliamentary term, the European institutions are trying to open up a new path – as suggested by the EU's progressive governments – that will end the line of rigour and austerity. With this report, Parliament sets out a complete framework of priorities to accompany the recent economic policies that have been launched. I would like to mention here some key points of the EU's new economic course: firstly, the investment plan for Europe, an important tool for increasing private and public investment, attracting investors and restoring confidence. I too believe, as the report rightly points out, that the investment plan for Europe should focus primarily on European value-added projects that are not yet eligible for bank financing and, above all, that it is geared towards growth and sustainability. In this regard, I hope that the Member States will be able to take up the call to contribute to EFSI by supplementing the amounts provided by the EU budget and the EIB, in order to guide and encourage the private sector to invest.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. It takes no less than three reports in the European Parliament - review of growth, coordination of social and employment policies, governance of the single market - to give its opinion on the European Semester. This is just enough to sweep away all the areas in which states must submit their policies to diktats, advice, guidance, etc. from Brussels: budgetary austerity, "liberalisation" of all that can still be done, extensive reforms - we know in what sense - of social protection, full application of the "services" directive, known as Bolkenstein, "flexibilisation" of the labour market, encouragement of the free movement of people, tax harmonisation and so on... This is the European Semester: the first annual stage of the tutelage of public spending and national policies, in the name of meeting the Maastricht criteria on public deficits and debt. Vague considerations about fighting poverty or taking social issues into account are hard to hide from the fact that it is the policies advocated that create social insecurity and precariousness. Between denial of sovereignty and announced economic and social disaster, the only vote that is required is "against". On all texts.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against this report, which defends private finances with a favourable heterodox monetary policy, the return of financial bubbles, the socialisation of losses, a privatistic investment policy, poorly conceived and meagging, and a persistence of the austerity policy that will continue to close social rights and public services alongside alleged structural reforms in labour markets (adapting the labour force to the labour force) , make employment relationships more flexible), while technological and energy innovation are left under providence.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as it welcomes the Commission's new approach to economic policy, with focus on growth and investment. The report also insists that reforms required from Member States must be socially balanced and growth-friendly and that surplus countries must do more to relaunch growth in Europe.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it underlines the whole point of the European semester.  This exercise makes it possible to put Member States on the test, to compare virtuous practices with those that are less so, to understand who are the good and bad students. It thus allows the European Commission to make useful recommendations to Member States that do not respect the rules of the Stability and Growth Pact.  As such, I am particularly surprised at the leniency enjoyed by France, which has been given an additional two years to carry out its reforms. This does not do our country any favours, it is an opportunity for the socialist government to push back on reforms, at the risk of burdening future generations with the debt burden!

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the European Semester for economic policy coordination: Annual Growth Survey 2015. I do believe that country-specific recommendations are very helpful; and it is a shame that Member States are barely implementing them (only 9% were fully implemented in 2013). I call for increased involvement of national parliaments, with a view to strengthening national ownership of structural reforms.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against this report, which defends private finances with a favourable heterodox monetary policy, the return of financial bubbles, the socialisation of losses, a privatistic investment policy, poorly conceived and meagging, and a persistence of the austerity policy that will continue to close social rights and public services alongside alleged structural reforms in labour markets (adapting the labour force to the market) , make employment relationships more flexible), while technological and energy innovation are left under providence.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the European Semester of Economic Policy Coordination: Annual Growth Survey 2015. The introduction of the European Semester improved economic policy coordination by analysing countries' plans for macroeconomic, budgetary and structural reforms, but I also support the proposal to simplify the European Semester and further strengthen and stimulate the European Union economy globally, making it more competitive. I agree that investment and a return to higher levels of growth need to be further stimulated by supporting the Investment Plan for Europe and continuing structural reforms in individual Member States. In order for the Results of the European Semester to be effective, more severe fiscal consolidation and reduction of internal imbalances within Member States and their coordination with each other is also needed.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. This report aims to strengthen the internal market, without seeking to coordinate national objectives, in order to define common strategies in key sectors.  This is the purely ideological objective of this text: the convergence of the Union's economies and regulatory harmonisation.  This report does not meet the needs of Member States by focusing only on supranational political objectives. So I voted against it.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the Annual Growth Study because it recognises that, together with the reforms for increased productivity and competitiveness, it is necessary to accompany the pace of fiscal adjustment with the growth rate of Member States' gross domestic product, as well as to implement the Investment Plan for Europe. This is the European Parliament's first report on the so-called European Semester for economic policy coordination which is adopted after the election of the new Commission, and it follows the turn in European public policies which we Socialists have long demanded.  However, I believe that the EU's economic policy should not only rest on these three pillars (reforms, gradual fiscal consolidation and investments), but should be added to the fiscal pillar (automatic exchange of information, harmonisation of corporation tax) and the social pillar. In this sense, reforms cannot be synonymous with cuts to the welfare state, but should be conceived as instruments to improve worker productivity, increase the accumulation of human capital, increase per capita income and reduce social and territorial inequalities.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Dariusz Rosati's report on the annual growth review as part of the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination. This annual report is based on the European Commission's annual growth review and winter forecasts and focuses on structural reform efforts undertaken by countries with excessive deficit procedures.  Through this semester, the European Commission analyses the Member States' budgetary, economic and structural reform plans and makes recommendations for the coming year.  The text also regrets the lack of visibility given to the States Parties to the Stability and Growth Pact on the country-by-country recommendations. The report was adopted by a large majority of 437 votes in person, 249 against and 11 abstentions, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the European semester for economic policy coordination in 2015. The economic recovery in the European Union slowed considerably during 2014 but, according to the European Commission, a catch-up is expected in 2015 and improvements could occur in 2016. At present, the challenge is to address both cyclical and long-term structural problems. Urgent measures should be taken by the Commission to combat tax evasion and tax evasion.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. The report ignores the situation that the European economy needs incentives to produce more, to innovate and to create jobs. Instead, it demands that the state step in with money and expand the public sector. Fiscal consolidation is necessary, but individual governments will have to accept spending cuts. Since the essence of the report calls for more government rather than incentives for the private sector, I must reject it.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on the European Semester for economic policy coordination at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg. In its resolution on the Annual Growth Survey 2015, the European Parliament stresses the need to invest, carry out structural reforms and fiscal measures to boost growth. The resolution stresses the need to take the measures that will ensure stability in the European Union, which is so badly needed by Latvian entrepreneurs exporting to other EU countries.  The European Semester, or European Semester for economic policy coordination, includes measures to prevent a repeat of the financial crises in the EU, as we experienced in 2008. The European Semester process begins with the opinion of the European Commission, or growth survey, setting out the overall state and challenges of the European Union economy, as well as giving specific guidance.  The resolution stresses the need to take the measures that will ensure the stability in the European Union, which is so badly needed by Latvian entrepreneurs exporting to other EU countries, which i supported.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report. It welcomes the Commission's new approach to economic policy, with focus on growth and investment, and insists that reforms required from Member States must be socially balanced and growth-friendly and that surplus countries must do more to relaunch growth in Europe.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report endorses the system of budgetary supervision which allows the Commission not only to audit budgets and to ask for changes before they are even adopted by national parliaments, but also to push for further cuts or reforms if the proposed budgets do not suit it.  I reject this process of increasing the reduction in wages and pensions, raising the retirement age and continuing privatisations and liberalisations, with the sole result of the ironing out of public services and social rights. It is also in the context of the European semester that the Commission regularly denounces the CDI and the monopolies of SNCF or EDF in France.
