While I have supported proposals that can improve the social dimension, I am no less critical of this tool which allows the European institutions to dictate their policies to states in defiance of popular sovereignty.  As a result, I voted against these three reports.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. The coordination of economic policies as presented in the European semester does not seek to combine the different national objectives to define common strategies in certain key sectors, but tends to strengthen the internal market. The latter appears to be the central concern of the proposed text, whose incantations can only seek convergence of the Union's economies and regulatory harmonisation. The European semester is an economic plan that does not meet the needs of the Member States and only meets supranational political objectives, which is why I voted against this text.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I supported the report because it presents a more balanced approach to structural reforms and their impact on programme countries. I welcome the Commission's new approach to economic policy with a focus on development and investment – but the reforms required of the Member States must be socially sustainable and growth-friendly.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. In general, the report contains the following positive elements: (a) it recognises that the EU's economic problems are cyclical and structural; (b) supports the strategy of the Commission's three pillars: increased investment, structural reforms and growth-friendly fiscal consolidation; c) supports the Juncker Plan; (d) supports the Commission's proposal for the simplification of the European Semester; (e) supports increasing the degree of empowerment of States with respect to Country-Specific Recommendations and structural reforms;  (f) expresses concern about the overall competitiveness of the EU; (h) says that the social and employment effects of structural reforms must be taken into account, which need to be socially balanced and generate quality jobs; (i) calls for combating tax evasion; (j) recognizes that you cannot compete only in costs and that research and education must be invested; (k) calls on States with fiscal leeway to spend and invest; considers that fiscal adjustment should protect utility users.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it positively sanctions the neoliberal orientation of the economic governance framework. The annual prospective study is the European Commission's economic study that starts the entire European Semester process. This study develops a very limited monetarist analysis, which does not take into account eer the social effects of austerity policies or differences in the productive structures of EU Member States. On the basis of this limited analysis, austerity recommendations to Member States will be justified, deepening the effects of the crisis. This report does not in any way condemn the way in which this study is drawn up and that is why I have decided to vote against it.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. This motion for a resolution which highlights the pressing need to effectively address the tax evasion that could be depriving the EU budget of large resources and which calls on the Commission to present an analysis of the potential impact of the redistribution of funds from EU programmes, such as the Connecting Europe Facility and Horizon 2020, is welcome.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the Annual Growth Survey for the European Semester because this whole programme is undemocratic and interferes with the sovereignty of the Member States. Member States are fully capable of setting their own macroeconomic and budgetary policies, and economic growth in the EU is best supported by the abolition of excessive regulations resulting from the acquis communautaire.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support this report, which highlights in particular the importance of the social aspect and job creation within the framework of sound economic governance and the implementation of the European Semester. It is important to implement comprehensive and well-balanced economic policy measures that must be specifically created for each Member State taking into account its specificity. Somewhere, reducing wages will increase productivity, attract investors and thus lead to job creation. Somewhere the opposite will happen – the highest quality, capable and educated will leave the country and competitiveness will fall that even investors will not be interested in investments and unemployment will rise. This report warns us how careful we must be when making decisions on economic measures if we are to preserve the jobs and social security of our citizens.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the European Union is not meeting the economic growth targets it has set itself. The Commission must therefore revise its development forecasts. The situation is serious and requires the search for all possible sources and instruments of development. The high rate of long-term unemployment, coupled with a high percentage of the population of the European Union at risk of poverty and social exclusion, is alarming. Unemployment not only has economic and social impacts, but also affects the mental life and health of the population. Investment support measures are an important factor that will also affect employment growth when used meaningfully. It is essential that the Commission, in cooperation with the Member States, seeks a solution for the most vulnerable regions and populations, which will halt current negative developments and lead to the creation of permanent jobs. I am pleased that the European Parliament has today approved my amendments, among them an amendment that, as a matter of principle, changes the unfair and incomprehensible way of financing the European budget for citizens. The billions of euros saved will be able to be used by states to solve their consolidation problems.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. – I am voting against the report on the European Semester for the coordination of economic policies: Annual Growth Survey 2015, because the European Semester is an institutional way of limiting the national sovereignty of the Euro area Member States. The parliaments of the eurozone countries now lack sovereign rights in shaping national budgets, as the Eurogroup, an unelected body, has made them a tight corset by imposing mercely austerity.  The dominant element today, in relation to the European Semester, is the huge democratic deficit it has created in the name of reducing budget deficits. Thus, through an undemocratic institutional framework, the old political world of Europe is trying to chain the people and impose on them the policy of mercelial austerity, poverty and social exclusion.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report which stresses that reducing the EU’s dependence on external energy sources must form part of its growth strategy; it reiterates, therefore, the need to diversify external energy supplies, to upgrade the EU’s energy infrastructure and to complete the EU internal energy market as key priorities of the EU energy security strategy.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. Ladies and gentlemen, growth is returning to prominence, albeit still in a reduced form. Many Member States are still in the midst of structural reforms and are striving to achieve budgetary balance. In addition, there is a general departure from the use of fiscal adjustments for growth, i.e. that a tax increase is not currently considered useful for growth and to stimulate investment. Mr Rosati's text on the European Semester for the Coordination of Economic Policies explains precisely the European Union's strategy, which is now based on three main pillars: fiscal adjustment, structural reforms and growth that strongly favours investment.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 During 2014, the economic recovery of the Member States of the European Union slowed down sharply. The euro area still has record levels of unemployment, while some countries are still engaged in the implementation of structural reforms, and measures to clean up national budgets. I voted in favour of the Rosati report, as it proposes a coherent recovery strategy, based on fiscal consolidation, structural reforms, and increased investment aimed at promoting growth.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Union must persevere in implementing a strategy to ensure economic growth and recovery in Europe through investment, the implementation of structural reforms and also the consolidation of a fiscal model that is respectful of growth, as we have discussed, and fully shared, in this Parliament. It is important, with a view to advancing all these purposes, that we achieve greater involvement of national parliaments in the discussions on the European Semester and greater national monitoring and autonomy in country-specific recommendations. It is important, and we have discussed this here on numerous occasions, that Member States follow the recommendations made from the Commission, as only 9% were implemented in 2013.  In addition, measures need to be put in place to advance a more competitive and adaptable Europe in dealing with future crises, through joint work towards capital market integration, the fight against tax evasion and evasion, the creation of an EU internal energy market and the achievement of a more efficient labour market.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. I voted against the draft resolution on the European Semester for the coordination of economic policy and thus against the 2015 Annual Growth Survey. In my opinion, the European Semester for the coordination of economic policy is the demand for more state and less private responsibility. The aim of fiscal consolidation on the part of the Member States is seen as necessary, but the European Semester does not want to accept spending cuts.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because the European Semester process ensures that Member States' budgetary and economic policies are consistent with their commitments to the EU (that they meet the debt and deficit commitments set out in the Stability and Growth Pact, the economic reform plans set out in the 2014 Country Strategy and the long-term objectives of growth and jobs set out in the Europe 2020 strategy).  I have taken the integrated approach proposed by the Commission to pursue economic policy in three main directions: to stimulate investment, accelerate structural reforms and to pursue responsible and growth-friendly fiscal consolidation.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report calls for a boost to European competitiveness through "increased competition in the markets for goods and services" by pointing out that "labour costs must be in line with productivity". It also calls on states to "reduce current spending."  As a good defender of free trade, the report "is concerned about the protectionist tendencies of some Member States".  Finally, the report welcomes the good results achieved by the austerity measures imposed on States, which would have "successfully implemented adjustment programmes". Names?  Only one failure of this policy is conceded, the fact that "only five Member States fully comply with the provisions of the Stability and Growth Pact (PSC)". That should be enough to question... I'm voting AGAINST.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. The euro area recession came to an end in numerical terms in the second quarter of 2013, but annual growth in the euro area remains fragile in 2014, and unemployment remains at a very high level. Sustainable growth needs to be significantly strengthened in order to be seen as a long-term recovery that can set the pace for mitigating the EU's socio-economic challenges.  Only with investment capacity will incentives for economic growth be possible. Only the budget surplus and the budgetary balance of the Member States will free up the funds needed for the investments that will lead to sustained growth in the euro area.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because of the emphasis given to the need for greater collaboration between the European Parliament and the national parliaments in the context of the European Semester on economic and budgetary governance. The report also highlights the fact that there has been a significant decrease in the number of countries under the excessive deficit procedure – down to 11 in 2014 from 24 in 2011. It is clear that Europe is moving in the right direction to combat the economic downturn.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Union is feverishly trying to emerge from a considerable crisis, trying to consolidate a fragile recovery with the aim of supporting growth and employment. The three-pillar approach (investment, structural reforms and responsible fiscal consolidation) is the right way to achieve these goals. The European Semester, which was introduced in 2010, sets up an annual cycle for the coordination of economic policies, including a detailed analysis of the budgetary, macroeconomic and structural reform plans of the various Member States.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Rosati report, which welcomes the Commission's new approach to economic policy, with focus on growth and investment, but also insists that reforms required from Member States must be socially balanced and growth-friendly and that surplus countries must do more to relaunch growth in Europe.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Semester has become, in a relatively short period of time, part of Europe's institutional culture and, moreover, is increasingly part of national policy-making culture. The previous open method of coordination, one of the most direct ancestors of the European Semester, was treated more or less as a joke; it was an exercise for academics more than practitioners. Now we can see how very powerful Member States - whether they like it or not - take the European Semester seriously and explain and defend their choices. Even when they try obtain exceptions from the rules, they still explain themselves in relation to those rules, which are thus confirmed and strengthened. We now have an enriched process, with a clearer social dimension (Juncker's 'social triple A' is a great metaphor and - it is to be hoped - much more than that) and decent flexibility with the 'Moscovici package'. It is almost mystical how Europe, painfully, finds resources to fix itself after crises.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the concept of restoring Economic Growth in Europe, with investment stimulus, structural reforms and prudent fiscal policy as its main elements, I endorse the efforts to further unify the European market and I agree that in order to recover, the competitiveness of the EU economy as a whole must be enhanced, in particular by strengthening competition to increase efficiency driven by innovation.

name: Bernard Monot (NI)
text: In writing. The European semester is proof of the chronic divergence of the euro area economies. This cycle of economic policy coordination has never succeeded in creating, ex post, the optimal conditions of the single currency area. The specific state-specific recommendations it makes are only followed in less than 10% of cases, evidence of the ineffectiveness of the mechanism. Moreover, it is up to the sovereign states to decide on the reforms to be implemented, not on the European Union through a binding mechanism.  In the end, the report on the European semester multiplies the consensual incantations to growth or full employment, thus thinking that they will reappear. This is, of course, just one more illusion of economic and monetary union.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the practice of previous years, in which there have been low economic growth, it is understood that 2015 could be the year of economic recovery and long-awaited job creation at European level. I am voting in favour of the Commission's 2015 Annual Growth Survey as it promotes new levels of growth in order to achieve higher growth levels and strengthen recovery. I see the three-pillar approach as very fruitful; promoting investment, accelerating structural reforms and pursuing responsible and growth-friendly fiscal consolidation. I also believe it is essential that Member States do not slow down the structural reforms they should adopt, thereby facilitating rapid economic recovery.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. This initiative report on the annual review of growth in 2015 in the context of the European semester shows great hypocrisy. On the one hand, he complains that public investment has dried up and calls on the other to continue austerity and the decline in public spending. These pro-cyclical policies demonstrate a great economic imperative by breaking any hope of recovery. The contrast with the U.S. economic situation is, on this point, striking.  On the other hand, GDP in the euro area is 2 percentage points below its 2008 level, while that of non-euro area countries is 4.5 percentage points higher. With regard to unemployment, the situation is similar. It reaches 11.5% in the euro area and only 7.3% outside the euro area. This therefore demonstrates the clear failure of the European and anti-democratic policies carried out by the Organisation of Brussels with the complicity of the national authorities. I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which welcomes the Commission's new approach to economic policy, with focus on growth and investment. Moreover, it insists that reforms required from Member States must be socially balanced and growth-friendly and that surplus countries must do more to relaunch growth in Europe.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the 2015 Annual Growth Review as part of the European Semester. As part of the European Semester, the European Commission analyses the Member States' fiscal, economic and structural reform plans and makes recommendations for the coming year.  The report points out that the level of investment in Europe has fallen by 470 billion euros since the peak of the crisis and that the euro area still faces record unemployment (12%). It supports the Commission's approach to consolidating recovery on three fronts: boosting investment, accelerating structural reforms and cleaning up public finances to return to sustainable growth. He also welcomes Juncker's 315 billion euro investment plan.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this report because we share the importance of the role played by the European Semester, introduced in 2010, as an annual instrument for coordinating economic and budgetary policies, macroeconomic and structural reforms of the Member States of the European Union. At a time of severe investment crisis due to low market confidence, low demand expectations and high indebtedness, we believe that the investment plan for Europe proposed by the Juncker Commission is a first step towards stimulating new resources and developing new projects, attracting investors and re-establishing consumer confidence. However, we call on the Member States to safeguard and strengthen the inclusiveness, sustainability and fairness of social protection.  The reforms required of states should be socially balanced and more oriented towards growth and employment. We call on the Commission to implement measures to make the European Semester process more effective and democratic, for example by formally involving the European Parliament. We consider the current framework of economic governance still lacking sufficient democratic accountability in the application of its rules and the institutions and bodies concerned.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this text because it provides a fair analysis of the needs to improve the governance of the single market so that it can fulfil its role as a European engine and it identifies key growth sectors that will improve the functioning of the single market.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In his report, Mr Rosati gave a positive opinion on the annual growth survey which starts the cycle of coordinating member states' economic policies. The document found that the eurozone is still at risk of stagnation. In particular, the level of investment is well below the level reached in 2007, with a lack of investment of EUR 304 billion. The reasons for this are both the lack of credit demand due to the climate of uncertainty and the reluctance of institutions to provide investment finance. Furthermore, the high rate of unemployment remains worrying, so effective and timely action is needed.  However, there are also signs of hope, such as the reduction in the number of countries that are under excessive deficit procedure and the fall in the price of oil, which will benefit importing countries and lead to an increase in GDP. I have chosen to vote in favour of the report because the approach proposed to relaunch growth, with the three pillars represented by the investment plan, structural reforms and fiscal consolidation, seems to be the right way forward.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Economic recovery is one of the objectives of the European Union, with the aim of annihilating the economic declines that have occurred as a result of the global financial crisis installed in recent years. I voted for this particularly important report because it brings a number of concrete proposals with a role in the economic recovery of the Union.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the European Semester and the 2015 Economic Growth Survey. The euro area is still grappling with the consequences of an unusually long recession after 2008. The economic recovery remains fragile and needs to be strengthened in order to achieve significantly higher growth and employment in the medium term.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report.  It should be noted that the euro area has still not overcome an exceptionally long economic downturn, although the recovery is visible, but it is still very weak and should be strengthened.  In particular, there is a need to improve the European Semester, streamline existing procedures and increase national ownership. The three main pillars approach must be effectively implemented. There is a need to invest, accelerate structural reforms and achieve responsible, growth-friendly fiscal consolidation. Innovation-based efficiency needs to be improved and Member States should therefore reduce current expenditure rather than investment commitments.  It should be noted that a significant number of countries still need structural reforms. In this context, more attention should be paid to the social and employment impact of reforms. Increasing inequalities, the decline in purchasing power, high long-term unemployment and youth unemployment remain among the biggest problems.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The reports on the implementation of the 2015 European Semester and enhanced economic governance support its three unpopular pillars, identified by the EU and its institutions: Investment - accelerating unpopular reforms - extending cuts in social spending.  The European Parliament, firmly expressing the interests of plutocracy, is at the fore in promoting the reforms that capital needs around three main axes which are: a. Reducing corporate taxation and their social security obligations b. Liberalisation of the EU's single capitalist market in sectors critical to the profitability of groups, such as services, the digital market , energy, research and innovation, Greater connection of education with businesses and their needs c. Further reduction in the price of labour force, new blows to public social security and welfare systems, industrial relations and stable work with rights, increased mobility - work wandering at transnational and cross-sectoral level, with emphasis on promoting disposable skills , necessary for the specific needs of the capital.  It is up to the peoples to organise their struggle to recover the losses of the crisis, for their modern needs, with the release from the EU and the people in power.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering that the economic recovery in the EU slowed down sharply in 2014 but that, according to the Commission, recovery prospects are looming in 2015 and a further improvement is expected in 2016; that, six years after the start of the financial crisis in 2008, the euro area still has record levels of unemployment of almost 12%; considering that the euro area is still grappling with the consequences of an exceptionally long period of economic decline that began in 2008; pointing out that the recovery is still fragile and that it must be strengthened if growth and jobs are to be substantially increased in the medium term; noting, however, that growth in 2014 is more widespread and the Commission's 2015 Annual Growth Survey, which works to promote a return to stronger levels of growth and to strengthen recovery; In favour of the approach based on three main pillars (relaunching investment, speeding up structural reforms and pursuing responsible and pro-growth budgetary consolidation), I voted in favour.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The crisis has shown how things cannot go any further. Structural reforms with the aim of achieving fiscal consolidation, increased productivity and enhanced functioning of the social market economy are the ways to create stability, growth and increased employment prospects. The only way to achieve all of these on a European scale is for Member States urgently to start implementing the recommendations formulated during the semester exercise, applying reforms and respecting the growth pact. I support all actions and semester enhancements that will provide the necessary strength for the reforms to happen, and I believe that the semester is the necessary tool to achieve such EU coordination.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. This initiative report on the 2015 annual growth review for the European semester is highly hypocritical. On the one hand, he complains that public investment has dried up and calls on the other to continue austerity and the decline in public spending. These pro-cyclical policies demonstrate a great economic imperative by breaking any hope of recovery. The contrast with the U.S. economic situation is, on this point, striking.  On the other hand, GDP in the euro area is 2 percentage points below its 2008 level, while that of non-euro area countries is 4.5 percentage points higher. With regard to unemployment, the situation is similar. It reaches 11.5% in the euro area and only 7.3% outside the euro area. This therefore demonstrates the clear failure of the European and anti-democratic policies carried out by the Organisation of Brussels with the complicity of the national authorities. I voted against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ In 2011, there were as many as 24 countries undergoing excessive deficit proceedings. Six years after the start of the financial crisis in 2008, the eurozone remains exposed to record levels of unemployment with a rate of almost 12%. Since the height of the crisis, investment levels have decreased by €470 billion and the investment gap has been estimated at between €230 billion and €370 billion compared to its long-term trends. Member States only fully implemented around 9% of the recommendations in 2013. All this data suggests that the approach so far has not been adequate. The EU economy as a whole needs to further boost its competitiveness in the global economy, in particular by increasing competitiveness in product and service markets to improve innovation-driven efficiency. The Investment Plan for Europe is an important instrument for increasing private and public investment and aims to encourage additional investment, develop new projects, attract investors and restore trust. Although the Report was initially tailored to past, conservative policies, much has been changed through amendments during the negotiations. The rhetoric concerning liberal and structural reforms has been softened and therefore I support the rapporteur.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Taking into account the specific recommendations for Member States, the European Semester, with the support of the Commission, which monitors and provides clear guidance to countries, allows countries to better coordinate budgetary and economic plans. The Annual Growth Survey for 2015 points to the promotion of the three main pillars to achieve higher growth rates and strengthen the recovery.  Low confidence, high indebtedness and a reluctance to risk investors can be addressed through higher targeted, public investments from the European Fund for Strategic Investments supported by Member States, which are invited to contribute additional funds coming from the EU budget. Strengthening investments planned to mobilise 315 billion euros will boost SMEs as a carrier of economic recovery. Strengthening structural reforms and implementing responsible fiscal consolidation will lead to improved labour markets, pension and health systems, long-term deficit control and removal of barriers to the single market. Which ultimately favors growth and strengthens a recovery that has still slowed, stressing the importance of consistently implementing all three measures.  The Commission's contribution to improving and aligning the legal structure with the EU framework and combating tax evasion and fraud will make the system more transparent and simple. Cooperation between the European Parliament and national parliaments is crucial in developing national budgets to achieve stability and convergence. I therefore support colleague Dariusz Rosati's report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Since the new Commission took office in November 2014, President Jean-Claude Juncker has focused his efforts on resuming growth within the Union. The EU's priorities are to promote strong growth and consolidate the recovery based on three pillars: fiscal discipline, structural reforms and investment. The European Parliament adopted this report. I am delighted to have spoken in favour of this text. I believe that growth will be able to return to Europe in a sustainable way if the UNION encourages and facilitates investment in Europe and abroad, and that it largely involves SMEs in the recovery of growth. In addition, it is important to strengthen coordination between the different policies of the Member States and to ensure the economic and budgetary cohesion of the Union.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Semester, which began in 2010, sets out an annual cycle of economic policy coordination with a detailed analysis of Member States' plans in terms of budgetary, macroeconomic and structural reforms. This resolution concerns the 2015 Annual Growth Survey, prepared by the Commission in the framework of the European Semester, whose main objective is to promote a return to higher growth levels and strengthen recovery. In fact, the euro area continues to struggle with the consequences of an exceptionally long economic slowdown, which has lasted since 2008, and the recovery remains fragile.  In this context, the Commission has adopted an approach based on three main pillars: the promotion of investment, the acceleration of structural reforms and the pursuit of responsible fiscal consolidation that is conducive to growth. The Commission also underlined the importance of the European Structural and Investment Funds (including the Youth Employment Initiative), with these funds representing 10% of total public investment on average in the EU.  Finally, it stressed the urgent need to effectively combat tax fraud, which is estimated to be depriving the EU budget of substantial resources. I voted in favour.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it advocates the focus on the three pillars (promoting investment, accelerating structural reforms and pursuing responsible fiscal consolidation in favour of growth) which I consider essential to promote a return to higher growth levels and strengthen economic recovery and jobs at Union level.  I also believe that this bet should be incorporated into the forthcoming country-specific recommendations, also increasing the participation of national parliaments with a view to strengthening national ownership of these measures, given that only about 9 % of the country-specific recommendations were fully implemented by the Member States in 2013. I support the intention that Member States should manage their expenditure in accordance with the requirements of the Stability and Growth Pact (SGP), cutting current expenditure rather than reducing investment commitments.  Reforms are also needed to facilitate a new climate of entrepreneurship that stimulates business creation, new investment and innovation. Finally, it is essential and urgent to effectively combat tax fraud which is likely to deprive the EU budget of substantial resources and create serious economic distortions.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination shows that the euro area is still struggling with the consequences of the economic slowdown that began in 2008. The recovery we have been finding is still fragile. In this sense, it is important that Member States, in coordinated action with European bodies, continue to work to revive the European economy.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the austerity policies carried out so far have prevented us from achieving the EU's growth, employment and social objectives. Fiscal consolidation must be compatible with sustainable growth, decent employment and the maintenance of the welfare state, so I believe we must make use of as much flexibility as possible. I also believe that a plan is needed for SMEs to promote their access to cheap credit, EU innovation and research policies and to promote debt restructuring to prevent bankruptcy, as these are the backbone of EU job creation.  50% of the employment created today in Europe does not serve to ensure a decent life for families, so there is an unbearable pocket of labour poverty that must be urgently reversed, as decent wages are essential for social cohesion. Finally, I voted in favour of this report because it calls on the European Commission for an initiative to promote and boost minimum income in all Member States.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Parliament yesterday voted on three reports setting out our position on the 'European Semester' budget process for the Spring European Council, which will mark an intermediate step in the definition of the Union's socio-economic policies. The approach contained in this report on the European Commission's 2015 Annual Growth Review is based on the following triptych: stimulating investment in key sectors (infrastructure, education and research), pursuing structural reforms and maintaining fiscal responsibility.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. This report supports the European Commission's approach to growth and recovery, which is based on three pillars: investment, structural reforms and growth-friendly fiscal consolidation.  These pillars and reforms are part of the solution to reduce unemployment and poverty and to return to sustainable growth.  I have therefore supported this text, which also calls for greater involvement of national parliaments in discussions on the European semester and for greater national ownership of country-by-country recommendations. It is essential that Europe becomes more competitive and continues its actions in the fight against tax evasion and evasion and the strengthening of the labour market.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Growth is slowly returning to Europe, but some Member States are still in the process of carrying out structural reforms and budgetary consolidation. The Community strategy is based on three pillars: fiscal adjustment, structural reforms and increased investment for growth. Fiscal discipline is necessary, but without investment there can be no growth!

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote against it because the report supports the Commission's approach based on three pillars: relaunching investment; structural reforms; Austerity. Some examples of the proposed 'cure' are: institutionalising the troika; common European corporation tax to combat tax fraud; cross-border and cross-sectoral mobility of workers and more immigrants to foster growth; to compensate for the democratic deficit of the European Semester with a more binding EMU; attention only to the excessive deficit/debt and no mention of the excessive surplus.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against this report, which defends private finances with a favourable heterodox monetary policy, the return of financial bubbles, the socialisation of losses, a privatistic investment policy, poorly conceived and meagging, and a persistence of the austerity policy that will continue to close social rights and public services alongside alleged structural reforms in labour markets (adapting the labour force to the market) , make employment relationships more flexible), while technological and energy innovation are left under providence.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the annual growth review drawn up each year by the European Commission, which launches the 'European Semester'. I support the three-pillar approach - fiscal consolidation, investment and structural reforms - to support the return of sustainable growth and job creation in Europe.  In order for Europe not to fall back into a crisis as terrible as the one it has just experienced, we must now continue on the path of better coordination of our economic policies, by strengthening and deepening the European semester. This includes greater involvement of national parliaments in the development of country-specific recommendations to ensure greater democratic legitimacy to the process. Member States should also be encouraged to implement the Commission's recommendations. They are intended to help return to growth and employment. Finally, the European semester must also take the path of better integration of financial markets, an active fight against tax fraud and evasion and an improvement in the efficiency of the labour market.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (NI)
text: In writing. This report is based on the fact that the main economic policy directions must be decided in Brussels. I oppose it in defence of democracy and the social and political rights of our citizens.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it positively sanctions the neoliberal orientation of the economic governance framework. The annual prospective study is the European Commission's economic study that starts the entire European Semester process. This study develops a very limited monetarist analysis, which does not take into account eer the social effects of austerity policies or differences in the productive structures of EU Member States. On the basis of this limited analysis, austerity recommendations to Member States will be justified, deepening the effects of the crisis. This report does not in any way condemn the way in which this study is drawn up and that is why I have decided to vote against it.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on paragraph 29, split 1, because, while we cannot support calls for the EU to interfere in the tax and criminal law of Member States, we of course do not oppose cracking down on tax fraud and illegal activity.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 It is well known that Europe needs economic growth that can solve many of our problems. Only recently have we started to rise very slowly from our knees. The examples of Ireland and Spain show that fiscal consolidation and refom programmes produce positive results. However, it must be borne in mind that several countries in the zone are still struggling with a lack of economic growth and poor economic forecasts. The European Semester was established in 2010 for better economic coordination. However, this cooperation is difficult. Member States' economies and priorities vary, but this is a forum for joint discussion.  The biggest challenge now is to implement the so-called Juncker Investment Plan as soon as possible, which aims to restore sustainable growth in Europe. In addition, the structural reforms that have started should continue. The fight against public debt still deserves special attention, as it is necessary to protect the still weak economic recovery. Priority must now be given to tax reforms. The EU's European Single Market must now m.in focus on creating a digital market and a common energy market.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted with my S&D Group colleagues in favour of the report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: Annual Growth Survey 2015.  The report draws attention to the fact that the euro area is still struggling with the consequences of an exceptionally long economic downturn after 2008. It points out that the recovery is still fragile and should be enhanced if it is to deliver substantially more growth and jobs in the medium term. However, growth in 2014 is more broadly based. Economic recovery in the EU slowed down considerably in the course of 2014 but, according to the Commission, has a prospect of catching up in 2015 and of doing even better in 2016.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ We have clear rules on budgetary responsibility in the EU and it is crucial for further developments to comply with them. In order to stimulate compliance, we must motivate responsible countries and punish irresponsible financially.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ In 2014 there was a significant slowdown in the economic recovery in the EU. Six years after the start of the financial crisis in 2008, the euro area remains at record levels of unemployment with a rate of almost 12%. Weak growth has also been reinforced by the disinflation trend, and since the height of the crisis, investment levels have decreased by EUR 470 billion. The Investment Plan for Europe is an important instrument for increasing private and public investment, noting that it aims to stimulate additional investment, develop new projects, attract investors and restore trust. In particular, I would point out that one of the biggest barriers to growth in the EU is the lack of access to finance, especially for SMEs, and the downfall is that SMEs continue to find it difficult to obtain bank loans. I also think that alternatives to bank financing are needed, in particular by improving the business environment for venture capital. For this reason, I support this report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Annual Growth Survey 2015 as it sets out what more can be done at EU level to help Member States return to higher growth levels.  Specifically, it proposes that the process be streamlined, with a view to increasing political ownership, accountability and acceptance of the process, to strengthening its credibility and comparability across Member States and to improving the implementation of country-specific recommendations.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. – The Commission's Annual Growth Survey 2015 aims to promote a return to higher levels of growth and to strengthen recovery by supporting a three-pillar approach (strengthening investment, accelerating structural reforms and leading responsible growth-friendly fiscal consolidation) seeing this as the right way to achieve these objectives. I underline that the investment gap can be addressed through targeted public investment and greater investment in private companies and European companies.  I call for reforms that would allow for a new entrepreneurial climate that encourages new businesses, new investment and innovation, with investment opportunities a key factor for attracting financial capital.  I welcome the Investment Plan for Europe, which is an important instrument for increasing private and public investment, as it aims to stimulate additional investment, develop new projects, attract investors and restore trust. I believe that one of the biggest barriers to growth in the EU is the lack of access to finance, especially for SMEs. Small and medium-sized enterprises still find it difficult to get bank loans.  I believe that alternatives to banking financing are needed, in particular improving the business environment for venture capital, promoting credit unions, but also generally creating the conditions for effective capital allocation through capital markets. That's why I support this report.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: I did not support the report in writing ‒ because it supports a number of policies that are directly at odds with achieving real growth. These include, for example, progress on the consolidated corporate tax base, a step towards reducing tax competition and, for example, calls for greater redistribution in some programmes, which will also not help growth.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported my colleague Rosati's report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination, the 2015 Annual Growth Survey, because it aims to restore higher growth rates and strengthen recovery rates and supports an approach based on three main pillars: strengthening investment, accelerating structural reforms and implementing growth-friendly fiscal consolidation. I also endorsed the report because I agree that the EU economy as a whole must further strengthen its competitiveness in the global economy, in particular by increasing competition in the product and services market, in order to improve efficiency based on innovation. Labour costs should remain in line with productivity and wages should contribute to sustainable social protection systems.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report underlines the need to curb labour costs in line with production (i.e. lower wages and increase productivity), gives clear support to the Juncker Plan and stresses the need to continue structural reforms. The legitimacy of the Troika through European law is also called for.  The report legitimises all the mnemonic policies of harsh austerity and gives full support to the policies promoted by the Juncker Commission. That is why we voted against the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Process of the European Semester is undemocratic and violates the right of each Member State and its people to decide their policies according to their economic and social situation, as well as their rights and aspirations. We do not want any more structural reforms aimed at weakening the south.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the 2015 Annual Growth Survey. I consider the practice established in 2010 to analyse the budgetary, macroeconomic and structural reform plans of the EU Member States every year to be correct and further developed.  However, it is important that all democratic deficits in the European Semester are remedied as soon as possible and in a truly effective manner. This is also a condition for further strengthening the Competitiveness of the Union. It is also right that the report pays particular attention to investment and the Investment Plan for Europe, paying particular attention to the specific situation of SMEs.  I also think it is important that the report underlines the need to pay due attention to the social and employment impact of structural reforms. I, too, believe that structural reforms should only be implemented in a socially balanced and socially sustainable way.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. We, in the Belgian delegation, rejected the text en masse. We cannot accept that the individual is seen as a working machine, without rights!

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. I believe that we need to provide entrepreneurs with a stimulating and unburded business environment in order to find long-term solutions that will enable their stability and liquidity. I agree with that part of the report that recognises small and medium-sized enterprises play a major role in achieving economic growth. But certain parts represent provisions that they cannot support. The report reiterates the importance of ensuring worker mobility, stressing that greater mobility can help reduce high levels of unsubted jobs. Therefore, I reiterate my concern, because this policy does not take into account the consequences that the emigration of the working-age force of primarily young people can have on the economic and demographic picture of a particular country.  We have stressed countless times the importance of restructuring economies in order to achieve the revitalisation of the Union single market. However, I believe that such measures go at the expense of these efforts. As an MP from a country where the trend of emigration of young people is increasing by the day, I believe that only the creation of measures for more dynamic employment and retention of young and educated populations can prevent negative effects on the growth of the economy and ultimately contribute to a better quality of life. So I voted no.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is my belief that a bigger policy coordination among Member States is of the utmost importance for the future of the Union. The experience of the recent past shows us that despite the political costs that all reforms entail, their benefits in the medium term are fundamental to raising the growth potential of the eurozone.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against this report, which defends private finances with a favourable heterodox monetary policy, the return of financial bubbles, the socialisation of losses, a privatistic investment policy, poorly conceived and meagging, and a persistence of the austerity policy that will continue to close social rights and public services alongside alleged structural reforms in labour markets (adapting the labour force to the labour force) , make employment relationships more flexible), while technological and energy innovation are left under providence.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted against this report as it proposes to delve into structural reforms and austerity by obviating the impact on the real economy. It praises the results of the last European Semester without regard to the serious social impact of EU recommendations or the deterioration on the road to targets such as the Europe 2020 Strategy.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. As every year, the European Parliament presents an own-initiative report in which it delivers an opinion on the text Analysis of Growth (AGS) where the European Commission identifies the main objectives to be pursued for the following year. The M5S has put forward a number of proposals and identified several measures to start growth. However, despite lengthy and difficult negotiations, the text has remained unchanged and none of the proposed amendments have been accepted. The result is unbalanced and un objective text. Indeed, the text welcomes the measures taken after the crisis and does not recognise austerity measures as the cause of the lack of growth. Even worse, additional efforts are being made by countries in difficulty in terms of fiscal consolidation and structural reforms and, finally, insufficient reference is made to social policies and the fight against tax evasion and avoidance. In conclusion, the text has not only made no contribution to the formulation of the next AGS. This, too, was another wasted opportunity for Parliament to denounce the ineffectiveness of austerity policies and to seriously identify alternative measures to revive growth.  For these reasons, the M5S voted against.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it positively sanctions the neoliberal orientation of the economic governance framework. The annual prospective study is the European Commission's economic study that starts the entire European Semester process. This study develops a very limited monetarist analysis, which does not take into account eer the social effects of austerity policies or differences in the productive structures of EU Member States. On the basis of this limited analysis, austerity recommendations to Member States will be justified, deepening the effects of the crisis. This report does not in any way condemn the way in which this study is drawn up and that is why I have decided to vote against it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the Annual Growth Survey (2015) represents the starting point of the European Semester and the whole process of economic governance. This report provides the main policy guidelines on which national budgets should be built.  As expected, he continues to advocate austerity and structural reforms, particularly in the labour market and the privatisation of companies and public services that guarantee access to social rights gained after decades of struggle. This is totally unacceptable because, at this time of crisis, it prevents countries from intervening with redistributive policies to help those in need and to prevent the collapse of aggregate consumption. Economic governance and the European Semester are a way of tassing national states to the neoliberal agendas of the European Union at the service of major economic interests. They prevent countries from being able to sovereignly decide their collective future, forcing them to watch their economies in arms. We cannot accept this passively and we will do anything to break with this monetary dictatorship.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. The European Semester for the coordination of economic policy is, in my view, the demand for more government and less private accountability. It sees fiscal consolidation on the part of the Member States as necessary, but does not want to accept spending cuts. That is because of this, I have decided against this report.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I do not agree with the draft European Parliament resolution on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: Annual Growth Survey 2015. The report as a whole is a farce, as it assumes that the European economy can be influenced by the Commission in its interests as well as taxable. It is also written in the hubris that the European political institutions have superior knowledge of the economic governance of the European economy. And if these fundamental considerations are not sufficient for rejection, it is sufficient that the report welcomes Juncker's "Investment Plan for Europe as an important instrument for increasing private and public investment" with kind words.

name: Steven Woolfe (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on paragraph 29, split 1, because while we cannot support calls for the EU to interfere in the tax and criminal law of Member States, we do not, of course, oppose cracking down on tax fraud and illegal activity.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has also presented this own-initiative report this year in which it analyses the aspects related to the Analysis of Growth (AGS). I believe, however, that the text is a little too pleased with the measures taken after the crisis and does not recognise that austerity measures have only choked growth. This report is based on an overly optimistic approach to future growth prospects and the added value that the new European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) could bring. I do not think it is appropriate for countries to continue to demand additional efforts in terms of fiscal consolidation and structural reforms. In the final analysis, insufficient reference is made to the measures needed to return to growth, too few references to the internal market, social policies and the fight against tax evasion and avoidance. For all these reasons, I voted against this report, which I believe has many critical issues and does not make substantial contributions to the formulation of the next annual analysis.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The reports on the implementation of the 2015 European Semester and enhanced economic governance support its three unpopular pillars, identified by the EU and its institutions: Investment - accelerating unpopular reforms - extending cuts in social spending.  The European Parliament, firmly expressing the interests of plutocracy, is at the fore in promoting the reforms that capital needs around three main axes which are: a. Reducing corporate taxation and their social security obligations b. Liberalisation of the EU's single capitalist market in sectors critical to the profitability of groups, such as services, the digital market , energy, research and innovation, Greater connection of education with businesses and their needs c. Further reduction in the price of labour force, new blows to public social security and welfare systems, industrial relations and stable work with rights, increased mobility - work wandering at transnational and cross-sectoral level, with emphasis on promoting disposable skills , necessary for the specific needs of the capital.  It is up to the peoples to organise their struggle to recover the losses of the crisis, for their modern needs, with the release from the EU and the people in power.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the Annual Growth Survey (2015) represents the starting point of the European Semester and the entire economic governance process, providing the main policy guidelines on which national budgets should be built. It continues to advocate austerity and structural reforms, particularly in the labour market and the privatisation of businesses and public services that guarantee fair access to social rights achieved after decades of struggle. This is totally unacceptable, because at this time of crisis, it prevents countries from intervening with redistributive policies to help those in need and to prevent the collapse of aggregate consumption. Economic governance and the European Semester are a way of tassing national states to the neoliberal agendas of the European Union at the service of major economic interests. Of course, we voted against it.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. The European Semester, launched in 2010, has proved to be the right mechanism to establish an annual cycle of economic policy coordination, including a detailed analysis of Member States' plans for budgetary, macroeconomic and structural reforms. It is particularly important for partly reformed economies such as The Slovenian Economy, as it shows a clear path that countries need to take. I agree with the caveats that the recovery in the EU is still fragile and needs to be strengthened. We have the most work to do with all those Member States that have not yet achieved the objectives that we have agreed with the Commission. First and for the part, I would like to highlight the importance of structural reforms that a number of countries, including Slovenia, have to implement. We need to increase the efficiency of the labour market, modernise social protection systems, including pension protection, and at the same time we need to improve and simplify the legal framework for business investment, as Commissioner Jourova pointed out in her report these days, and to carry out transparent privatisation. Structural reforms must bring sustainable growth, higher employment and prosperity for all. Fiscal responsibility, however, is essential. I am pleased that the number of countries that are in the process of being enth out of the excessive deficit has fallen sharply. The golden fiscal rule for sustainable public finances is crucial here.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the austerity policies carried out so far have prevented us from achieving the EU's growth, employment and social objectives. Fiscal consolidation must be compatible with sustainable growth, decent employment and the maintenance of the welfare state; therefore, I believe that we must make use of as much flexibility as possible. I also believe that a plan is needed for SMEs to promote their access to cheap credit and EU innovation and research policies, and that debt restructuring is encouraged to avoid bankruptcy, as SMEs are the backbone of EU job creation.  50% of the jobs created today in Europe do not serve to ensure a decent life for families, so there is an unbearable pocket of labour poverty that must be urgently reversed, as decent wages are essential for social cohesion. Finally, I voted in favour of this report because it calls on the European Commission for an initiative to promote and boost minimum income in all Member States.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it does not imply any change in the neoliberal orientation of the economic governance framework. The Annual Prospective Study is the European Commission's economic study that starts the entire European Semester process. This report seeks to include social and employment indicators in the Study to improve its quality. However, this inclusion is superficial in nature and does not link these indicators to the recommendations; it is a mere decoration that will not reform the framework of economic governance at all. A real review in this regard should link and force the Commission to reformulate its recommendations and to bet on binding social objectives, overcoming the monetarist logic of its policies. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The Employment Committee Report refers to the social aspects of the Annual Report on Development presented by the European Commission. It calls for more growth-friendly policies aimed at creating quality jobs. It also calls for the establishment of a pan-European minimum income system and calls for policies to achieve the objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy.  Finally, it calls for Parliament's participation in the process of writing and approving the Annual Report on Development and the European Commission's Recommendations on Economic Policies and the Labour Market.  For all the above reasons I voted in favour of the Employment Committee's report entitled "European Semester for the Coordination of Economic Policies: Employment and Social Aspects in the 2015 Annual Growth Survey".

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. The supranational objectives of the European Semester are here in proposals for structural reforms that refer to two pitfalls of European employment policy and social aspects: the search for greater flexibility in the labour market in a context of free movement of workers and a fundamental trend towards the harmonisation of employment protection rules. The convergence of economies and labour market frameworks is also not based on any legitimacy or on the possible feasibility of these proposals. The text submitted to the European Parliament is therefore incantatory and based more on political considerations than on real needs.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I do not believe that the European Semester process is sufficiently democratic, and in any event as a UKIP MEP I should vote against for reasons of principle. In terms of economic and social aspects, I am concerned that many suggestions – however laudable – should fall within the remit of the Member States.

name: Janice Atkinson (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on paragraph 29, split 1, because, while we cannot support calls for the EU to interfere in the tax and criminal law of Member States, we of course do not oppose cracking down on tax fraud and illegal activity.

name: Guillaume Balas (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the final resolution on employment and social aspects in the annual growth review, published in November 2014 by the European Commission, which aims to ensure the coordination of economic policies within the Union. It provides a lucid analysis of the disastrous consequences of the austerity policies that have taken place in the peripheral countries of the Union, but also of the accelerated measures of fiscal consolidation which have broken the mechanics of recovery in the other States of the European Union.  The quality of the recommendations contained in this resolution owes much to the excellent work done by the Socialist rapporteur Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto, who managed to convince a majority of MEPs to support, among other things, a plan to combat dumping and tax evasion and to call for the introduction of an ambitious tax on financial transactions.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a Semester for the coordination of European economic policies. According to this year's European economic growth forecasts, high unemployment rates will continue to persist. This shows that fundamental structural reforms in the economic and social areas are struggling. I support the investment promotion plan put forward by the President of the Commission, but it should not be seen as an alternative to the necessary reforms, but an additional instrument that will allow funds to be allocated to projects with European and economic and social returns. The creation of a single energy market and the promotion of energy independence in EU countries must be accelerated. The creation of an energy union is essential and will make Member States more competitive and resilient to political pressure from third countries.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because I am opposed to the 'European Semester for the Coordination of Economic Policies', which is contrary to the fundamental right of each Member State and its people to decide their policies according to their economic and social situation, as well as their rights and aspirations.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. This report stresses the need to fight for decent jobs and against youth unemployment. It also stresses that professional mobility must be voluntary and not subject to economic pressure. It reminds us of the need to introduce a minimum income throughout Europe in order to limit the social dumping we are experiencing today. When it comes to taxation, the emphasis is on moving from labour taxation to capital taxation. These principles seem to me to be essential to respect in view of the current economic crisis in Europe, and that is why I have positioned myself in favour of this report.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I believe that the new Commission should make it clear from the beginning of its mandate that it has come to change the sign of the policies we have implemented to date in the face of the crisis. The center of political action is people. People are the goal of the 2020 Strategy and the means of growing in an intelligent, sustainable and cohesive way. That is why I support the need to implement a minimum income programme at European level. It is set out in the Juncker Commission programme. I have seen how it has served in my country, the Basque Country, for 27 years to avoid exclusion. It is time to rescue people from poverty more hard than the time spent rescuing the financial system and safe than at much less cost.  We need a Commission with more resources and more power and capacity to lead productive investments and mobilize private capital in favour of the real economy by penalizing speculation. That's a social and federal Europe for me. People's Europe.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This second report on the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination focuses on employment and social aspects. The Austerity Policies of the European Union and the fall in investment spending prevent and prevent any resumption of growth and lower unemployment. The fall in the price of the euro (which European leaders welcome when they did not want it before) must allow the recovery. Unfortunately, this situation may not last, as with the fall in the price of oil, which does not improve the purchasing power of households, since prices at the pump have fallen only slightly.  It is becoming urgent for the Union to put an end to this policy of austerity and flight forward by working to save a single currency that is not adapted. So I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this report, which celebrates the practice of the European Semester as useless as it is harmful.  It is useless because the coordination of economic policies, apart from showing that Europe has also deprived us of the opportunity to decide how to spend our money, has not solved any problems. It is harmful because, through this process, Europe has been accused of austerity and absurd measures by those Member States which did not respond to the berlin diktats, bringing entire economies to their knees.  An example of all, Veneto! Here the "Eurofollie" have sent a hundred thousand jobs into smoke, closing, in 2014 alone, at least three thousand companies. If these are the wonderful results of the European Semester then let us cancel it! No more proclamations, no more propaganda, no more lies!

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the austerity policies carried out so far have prevented us from achieving the EU's growth, employment and social objectives. Fiscal consolidation must be compatible with sustainable growth, decent employment and the maintenance of the welfare state; therefore, I believe that we must make use of as much flexibility as possible. I also believe that a plan is needed for SMEs to promote their access to cheap credit and EU innovation and research policies, and that debt restructuring is encouraged to avoid bankruptcy, as SMEs are the backbone of EU job creation.  50% of the jobs created today in Europe do not serve to ensure a decent life for families, so there is an unbearable pocket of labour poverty that must be urgently reversed, as decent wages are essential for social cohesion. Finally, I voted in favour of this report because it calls on the European Commission for an initiative to promote and boost minimum income in all Member States.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the European Union must continue to improve its economic and social policies, which pursue the Europe 2020 objectives, while at the same time avoiding the risk of long-term stagnation and deflation. It is important to note that the European Investment Plan is essential to complement efforts to promote sustainable growth and jobs, and that it needs to be supported by private and public resources in order to be successful. In addition, small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are the basis for job creation in the European Union. They continue to face serious difficulties and indebtedness in access to finance in order to access finance, and the European Parliament welcomes the Commission's new recommendations on access to finance for SMEs, which includes a new approach to insolvency and business failure. We should also welcome the fact that, in the 2015 Annual Growth Survey, the Commission calls on the Member States to protect or promote long-term investment in education, research and innovation. It should also be noted that youth unemployment has fallen, but Parliament continues to call on the Commission to propose a European framework setting minimum implementation standards for the Youth Guarantee and specific measures to raise public awareness.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The latest figures recorded, namely those for 2013, show that long-term unemployment is at a historically high level of 5.1% of the workforce in EU-28 countries.  I support the Commission's integrated approach to growth, which is based on three main pillars: the Investment Plan for Europe, structural reforms and fiscal responsibility.  The report calls for ambitious economic policies for growth, job creation and the fight against deflation.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. This initiative report on the European semester reflects a real schizophrenia. He denounces the drying up of public investment while calling for the continuation of austerity policies. These pro-cyclical policies are a sign of economic imperiousness. One might think that the European Commission is seeking to contain the public investments of the Member States to support the Juncker plan at European level. The contrast with the economic vitality of the United States is, as such, striking. It should be noted that GDP in the euro area is 2 percentage points lower than in 2008, while that of non-euro area countries is 4.5 percentage points higher. With regard to unemployment, the situation is similar. It reaches 11.5% in the euro area and only 7.3% outside the euro area. This demonstrates the clear failure of the European and anti-democratic policies pursued by the Brussels Commission. I voted against it.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against. The report criticises the negative impact on employment of austerity, but only because it is so obvious that it cannot be denied. The text reiterates its support for the Commission's three-pillar approach, boosting investment, reform and austerity. Wrong solutions.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the austerity policies carried out so far have prevented us from achieving the EU's growth, employment and social objectives. Fiscal consolidation must be compatible with sustainable growth, decent employment and the maintenance of the welfare state; therefore, I believe that we must make use of as much flexibility as possible. I also believe that a plan is needed for SMEs to promote their access to cheap credit and EU innovation and research policies, and that debt restructuring is encouraged to avoid bankruptcy, as SMEs are the backbone of EU job creation.  50% of the jobs created today in Europe do not serve to ensure a decent life for families, so there is an unbearable pocket of labour poverty that must be urgently reversed, as decent wages are essential for social cohesion. Finally, I voted in favour of this report because it calls on the European Commission for an initiative to promote and boost minimum income in all Member States.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the employment and social aspects report as part of the 2015 Annual Growth Review of the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination. One of the findings of the crisis was the need to coordinate the economic policies of the Member States. It is true that europe's interdependent economies have an impact on each other. We must now realize the need to do the same at the social level. The crisis has had devastating social consequences. The unemployment rate continues to rise. This is most often due to a lack of political courage by some governments that are failing to implement appropriate structural reforms to fix their country's economy. If we want to create growth and jobs, we need to be politically realistic. This report was also an opportunity for me to reiterate my positions in favour of a fierce fight against social and fiscal dumping, as well as for the introduction of minimum wages adapted to the situation of each Member State.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination on employment and social aspects in the 2015 Annual Growth Survey.  The report showed that the economic and social environment in the EU continues to show alarming data. The unemployment rate remains at historically high levels, with almost 25 million unemployed in the EU and a particularly critical labour market situation for young people. It is therefore essential that a European framework be established to ensure that all investments under the Investment Plan for Europe have a significant impact in terms of job creation. The economic and social impact of real investment will have to be carefully assessed by the Commission. Finally, I note that SMEs, which form the backbone of job creation in the EU, continue to face serious difficulties in accessing finance and are in worrying conditions of excessive indebtedness. The Commission and the Member States should therefore restore the capacity of the economic system to lend, thus enabling SMEs to invest and create jobs.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒  I voted against this report as it is futile to discuss the proposed aims for the European Semester in 2015 when the European Commission unremittingly refuses to acknowledge the underlying structural and economic problems which the two-pack and six-pack reforms pose, specifically failing to address the need for wide-scale investment in employment and social investment.  In the light of the aims of the European Commission for the 2015 European semester, the focus is supposedly on avoiding economic boom-and-bust cycles and restoring economic growth to the EU. However, there is no mention of equitable growth and poverty reduction. It shows a clear disconnect between European bureaucrats and the reality that is facing millions of struggling working families in Ireland and right across the EU. The primary aim of reforms concerning the European semester seems to be just to ensure that Member States do not deviate from the economic neo-liberal ideology that is being pushed. It does not leave Member States with flexibility to implement alternative policies, which would be pro-investment, pro-growth and pro-jobs. In effect it is working to deny both Irish and other EU citizens real political choices when electing their governments and is further eroding sovereignty and reducing economic independence.

name: David Casa (PPE)
