text: in writing. ‒ The report places strong emphasis on elements aimed at boosting sustainable economic growth, job creation in all age groups and fostering social progress, whilst respecting the European social model.  Inter alia it lists various measures announced by the Commission to boost job creation in SMEs. Whilst SMEs are widely acknowledged to be the backbone of the Union's economy, they are still burdened by unnecessary administration and bureaucracy. On the other hand, these ambitious economic policies need to be pursued in parallel with fiscal consolidation and the use of a degree of flexibility within the rules of the Stability and Growth Pact, particularly in terms of social investment in people. The report calls on Member States to implement these measures in a quick and faithful way. It also focuses on the importance of the fight against youth and long-term unemployment, calling for urgent solutions to be found in order to allow a balance between work and family life and to encourage training and learning. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report is a good text from a general point of view, but we cannot ignore the paragraphs which once again refer to the need for structural reforms, as well as the reference to fiscal responsibility. In the current economic climate, where unemployment is rampant combined with dangerous deflation, investment (particularly in small and medium-sized enterprises) and employment measures should be the priority. I have therefore chosen to vote against.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. Because I am opposed to the European Commission's tutelage over the Member States, particularly in the context of their economic policy, I voted against this report on the European Semester for the Coordination of Economic Policies. Especially since this report is an observation of the failure of the economic and budgetary diktat imposed by Brussels. Indeed, the rapporteur acknowledges that the economic and social situation in the euro area continues to deteriorate. The solutions advocated are also the opposite of what should be done to reinvigorate employment: the Junker plan is expected to be the providential solution, even though the social impact is excluded from the plan's strategy. Finally, the recent reforms imposed by Brussels have, let us not forget, led to an increase in precarious work, which is the opposite of a sustainable strategy for jobs and growth.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Numerous indicators show an improvement in the employment situation, but the unemployment rate is still too high, with dramatic peaks in the weaker areas. A key role can be played by the Commission's recommendations to the Member States on consolidation and structural reforms, but above all in terms of economic and social policies that promote smart and sustainable growth, through the creation of quality jobs and support for those SMEs that are currently excluded from the global competitive game due to excessive and undue difficulties in accessing finance. Equally important is the provision for greater commitment by all the European institutions to encouraging the initiative of states and local and regional authorities for the full and effective use of European funding, which is often used little or badly. Only in this way will it be possible to bring reality closer to the objectives set out in the Europe 2020 Strategy. The report goes in this direction and I therefore voted in favour of it.

name: Ole Christensen (S&D)
text: Written. As can be seen from the recitals in this report, the fixing of salaries falls within the competence of the Member States. A European minimum wage is not in line with the Danish labour market model and, against this background, we are critical of all actions and calls that could potentially promote the EU's influence in the setting of wages in Denmark.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The measure refers to the Commission's 2015 Annual Growth Survey, which worked in particular on the employment and social aspects, based on three main aspects: relaunching investment, cleaning up a responsible budget and structural reforms. The European Semester provides in detail macroeconomic and structural budgetary reforms of the EU Member States. I consider the measure to be satisfactory and have voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the European Semester for economic policy coordination because it provides a detailed analysis of the eu Member States' budgetary, macroeconomic and structural reform plans. With regard to the Commission's 2015 Annual Growth Survey, which is particularly concerned with employment and social aspects, I support the three-pillar approach (relaunching investment, accelerating structural reforms and pursuing responsible fiscal consolidation). For these reasons, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination, which deals with the annual analysis of employment and social aspects for 2015, for the following reasons.  Economic growth in Europe remains fragile despite upward estimates of a growth rate for 2015 of 1.1 % compared to 0.8 % in 2014. The path taken in order to consolidate public accounts has prevented Member States from achieving the objectives set out in the Europe 2020 strategy by demonstrating once again how fiscal policies cannot take a universal approach, but must take into account the micro-economics and the state of health of the public accounts of the various Member States. The gradual complementarity of the European economy with the now major US and Asian economies, and the simultaneous weakness of the internal market, have led to an unemployment rate of 21.2%, of which 75 % are young people under 35. The Community strategy based on fiscal adjustment, structural reforms and increased investment in growth appears to be in line with the need to revive the European macro-economy, which, however, cannot ignore private investment.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the fact that this year, for the first time, the draft Joint Employment Report annexed to the Annual Growth Survey includes a scoreboard for employment and social policies, which will help to strengthen the monitoring of employment and social developments. The EU needs more adaptive and dynamic labour markets, able to adjust to disruptions in the economic situation without causing redundancies and excessive adjustments in salaries. Measures for tackling youth unemployment are of the utmost importance. I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 On the Council and Commission statements on the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination: Annual Growth Survey 2015, I am voting against it because, following the long and difficult negotiations with the rapporteur, the text has been slightly amended but not to such an extent that it is acceptable. In particular, the text is too pleased with the measures taken after the crisis and does not recognise that austerity measures have choked growth. In our opinion, the text is based on an optimistic approach to future growth prospects and the added value that EFSI can bring. No amendments proposed by the EFDD Group have been included in the compromises.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which focuses on the employment and social aspects of the Annual Growth Survey. However, I voted against the inclusion of part of a paragraph which calls for the adoption at Council level of an ambitious financial transaction tax. I believe that tax issues should remain a Member State competence.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that it is necessary to identify important macroeconomic and macro-social imbalances in the EU and euro area economies and to formulate on this basis the country-specific recommendations prepared within the European Semester, including measures to improve labour and social standards, as well as coordination of wage setting.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report focuses on social and employment aspects as part of the 2015 Annual Growth Review and calls for ambitious and responsible economic policies for growth, quality job creation and the fight against deflation. In particular, the report calls on the European Commission to take urgent measures to combat tax dumping, tax evasion and tax evasion and calls for the adoption at Council level of an ambitious tax on financial transactions. Considering all these aspects, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which dealt with the social aspects of the European Semester, which is an annual round of economic policy coordination. Through this Semester, the European Commission must be able to analyse the member's budgetary, economic and structural reform plans, and then send them its recommendations on their economic trajectory. In particular, I wanted to support a recital that protected our small and medium-sized enterprises from relocation, as well as a paragraph to quickly introduce a tax on financial transactions and combat tax evasion.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: in writing. – The European Semester - AGS Growth Survey 2015 is extremely important for Europe as a tool for economic policy coordination and governance. I abstained from voting on the EMPL opinion because it weakens the focus of the report and has some fundamental flaws in some of its assumptions. Like EMPL I am opposed to any form of tax evasion or dumping. However, it is inappropriate to suggest implementing a tax on financial transactions in order to finance public investment for growth and quality jobs. The suggestion to exclude productive investments in education, research and development from the deficit targets increases the scope of 'flexibility' rules. It is also incorrect to suggest that minimum wages at European level will lead to a recovering and productive economy. In fact, some Member States need lower minimum wages as a competitive advantage, as without that there is no growth in production.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European semester frames the economic and budgetary policies of the Member States. It is a tool for common economic governance, and as such is a further step towards greater integration of the euro area. This coordination at European level must give priority to growth and employment, cohesion and investment, and ensure a macroeconomic rebalancing of the euro area. In order to make this process better, it is of course necessary that the European Parliament be more involved, but also our national parliaments. In this resolution, the European Parliament called on the Commission to study the introduction of minimum wages in Member States to reduce wage inequality, and to organise a conference on a European framework setting minimum wages. This initiative is in the direction of fiscal and social convergence, which we have long called for, and which is the only way to combat unfair competition between European countries.

name: Karima Delli (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament voted on 11 March 2015 on the Guttierez report on the employment component of the 2015 semester. I support this report, which makes several important proposals to underline and strengthen the social dimension of the European semester. In particular, it stresses the fight against tax evasion and the need for a tax on financial transactions that meets the needs. It calls on the European Commission to organise a conference on a European framework for setting minimum wages. It calls on the Commission to table a legislative proposal on minimum income, and calls for an increase in the budget sufficient for the implementation of the Youth Guarantee, particularly during its mid-term review. Finally, this report condemns austerity policies, so it regrets the negative consequences on social cohesion. It allows the need, instead of the ineffective and destructive austerity of solidarity, to be confirmed in place of the ineffective and destructive austerity of solidarity, to form a social union as a counterweight to the existing economic and monetary union.

name: Martina Dlabajová (ALDE)
text: in writing. – As much as I wished that I could, I could not support the Annual Growth Survey 2015 report adopted by the European Parliament. The focus of such reports should be economic and budgetary policy coordination, in line with the Member States' commitments under the Stability and Growth Pact.

name: Anneliese Dodds (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Amendment no.2 I voted for this amendment because I believe it is essential that the European Parliament take every opportunity possible to highlight the need to combat precarious work. This includes combating the scourge of zero-hours contracts and short-hours work, which is making forward planning all but impossible for many working people in the UK.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. The supranational objectives of the European semester are here in proposals for structural reforms that refer to two pitfalls of European employment policy and social aspects. Firstly, it is a search for greater flexibility in the labour market in a context of free movement of workers, as well as a fundamental trend towards the harmonization of employment protection rules. The convergence of economies and labour market frameworks is not based on any legitimacy or the possible feasibility of these proposals. The text submitted to the European Parliament is therefore incantatory and based more on political considerations than on real needs.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The 2015 AGS is accompanied by the draft Joint Employment Report (JER). The JER takes stock of employment reforms in Member States, expands on the key employment messages contained in the AGS and includes for the first time the findings of the "Social and Employment Scoreboard", which was introduced last year to strengthen the social dimension of the EMU. While the AGS does not in itself have any regulatory implications, this own-initiative report seeks to build on the JER. While it is quite balanced in places and contains a number of key ECR priorities, it also calls for a number of initiatives at EU level that the ECR cannot support, including: a European framework for minimum wages; a proposal for a European minimum income; a European framework for introducing minimum standards for the implementation of youth guarantees; the introduction of an EU child guarantee against poverty; a Green Paper on automatic stabilisers in the EMU (EU unemployment benefit scheme); and making the "social and employment scoreboard" binding.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the Report because it promotes the economic policy that led to the destruction of my country. The Union needs a radical change in its economic outlook, otherwise it will face structural problems.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I believe that employment and social considerations should be on a par with macroeconomic ones in terms of EU economic policy coordination. In-work poverty persists in Wales and low wages are a serious problem. We need to create good-quality, well paid and sustainable jobs. We also need security at work and an end to exploitative contracts and practises, as well as an end to discrimination. The report recognises these issues. Plaid Cymru has the policies to address these problems to revitalise the Welsh economy and ensure social protection for all workers.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering that the latest data available for 2013 show us a Europe on its knees, in which as many as 25% of citizens are at risk of poverty and social exclusion, we can well understand how the austerity measures promoted by the Commission and carried out in the Member States through the individual national structural reform plans are bankrupt and indeed exacerbate a socio-economic crisis and which we believe can only be curbed by measures that aim at the establishment of a minimum wages across the Union. We are faced with a Europe in which, for example, in 2012 only half of men between the age of 55 and 65 had jobs, so it would seem necessary to guarantee a minimum income also with a view to achieving the poverty reduction targets set out in the Europe 2020 strategy; Unfortunately, however, this need is not perceived as such and is therefore accepted in this text, although good in many respects, which is why I am voting against it.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Semester process is a valuable tool in coordinating the economic and social policies of the Member States. In this context, greater emphasis and better integration of the economic, social and employment dimension must be advocated in an instrument which has so far focused too much on the macroeconomic and monetary dimension of the European Union. The Resolution stresses that social and employment considerations should be put on an equal footing with macroeconomic considerations in the European Semester process. On the other hand, it expresses concern about the social and employment indicators that are used that do not take into account the quality or sustainability of the employment created. Stresses that when unemployment rates are analysed, due attention is not paid to factors such as increased rates of inactive people and migration; Reforms should be undertaken to promote human capital through education policies appropriate to market needs to make Europe a more attractive place for investment, particularly in those areas with the highest added value. The European Semester should be instrumental in this diagnosis and in the definition of new policies.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. Europe must be committed to a model of the social market economy that ensures sustainable growth in order to provide jobs rather than debt to the next generation. According to the report, despite negative growth rates in the euro area in the last two years, growth in the euro area is expected to reach 0.8% in 2014 and 1.1% in 2015. On the other hand, the overall deficit predicted in the EU-28, despite the fact that it was reduced to 3 % in 2014, remains high in some Member States, demonstrating the need for further fiscal consolidation compatible with sustainable growth and job creation. The sharp fall in oil prices could give an additional boost to the economy of many Member States, especially if it translates rapidly into lower energy costs for households and businesses. To this end, the EU needs to continue to improve its economic and social policies in order to achieve the europe 2020 objectives and to make efforts to promote investment and structural reforms that increase economic competitiveness in a socially responsible manner.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is one of three reports on the European Semester procedure, addressing social and employment aspects.  The report recognises increased unemployment, the growth of poverty and social exclusion and considers that these are more or less inevitable and necessary consequences of 'fiscal consolidation'. We are therefore faced with a certain hypocrisy and even a certain cynicism. The report continues to advocate measures that have been integrated into so-called "fiscal consolidation" policies, "structural reforms", i.e. the measures that have led to the problems that the report itself diagnoses. Lower wages, lay-offs, cuts in public investment opposed to economic growth and therefore responsible for increasing the unemployment rate. The report recommends, for example, "flexicurity", the alignment of wages with productivity, the increase in the retirement age, the promotion of mobility as a way to reduce unemployment in some countries. Finally, the neoliberal booklet, shared by both the right and social democracy. Obviously, we voted against it.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 Solidarity is the main value on which the European Union is built. Therefore, even when supporting economic policies, it is important that Member States focus not only on fiscal consolidation, but also on structural reforms in a socially balanced and economically efficient way. Structural reforms in the Member States must be linked not only to growth, but also to the creation of decent jobs, and in these reforms important for the labour market, Member States must bring the flexibility and security necessary to ensure decent wages. As regards the reduction of macroeconomic imbalances characteristic of most Member States, we support the recommendation that increasing growth, employment and poverty rates should be a central priority.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am strongly opposed to yet another report drawn up by the Internal Market Commission, which supports the Commission's approach to trade policies which are, for us, unsuccessful.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the European Semester on the coordination of economic policies: Employment and social aspects in the 2015 Annual Growth Survey, because the report promotes the economic policy that led to the destruction of our country. The Union needs a radical change in its economic outlook, otherwise it will face structural problems.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report focuses on the employment and social aspects of the Annual Growth Survey. It calls for the European Union to shift its policies in this area towards growth-led policies which focus on the creation of quality jobs in Europe in sustainable industries. It also highlights numerous S&D key points in this area, such as the need to have a refocusing of policies so as to achieve the Europe 2020 targets, the fight against inequality, the need to move away from jobless growth, combating youth unemployment, giving SMEs adequate tools with which to operate, voluntary mobility and shifting taxation from labour to capital. The report also makes reference to the need to introduce a minimum income scheme throughout the EU and stresses that the employment and social considerations in the European Semester should be put on a par with macroeconomic ones. We also call for a larger role for the European Parliament in drafting and approval of the AGS and the Economic and Employment Guidelines. Accordingly, I supported adoption of this report in plenary.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. Europe is, and must continue to be, a social market economy, ensuring sustainable growth, in order to provide jobs and well-being to its citizens. Therefore, the need for budgetary consolidation must be compatible with quality and sustainable growth and employment. We cannot forget that 25.1% of the EU population is currently at risk of poverty or social exclusion; we must act through public policies to help families achieve an income level that allows them to live worthily, while reducing the differences between the more and less have. We must recover the concepts of solidarity and effort to re-route Europe on the path of sustainable and equitable growth.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the austerity policies carried out so far have prevented us from achieving the EU's growth, employment and social objectives. Fiscal consolidation must be compatible with sustainable growth, decent employment and the maintenance of the welfare state; therefore, I believe that we must make use of as much flexibility as possible.  I also believe that a plan is needed for SMEs to promote their access to cheap credit and EU innovation and research policies, and that debt restructuring is encouraged to avoid bankruptcy, as SMEs are the backbone of EU job creation.  50% of the jobs created today in Europe do not serve to ensure a decent life for families, so there is an unbearable pocket of labour poverty that must be urgently reversed, as decent wages are essential for social cohesion. Finally, I voted in favour of this report because it calls on the European Commission for an initiative to promote and boost minimum income in all Member States.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the austerity policies carried out so far have prevented us from achieving the EU's growth, employment and social objectives. Fiscal consolidation must be compatible with sustainable growth, decent employment and the maintenance of the welfare state; therefore, I believe that we must make use of as much flexibility as possible. I also believe that a plan is needed for SMEs to promote their access to cheap credit and EU innovation and research policies, and that debt restructuring is encouraged to avoid bankruptcy, as SMEs are the backbone of EU job creation.  50% of the jobs created today in Europe do not serve to ensure a decent life for families, so there is an unbearable pocket of labour poverty that must be urgently reversed, as decent wages are essential for social cohesion. Finally, I voted in favour of this report because it calls on the European Commission for an initiative to promote and boost minimum income in all Member States.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on paragraph 29, split 1, because, while we cannot support calls for the EU to interfere in the tax and criminal law of Member States, we of course do not oppose cracking down on tax fraud and illegal activity.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report and I thank Mr Prieto, because in the face of widespread optimism on the part of the Community institutions, which continue to tell us that there will be growth, there is still no recovery in many Member States. What we are seeing is rather negative growth rates, still very high levels of unemployment, a high percentage of the Union's population at risk of poverty. The gap between the centre and periphery of the Union has widened, marking the failure of cohesion policy, which is the most important European policy for resources used and for political significance.  I agree with the recipe proposed by my colleague. In order to cope with the current socio-economic situation, it is necessary to intervene on the labour market in order to expand human capital. There is a need for long-term investment plans and in strategic sectors. And most importantly, we will never tire of it, we must break these investments away from the calculation of the deficit.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the report because, while it raises and recognises important aspects to take into account in the consolidation of a European Union that takes into account social aspects and the fight against high unemployment rates, such as gender-sensitive, taking more account of the most vulnerable sectors and with greater risks of exclusion , or to improve the conditions of access to credit for SMEs, proposes measures which, in our view, are only detrimental to this situation that is to be improved. It proposes the mobility of workers as a way to combat unemployment, raise the retirement age, continue to delve into structural reforms or align wages with productivity. These are but the measures that have brought us to this situation and we know that implementing the same antisocial measures is not going to lead to different results.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on social aspects as part of the 2015 Annual Growth Review. Firstly, it is essential that the European Semester, which coordinates the economic and budgetary policies of states within the European Union, also take into account the 'social dimension': job creation, education and active labour market policies to increase human capital, youth unemployment, labour mobility,—labour, etc. In particular, I supported the paragraph which calls for and insists on the introduction of an ambitious tax on financial transactions, which we have been calling for for several years now. I also supported the paragraphs calling for a European minimum income. Indeed, from the perspective of a real social Europe, we want to start real discussions on the creation of a genuine European SMIC. On the other hand, I voted against a paragraph which proposed to reverse the budgetary targets of 'public deficit' that were set by the European Union under the Stability and Growth Pact, because the reduction of debts and deficits, which have reached unprecedented sums in Europe, must remain a key objective.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as it calls for the EU to focus on growth-led policies, the creation of quality jobs, support for SMEs and tackling inequality.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report highlights the need for structural reforms in Member States and, as a Member from the United Kingdom, I fully support that call. The structures of the UK should be dismantled so that the people of Scotland can choose the government they want at every election. The Westminster system is broken and full powers must be returned to the people of Scotland.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against the report because, while it raises and recognises important aspects to be taken into account in the consolidation of a European Union that takes into account social aspects and the fight against high unemployment rates, such as gender-sensitive, taking more account of the most vulnerable sectors and with higher risks of exclusion , or to improve the conditions of access to credit for SMEs, proposes measures which, in our view, are only detrimental to this situation that is to be improved. It proposes the mobility of workers as a way to combat unemployment, raise the retirement age, continue to delve into structural reforms or align wages with productivity. These are but the measures that have brought us to this situation and we know that implementing the same antisocial measures will not produce different results.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report focuses on the employment and social aspects of the Annual Growth Survey. The report has some good points, such as the need to have a refocusing of policies so as to achieve the Europe 2020 targets, the fight against inequality, the need to move away from jobless growth and combating youth unemployment. It also stresses that the employment and social considerations in the European Semester should be on a par with macroeconomic ones. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the European Semester of Economic Policy Coordination: Employment and Social Policy Aspects in the 2015 Annual Growth Survey, bearing in mind the great need to boost employment and improve social policies. I support the European Commission's integrated growth approach, which provides for an investment plan for Europe, structural reforms and fiscal reforms. The current downward trend of investment needs to change with common incentives for a sustainable and competitive economy, which entails accompanying measures such as eliminating unnecessary administration and red tape. Cohesion policy instruments play a key role in reducing inequalities within individual European regions when it comes to job creation. In this context, I agree with Parliament's proposal that additional incentives are needed to create new jobs for the long-term unemployed, which also foresee a reduction in the youth unemployment rate. Global socio-economic challenges will be major factors in achieving more effective social policies aimed at ensuring sustainable growth and competitiveness of the European economy.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. The reforms proposed in this report, in the context of the European semester and its supranational objectives, face two pitfalls: the Union's employment policy and its social aspects. The search for flexibility through the free movement of people, against a background of harmonization of employment protection rules, allows the convergence of economies and labour laws without this process being legitimate and without being sure that it is feasible.  The text submitted to the European Parliament is therefore incantatory and based more on political considerations than on real needs.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on paragraph 29, split 1, because, while we cannot support calls for the EU to interfere in the tax and criminal law of Member States, we, of course, do not oppose cracking down on tax fraud and illegal activity.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 For several years now, the European Commission and the Member States have been taking steps to improve the situation on the EU labour market, including through recommendations and actions under the European Semester. That is why I voted in favour of all three reports on economic issues, the labour market and the internal market. However, in the case of sergio Gutiérrez Priety's report, I voted against a number of provisions, including proposals that investment expenditure should not be subject to an excessive deficit procedure and that social indicators should be treated on an equal footing with economic indicators. I believe that increased scrutiny of public finances should continue to be a priority in order to prevent a repeat of past mistakes.  Furthermore, I would like to draw attention to the provisions in Mr Priety's report on so-called social dumping. The term 'social dumping' began to appear populistly in the debate at EU level a few years ago. This is an undefined and incorrectly used phenomenon in relation to competitiveness based on lower labour costs under existing EU law. It is therefore inappropriate to maintain such an expression in EU legal documents.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto's report on the social aspects of the annual growth review as part of the European Semester for economic policy coordination. Through this semester, the European Commission analyses the Member States' budgetary, economic and structural reform plans and makes recommendations for the coming year. This report looks at the social aspects of the European Semester and points to Member States in need of further analysis to determine whether real imbalances exist. The report was adopted by a large majority of 477 votes in person, 203 against and 23 abstentions.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report on the social aspects of the European Semester. The report calls for ambitious economic policies for growth and job creation, support for SMEs, encourage more rational use of European funds and combat unemployment, poverty and social exclusion.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. Although the report makes some good proposals, such as giving Member States more freedom to shape their social policies, it continues to assume that the public sector should be the main driver for generating economic growth and creating jobs. He ignores the fact that the problem is actually due to the economic environment, which is characterised by over-regulation and offers little incentive for the private sector to expand. The report maintains that the public sector needs to be strengthened and a European minimum wage must be introduced. For these reasons, I am opposed to the report that has been presented.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report as it calls for the EU to shift its policies towards growth-led policies focusing on the creation of quality jobs in Europe. It also highlights numerous key points, such as the need to have a refocusing of policies so as to fight against inequality, the need to move away from jobless growth, combating youth unemployment, giving SMEs adequate tools with which to operate, voluntary mobility and shifting taxation from labour to capital.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D)
text: Written. As can be seen from the recitals in this report, the fixing of salaries falls within the competence of the Member States. A European minimum wage is not in line with the Danish labour market model and, against this background, we are critical of all actions and calls that could potentially promote the EU's influence in the setting of wages in Denmark.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am very pleased that it must now become clear to the majority of the EP that the policies of the Hungarian government are increasingly to be followed. In particular, public support for children's meals highlighted in Section 80 (school) is Hungary good example and practice that Hungary is explicitly pursuing in the fight against child poverty, recognising its importance. The amendments I tabled and adopted by the majority of the EMPL clearly adopted the Hungarian Government's approach. The background to this is that Hungary has doubled the budget (from 29 billion) in the last 3 years and the Hungarian government is now spending more than HUF 60 billion this year. Starting in 2016, nurseries and preschoolers at risk of poverty will be 100% covered.  This is all the more interesting because, while in 2009-2010 the left-wing government initially sought to reduce the amount spent on children's meals by 2/3, saying that "there is no substantial need for additional resources", the right-wing-civic government made more concrete efforts both to combat child poverty and to help foreign currency creditors or even to reduce overheads, helping millions of Hungarian families.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – The virtues of the proposal include emphasis on employment and social aspects, people-centredness, harmonisation of wage regulation and criticality against austerity. The proposal is not to blame for the unsustainability of the liberal market economy theory and the resulting practice of inhumanity and anti-socialism. Because what kind of world owns 48% of the wealth? What kind of world where wars are being launched for profit? How far can this road go? We don't have another Earth, what do the rich do with their wealth if they destroy this planet?

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of Mr De Clercq's report. Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto as it contains useful guidelines for applying a responsible investment policy that can guarantee employment growth at the same time. The European Union must commit itself to promoting a model of a social market economy that can guarantee sustainable growth, as well as ensuring the creation of jobs for European citizens and, above all, for our young people.

name: Jérôme Lavrilleux (PPE)
text: In writing. As I had already had the opportunity to do so in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I voted in favour of the GUTIERREZ PRIETO report on the coordination of economic policies in the context of the European semester. This report focuses on the social issues that should guide the EU and Member States' annual policy on growth and employment. In particular, it highlights the need to take social indicators into account and to promote the creation of decent jobs in the context of sustainable and solid growth. I regret, however, that he does not insist more on the absolute need to implement the structural reforms that are crucial in order to achieve the economic and social objectives.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report endorses the system of budgetary supervision which allows the Commission not only to audit budgets and to ask for changes before they are even adopted by national parliaments, but also to push for further cuts or reforms if the proposed budgets do not suit it.  I reject this process of increasing the reduction in wages and pensions, raising the retirement age and continuing privatisations and liberalisations with the sole result of the piece of public services and social rights being undermined. It is also in the context of the European semester that the Commission regularly denounces the CDI and the monopolies of SNCF or EDF in France.  While I have supported proposals that can improve the social dimension, I am no less critical of this tool which allows the European institutions to dictate their policies to states in defiance of popular sovereignty.  As a result, I voted against these three reports.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. The supranational objectives of the European semester are here in proposals for structural reforms that refer to two pitfalls of European employment policy and social aspects. Firstly, it is a search for greater flexibility in the labour market in a context of free movement of workers, as well as a fundamental trend towards the harmonization of employment protection rules. The convergence of economies and labour market frameworks is not based on any legitimacy or the possible feasibility of these proposals. The text submitted to the European Parliament is therefore incantatory and based more on political considerations than on real needs.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. A report based on 4 parts was raised: (1) ambitious economic policies for growth, quality job creation and the fight against deflation;  (2) labour market reforms to increase growth potential, human capital and productivity; (3) a decisive request for eu convergence and social dimension; and 4) strengthening the democratic legitimacy of the European Semester. The rapporteur of the Spanish socialist delegation has managed to maintain most of his initial proposals, and the Group's priorities such as: 1) that the AUsterity policy carried out so far by the EU has impeded the EU's growth, employment and social objectives; (2) that 50% of the employment created today in Europe does not serve to ensure a dignified life for families; (3) that Juncker's investment plan is not sufficient to stimulate growth; 4) that decent and sufficient wages are essential for social cohesion.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it does not imply any change in the neoliberal orientation of the economic governance framework. The Annual Prospective Study is the European Commission's economic study that starts the entire European Semester process. This report seeks to include social and employment indicators in the Study to improve its quality. However, this inclusion is superficial in nature and does not link these indicators to the recommendations; it is a mere decoration that will not reform the framework of economic governance at all. A real review in this regard should link and force the Commission to reformulate its recommendations and to bet on binding social objectives, overcoming the monetarist logic of its policies. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Thomas Mann (PPE)
text: Writing. With the Annual Growth Survey for 2015, we are proving that the European Union is capable of acting with concrete measures for all those particularly affected by the financial crisis: marginalised, unemployed, hopeless. The Prieto draft report was marked by pessimism; the economic and social situation has been portrayed as bleak. This applies to some, not all, EU Member States. In order to strike the necessary balance, I have tabled 33 amendments, almost all of which have been accepted or incorporated into compromises. There are some of the claims in the report that cannot be shared by the PPE-DE, such as the introduction of social stabilisers, which indirectly call for Europe-wide unemployment insurance. What sounds like solidarity is, in fact, a transfer of billions. Collective bargaining is still conducted by social partners in Member States, not at European level! Nor is it true that the austerity measures imposed by the EU have led to a deterioration in employment conditions and the social situation across Europe. Our Member States have had different experiences! Where reforms have taken place – in Spain, Portugal, Ireland – there is a legitimate prospect of growth and sustainability.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report because the European Semester is an institutional way of limiting the national sovereignty of the Euro area Member States. The parliaments of the eurozone countries now lack sovereign rights in shaping national budgets, as the Eurogroup, an unelected body, has made them a tight corset by imposing mercely austerity.  The dominant element today in relation to the European Semester is the huge democratic deficit it has created in the name of reducing budget deficits. Thus, through an undemocratic institutional framework, the old political world of Europe is trying to chain the people and impose on them the policy of mercelial austerity, poverty and social exclusion. These are also very clearly expressed in this report, which I voted against.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. Dominique Martin voted against this report, as he had already done in the EMPL committee. The very principle of the European semester runs counter to the sovereignty of the Member States by imposing impossible/difficult recommendations on them and ongoing monitoring by Brussels on how they manage their affairs. We oppose this interference in the national affairs of the Member States.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report which welcomes the fact that the new policy mix adds investment to the previous priorities of fiscal consolidation and structural reforms. It considers, nevertheless, that the Annual Growth Survey (AGS) should pay greater concern to aggregate demand and its connection to wage increases and social inequalities. It underlines that the top priority when it comes to reducing macro-imbalances should not be to increase current account surpluses, but rather to raise the growth, investment and employment rates, and to reduce the poverty rate.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with the report on the European Semester for the Coordination of Economic, Employment and Social Policies in the 2015 Annual Growth Survey. As Europe's economic recovery remains fragile at the moment, growth-friendly budgetary consolidation remains extremely important. Work to improve social and economic policies can lead to multiple positive results: both a rapprochement with the Europe 2020 objectives and a move away from the risks of stagnation and long-term deflation. There is also a need for strong action on the figure of 25.1% of the EU population currently at risk of poverty and social exclusion. We need development and policies that best support the economy and allow for a general recovery, an increase in productivity and a regaining of confidence.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union must commit itself to implementing a model of social economy, and market economy, capable of ensuring sustainable growth.  I thought it appropriate to support the Gutiérrez Prieto report with a vote in favour, because I believe that it contains the right guidelines for a responsible investment policy.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. On the employment and social aspects of the 2015 Annual Growth Survey, I voted against the draft resolution on the European Semester for the coordination of economic policy. Despite some of the report's good proposals, such as giving the Member States more freedom to implement their social policies, the report as a whole is not what I want. The state cannot be the main driver of the fight against unemployment, since the creation of high-quality jobs, the fight against deflation and the increase in growth potential do not depend solely on the state.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report notes an alarming situation on the employment front with 25 million people out of work in the EU. It therefore sets out the European Parliament's recommendations on 'employment and social aspects'. As usual, the report urges us to pursue fiscal consolidation and structural reforms. It is about reducing the tax burden on work, raising the retirement age, aligning wages with productivity... and other liberal litany that has proved their failure. I'm voting against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. The euro area recession came to an end in numerical terms in the second quarter of 2013, but annual growth in the euro area remains fragile in 2014, and unemployment remains at a very high level. Sustainable growth needs to be significantly strengthened in order to be seen as a long-term recovery that can set the pace for mitigating the EU's socio-economic challenges.  Only with investment capacity will incentives for economic growth be possible. Only the budget surplus and the budgetary balance of MS will free up the funds needed for the investments that will lead to sustained growth in the euro area, as well as the fight against unemployment, especially that of young people.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report expressed the need for increased democratic legitimacy of the European Semester. If the EU is to have effective governance of the Single Market, it would be beneficial for national parliaments as well as social partners and civil society organisations to be able to play a role in the formulation, monitoring and implementation of economic and social priorities in the European Semester.  Therefore I voted in favour of this report.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Quality education leads to a skilled European workforce to compete internationally. Young people are the most mobile workers in the European Union. They must be integrated into the labour market in order to ensure that they have a future that lives up to their expectations. Meeting this challenge requires more investment in education and training budgets (1/5 of 20-24 year olds have not completed higher secondary education), as well as a better flow of information in synergy with the world of work.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The employment and social aspects of the European Semester and Annual Growth Survey are fundamental in order to put Europe back on track. We need to ensure that they are given adequate importance, moving forward. Therefore I voted in favour of the European Semester for economic policy coordination: employment and social aspects in the Annual Growth Survey 2015. However, I did not support the paragraphs calling for adoption of a more ambitious financial transaction tax.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Semester has become, in a relatively short period of time, part of Europe's institutional culture and, moreover, is increasingly part of national policy-making culture. The previous open method of coordination, one of the most direct ancestors of the European Semester, was treated more or less as a joke; it was an exercise for academics more than practitioners. Now we can see how very powerful Member States - whether they like it or not - take the European Semester seriously and explain and defend their choices. Even when they try to obtain exceptions from the rules, they still explain themselves in relation to those rules, which are thus confirmed and strengthened. We now have an enriched process, with a clearer social dimension (Juncker's 'social triple A' is a great metaphor and, it is to be hoped, much more than that) and decent flexibility with the 'Moscovici package'. It is almost mystical how Europe, painfully, finds resources to fix itself after crises.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that education and training create jobs in addition to investment: capital holders invest and create new jobs where there is a sufficient mass of highly skilled, high-quality, high-value-added workers. I therefore consider it extremely important to develop human capital through education, training, active labour market policy, to solve financing problems for small and medium-sized enterprises, to tackle worryingly high youth unemployment, and to support research, development and innovation in order to increase productivity.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Semester should take a decisive strategic position to leverage investment, job creation and new periods of economic growth in the European Union. I voted in favour of this report because It recognised that Member States implementing structural reforms have been able to regain their competitiveness in the global market, as well as because they consider it important to boost private investment and facilitate access to finance for SMEs. I also believe that there should be a more efficient and efficient use of European public resources, and that these funds should be channelled into projects that enhance employment, especially young people, and the competitiveness of enterprises.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. Fiscal consolidation in euro area countries is far from over and EU leaders continue to promote deadly austerity. This prevents any resumption of growth and any decline in unemployment. Indeed, since the average budget multiplier is greater than 1, any additional austerity measures reduce the GDP of the states.  The European Union is relying only on the fall in the euro and the price of oil in order to hope for a recovery. But it may not last.  The Youth Employment Initiative and the Youth Guarantee will not solve these problems, nor will those related to low worker qualifications and training deficits.  While the unemployment rate in the euro area stands at 11.5% against "only" 7.3% outside the euro area, the EU refuses to open any real debates on the single currency and on intelligent protectionism, the only ones capable of pulling eurozone countries out of the current slump.  I have therefore decided to vote against this text.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the social aspects of the European Semester. As part of the European Semester, the European Commission analyses the Member States' fiscal, economic and structural reform plans and makes recommendations for the coming year. The report reiterates the need for Member States to carry out real structural reforms, as they are the condition for the return of long-term competitiveness. It also draws attention to the difficulties of financing SMEs and calls on Member States to remove all unnecessary administrative burdens on smes, which account for more than 90% of European jobs.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With this report we support the integrated approach to growth recently adopted by the European Commission and based on three main pillars, namely: a new investment plan for Europe, structural reforms and fiscal responsibility. Indeed, we are calling for an ambitious economic policy, which will indeed remain within the existing rules of the Stability and Growth Pact, but which is at the same time capable of stimulating intelligent and inclusive growth and creating better and more sustainable jobs. We also call on the Commission to take urgent action to combat social dumping, numerous frauds and the fight against tax evasion. We express, once again, our deep concern at the limited role that the European Parliament, national parliaments and social partners and civil society organisations play in formulating, monitoring and implementing the economic and social priorities of the European Semester. We therefore reiterate our call for greater and more structured involvement of civil society and the social partners at EU and national level, in order to improve the legitimacy of the European Semester process through the development of democratically recognised concrete guidelines.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In his report, Mr De Clercq said that the Commission was not in a position to take a decision on this report. Gutiérrez Prieto gave a positive opinion on the annual growth survey which starts the cycle of coordinating member states' economic policies.  This year's analysis has as its central theme to firmly restore Europe to a sustainable path of economic growth and job creation.  As part of this approach, the report recommends that the Commission pursue an economic and social policy based on three main pillars: 1) the revival of investment, 2) a renewed commitment to structural reforms and 3) the pursuit of budgetary responsibility.  In the light of the above, I have decided to support this report because I believe that an ambitious expansionist economic and fiscal policy, within the existing rules of the Stability and Growth Pact, is essential to stimulate smart, sustainable and inclusive growth and to create better and more sustainable jobs. I also believe that the proposed approach is the right way forward, but I would like to point out that it is essential to support the efforts of the Member States to ensure not only fiscal consolidation, but also structural reforms in a socially balanced and economically efficient and sustainable way.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to the figures recorded, most recently in 2013, the socio-economic situation of the European Union is a rather sensitive one. In this context, long-term unemployment at EU level has one of the highest levels, i.e. 5.1% of the workforce, while 25.1% of the Union population is at risk of poverty or social exclusion.  I voted for this report because it brings a number of extremely necessary measures for post-crisis economic, financial and social rehabilitation. Thus, it is worth noting the ambitious economic policies for growth, creating quality jobs and combating deflation, restoring funding for SMEs in order to stimulate private investment, making more efficient use of funds, implementing new policies in the field of education, but also health, poverty reduction and social exclusion, etc., all of which are aimed at contributing to the achievement of the EU objective. , i.e. decent living conditions for all its citizens.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported and voted in favour of this report because it brings to the fore the serious impasse in which the European Union economy lies, which translates into small and unsupported economic declines or increases, with extremely serious effects on the unemployment rate, poverty and social exclusion. The report shows that economic disparities between Member States have increased and the number of unemployed at EU level has reached a historic figure of 25 million people. In this regard, the rapporteur calls on the Commission, the Member States and the European Investment Bank to rethink and recalibrate the funds allocated for strategic investments. The fact that the EU chose to respond to the crisis and the lack of productivity by reducing costs has taken us away from the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, which involved building economies on a sustainable, sustainable basis with investments that create quality jobs. It is important that these investments are made in areas where they propagate and create jobs, and investments in human capital are, in my opinion, the ones with the greatest contribution both in the medium term and especially in the long term, being the only ones that can ensure a sustained growth of the EU economy.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the employment and social aspects of the European Semester and the 2015 Growth Survey. The EU's economic and social situation remains weak and the economic recovery remains uncertain. The EU must continue to improve economic and social policies with a view to achieving the Europe 2020 targets as soon as possible.  Smart, sustainable and inclusive growth must be stimulated and better and sustainable jobs must be created. Solidarity is the fundamental value on which the European Union is founded.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. The Resolution on Employment and Social Aspects of the European Semester highlights the need to change economic policies in order to achieve the objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy. The crisis has significantly increased the levels of poverty, social inequality and social exclusion, especially in states where financial assistance programmes have been implemented, such as Spain. We need economic and structural reforms that are capable of integrating and addressing social and employment challenges. That is why, because of the holistic approach to the text, that I have decided to vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I believe that the employment and social dimensions must be given more attention in the Annual Growth Survey. In particular, it should be determined how the social approach will manifest itself in the investment plan and in the exercise of fiscal responsibility. Ambitious economic policies to promote smart, sustainable and inclusive growth and create better sustainable jobs should include employment and social aspects. Future investments should be assessed not only from an economic but also social point of view. It is necessary to ensure that the most vulnerable members of society across the EU have access to the labour market and receive sufficient income. In this context, I believe that the Commission should step up its efforts to ensure greater social convergence between Member States and to achieve poverty reduction targets. The EU must apply common minimum wage standards and establish an EU minimum wage policy. In addition, it is necessary to better involve the social partners and civil society in order to improve the quality of jobs and ensure sustainable inclusion in the labour market.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on paragraph 29, split 1, because while we can't support calls for the EU to interfere in the tax and criminal law of Member States, we of course do not oppose cracking down on tax fraud and illegal activity.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Whereas Europe must commit itself to a social market economy model that guarantees sustainable growth to ensure future jobs rather than debts for the generation; that the economic and social environment in the EU continues to be bleak and that, according to the Commission's autumn 2014 economic forecasts, the economic recovery remains fragile; that the sustained pace of budgetary consolidation imposed during the economic crisis has hampered Member States in achieving the Europe 2020 targets, which shows that budgetary policies should be differentiated and adapted to the situation in each Member State; stressing the need for structural reforms in the Member States; Welcoming the Integrated Approach to Growth adopted by the Commission, based on the three main pillars, calling on the Commission to ensure investment in economically weaker regions suffering from high unemployment, I voted in favour.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. Fiscal consolidation in euro area countries is far from over and EU leaders continue to promote deadly austerity. It prevents any resumption of growth and any decline in unemployment. Indeed, since the average budget multiplier is greater than 1, any additional austerity measures reduce the GDP of the states.  The EU is relying only on the fall in the euro and the price of oil in order to hope for a recovery. But it may not last.  The Youth Employment Initiative and the Youth Guarantee will not solve these problems, nor will those related to low worker qualifications and training deficits.  While the unemployment rate in the euro area stands at 11.5% against "only" 7.3% outside the euro area, the EU refuses to open any real debates on the single currency and on intelligent protectionism, the only ones capable of pulling eurozone countries out of the current slump.  I have therefore decided to vote against this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ In October 2014, the IMF estimated that the possibility of a recession in the eurozone had increased and would be between 35% and 40% by the end of the year. The unemployment rate remains at historically high levels with nearly 25 million people out of work in the EU. Long-term unemployment is at worryingly high levels and 12 million people are out of work for more than one year (4% more than last year). Youth unemployment rates have not decreased significantly (they only decreased by 1.9% compared to 2013), reaching an EU average of 21.2%. 75% of the long-term unemployed in the EU are under the age of 35. Socio-economic imbalances between Member States have increased further. The disparities in unemployment between the core and the periphery have increased from 3.5% in 2000 to 10% in 2013. Labour market reforms in many Member States have failed to reduce the number of precarious jobs - with temporary jobs representing 50% of job creation in 2014. All this data shows that economic and monetary policies so far have not been adequate, especially when analysing their impact on social and employment policies, where Europe needs structural reforms so that our most educated generation does not become a lost generation.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Semester, which began in 2010, sets out an annual cycle of economic policy coordination with a detailed analysis of Member States' plans in terms of budgetary, macroeconomic and structural reforms.  This resolution concerns the social and employment aspects of the 2015 Annual Growth Survey, prepared by the Commission under the European Semester, which aims to support growth and jobs in parallel with fiscal consolidation. Indeed, the EU's economic and social context continues to inspire concerns, and according to the Commission's economic forecasts for autumn 2014, the economic recovery will remain fragile. Indeed, the unemployment rate remains at a historically high level, with almost 25 million unemployed people in the EU, a quarter of Europeans are at risk of poverty, and underemployment and precariously have reached historic highs.  The EU therefore needs to continue to improve its economic and social policies in order to achieve the europe 2020 objectives by promoting investment and structural reforms that increase economic competitiveness in a socially responsible manner.  I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, as it advocates three pillars for the European Semester: investment, structural reforms and fiscal responsibility, supported by a market economy model with strong social concerns. Only in this way is sustainable growth guaranteed, in order to transmit to the next generation better job opportunities rather than a heavy legacy, by responsible for debts they have not committed. It should not be forgotten that it is only by promoting reproductive investment that we will be stimulating sustainable job creation, enabling real investment in human capital, professional mobility, research and innovation, which are essential to expanding the EU's economic potential, thereby bringing prosperity to the peoples of Europe. Europe is a Europe of regions, and the European project should leave no one behind. We must therefore continue to pay particular attention to the outermost regions, to the less developed regions, so that we have real social and territorial cohesion in a Europe at just one speed. Member States also have to do their part by eliminating unnecessary administrative burdens and bureaucracy that discourages entrepreneurship, self-employed people, the creation of start-ups, Micro, SMEs which are the catalysts for economic growth, innovation, employment and social integration.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination shows that the euro area is still struggling with the consequences of the economic slowdown that began in 2008. With regard to social aspects and employment, it is important for the Commission to ensure investment in economically disadvantaged regions. Investment should be for training and education, combating poverty, job creation and combating unemployment, support for SMEs and research.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the austerity policies carried out so far have prevented us from achieving the EU's growth, employment and social objectives. Fiscal consolidation must be compatible with sustainable growth, decent employment and the maintenance of the welfare state; therefore, I believe that we must make use of as much flexibility as possible. I also believe that a plan is needed for SMEs to promote their access to cheap credit and EU innovation and research policies, and that debt restructuring is encouraged to avoid bankruptcy, as SMEs are the backbone of EU job creation.  50% of the jobs created today in Europe do not serve to ensure a decent life for families, so there is an unbearable pocket of labour poverty that must be urgently reversed, as decent wages are essential for social cohesion. Finally, I voted in favour of this report because it calls on the European Commission for an initiative to promote and boost minimum income in all Member States.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report on the social aspect of the European semester.  It is essential that Europe focuss on reviving growth and jobs and continue its efforts in this area. Indeed, labour market reforms in many Member States have not reduced precariousness. Therefore, and through this text, we call for greater flexibility in the implementation of reforms by Member States in difficult economic and financial situations, with the aim of ensuring that the measures taken by Member States are compatible with job creation, social responsibility and growth.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote against it because the report criticises the negative impact on employment of 'austerity', but only because it is so obvious that it can no longer be concealed. In fact, the text reiterates its support for the Commission's approach based on three pillars (relaunching investment; structural reforms; austerity), which is like saying: I cure the flu by inoculating other pathogenic viruses in the patient.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against the report because, while it raises and recognises important aspects to be taken into account in the consolidation of a European Union that takes into account social aspects and the fight against high unemployment rates, such as gender-sensitive, taking more account of the most vulnerable sectors and with higher risks of exclusion , or to improve the conditions of access to credit for SMEs, proposes measures which, in our view, are only detrimental to this situation that is to be improved. It proposes the mobility of workers as a way to combat unemployment, raise the retirement age, continue to delve into structural reforms or align wages with productivity. These are nothing more than the measures that have brought us to this situation and we know that implementing the same antisocial measures will not produce different results.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the social component of the European semester for the coordination of economic policies. The European semester is a very important tool, created in response to the recent economic and financial crisis and the sovereign debt crisis, so that Europe never again finds itself in a situation as critical as the one from which it is barely recovering.  In concrete terms, the European Semester is an annual cycle of economic policy coordination, through which the European Commission analyses the Member States' fiscal, economic and structural reform plans and then makes recommendations for the coming year. In parallel to this report, the Commission is also publishing its report on the Alert Mechanism, the heart of which is a scoreboard composed of indicators, including social indicators, which allows the Commission to determine whether real imbalances exist in a Member State and to recommend the measures and reforms to be put in place to address them. In this exercise, if compliance with current budgetary rules is essential, the Commission should also take into account the social context of Member States in difficult financial situations.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (NI)
text: In writing. This report is based on the fact that the main economic policy directions must be decided in Brussels. I oppose it in defence of democracy and the social and political rights of our citizens.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, economic growth is created by companies and businesses are creating new jobs as a result: it is therefore important to have an employment-friendly environment in Europe where people love to start a business and implement their business idea. To support this, financial start-up can come from the relevant EU programmes, for example through micro-credits. Member States can also support the shift towards more entrepreneurship: efficient administration is just as much a part of this as simple and fast company registrations.  However, stable public finances are also important. We must therefore keep reminding us of compliance with the Stability and Growth Pact. The Stability and Growth Pact prevents member states from over-indebtedness. This will create financial room for manoeuvre in national budgets. The left side of the House is inventing new exceptions almost every day as to why something should not be included in the calculation of budget deficits. We cannot allow this to happen under any circumstances.  I therefore call on the Commission to remain visible as a common thread for the future country-specific recommendations in the European Semester. Thank you very much!

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it does not imply any change in the neoliberal orientation of the economic governance framework. The Annual Prospective Study is the European Commission's economic study that starts the entire European Semester process. This report seeks to include social and employment indicators in the Study to improve its quality. However, this inclusion is superficial in nature and does not link these indicators to the recommendations; it is a mere decoration that will not reform the framework of economic governance at all. A real review in this regard should link and force the Commission to reformulate its recommendations and to bet on binding social objectives, overcoming the monetarist logic of its policies. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since 2011, the European Semester has been allowing Member States to coordinate economic policies and efforts to promote growth, employment and investment in the EU. I believe that the report adopted today provides clear guidelines not only for initiating the necessary structural reforms of the labour market, but also for drawing attention to the importance of the social dimension of European policies for growth. I would, however, be more cautious about the introduction of a minimum income, which is explicitly referred to at various points in the report. Despite achieving the objective of the Europe 2020 strategy of reducing people at risk or in poverty and social exclusion by at least 20 million by the end of the decade, I believe that it is primarily up to the Member States to carefully consider the most appropriate means of guaranteeing their citizens a decent job and standard of living. I believe that it is essential to safeguard the principle of subsidiarity and thus ensure that the specificities of the Member States and their socio-economic contexts are taken into account in the definition of welfare policies.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: employment and social aspects in the Annual Growth Survey 2015. The report emphasises that Europe must be committed to the model of the social market economy, ensuring sustainable growth in order to provide the next generation with jobs instead of debts.  It must also be noted that the European Social Fund, with the Youth Guarantee, and the Youth Employment Initiative have to be used fully and correctly to finance sustainable projects in order to fight unemployment, in particular youth unemployment. The share of young people not in education, employment or training (NEETs) has remained high. This is unacceptable and measures must be taken to tackle this issue.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ Citizens need to be provided with a dignified life from their work. Nearly 25 million people in the European Union are currently out of work, while 12 million have been unemployed for more than a year. The most vulnerable group on the European labour market are young people whose unemployment rate stands at 21.2%.  Croatia, with more than 300,000 unemployed, almost half of them young, ranks high in the rankings, after Spain and Greece. Annually, 12,000 people leave Croatia due to the lack of creative solutions and public policies that will keep them and ensure their worthy and safe existence. Green local jobs are the best tool to counteract the aforementioned negative trend. Applying the principle of circular economy in public policy-making would create a whole range of new jobs and ensure sustainable growth of Croatia and the European Union.   The great potential for economic growth and the creation of quality jobs lies in the transition to a Green Economy that employs young people, who are the most vulnerable group, which is why it is essential to financially steer SMEs towards green growth. As part of the Integrated Approach of the European Semester, Member States need to implement structural reforms and promote financial support programmes for young people and businesses, such as Horizon 2020 or COSME, whose potential should be used to create a stronger entrepreneurial culture in the European Union.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing – I supported a report that very really mentioned the EU's employment problems. Almost 25 million people are unemployed, long-term unemployment has increased by 4%. Also, the youth unemployment rate has not fallen significantly. Also alarming is the figure, which says that up to 75% of the long-term unemployed are under the age of 35.
