Ambitious economic policies for growth, the creation of quality jobs and the fight against deflation are the starting points for this situation. Investment plans must include promoting sustainable growth, creating quality jobs and promoting social progress. Funds from EU funds must be used more effectively for education and active labour policies designed to develop human capital. Member States must adapt their employment policies to support the long-term unemployed, young people, the elderly unemployed, women and other priority groups most affected by the crisis, such as people with disabilities, including lifelong learning and training, as well as to combat low levels of education.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Annual Growth Survey gives us an insight into the economic and social situation in Europe and sets out priority policies and measures for the EU for the whole of the year ahead. While we have made some improvements in the economic and social situation through various measures in recent years, the unemployment rate remains at historically high levels, especially when it comes to young people. Poverty and social exclusion are also at a high level. I supported rapporteur Prieto's report on the European Semester of Economic Policy Coordination because I think it is time for a responsible economic policy for growth, creating quality jobs and fighting deflation. It is also time for reforms aimed at increasing growth potential, human capital and productivity. The EU must continue to improve its economic and social policies in order to achieve the Objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy as soon as possible.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the employment and social aspects in the Annual Growth Survey 2015 as it sets out what more can be done at EU level to help Member States return to higher growth levels.  Specifically, it proposes that the process be streamlined, with a view to increasing political ownership, accountability and acceptance of the process, to strengthening its credibility and comparability across Member States and to improving the implementation of country-specific recommendations.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - Europe must be committed to a social market economy model, which guarantees sustainable growth to provide jobs to the next generation instead of debts. I welcome the Commission's integrated approach to growth, which is based on three main pillars: the Investment Plan for Europe, structural reforms and fiscal responsibility. We call for an ambitious, expansionary economic and fiscal policy, within the existing rules of the Stability and Growth Pact, which will boost smart, sustainable and inclusive growth and create quality jobs. That's why I supported this report.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: I did not support the proposal in writing ‒ because it represents intentions that would very fundamentally damage employment in the European Union. These include, for example, the intention to create a common European framework for the minimum wage, a proposal for the introduction of a basic income in the EU, as well as other initiatives.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: employment and social aspects in the 2015 Annual Growth Survey. Europe must be committed to a social market economy model that delivers sustainable growth in order to provide jobs for future generations, not debt. I agree with the report that Member States play a major role in the formulation of employment policies, including youth employment policies, and that these measures are best implemented at national level. There is an urgent need to tackle high unemployment. the unemployment rate is still higher than ever, with almost 25 million people unemployed in the EU.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The report promotes an economic policy that has led to the destruction of our country. The European Union needs a radical change in its economic vision, because otherwise it will face structural problems.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the employment and social aspects of the 2015 Annual Growth Survey. The European Semester, which has been in place since 2010, is an important tool for maintaining and improving the Competitiveness of the Union, but it can only work well if employment aspects are taken into account with sufficient emphasis in its application.  It is not enough to focus on protecting jobs in the context of structural reforms that have sometimes been misguided, but we also need to ensure that the newly created jobs guarantee a high standard of living, ensuring a decent living. The report also deals with these issues in detail, among other things, which is why I was able to support it.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Mr Gutiérrez's text. We must be aware of the link between fiscal responsibility and the need to strengthen investment and structural reforms in the Member States, in the context of the Stability and Growth Pact.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. The resolution on the 2015 Annual Growth Review allows the European Parliament to decide on the state of the Union and make economic policy recommendations for its Member States.  It is regrettable that some of the proposals made by the right have been incorporated into the final compromise. I can quote among other things: - The demand for reduction in labour costs as an element of competitiveness, in paragraph 5, even as deflation threatens in Europe.  - In paragraph 13, austerity programmes are welcomed and euro area states are encouraged to cut their budgets, even as all the countries under the troika's programme have seen their economies plunge, their debts soar and their social programmes undermined.   - The resolution encourages, in paragraph 25, the flexibilization of the labour market, a well-known liberal.  These are proposals that I consider fundamentally unfair, destructive, ineffective and conducive to the continuation of the crisis in Europe. So I voted against this resolution.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I think that social policies and social structural reforms are an important of the policy mix, particularly in a time of big changes in economic relations and high levels of indebtness in public finances of many Member States.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the report because, while it raises and recognises important aspects to take into account in the consolidation of a European Union that takes into account social aspects and the fight against high unemployment rates, such as taking into account the gender aspect, taking more account of the most vulnerable and risky sectors of exclusion or improving the conditions of access to credit for SMEs. , proposes measures which, in our view, are only detrimental to this situation which is to be improved. It proposes the mobility of workers as a way to combat unemployment, raise the retirement age, continue to delve into structural reforms or align wages with productivity. These are just the measures that have brought us to this situation and we know that implementing the same antisocial measures is not going to lead to different results.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I abstained in this report, even though it contains a lot of positive elements, because it shares the 'three pillars approach', which I do not share, as structural reforms and fiscal consolidation is a combination that delves into recession. Moreover, it also argues that any expansive policy must fall within the existing rules of the Stability and Growth Pact, which my group does not share.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the austerity policies carried out so far have prevented us from achieving the EU's growth, employment and social objectives. Fiscal consolidation must be compatible with sustainable growth, decent employment and the maintenance of the welfare state; therefore, I believe that we must make use of as much flexibility as possible. I also believe that a plan is needed for SMEs to promote their access to cheap credit and EU innovation and research policies, and that debt restructuring is encouraged to avoid bankruptcy, as SMEs are the backbone of EU job creation.  50% of the jobs created today in Europe do not serve to ensure a decent life for families, so there is an unbearable pocket of labour poverty that must be urgently reversed, as decent wages are essential for social cohesion. Finally, I voted in favour of this report because it calls on the European Commission for an initiative to promote and boost minimum income in all Member States.

name: o Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. This resolution on employment and social aspects in the annual growth survey could have been an excellent opportunity to call into question a model of economic policy coordination and crisis management that has proved to be completely counterproductive and unsustainable, especially from a social point of view. Unfortunately, over and above the noble declarations of intent, this resolution shows that it wants to support the same approach that has clearly failed to promote intelligent, sustainable and inclusive growth. Although, in fact, there are positive and acceptable points in the report, such as the attention paid to small and medium-sized enterprises, the problem of inequalities and social stabilisers, there is still too much conviction in the report that the strategy to take Europe out of the crisis must be based on recipes from the past, namely the combination of private capital, structural reforms and fiscal consolidation (austerity laws). Furthermore, our proposal to introduce an income of European citizenship, which would be an extraordinary economic manoeuvre to revive the real economy and facilitate the professional re-employment of millions of people who continue to lose their jobs, has not been incorporated into the resolution.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it does not imply any change in the neoliberal orientation of the economic governance framework. The Annual Prospective Study is the European Commission's economic study that starts the entire European Semester process. This report seeks to include social and employment indicators in the Study to improve its quality. However, this inclusion is superficial in nature and does not link these indicators to the recommendations; it is a mere decoration that will not reform the framework of economic governance at all. A real review in this regard should link and force the Commission to reformulate its recommendations and to bet on binding social objectives, overcoming the monetarist logic of its policies. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ My Socialist colleagues and I voted in favour of this report because it welcomes the Commissionʼs new approach to economic policy with focus on growth and investment. The report also insists that reforms required from Member States must be socially balanced and growth-friendly and that surplus countries must do more to relaunch growth in Europe.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The European semester is nothing more than one of the translations of the budget treaty into European law. That he recognizes the consequences in terms of unemployment and precariousness is therefore the least of it, but he draws no lesson from it and even suggests continuing on the same path. Symptomatic of this hypocrisy, a paragraph recognises that Member States, whose budgets are being cut by austerity, are not in a position to protect and promote the crucial sectors of education, research and innovation. However, the majority of MEPs refused to draw the consequences by excluding them from the calculation of public deficits. The same goes for social dumping, which we want to recognise if we exclude the fight against wage dumping. The only downside to this is that the European Parliament has once again reaffirmed its position in favour of an 'ambitious tax on financial transactions'.  So I voted against this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 We believe that the economic and social context in the EU remains bleak, and that, according to the Commission's economic forecasts for autumn 2014, the economic recovery remains fragile. Growth rates have been negative in the euro area in the last two years. We regret that the European Semester has no social and employment objectives and is not aligned with the social principles enshrined in the Treaties. We see no more determined efforts to guide and coordinate EU policies to foster better growth and job creation. Thus, without new policies, the situation will continue to weigh on families and workers.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. The European Semester for the coordination of economic policy is, in my view, the demand for more government and less private accountability. It sees fiscal consolidation on the part of the Member States as necessary, but does not want to accept spending cuts. That is because of this, I have decided against this report.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ My Socialist colleagues and I voted in favour of this report because it welcomes the Commission's new approach to economic policy, with focus on sustainable growth and investment. The report also insists that reforms required from Member States must be socially balanced and growth-friendly and that surplus countries must do more to relaunch growth in Europe.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on the basis of the commitments reached in the IMCO Commission. These reflect the S&D Group's priorities for the internal market pillar, highlighting the need to revitalize the European economy through better and fairer functioning of the single market, capable of boosting sustainable growth and social cohesion, creating quality jobs and increasing competitiveness based on R&D investments, training and training.  It also reflects the need to target investments in European re-industrialization and strategic growth sectors such as the digital single market, with an emphasis on the essential interconnection between high levels of network penetration and high levels of ICT skills for citizens and businesses. The report includes a key point for the S&D Group and calls for renewing efforts to combat fraud, evasion and tax avoidance, as well as to build good fiscal governance and improve fiscal coordination, in order to avoid distortions of unfair competition and market and to ensure equal opportunities in the single market.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it deepens the development of the single market through the framework of economic governance. This report is aimed at integrating the implementation of the single market as a requirement within the framework of the objectives of the Stability and Growth Pact. This results in direct attacks on the public sector, considering it a barrier to the single market, giving a political impetus to the implementation of the energy union and insisting on the elimination of public aid to avoid market distortions, etc. The report seeks to condition the deficit objectives of the economic governance framework on the implementation of the internal market, which directly erodes the possibility of governing against neoliberal policies. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. This report is a concentration of ideologies: opening the last borders described as "recalcitrant barriers", signing international trade agreements such as TTIP, opening public procurement contracts to concession contracts to private companies... This report aims to bring down the latest protectionist impulses and recommends that the Commission systematically monitor the docility of States in the implementation of its recommendations. So I objected.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I do not believe that the European Semester process is sufficiently democratic, and in any event as a UKIP MEP I should vote against for reasons of principle. I am also concerned about the potential impacts of EU-wide minimum wage legislation.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on single market governance in the context of the 2015 European Semester. According to this year's European economic growth forecasts, high unemployment rates will continue to persist. This shows that fundamental structural reforms in the economic and social areas are struggling. I support the investment promotion plan put forward by the President of the Commission, but it should not be seen as an alternative to the necessary reforms, but an additional instrument that will allow funds to be allocated to projects with European and economic and social returns. The creation of a single energy market and the promotion of energy independence in EU countries must be accelerated. The creation of an energy union is essential and will make Member States more competitive and resilient to political pressure from third countries.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. This governance of the single market represents a serious attack on the sovereignty of Member States and is a further step towards putting them under the tutelage of an ultra-centralised system, led by an unelected Commission with ever-increasing and strengthened powers. Of course, I voted against this dangerous text.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. A pillar of the European semester will be devoted to strengthening the governance of the single market. This pillar should be based on a defined set of priorities related to the real economy and key growth sectors. This report focuses on several aspects, namely: - the consolidation of internal market governance through evaluation criteria that could strengthen growth;   - the need to use the "internal market" pillar of the six-month period to link indicators to growth and job creation, particularly in the digital market;    - the need for an investment strategy with a more competitive single market;    - the compatibility of trade and investment agreements with key single market factors relating to social, environmental and consumer standards;    - the fight against tax evasion and evasion and the improvement of tax coordination...

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This third report on the governance of the single market in the context of the 2015 European semester is particularly binding on Member States. This report is therefore presented to us here as the 'Holy Grail', the magic weapon for ever more economic integration in order to lift the European Union out of its doldrums. States should then follow the Commission's recommendations and put an end to the last recalcitrant barriers (i.e. fewer borders). Moreover, it will obviously be necessary to go further and further in the digital or energy single market, to facilitate even more the free movement of goods, through TTIP in particular, to open public procurement to private concessions (privatisation therefore!) and to further promote the application of the Services Directive. I have therefore spoken out against this report.  Finally, it is more than necessary to put an end to this technocratic Union, totally disconnected from economic realities. It is time to break free from the dogma of the single currency, establish intelligent protectionism and increase support for SME-TPE.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Internal Market Commission's report on the European Semester is based on a series of statements that are too optimistic and for their own sake. There are no references to EU costs and to the dysfunctions of the internal market that generate unsustainable costs for our businesses and local authorities. Not to mention the rapporteur's reference to the issue of competition in the services sector without any criticism of existing European measures: for years I have been fighting against the reckless application of the Bolkestein Directive, which is killing both the bathing and itinerant sectors in Italy. For all these reasons, I voted against this report.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report on the basis of the commitments reached in the IMCO Commission. These reflect the S&D Group's priorities for the internal market pillar, highlighting the need to revitalize the European economy through better and fairer functioning of the single market, capable of boosting sustainable growth and social cohesion, creating quality jobs and increasing competitiveness based on R&D investments, training and training.  It also reflects the need to target investments in European re-industrialization and strategic growth sectors such as the digital single market, with an emphasis on the essential interconnection between high levels of network penetration and high levels of ICT skills for citizens and businesses. The report includes a key point for the S&D Group and calls for renewing efforts to combat fraud, evasion and tax avoidance, as well as to build good fiscal governance and improve fiscal coordination, in order to avoid distortions of unfair competition and market and to ensure equal opportunities in the single market.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because a well-functioning and efficient single market based on a sustainable, highly innovative and competitive social market economy is needed in order to revitalise the European economy, boost sustainable growth and competitiveness, attract investment, promote social cohesion and create new jobs. A stronger and fairer internal market with a stronger industrial base is an important priority of the Commission's work programme for 2015, and member states and the European Union should jointly develop an EU industrial policy, building on the work already done in this area in recent years. In its report, the European Parliament calls on the Commission, the Member States, the regions and relevant stakeholders to focus on the real economy by developing and improving investment policy, which in turn will attract private investment. Calls also for investment in the preparation of people and businesses for the digital era, including the latest technologies in the energy sector, as only in this way will it be possible to ensure a global digital network by supporting education and quality research and innovation. It is also important for the Commission and the Member States to improve the regulatory framework for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), taking into account the capacity of SMEs to create jobs.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. The report highlights the importance of the digital market for boosting growth, creating quality jobs, maintaining the competitiveness of the European economy on the global market and providing benefits for businesses and consumers.  It also highlights the importance of investing, including in broadband to achieve priority targets in a key area of the digital market, which I fully support. He says fragmentation and lack of legal certainty are major concerns and calls for harmonisation of all EU regulations.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The governance of the European Single Market takes into account, in all its areas, the needs of consumers and the mechanism for the provision of goods and services in the interests of European citizens. We continue to face a phenomenon of market stratification, and the uniform implementation of Community legislation across all Member States continues to face difficulties. The functioning of the Single Market is also conditional on the application of rules ensuring clarity and operability of European policies. There are also optimistic signals: according to the Now Casting Economics study, in the first quarter of 2015, the euro area saw an increase of 0.4%. A shy but promising result given the positive trend of the last six months. I have expressed myself in favour of this report because strengthening the euro area economy is essential, and the achievement of this process involves removing unnecessary obstacles and bureaucratic burdens that stand in the way of development.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 The text is based on a series of statements that are not concrete and absolutely instrumental and part-time. On the other hand, there is no reference and criticism of the costs that This Europe and its rules place on our businesses and local authorities. I voted against.

name: Cristian-Silviu Bușoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The crisis has shown that the EU must act to improve its own economic model and restore competitiveness. This requires a combination of solid-based public finances, structural reforms and targeted investments. Europe 2020 is the EU strategy for boosting sustainable growth and job creation, and the Single Market has a key role to play in this process. However, the Single Market is currently not fully exploiting its potential. The EU must support Member States to trade more cross-border services and must take urgent action to keep up with changes in digital technologies. Europe needs a single market ready for the 21st century, enabling European businesses to remain at the forefront of competition and allowing consumers access to high-quality products and services across the EU. Relaunching the Single Market contributes to reactivating the engine of growth and employment in Europe and, ultimately, to multiplying opportunities for citizens. Thus, the first challenge is to empower citizens so that they become full players within the Single Market.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report on the basis of the commitments made in the IMCO Commission, these reflect the priorities of the S&D group with regard to the internal market pillar, stressing the need to revitalize the European economy through a better and fairer functioning of the single market, capable of boosting sustainable growth and social cohesion , create quality jobs, increase competitiveness based on investments in R&D, training and training.  It also reflects the need to target investments in European re-industrialization and strategic growth sectors such as the Digital Single Market, with an emphasis on the essential interconnection between high levels of network penetration and high levels of ICT skills for citizens and businesses. The report includes a key point for the S&D group, calls for renewing efforts to combat fraud, evasion and tax avoidance, to build good fiscal governance and improve fiscal coordination in order to avoid distortions of unfair competition and market and to ensure equal opportunities in the single market.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the single market governance report in the context of the European semester. With the crisis, Member States have understood the need to coordinate their economic policies. We must build on this momentum by bringing national social and fiscal policies together. Complementing the internal market is also an absolute necessity. We see on a daily basis that many obstacles to the proper functioning of the European economy remain. One solution to the resumption of growth is to remove these barriers. Some sectors have very strong growth potential and are constrained by disparate national policies. It is our duty, as a European co-legislator, to optimise the single market to meet the needs of our citizens. With this in mind, I welcome the new Commission's commitment to removing barriers to investment by complementing the single market, particularly in the energy and digital sectors.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the governance of the single market under the 2015 European Semester.  I see the single market and the digital single market as two key instruments for reviving economic growth and creating jobs in the European Union. Further development of the single market can also favour more traditional drivers of growth such as the promotion of investment in research and development, particularly in SMEs, training and education. The report I voted on stressed the need to strengthen the governance of the single market within the European Semester as a horizontal priority of the union's different policies, in order to ensure the necessary balance between the economic, social and environmental dimension, and to improve the quality of the transposition, implementation and application of the rules governing it.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as it contained nothing new or of substance. It was simply repackaging earlier reports and advocating what is a failed economic paradigm. Moreover, the singular focus on the single market fails to address serious democratic deficit concerns,  further eroding sovereignty and reducing economic independence for both Ireland and other Member States.  For this reason, I voted against.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report focuses on single market governance within the European Semester 2015 in response to the Annual European Semester cycle, Annual Growth Survey 2015(AGS) as published by the Commission. Disappointingly, unlike in previous years, the Commission has not published, together with the AGS, its annual 'Report on the Single Market Integration'. It is quite surprising that the analysis of the functioning of the Single Market and its areas with greatest growth potential has not been published, considering the emphasis that the current Commission is placing on the single market and its potential for growth. In view of this, the report builds on previous Parliament resolutions on single market governance and underscores the need for a single market pillar to be included in the European Semester in order to better support the real economy and stimulate growth and jobs. The report also places emphasis on other important key areas with the biggest growth potential, such as the digital single market, services and the consumer acquis.  I voted in favour of this report.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Failure to complete the market deprives producers and consumers of rights that should be guaranteed to them and is at the same time a brake on the economy. A special mention goes to the digital single market, which, although it has a very strong potential, still has problems with the reluctance to create a truly single market and, in fact, usable as such.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which is part of a desire to establish a single market, which is obviously an attack on our national sovereignty.  Indeed, the goal is always the same and we know it: to break down territorial, cultural and mental boundaries, to establish a large global market that would benefit only a globalized elite and would be at the expense of the peoples. This report seeks to put states under guardianship since the serious macroeconomic gaps could only be explained by a lack of Europe. As usual, ideology is at work: more integration will solve problems as if by magic, through the establishment of the digital single market, the free movement of goods, capital, services and people; to do this, it is a matter of closely monitoring every protectionist temptation of the Member States. A report that constitutes a real attack on peoples, their freedom, their independence and their prosperity.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The measure aims to increase the integration of the single market. It must be helped and encouraged because I am sure it gives the European Union the status of a world economic power. I have been able to verify that the potential of the single market has not yet fulfilled the process envisaged. One of the solutions could be for the European Union to help Member States to take greater action on cross-border trade in services. Urgent measures must be taken to keep up with digital technologies that have continuous development. I thought I voted in favour of the measure.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution because it sets as my objective the growth of the integration of the single market, to be encouraged because it is precisely the single market that gives the European Union the status of a world economic power. To date, however, I believe that the single market is not realising its full potential. The European Union must help Member States to implement much more cross-border trade in services and must take urgent measures to keep up with the constantly developing digital technologies.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The strengthening of single market governance is inseparable from the concrete possibility of establishing a specific pillar of the European Semester dedicated to it. The coordination of economic and employment policies must be supplemented by a key part covering all possible levers to stimulate the real economy that could otherwise be left out of the overall coordination of the European Semester.  I believe that priority areas such as the free movement of goods, services, public procurement and concessions, the digital agenda, consumer protection, energy and transport should be coordinated at the highest level within the framework of the annual cycle of governance. Leaving them on the sidelines of the European Semester would be a huge mistake in the EU's economic growth policy by obliterating the untapped potential of this market rather than leveraging it as a catalyst for economic recovery and sustainable growth while attracting investment and promoting social cohesion. Only by deepening and paying special attention to the internal market, in the context of the European Semester, taking advantage of its growth and employment potential, will the European Commission achieve the priorities it has drawn for 2015 and member states to overcome the challenges that globalisation and the crisis pose.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the governance of the single market under the 2015 European Semester, as it presents a plan of measures aimed at ensuring the complete achievement of a functioning, digital and effective single market that acts as an accelerator of sustainable economic growth and the development of competitiveness.  The social and economic policies adopted by the European Union are intended to stimulate public and private investment, to develop new projects with a particular focus on the needs of SMEs and job creation, and to provide tangible benefits for citizens.  In order to achieve the above objectives, I believe that close cooperation between the European Parliament and the national parliaments and a clear assumption of responsibility on the part of the European institutions to strengthen economic governance and partnership in the single market are necessary.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Unlike previous years, the Commission did not attach the Annual Growth Survey with its annual report on single market integration which would be necessary to attain the objectives on growth and employment. This report builds on Parliamentʼs resolutions on single market governance and emphasises the digital single market, free movement of goods, services, public procurement and concessions, and consumer acquis as key areas of growth potential. I support these. I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I consider the coordination of economic and employment policies within the single market to be of primary importance for growth and for the state of the integration process. The implementation and implementation of those provisions can play a decisive role in contributing to economic recovery. However, It is necessary for Member States to transpose the rules of the single market effectively in order to achieve concrete results.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which stresses the need to consolidate single market governance by establishing an annual single market governance cycle as a specific pillar of the European Semester with the aim of revitalising the European economy through a well-functioning, deeper and fairer single market capable of boosting sustainable growth, quality jobs, competitiveness and social cohesion, attracting investment and strengthening the European industrial base.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the Commission should introduce a new methodology for quantitative targets for reducing administrative burdens at European level. In view of the positive experiences in some Member States in setting net reduction targets in order to reduce compliance costs, I believe that it is necessary to discuss this methodology in the new Commission initiative with the aim of reducing administrative burdens.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. The main focus of this report is to improve the governance of the single market by developing a set of analytical tools to better measure the economic and regulatory performance of the single market within the framework of the European semester pillar dedicated to it. In this regard, such tools would be useful in supporting country-specific recommendations, the annual growth review, the European Council guidelines for Member States and national action plans to implement single market guidelines.  The report also highlights the untapped potential of the single market in key growth sectors. I am pleased that the European Commission has adopted energy initiatives and is expected to propose a strategy for the Digital Single Market in the coming months. Finally, I support the proposal to develop an indicator to measure the shortcomings of the single market, that is, the additional burden borne by citizens and businesses in cross-border activities because of the inadequacy of common European rules. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The completion of a genuine single market is still a work in progress. With this report, it is a reminder of how the single market is a real lever for growth. For example, the completion of the Digital Single Market could generate 0.4% additional GDP growth and create more than 223,000 jobs by 2020. In addition, the rapporteur of the text rightly calls on the European Commission to design tools capable of measuring the economic and regulatory performance of the single market and to improve the regulatory framework for SMEs.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This report considers the single market aspects of the economic governance framework, and in particular how these might be improved. In the past the Commission has reported annually on progress as regards single market objectives as part of the Annual Growth Survey. For 2014, however, this was omitted. The report is critical of this approach, and indeed notes that it strengthens the case for a more formal consideration of the single market pillar within the European Semester, as previously called for by Parliament. I can support this position and the conclusions drawn in this report, which are broadly pro-growth and anti-red-tape in nature

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Dear Colleagues, I supported this report as its adoption is imperative due to the fact that already in 2012 the European Council recognised the need to improve the governance of the Single Market. The proposals set out in this report are aimed at improving the implementation and implementation of the Single Market, ensuring full compliance with the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. This expresses the involvement of national parliaments in coordinating single market priorities. It is of particular importance to me and the Group of European Conservatives and Reformists that the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are strongly established in all areas and policies, as only they are a guarantor of national sovereignty in the current image of the Union, in which the European institutions increasingly seize the competence of national legislative authorities.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report as I believe that the common labour market will weaken countries with a weak economy even further.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as it recognises the importance of the Single Market as an element of attraction to investment and business activity, being at the heart of Europe's competitiveness and representing its greatest economic strength. The EU must support Member States to increase cross-border trade in services, create a single energy market, and take urgent action to keep pace with developments in digital technologies. Strengthening the governance of the Single Market is the concrete possibility of establishing a specific pillar within the Framework of the European Semester. I support the Rapporteur when he considers that the coordination of economic and employment policies should be supplemented by a fundamental pillar covering the Single Market with the purpose of stimulating the real economy. This pillar should cover a clear set of priorities related to the real economy and key growth areas.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The Single Market and the Digital Single Market are two key tools for relaunching economic growth and creating quality jobs in the EU. Complementarity with more traditional growth engines, such as expanding investment in research, development and innovation in training and education, should be ensured at the same time, and particular attention should be paid to the needs of SMEs. This report stresses the need to strengthen single market governance as a horizontal priority of the union's different policies, while preserving the necessary balance between the economic, social and environmental dimensions. For a Single Market to work well and effectively, it must be based on a sustainable and highly innovative and competitive social market economy, as it is necessary to increase sustainable growth and competitiveness, attract investment, promote social cohesion and create jobs in order to revitalise the European economy.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The single market – the principle, pillar, objective and priority of this integration – is one of the main driving forces of divergence and deepening inequalities between countries in the EU. For countries such as Portugal, the single market meant imbalances in the trade balance and a weakening of the national production system, in the face of competitive pressures generated and for which the country was not prepared. This report aims to strengthen the governance of the single market under the European Semester by giving top priority to horizontal implementation in all EU policies. No lesson is taken from the negative consequences of policies that have been defended and implemented. On the contrary, it insists on these policies. Such priorities are a source of deep concern, despite the permanent attempts to seek to brown the pill with the usual brushstrokes of "social", "sustainable" and "innovation". We voted against it.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 The third report on single market governance in the framework of the European Semester focuses on the Single Market for growth and jobs. The Single Market is at the heart of Europe's competitiveness and is also its greatest economic force. However, the economic crisis has revealed that the European Union must take measures to improve its economic model to restore competitiveness. In fact, the Single Market is not currently making full use of its potential, and it is our duty to adapt it to the 21st century so that European businesses can better compete. We also need to improve the ability of consumers to access high-quality products and services in the European Union. At the same time, the relaurgence of the Single Market will also serve to increase employment and increase opportunities for citizens of the Member States, thereby becoming full members of the Single Market.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the governance of the single market in the context of the European Semester 2015, because the common labour market will weaken countries with a weak economy even further.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report stresses the need to consolidate single market governance by establishing an annual single market governance cycle as a specific pillar of the European Semester, with the aim of revitalising the European economy through a well functioning, deeper and fairer single market capable of boosting sustainable growth, quality jobs, competitiveness and social cohesion, attracting investment and strengthening the European industrial base. A consistent package of compromises adequately endorsing S&D priorities has been negotiated and successfully adopted. The final text concentrates on the single market as a pillar of the European Semester and on its untapped potential in key growth areas, notably in the digital single market, and its governance. I therefore voted in favour of the Gall Pelcz report.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. Europe has all the tools to be a fundamental economic player globally. The European single market of 500 million people gives the EU the opportunity to be the economic engine. However, Europe must face with resolution the challenges ahead; improve its economic model and restore competitiveness. A balance is needed between the consolidation of public finances and structural reforms with investments in the driving sectors of the European economy. The single market plays a key role, but it is not developing its full potential. A potential that could bring European companies to the global forefront. To this end, the transposition of directives in the Member States should be improved and the governance of the single market improved.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report on the basis of the commitments reached in the IMCO Commission. These reflect the S&D Group's priorities for the internal market pillar, highlighting the need to revitalize the European economy through better and fairer functioning of the single market, capable of boosting sustainable growth and social cohesion, creating quality jobs and increasing competitiveness based on R&D investments, training and training.  It also reflects the need to target investments in European re-industrialization and strategic growth sectors such as the digital single market, with an emphasis on the essential interconnection between high levels of network penetration and high levels of ICT skills for citizens and businesses. The report includes a key point for the S&D Group and calls for renewing efforts to combat fraud, evasion and tax avoidance, as well as to build good fiscal governance and improve fiscal coordination, in order to avoid distortions of unfair competition and market and to ensure equal opportunities in the single market.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report on the basis of the commitments reached in the IMCO Commission. These reflect the S&D Group's priorities for the internal market pillar, highlighting the need to revitalize the European economy through better and fairer functioning of the single market, capable of boosting sustainable growth and social cohesion, creating quality jobs and increasing competitiveness based on R&D investments, training and training.  It also reflects the need to target investments in European re-industrialization and strategic growth sectors such as the digital single market, with an emphasis on the essential interconnection between high levels of network penetration and high levels of ICT skills for citizens and businesses. The report includes a key point for the S&D Group and calls for renewing efforts to combat fraud, evasion and tax avoidance, as well as to build good fiscal governance and improve fiscal coordination, in order to avoid distortions of unfair competition and market and to ensure equal opportunities in the single market.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The crisis has shown that single market governance also needs urgent reform to restore lost competitiveness and make the most of its full potential. I therefore voted in favour of today's resolution, which aims to create a transparent and reliable frame of reference, based on a periodic assessment of the condition of the single market and greater political responsibility at Member State level within the framework of renewed subsidiarity.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. Mr Gáll-Pelcz's report offers a very interesting perspective in the context of our reflection today on the European Semester procedure for the coordination of economic policies. The measures resulting from the objective of completing the internal market are in fact decisive, both those of economic and social policy, in order to ensure the implementation of effective instruments for growth and employment.  I would like to highlight in particular some significant aspects that have led me to strongly support my colleague's report. The emphasis on completing the digital single market seems to me to be particularly important and essential for stimulating growth, creating quality jobs, keeping the European economy globally competitive and bringing benefits to both businesses and consumers. In this context, it will be crucial to ensure a good deal of investment in broadband networks, with a view to achieving the objectives and priorities in the key sector of the digital market.  The completion of the digital single market – many studies confirm this – could produce additional GDP growth of 0.4% (i.e. €520 billion) until 2020, with employment increasing by around 0.1%, equivalent to creating more than 223,000 jobs by 2020. These objectives are certainly very important and ambitious, but we could achieve them if the strategic priorities of future European investments are addressed in a substantial and efficient manner to this end.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because if we think that it would only be enough to complete the digital single market to produce additional GDP growth of 0.4% and the creation of more than 223,000 jobs by 2020, we realise that the completion of the single market, in all its forms, is the priority of the European political agenda. The objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy are ambitious, but Europe cannot only set goals, it must also create the instruments, it must show the way to achieve them. The single market is one of these avenues. Provided that it is a real market, that we invest in the training of individuals and companies in order to prepare them for the digital age, that complements the single transport market, that the single energy market develops. It's a market of 500 million people, it's our economic strength. The right governance includes strong leadership on the part of all European institutions and a clear political accountability on the part of the Member States.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report. The report, among others, reiterates support for TTIP, a free trade agreement that we can oppose. On the other hand, it does not include any reference to the fight against unemployment and poverty, particularly serious problems in our country, which require structural changes. Likewise, as in the TTIP, it is urged to remove 'regulatory barriers' (social, labour rights, etc.), in order to ensure that certain services not too "explored" are competitive and bring benefits. It also mentions the need to further liberalize financial services and to remove any regulatory barriers that may be detrimental. Therefore, as it is a report which aims to put in place policies that will not favour people, we vote against it.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report, along with my S&D colleagues, as the single market is one of the defining characteristics of the European project and its exploitation needs to be fully realised so that we can all benefit from the sustainable growth and quality jobs it offers.  Creating a deeper and fairer single market will ensure European competitiveness and can promote social cohesion within Europe, as well as attract investment and strengthen the European industrial base.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report on the basis of the commitments reached in the IMCO Commission. These reflect the S&D Group's priorities for the internal market pillar, highlighting the need to revitalize the European economy through better and fairer functioning of the single market, capable of boosting sustainable growth and social cohesion, creating quality jobs and increasing competitiveness based on R&D investments, training and training.  It also reflects the need to target investments in European re-industrialization and strategic growth sectors such as the digital single market, with an emphasis on the essential interconnection between high levels of network penetration and high levels of ICT skills for citizens and businesses. The report includes a key point for the S&D Group and calls for renewing efforts to combat fraud, evasion and tax avoidance, as well as to build good fiscal governance and improve fiscal coordination, in order to avoid distortions of unfair competition and market and to ensure equal opportunities in the single market.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of single market governance within the European Semester 2015. I cannot see a successful Union without a strong and efficient single market. Therefore it is of the utmost importance to include this pillar in the country-specific recommendations and ensure that they are followed.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report on the basis of the commitments reached in the IMCO Commission. These reflect the S&D Group's priorities for the internal market pillar, highlighting the need to revitalize the European economy through better and fairer functioning of the single market, capable of boosting sustainable growth and social cohesion, creating quality jobs and increasing competitiveness based on R&D investments, training and training.  It also reflects the need to target investments in European re-industrialization and strategic growth sectors such as the digital single market, with an emphasis on the essential interconnection between high levels of network penetration and high levels of ICT skills for citizens and businesses. The report includes a key point for the S&D Group and calls for renewing efforts to combat fraud, evasion and tax avoidance, as well as to build good fiscal governance and improve fiscal coordination, in order to avoid distortions of unfair competition and market and to ensure equal opportunities in the single market.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ The single market remains one of the greatest achievements of the EU albeit much work has still to be done, as this report highlights. Unfortunately, Scotlandʼs continued membership of the single market is threatened by our remaining within the United Kingdom. The Westminster parties are increasingly following an insular and xenophobic agenda and an in/out referendum on the EU is looking increasingly likely. If and when such a referendum takes place, it is vital that each of the constituent nations of the UK can veto an EU exit if that is what their electors wish.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU Single Market started its 23th year. It has transformed the way Europeans live, study, work, travel, how businesses do business.  Only in the last three years has a report on single market governance under the European Semester been included in the Annual Growth Survey. I note this in order to justify my dissatisfaction with the fragile progress on the same recommendations for those three years aimed at strengthening the level of single market integration.  Otherwise, objectivity requires us to stress that it is precisely the path taken to strengthen the integration of the EU single market that is an expression of new political thinking, a key to increasing the EU's competitiveness and a responsible position towards a changing world. In order to implement it, Member States' actions are most important and it is therefore imperative that the single market is built as a pillar of the European Semester.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against this report. The report, among others, reiterates support for TTE, a free trade agreement that we can oppose. On the other hand, it does not include any reference to the fight against unemployment and poverty, particularly serious problems in our country that require structural changes. Similarly, as in TTE, it is urged to remove 'regulatory barriers' (social, labour rights, etc.) to ensure that certain services not too "explored" are competitive and profit-producing. It also mentions the need to further liberalize financial services and to remove any regulatory barriers that may be detrimental. Therefore, as it is a report which aims to put in place policies that will not favour people, we vote against it.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the management of the single market in the European Semester in 2015, because the single market is one of the european union's greatest achievements making it a global economic power. However, the Single European Market has not reached the ultimate level of efficiency, and therefore healthy public finances, targeted investments and structural reforms are needed. A market that is in line with the challenges and changes of the 21st century is needed, and additional integration that must be aligned with the priorities of the Europe 2020 strategy. Better governance of the single market is also necessary in order to stimulate growth and establish effective surveillance mechanisms, and to strengthen the coordination of economic and employment policies.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. This report represents everything the National Front intends to fight against: opening the last borders, described as "recalcitrant barriers", signing international trade agreements, such as TTIP, opening public procurement contracts to concession contracts to private companies... I will vote against this text, which wants to combat any protectionist impulse, which defends a Union at all costs and which wants the Commission to systematically monitor the docility of States in the implementation of its recommendations.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Ildiko Gall-Pelcz's report on the governance of the single market in the context of the 2015 European semester. This report reiterates the European Parliament's call for a single market pillar in the European semester to better support the real economy. In addition, the report identifies sectors with high growth potential, such as the Digital Single Market or public procurement and concessions. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on the governance of the single market in the context of the 2015 European semester. More than twenty years after its creation, the single market is still not complete, mainly because the Member States have not fully transposed or implemented EU legislation. There is a need to put more emphasis on the single market in the context of the European semester in order to better exploit its potential for growth and job creation and to place its strengthening at the heart of the European industrial strategy.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe that the single market is at the heart of Europe's competitiveness and is its greatest economic advantage. Europe needs a single market that can meet the challenges of the twenty-first century, enabling European businesses to maintain their competitiveness and consumers to have access to high-quality products and services from across the EU. The EU should therefore support Member States to expand their cross-border trade in services and empower citizens to participate in the single market. But there is a need for clearer and stricter governance of the single market. To this end, it is necessary to establish a transparent and predictable framework reflecting adequately, and on a regular basis, the possible negative and positive results of the Member States in implementation and implementation, while such strict governance of the single market should be organised within an annual governance cycle and should be considered in the context of the European Semester. Given the economic importance of the single market, a regular assessment of its situation will give a more complete picture.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. The report makes some good proposals, such as transferring responsibility for the implementation of the country-specific recommendations to parliaments, thereby increasing subsidiarity, but it also calls for Brussels to have more control over the Member States and their budgets. That is why I can only reject this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the report as it sends a strong message to the Commission and Member States and calls for the improvement of single market governance to promote and facilitate growth and jobs, but also to serve as a benchmark for commitment to structural reform in the Member States. The report identifies a number of key sectors (SMEs, public procurement, the digital single market, free movement of goods, better consumer protection, assessment tools for single market integration) and provides recommendations on how to further improve them in order to unlock the potential of the single market, which could generate billions of euros in additional revenue.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – We, as a central European country, have benefited from the single market, the poor quality agricultural products in Western Europe have made domestic production impossible, and we have added our meat and dairy standards guaranteeing quality food to EU rules. Since then, you can eat Parisian sour cream made from wallpaper and palm oil. Our formerly world-famous factories such as Ikarus, Ganz, Flame, etc. are closed, even dismantled, our markets are being sithed. The country is colonized.  The report expects the crisis to be resolved by pushing the already failed neoliberal economic policy and should therefore be rejected. Even if someone wants to do a bad cause better, it is pointless and harmful, and it is worth serving a good cause even less effectively.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Gáll-Pelcz's report focuses on the need to help Member States to increase cross-border trade in services and to take urgent measures to keep up with new digital technologies. In order to achieve more transparent governance of the European single market, I believe that a transparent framework should be established, and one that adequately reflects the possible outcomes of the implementation of the rules in the Member States.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report endorses the system of budgetary supervision which allows the Commission not only to audit budgets and to ask for changes before they are even adopted by national parliaments, but also to push for further cuts or reforms if the proposed budgets do not suit it.  I reject this process of increasing the reduction in wages and pensions, raising the retirement age and continuing privatisations and liberalisations, with the sole result of the ironing out of public services and social rights. It is also in the context of the European semester that the Commission regularly denounces the CDI and the monopolies of SNCF or EDF in France.  While I have supported proposals that can improve the social dimension, I am no less critical of this tool which allows the European institutions to dictate their policies to states in defiance of popular sovereignty.  As a result, I voted against these three reports.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. The report on the governance of the single market in the context of the 2015 European semester is based on the sole desire to strengthen the European single market or to extend it to many sectors such as energy or digital, as well as to public procurement. Governance is then understood as ever-increasing harmonisation and economic integration in order to achieve more ambitious European objectives based on supranational management of Member States' economic policies.  Furthermore, the criterion for assessing the effectiveness of the single market used in this report comes from the study commissioned in September 2014 entitled "The Cost of Non-Europe". It is therefore an apagogic reasoning within the uchronie which does not bring any tangible and relevant elements to the assessment of the governance of the single market.  By proposing to speed up the competition and liberalisation of economic sectors in the Union without having produced an after-the-fact assessment of the economic integration already undertaken, the Gall-Pelcz report confirms the Union's blindness in pursuing its supranational ideological project. I therefore strongly opposed this text.

name: Philippe Loiseau (NI)
text: In writing. Vote against. The establishment of centralised governance of the single market is presented as a miraculous remedy that would enable sustained growth and job creation. But the real result of the policies pursued by the European Union is 11.4% unemployment in the euro area, zero economic growth and social, moral and political decay as well as corrupt elites.  This report aims to put Member States under guardianship and force them to report regularly and to implement the Commission's binding recommendations. This policy of guardianship is unacceptable in more ways than one and especially in view of the results.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it deepens the development of the single market through the framework of economic governance. This report is aimed at integrating the implementation of the single market as a requirement within the framework of the objectives of the Stability and Growth Pact. This results in direct attacks on the public sector, considering it a barrier to the single market, giving a political impetus to the implementation of the energy union and insisting on the elimination of public aid to avoid market distortions, etc. The report seeks to condition the deficit objectives of the economic governance framework on the implementation of the internal market, which directly erodes the possibility of governing against neoliberal policies. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 The governance of the single market must be improved to be the engine of the EU, and not only so that it can promote and facilitate growth and employment, but also to serve as a benchmark for Member States' commitment to the structural reforms that are necessary. I voted in favour of this report which considers it necessary to restore political supervision at the highest level, avoiding artificial distinctions between what is happening at EU level and what is being carried out in the Member States, while developing more efficient tools to ensure that citizens and businesses enjoy the benefits of the single market.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. One of the important structural reforms at European Union level is to strengthen the single market, from the building of the Banking Union to the Digital and Energy Single Market. When presenting the new investment plan, the European Commission underlined that the key elements, in addition to establishing the new fund itself as a source of financing, are the establishment of a list of projects and structural reforms.  Structural reforms at Member State level, which must create a favourable entrepreneurial and investment environment, are particularly prominent. Reforms that must be done at European Union level are to work to further strengthen the single market and ease business conditions and reduce fragmentation.  The good governance and functioning of the single market in practice is essential for the development of the European Union and I voted today for this report, which highlights this in particular.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ Successful achievement of the objectives of the Single European Market requires the adoption of clear, comprehensible and at the same time simplest regulations and directives, which must be flexibly transposed into the internal standards of the Member States. Member States must make every effort to simplify their standards so that they are not an obstacle but, on the contrary, a driver of the development of employment, economic growth and competitiveness throughout the European Union.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report because it also legitimises the implementation of the European Semester 2015 also in the area of the single market. In particular, the European Semester is an institutional way of limiting the national sovereignty of the Euro area Member States. The parliaments of the eurozone countries now lack sovereign rights in shaping national budgets, as the Eurogroup, an unelected body, has made them a tight corset by imposing mercely austerity.  The dominant element today in relation to the European Semester is the huge democratic deficit it has created in the name of reducing budget deficits. Thus, through an undemocratic institutional framework, Europe's old political world is trying to shackle the people and impose on them the policy of mercelial austerity, poverty and social exclusion.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. Vote against this project, again. As with the coordination of economic policies, this governance of the single market runs counter to the sovereignty of the Member States. Pyramid monitoring, with the European Commission at the top, can only take away the possibility of free action and legislation from the Member States, and we can only oppose it.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution which acknowledges the continuous increase in the use of the Your Europe and Your Europe Advice portals, which should be able to provide the necessary information to anyone living, working or studying in or moving between Member States in the EU.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the report on The Governance of the Single Market under the 2015 European Semester. Considering the need to improve the governance of the single market and stressing the importance of economic and regulatory efficiency, this report makes a positive contribution. It is clear that modernising public administration can bring benefits both by eliminating bureaucracy and by removing regulatory obstacles. The key sector for growth is the digital single market, with reference also to e-commerce. An integrated approach to problem-solving and a solution to the increasingly low levels of private investment is crucial, which is a cause for concern. The Europe 2020 strategy is designed precisely to stimulate sustainable growth and consequent job creation, so we need a constant and intensified commitment on these points.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to ensure clearer and more rigorous governance of the European single market, a transparent framework should be established, adequately reflecting the possible outcomes of the implementation of the rules within the Member States of the European Union.  I have decided to vote in favour of the Gáll-Pelcz report, as I believe that it focuses adequately on the need to support Member States in the intensification of cross-border trade, in the services sector. In particular, I welcomed the reference in the document to the need to take urgent measures to ensure the development of digital technologies.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. The report on internal market governance within the European Semester 2015 received my negative vote, as the overall orientation of Brussels' control over the Member States must be rejected. I cannot support the approach of political supervision at the highest level and therefore control at EU level.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report considers that "the free movement of goods, capital, services and people still has untapped potential for businesses and citizens in terms of efficiency, growth and job creation". Once this premise has been stated, the resulting recommendations are aimed at strengthening the single market. The aim, of course, is to "avoid overly restrictive regulations", to reduce "the administrative burden at European level" or to carry out "increased surveillance of existing barriers within the single market for goods". Disgusting rebuff of the liberals' cruel recipes. I'm voting AGAINST.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The strengthening of single market governance is closely related to the concrete possibility of establishing a specific pillar of the European Semester. The coordination of economic and employment policies must be supplemented by a key part covering all possible levers to stimulate the real economy that could otherwise be left out of the overall coordination of the European Semester. The coordination of Single Market priorities in the context of the European Semester should be based on a stronger democratic process with the full participation of national parliaments. And you should be concerned about policies that lead to economic growth and job creation.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I share the rapporteur’s view that many of the issues encountered by EU businesses and citizens remain unresolved, or are resolved at great cost and after too much time. It is essential for the EU to have streamlined and transparent governance of the single market in order for business and citizens to know their rights and opportunities and fully generate the economic growth they are capable of. Therefore I voted in favour of this report.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. It is important to improve the governance of the single market by developing a set of analytical tools that would better measure the economic and regulatory performance of the single market within the framework of the European semester pillar dedicated to it. Indeed, the single market is one of the main drivers of growth and job creation. Finally, in order to promote and contribute effectively to economic recovery, the implementation and proper implementation of governance rules is becoming increasingly important. Good governance means sharing, explaining the nature of European issues, explaining company projects and, above all, producing results. It is also about promoting common policies to combat unemployment and creating sustainable growth potential in order to restore the cohesion of the Union.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ For a successful European Semester cycle, concrete focus on the real economy is a key priority. Therefore, I voted in favour of a coordinated and efficient single market governance cycle focused on key growth sectors, notably the digital single market, consumers and workers, which will boost growth and jobs and ensure economic convergence between the euro and non-euro zones.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Semester has become, in a relatively short period of time, part of Europe's institutional culture and, moreover, is increasingly part of national policy-making culture. The previous open method of coordination, one of the most direct ancestors of the European Semester, was treated more or less as a joke; it was an exercise for academics more than practitioners. Now we can see how very powerful Member States - whether they like it or not - take the European Semester seriously and explain and defend their choices. Even when they try to obtain exceptions from the rules, they still explain themselves in relation to those rules, which are thus confirmed and strengthened. We now have an enriched process, with a clearer social dimension (Juncker's 'social triple A' is a great metaphor and, it is to be hoped, much more than that) and decent flexibility with the 'Moscovici package'. It is almost mystical how Europe, painfully, finds resources to fix itself after crises.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Single Market and the Digital Single Market should be considered as two key tools for relaunching economic growth and creating quality jobs in the European Union, and complementarity with the more traditional growth engines should be ensured. I am voting in favour of this report, especially because I recognise that there is enormous untapped potential in the Single Market and that certain strategic areas could make a decisive contribution to improving the quality of life of citizens and increasing Europe's competitiveness. I would therefore like to emphasize the will of finalising the single market for services and of moving quickly towards the digital single market, as both areas of activity could contribute more than 3% of GDP and thousands of jobs each year.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. This report on the internal market and consumer protection testifies to the ordoliberalism of the European institutions by wanting to push further the completion of the single market. It is funny that it promotes the reduction of administrative burdens, given the legislative inflation of the European Union in recent years, which threatens the legal security of companies and increases their management costs. It also calls for investment support at a time when recent surveys show no recovery in the euro area, with orders for capital goods stable.
