On the other hand, disinflation leads to higher real interest rates and while the natural real interest rate, for the southern euro area countries in particular, is probably negative. Investment cannot go away for the long term and the Juncker plan will fail and will only lead to windfall effects.  The single market is the embodiment of the failure of the principle of free and undistorted competition and of ordoliberalism between countries of different economic levels and unitary labour costs.  So I voted against this report.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which will enhance the single market in order to boost growth, competitiveness and the creation of new jobs in Europe.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the governance of the single market relating to the European Semester. As part of the European Semester, the European Commission analyses the Member States' fiscal, economic and structural reform plans and makes recommendations for the coming year.  The single market is an essential component of the Union's competitiveness. This market of 500 million people makes the European Union the world's leading economic power. It is based on the free movement of goods, capital, services and people. However, the report stresses that the potential of the single market is not fully exploited today. Strengthening the single market requires faster transposition of directives by Member States to strengthen the rights and level of information of consumers and businesses. The text also highlights the economic potential of completing the Digital Single Market.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The coordination of the economic and employment policies of all Member States, provided for in the European Semester, should include a key chapter devoted to possible levers aimed at stimulating the real economy, which would otherwise remain outside the agreement. In this respect, we believe that the single market pillar can cover a well-defined set of priorities and key sectors of growth.  We therefore support the rapporteur's position to encourage a targeted organisation of the work of the Competitiveness Council, which explicitly brings together in the European Semester the priorities relevant to the real economy. The achievement of these priorities is essential to stimulate growth and employment and to close the current gap in achieving the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, while making full use of the potential of the single market to ensure economic convergence between Member States inside and outside the euro area, as well as in the EU's central and peripheral sectors.  The Italian Presidency's initiative on a new 'approach to the internal market' (new AIM), as part of the mid-term review of the Europe 2020 strategy, is certainly a step in the right direction.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report, part of a package of three reports covering the 2015 European Semester, specifically examines the state of the process of integrating the single market. The recent crisis has shown that the EU needs to rebuild its competitiveness: the study on the cost of non-Europe has been a useful tool for understanding how there is unexpressed potential to exploit in areas such as cross-border trade and technological change. The relaunch of the single market is therefore aimed at restarting the economic engine, employment and growth in Europe, while also aiming to improve the quality of life of European citizens.  I have decided to support the report in a favourable way because I believe that, in order for the market to be effectively relaunched, we need to work on the key issues set out in the report, namely the Digital Agenda, the free movement of goods and services, the consumer acquis, public procurement and concessions, thus removing the existing barriers so that everyone can enjoy the rights and freedoms of the European single market.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am very pleased that after a somewhat bumpy road we managed to get the support. I welcome the definition of a specific single market pillar in order to better support the real economy and create growth and jobs within the European Semester. In particular, I see a great need to train individuals and companies in the digital age, including a description of the latest technologies in the energy sector. This would greatly help them to catch up, as the presence of a advancing digital single market is essential to stimulate growth, create new jobs and maintain the competitiveness of the European Union. With this step, we would represent not only the interests of companies, but also of consumers, which is one of our top priorities. We would also encourage Member States to share more information online, which would ensure that residents are better informed.  However, in order to achieve this, we must first face our concerns about fragmentation and legal certainty. In order for the economy and the social market economy to develop, member states must act together, i.e. in a uniform way, like the European Union.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Single Market is the economic strength of the European Union, giving it the opportunity to become the economic engine of the world. The economic crisis of recent years has unfortunately also affected this market of 500 million people.  I voted for this report because, through it, the European Parliament comes up with a number of measures that are extremely necessary for the recovery of the single market. Building the Single Market Pillar within the European Semester is one of the measures that requires a clear set of priorities related to the real economy and the main areas of economic growth. "Free movement of goods, services, public procurement and concessions, the digital single market, consumer protection legislation (acquis), but also energy, and transport" are key areas to be exploited because, through their development, the single market will become more efficient and competitive worldwide.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on the governance of the single market in the context of the 2015 European Semester. The single market is a key driver of growth and job creation and is essential for achieving the Europe 2020 goals for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. However, this potential is still untapped in many respects. Member States and regions have the opportunity to focus their policies and investments on sectors that will create more growth and jobs in 2014-2020, especially for young people, such as the Digital Single Market, energy, services and the green economy.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report.  A well-functioning, integrated and even more liberal EU Single Market must become an essential tool to respond adequately to the challenges of globalisation, to take a leading position in global competition and to ensure EU social standards. It is therefore essential that the Single Market be used as the third pillar of the European Semester. This would help to better identify clear priorities for the real economy, while fully respecting the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality in the EU. The governance of the Single Market needs to be improved by developing analytical tools, integrating an evaluation system for assessing the results of the Single Market and combining a wide range of methodologies. In addition, it is appropriate to set a composite indicator in order to assess the results of single market regulation. Another important aspect is that the main growth areas still have significant untapped potential of the Single Market. In this context, investments should be linked to innovation and entrepreneurship, making the best use of the opportunities offered by the digital economy and society and developing an advanced EU industrial policy.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the governance of the single market because I believe it contains important guidelines necessary to give new impetus to the European economy. The European Union begins with economic union. The single market has been the main driver of European integration but more than 20 years after its creation it has not been fully completed due to delays by Member States in transposing Community legislation.  It is necessary to ensure a holistic approach involving all European sectoral policies, so as to strengthen the area of free movement and stimulate economic recovery by attracting private investment and creating jobs. Administrative easing would facilitate access to finance, particularly in the areas of research and innovation, which is the main lever for ensuring a high level of European competitiveness in the world.  Single and integrated indicators would ensure more appropriate criteria for assessing market performance and making ad hoc recommendations for different Member States. The current international situation shows an energy-vulnerable Europe. Concrete steps are needed in this direction. The Europe 2020 objectives represent a challenge and provide an essential engine for growth, sustainability, employment and security in Europe.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Whereas, in the context of the mid-term review of the Europe 2020 strategy, the single market and the digital single market should be seen as two key tools for reviving economic growth and quality job creation in the EU, while ensuring complementarity with more traditional growth engines such as, for example, the promotion of R&D investment , in training and education, while paying particular attention to the needs of SMEs; that the Single Market Strategy requires a holistic approach that takes into account the concerns of citizens, consumers and SMEs; that a properly functioning and effective single market, based on a sustainable and highly innovative and competitive social market economy, is necessary to boost sustainable growth and competitiveness, attract investment, promote social cohesion and create jobs, in order to reinvigorate the European economy; By renewing my call on the Commission to improve the governance of the single market by developing a set of analytical tools to better assess the economic and regulatory efficiency of the single market in the context of the Single Market Pillar of the European Semester, I voted in favour.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Completion of the single market is the urgent priority for achieving enhanced, sustainable growth. There is still great potential to be achieved and the EU should keep on removing barriers which disrupt the single market, and enhancing mechanisms, governance and coordination.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. This report on the internal market and consumer protection testifies to the ordoliberalism of the European institutions by wanting to push further the completion of the single market. It is funny that it promotes the reduction of administrative burdens, given the legislative inflation of the European Union in recent years, which threatens the legal security of companies and increases their management costs. It also calls for investment support at a time when recent surveys show no recovery in the euro area, with orders for capital goods stable. On the other hand, disinflation leads to higher real interest rates and while the natural real interest rate, for the southern euro area countries in particular, is probably negative. Investment cannot go away for the long term and the Juncker plan will fail and will only lead to windfall effects.  The single market is the embodiment of the failure of the principle of free and undistorted competition and of ordoliberalism between countries of different economic levels and unitary labour costs.  So I voted against this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I support colleague Gáll-Pelcz's report because after more than 20 years since its official creation, the single market has not yet been fully completed. And it is precisely the completion of the process of establishing a Digital Single Market that could generate additional GDP growth of 0.4% in the period up to 2020. (or EUR 520 billion in 2014 prices), with employment gains ranging from 0.1%, equivalent to over 223 000 jobs created by 2020 according to data from the study 'Cost of non-Europe in the single market'. It is particularly important to remove unjustified restrictions and barriers to entry into key sectors such as retail, e-commerce and business services. Europe needs a holistic single market strategy that takes into account the problems of citizens, consumers and SMEs and projects single market priorities into all policy areas. As part of the Europe 2020 Mid-Term Strategy Review, the Single Market and the Digital Single Market should be considered as key instruments to relaunch economic growth and create quality jobs in the EU, while ensuring complementarity with more traditional growth drivers such as boosting investment in R&D and innovation, upskilling and education, in particular taking into account the needs of SMEs.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support my colleague Gall-Pelcz's report on Single Market Management under the European Semester 2015. The practicality and economic functionality of the whole system will enable the consistent implementation and application of the rules governing the Single Market and taking into account market priorities, citizens' problems and SMEs.   The Commission's involvement in political priorities, the introduction of quantitative objectives methodology and the presentation of annual reports will contribute to a more transparent picture of the state of single market integration and the realisation of the market's full growth potential. Achieving the single market objectives provides an opportunity for the EU market of 500 million people to become a global actor.  By taking measures to ensure that the transfer is effectively addressed at national level, the benefits for consumers will increase many times by establishing better quality standards, more competitive prices and new opportunities in the Digital Single Market.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I consider the single market to be the very essence of the European Union. I therefore welcomed the report on this issue. From the point of view of the Czech Republic, but I think that there are still areas in the union as a whole where we must strive to achieve the single market. For example, I consider energy or the digital market to be such areas. Given that my colleague Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz's report is based on these results, it deserves support.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In order to encourage the resumption of European economic growth and stimulate job creation, the EU must focus part of its efforts on deepening the single market. This point was highlighted by MEPs in the report on the governance of the single market. I voted for this text and I support the main arguments put forward for better governance of the single market and a resumption of growth. The report focuses mainly on the Digital Single Market, the free movement of goods, services, public procurement and concessions. These sectors have strong growth potential, hence the importance of better coordinating these sectors within the single market.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Semester, which began in 2010, sets out an annual cycle of economic policy coordination with a detailed analysis of Member States' plans for budgetary, macroeconomic and structural reforms. This resolution concerns the governance of the Single Market under the European Semester, with the aim of strengthening it. In fact, the Single Market has not yet realised its full potential. It is therefore necessary to strengthen the governance of the Single Market within the Framework of the European Semester, preserving the necessary balance between the economic, social and environmental dimensions, and to improve the quality of transposition, implementation and supervision of the rules governing the Single Market, while also significantly reducing the duration of infringement procedures. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that clearer and more rigorous governance of the Single Market is necessary, especially in the context of the European Semester. The coordination of economic and employment policies must be supplemented by a key part covering all possible levers to stimulate the real economy. Particular attention is also needed on key growth areas with a potential for economic recovery and relevant convergence, such as the free movement of goods, services, public contracts and concessions, the Digital Single Market, the body of consumer protection legislation, energy and transport. The re-establishment of political supervision should be imposed at the highest level, avoiding any distinctions between actions undertaken at EU level and those undertaken at Member State level. The Single Market is a key driver of growth and jobs and has an indispensable role to play in achieving the objectives of the EU 2020 strategy.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which reminds us that the single market is a key element of the European semester. By making full use of the single market, the EU will be able to create the opportunities it lacks to stimulate investment and create the conditions under which citizens, consumers, investors and businesses can operate in a better context of growth and quality jobs. This involves not only new initiatives, but also better implementation of everything we have already planned to give shape to the single market. For the new initiatives, we look forward to the two major projects that the Commission is due to launch this year: the Digital Single Market Package in May and the new Single Market Strategy at the end of this year. It is time for the Union to regain its self-confidence and fully enter the digital age, to regain its place in the global economy and improve the lives of our fellow citizens. With regard to the Digital Single Market package, I stress the improvement of digital competences in the Union, the reduction of administrative burdens for businesses and the importance of providing consumers with the same level of protection as they are accustomed to in their traditional market.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With regard to the governance of the single market, the Commission's support for developing a set of analytical tools to correctly measure economic performance is important. Investments should be made in view of the objectives set out under the 2020 Strategy. This will achieve smart, sustainable and inclusive growth.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report on the basis of the commitments reached in the IMCO Commission. These reflect the S&D Group's priorities for the internal market pillar, highlighting the need to revitalize the European economy through better and fairer functioning of the single market, capable of boosting sustainable growth and social cohesion, creating quality jobs and increasing competitiveness based on R&D investments, training and training.  It also reflects the need to target investments in European re-industrialization and strategic growth sectors such as the digital single market, with an emphasis on the essential interconnection between high levels of network penetration and high levels of ICT skills for citizens and businesses. The report includes a key point for the S&D Group and calls for renewing efforts to combat fraud, evasion and tax avoidance, as well as to build good fiscal governance and improve fiscal coordination, in order to avoid distortions of unfair competition and market and to ensure equal opportunities in the single market.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report we adopted reiterates and puts at the fore Parliament's call for a single market pillar within the Framework of the European Semester to better support the real economy and stimulate growth and job creation.  The report also focuses on the Digital Single Market, the free movement of goods, services, public procurement and concessions, as well as the consumer protection acquis, which it identifies as key elements with the greatest potential for growth.  With regard to the assessment of the integration of the single market, the text finally proposes the development of a composite indicator to better measure the shortcomings of the single market as well as the regulatory performance of member states.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Like the rapporteur, I consider the completion of the Single Market, made up of more than 500 million Europeans, a key instrument for relaunching fairer economic growth and generating quality jobs in the EU, as outlined in the Europe 2020 strategy, which aims to create the conditions for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. To this end, there must be a concerted effort between the EU and the Member States to foster cross-border trade in services, a good and correct application and implementation of single market rules, as there are improvements to be made, in particular, in terms of transposition into national legislation, understanding of the legislative framework and duration of infringement procedures. To this end, I agree with the general guidelines contained in this report in the framework of the European Semester as a horizontal priority of the different Union policies, preserving the balance between the economic, social and environmental dimensions and improving the quality of transposition, implementation, implementation and supervision of single market rules, ensuring that companies have access to an internal market capable of attracting investment and ensuring the necessary competitiveness for the EU to improve its economic model and to ensure that it is as an effective global economic power.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report, which stresses the need to put more emphasis on the single market in the context of the European semester in order to better exploit its potential for growth and job creation, as well as to place its strengthening at the heart of the European industrial strategy.  Thus, it is important that the Commission sets priorities for action in the annual growth review and works to reduce administrative burden at European level, while working more with Member States.   Priority must also be given to key sectors of growth and the creation of quality jobs such as services, transport and the digital single market.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The completion of the single market is crucial to the success of the European project and to Europe's economic recovery. The Community institutions are doing a great deal to implement it, but its implementation must also be monitored in the Member States, which all too often hold back or burden Community legislation. That is why the Commission needs to resume a constant analysis, based on clear indicators, of the gaps that still exist.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote against it because, in the case of this report, we are faced with a number of unsea concrete statements.  In my opinion, the IMCO Committee makes too optimistic assumptions about the contribution that greater development of the internal market and the digital single market can make to the growth of the European Union economy. Furthermore, there are too many references to the content of the study – evidently part-based and instrumental – commissioned by the IMCO Committee on the 'cost of non-Europe in the single market'.  On the contrary, there are no references to costs which, on the other hand, this Europe and its rules, including many of those relating to the internal market, cost our businesses and local authorities.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against this report. The report, among others, reiterates support for TTIP, a free trade agreement that we can oppose. On the other hand, it does not include any reference to the fight against unemployment and poverty, particularly serious problems in our country, which require structural changes. Likewise, as in the TTIP, it is urged to remove 'regulatory barriers' (social, labour rights, etc.), in order to ensure that certain services not too "explored" are competitive and bring benefits. It also mentions the need to further liberalize financial services and to remove any regulatory barriers that may be detrimental. Therefore, as it is a report which aims to put in place policies that will not favour people, we vote against it.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which reiterates the demand for a specific pillar of the single market within the framework of the European Semester.  Unlike previous years, the European Commission has not published a report this year on the integration of the single market in parallel with its annual growth review 2015. While the objective of the new Juncker Commission is to deepen the single market, it seems quite contradictory not to look at the very analysis of how the single market works. In order to support the real economy more effectively, promote growth and stimulate job creation, the internal market needs to be more integrated into discussions at European level on the coordination of Member States' economic policies. It is by ensuring better European governance of the internal market, particularly in key sectors, such as the digital single market, the free movement of goods, services, public procurement and concessions, that we can return to growth and jobs in Europe.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (NI)
text: In writing. This report is based on the fact that the main economic policy directions must be decided in Brussels. I oppose it in defence of democracy and the social and political rights of our citizens.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it deepens the development of the single market through the framework of economic governance. This report is aimed at integrating the implementation of the single market as a requirement within the framework of the objectives of the Stability and Growth Pact. This results in direct attacks on the public sector, considering it a barrier to the single market, giving a political impetus to the implementation of the energy union and insisting on the elimination of public aid to avoid market distortions, etc. The report seeks to condition the deficit objectives of the economic governance framework on the implementation of the internal market, which directly erodes the possibility of governing against neoliberal policies. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in support of the report on single market governance within the European Semester 2015. A very positive process has developed through single market hovernance within the European Semester and the corresponding country-specific recommendations for a more competitive Europe. Single market governance generates quality jobs with equitable growth while better attracting investors. It must be emphasised that the single market strategy requires a holistic approach taking into account citizens’, consumers’ and SMEs’ concerns. Projecting single market priorities into all policy areas would ensure the completion of a viable single market serving as a catalyst for economic recovery and sustainable growth.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing , the EU Single Market, with its 500 million people, has played – and I expect it will continue to play – a key role in achieving the Europe 2020 objectives. Although strong innovative and competitive single markets have recently succeeded in expanding trade within the 28 EU countries, thereby supporting the creation of new jobs, stimulating growth and competitiveness, I think, and the report gives me the truth that the single market is still not fully exploiting its potential at present. I voted in favour of the report because I believe that the single market must work in practice and bring greater choice for consumers and better opportunities for businesses. I believe that the measures taken will provide consumers with even greater protection, especially as regards respect for fundamental rights, including equal opportunities, choice and quality of products and prices. In this context, I also consider it extremely important that the Commission and the Member States must, to the limits of their capabilities, strengthen the governance of the Single Market, improve its implementation and enforcement, and must develop instruments and mechanisms that will lead to its recovery and smooth functioning.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The Single Market Strategy requires an integrated approach that takes into account the interests of citizens, consumers and SMEs. In order for the single market to function well and successfully, it must be integrated into all policy areas. However, attention should be paid to maintaining a balance between the economic, social and environmental dimensions. It should be borne in mind that growth and competitiveness and job creation to revitalise the European economy require a well-functioning and efficient single market based on a competitive and social market economy. It is therefore necessary to avoid unnecessary regulatory burdens, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises. They should be given better access to finance. At one point, a great deal of attention must be paid to preventing unfair competition and market distortions. The single market must become the third pillar of the European Semester so that it can clearly cover the sets of priorities relating to the real economy. However, the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality within the EU must be fully respected. The economy must be focused on innovation and knowledge, as this will prepare us for the demands of the digital age in the future. For these reasons, I supported the report and voted in favour of its adoption.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ the Common European Market is one of the most important pillars of European integration and we must continue to break down barriers, especially in services, so that we can reap the full benefits of the common market. This also applies to the common digital market. One example of how to reap the benefits of the common market is the forthcoming SUP legislation for the creation of new firms.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Strategy Europe 2020, in the middle of the implementation period, the Single Market and the Digital Single Market should be considered as important instruments for restarting economic growth and creating quality jobs in the EU, while ensuring complementarity with more traditional growth drivers such as boosting investment in R&D and innovation, upskilling and education, in particular taking into account the needs of SMEs. I therefore call for the development of analytical instruments to measure the economic and regulatory performance of the Single Market under the Single Market Pillar of the European Semester in order to improve the governance of the Single Market. I would emphasise the importance and added value of the single market integration report from previous years, given their contribution to the overall priorities set out in the Commission's Annual Growth Survey and the setting of Member States' recommendations in the context of the European Semester, and I support the report for all of the above.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report on single market governance within the European Semester 2015 calls for action to unlock the potential of the single market (SM). I support this report as the SM is one of the most powerful engines at EU level and its potential needs to be fully exploited in order to boost growth, competitiveness and the creation of new jobs.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - The governance of the Single Market under the European Semester as a horizontal priority of the different Union policies should be strengthened, maintaining the necessary balance between the economic, social and environmental dimensions, and improving the quality of transfers to national legislation, implementing and implementing the rules governing the single market in order to be practical and economically functional. A greater focus on the Single Market under the European Semester is necessary with a view to making better use of its growth and employment opportunities, better communication on positive impacts so that citizens and businesses can take full advantage of its benefits. That's why I supported this report.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I agree with the proposal as it points to a number of stimulating solutions to improve the functioning of the Single Market and therefore of the European Union economy. These include, for example, calls to reduce regulatory burdens, remove existing barriers to the single market and so on. Contrary to the frequent intentions to increase redistribution or otherwise increase interventions in the economy, these are the means that are really beneficial for boosting growth.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on single market governance in the context of the 2015 European Semester. The European Semester, which was established in 2010, is a cycle of coordination of economic and fiscal policies in the EU. It is part of the European Union's economic governance framework. Economic indicators are better today than they were years ago, but we all recognise that we are not where we want to be yet. The debate on the European Semester is a very important debate. I believe that we need to deepen the single market even further. The debate has shown that we need more coordination in order to improve the single market. We have so many regulations and rules that are so complex that their implementation is really a real challenge. We need restructuring, but we cannot do so overnight. We must stay on this path and I am confident that we will work together to achieve the desired results.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report moves in the familiar context of neoliberal policies. It is only called for private investment to be promoted, the EU's role as a protector (and not a regulator) of the market is promoted, and there is no mention of workers' rights. Nor is there any mention of the need to boost the real economy, but only the need to support the financial services sector is underlined. That is why we voted against the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The common labour market weakens countries with a weak economy even more.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Europe needs to reform its economic model in order to create an effective internal market environment that supports competitiveness. In this connection, the FIDESZ delegation to the People's Party aims to provide support to the Member States in order to stimulate cross-border trade and to make the appropriate digital tools to facilitate this available to all and in a positive way.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, as I, too, believe that the Union's potential can be further enhanced if we continue to expand single market integration. We must continue to strive to break down all obstacles in this area as much as possible and for the common benefit of EU citizens. I think it is a very good approach that the report deals with the Digital Single Market in a separate chapter, an area in which the need to strengthen is no longer in question. I, too, believe that progress in the creation of the Digital Single Market is essential in order to stimulate growth and create quality jobs and to preserve the COMPETITIVENESS of the Union.  This is one of the reasons why the recent Decision of the European Council to abolish roaming charges is particularly regrettable. For my part, however, I also think it is important to reduce costs for cross-border calls not only when we are talking about a call from or received from another Member State, but also when we make a call to another Member State from the country of the member state service provider issuing the SIM card. It is unacceptable for service providers to apply a price difference in this area, as this is also a factor against the single market.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I work for the Internal Market Committee. As such, I would like to point out that the single market is an essential component of the Union's competitiveness, as well as its greatest economic strength. This market of 500 million people gives the European Union the opportunity to be the world's leading economic power. It offers companies across the continent a "domestic" market on which to sell their products and services, attracts investment from around the world and is the springboard for European trade with distant markets.  The crisis has shown that the European Union needs to act to improve its economic model and strengthen its competitiveness, which requires a combination of sound public finances, structural reforms and targeted investment. Europe 2020 is the EU's strategy to boost sustainable growth and job creation, and the single market has a crucial role to play in this area.  However, the potential of the single market is not being fully exploited at present. The European Union must encourage Member States to increase their cross-border trade in services and must take urgent measures to adapt to the evolution of digital technologies!

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the Single Market and the Digital Single Market (DSM) should be considered two key tools for reigniting economic growth and creating quality employment in the EU, at the same time as ensuring complementarity with the more traditional drivers of growth, such as boosting investment in RDI, training and education, while paying particular attention to the needs of SMEs. The Single Market strategy requires a holistic approach taking into account citizens’, consumers’ and SMEs’ concerns and projecting Single Market priorities into all policy areas, so as to ensure the completion of a viable Single Market serving as a catalyst for economic recovery and sustainable growth. More than 20 years after its official creation, the Single Market has not yet been fully completed, primarily because Member States have not fully transposed or implemented Union legislation. Finally, I want to stress that despite this I very much welcome the Digital Single Market strategy, I believe that if it wants to be credible the European Commission must solve urgently the Google antitrust case.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although it has been 20 years since its creation, the single market has not been fully completed. Due to the financial crisis, the level of investment has decreased by around EUR 430 billion from the peak reached in 2007. Although there are many instruments at Union level to measure the economic performance of the single market in the European Semester, they have so far had no clear impact. There is therefore a need for sustained efforts by all Member States to overcome this difficult period and to ensure a sustainable economic recovery of the Union. Through the adopted report, the European Parliament draws attention to the need to strengthen the single market and calls on the European Commission to report as quickly as possible on the current state of single market integration.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report. The report, among others, reiterates support for TTIP, a free trade agreement to which WE CAN oppose. On the other hand, it does not include any reference to the fight against unemployment and poverty, particularly serious problems in our country, which require structural changes. Likewise, as in the TTIP, it is urged to remove 'regulatory barriers' (social, labour rights, etc.), in order to ensure that certain services not too "explored" are competitive and bring benefits. It also mentions the need to further liberalize financial services and to remove any regulatory barriers that may be detrimental. That is why a report which aims to put in place policies that will not favour people, we vote against.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report. The result is generally positive, given that many contributions from my group have been incorporated, in particular as regards the need to include social and environmental dimensions in the single market, and to move towards fiscal coordination.

name: Inese Vaidere (PPE)
text: Writing. – The free movement of Citizens, Goods and Capital of the European Union is at the heart of the EU's single market. The single market is a key component of the EU's economic growth, giving Latvian producers the opportunity to market their products in other EU Member States, while consumers are provided with a wide range of products.  Although the single market officially started 20 years ago, it has not yet been fully completed, with the result that the potential of the single market is not fully exploited, mainly because member states have not fully implemented the single EU legislation. As a result, Latvian exporters also often face mechanisms restricting the single market in other EU countries.  I support the report's call for the European Commission and the Member States to do their utmost to ensure that the legislation adopted in the area of the single market actually works, thereby improving the governance of the single market.  I also believe that there is a need to increase the EU's competitiveness in the global market by eliminating unduly burdensome regulation, in particular for SMEs, as well as by improving access to finance and ensuring quality investment in research and innovation. There are still a number of key areas of the single market that are not fully organised, thus creating unjustified barriers for economic operators, such as the Digital Single Market. Likewise, the single market for transport and energy so important has not been created for Latvia.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report on the basis of the commitments reached in the IMCO Commission. These reflect the S&D Group's priorities for the internal market pillar, highlighting the need to revitalize the European economy through better and fairer functioning of the single market, capable of boosting sustainable growth and social cohesion, creating quality jobs and increasing competitiveness based on R&D investments, training and training.  It also reflects the need to target investments in European re-industrialization and strategic growth sectors such as the digital single market, with an emphasis on the essential interconnection between high levels of network penetration and high levels of ICT skills for citizens and businesses. The report includes a key point for the S&D Group and calls for renewing efforts to combat fraud, evasion and tax avoidance, as well as to build good fiscal governance and improve fiscal coordination, in order to avoid distortions of unfair competition and market and to ensure equal opportunities in the single market.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it deepens the development of the single market through the framework of economic governance. This report is aimed at integrating the implementation of the single market as a requirement within the framework of the objectives of the Stability and Growth Pact. This results in direct attacks on the public sector, considering it a barrier to the single market, giving a political impetus to the implementation of the energy union and the elimination of public aid to avoid market distortions, etc. The report seeks to condition the deficit objectives of the economic governance framework on the implementation of the internal market, which directly erodes the possibility of governing against neoliberal policies. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave with my Socialist colleagues our full support to this report as it believes the Single Market is one of the most powerful engines at EU level and its potential needs to be fully exploited to boost growth, competitiveness and creation of new jobs and the report fully reflects this.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The single market is now a priority of the European Union. The European Semester does not provide for any formal monitoring system on this issue. This report, in proposing the inclusion of a pillar (plus one) of the European Semester dedicated to the single market, represents another unacceptable step in the process of ceding the sovereignty of national states in the conduct of their policies. Such priorities are cause for deep concern, especially when the pill comes from golden features of social, sustainable and innovative façade with the objective stems from the construction of a European industrial strategy, which does not always take into account the specificities and needs of industrial development in each Member State.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. This report on internal market governance within the European Semester 2015 provides some points that could be endorsed, but the overall orientation of Brussels' control over the Member States must be rejected. That is why I voted against this motion.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave, together with my Socialist colleagues, full support to this report as it believes the single market is one of the most powerful engines at EU level and its potential needs to be fully exploited to boost sustainable growth, competitiveness and the creation of new jobs; and the report fully reflects this.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the governance of the single market in the context of the European Semester 2015, as the single market and the digital single market should be seen as two key tools for restoring economic growth and creating quality jobs in the EU. The Commission should respond to Parliament's request and present the report on the completion of the single market as soon as possible.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the governance of the single market in the European Semester. I believe that establishing annual governance cycles can improve single market management and that this ultimately increases social cohesion, attracts investment and strengthens sustainable growth. I will conclude by emphasising the need for this new pillar of the European Semester to be focused on clear priorities linked to the real economy.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report recognises that the increase in unemployment and the growth of poverty and social exclusion is due to the impact of "fiscal consolidation". However, in the proposals it continues to advocate for measures that have been integrated into the policy of fiscal consolidation and structural reforms, which have led precisely to the problems that the report itself has seen. These are the measures that have led to lower wages, lay-offs, cuts in public investment opposed to economic growth and therefore responsible for increasing the unemployment rate. The report recommends, for example, continued fiscal consolidation and structural reforms, flexicurity, the alignment of wages with productivity and the increase in the retirement age, the promotion of mobility as a means of reducing unemployment in some countries. We voted against it.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. The six months of economic policy coordination have been characterised in recent years by the cold severity with which the European Commission imposes suffocating rules on Member States. Rules too often inspired only by austerity, which undermine national autonomy and sovereignty. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the European Semester should be the time to see where we are with the construction of the single market that we have been pursuing for a long time, in which all consumers are given equal rights and guarantees, in order to ensure that common membership of the European home becomes a source of opportunity and not just of obligations. In particular, we need to coordinate concrete initiatives to support domestic demand, paying particular attention to the needs of the most vulnerable consumers, in order to create a large market in which the same rules really apply to everyone. Electronic transactions, especially cross-border transactions, are becoming increasingly important. If we want to encourage these activities, we must give uniformity and coherence to the regulatory framework: online consumers must be guaranteed a level of protection equal to that to which they are accustomed in the traditional market.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on single market governance in the context of the 2015 European Semester, which is a key mechanism for coordinating member states' economic policies, preventing excessive macroeconomic imbalances, ensuring sound public finances and economic stability of the EU. The semester is supposed to ensure that countries really take into account the objectives they have set each other at EU level, which is important because their economies are strongly linked. It is good to also include the unification and deepening of the single market in the European Semester, with a particular focus on the Single Energy Market and the Digital Single Market. The Single Market is a tool for boosting economic growth and creating quality jobs in the EU, but more than 20 years after its official establishment it is still not complete. The completion of the Digital Single Market could generate an additional 0.4% GDP growth (EUR 520 billion compared to 2014) by 2020 and an increase in employment of around 0.1% (more than 223 000 new jobs by 2020). The creation of a single energy market, however, would bring greater security to the EU in the area of energy supply and greater independence from Russia. Unfortunately, the current implementation rate of the European Semester is very low, so all countries, large and small, must respect more the rules of the Stability and Growth Pact, which is the cornerstone of the European Semester.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I welcome the intentions of the text, which are the fight against pedophilia and child abuse and against the distribution of images of this type of violence, and I share the importance of taking action in this area. However, the non-reference to a prior court order for the disposal of materials from the internet would set a dangerous precedent. In addition, an interested reference is made to the dark network, when less than 1% of these contents come from there, which would mean another attempt to end online privacy. Access to private citizenship data without a court order is unacceptable and, instead of lowering European data protection standards, it should move towards faster justice, with specialized cybercrime units with sufficient resources to do their job.  That is why, despite sharing the objective pursued by the Resolution, I reject the proposed ways to reach it, and that is why I abstained in the vote of the Resolution on combating online child sexual abuse.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I abstained on this resolution as my party's focus is primarily on the safety and well-being of the child. It is our collective responsibility to ensure that there are genuine measures to protect children, but we must ensure such measures are appropriate and proportionate; to ensure that measures protecting children are balanced with children's rights to access information on the internet and utilise it for educational and communication purposes; to protect fundamental rights of people in relation to internet freedom; and to protect against the privatisation of internet security/policing. The resolution that we tabled was child-centred and protected the best interests of the child. Moreover, unlike the resolutions from the other groups, the GUE/NGL resolution respects legal due process and the separation of powers, balanced with the protection of children's rights and citizens' fundamental and democratic rights.  For this reason we abstained on the joint motion for a resolution.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. Children are the most vulnerable group in today's society and should be most protected as a result. Sexual abuse and exploitation of children constitute serious violations of fundamental rights which must continue to be combated. This motion for a resolution is, without a doubt, right and important.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. The motion for a resolution on the fight against child pornography on the internet calls on Member States to improve cooperation with law enforcement systems and to increase human and material resources taking into account technological developments to combat these crimes against children. The defence of children's rights is particularly important to me, and I naturally voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I have abstained on this resolution because it causes a conflict between two fundamental principles: 1. It calls for more power to be given to Europol and Eurojust, organisations which lack the required democratic scrutiny, rather than to Interpol. It calls for further EU funding in terms of education and campaigns, when such campaigns are best left to the Member States. I oppose these points in principle. 2. It calls for tougher action to be taken against child sexual abuse, it recognises the scale of such abuse and opposes the possession and distribution of ‘child pornography’ (though the report also questions the use of such terminology). I am strongly in favour of these points in principle.

name: Guillaume Balas (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on the fight against child pornography on the internet to strengthen the protection of children's rights; in a worrying context of the development of commercial sexual exploitation of children online, including through new models of commercial distribution and child pornography transactions, including the Darknet, and in particular the phenomenon of the live dissemination of child pornography content for payment. Children are also at risk of intimidation, harassment and "childishness". The European Union and its Member States must therefore protect and guarantee a safe environment for children and their development. Protecting minors in the digital sphere means strengthening information, children first, parents and teachers, so that minors know how to use the internet safely.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to combat child sexual abuse and to stop the spread of pedophilia on the Internet. I support calls on EU Member States to step up their efforts in the implementation of the 2011 Directive on combating the sexual exploitation of children, to ensure more effective prosecution and to cooperate more closely with providers of online services and the EUROPOL agency in order to remove illegal images.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to combat this monostrosity that is child pornography... but I will remain vigilant because "Big Brother" is all too inclined to confuse a criminal "Dark Web" and a "Deep Web" that is mainly used by peaceful dissidents and other whistleblowers, who were able to reveal by this way the scandalous eavesdropping of the NSA ...

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. It is our responsibility to protect and ensure a safe environment for children and their development, including on the internet, and in cooperation with all relevant levels of power in and beyond the European Union.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. With the development of the internet and new technologies, unfortunately, practices are also developing encouraging fraud, trafficking or, more importantly, child pornography, which is the subject of this resolution. In order to protect our children, it is vital to fight this growing problem. We need to ensure more effective prosecutions, raise awareness of the situation and reduce the amount of child pornography available online. An initiative by the European Union and 55 countries has been taken in this direction, but we must go further and the Member States must be able to put in place, in a spirit of international cooperation, a policy of prevention, detection but also effective repression. Nevertheless, I would like to remain vigilant on the internet as a space for freedom of expression and on the possible abuses of control that this project could bring. I therefore abstained on this proposal.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution which not only represents the best compromise between the texts presented by the different political groups, but above all focuses on the call for closer cooperation between Europol and the national authorities to combat the commercial exploitation of children online and the removal from the network of content potentially most dangerous to children.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted in favour of the resolution. The sexual abuse of children and the best interests of children must be put first, and I believe that further action is needed to combat this type of crime against children.  On the other hand, I believe, however, that the GUE/NGL motion for a resolution was clearer in terms of proportionality and necessity, and especially with regard to people's fundamental rights in relation to public authorities and internet service providers. I believe that it is absolutely necessary to make a clear distinction between the responsibilities of private actors (e.g. ISP) on the one hand, and law enforcement and prosecution authorities on the other. With this clarification, I choose to vote in favour of the resolution.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because the protection of minors and the guarantee of a safe environment for their development is and should be a priority for the EU, also in the digital environment. The worrying evolution of pedophile threats on the internet, including increased demand, violence and the use of social media as a method of attracting minors, requires determined action by the EU and Member States to combat and eradicate such threats and criminal behaviour.  Of course, a comprehensive and coordinated European approach is needed, but also to strengthen international cooperation to combat child sexual abuse by effectively investigating, dismantling and pursuing child sex crime networks. In this regard, I believe that the joint initiative of the EU and fifty-five other countries within the framework of the Global Alliance against Online Child Abuse will make a decisive contribution to achieving this objective.  It is also necessary to involve law ensuring the rights and protection of children on the internet.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Reports of child sexual abuse online show alarming trends. There is a growing demand for online content depicting child sexual abuse, there is more violence in such content and the age of victims is getting lower.  According to Europol, 10% of victims are under two years old. The development and availability of technology creates a great space for manipulation. It is very difficult for police to trace the perpetrators, and the content at issue remains online, presenting lasting trauma for the victims. It is estimated that every year uploads about 50 thousand disputed photos. I believe that joint action at the supranational level is a necessary precondition for the successful suppression of these trends. Parliament must create the most effective legislation by which the police and judiciary will act to tackle this frightening problem the fastest.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Our focus in this resolution is on the safety and well-being of the child. It is our responsibility to ensure that there are genuine measures to protect children, but we must ensure such measures are appropriate and proportionate; to ensure that measures protecting children are balanced with children's rights to access information on the internet and utilise it for educational and communication purposes; to protect fundamental rights of people in relation to internet freedom; and to protect against the privatisation of internet security/policing.  Unlike the resolutions from the other groups, the GUE/NGL resolution respects legal due process and the separation of powers, balanced with respect for citizens' fundamental and democratic rights. For this reason we abstained on the joint motion for a resolution.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. These motions for a resolution aim to combat the worrying phenomenon of child pornography more effectively. The emergence of new technologies and communication, such as the internet, has changed child pornography practices and has necessitated stronger detection and response policies. While this struggle is in the best interests of child protection, it should not become a pretext for the widespread guardianship of the internet. This is why prevention needs to be improved among at-risk audiences and parents should be empowered. Finally, the strengthening of the criminal arsenal against child criminality must be a priority for Member States to strongly condemn those who commit such vile acts. If the fight against child pornography requires better coordination between Member States, there is no reason why their powers should be transferred to EU level in this area.  Naturally, I voted for these motions for a resolution.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Sexual exploitation of children online is a flagrant violation of fundamental rights and a particularly serious criminal act that requires immediate and concerted action to identify those who commit it. Although I support free and confidential access to the internet, I believe that the sexual exploitation of children online must be subject to clear rules and that such abuses can be easily identified. Anonymous online communities, information encryption, or electronic payment methods through virtual currencies make tracking suspects very difficult. Common measures should therefore be put in place to allow access to data flows with suspicious destinations. I support this resolution and categorically combat any abuse against minors in the virtual environment! I am convinced that data service providers can contribute more effectively to identifying and blocking those who do it.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 The text is not critical and is the best compromise between the texts presented by the various groups. The fight against internet abuse against children is an issue that sees all Members united.

name: Cristian-Silviu Bușoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Child sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children, including images of child abuse, are serious violations of the fundamental rights of children stipulated in the 1989 United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. The Internet can expose children to sexual exploitation materials, cyber "predators", exchanges of violent content, intimidation, harassment or luring children for sexual purposes. Measures to combat these offences must be centred on the best interests of the child and be in line with the rights of the child. Serious crimes such as child sexual exploitation and child abuse images require a comprehensive approach that includes investigating crime, prosecuting offenders, protecting child victims and preventing it.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Children are likely to be victims of criminals who misuse the internet. We must fight against images and other child pornography that circulate on the internet. Children must be protected at all costs and this requires an increased and appropriate prevention campaign. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on online child sexual abuse. I have to record, unfortunately, that so far less than half of the Member States have implemented Directive 2011/93/EU on combating the sexual abuse and exploitation of children and child pornography, which should have been transposed by the Member States on 18 December 2013. This makes me realise how far the problem is from the solution. On this issue must therefore be present maximum alert and caution against the negative potential of a very useful and essential tool such as the Internet, whose use by minors, if not managed, emphasizes and makes possible specific risks on minors, such as violence, intimidation, bullying or baiting as well as more generically redeemability and progressive invasiveness of harmful behaviors. It is painful to see that according to information provided by NGOs on Internet pages containing child abuse material, more than 80% of victims are under the age of 10. Consequently, I strongly urge The Member States to make every effort to transpose Directive 2011/93/EU, calling on the Commission to closely monitor its full and effective implementation.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this resolution as my party's focus is primarily on the safety and well-being of the child. It is our collective responsibility to ensure that there are genuine measures to protect children, but we must ensure such measures are appropriate and proportionate; to ensure that measures protecting children are balanced with children's rights to access information on the internet and utilise it for educational and communication purposes; to protect fundamental rights of people in relation to internet freedom; and to protect against the privatisation of internet security/policing.  The resolution that we tabled was child-centred and protected the best interests of the child. Moreover, unlike the resolutions from the other groups, the GUE/NGL resolution respects legal due process and the separation of powers, balanced with the protection of children's rights and citizens' fundamental and democratic rights. For this reason we abstained on the joint motion for a resolution.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The data provided, both by NGOs and institutional bodies, clearly show how the use of the Internet can have negative implications of great importance. It is therefore necessary to introduce effective safeguard systems, so that the web does not become an instrument of crime, and worse, of a crime such as the abuse of children.  The instruments developed to date have not been up to scratch, and it is therefore important that we make a joint effort, at European as well as state level, to turn the situation around.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to protect children from sexual predators on the internet. If the nternet offers an undeniable space of freedom, it is necessary, as the resolution does, to recall that the best interests of the child must be a primary consideration for the legislator. However, the internet can expose children to certain risks, as they may access or be exposed to child pornography or be exposed to cyber predators. I therefore welcome this resolution which provides for the protection of the child, his physical and psychological integrity and his image.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. – Children are our future and we must do everything in our power to keep them safe. The EU has the chance to establish laws that will apply across borders, something which is ever more relevant when we are dealing with crimes perpetrated through the Internet. The Directive on combating sexual abuse and exploitation of child on the Internet finally lays down the common minimum sanctions for the offences. It is now up to the individual Member States to transpose this Directive into effective national law.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the spread of the Internet, the abuse and forms of sexual exploitation of children, often for profit, have multiplied with business models of commercial distribution and types of new transactions. Tools such as chats, forums, live streams, the submerged internet, the darknet, image and movie encryption offer unprecedented opportunities for baiting and enrichment, while making it easier, more profitable and more difficult to discover often very serious activities to the detriment of minors. And it turns out that over 80% of the victims are under 10 years old. The resolution – in addition to urging states to implement important expired or expiring directives (Directive 92/2011 against the sexual abuse and exploitation of children, 'expired' in 2013, and Directive 29/2012 on victims). By entrusting the LIBE Commission with a deepening of the current framework on combating child sexual abuse – it identifies various measures, on the one hand, to combat these phenomena, including through a system of exchange of information between all those involved, including internet providers and banks; and, on the other hand, to protect victims, to start with the complete removal of material circulating online, to prevent secondary or "chronic" victimizations. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The sexual abuse and exploitation of children through online, I consider it a problem to be combated with the utmost energy. The measure before us provides for important initiatives to combat this exploitation. In particular, I believe that cyber predators must be prosecuted so that they cannot threaten young people or children through extortion and psychological blackmail. For these reasons, I have decided to vote in favour of the measure

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure because the sexual exploitation of children and the sexual abuse of children online continue to be a matter of great concern to me, and I strongly support all initiatives aimed at combating such exploitation. In particular, I believe that all young people who are persuaded or forced to send or publish sexually explicit images of themselves should be protected, because this allows cyber predators to blackmail children, with unscrupulous use of psychological violence absolutely to be condemned.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution focuses on one of the most pressing problems of the new virtual world and which - despite the efforts that have already been made - unfortunately continues to happen and put our children at risk.  It is therefore crucial to respond to the dangers that still abound on the internet and to ensure that the authorities have an effective monitoring and prevention capability. Not least, the Union and the Member States should also make their efforts to improve the awareness of educators, families and children themselves. But it is still the responsibility for member states to rapidly implement the Community framework in this area, ensuring concerted action for this phenomenon that knows no borders. In this context, the in-depth analysis to be carried out by the LIBE Commission on this matter is of particular importance and I will put every effort into it to better protect our children throughout the Union. For all this, I could only vote in favour of this resolution and contribute to the broad consensus it has managed to achieve.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Child sexual abuse online is a crime that is ubiquitous and knows no borders. Child pornography offenders are increasingly operating in international online groups that use high standard technology and security protocols to frustrate the efforts of law enforcement to investigate their crimes. We need to focus on prevention and need effective campaigns to support parents and educators on how to identify the online risks and an effective mechanism for reporting suspected sexual behaviour. We need further EU action with the commitment of online platforms, internet providers and other stakeholders outside of the EU as well to fight against online child exploitation and to build powerful reporting tools and educational resources.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The sexual abuse and exploitation of children, including images of child abuse, constitute serious violations of fundamental rights, in particular the right of children to the protection and care necessary for their well-being. Furthermore, the international nature of the problem – child exploitation and the sexual exploitation of children online affects hundreds of countries and involves hundreds of jurisdictions and law enforcement authorities – requires an international solution.  That is why I agree with and voted in favour of the directive which, among other things, stresses the need to take measures to combat the lure of children online and considers that the Commission, together with national governments, civil society, social media companies, parents, teachers, social workers, child protection officers and , paediatricians and childcare and adolescence organisations, must play an active role in raising awareness of this issue through defined guidelines, including through the exchange of good practices and the creation of social platforms for cooperation and the exchange of information on the subject, with a view to identifying potential risks and threats to children.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am pleased that a number of words that I have tabled have been included in the joint resolution on sexual abuse of children on the Internet. Displaying child sexual abuse online is a serious crime that requires a comprehensive approach. This should include effective criminalisation, the accountability of perpetrators, the protection of victims of childhood and steps to prevent this phenomenon. Effective, proportionate and dissuasive sanctions against offenders are essential. The Internet is becoming more widely accessible, but it also carries increasing dangers that many minors do not realize. Since images and videos can be shared long after sexual abuse has occurred and remain freely available to anyone on the Internet, victims are constantly in danger of being victimised and stigmatised again. Special attention should also be paid to darknet, which presents specific challenges. I consider it important that existing EU legislation, in particular Directive 2011/93/EU on combating child sexual abuse, should be transcreated immediately by all Member States into their national legal order. We need a coordinated European approach. In order to act effectively, it is essential that Member States take seriously their commitments in European and international for a and do everything possible to protect children. That is why I supported the report with my vote.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As a signatory of the joint motion for resolution on the fight against child sexual abuse on the Internet and as a convinced advocate on the matter I was more than happy to vote in favour of this joint motion for resolution which signals that the European Parliament wants to take this measure seriously. This motion for a resolution emphasises a key principle that I have brought forward to the European Parliament last February including the need to educate children through awareness campaigns, self-regulation by the industry and the need to address the Darknet.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that international cooperation with the EU's strategic partners and law enforcement authorities around the world is needed to combat the proliferation of child sexual exploitation material. I believe that both the Commission and the Member States need to strengthen their cooperation between law enforcement authorities, including through Europol and the European Cybercrime Centre (EC3), with a view to investigating, eliminating and prosecuting networks of persons guilty of sexual offences against children, more effectively, while prioritising the rights and safety of the children involved.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This resolution calls on the European Commission to monitor the effective implementation of the existing positive law on the fight against child pornography by the competent authorities of the Member States. The protection of children must be one of the main objectives of the European Union, and this resolution considers that there is a need to improve international cooperation in investigating, dismantling and prosecuting paedophile networks more effectively, while at the same time prioritizing the rights and safety of affected children. In this context, it is also important to organise greater cooperation with multimedia and social media companies to combat these crimes. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The vote on this resolution on the fight against child pornography on the internet is a strong sign of the European Parliament's commitment to this issue. In supporting this resolution, I wanted to stress in particular the need for greater cooperation between the competent services active in the fight against this phenomenon, in particular by relying more on Europol and the European Cybercrime Centre. As such, the European Parliament has called for an effective partnership and information exchange system between the relevant services. The sharing of information is an essential aspect of this struggle, as the Internet promotes the blurring of national borders and develops transnational offences.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I am pleased that Parliament has taken a concrete initiative to combat child pornography on the internet.
