I voted in favour of this text because it encompasses a large number of key aspects: the rapid removal of illegal content, reporting to member states' law enforcement agencies, measures to combat online child care, etc. I welcome the fact that the text strongly advocates for a comprehensive approach to the phenomenon and for wider collaboration, and that it does not forget to address the situation of victims of sexual abuse on the net. However, I consider that the resolution could also have included provisions against cyber predators. The manipulation of children on the internet for sexual purposes is not the only example of cyberpredation. There are other forms of manipulation for the purpose of committing or committing a criminal act, kidnapping, incitement to hatred, suicide or anorexia, terrorist recruitment, misappropriation of personal data, etc. In addition, additional initiatives could be considered to codify the status of a minor in cyberspace.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – Sexual abuse of children seriously affects fundamental rights. The online emergence of such abuses requires a comprehensive approach, including criminal investigation, prosecution of perpetrators, protection of child victims and preventive measures. Sexual exploitation can take many forms in an online environment and involves children being threatened with sharing images/videos if they do not continue their sexual activities. The problem is international in nature and in most cases only a small part of it is reported to law enforcement authorities, which requires swift and effective cross-border action against child sexual exploitation.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. The motion for a resolution on the fight against child pornography on the internet calls on Member States to improve cooperation with law enforcement systems and to increase human and material resources taking into account technological developments to combat these crimes against children. The defence of children's rights is particularly important to me, and I naturally voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution as the issue of child sexual abuse on the internet is non-negotiable and we must all oppose it. This issue is becoming increasingly important against the backdrop of a growing digital society with almost unlimited access to information, which, on the one hand, has an inclusive effect on adults but on the other, can pose a serious threat to the youngest members of our society who are most susceptible to harmful and unreliable information. Unfortunately, there are too many cases revealing the imperfections of the current safeguard measures, and it is therefore imperative to put this issue on the agenda. There is a huge need for additional protection and it is our common responsibility to work towards creating a safe digital space for future generations to have free access to information.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report because any measure against child pornography is welcome. My only objection is the need for even greater tightening of measures against those who commit such heinous crimes.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 There is an increase in sexual violence against minors in the internet. These crimes leave serious aftermath in the victims, who are increasingly young (more than 10% of them are under the age of 2). New technologies are fully rooted in the daily lives of European children and adolescents, while advancing rapidly and leading to the creation of "dark spaces" on the network through which criminals commit their crimes with increasing impunity. Efforts to protect victims must therefore increase in parallel. More efficient control is needed on the internet, so that these crimes are effectively prosecuted and punished until they are fully eradicated. Everyone's will is not enough to achieve results. Because of the international nature of these crimes, cooperation needs to be strengthened because it is the only way to suppress them, as each State cannot fight this crime individually and an effort must be made at European and global level to coordinate instruments to combat sexual abuse on the internet.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. Through this legislation, the European Parliament aims to combat the sexual exploitation of children by cracking down on criminals, raising the protection of children who are victims of crime and betting on the prevention of the phenomenon. The wording of this resolution had already been agreed with the different political groups of the EP, demonstrating the relevance and relevance of the theme. There is, in fact, a convergence as to the need for the adoption of measures to manage child pornopornographic content on the internet, the existence of sufficient legal instruments to investigate and prosecute criminals, early childhood education through easily understandable ways for children to protect their personal data on the net, European cooperation and the establishment of best practices.  The proposal also aims to address a new dimension of the phenomenon, including its expansion through the "deep web", and urges representatives of alternative payment systems (e.g. bitcoin) to join in the fight against child abuse, while strengthening the competence of judicial and police units in the field of high technology to address the challenge of analysing the large volume of images or pedopornographic materials.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. More efforts need to be made to investigate child sexual abuse on the Internet, prosecute criminals, protect children and suppress illegal content online. More than 80% of children who are victims of sexual abuse on the net are under the age of ten. Sexual exploitation of children and images of abuse need to be dealt with comprehensively, including the investigation of these crimes, the repression of criminals, the protection of children and the prevention of this phenomenon. I agree that illicit content should be immediately withdrawn and communicated to the police authorities, that Europol and national law enforcement authorities should be endorsed with the funding, human resources, investigative skills and technical capabilities they need to investigate and prosecute criminals effectively. EU countries that have not yet transposed the 2011 Directive on combating sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children and child pornography into national law should do so.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We share the general concerns expressed in this resolution. The internet can expose children to specific risks. Measures are needed to ensure their defence. However, the resolution does not avoid mixing concepts and fair concerns with intentions that could be attacked against fundamental rights and freedoms. Restricting widespread access to information technologies, mobile communications and the internet are obvious dangers. It is necessary to ensure that, under the UNCRC, the child has the right to freedom of expression, which includes the freedom to seek, receive and disseminate information, and that children are given the right to access information and materials from various national and international sources. It is also the role of states and companies providing these services to provide information to children and young people so that they can effectively manage risks and know who to turn to for help.  States should have sufficient resources to prevent cyberpredation and cyber-harassment content on the Internet, policies that have led to underfunding of educational programmes aimed at children and parents to protect children from these risks must be reversed.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: writing \ u2012 One of the main objectives in the area of respect for fundamental human rights is to protect children and ensure a safe environment for their undisturbed development. The rapid technological advancement and development of the Internet, but in particular illegal content or children's personal data on the Internet, justify the adoption of measures ensuring the immediate removal of illegal content, its reporting to the competent authorities and the subsequent investigation and prosecution of perpetrators. The cross-border nature of the Internet requires a comprehensive and coordinated European approach that includes combating this crime, together with the protection of fundamental rights, privacy and data. The European Commission, together with Member State governments, civil society, social media companies, parents, teachers and so on, must also play an active role in raising awareness of this issue in order to identify potential risks and threats to children.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support this joint resolution of the various groups calling not only for greater attention in the internet/child combination, but also for the fight against the commercial sexual exploitation of children online.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I agree and vote in favour of the joint motion for a resolution to combat child sexual abuse on the Internet . Any measure against child pornography is welcome. My only objection is the need for even greater tightening of measures against those who commit such heinous crimes. My firm position is to reinstate the death penalty for proven juvenile rapists.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution. This is one area where the EU can work together to protect the vulnerable. Since this type of crime is not confined to individual Member States, a Europe-wide approach may be beneficial for organising cooperation between law enforcement agencies.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Directive 2011/93/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of 13 December 2011 aims to combat sexual abuse, sexual exploitation of children and child pornography, and harmonises criminal offences relating to sexual abuse committed against children throughout the EU. It also lays down the common minimum sanctions for the offences. I therefore voted in favour of adoption of the report in plenary.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As one of the drafters of the text, I would like to welcome the resolution that has just been adopted on online child abuse, which is another milestone in the fight against cyber-bullying that is increasingly endangering our children. Unfortunately, the generations that are now growing up have been particularly exposed to this cruel form of abuse, which is becoming more and more easily victim as the Internet spreads and technology advances. We need exemplary international cooperation to stem the spread of child sexual abuse online. I would like to welcome the fact that the European Commission is taking particular account of this area. By supporting hotlines, setting up awareness-raising centres and exchanging information, we can indeed act more effectively to protect our children at EU level, as the Internet knows no borders, so it is not enough to combat this phenomenon individually at Member State level.  The Global Alliance against Child Online Abuse, of which 54 states are currently members worldwide, is also helping to take global action. A comprehensive, international association of legal, technical and educational measures alone will enable us to effectively combat these threats, which penetrate even the most protected children's rooms through the world of the Internet.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 Minors are one of the most defenceless groups in our society, so we must extreme protective measures towards this group. The sexual abuse and exploitation of minors, including images related to child sexual abuse, constitute serious violations of fundamental rights. The fight against child abuse on the Internet must be one of our priorities in this area, so the authorities must investigate and punish all possible cases of abuse, bearing in mind that we are facing a global problem, so international cooperation is essential. It is our duty to protect and defend those who cannot do so on their own.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Young people represent the most precious resource we have, our future: it is from the way a society protects them that you understand humanity and the value of it. 91% of EU children have access to the Internet and the number of hours children aged 12-15 spend online each week rose from 14.9 in 2011 to 17.1 in 2012, an increase of almost 15%. The virtual environment, due to its peculiarities, is increasingly dangerous for minors who are lent here through increasingly devious and technically advanced means. In the light of these facts, it is therefore more necessary than ever for measures to be taken at EU level to ensure safe online access for all children and for the means to identify and punish those guilty of one of the most reprehensible and repulsive crimes that can be thought of to be increased.  For these reasons, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution, which addresses this tragic problem with a pragmatic and concrete approach.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I fully support and support Parliament's resolution on combating child pornography and online child abuse. Access to modern technologies represents a rich, informative and accessible potential for all, but we must put in place all the tools that prevent risks and traps for children, which could all too easily underestimate the risks involved. In line with the EU Agenda for the Rights of the Child adopted in 2011, the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child and, above all, Directive 93 of 2011, Europe is confirmed in its role as guarantor of citizens' rights and, in particular, of the well-being and protection of children, exercising every action that allows to guarantee access to information for the little ones controlled, protecting them from the many potential hidden threats connected such as sexual ly having sex, bullying, induction to exploitation, trafficking in child pornography images or videos, threats and mortifications to which children can all too easily be exposed thanks to the ambiguity of anonymity, the dark web or encrypted languages. Europe is intervening to limit the dangers of the children's network, through operations of greater control, cooperation and exchange of transnational information between national law enforcement authorities, Europol, and the European Centre for Cybercrime. Let us strengthen legislative coordination so as to immediately block and report the online posting of illegal content, promoting effective information campaigns for children, but also for schools and parents, and ensuring that Directive 2011/93 is finally finally effectively transposed by all Member States.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The debate of the last few days has once again sanctioned the political role of Parliament, an authoritative bulwark against any violation of human rights, especially if the victims show a particular vulnerability. Therefore, on the side of boys and girls, members of the European Parliament always take the side. Digital violence against children through modern technology is a threat to the human capital of our children for whom every level of responsibility must be recalled. Our responsibility as legislators, that of all the European institutions and the governments of the Member States called upon to implement any useful action from the point of view of repression, is accompanied by the responsibility of the education agencies. Raising the awareness of every institutional level involved in training and education, which also involves the families who are the first actresses of the training course, can and must be the useful strategy to create an effective protection network against the violence of images and words. My firm vote supports the content of the resolution.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. •u2012 Child sexual abuse on the Internet constitutes a serious violation of human rights. Member States should take concrete steps without delay to address this growing phenomenon. I am deeply alarmed that there are still eight Member States which have not fully transposed the Directive on combating sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of minors and child pornography adopted in 2011. Child sexual abuse knows no boundaries. It is urgent to strengthen international cooperation and transnational investigations and to improve prevention and reporting mechanisms in this area. Internet providers need to play a key role in alerting and quickly removing illegal content from the network. I can only strongly support this Resolution, which calls for an effective joint approach involving the administration of Justice, law ensuring the protection of children and their rights on the internet.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, because monsters must be stopped. The figures are alarming. Abuse is increasing, the age of the victims is falling, violence is increasing. And what we know are just trends. We are aware of the tragedy of online abuse, but we are not fully aware of the spread of this worrying phenomenon. What can we do to protect our children, our future? First of all, to strengthen police resources and international cooperation, that no one can hide behind a computer any more, we must attack the dark web. Then you have to involve the world of ITC companies, so that no one feels excluded. Finally, we must educate and raise awareness of the safe use of the Internet. To make known the potential of the network, but also the risks it entails.  The network is by nature agile and fast. It is necessary for the protection to travel at its own speed.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the joint motion for a joint resolution on the fight against child pornography on the internet. In particular, this proposal aims to increase the material and human resources to combat child pornography on the Internet, taking into account technological developments. It also underlines the importance of cooperation between Member States, which still needs to be improved in effectiveness. Nevertheless, I will be vigilant about the protection of freedoms on the Internet, namely freedom of expression and respect for privacy, which must be guaranteed to the vast majority of Internet users who do not commit crimes.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. I consider the sexual exploitation of children to be one of the worst crimes in the world. I support the harshest punishments against those who commit them, including the death penalty for the organizers of paedophile networks. I am aware that the internet is a great tool for communication and exchange, for everyone, including people with abhorrent practices. The text calls for strengthening the fight against this type of crime and, for once, for increased cooperation between national authorities and law enforcement agencies, rather than wanting to give the Commission prerogatives. I am in favour of all this, even though I believe that the States did not wait for the European Parliament's resolution to do so. But I keep in mind, thanks to the United States, that the legitimate fight against crime and criminals can degenerate into systematic, illegitimate and immoral surveillance of all citizens and a violation of their rights, freedoms and privacy. On this point, the text is not clear, even silent, retaining for example only traffic on the "dark web", but obscuring the fact that Chinese dissidents or whistleblowers also shelter there. That's why I abstained.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck (ALDE)
text: In writing. Sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children and child pornography are dramatic, monstrous and ever-increasing scourges and constitute serious violations of fundamental rights. This resolution calls for an in-depth analysis of the current policies in the fight against child sexual abuse, which will be carried out in the coming months by the parliamentary committee LIBE, in which I sit. It is scandalous that more than half of the Member States have not yet transposed the 2011/92/EU Directive on the fight against sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children and child pornography! Member States must take immediate action. It is also essential that companies in the sector engage in this fight, particularly with regard to the removal of illegal content online. I therefore welcome the adoption of the cross-party resolution on the fight against child pornography on the internet.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ It is absolutely essential that we work together, and do more, to protect our children, across all Member States, and across the world, against paedophilia.  The internet can be the source of very many good things - connections, creativity and business possibilities – but we must not ignore its negative sides.  We must work to combat the growing rise of paedophilia online and the shady networks that hide behind advanced levels of encryption. We must not let them hide in the ‘shadowy web’ and prey on our innocents.  More and better technological capabilities need to be employed by agencies and authorities to ensure that child pornography cannot be created and distributed in this secretive and so-called anonymous world.  More must be done to enforce the 2011 Directive to combat the sexual abuse and exploitation of children and to make sure that Member States and Europol are doing more to tackle and eradicate these horrific crimes, with more effective investigations and prosecutions. We must not and cannot fail our children.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. On Wednesday, I voted in favour of a resolution to combat child pornography on the internet, 80% of whose victims are children under the age of 10. Child pornography, through the internet, threatens the safety of our children on a daily basis. It is therefore essential to protect them from the risks conveyed on the Web, such as access to services inappropriate for their age, bullying, cybercrime or the solicitation of children for sexual purposes. The resolution calls for more cooperation between Member States and members of the international community to combat child pornography, including encouraging the establishment of a centralised information exchange system between law enforcement agencies, judicial authorities, internet service providers, NGOs and the banking sector.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the fight against child pornography on the internet. While the current EU data protection reform contains changes that will better protect children's rights on the internet, European arrangements already exist in this area. These include the 2011 directive on "the fight against sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children and child pornography". However, more than half of the Member States have not yet transposed this directive into national law. The message from the European Parliament to the Member States is therefore clear: a mechanism has been adopted at European level, now it's up to you!  Apart from the urgency of transposing the 2011 directive, the European Parliament also defended the need to develop a comprehensive strategy in this area. This strategy covers both the investigation of offences and prosecutions against their perpetrators, the protection of child victims and the prevention of the phenomenon. Given the transnational dimension of the scourge, this global approach must obviously not stop at Europe's borders, but be brought to the international level.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the fight against child sexual abuse on the Internet. First, it is our responsibility to ensure a safe environment for children's development. Second, national governments, civil society, social media companies, parents, teachers and social workers must play an active role in raising awareness of this issue. There should be social platforms for cooperation and the exchange of information on this subject, with a view to identifying potential risks and threats to children.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. Child pornography on the internet is a scourge that thrives in the absence of harmonization of national laws.  This resolution is a wake-up call. The Member States of the Union and even all the States in the world must propose common solutions to put an end to this phenomenon which threatens our children. As you should know, 80% of the victims are children under the age of 10.  The establishment of special cells within our police services is a good thing to track down paedophiles. However, I remain convinced that upstream action to empower internet service providers would greatly amplify our means of preventing and combating child pornography. As with terrorism, we always return to the perennial debate on freedom on the Internet, namely: should information be regulated and limited? In this particular case, where minors are endangered, I believe that limiting and removing access to illegal content is amply justified.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst criminal law remains a national competence, there are clearly certain areas where pan-EU cooperation can greatly assist the fight against crime. Child sexual abuse on the internet is one such area and I welcome today's report.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the development and comprehensive use of high-speed Internet and with a view to turning social networking sites into a social and economic phenomenon that has changed the face of communication and information exchange, the youngest and most vulnerable members of our society are exposed to specific dangers such as cybercrime, dissemination of violent content material, cyber-espionage, misuse of personal information and data. The resolution on combating child sexual abuse on the internet is extremely important as it focuses on this serious problem and on the need to develop a comprehensive approach and a broad strategy to combat child abuse and exploitation on the internet and to protect the best interests of the child.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because of the urgent need to pursue all sexual abuse against children on social media and create a healthy developmental environment for minors.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a resolution to combat child sexual abuse online, as new modern technological opportunities also create new threats to safety. The Internet and other possibilities of new technologies are particularly dangerous because legal regulations and legal practices are not fast enough and with their solutions they are largely lagging behind possible threats. In this sense, but also because of the obvious existence of child abuse that is not as of today, and with new technologies it only gets new opportunities and different forms of manifestation, I strongly support this resolution as well as the continuation of the fight against probably the worst form of abuse.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. The proposed resolution on the fight against child pornography on the internet calls on Member States to improve cooperation with law enforcement systems and to increase human and material resources taking into account technological developments to combat these crimes against children. Considering that child pornography on the internet is one of the scourges of the 19th century, I voted for this text, while remaining vigilant on the subject of individual freedoms.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am deeply concerned about the protection of children from harmful content on the internet. It is important that we strengthen protective mechanisms which ensure that children are not sexually exploited through online platforms. I support developing early-warning systems to flag harmful content and believe that it is essential that we do all in our power to ensure that children can safely use the internet.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the fight against child pornography on the internet, which affects 80% of children under the age of 10. In particular, the text recalls the responsibility of the digital industry to prevent access to illegal content and to remove it at the request of the authorities, thus the duty of Member States to transpose a 2011 directive on the subject, less than half of them having done so despite the deadline set for December 2013. The resolution was adopted by an overwhelming majority of 606 in the right, 4 against and 67 abstentions.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ EH Bildu has abstained on the vote on joint motion for a resolution RC8-0217/2015 on the fight against child sexual abuse on the internet tabled by EPP, S&D, ECR, ALDE and EFDD as we believe that it is our responsibility to ensure there are genuine measures to protect children, however, we must ensure such measures are appropriate and proportionate; that measures protecting children are balanced with children’s rights to access information on the internet and utilisation for educational and communication purposes; to protect fundamental rights of people in relation to internet freedom; and to protect against the privatisation of internet security/policing. Unlike the resolutions from the other groups, the GUE/NGL resolution respects legal due process and the separation of powers, balanced with respect for citizens’ fundamental and democratic rights.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on the fight against child pornography on the internet. Sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children, including child pornography, constitute extremely serious violations of fundamental rights, in particular the right of the child to the protection and care necessary for his well-being, as enshrined in the 1989 Un Convention on the Rights of the Child and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.  It is now our duty to launch an information campaign involving all relevant stakeholders to empower children and help parents and teachers understand and manage risks online, as well as protect children's safety online. Member States must also be helped to set up online sexual abuse prevention programmes, encourage awareness campaigns on responsible behaviour on social media and encourage leading search engines and social media networks to take a proactive approach to protecting children's safety online.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 Combating the sexual abuse of children on the Internet I supported this motion for a resolution because sexual abuse and exploitation of children in general, but also in particular on the Internet, where they are potentially exposed to specific risks, constitute serious violations of fundamental human rights, as provided for in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, but also in the 1989 International Convention on the Rights of the Child.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. The report calls for an increased fight against child abuse on the Internet. This problem is becoming increasingly apparent and, because of its cross-border nature, requires a united and decisive approach. That is why I can only fully support the proposal.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Children are the most vulnerable group in our societies and they are permanently in danger due to new technologies and the internet. Child abuse and online exploitation require our special attention globally as such threats can only be fought efficiently by the international community as a whole. The Commission and the Member States must act now with a comprehensive and coordinated European approach in order to ensure consistency in policy making and the resulting actions. Full engagement and cooperation between all the relevant stakeholders is needed so as to share best practices and information, identify potential risks and threats to children, and raise awareness. Children are our future and we must do our utmost to protect them.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I abstained on the joint motion for a resolution on combating child sexual abuse on the Internet. It is true that most children today routinely carry smartphones with instant internet access in their pockets. However, very few of them are aware of the risks associated with it. Today, the Internet can almost at any time expose children to risks through phones in the form of events such as pornography, the exchange of material on violence, intimidation, bullying, making contact with children for the purpose of their sexual abuse, etc. Moreover, innocent photos of children taken by phones and children posted on social media have recently been posted on pornographic websites used by paedophiles. That's a completely unacceptable thing. Child sexual abuse and child pornography require a comprehensive approach that would apply to protection, including care, prevention of this phenomenon and prosecution of perpetrators, in this respect the motion for a resolution has gone in the right direction by precisely defining the most pressing issue. Unfortunately, several calls for rules have been incorporated into the resolution, which would lead to censorship and the suppression of freedoms on the Internet. In protecting one right, there is a need to weigh well and measure the limitations that this will bring to others' rights. Therefore, in order not to spill the baby with the bath, I decided to abstain from voting.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With this vote, the European Parliament has strongly stressed the need to ensure that the rights of the most vulnerable in our society, children, are respected. Each country has a responsibility to protect children from all forms of abuse, by all possible means.  We call for more efforts to protect children, especially on the Internet, through awareness-raising campaigns for parents, because the issue of the dissemination of children's online data is still too underestimated, but also through the development of new technologies capable of eliminating the scourge of child pornography that spreads in the darkest corners of the web.  All this cannot, however, take place without the active collaboration of web service providers and the telecommunications industry. 80% of children who are abused are under the age of 10. We can no longer tolerate such barbarism.  That is why it is imperative that all Member States transpose the 2011 directive on combating the abuse, sexual exploitation of children and child pornography into their national legislation. Heinous crimes that are difficult to prosecute in a transnational dimension to which we must respond with a strong global alliance against abuse.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of the resolution on combating the sexual abuse of children online as it highlights the strong need to protect children's rights through the adoption of measures specifically aimed at combating certain dangerous practices, such as the lure of children through the online network. It is clear that the Internet is a resource to be exploited, but unfortunately it is also the place where children, unpervised, are sometimes exposed to risks related to sexual exploitation also through images depicting abuse of the same minors. For these reasons, I strongly support the resolution.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. These motions for a resolution aim to combat child pornography more effectively. The emergence of new communication technologies, such as the internet and smartphones, has changed child pornography practices, requiring a change in response and detection. If this struggle is in the public interest, it must not be established, under the guise of this struggle, a complete guardianship of the net. There is also a need to increase awareness of the situation among at-risk audiences (through prevention among parents and children) and to reduce the amount of child pornography data available on the net.  I voted for this proposal.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I welcome the intentions of the text, which are the fight against pedophilia and child abuse and against the distribution of images of this type of violence, and I share the importance of taking action in this area. However, the non-reference to a prior court order for the disposal of materials from the internet would set a dangerous precedent. In addition, an interested reference is made to the dark network, when less than 1% of these contents come from there, which would mean another attempt to end online privacy. Access to private citizenship data without a court order is unacceptable and, instead of lowering European data protection standards, it should move towards faster justice, with specialized cybercrime units with sufficient resources to do their job. For all this, I abstained.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. I believe that the protection of minors and ensuring a safe environment is one of the main objectives of the EU and its Member States. You need to inform them about the risks and consequences of using your personal data online.   All children should have the right to enjoy an online environment and healthy and secure internet access. This Resolution calls on the Commission and the Member States to promote resources devoted to the identification of victims, and to urgently create platforms for this purpose. Member States are also requested to implement Directive 2012/29/EU laying down minimum standards on the rights, support and protection of victims of crime, taking into account the regrettable fact that many Member States have not yet transposed them. I voted in favour of this Resolution which welcomes the joint initiative of the EU and 55 other countries around the world, meeting within the framework of the Global Alliance against Online Child Sexual Abuse.

name: Peter Lundgren (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour, since it calls for more to be done to protect children online and social media. Transposition of the EU directives on child protection. Illegal content should be removed online. Steps to stop cyber grooming.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: written \u2012 Sexual abuse of children via the Internet is a very sensitive but especially highly topical global problem that requires the attention of all of us. Social networks cannot replace a child's contact with family, friends, society. Disreerration of the child's problems and interests increases the preconditions for the child to be the victim of such illegal acts. The solution to this problem requires active cooperation between family, school, society and the state. The detection of such illegal activity must be a priority for all investigative and control bodies. It is the task of the Commission and the Member States to establish the widest possible system of control and security measures and regulations to prevent such action in advance.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the Joint Motion for a Resolution, because the fight against the sexual abuse of children on the internet must be immediate, decisive and continuous. We cannot leave our children at the mercy of the various circuits and criminals.  This requires strict and effective legislation. Coordination of the action of the Member States of the European Union is needed, and the European Commission is also called upon to play an important role here. However, effective implementation of the relevant EU Directive on sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children and child pornography is required.  At the same time, the prosecuting and judicial authorities of the EU Member States must become even more effective in hitting cybercrimes that know no borders.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this proposal and welcome its call on the Commission and the Member States to further engage with representatives of alternative payment systems in order to identify means of better cooperation with law enforcement authorities, including training for more effective identification of payment processes linked to commercial distribution of child abuse material.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the motion for a resolution on combating online child sexual abuse. This is one of the essential objectives of the European Union and an inseparable point to be supported in the strongest possible terms.  We need protection to protect children's rights online and child-friendly information that makes protection effective. An integrated and coordinated European approach will make it possible to combat the lure of children online; We also need resources to be able to identify victims and culprits in a certain way by consolidating what is already present in europol. The new trend of commercial sexual exploitation must be combated and live streaming abuse is a reality to be fought strongly and decisively, eliminating all illegal content online.

name: Michał Marusik (NI)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I voted against because I take it for granted that the intention of the originators was to obtain Parliament's consent to control the content transmitted on the internet and to obtain Parliament's consent to censor that content. "Child abuse..." is, in my opinion, only a false justification; the pretext given for the extortion of members' consent to the actual and undisclosed intentions of the originators.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On our shoulders lies the moral duty, and the political responsibility, to ensure that all Community citizens have an adequate defence of their security, freedom and dignity. This is all the more true for children, whose level of knowledge and judgment is limited.  The data according to which the number of abuses against children has increased exponentially, due to the epidemic spread of the Internet, are sufficient to justify mobilising the European institutions, with the aim of curbing this disturbing trend. The rise of the phenomenon requires a shared response, with common criteria for action on online legal interception.  It is for all these reasons that I felt it necessary to support this resolution, through which the European Parliament strongly condemns this alarming reality.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. Europe has to make a greater effort in combating the sexual exploitation of children and images of child abuse, and coordination is essential for this. All my support for this European Parliament's resolution promoting a comprehensive approach covering crime investigation, criminal prosecution, the protection of child victims and prevention measures.  We must ensure that any illegal content is removed immediately and notified to the authorities. For their part, Europol and national security agencies must ensure the necessary funds, human resources, technical and research capabilities to seriously and effectively prosecute and prosecute criminals. It is now possible to develop new high-tech capabilities to address the challenges of analyzing large amounts of child abuse images, including the material hidden in the so-called "dark web". It's everyone's job to get it.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. The fight against the sexual abuse of children on the Internet must, of course, be supported; Consequently, this motion received my positive vote. Children are the most vulnerable group in our societies, which is why it is essential to protect them. The sexual abuse and exploitation of children, including online, constitute serious violations of fundamental rights. For this reason, it is important to combat and end the sexual abuse and exploitation of children.

name: Emma McClarkin (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I wanted to signal my support for this resolution, which, I believe, makes a number of important recommendations in tackling the spread of child sexual abuse material. This is particularly relevant at a time when technological advancement has led to an increase in the spread of these images, particularly through the deep web and darknets. It is clear that law enforcement agencies, including Europol, must be able to keep up with this advancement and to ensure that they have the technical expertise available to find and remove this material as well as to locate and to prosecute offenders.  In particular, and as I have mentioned previously in my work in this area, it is important to emphasise that this crime can only be tackled through global cooperation, and references to the Global Alliance are particularly relevant. While Europe has the resources and expertise to enable it to export its practices around the world, it is also important that Member States be seen to be practising what they preach. Therefore, I fully support calls for Member States which have not yet done so to transpose the Directive on combating the sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children and child pornography.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is vital to protect child victims, 80% of whom are under 10, and remove any illegal online content.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I welcome the idea of information campaigns and real ways to combat online images, sexual abuse and other illegal practices involving children on the net. This is a necessity and a challenge all the more complex because the perpetrators of these crimes, often hidden behind encrypted information, are difficult to trace. Data is constantly evolving and changing, and there is a lack of resources, especially to prevent potential cyber predators from taking action.  However, we must ensure that this fight does not come at the very expense of children's rights. For example, the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child ensures that children have freedom of expression and access to information online. This resolution tends to present an early security vision, at the risk of approving repressive measures. I cannot concede that the exchange of information in all directions is the only key to the success of this battle against cyber predators. However, given the theme, I am voting to encourage the fight against child pornography.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. More efforts are needed to investigate child sexual abuse on the Internet, prosecute criminals, protect children and suppress illegal content online. This resolution underlines that the reform of the data protection rules, currently underway, will bring important changes to better protect children's rights on the Internet. More than 80% of children who are victims of sexual abuse on the net are under the age of ten.  There is a need to improve international cooperation and transnational investigations in this area, as these crimes cover hundreds of countries, with their jurisdictions and law enforcement authorities.  In this regard, the joint initiative of the EU and 55 countries around the world, meeting in the World Alliance against the Sexual Abuse of Children on the Internet, which aims to save more victims, ensure more effective repression, raise awareness and achieve a general reduction in the child pornography materials available online, is very important. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ As one of the co-authors of this motion for a resolution, I voted in favour of its adoption. The resolution highlights the need for further steps to combat cyber grooming, and urges the Commission, national governments, civil society, social media companies and all care givers to play an active role in raising awareness of this issue through defined guidelines and exchanging best practices on how to tackle and identify cyber grooming. It is also crucial that international cooperation and transnational investigations in this area improve.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ Children are clearly the most vulnerable group in our society and therefore deserve special attention and protection from all adults, including legislators. I consider the sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children to be a particularly despicable violation of fundamental rights, and therefore a sufficiently effective strategy for the legal protection of children is needed, which, given the seriousness of the acts, must include criminal instruments such as prosecution and sentencing. I find it sad that more than half of the Member States have not transposed as a matter of priority the 2011 directive on combating the sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children and child pornography, which was to be transposed into the national law of the Member States by 18 December 2013. This extremely serious problem requires close transnational cooperation within the EU, but also on a global scale.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support Directive 2011/93/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of 13 December 2011 on combating the sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children and child pornography, which harmonises criminal offences relating to sexual abuse committed against children, the sexual exploitation of children and child pornography throughout the EU.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is one of the most disgusting abuses that exponents of the human race are capable of. Fighting against him is a noble and binding cause for any sane man.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Sexual abuse and exploitation of children is always sexual violence, even if acts or motives normally associated with the notion of violence do not happen to be used. It is also clear that the Internet, in addition to its many advantages, is a particularly suitable tool for this type of abuse, so the internet has increasingly become a place of child sexual abuse. In order to protect children's rights and healthy psychosexual development, everything must therefore be done to prevent and prosecute such harassment. A motion for a resolution of this content has been tabled by most of the EP's political groups, and the synthesis of these draft resolutions has been submitted to the European Parliament, which, of course, I voted in favour of with most of my fellow Members.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The fight against child sexual abuse on the Internet and in new forms of mobile technologies should be regarded by all of us as a serious violation of children's Fundamental Rights. As expressed in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union and the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, the interests of our children must prevail and the fight against these crimes must be dealt with appropriately by the Member States.  I believe that this phenomenon should be integrated into a broader and more comprehensive strategy for the exploitation and sexual abuse of children. Governments must do more to prevent illegal content online, but there must also be action by industry and by all of us parents, educators and citizens.  I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution and I call on the Member States to implement Directive 2011/93/EU on combating sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children and child pornography.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. These motions for a resolution aim to combat child pornography more effectively. The emergence of new communication technologies, such as the internet, has changed child pornography practices, requiring a change in response and detection. If this struggle is a compelling reason for the public interest, it is not necessary that, under the guise of this struggle, a complete guardianship of the net should not be established. It is also necessary to make the situation better known to the public at risk (through prevention with parents and children), reduce the amount of child pornography data available on the net... However, the initiative of the European Union and 55 countries does not go far enough and Member States must coordinate their detection and enforcement practices.  I voted for this proposal.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it gives the LIBE Committee the mandate to carry out an implementation report on  Directive 2011/92/EC on combating the sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children and child pornography, given that fewer than half of the Member States have fully implemented the Directive more than a year after the deadline for implementation has passed (18 December 2013).

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which I co-signed on behalf of the EPP Group.  The fight against the scourge of child pornography, which takes advantage of the lack of harmonization of legislation between states and in 80% of cases involves children under the age of 10, is a global issue. I put a lot of effort into this subject when I was minister in charge of the family. I am actively pursuing this commitment at European level and I am pleased that Europe is taking up this and showing determination. The resolution stresses that it is the responsibility of the digital industry, in particular internet service providers (ISPs), to prevent access to illegal content and to remove it at the request of the authorities. It also reminds Member States of their duty to fully implement the 2011/93/EU Directive on combating sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children, which gives Member States the means to harmonize their legislation against paedophilia.  The resolution calls on the Commission and Member States to launch an information campaign for children, teachers and parents to raise awareness of the risks online. It also calls for strengthening the means of reporting abuse available to children.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which is jointly adopted by five political groups on the fight against child pornography on the internet, which affects 80% of children under the age of 10. It recalls the responsibility of the digital industry to prevent access to illegal content and to remove it at the request of the authorities. The resolution calls on the Commission and Member States to launch an information campaign for children, teachers and parents to raise awareness of online risks and then to strengthen the means of reporting child abuse. Finally, it reminds Member States of the duty to transpose the 2011/93/EU directive on the fight against sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children and child pornography. Indeed, the deadline for transposition was 18 December; less than half of the Member States have fully implemented it. France, for its part, transposed it by a law of 5 August 2013.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The sexual abuse and exploitation of children constitute serious violations of fundamental rights (UN Convention on the Rights of the Child and EU Charter of Fundamental Rights). We believe it is right to promote every measure aimed at adequately protecting the personal data of children online, highlighting the need for a coordinated and comprehensive European approach, ensuring consistency in policy-making and subsequent actions, including the fight against crime, fundamental rights, privacy, data protection, cybersecurity, consumer protection and e-commerce. The Commission and national governments are called upon to raise awareness through defined guidelines, through the exchange of best practices, the establishment of social platform for cooperation and the legitimate exchange of information aimed at identifying potential risks for children. Any measure limiting fundamental rights on the Internet must be necessary and proportionate, in line with EU and Member State law; illegal online content must be deleted immediately, based on regular procedures. We therefore call on those Member States that have not yet fully transposed Directive 2011/92/EU to proceed without further delay, and we therefore call on the Commission to closely monitor its full implementation by reporting to the EP in good time.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this resolution because child pornography is a scourge still present in Europe and it is our duty to fight it by all means. In this regard, I particularly welcome the text's initiatives to make internet service providers accountable by preventing access to illegal content and those calling on the European Commission and Member States to launch an information campaign for children, teachers and parents to raise awareness of online risks.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The advent of the Internet and new technologies, in general, has radically changed the scenario of a non-new phenomenon: the sexual abuse of children. Hundreds of thousands of often easily accessible child pornography images and videos circulate online. The material can be produced with extreme ease, using mobile phones or cameras, and just as easily loaded on the net. The network can also be used by adults sexually interested in minors as a tool to treat potential victims.  Faced with this scenario, I supported the resolution calling on the Commission and the Member States to make further efforts to combat such child abuse. I also welcome the joint initiative by the EU and 55 countries to form the Global Alliance against Child Sexual Abuse on the Internet. The aim of the initiative is to save more victims, ensure the most effective prosecution of the culprits, raise awareness of the issue and lead to an overall reduction in the amount of child pornography available online.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Child sexual abuse is a disgusting sin and unacceptable. Unfortunately, it's not as rare as we'd hope. And the Internet is a very good place to do that.  I confess that I am shocked by europol's Cybercrime report. Of course, I also know that human liberties are inalienable. They can only be limited in very exceptional cases and under strict conditions. And I also know what a key issue privacy is today.  However, I find it ludicrous that while commercial portals browse people's data on the web and bombard them accordingly with advertisements, law enforcement cannot take action in cases where they can investigate the perpetrators of the crime, because they are effectively exempted by our data protection rules.  It's not right, and in my opinion, we can't measure it when it comes to such heinous crimes. I urge us to find the means to conduct a harmonised investigation between Member States as soon as possible.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children are serious violations of the fundamental rights of children, in particular their right to care and protection, as stipulated in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, but also in the UN Charter.  I voted for this resolution because, in addition to a number of measures it proposes to combat this scourge of child sexual abuse on the Internet, it comes to reiterate the need for the adoption and implementation of two European directives, whose transposition into the national legislation of each Member State would contribute to an easier detection, combating and resolution of such abuses, namely Directive 2011/93/EC on combating child sexual abuse, sexual exploitation of children and child pornography, which has been transposed into less than half of the Member States, and Directive 2012/29/EU laying down minimum rules on the rights, support and protection of victims of crime.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this resolution because I believe that sexual abuse of children on the internet is a current problem, of great gravity for the society in which we live. I believe that we, as adults, parents or not, are obliged to accept that this phenomenon is closer to us than we can imagine. As legislators, we must do everything legally possible so that we can combat it and punish the guilty.  In this case, sexual abuse on the Internet, it is also important to inform the public about the risks, to explain to people how to protect themselves and how to protect their loved ones from becoming victims of deviant individuals. I believe that this resolution draws constructive attention to this problem, also offering solutions to the Member States, and that is why today, in my vote, I join this approach.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this resolution as my party's focus is primarily on the safety and well-being of the child. It is our collective responsibility to ensure that there are genuine measures to protect children, but we must ensure such measures are appropriate and proportionate; to ensure that measures protecting children are balanced with children's rights to access information on the internet and utilise it for educational and communication purposes; to protect fundamental rights of people in relation to internet freedom; and to protect against the privatisation of internet security/policing.  The resolution that we tabled was child-centred and protected the best interests of the child. Moreover, unlike the resolutions from the other groups, the GUE/NGL resolution respects legal due process and the separation of powers, balanced with the protection of children's rights and citizens' fundamental and democratic rights. For this reason we abstained on the joint motion for a resolution.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of tighter controls on the Internet and fighting against child sexual abuse on the Internet. I am clearly in favour of tighter controls, tougher penalties and prosecution of criminals. Our justice system cannot cope with the dramatic flood of child pornography on the Internet. We must be able to combat the sexual abuse of children effectively throughout Europe. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the bill because children's rights must be protected in the best and most effective way. Serious crimes, such as the sexual exploitation of children, require a holistic approach that includes the protection of child victims, care, prevention of this phenomenon and prosecution of offenders. States must fully implement the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child and, in particular, its general principles.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. In the 21st century we have a physical universe, but we are part of a digital universe that is expanding and in which the fight against child abuse goes behind the criminals who take advantage of the new spaces.  In addition to resolutions like this, parents, educators and the whole community must be aware of this circumstance to protect children and to move our sons and daughters new knowledge to help them guide themselves in the face of the traps of the cruellest and most miserable beings.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because, on the basis of a comprehensive EU-wide, coordinated approach, sexual abuse of children online must be prevented and its safety ensured.  The main focus should be on combating the sexual abuse of children and the sexual exploitation of children, which are serious violations of fundamental rights. In the fight against serious criminal offences such as the sexual exploitation of children and child pornography, a comprehensive approach is needed, covering the prosecution of offenders, the protection of children affected and the prevention of criminal offences. First of all, it is necessary to identify, save and support victims, take action against criminals and curb further circulation of images by detecting and removing images of child sexual abuse online, as well as preventing them from reloading there. The systematic detection, removal and prevention of the re-publication of images of child sexual abuse needs to be improved. As there are no borders on the Internet, it is therefore necessary to improve international cooperation and cross-border investigations in this area. Greater attention must be paid to an effective partnership involving law enforcement authorities, judicial authorities, the information and communication technology sector.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The abuse and exploitation of children is one of the most indecent violations of fundamental rights, as it is perpetrated against innocent and defenceless human beings by nature. The use of the Internet has not only made the problem worse – exposing children more to the risk of online baiting by cyber predators – but has also given it a transnational dimension, which must necessarily require an equal solution.  The search for a more effective strategy for the protection of children's rights must involve greater cooperation and include the exchange of excellent practices between Member States.  I would like to express my full support for this and therefore declare my vote in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the sexual abuse of children online, because I believe that only a coordinated approach at European level between institutional bodies, civil society and companies operating in the IT and social media sector can result in an improvement in measures to prevent, combat and respond to these violations.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The JRC condemns in the most unequivocal and unequivocal way the crimes of sexual abuse of children, in any form, in any way and by any means. It advocates more severe punishment for perpetrators and those who in any way engage in such heinous criminal acts. It considers effective measures to prevent, inform and protect children, particularly in the use of the Internet, to be extremely important. Pornography is only part of a huge industry, as is sex tourism, which cultivates the sickest perversions for profit.  The resolution not only hides the causes, but also exploits the huge problem of child sexual abuse as a pretext to promote the strengthening of the EU's reactionary repressive mechanisms, such as Europol. What protection, information and prevention can there be for the children of the unemployed, working-class families living in poverty? What protection of children on the internet is it about when it is controlled by monopolistic groups, while the EU and governments ensure their profitability?  Capitalism cannot cope with the rot and perversion that are intertwined with its exploitative nature. Another socio-economic system is needed with a focus on man and meeting his needs, with the people owning the wealth he produces.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that children are the most vulnerable group in our society and that the legislator must pay particular attention to them in order to protect them; that particular attention should be paid to the correct use of terminology relating to the sexual exploitation of children in communication to the public; given its international character, the sexual exploitation of children and the sexual abuse of children online, including the proliferation of material relating to the sexual use of children on the Internet and online predation, continue to be a matter of great concern to law enforcement authorities, considering that the protection and guarantee of a safe environment for children is one of the main objectives of the European Union; calling on the Commission and the Member States to promote and strengthen resources dedicated to victim identification and victim-centred services, by rapidly soliciting the creation of platforms and strengthening existing ones under Europol; stresses, moreover, the urgent need to improve assistance for children who are victims of abuse through personalized recovery and reintegration programmes; calls on the Member States to implement Directive 2012/29/EU establishing minimum standards on the rights, assistance and protection of victims of crime. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Protecting children and ensuring a safe environment for their development are one of the primary objectives of the European Union and its Member States. We need to ensure children's rights online and their protection as well as take measures to remove and report illegal content to law enforcement as a matter of urgency. Sufficient legal instruments should be provided for to carry out investigations and prosecutions of perpetrators and to strengthen cooperation between law enforcement authorities. I believe that children's personal data online must be properly protected and that children should be informed in a simple and understandable way about the risks and consequences of using their personal data online. First of all, it is necessary to educate the parents who are in charge of raising their children in order to know how they can track who their children are communicating with, and this is achieved above all by developing mutual trust. Parents' insight into what their children are doing and with whom they communicate can greatly contribute to reducing the occurrence of child sexual abuse online and to detecting perpetrators in a timely way that needs to be punished in the strongest possible way.

name: Florian Philippot (NI)
text: In writing. With the development of the internet and new technologies, unfortunately, practices are also developing encouraging fraud, trafficking or, more importantly, child pornography, which is the subject of this resolution. In order to protect our children, it is vital to fight this growing problem. We need to ensure more effective prosecutions, raise awareness of the situation and reduce the amount of child pornography available online. An initiative by the European Union and 55 countries has been taken in this direction, but Member States must be able to put in place, in a spirit of international cooperation and not under the aegis of a supranational body, a policy of prevention, detection but also effective repression. I voted for this proposal.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ There is a growing demand for online content depicting child sexual abuse, there is more violence in such content, and the age of victims is getting lower. According to Europol, 10% of victims are under two years old. Research suggests that at EU level, children start using the internet on average at the age of seven. At the age of 9-16, they spend on average about an hour and a half a day on the Internet, but as technology becomes more accessible and developed, there is more and more manipulation of children. Due to its international nature – child exploitation and online child sexual exploitation are present in hundreds of countries and involve hundreds of judicial authorities – this problem clearly requires a solution internationally. The measures taken by Member States to prevent illegal content online are not sufficiently effective. We must provide protection to minors in the digital world at regulatory and local level by applying more effective measures with the cooperation of law enforcement authorities with industry in accordance with the principle of due process and at educational and training levels by educating children, parents and teachers with a view to protecting minors online and teaching how to use the internet safely.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ We are all aware of how serious and difficult the problem of child sexual abuse is. Therefore, the EU must take further steps to combat and prevent these monstrous crimes. The Child Sexual Abuse Directive is the most important document, covering a large number of tools to improve member states' efficiency and facilitating international cooperation in combating this type of criminality. These crimes also happen in reality, but in large part today, due to the growth of the internet and on social networks, and this should be particularly attentioned because it is a "new kind of violence". By establishing an Internal Security Fund, the Commission will support the establishment of a public-private partnership between key private sector factors and the Law Enforcement Agency. By fusion of these two parties, the Commission will continue to co-finance the Secure Internet Centres broadband network, whose key role is to raise awareness of online safety issues for children across the EU. Safer Internet Centers are tasked with teaching both children and parents the purposeful use of the internet. By supporting law enforcement to identify victims and perpetrators more effectively, co-financing the development of common databases currently in Interpol provides a legal basis for better availability of data and evidence available worldwide. I therefore support the proposal for a Resolution on Child Sexual Abuse online.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am delighted that the important resolution on combating online child sexual abuse has been voted on by a very large majority. The protection of children and the obligation to provide them with a safe environment for their development must be one of the EU's priority objectives.  For this reason, we must act with the utmost firmness and effectiveness in taking measures to ensure that any illegal content put online is removed and reported to the competent authorities and that appropriate legal means are available to investigate the perpetrators. In order to achieve the best results, it is essential that there is better international cooperation and that transnational investigations can be carried out effectively with appropriate agreements.  I hope that Directive 2011/93/EU on combating the sexual abuse and exploitation of children and child pornography will be transposed by all Member States as soon as possible and that the Commission will control its full and full implementation.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children are, from my point of view, one of the most serious forms of violation of fundamental rights, as laid down in the 1989 United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. Serious crimes, such as the sexual exploitation of children and child pornography, require a clearly comprehensive approach involving not only the prosecution of criminals, but above all the protection and prevention of child victims themselves. International cooperation in this area is essential not only in the state sector, and I therefore welcome the Commission's initiative to establish a coalition for a better and safer Internet for children, which also brings together the 31 largest technology and media companies, whose involvement could significantly strengthen our joint fight against online child abuse.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Today, too many children in the EU are affected by child pornography. This is a serious problem for which the European Parliament must actively mobilise and accelerate awareness at European and national level.  Parliament has thus adopted a resolution to combat child pornography. It was important to speak in favour of this text, which addresses a subject that affects European citizens very closely. This resolution stresses the responsibility of the Commission and Member States to inform and educate parenting leaders and children about the risks of the web. In addition, it highlights the responsibility of the digital industry to prevent access to illegal content, or even remove it at the request of the authorities.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. Sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children, including images of child abuse, constitute serious violations of fundamental rights, in particular the right of children to the protection and care necessary for their well-being, as set out in the 1989 United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. This resolution considers that the Internet may expose children to specific risks by allowing them access to or exposing them to child pornography materials or by subjecting them to cyberpredators, the exchange of violent content, intimidation, harassment or grooming. The protection of children and the guarantee of a safe environment for their development are the primary functions of the European Union and its Member States. It is therefore necessary to adopt a comprehensive and coordinated European approach, ensuring consistency in the development of subsequent policies and measures and enabling adequate response to the challenges of combating crime, defending fundamental rights, privacy and data protection, cybersecurity, consumer protection and e-commerce. I voted in favour.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. With this resolution, which I fully support, the European Parliament reiterates the need to effectively combat child pornography and its dissemination on the internet. We recall the need to implement a comprehensive strategy adapted to new information and communication technologies in order to provide a more effective criminal response. Our approach is part of a desire to adapt our legislation to the technological developments used by paedophiles (smartphones, encryption, setting up hidden data storage bases, development and expansion of new online child pornography, etc.).  Thus, it is necessary to adapt our criminal responses to better protect our children and their rights. The resolution stresses the need for all states to implement the 2011 directive on combating sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children, as well as child pornography, and to better protect children's personal data.  In order to effectively combat child pornography, the European Parliament calls for better inter-State and European cooperation, through Europol and the European Cybercrime Centre and in collaboration with companies in the new technology sector.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I firmly argued that the rights and protection of children on the Internet should be safeguarded. I agree that measures are put in place quickly to ensure the immediate elimination of illicit content and its swift communication to law enforcement authorities and to ensure that sufficient legal instruments are in place to investigate and prosecute criminals. In view of the serious proportions that this problem has been taking, I agree that an awareness-raising campaign should be launched as soon as possible to empower children and support parents and educators to understand and deal with online risks.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
