text: In writing. The observation is clear: in the last ten years, the number of child pornography sites has literally exploded, the number of visitors too! Europol's latest report on this issue confirms that there are more and more online paedophiles as they become more and more difficult to trace. New technological developments allow them to share their criminal acts easily and safely.  It is in this context that the European Parliament this afternoon urged Member States to effectively combat child pornography on the internet. Starting with those - more than half - who have not yet fully implemented the directive on combating sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children.  After the Dutroux affair, in particular, in Belgium, especially but in the four corners of Europe as well, an arsenal of tools was created. Today, we need to go even further, and new measures at European level are needed: strengthening mechanisms for reporting and removing illegal content, improving the education of children to the dangers of the internet, improving international cooperation (investigations and prosecutions)... For it is our duty to help our children protect themselves from this "murderous web" that has become the internet.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the fight against child pornography on the internet.  Since the measures taken by Member States against online content have not always been effective enough and since this problem goes beyond the borders of a State, we recall that the European Union has the objective of protecting children, especially on the internet.  We demand an ambitious approach to enabling law enforcement agencies to have legal tools to investigate, prosecute perpetrators and protect victims. Ensuring a safe environment for children's development also requires prevention. At the same time, we call on the Commission, states and all relevant actors to launch information campaigns and implement online sexual abuse prevention programmes.  We will continue to monitor this critical issue and conduct a thorough and regular analysis of the current policy framework for combating child pornography.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. The protection of children and the guarantee of a safe environment for their development are the main functions of the EU and its Member States. The rights and protection of children on the Internet must be safeguarded and measures need to be taken to ensure that illicit content is immediately withdrawn and communicated to law enforcement authorities.  In this context, and in order to combat child sexual abuse on the Internet, the Commission and the Member States should carry out an awareness-raising campaign involving all relevant actors, with a view to empowering children and supporting parents and educators to understand online risks, to protect children's safety in this context. It is also important to support Member States, by European structures, in the creation of programmes to prevent sexual abuse on the Internet.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because the protection of minors and the guarantee of a safe environment for their development is and should be a priority for the EU, also in the digital environment. The worrying evolution of pedophile threats on the internet, including increased demand, violence and the use of social media as a method of attracting minors, requires determined action by the EU and Member States to combat and eradicate such threats and criminal behaviour.  Of course, a comprehensive and coordinated European approach is needed, but also to strengthen international cooperation to combat child sexual abuse by effectively investigating, dismantling and pursuing child sex crime networks. In this regard, I believe that the joint initiative of the EU and fifty-five other countries within the framework of the Global Alliance against Online Child Abuse will make a decisive contribution to achieving this objective.  It is also necessary to involve law ensuring the rights and protection of children on the internet.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. This resolution, in which I voted, calls on Member States to do more to investigate cases of child sexual abuse on the internet, prosecute criminals, protect child victims and remove illegal content online.  More than 80% of victims of child pornography on the internet are under the age of ten. To combat the sexual exploitation of children and child pornography, a comprehensive strategy must be implemented covering the investigation of offences, prosecutions of their perpetrators, the protection of children who are victims and the prevention of the phenomenon. To do this, the law enforcement agencies of the Member States and Europol must finally have the funds, human resources, investigative powers and technical capacity to seriously and effectively investigate and prosecute offenders! New high-tech capabilities should also be developed to overcome the problems associated with analyzing large quantities of child pornography images.  Finally, the voted text states that children's online personal data should be better protected and children more aware of the risks and consequences of using their personal data online. The ongoing data protection reform provides specific articles for minors.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this resolution, which recalls the responsibility of the digital industry to prevent access to illegal content and remove it at the request of the authorities.  The text also discusses the obligation of Member States to transpose the 2011/93/EU Directive on the fight against sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children and child pornography, as less than half of the Member States have fully implemented it.  Finally, through this text, we call on the Commission and member States to launch an information campaign for children, teachers and parents to raise awareness of the risks online; it is also essential to strengthen the means of reporting child abuse.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote in favour because this report is not critical and is the best of those proposed by the various political groups. It calls for closer cooperation between the various authorities in the Member States and Europol, also with a view to the rapid removal of content dangerous to children from the Internet. In addition, references appear to the need to combat the sexual exploitation of children.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution calling for urgent measures to ensure that all child pornography on the internet is promptly deleted and reported to the enforcement agencies. According to NGOs, 80% of child pornography victims are under the age of 10 and the number of children affected is increasing. The authorities must have sufficient legal tools to investigate and prosecute criminals. The text calls for the digital industry to also assume its responsibilities in this fight, to prevent access to illegal content and to remove it at the request of the authorities. The last Member States that have not yet done so are invited to quickly transpose the 2011/93/EU Directive on the fight against sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children. Finally, we need to strengthen the means of prevention, information and reporting of child abuse to ensure more secure use of the internet.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. What time has been wasted for 10 years, the date of the european Parliament's first report on this subject. If we do not mobilize all our forces, we will lose this battle against child pornography on the internet. Because everything is going faster and faster today, with the "darkweb" or the "deepweb".  We know the answers. First, we need a country-by-country state of affairs. Secondly, we need to work on a European cooperation plan and take a number of measures. There needs to be an awareness of parents and children, teacher training and a European green telephone number on this issue. We also need systems to block and filter sites.  Clearly, Europol's resources are paltry. They need to be really strengthened to better search for and find predators, to better identify victims and to facilitate data sharing.  To protect our children, we need this unwavering mobilization, not only of ourselves as politicians, but also of society as a whole.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (NI)
text: In writing. Protecting children from the threat of child crime is a priority. It is up to the States to decide on the policy in this area and the Union to understand that its laxity, by prohibiting States from putting in place this protection, makes it the best ally of those who lend themselves to this horrible traffic.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that it is trying to respond to a major problem, and I welcome the agreement of the majority of Members across the clubs. Protecting and providing a safe environment for children should be our priority, including the internet environment. These objectives should be closely pursued by the EU institutions and the Member States, together with other structures in the world designated for this purpose, as mentioned in the resolution. Of course, the main role is for law enforcement authorities, whose technical capacities need to be properly improved and strengthened in this regard. It is necessary to be able to effectively prosecute e.g. the mentioned "cybergrooming", which is a very dangerous and unfortunately quite widespread phenomenon. I also agree that it is appropriate to clarify the terminology and term 'child pornography' when describing or referring to child sexual abuse by the term 'child sexual abuse material'.  In this context, I am very sorry that many Member States have not yet transposed Directive 2011/93/EU on combating the sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children and child pornography into national law. I am proud that this is not the case in the Czech Republic, which used the amendment to the Criminal Code of 2014 for this purpose.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing \u2012 Freedom has its limits if its application threatens others. All the more so when it comes to the most vulnerable. I am in favour of internet content being monitored where justified. However, close control and transparency of the whole process must be ensured in order to exclude misuse of the information obtained.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today the Socialist and Democrats Group voted in support of the motion for a resolution on child sex abuse on the internet.  Sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children, including child abuse images, constitute serious violations of fundamental rights, in particular of the right of children to the protection and care necessary for their well-being, as provided for by the 1989 UN Convention on the Rights of the Child and by the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.  The rights and protection of children online must be safeguarded and steps must be taken to ensure that any illicit content is promptly removed and reported to law enforcement authorities. There must be sufficient legal instruments for investigating and prosecuting offenders.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I am strongly committed to combating child sexual abuse online and I believe that combating the disturbing growth of violence against children should be a priority of our action. In proportion to the advancement of technology, the percentage of abuse is also increasing. The advancement of technology and the increasing availability of information in this context therefore pose a threat. According to a recent survey, in Croatia as many as 93% of minors have a social media profile, and one in five minors spend more than three hours a day on them. A survey of a large number of children active on social networks in Croatia found that most of them have between 300 and 500 "friends" on their profile, and in case an unknown person invites them to meet, as many as 18% of children say they may agree to meet, while 8% have already found themselves in such a situation and went to a meeting The situation is further hampered by the very nature of children who are often embarrassed or terrified to report abuse. For all this, I believe that the European Union must take strong measures to combat child sexual abuse online, and I support and welcome the establishment of various mechanisms to achieve this objective.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: writing – Child sexual abuse and sexual exploitation and child sexual abuse material are a serious violation of fundamental rights, in particular children's right to protection and care. Current trends and the development of commercial sexual exploitation of children online, including new business models of commercial distribution, are worrying. The internet environment exposes children to specific danger because they have very easy and virtually unlimited access to child sexual abuse material, are themselves easily manipulated, are subjected to bullying, intimidation many times without realising it. Therefore, the protection of children in the digital world must be addressed both at its regulatory level, but also by cooperation in prevention and education by parents, teachers, medics, social workers and organisations working with children and young people. International cooperation between law enforcement authorities and organisations concerned with the protection of children's rights and a comprehensive and coordinated approach in the development of European policies to combat child sexual abuse must also be very important.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. Children are the most vulnerable group in our society and need special attention to be paid to protect them. Online sexual abuse and exploitation of children constitute serious violations of fundamental rights and remain a leading problem for law enforcement. Internet, information and communication technology is part of the everyday life of children in the EU, and with all the advantages it provides, children are increasingly exposed to risky situations and perpetrators of crimes on the Internet. I supported this resolution, in order to adequately protect the personal data of children on the Internet, to provide all necessary information to children and parents and to improve the international cooperation of Member States in combating child sexual abuse and exploitation.  A partnership approach and exchange of information between Member States and public awareness of this problem contributes to creating a safe environment for children, which is one of the primary roles of the European Union.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution asking for a draft report by LIBE on the implementation of the directive aiming to harmonise criminal offences relating to sexual abuse committed against children, the sexual exploitation of children and child pornography throughout the EU and establish a common minimum sanction for the offences.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. – The number of children who have received unsolicited requests and suggestions of a sexual nature online is growing at a frightening rate, following alarming trends in abuse. It is necessary to condemn the sexual abuse and exploitation of children in time because we are witnessing today's weather and the speed with which this kind of thing is going. In particular, it is necessary to pay attention to the protection of developing countries where the internet is nevertheless less represented than in Western countries. Insisting on an accurate list of crimes, setting minimum sentences, educating and ensuring the flow of information and criminal records is crucial in raising awareness of the importance of this problem. It is important for us to protect children online and to carry out active prevention while providing victims with a reliable legislative framework to find, identify and punish perpetrators. Children are our future, vulnerable and dependent on us and we must have full responsibility to protect them and therefore by voting yes I join this initiative.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I abstained from voting on the proposal. I consider online sexual abuse to be an extremely serious problem. However, the solutions proposed can lead to a restriction of freedom on the Internet without actually addressing the causes of the problems presented.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the resolution on combating child sexual abuse on the Internet. Serious offences such as child sexual exploitation and images of child abuse require a comprehensive approach, including criminal investigation, prosecution of offenders, protection of child victims and prevention of these phenomena. I voted in favour of the resolution because it strongly emphasises the need to protect children's rights on the Internet and to take measures to ensure the immediate removal of all illegal content and the notification of law enforcement agencies. It is also necessary to call on the Member States to take appropriate measures to make it easier and more frequent for children to report abuse, to improve and strengthen the measures following such notifications, and to consider establishing mechanisms for systematic and direct reporting of these acts.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Sexual abuse of children on the internet is reprehensible and therefore any measure that leads to its treatment is welcome.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The protection of children and families is one of the priorities of the FIDESZ PP group, which is why it is very important that our fellow Member Kinga Gál has co-authored the fight against violence against children on the Internet, which is also a cross-border one, which is a successful step in the fight against abuse.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on sexual abuse of children on the Internet. In my opinion, protecting and guaranteeing the safe environment and development of children is one of the most important tasks of the European Union and its Member States. I agree with the elements in the motion, and I believe that serious crimes, such as child sexual exploitation and material relating to child sexual abuse, require a comprehensive approach, including the investigation of criminal offences, the prosecution of offenders, the protection of child victims and the prevention of the phenomenon. I also believe that international cooperation and cross-border investigations in this area need to be improved. I also expect closer cooperation between Member States, Internet service providers and Europol. This motion is consistent with my initiative to extend prevention in retaliation for violence or abuse against vulnerable groups, such as women and children, as well as the elderly and disabled.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. Sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children, including child pornography, constitute serious violations of fundamental rights, in particular the right of the child to the protection and care necessary for his well-being, as enshrined in the 1989 UN Convention on the Rights of the Child and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union!  The rights and protection of children on the internet must be preserved and steps taken to ensure that all illegal content is promptly deleted and reported to law enforcement agencies, and that there are sufficient legal instruments to investigate and prosecute offenders.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution calling on Member States to make further efforts to investigate online child sexual abuse, prosecute offenders, protect child victims and remove illegal online content. To combat the sexual exploitation of children on the internet, we need a comprehensive approach involving investigation of offences, prosecution of offenders and protection of child victims.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a resolution on combating child sexual abuse online because I consider it extremely dangerous to increase the trends of this sleam, but also to manifest it through other telecommunication and information technologies that are increasingly developed and accessible. Perpetrators of sexual violence against children are taking on more and more in carrying out their intentions, as the internet has become a more than attractive place for those who commit these monstrous crimes. For preventive and proactive action, we must focus primarily on raising awareness among children and parents and informing about the dangers potential victims are exposed to and how they can respond in the fight against child sexual abuse and sexual exploitation. I agree that it is necessary to enable coordinated exchange of information and enhance cooperation between states and national legislations on the one hand and EUROPOL on the other, but it is equally important and stronger to put internet service providers under stronger supervision in order to enable all public authorities to act properly and effectively.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the motions for a resolution because the sexual abuse and exploitation of children, including child pornography and child prostitution, are very cruel crimes and are a serious violation of fundamental rights. Smartphones that are easily accessible to children and the use of the internet are a threat to children themselves. It is important to raise awareness of the potential dangers of parents and children on the internet in order to avoid becoming a victim. Efforts to combat online sexual exploitation of children are essential. There must be a greater legal basis for prosecuting criminals and more attention must be paid to preventing such offences.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I not only signed the resolution on child sexual abuse on the Internet, but also supported it by voting. I have been working on the EU telecommunications link and related issues for a long time – as rapporteur for the telecommunications part of the CONNECTING Europe Facility, I have advocated the establishment of safer internet centres, which are closely linked to the resolution. The main motivation for today's vote is to protect children from online attacks by mentally disturbed people, exploitation and abuse.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour and I welcome the positive vote on the PPE, S&D, ECR, ALDE and EFDD joint resolution on child sexual abuse online, which took place in the plenary in Strasbourg today. I want to highlight the importance of this resolution, which calls on Member States to tackle child sexual abuse on the internet vigorously, and points out that some of them have not fully implemented Directive 2011/92/EU on combating the sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children and child pornography. Child sexual abuse online knows no borders and therefore it should at least be combatted at European level through further cooperation on policing and justice as well as better prevention and reporting mechanisms.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – I supported this resolution. My justification for that is that we Greens support the fight against the sexual abuse of children, in particular through proper implementation of Directive 2011/93/EU on combating the sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children, and child pornography.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I welcome the intentions of the text, which are the fight against pedophilia and child abuse and against the distribution of images of this type of violence, and I share the importance of taking action in this area. However, the non-reference to a prior court order for the disposal of materials from the internet would set a dangerous precedent. In addition, an interested reference is made to the dark network, when less than 1% of these contents come from there, which would mean another attempt to end online privacy. Access to private citizenship data without a court order is unacceptable and, instead of lowering European data protection standards, it should move towards faster justice, with specialized cybercrime units with sufficient resources to do their job.  That is why, despite sharing the objective pursued by the Resolution, I reject the proposed ways to reach it, and that is why I abstained in the vote of the Resolution on combating online child sexual abuse.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The fight against the internet of images of sexual abuse or other illegal practices involving children is an urgent and necessary struggle. Child pornography, child sexual exploitation or other similar practices constitute major violence against children and violations of their rights.  I therefore welcome the European Parliament's wish that the European Union should act in this area and that the measures leading to the closure of sites disseminating child pornography material should be taken on the basis of a judicial decision.  However, this text calls, as is often the case in this area, for measures that are fraught with security and freedom and can endanger the protection of personal data, with the consequence of restricting the exercise of fundamental rights and civil liberties.  This is the case with the exchange of information between states, civil society organisations, social media companies, parents, teachers, social workers... or the supervision of all by all. And since I know that the protection of children is often used as a Trojan horse to restrict freedoms more broadly, in the end I abstained on this resolution, because the protection of children's rights must not be exploited.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children, including images of child abuse, constitute serious violations of fundamental rights, in particular the right of children to the protection and care necessary for their well-being, as set out in the 1989 United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. We therefore support the need for a comprehensive and coordinated approach in order to ensure consistency in policy-making and subsequent measures, including the fight against crime, fundamental rights, privacy and data protection, cybersecurity, consumer protection and e-commerce. We cannot fail to complain about the treatment of social issues that are often the basis of the sexual exploitation of children as well as other types of abuse.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. The fight against the sexual abuse of children on the Internet is a concern for me, which I support with all the means at my disposal. The Internet in particular is a frightening platform in which child abuse is strongly expressed. That is why I voted in favour of this motion.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. The common, valuable concern to protect children from sexual abuse is at the heart of this motion for a resolution, but it is surrounded by a bitter shell. I support the motion because the concern is too important. I have doubts about the legal basis of Parliament's demands. The EU's criminal competence is limited to particularly serious crime with a cross-border dimension. Sexual exploitation of children is a particularly serious crime, but the mere reference to the Internet does not justify the cross-border dimension. The mere fact that data are transferred from one Member State to another is not sufficient to satisfy the 'cross-border' feature. I see a parallel with the American federal legislature, which has acquired inadmissible powers by reinterpreting the commerce clause. In particular, I reject the call for 'partnership cooperation ... between law enforcement authorities, judicial authorities, information and communication technology companies, Internet service providers, web hosting providers, social media companies, banks and non-governmental organisations". This is the entry into total surveillance under the pretext of protecting children. Furthermore, I do not see why EU action is necessary. I can hardly imagine that there are criminal justice systems in the EU that do not adequately protect children and fail to take into account the context of modern media. The principle of subsidiarity is being violated

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this text since it calls for more to be done to protect children online and social media. Transposition of the EU directives on child protection. Illegal content should be removed online. Steps to stop cyber-grooming.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ child sexual abuse and figurative materials representing child abuse seriously violate fundamental rights, in particular children's rights to the protection and care necessary for their well-being. The measures taken by the EU by the Member States to prevent illegal content on the Internet have not always been effective. In an online environment, sexual abuse can take various forms, young people may be persuaded or forced to post their own sexually explicit images online. Children's personal data on the Internet must be protected. At the same time, we must inform children in an appropriate manner about the risks of using personal data on the Internet. Illegal content should be removed immediately in cooperation with ISPs. The Commission and the Member States should combat the spreading trends for the distribution of child abuse material, such as the 'Deep Web', private networks (Darknet) and the live broadcasting phenomenon for payment. It is important that Member States provide national contact points with sufficient financial resources to enable them to report criminal content on the Internet.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 International cooperation for the protection of children on the Internet must be a primary political objective at European level. The dangers of the internet to children are many and complex. The Commission and the Member States should immediately launch an awareness-raising campaign to enable children, as well as support for parents and teachers, to understand and manage online risks in order to protect children's online safety. At the same time, effective cooperation between Member States is needed with a view to more effective investigation, dismantling and prosecution of child sexual abuse networks.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the resolution voted on today in Strasbourg, we called for further efforts to combat online child sexual abuse, prosecute perpetrators, protect victims and remove illegal content from the Internet. The data provided by NGOs on internet pages containing material relating to child abuse is appalling; In fact, 80% of the victims are under the age of ten.  Unfortunately, the measures taken so far by the Member States for prevention have not always been effective, which is why we need a more global approach, a strengthening of international cooperation and transnational investigations, since each country has different laws in this area.  There is no need to introduce greater education and awareness of the potential risks of the network, and to this must be added measures that commit the social media sector to take its share of responsibility.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The JRC condemns in the most unequivocal and unequivocal way the crimes of sexual abuse of children, in any form, in any way and by any means. It advocates more severe punishment for perpetrators and those who in any way engage in such heinous criminal acts. It considers effective measures to prevent, inform and protect children, particularly in the use of the Internet, to be extremely important.  Pornography is only part of a huge industry, as is sex tourism, which cultivates the sickest perversions for profit.  The resolution not only hides the causes, but also exploits the huge problem of child sexual abuse as a pretext to promote the strengthening of the EU's reactionary repressive mechanisms, such as Europol. What protection, information and prevention can there be for the children of the unemployed, working-class families living in poverty? What protection of children on the internet is it about when it is controlled by monopolistic groups, while the EU and governments ensure their profitability?  Capitalism cannot cope with the rot and perversion that are intertwined with its exploitative nature. Another socio-economic system is needed with a focus on man and meeting his needs, with the people owning the wealth he produces.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I consider this resolution to be very important. Child protection has been a topic I have been dealing with for a long time, and it is the abuse of children over the Internet that has recently become a common problem. I insist that children's rights must also be protected online. We need to work together at EU level, but also globally. That is what this joint resolution calls for.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing \ u2012 I supported a resolution whose content cannot be disagreed with. It mentions, among other things, prevention, which is key to protecting children in cyberspace. The Commission should focus on it and report on the risks on the Internet not only to children, but also to parents or educators. As a precaution, it would be useful to have specific case numbers in your hands in recent years. I believe that increased cooperation between Europol, Eurostat, non-profit organisations and the private sector could produce more detailed statistics on victims and perpetrators, so that we could better face the abuse of the weakest in the future.

name: Damiano Zoffoli (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am very pleased with today's vote. Online sexual abuse of children is an abhorrent crime and we must all strive to ensure that this phenomenon is finally curbed. We must not forget that children are the most sensitive and vulnerable group in our society and it is our duty to defend them against the dangers that the Internet and new technologies represent. Above all, I believe it is essential to insist on the need for all parts of Directive 2011/93/EU on combating the sexual abuse and exploitation of children to be transposed by all Member States, since it is no longer acceptable or justifiable that more than half of them have not yet done so. We need coherent and comprehensive policies that lead to real results and involve, in close synergy, national law enforcement agencies, Europol and service providers themselves.

name: Stanisław Żółtek (NI)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The resolution on sexual abuse of children on the internet' is a camouflaged authorisation by the European Parliament for internet censorship. This means that EU and state institutions could, under the pretext of checking 'hidden paedophile content', control and block the flow of ANY information between natural and legal persons. Internet and hosting service providers, social media management companies, banking sector, etc. they would be obliged to provide the institutions/services with all information and content previews (even private correspondence and private bank transfers) and to block them, on the pretext of scrutiny, without the need for any court orders. In the whole resolution, apart from trivial content and noble names, only the content contained in paragraphs 15 and 17, quoted as "15. ... providing member states' law enforcement authorities and Europol with the necessary funds, human resources, investigative powers and technical capabilities (...)"; " 17. (...) exchange of information between law enforcement authorities, judicial authorities, the ICT industry, internet service providers, hosting service providers, social media management companies, the banking sector (...), with a view to (...) rapidly removing illegal content from the internet (...);" As a consequence, any online transmission will be fully censored by the EU services and the Member States. Under the guise of a noble-sounding name, the resolution calls for total censorship of the internet.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Communing with the general concerns expressed by this resolution, such as the fact that the Internet can expose children to specific risks, with the aim of defending the rights and protection of children on the Internet that must be safeguarded and with the need to take action to ensure their defence, what we see is that concepts and fair concerns are intentionally mixed with intentions that match fundamental rights and freedoms.  We cannot therefore agree that we want to restrict widespread access to information technologies, mobile communication and the internet, or that measures are called for to ensure that illicit content is immediately withdrawn and communicated to the police authorities, without mentioning the need to guarantee and respect the right to a fair trial and without mentioning the importance of respect for the separation of powers. It is not surprising, therefore, that there is no reference to the subjects of this resolution, children, who do not define concepts such as "illicit content", or even insert these concepts into the object of the resolution. We believe that the policies that have led to underfunding of educational programmes for children and parents in the Member States to protect children on the Internet should be reversed.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution calling for a stronger fight against child sexual abuse on the Internet, as children are particularly vulnerable to such crimes and because one of the most important tasks of the EU and the Member States is to protect children and to provide a safe environment for their development. On the Internet, children can quickly access material about sexual exploitation or be exposed to it or be subjected to bullying and grooming for sexual purposes. Exposure is exacerbated by increasing accessibility to mobile technology and the Internet. The reporting rate of these acts is very low and therefore the available data on the number of offences committed do not reflect the true scale of this problem, as in the case of 'invisible children' who are victims of trafficking and therefore do not have a legal identity. Unfortunately, less than half of the EU countries have fully implemented directive 2011/93/EC on combating child sexual abuse and child pornography, so implementation needs to be accelerated as much as possible. The strengthening of the European Cybercrime Centre, which currently has only three staff, would also be welcome, as Europol is also fighting trafficking in human beings and organised crime.

name: President. –
text: We will take the remainder of the explanations of votes tomorrow after the voting session. That concludes the explanations of vote. (The sitting was suspended at 14.45 and resumed at 15.00)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the assassination of Russian opposition leader Boris Nemtsov and the state of democracy in Russia (2015/2592(RSP)).

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I would like to thank this Chamber for the chance to discuss here today something that is extremely serious. I believe, as do you, that we all shared a sense of not only sadness, but also indignation, when we learned on the evening of 27 February of the murder of Boris Nemtsov in Moscow. He was killed just two days before leading a demonstration against the war in Ukraine and the effects of the economic crisis in Russia. On Sunday last week, tens of thousands of citizens in Moscow, but also in other cities, turned these marches into a tribute to a man who served his country as a deputy prime minister in the 1990s and who since then had relentlessly tried to bring his country forward. All 28 European Union Ambassadors, together with our European Union Head of delegation, were united in attending his funeral on Tuesday, joining an impressive crowd. Let me share here the words expressed by President Schulz on Russia’s refusal to let one of you, Ms Kalniete, into Russia to attend his funeral. The same also happened to other representatives of European Union Member States. This goes against the spirit of our visa facilitation agreement and follows similar incidents that have happened already. I remember when Ms Harms and Mr Landsbergis received a similar refusal to enter the country. They joined the words of the President of the European Parliament in saying that this is simply not acceptable. We shall remember Boris as a strong advocate for a modern, democratic and open Russia – a Russia open to the world. He defended values which we all share: respect for human dignity; commitments to democracy and to accountability; belief in civil society as a force. He was opposed to war in Ukraine, and he was gathering evidence on the involvement of Russian troops. Yesterday, here in Strasbourg in this Parliament, I met with Mikhail Kasyanov, who shared his political commitment. For me, it was a way to honour his memory and to express, once again, our sadness at the loss that his family, friends and his colleagues have suffered, and for the gap he leaves in political life in Russia.  But it also gave me a chance to discuss the state of democracy in Russia. Russian citizens deserve no less than a democratic and open Russia. Strengthening political freedoms and supporting the consolidation of democracy are, moreover, objectives set out in the first article of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and Russia. We support Russian organisations who are working on improving the legal framework in Russia. In our human rights consultations, we have called on Russia – time and again – to establish a level playing field for political parties by allowing opposition parties to play a role and by ensuring diversity of the media. Looking at the state of democracy in Russia today, we see that freedom of expression is under increased pressure. Opposition parties struggle to exist and to have access to mainstream media. Some have been repeatedly denied registration. The last Duma elections in 2011 were described as ‘slanted in favour of the ruling party’ by OSCE/ODIHR. Remember that the Russian population opposed those practices by taking to the streets, leading to the well—known Bolotnaya Square trials. Individual leaders who emerged from those events are constantly harassed, while others left Russia out of fear for their freedom or for their lives.  This recent assassination brings back to our minds the memories of many others: Natalia Estemirova, Anna Politkovskaya, Stanislav Markelov, Anastasia Baburova, Sergei Magnitsky and Alexander Litvinenko. Journalists, lawyers, intelligence officers, human rights defenders – they had little in common until they became victims of those who portray so—called ‘enemies of the state’ as legitimate targets.  We all know that the conflict in Ukraine has intensified the public discourse against the too—famous Fifth Column. Let us not forget those who face trial in Russia through unfair procedures because of the Ukrainian conflict, such as Nadia Savchenko and Oleg Sentsov, who was arrested in Crimea. The Russian authorities have not only the duty to conduct a full and transparent investigation into the murder of Boris Nemtsov, but they also have to put an end to the climate of suspicion, hatred and intolerance for diversity of opinion. The defence of basic freedoms, including the freedom of expression, is – I would like to remind you in this room – a statutory obligation for all members of the United Nations.

name: Sandra Kalniete
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the – The murder of the villainous Takecova is a 'hybrid message' of Putin's system to the whole liberal democratic world: we are ready for everything to preserve our dictatorship. However, we Europeans know from experience that, sooner or later, every dictatorship is destroying itself from within, so we must arm ourselves with strategic patience and prepare ourselves to defend ourselves against the agony of the Putin regime, which may last for years. Of the many works, I would like to highlight some of the most important: – Putin's system feeds on our petrodollars. That is why we need joint gas purchases within the European Energy Union. It will be cheaper and fairer. – Putin's false propaganda machine is actively taking over people's minds. Europe must therefore create counter-measures: high-quality and attractive media and support journalists who write in Russian. – European countries have enjoyed 'peace dividends' for decades and have not invested adequately in defence. President Juncker has begun talking about a European army, so Member States should start with an adequate defence budget, reaching 'two per cent of GDP'. And, finally, we must continue to have dialogue and contact with the Russian people, to educate young people so that, as the regime collapses, Russia has modern and European people capable of bringing the country out of the curse of repeating dictatorships. Thanks for the attention! (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. "Mr President, Congresswoman, I am really very honest, I do not mean to be a nuisance. I am simply asking you honestly that there are 12 Fidesz members in your people's party group, which is a party whose boss, leader Viktor Orban, the current Hungarian Prime Minister, has called Vladimir Putin a role model in several interviews and in public interviews, and cited as an example the Russian way that we condemn here today and have done so in comparison to the European way. Don't you talk about that within your own group?

name: Sandra Kalniete (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – I will answer your question. Prime Minister Orbán was elected with a great majority by the Hungarian people and no other European Member State can change that. That is why it is important that we have him in our EPP political party, and we have a current and ever—growing dialogue on the values that we share.

name: Knut Fleckenstein
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which We Social Democrats are dismayed by the murder of Boris Nemtsov, and we mourn with his family and friends and with all those who want to open up Russia and to ensure that the people of Russia can also lead a life of more democracy and more civil liberties. We condemn the cowardly murder, the murderers and, above all, their backers. And we urge the Russian Government not only to investigate this crime thoroughly, but above all transparently. We do not engage in speculation, but we know that such things happen whenever the environment invites them to do so. The incredible propaganda machine, the vilification of dissidents, the nationalist tendencies in government and the state, and the NGO legislation – keyword: foreign agent – are just four examples of how to create an atmosphere that then accepts such acts. Those who are rightly appalled by the murder of Boris Nemtsov must not leave it to the expressions of condolences, but must work for full enlightenment and, above all, to want to change the living conditions. In other words, it must promote a free, open dialogue between its citizens, freedom of the media and democracy and an atmosphere of tolerance. We here in the European Parliament, who want to support such a development, should make this clear, but also in a process that will allow for a free, open dialogue in the future, so that we can make a difference.

name: Andrzej Duda
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Anna Politkovskaya, Alexander Litvinenko, Natalia Estemirova and Sergei Magnitsky are a very narrow, small fraction of those who have been assassinated in Russia in recent years or died in prison in strange circumstances. Most recently, Boris Nemtsov. Shot on a bridge near the Kremlin wall, in a zone (i don't think anyone doubts about it) closely watched by the Russian special services, if only for the protection of the Russian authorities and their headquarters.  Is there democracy in Russia at all? Are there no fair elections in a country where (no doubt) there are fair elections; in a country where the judiciary, despite constitutional provisions, despite a number of constitutional guarantees also as to the observance of citizens' rights, is in principle entirely dependent on power; in a country where there is such extensive propaganda that it is difficult to find anywhere any reliable information about what is happening inside and outside this country, where independent media and NGOs are choked, where fear in any way opposes power; in a country where people who are real opposition must today be called by us not ordinary politicians, as is the case in democratic countries, but simply heroes (because if only looking at the examples that I have mentioned, in fact, every day when they say how power works in Russia, they have to reckon with death) – can we even talk about democracy in such a country? It seems to me that today's Russia has nothing to do with democracy. This proves just how drastically the Russian Constitution is violated on a daily basis. This is demonstrated by the fact that Russia, after all, is a member of the Council of Europe and has signed all the related commitments, and as it observes in internal affairs, we all see.  But it is not only a problem of Russia's actions in the internal sphere, it is also a problem of Russia's actions in the external sphere. It is the first European state to militarily invade another sovereign, independent European state, taking away part of its territory. Today, Vladimir Putin is pleased to say that he gave a secret order a year ago to seize Crimea, and yet a year ago he and Russian politicians said that they had nothing to do with it at all. The "green men", however, turned out to be the Russian army. Today, the direct participation of Russia and Russian soldiers in what is happening in Donetsk, in a war in which ukrainians, including civilians, are killed. In a year's time, will we hear that, however, these were Russian soldiers who were officially sent there by the Russian President? Finally, the last point I would like to raise, namely the tragedy in Smolensk five years ago, where a plane crashed with the Polish President on board and people who are extremely important in the sphere of Polish social and political life. They all died. To date, no reliable investigation has been carried out, no Polish or plane wreckage has been returned (...).

name: Johannes Cornelis van Baalen
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Boris Nemtsov was our man. His party belongs to the ALDE family, but he is a man we do not claim for ourselves: he belongs to all of us. He – like many others – wanted to make Russia a better place. Mikhail Kasyanov was here – also a dear friend – and he was quite clear: we in this Parliament should not look into the mirror and say that we have made mistakes or that the enlargement of NATO was a mistake because it provoked Putin. No, that is nonsense. NATO has brought shelter to the countries in Eastern Europe which are now members of the organisation. Also, Putin knows that ‘it stops’ over there. So the enlargement of NATO did not incite Putin’s policy, which is a long—term policy of crippling the neighbouring countries and of restoring the influence, at least, of the former Soviet Union. It is also about restoring an absence of the rule of law because, even if you do not like a politician, you should respect him or her and that politician should be safe. If you declare that they are enemies of the state, and if a person like Ramzan Kadyrov says that enemies of the state will face a bleak future, that means that you hate democracy and you make it impossible for Russia – a great nation, whose people we love and respect – to have a relaxed and normal relationship with other people. The international dimension and the internal dimension come together here. It is up to Putin to make sure that those who killed Nemtsov are brought to real justice and that everything is done to clear up this situation. What we should do is to talk with Russians and with human rights organisations because, on the one hand, we have sanctions – and they should stay – but, on the other hand, we are reaching out to the ordinary people in Russia.

name: Merja Kyllönen
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the assassination of Boris Nemtsov once again brought before us the climate of hatred and intolerance that has expanded in Russia, but it is also increasingly present in our Europe. I am very concerned that civil society, civil and human rights, freedom of expression, democracy and equality will soon be called into question everywhere. All of these, which I have just listed, are signs of a civilised society. Even a strong society can withstand critical voices without anyone having to die because of their political opinions. We must not give any ground to racism, xenophobia and far-right movement. It is our common responsibility to strive for a constructive climate of debate, especially when we are living in the midst of conflicts. And we must honour the memory of Boris Nemtsov and the great sorrow of his family, friends and colleagues, even enough for no party to use this sad death for its own political ends. Let's not give the propaganda war weapons. The European Union has been built into a Union of peace. Therefore, as one of the reasons, it was originally established. We must work for peace, democracy and human rights, tirelessly and always. (The speaker promised to answer the blue card question under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card question. – Colleague, I would like to ask whether you would be prepared for your group also to agree to the statement that we should honour the memory of the murdered Mr Nemtsov also by clearly denouncing the environment of hate that has been created against Russian opposition figures by the Kremlin?

name: Merja Kyllönen (GUE/NGL)
text: The answer to the blue card question. – Mr President, our group is always prepared to work for peace and precisely for freedom of expression and people's right to opinion and democracy in this world to progress.

name: Rebecca Harms
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the My group has really been very much in favour of having this debate after the murder of Boris Nemtsov. We are convinced that the courageous Boris Nemtsov, who has paid for his political courage with his life, deserves this debate and more. We believe that we must take his family's grief seriously, that we must encourage his intimidated friends. I think that the resolution that we are going to adopt today contains a great deal of that. But why did Boris Nemtsov have to die? "The crisis is mainly rooted in the fact that Putin has begun an insanely aggressive policy of war against Ukraine, which is deadly for our country and many citizens." Boris Nemtsov said this in an interview in Russian media just hours before his death. Clearly, those who are trying to bring the truth forward in Russia are again at great risk. At the funeral rally, there was a poster that read: "Propaganda kills! Who of us is next?" This shows the whole challenge for the European Union. President Putin has brought his country back in time, opponents are seen as traitors, they are now being treated like dissidents again. It's an incredible leap back in time. Glasnost and perestroika – when was it? That is a quarter of a century ago! I can only agree with Mr van Baalen: we must find an appropriate course towards Russia, with regard to leadership. However, we should also do everything we can to keep our contacts with civil society alive, because our policy is directed against President Putin's regime, but not against Russia.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, Boris Nemtsov was the leader of opposition and free thought in Russia. Boris Nemtsov was Russia’s hope to become a democratic state. It is less important who actually pulled the trigger: we must ensure that not only the killers but also those who ordered this assassination are punished. It is obvious that Boris was killed by forces that spread darkness, aggression and hatred in Russia. It is unfortunate that today it is precisely these forces which are represented by the current Russian leadership. For this reason, the Russian leaders are responsible for the death of Boris Nemtsov. Boris Nemtsov is gone, but let us hope that this tragedy will become a stimulus for the opposition’s unity in Russia. His unfinished work must be continued.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the murder of a person must always be condemned; of course the League condemns him and we hope that they will put the culprits in jail.  Having said that, this House scares me or makes me laugh. What title does this House have to try Putin and the Russian people? In order to decide who is democratic and who is a dictator? This Europe has nothing democratic. This Europe is dangerous. This Europe instigates war and violence. The support for the Arab spring, which you have supported and now in the middle of the African continent and in much of Asia, commands extremists and cutthroats. It is good for you to talk to Turkey, which has been militarily occupying a Member State of the European Union for forty years, putting journalists in jail and filling us with hundreds of illegal immigrants every week. You talk about hate – and I do not know if you have understood or are complicit – and deploy missiles, tanks and military on the border with Russia. You talk about work and impose unnecessary and idiotic economic sanctions, which harm the Russian people and thousands of Italian and European workers and entrepreneurs. We must talk to Russia, we must trade, we must discuss, we must work together against Islamic terrorism: you prefer to play war, you prefer to support trade wars that appeal to others. They pay you a salary to take care of Europe, they pay you a salary to give jobs and a future to Europeans, not to go and export your dirty democracy around the world, not least because what you have done in recent years of positive results has not brought one.  (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr Salvini spoke of the state of democracy in Europe and Russia. I'd like to ask him a simple question. Does he consider Russia to be a more democratic state than Italy? I expect your answer.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: Answer to a blue card question. I believe that Russia is certainly much more democratic than the European Union as it is today, which is a fake democracy. Education predicts that a question can be answered, then mumbled outside in front of a coffee politely. I am giving you my opinion, if you may be interested in a democracy. I would make a change and take Putin to half of the European countries that are poorly governed by supposedly elected prime ministers, who are not elected by anyone but are remote-controlled by someone else.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: Mr President, I must always speak after statements like this. I'm a little embarrassed, but that's the way it is. I would like to point out a tragic coincidence: on 27 February 2014, the Parliament of Crimea was occupied. A year later, to the day, on the streets of Moscow, close to the Kremlin, this horrific assassination of Boris Nemtsov took place. Basically, there is a strong link between these two events. This is not just a coincidence of the calendar, because we know that the political author of these two acts is Vladimir Putin. Even if, indeed, a year ago, he pretended to completely ignore what is happening in Crimea, now, for him, the question of Crimea's membership is no longer debatable. For us, this is unacceptable, as we know.  As for Boris Nemtsov, we have just learned that the culprits are Chechens. However, as Prime Minister Kasyanov explained very well this morning at the meeting of our Committee on Foreign Affairs, this is almost impossible - it is a close friend of Boris Nemtsov who explained it to us - because Boris Nemtsov had excellent relations with this people.  This is therefore unacceptable, and we see in this particular case the two sides: the inner face, namely the crimes committed by the regime inside, and the external side of Putin's regime, aggressive, violent but which, unfortunately, has given rise to supporters, as we have seen here. These divisions of Europe are Putin's strategy and unfortunately we have colleagues here who fall into this trap. It's horrible, extreme left and extreme right combined. (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Marju Lauristin (S&D).
text: – Mr President, firstly I want to express my deep sorrow for the loss of Boris Nemtsov, a friend of many of us. He was killed not only by the gunmen: he was killed, as has been said, by an atmosphere of hatred; he was killed by this propaganda war launched by Putin against the West, against democracy and against all of us. We can see how Russia, Putin’s Russia, is shifting towards the darkest times, similar to the 1930s – it is not a coincidence that the murder of Nemtsov has been mentioned already as a parallel with the murder of Sergei Kirov, which was the start of Stalinist dark times in the Soviet Union. We can see too that this new, emerging neo-Stalinism in Russia is characterised by the very skilful use of new media. In the information war, it is one of the strongest tools for the massive brainwashing of young people in Russia and also all over the world. This is a very dangerous trend. I am sorry to say that Putin’s regime is encouraged by our own reluctance – that of us, the West, democratic public opinion – to recognise the full scale of the threat emerging from these current developments. The European Union should apply relevant counter—measures against this global brainwashing machinery created by Russia because we can see that it is expanding. Now they plan to raise the budget by 40% to be able to communicate not only in English but also in French and German, all over Europe and all over the world. In this context I also want to give a message of warning to those politicians and journalists who sometimes repeat ideas they pick up from Russia Today and other channels – among them the idea that Baltic countries will be easy targets. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: – Mr President, Boris Nemtsov was one of the most important bridge builders between Russia and Ukraine, one of the few politicians to openly and sharply criticize the authoritarian political climate in Putin's Russia. He called the conflict in Ukraine a painful fratricidal war and a pointless confrontation with Europe's neighbours. He was working on a report on President Putin's role in Ukraine. This morning we did indeed hear former Prime Minister of Russia, Mikhail Kasyanov, in the AFET committee. He, too, came to the conclusion: "This was a political assassination." There is no criticism of President Putin's role in Ukraine. The murder of Boris Nemtsov is a warning to all other political dissidents in Russia.  Let's take a look at the murder investigation: chechens' involvement raises questions. That would link Nemtsov's murder to his public support for Charlie Hebdo. Chechnya's strongman, Kadyrov, defended the prime suspect in the murder on Monday, portraying him as a "true Russian patriot" and a "devout Muslim" shocked by the caricatures at Charlie Hebdo. Nemtsov regularly accused Kadyrov of intimidating journalists and in November called for an investigation into the involvement of Chechen fighters in eastern Ukraine. But no, as Kasyanov also confirmed this morning, he has spoken out against Muslims or against Islam. On the contrary, he was always an advocate of tolerance. The main suspect in this Russia is out of suspicion. For years, Putin's regime has created a climate of distrust and hatred of dissidents. He calls the opposition the "fifth column." Meanwhile, the ultimate fear of the opposition becomes reality: the assassins have been arrested, but the principals remain at large. I certainly call on the Russian opposition not to be weakened. For our part - and I quote Mikhael Kasyanov again - we must clearly demonstrate to Putin that we will continue to defend and protect our values and stick to our democratic principles! (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – I would like to ask our colleague and friend: do you not think that there are lots of rifts between the European Union countries concerning a common foreign and security policy? Do you not see that there are European leaders that are approaching Russia in a different way and do you not think it is time for unity, solidarity and common positions towards Russia between the European Union countries?

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: "blue card" answer. – I wholeheartedly agree with you. I couldn't put it better myself. We do indeed need a united voice, and I have actually ended my speech with it. We must show - but must indeed do so in unison - that we do indeed stand by our democratic principles, while respecting the international rule of law. With that clear message, we must also dialogue with Putin's Russia. We must make that message clear and act on it.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the picture of the body of Boris Nemtsov lying in front of the Kremlin was a message someone chose to send in such a shocking way. This message is for us who represent democracy and values and who knew Boris personally – knew him as a man of exceptional courage and strength. But, first and foremost, this is a brutal reminder for those in Russia who are still trying to save their country from sliding into the darkest ages of its past. The parallel with the USSR of blood and terror of the 1930s is appalling and the message is that the dark times may become the unfortunate reality of Russia tomorrow. Everyone who perceives Russia as a European state and nation is a spy, whoever speaks about corruption is an enemy, and whoever has his own opinion is a traitor. No one can feel safe – anyone could be next.  It is clear that the atmosphere of hatred towards the West and of hostility to the open—minded people of Russia made it possible for this to happen. It is a logical outcome of the policy line pursued in the last 15 years, namely Putinism. Today, by respecting the memory of Boris Nemtsov, we should not forget the fate of Nadia Savchenko. Putin, free Savchenko! (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (NI)
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, when I hear you, and given my positions, I feel like I am in exactly the same situation.  As soon as I express a point of view that is opposed to your assembly, I am absolutely demonized. So ask yourself the question not only on the side of Russia, also ask yourself the question of your assembly and how your assembly reacts as soon as it encounters a little opposition that is made to it simply to recall the truth of the facts. Because what I am saying is what our president, among others French, says.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – I believe we have common sense and we know the colours of black and white. This is not painting in different colours; we know who is waging war in Ukraine. Those soldiers have insignia and armoured vehicles and we recognise those tanks and colours. Please do not try to get away from the truth; face it and you will be freed.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL).
text: – I have never forgotten my encounters with Boris Nemtsov. His murder added a Shakespearean touch to those memories. A man who loved life above all else and knew how to live was murdered. He could enjoy winning, but he could lose. He was a big, happy child. He was also a man of his time and a participant in Russian destiny.  I don't want to spark emotions that are usually more than healthy in this room. However, I must say that the negative reflex by which some Western politicians and journalists respond to perhaps all information from Russia is extremely inappropriate in this case.  Boris Nemtsov was an opposition politician who liked Russia. He was in opposition not because he wanted to unite the world against Russia, but because he had a different view than the Kremlin on the road to a quality life in Russia. For various reasons, his ideas have come to the margins of public interest. But that does not mean that one day they cannot be a successful vision, that is political life.  I am deeply convinced that Boris Nemtsov would disagree if his death were used to spread anti-Russian hysteria.

name: Tamás Meszerics (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President: this is yet another tragedy on which we are entitled to speak and we need to speak. The death of Boris Nemtsov is not just the murder of a politician. Politicians can be murdered for many different reasons all around the world. When politicians are murdered in Russia it is usually a political murder. Of course, what we demand from the Russian authorities is the swift and timely revelation of all the facts they know, but we have the suspicion that this may not extend to telling the whole story. After all, the official report on the murder of Sergei Kirov is still that a lone murderer was responsible. There have been other cases, like the murders of Anna Politkovskaya and numerous others, which raise the question as to how far the Kremlin is actually willing to go in preventing atrocities happening to opposition politicians. If standing in elections as an opposition candidate puts your life at risk, and if standing up for values and criticising the policies of your government puts your life or your freedom at risk, then this calls into question the degree of democracy in the country concerned. If Russia is a democracy then it should respond to acts of terror like this in the way that democracies do. France stood up after the Charlie Hebdo attack and unequivocally said that the appropriate response was to strengthen freedom of expression, to strengthen the rule of law, and to strengthen individual political freedoms for everyone in the country in order to prevent any repeat. This is what we require from Russia. This is what we ask of Russia. We cannot and will not decide for Russia what kind of political system its people wish to live under, but Russia deserves better.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, our Parliament, in the absence of a vision of the future and peace in our unity, has already judged. We have members of Parliament who are both police officers and judges. Boris Nemtsov had just been cowardly assassinated as our chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee was already condemning "Russia and Putin's gulags". I wish he was with me when I was fighting the real Bolshevik gulags.  Boris Nemtsov is not the leader of the opposition in Russia. It represents 4% of the voters cast. The leader of the opposition is the Communist Party, which represents 20%. The ultranationalist Jirinovsky makes 9%. These parties are totally opposed to the current Europe and Putin, believe me, compared to them, is frankly a moderate. We would do better to support the Minsk and peace agreements and not respond to provocations.

name: Elmar Brok (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Schaffhauser, I regret that I am in favour of positions that are alien to you: for parliamentary democracy, for tolerance, for pluralism, for freedom of expression and media, for not creating a climate of fear, for not hanging posters in a city declaring people bird-free because they are traitors to the fatherland. These were all boris Nemtsov's positions. I do not expect any other statement from you, who are said to be the money-payer between Putin and Le Pen, because your speech is probably also part of the fee you received from Putin for your party. I would just like to say that an atmosphere in a country is possible here ... (Interjections from Mr. Schaffhauser without a microphone.) Mr Schaffhauser, I have the problem that I do not understand you either with or without headphones, because I can never understand what you are saying anyway! We must make it clear that an atmosphere is being created that promotes such crime. If someone is declared bird-free and called a traitor to the fatherland, then such murders happen. And coincidentally, these murders are always directed against opposition politicians. And coincidentally, the perpetrators always come from the Caucasus. And coincidentally, you never find the people behind it. This is a system that we cannot accept, and it must be branded. Boris Nemtsov has spoken out in favour of territorial integrity. He has called for Russia to comply with the treaties that that country has concluded. And he has had to pay for it. We have here a man whom we have to honour as a democrat, as a courageous person, as a man who has stood up for the rights of others. I bow to that!

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr Schaffhauser, I would like to thank Mr Schaffhauser for his You have been directly mentioned. The Rules of Procedure now give you the opportunity to answer the facts raised by Mr Brok for half a minute.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (NI).
text: Mr President, I will only ask for one thing - and I hope that we will remain friends - I ask my colleague Mr Brok to withdraw what he said. Otherwise, of course, I will have to sue him, which I will win, for what he said, which is absolutely defamatory.  So, dear colleague, are you prepared or not to take away what you said defamatory?

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr Brok can comment on this at the end of the debate. We are now continuing the debate in memory of Boris Nemtsov. (Interruption Schaffhauser: Non, il veut parler...) Mr Brok, do you want to take a position immediately? Please very much, sir.

name: Elmar Brok (PPE).
text: I have set out a fact, I have said that it is said that you played a role in these financial transactions between Putin and Le Pen. I have not said anything else.

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the truly cowardly murder of the Russian opposition leader, Boris Nemtsov, is the result of the fervent propaganda that Russia has been using towards the so-called West. That is where Mrs Lauristin said quite rightly. Relations between the European Union and Russia are now difficult and in a certain stress test. Until recently, a couple of decades ago, the European Union supported Russia as a member of the WTO, with the aim of a common objective, a democratic and modern Russia. And now we see that Russia has become an authoritarian and aggressive country for which the West is the enemy. However, this cooperation between the EU and Russia, which was once built in agony, must not be worsened. We must try, of course, to engage in self-criticism, but not to blame ourselves, because the decisive change in doctrin has taken place in Russia. It is a great pity that these relations are now so bad, because the efforts of Europe, Russia and the international community as a whole are needed to combat terrorism, to mitigate climate change, and Arctic cooperation also requires more cooperation than hitherto.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by How can the world be safe, how can we be safe, and how can the Russians themselves be safe if communism and the communist past are still subject to public worship in Russia? It's not just that this cult takes place in Moscow's Red Square. In the smallest cities of Russia there are monuments of Lenin. Dzierżyński, one of the greatest criminals in human history, is the patron saint of the Russian special services. Stalin's imperialist policy is still publicly defended by the Russian authorities. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur Condemnation of communism is needed not only for us, not only for Europe, but also for us. It is necessary for Russia itself, it is needed by the Russians and especially for those who suffered the most there.

name: Kaja Kallas (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I join colleagues in expressing my deepest condolences to the family and friends of Boris Nemtsov. His name has very sadly been added to the far—too—long list of Russian politicians and journalists murdered for speaking out against the system. I grew up during Soviet times with stories from my mother who was deported to Siberia in a animal wagon when she was just six months old; of my grandfather who was sent to a prison camp; of my grandmother who lost two children during the war. Every family in our country has a similar story and so do Russian families. I still remember the fear of wondering what might happen to my father who opposed the regime. Therefore, I understand the fears that the opposition in Russia might have.  Speaking up in Russia for democracy, fundamental freedoms and respect for the rule of law takes lots of courage. Opposing Putin’s regime takes a lot of courage. I wanted therefore to express my admiration for those who speak out in Russia, but also to remind ourselves that, as politicians of Europe, where we have no reason to be afraid, we do not have any excuse for not speaking out against what is happening in Russia and in Ukraine.

name: Heidi Hautala (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I want to honour the memory of our friend Boris Nemtsov by quoting what he said in this House in a meeting on 16 February 2011 when he was our guest. He said: ‘Putin killed the democratic state’. There is a very good record of all that he said here on that day. He was here in Parliament to call for support for the forthcoming Duma and presidential elections, and many of us were participating with the democratic opposition in order to find ways to make sure that once again those elections would not be stolen. But, as we know, they were stolen.
