You have thus fostered the outbreak of a full-blown civil war in this country. This situation must not degenerate into a new war on European soil.  Changing its strategy is absolutely necessary to keep Europe at peace. No power of this continent should have an imperialist aim, none should be demonized!

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to congratulate and thank Mr Brok for his excellent report, which proposes both a genuine strategic vision of the Union's foreign and security policy and concrete measures to improve this policy. I will emphasize three things. First of all, I thank you, Mrs Mogherini, for making a great contribution to raising the profile of our work. Let's continue on this path. And for that, the special representatives also have a key role to play. We need to value their work better. At the operational level, too, we must continue to seek to equip ourselves with adequate means to enhance this visibility. Second, the coherence between our internal and external policies. Strengthening us externally will bring domestic benefits. Consider examples, particularly among sensitive topics such as migration. Consistency must also be ensured both at Council level and in third countries between EU delegations and embassies. It is a question of credibility. Finally, cooperation with regional organizations. Working with the African Union, the Arab League and the Gulf countries means giving us opportunities to fight terrorism better, to cooperate better, for the benefit of all citizens.

name: Vincent Peillon (S&D).
text: Madam President, Madam High Representative, yes, this report sets out what a common foreign and security policy ambition can be, knowing that for the construction of the European Union, it is probably a test, and the most difficult. We have heard that before. What would the founders have imagined when they heard some worried about the future about the quarrels over Gibraltar between the English and the Spaniards, in a continent that lived through two centuries of tragedies and managed to overcome them by building the Union? I would like to draw your attention to three or four conditions for the success of the work you are doing and for our full support. Firstly, we must, in fact, both bring our European policies into line and ask states to overcome their reluctance, their "cavalier alone" policy and their selfishness. Some do not realize that by weakening Europe, they are now weakening themselves on the international stage. From this point of view, you will find us at your side if you need help with a number of Member States which still consider the common foreign and security policy to be a national matter. Second, we must, of course, better coordinate our action with that of our allies. But it is important to hear - because we are Europe and we have different cultural and social values - that this better coordination should not prevent us from marking our independence and autonomy in all areas of the world, where we operate, vis-à-vis some of our allies.  Third, of course, there is no law without force. We have known this for centuries and the President of the Commission was right to say that the aim is to strengthen operational resources. Fourth, we need to further enhance our presence in our South.

name: David Campbell Bannerman (ECR).
text: – Madam President, this week we had the Commission President, Mr Juncker, blatantly calling for a common European army to, and I quote: ʽallow Europe to take on responsibility in the world and to send a clear message to Russiaʼ. I have no doubt that if we had an EU army now it would be losing thousands of troops in Ukraine in a futile exercise to prove that the EU is a powerful empire.  It is always a bad military tactic to divide your army, but this report would divide NATO and the EU. The Brok report calls for coordination of defence budgets, an EU arms trade authority, common EU defence attachés and a permanent EU headquarters – the very headquarters proposal that was voted down in the Council just over a year ago. Nor is it, I fear, a coincidence that all our national armed forces are being slashed. The true purpose is to destroy our national ability to act independently so we have no alternative but to pool and share our armed forces. These European defence moves are profoundly dangerous and must be stopped in their tracks.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI). Madam President, the Juncker Declaration on the transformation of the Euro-Army into a permanent body, the european Union's even greater coordination and joint action with NATO is a pre-confrontation of the European Union's aggression against the peoples and the suppression of their struggles. The European Union and its governments are "cutting", NATO is "stitching", peoples are being slaughtered and countries are being dismembered for imperialist interests, such as "in Ukraine, Libya, Iraq, Africa.  There is no security for the people within the European Union and NATO. Turkey's aggression against Greece and Cyprus these days is proof. Only illusions are sown by those who hypocritically present the European Union as the dove of peace. No illusions. The peoples should also be vigilant in their fight against imperialist plans to shake off the shackles of the European Union and NATO by overthrowing the exploitation system with their own authority.

name: Jo Leinen (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mrs Mogherini, you said that the EU can and must do more in foreign and security policy. We can only agree with that. President Juncker said in an interview over the weekend that the EU is unlikely to be taken seriously in the world. If you travel outside Europe, that is partly true. Whether in Beijing or New Delhi or Johannesburg or Brasilia, the EU is not visible, nor is it effective. You also said that, in addition to economic relations, we need a comprehensive political agenda with our strategic partners. We need dialogues and negotiations for this world order according to firm rules, be it with regard to the preservation of peace, the preservation of human rights, and this year also with regard to the preservation of the climate on the way to Paris. I would also encourage you not to forget the boom region of Asia, in addition to all the crises on your doorstep. We have not had a China strategy for ten years. We need a new strategy for this great country to cooperate with that country.

name: Udo Voigt (NI).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In this report, as a former air force officer, I hear the voice of the Cold War again, and I am very surprised, because that time is thirty years ago. The report fails to note that the geostrategic situation has changed completely over the last thirty years. Thirty years ago, it was the Warsaw Pact that embraced NATO and the EU Europe. But thirty years later, it is NATO that embraces Russia, and the Warsaw Pact no longer exists. There is no doubt that this must lead to a Russian need for security. I do not see that in this House that this is being debated at all. Mr Brok's language is that of the Cold Warrior and the Atlantic. I do not understand at all how we can demand here that the EU should continue to work closely with NATO in the future, because this will determine a non-spatial power, namely the United States of America, over Europe.

name: Ramona Nicole Mănescu (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the security situation around the EU is increasingly grave, both to the east with regard to Ukraine and Russia and to the south where terrorism is spiralling out of control. This is a serious challenge for EU foreign policy, since we must respond effectively and strategically without for one second losing sight of our core European values. Everything we do must foster democracy and the rule of law as well as human rights for all. I would like to underline the need to focus our attention on our vital role in bringing peace and stability to the Middle East, and also the need to rethink the common foreign and security policy, with a stronger foreign policy role for the Union. Religious extremism and terror are not only costing thousands of lives in Syria, Iraq and elsewhere but also increasingly pose a threat to our own national security. Therefore, I welcome Ms Mogherini’s decision to cooperate closely with the EU Counter-terrorism Coordinator because I believe that the better the coordination among us, the more effective European foreign and security policy will be.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I support Mr Brok’s report, but Parliament will understand if I use this short speech to warn how the security threats facing Europe underline how much my own country needs Europe and how dangerous is the domestic debate which threatens Britain’s future in the EU. How can the British Prime Minister call for tougher European action on Russia, then himself threaten European unity to achieve it? What if we want to resolve the conflict between Israel and Palestine, but seek to undermine the EU’s role as a member of the Quartet to achieve that? Or walk away from the negotiating table for nuclear non—proliferation in Iran, where Britain has negotiated on behalf of the EU? Or promote a trade agreement between Europe and the United States, then threaten to remove British business from its benefits? How can the British Government allow my country’s only aircraft carrier to be retired and rely on a French carrier, but then resist the development of common security and defence policy missions, which are both badly needed and which could help problems of overstretched defence resources? When in this debate we talk about common European values which underline our external policy, which is of these precisely is not a British value too?  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – Madam President, the biggest foreign policy challenge for the European Union in 2014 would have been to participate effectively in re-solving the Ukrainian conflict, but it failed. From the outset, the Union has been completely one-sided in assessing the situation. He supported the new government, which came to power with the help of the United States, in every way and uncritical, and simply described those fighting for their self-determination as separatist terrorists. He did not take into account that, in this conflict, Russia also has clear national security interests. Ukraine is the victim of a global power play. The United States seeks to restore a pole world order. The EU must not become a hench member in this game, it must pursue an independent foreign policy on a new footing for the benefit of its member countries and the peoples of Ukraine.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I welcome the High Representative’s statement that the EU has to start thinking in a strategic way. But now that we are facing the biggest instability in our neighbourhood, I am wondering whether we also need to act in a strategic and global way. Our security situation has worsened dramatically, and thus it is possible that different crucibles of conflict will spread contagion and develop synergies. This requires stronger and more coherent EU common policies. First of all, we need to increase coherence of CFSP with other policies of external dimension. I call on you, High Representative, to develop strategic priorities for applying the external energy policy in a more coordinated way, and to achieve clarity and unity on the practical use of solidarity mechanisms. Lastly, mainstreaming cyber defence into common foreign and security policy and providing political impetus to the EDA is enforcing cyber defence cooperation between Member States.

name: Eugen Freund (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I, too, would like to thank my colleague Elmar Brok for the comprehensive report. I agree in essence with what it says. My limitation relates to the premise of the report. The EU, it is said here, has not been able to reach its full potential because of its internal crisis. In a variation of a quotation from the epochal "Last Days of Humanity" by Karl Kraus, let me say: Let us stop the crisis-winelei! Europe is the world's largest economic power, Europe is more than ever – just think of the Ukraine conflict. A lot of things could be better, but let us show more self-confidence, let us show more optimism! Let me explain this with another quote. In the weekly newspaper Die Zeit recently, the authors asked: "Why is it so difficult for the EU to recognize its own successes?" And the authors answer: "In the think tanks and MPs' offices, we continue to work on talking about everything big small, all beautiful ugly and all juicy bland." That's what we should write in the family log!

name: Gerolf Annemans (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, you are in your delusion about creating a great European unitary state, now that it seems that you have also decided, in addition to the euro single currency, to place the icing of a foreign and even military policy on top of the cake of your unitary state. Slowly, we are shifting the intention here to pursue a less cacophonous foreign policy towards militarising a basically civil Union.  As a young man, I was a fierce Atlantic-focused supporter of NATO, and I fought side by side with Ronald Reagan for the deployment of nuclear missiles against the Soviet Union and against the then dominant left-wing and anti-American elite. But the euro crisis has taught me that the unity maniacs of the European Union are fuelling dangerous divisions within Europe rather than bringing unity and calm. For the same reason, the growing threat of war, I have become an opponent of your dangerous delusion of unity in terms of military and foreign policy, which is far too distant from European citizens.

name: Ελένη Θεοχάρους (
text: PPE). Madam President, High Representative, the Brok report is an integrated approach to the European Union's foreign policy, defence and security issues and its role as a regional global stability and peace force. In that regard, however, two important issues arise.  First, the need to strengthen the parameters of cybersecurity and cyber deterrence, which have multiple dimensions and include the protection of states, businesses and citizens. In the case of the Ukrainian war, the European Union experienced the traumatic experience of Russian cyberwar and malware with the Greek code name "Urvoros", the mythical snake that eats its tail, paralyzing Ukraine's armed forces and services, facilitating the work of the Russian armed forces. An integral part of modern strategy is cyber deterrence.  The second issue I want to raise is the war on terror that threatens us from everywhere. This requires a single and coherent policy in which Cyprus can play a key role, as an advanced outpost of the European Union for security, both in Europe and in the Middle East.

name: Javi López (S&D).
text: – Madam President, in recent years, as the European Union substantially improved its tools, foreign policy instruments, security challenges and threats, they approached the Eastern and Southern Neighbourhoods as never before, and were aggravated by the emergence of new failed States around us. In view of this reality, we must first improve our internal coordination by States, intelligence, diplomacies or the European External Action Service. And second, strengthen cooperation with the outside world, gaining in resolute influence. To this end, we need to develop a new, more practical and ambitious neighbourhood policy, but recalling that the European Union has deliberately decided not to emphasize the use of force. We don't want to fight. We prefer to convince and cooperate. And that doesn't make us weaker. It makes us stronger. That is why, by the hand of Parliament, by Federica Mogherini, let us put our democratic legitimacy and our foreign policy instruments at the service of the conquest of reason.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the EU’s international environment is volatile, with dire security challenges that range from long—lasting conflicts to the steady rise of authoritarianism and extremism. The current developments are unprecedented in the period since the end of the Cold War, and the situation is all the more pressing in that most of them are occurring in our immediate neighbourhood, both in the south and in the east. We need to react to this demanding international situation. The EU needs to step up its international role and to speak with one voice. We need to be strategic, consistent, coherent and efficient. Strong EU action is the only way forward in tackling the myriad of threats on our doorstep. In our response to challenges we should not lose sight of our values, which are directly linked to democracy, respect for human rights, the rule of law and, ultimately, peace. My utmost appreciation to Elmar Brok for preparing a very good, objective report.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D).
text: Madam President! In the text we will adopt tomorrow, we mention Russia a whole 22 times. We mention their illegal annexation of Crimea, their aggressive actions, our sanctions and our energy dependence on them. I would also like to add and mention the provocation flights that Russian military aircraft are making up close to Danish and Swedish airspace, for example, and which also endanger civil aviation. When, in a year's time, we are again in this Chamber talking about the annual achievements of a common foreign service, then we should have a comprehensive Russia strategy. A strategy that also considers security, foreign, trade and energy policy. A strategy condemning the dangerous Russian provocation flights. A strategy that clearly defines roles and responsibilities between the EU, member states and NATO, for example, as the world's strongest military defence organisation. A strategy in which we coordinate with the other international partners in the UN, the OSCE, the Council of Europe and so on. In short, we must have a strategy in which we take joint action against Russia and ensure that we can be safe in Europe in the future too.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, tá máistreacht ar an ábhar seo léirithe arís ag an Uasal Brok sa tuarascáil seo agus dar ndóigh nuair a fhéachaimid ar an scéal tá béim i bhfad níos difriúla ar an tuarascáil seo ón Ardionadaí i mbliana ná mar a bhí le cúpla bliain anuas. Tuigimid go bhfuil cúrsaí cosanta agus slándála i bhfad níos tábhachtaí ná mar a cheapamar b’fhéidir agus ní gá dúinn ach féachaint ar cad a tharla i bPáras agus san oirthear – san Úcráin – chun é sin a thuiscint.  Agus nuair a théimid isteach i bParlaimint na hEorpa anois, ní póilíní i ngluaisteáin in aice leis an bParlaimint a fheicimid ach saighdiúirí le gunnaí taobh amuigh den Pharlaimint. B’fhéidir nach leor sin ach sin an saol agus caithfimid bheith ar an airdeall mar a dúirt a lán cainteoirí roimis sin agus cinnte b’fhéidir nach n-aontaíonn a lán daoine gur ghá arm Eorpach a bheith againn faoi láthair ach gan dabht ar bith caithfimid labhairt le haon ghuth. Caithfimid bheith aontaithe agus mar a dúirt an Coimisinéir Mogherini, caithfimid obair le chéile. Dúirt sí gurb é sin an eochair chun dul ar aghaidh agus an ceart aici sa mhéid sin. Rud amháin ba mhaith liom a rá freisin, tá dóchas againn tar éis na hóráide breá a thug an Rí Abdulladh II dúinn inné agus má bhíonn gach duine cosúil leis beidh an saol níos fearr.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D).
text: – Mrs Mogherini, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by welcoming the report and the rapporteur and my speech is only to stress the importance of the Mediterranean and Atlantic dimensions of the European Union. And on the Mediterranean issue, and in the context of neighbourhood policy, I would like to stress the crucial importance of the relationship with the countries on the southern shore of the Mediterranean, for reasons that have to do with migration, which has to do with energy and which has to do with the issue of security. Moreover, when these countries are undergoing a phase of great transformation and, in some cases, as is particularly the case in Tunisia, a very serious effort is being taken to consolidate a democratic solution. And in the Atlantic component, I welcome, as has already been said, all the effort that is being made to bring the United States closer together, but I would also like to draw particular attention to the importance of investing in a new and deeper relationship with the countries of Latin America. Latin America is going through a difficult phase, some countries are going through a troubled period but it is essential to strengthen the European presence of Latin America and I believe that this should also be a plan of the European Union.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE).
text: – I would of course like to welcome Mr Brok for the excellent report he has produced in this area of foreign policy, but I would like to stress two aspects here. The first is that I think we had to talk about a single neighborhood policy. We shouldn't be separating the eastern neighbourhood from the Mediterranean neighborhood. We should look at the idea of a global neighbourhood, not least because we have a charneira area that is both east and is simultaneously Mediterranean, and therefore in which these two components can blend in. So I think it was worth it to look at each state individually and at the neighborhood policy because these situations are different.  And then I would like to stress this which Mr Assis has just stressed, which is the idea that the partnership with the United States is as strategic for our foreign policy and for our security policy as is the neighbourhood policy and that it implies an enlargement to the South Atlantic and, in particular, to Brazil, which needs great attention at the moment , Venezuela and Argentina, which are at great risk.

name: Boris Zala (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Europe needs to start thinking of itself as a serious geopolitical and security actor. It must treat its common external action in strategic terms. Take frozen conflicts, from Transnistria and Nagorno-Karabakh to Cyprus. These are serious security challenges in our backyard, but the EU simply choses to neglect them, ostensibly because it was imprudent to meddle because each conflict has its own history and established resolution format which, by the way, has done nothing to resolve them. If the EU wants to be taken seriously as a security actor, it must assume a much more active role in conflict resolution, especially in Transnistria, Nagorno-Karabakh and potentially in Ukraine.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – The war has returned to the European continent with Putin's russian aggression against Ukraine, as Europe faces an arc of conflict to the east and south. Perhaps the danger resurrects the idea of the European army, very desirable in the eyes of a federalist like me, but far from being realised by the continued reluctance of the Member States to invest in the common foreign and security policy and the common security and defence policy, coordinating and combining civil and military resources and capabilities.  Our governments cannot continue to cheapple taxpayers' money and compromise the security of our societies in the face of cross-border threats, which no Member State can face alone, such as terrorism. As Mr Brok's report points out, it is now impossible to separate internal security from external security. Strategic and coordinated investment in the necessary capabilities is required. We have the instruments but we lack strategic guidance and ambition. Just look at almost Somalia on our doorstep in Libya, by omission of Europe after the fall of Gaddafi. If the Union wants to defend its citizens and their interests and assert itself as a global security provider, then it must tidy up the house and implement the foreign policy and the common security and defence policy, strategically linking the whole spectrum of internal and external policies.  It must immediately review the funding of external action, in particular military missions under the common security and defence policy. It must deal, before waving at the European army, to establish a permanent headquarters and to strengthen the industrial and technological defence base that it has been destroying with austerity policies. And it must trigger the reform of the UN Security Council, where the European Union must have a permanent seat and be able to restrict the crippling right of veto.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, our fellow Member Elmar Brok has done a thorough job of the annual report of European Representatives on Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to the European Parliament. I appreciate your work. It is correct to conclude that the security situation in the immediate vicinity of the European Union has become dramatically serious. As a result, swift and effective efforts are needed to protect European values and interests, restore and preserve peace and stability. This is particularly the case in the light of the Russian-Ukrainian conflict, which has been going on for more than a year, which is taking place in the neighbourhood of the European Union. In this context, it is important that EU sanctions adopted in response to Russian aggression against Ukraine are amending the implementation of both Minsk ceasefire agreements in the context of russia's international obligations, such as compliance with the truce, withdrawal of heavy weapons and soldiers, and the development of a unified EU position.

name: Silvia Costa (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, High Representative Mogherini, rapporteur, I believe that we have an important report today in which, I think, we must take greater account of the heartfelt appeal made to us yesterday here in this House by the King of Jordan, when he reminded us that Europe has a fundamental mission in the troubled mediterranean scenario: that of cultural cooperation and mediation, interreligious solidarity and dialogue. I believe that this is the premise of a foreign and security policy, because we know that we must win together – as the Hashemite monarch has asked us – together with the Arab peoples, not only fundamentalism, which threatens Muslims above all and pursue Christian communities, but also those fundamentalists who, even in Europe, do not respect meaning and interreligious dialogue. That is why I believe that, in Parliament too, as well as in foreign policy, I hope – and I know federica Mogherini's interest in cultural policy – that we must work harder for cultural diplomacy, for the coordination of these policies, also through the cultural institutes of the Member States in third countries and to reflect on the educational policies of migration policies.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, Skopje is stepping up its provocative stance against Greece. They are changing history, taking the name of Macedonia and taking a sweeping action to change the borders in the Balkans by claiming Greek territory. Unfortunately, despite your experience, you too fell victim to Skopje's propaganda and so a few days ago in Brussels, at a press conference, you called Skopje 'Macedonia', in violation of UN and European Union resolutions. You should therefore refer to Skopje as FYROM, as this name is recognised by the European Union.  Therefore, I would like to hear you give an explanation for this. I also call on you, here in the plenary of the European Parliament, to withdraw and make amends, because what you said in your interview has caused a huge wave of protest against you in Greece. So as "good accounts make good friends" I look forward to your answer to the question I raised to you.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I am very pleased that you have mentioned, dear High Commissioner, his Excellency's speech to King Abdulah II of Jordan here in Parliament. I am extremely pleased to have heard this from many of my colleagues because I want to point out that Europe needs such allies. Europe, with its policy of such an alliance of building bridges, can remain a leader in creating a democratic environment in our closest countries, it can help those closest countries, many of which are in great catastrophic states, and that is why I support the policies you lead because I am convinced that only such an open policy of building bridges, but also warning about the problems that exist in individual countries can be a successful policy. I believe that in this mandate you will do this and that you will not forget the Balkans, regardless of my dear friend from Greece, I believe that the Balkans do not need more unrest and I expect that you will support peace in this area as well.

name: Tatjana Ždanoka (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I think the report of Mr Brok advocates the policy giving the High Representative a negative role regarding the current conflicts in its neighbourhood. This role is to be urgently corrected, and if not, this collation of conflicts, global and multiregional as well, will take place. Which mistake needs to be corrected first? It is a myth that there is constant equality of geopolitical and national interests of the EU Member States and the United States. The unipolar world is over. Strategic partnership of the EU and Russia, especially with the participation of China, Brazil and India, is a nightmare for American policy. The EU position towards Russia, which makes us economically and politically weaker than before, has become a hostage of anti—Russian sentiments, not only of Neocon circles in the United States but also in the Baltic countries and Poland, and the debates in this Chamber clearly prove this. A united Europe should be autonomous in its decisions.

name: President. –
text: According to the rule established by my predecessor, there are no blue cards. I am sorry about this.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, you said that you would take one ‘catch—the—eye’ from each group and I do not think EFDD has had a ‘catch—the—eye’. I asked an hour and a half ago if I could be considered, and no one from our group has spoken in catch—the—eye.

name: President. –
text: You are right. Therefore you have one minute to speak.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, thank you for this very generous ruling. It is dangerous to play games of bluff when one does not have a card in one’s hand. One has to able to back up strong words with action, otherwise one looks foolish. The spirit of Margaret Thatcher was referred to earlier on today in the debate on foreign policy. Margaret Thatcher and Ronald Reagan came from a position of economic and military strength – they could back up their words. The EU and its foreign policy cannot back up its words. Margaret Thatcher is not replaced by David Cameron – he is no kind of replacement – and Mr Juncker is no Ronald Reagan. It needs to be pointed out, although I know you should understand this, that the EU is not a nation. You do not need to be doing these things. A foreign policy and – God forbid! – an EU army is folly of the highest order.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, honourable Members, I will take some of the points that were raised, starting with some difficulties in our common foreign and security policy, which some of you mentioned. First of all, as in the report, many of you came back on the issue of lack of coordination. On the European Union level and internal-external policies among different European Union institutions: some of you might remember that at the beginning of October I started my hearing in the Committee on Foreign Affairs by saying that I would be satisfied if at the end of my five years in office I could hear that services were working with me as the European Union, instead of as the Commission, the Council, the EAS and so on. I think that is still very much a challenge. I cannot pretend that I have changed that after four months in office. It will need much more time, much more effort, but I can tell you that, when it comes to a stronger coordination between the work we do in the Council, the work we do in the Commission, the work we do with the European Parliament, we are making very relevant steps. I would not call it a revolution but it is something that is close to it in cultural terms. Think of the work we have done on the internal—external coordination. I think that it will be the first time that foreign ministers are going to discuss migration – that will be on Monday – with Commissioner Avramopoulos. If you see the innovation that the report calls for – this Commissioners’ Group on External Action – you see the core group that was established as something already ambitious. It has five Commissioners as a starting point, but at the last meeting on 4 March (last week) and the previous one, and the previous previous one we had ten Commissioners around the table. This included vice-presidents: Vice—President Georgieva when we discussed the budget, on how we prioritise inside the Commission and the proposal on how we use the budget on Heading 4; and Vice-President Šefčovič when we discussed energy or climate. If I could list all the different elements we have started to work on together on the Commission side in these four months, which is not an enormous amount of time, I can mention climate, energy, research, economic cooperation and development, culture – that was mentioned by Silvia Costa – security and counter-terrorism – here again we have been putting together all the different aspects and the tools available – migration, trade, and obviously development, humanitarian aid and our enlargement policies. Obviously this is a start. Obviously we still have a lot of difficulties and obviously we will still be fighting against a lot of difficulties but I think if I see these first four months in the light of the next four and a half years I can say I am encouraged by the steps that we have been able to take. When it comes to another difficulty that some of you have mentioned – some people in this room have said that Member States do not and cannot share a common policy. Well, you will be surprised to see how much Member States are sharing when it comes to deciding together. I always give this example: take the doorstep statements that the ministers make when they go to the Foreign Affairs Council and you will see all shades of different positions but the important thing to me is that we go through a process, not only in the meetings themselves but actually an everyday process, so that when it comes to take decisions we are all united. All the 28. Obviously I know very well we still have a long way to go. In October, I said in front of the Foreign Affairs Committee that my challenge is to shape a common foreign and security policy, one that is felt to be owned by everyone in Europe, because I know we are not there yet. I know that very well. What I see is that crises around us, starting from the crisis in Ukraine, are telling us, are telling our Member States, are telling the governments, are telling the national parliaments, are telling your fellow parliamentarians in your respective Member States that, yes, we do have an added value when we manage to decide and to act together as Europeans. If we did not have a European common reaction on the Ukrainian crisis, think of that. Think of where we would be here today. Even the Member States that are traditionally, historically more reluctant to see the added value of the common foreign and security policy at European level, I think after this past year have realised very well that a European common foreign and security policy is an added value also for their own national interests. Obviously we have to make this emerge more and more. It is not only but it is also a matter of narrative and visibility, as someone has mentioned. It is a matter of making the common interest and the common added value emerge. This will take time. This will take respect and I am fully ready to go through this process, taking the time and taking the respect we will need to have everybody on board. Everybody! I would not exclude anyone from the exercise because I see in everyday work that there is a need for that and there is also the willingness for that. Then obviously we all have internal national debates, we all have internal national electoral constraints and I understand that sometimes this reflects also in the debates in this room, which is natural. The real substance of the process is that we know, all of us, that without common real foreign policy each of our Member States will not have the means to respond to the challenges we have in front of us. Many of you mentioned, and this comes up also when we talk about security and defence, a sentence that was used by President Juncker in an interview a couple of days ago, which is something I think he has said in front of this Parliament in July. I was still a minister at the time, but that was something that I think he has always said throughout his whole life. What I think – and what I have also discussed not only with him but with many others – is something that I know this Parliament shares: that finally we have to use the tools that we have when it comes to common defence policy. Use the treaties, use the articles of the treaties that we are currently not using because we still need to build the political will that will allow us to use our full potential. I think that here we have a space to develop and to use in the coming years. This will be difficult in some national endeavours for sure but, again, crises around us tell us very clearly that the provisions that are there in the Lisbon Treaty are not there by chance. They are there because we need to use them, in strong cooperation with NATO, and not only with NATO but with other international organisations, starting with the UN and regional organisations. Many of you mentioned a series of issues that it would probably be too long to go into but I will just underline a couple of them. Starting from the Balkans, I will take this opportunity to correct myself. I always refer to fYROM. It happens sometimes, especially when you deal 24/7 with crises and jetlag, that you make a mistake, and I apologise for that because I always stick to the formal, official recognised name and I discussed that with the Greek authorities as well. Starting from the Balkans, where we now tend not think of it as a foreign policy dimension because it is part of our family somehow, this is the success story we can tell. Exactly 20 years after Srebrenica, look how much the investment in peace and European integration and regional integration can bring in terms of good results to the region. I share the view that somebody expressed: we also need to be self-confident and highlight the positive results of our policies. I will underline Latin America. Some of you asked for a relaunch of relations. I am fully committed to that. I started working with CELAC in view of the first summit in June. I have been to the CELAC summit in January and I will be visiting Latin America again before June. This is an area where a little bit of our serious, committed cooperation can develop a huge potential for both. We have to do the same in Africa and in Asia. There is not a single place in the word where we can afford not to invest politically. We have the time, the energy and the resources to do so. Another two elements I would like to underline. Yes, on cyber security. Many of you mentioned the need to give more attention to cyber security in our strategies and in our work, something we are already doing, in cooperation with NATO as well, and on strategic communication. We had that discussion just before we took this issue onto the agenda on Russia. Working on strategic communication, not only on Russian but on Arabic, is key to our policy. This might sound a small element but to me it is a very important element as a sign of strategic thinking and acting, in view of the cultural outreach that we need so much and of which His Majesty the King of Jordan was reminding us yesterday. If we want to build partnerships and cooperation and tools of partnership and cooperation we have to start from this very natural basis, which is also the mutual cultural respect that is at the basis of a partnership among equals. (Applause)

name: Elmar Brok
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, High Representative, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work and for the work she has Thank you very much for your two statements. I believe that the further focus on strategic challenges, which Mr Millin Mon has raised, with the Americas, the intensification of China policy and a greater focus on India – which has so far failed – and the context of all policies, is also very important. As well as migration. We can no longer separate internal and external security. How a comprehensive approach can be taken, how these can be put together, is of great importance. We will not be able to allay our concerns about migration in our countries, with the serious consequences they have for political developments, as well as the false fears of it and concerns about internal security, if we do not succeed in tackling the causes. The people of Africa must have a chance for the future, civil wars must be prevented. If this is not resolved, we will not end the floods of refugees, we should see that. And this in a region of the world that is seen as a paradise of wealth. However, let me make one final point – and you have already pointed this out in your opening remarks – namely the definition of interests. What interests can be enforced by one of our nation states alone in the fight against terror and for peace, in terms of our peace-building role in the world and the question of our trade, as well as the consequences of migration and climate change? Many of our Member States are still pretending to be able to do so at home. They conduct a purely national discourse, and act in this way to the outside world, in their travel activities. If we do not understand that we need to develop common interests and realise that sometimes we have to give up a little bit of our nationals in order to reach common positions, we are no longer in a position to regain sovereignty for our peoples. Sovereignty exists only if you have the strength to stand up for it. Not a single European country has the real capacity to deal with such crises on its own. That is why, under the Treaty of Lisbon, the Member States are called upon to be loyal to the promotion of common external security. There is a contract article that indicates this. We should remember this, and we should sometimes remind the governments of the European Union, so that better representation of interests for our citizens can be exercised in this way.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 12 March 2015. (The sitting was suspended for five minutes)

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. The annual report of the European Union High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy in the European Parliament is proof that the Union's attempts at diplomatic policy are doomed to fail, as they are based on an idealistic attitude and compromised in submission to international organisations and foreign powers. The text before us is very clearly aimed at Russia, against which some want to develop a health cordon by forming backward partnerships with its neighbours. This vision is clearly subservient to NATO and the transatlantic alliance and runs counter to the interests of the nation-states of Europe. An equally worrying dimension for the independence of European nations is that of a stated desire to create a concretely indefinite but ideologically marked world order. The means to achieve this fatal stage for peoples and their freedoms are partly described through the dream of a single market for cybersecurity products. Finally, the desire to aggregate more and more States around a supranational structure reveals that the Union has not found the power tools it claimed to possess and that only economic integration would enable these goals to be pursued.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – In the context of the report on foreign affairs and security policy, I fully agree with the rapporteur's view that we need a new European security strategy. This strategy must be based on the protection of human rights, fundamental values and include an educational aspect in the context of contemporary threats. Similarly, European external action must be implemented according to a comprehensive strategy, the main pillars of which, in addition to the protection of human rights, should be investment in education, which is part of the EU's humanitarian policy. In the context of future foreign policy challenges, there is also a reform of migration policy in order to prevent as far as possible the tragedies of illegal immigrants trying to enter the Union and to strengthen integration policies. In urgent human rights resolutions, we have also repeatedly called for humanitarian support for refugees and their host countries. I consider this aspect to be crucial in terms of protecting civilians and ensuring security and peace. I support the strengthening of regional protection programmes in cooperation with the UNHCR.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. – Following the inflaming of the conflict in Ukraine, the Security Environment of the European Union has deteriorated significantly, while relations between Brussels and Moscow are at their lowest level since the end of the Cold War. Following the terrorist attacks in Paris on the editorial board of the satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo, the security issue is high on the EU agenda, as we are obliged to ensure a high level of security within the space of freedom, security and justice for citizens to achieve this, appropriate reforms are needed. I think it is high time for Europe to be reunited, but this time on the basis of better cooperation between national authorities, intelligence services, here I mean the Air Passenger Data Sharing Directive, which will allow for the smooth exchange of private data on passengers on planes landing or taking off anywhere in the EU. The Union's foreign and security policy should be primarily in the function of preserving fundamental European values and interests with a view to strengthening the political and legal order, which will contribute to the preservation of peace and stability and the security of citizens. At all times, the Union must be ready to respond effectively to threats such as terrorism and arms, drugs and human trafficking, and this requires improving certain internal structures, but also creating partnerships with so-called third countries.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by Pier Antonio Panzeri, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World 2013 and the European’s Union’s policy on the matter (2014/2216(INI)) (A8-0023/2015).

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Parliament's report on human rights is an important tool for assessing the policies implemented by the European Union. I would like to highlight the important work done by the Special Representative right away. With this report we have chosen a thematic approach instead of a geographical one and we think it is very useful, because it identifies some guidelines on which to engage the European Parliament, the European Commission itself and individual Commissioners in their policies.  Ladies and gentlemen, in 1872 a small classic of legal liberalism appeared in Vienna, The Struggle for Law, by Rudolf von Jhering, which was republished as an antibody in the years of fascism in my country by Benedetto Croce. Today it is certainly fairer to talk about the fight for rights, which ranges from the defence of social and civil rights, to the protests of young people in Hong Kong and which can be summed up in the words of Hannah Arendt, the 'right to have rights'. But to prevent all this from being just a slogan, we must remember that phrase in its entirety: "The right to have rights, or the right of every individual to belong to humanity, should be guaranteed by humanity itself". It is quite clear that in this way the construction of rights becomes demanding and requires a policy of humanity, the opposite of the policy of disgust that some people have spoken about with regard to discrimination against homosexuals, but which we find in too many cases of rejection of the other. In the time we are living, rights are described as a luxury incompatible with the economic crisis, with the reduction in financial resources and also with the need for internal stability in some countries – I am thinking of the countries in our neighbourhood. But I ask myself: at a time when the promise of rights is not being fulfilled or removed, what are we taking leave of absence from? When you restrict rights to work, health, education and civil rights, you have an impact on the premises of a democracy. It is therefore not rights that are insatiable: so is the economy's claim to determine which rights are compatible with it. So reflection on rights brings us to the heart of a cultural debate that goes beyond contingency and reveals how references to the economic crisis and the new geopolitics have only made a much deeper transformation and conflict more evident, which concern the very way in which we must look at the evolution of our societies. , of the same global society.  With this report we want to send out a simple message that rights do not invade democracy but require us to reflect on how political discretion should be exercised. , from poverty, discrimination and violence against women, which erase the very dignity of the person. So there is a lot to be done and, ultimately, I think that Europe's task is to keep up the challenge, showing the coherence needed to really overcome this challenge on human rights everywhere.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: VPC/HR. – Signor Presidente, onorevoli parlamentari, vorrei iniziare ringraziando il relatore e tutti quelli che hanno lavorato con lui per la relazione eccellente ed estremamente utile per accompagnare l'inizio del mio lavoro sul campo dei diritti umani e affermando che condivido non solo l'analisi ma anche l'invito. Il nostro compito, quello dell'Unione europea, è quello di tenere alta la sfida e al tempo stesso trovare i modi concreti per fare dei piccoli grandi passi avanti in ognuna delle situazioni in cui i diritti umani sono o violati o messi in discussione. Mr President, I will continue in English to say that it is a great honour for me to participate in the discussion on the Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy. As your report rightly recalls, the Charter of Fundamental Rights affirms that we must place the individual and human dignity at the centre of EU activities.  Protection of human rights is, and will remain, the over-arching priority of our external action. It is not just one of the priorities, but the over-arching priority, and must remain the solid foundation underpinning all our relations with third countries. This House embodies this commitment. Parliament has constantly promoted human rights in its everyday political work with very concrete actions. It has visited countries in which these rights are threatened. Your urgency debates and the highly symbolic value of the Sakharov prize, these actions are key components of parliamentary diplomacy and are needed as a fundamental element of our overall European policy on democracy and human rights. Human rights in the world remain a challenge, but I share the view that we have moved forward on a number of important areas; in particular since the adoption of the 2012 human rights package and through our first EU action plan on human rights for the phase 2012-2015. The plan has allowed the European Union to fulfil a number of important objectives. All European actors have been engaged and committed to working on human rights and it has become a fully-owned process. We have given ourselves the tools to start applying and mainstreaming human rights into our external policies. We have announced our visibility and accountability in this area, thanks to the human rights dialogues that we have engaged in with our strategic partners in the course of these past years.  Your support in implementing this action plan has been crucial. Now I believe it is time to move forward and in particular to structure our common work based on a well-defined set of priorities. Since I have assumed my duties, I have engaged in moving the human rights agenda forward, starting with the definition of a new action plan and I want this action plan to be based, not just on a list of actions, but on political priorities. In this framework, I think one of our priorities should be to support democratic transitions around us. Our diplomatic efforts and your parliamentary work should go hand in hand in a mutually supportive way. In this respect, I am pleased to see in your report that you appreciate our efforts to report regularly to this House, in the many formats that we have agreed. We are also engaging more in reaching out to civil society organisations as key partners in order to consult on key EU human rights and policy developments. Holding consultations with civil society before and after human rights dialogues, on all important policy developments and after the meetings of the Council working party on human rights, has become systematic practice. Our annual NGO human rights forum in December last year, attended by more than 200 civil society participants from around the world, has been a key opportunity to discuss and review European policies in the area of freedom of expression. I am delighted to see that you share the deep appreciation I have for the action of the EU Special Representative for Human Rights, and a former colleague of yours, Stavros Lambrinidis. Stavros – I am not saying this as he is sitting next to me – is invaluable in helping us to promote our human rights priorities across the world, engaging with key partners, enhancing cooperation with regional mechanisms, and advancing the universality of human rights. It is with great pleasure that I can officially announce here to you today that I decided to extend his mandate and that the Council endorsed this decision. (Applause) Coming back to our joint work of setting priorities for our human rights action, allow me some substantial remarks. On a general point, let me say I fully share your approach. It is high time we put all our efforts into improving EU internal and external coherence. If we want to strengthen the credibility of the Union as a global actor we all need to seriously consider the human rights impacts that our policy has outside our borders, as well as our efforts in the external domain, which must be complementary to the work that Vice—President Timmermans is doing to ensure compliance of EU policies with the Charter of Fundamental Rights. We need to be consistent on human rights outside and inside our borders – I would say inside our borders first of all to have real credibility when we act outside. I would now like to focus on our priorities: when reading Parliament’s report I recognise many issues which I also would like to prioritise in the new Action Plan. Let me give you a few examples. Besides addressing the need to increase the internal-external coherence of our policies, I would first like to announce our support to civil society – political, technical and financial support as well as redoubling our efforts to fight its ever shrinking space in so many countries.  Secondly, I think that we need to address the massive human rights violations and abuses that take place in conflicts and crisis around us. We must improve our capacity to prevent these violations and increase the effectiveness of the international mechanism to tackle impunity.  Thirdly, promoting human rights is not an abstract exercise. We have concrete tools we can use at European Union level, but we must improve their effectiveness. Let me say a few words on this. It is my intention that our dialogues on human rights not remain an isolated opportunity for the discussion of human rights issues. In my view they should rather feed into all bilateral contacts with partner countries, and that is also how the work that Stavros is doing coordinates very much with the level of commitment I have with all our partners and interlocutors in the world.  Fourthly, I want to step up our promotion of the rights of children, LGBTI and women, as well as the freedom of expression, freedom of religion and belief, which would include guidelines increasing awareness of our human rights which would be directed, above all, at EU staff and also at Member States’ diplomats. I appreciate in this context the efforts you want to make to ensure that your delegations, which have very close contacts with so many countries around the world, also focus more on promoting these values. I think that in this respect we can coordinate our efforts along similar lines. Fifthly, in the context of promoting the indivisibility and universality of human rights we will continue promoting and defending economic, social, cultural rights not least through our unequalled—in—scope development aid. In this context, too, I believe that the European Union can become a leader in implementing the UN guiding principles on business and human rights as recommended by Mr Howitt in his parliamentary report on corporate, social responsibility.  With regard to religious minorities – a major concern for all of us – I have already started to engage together with our partners to fight against violence committed in the name of religion and take action to address the root causes, – be they social, economic but also political – of radicalisation in our societies and in the Middle East but also in other places of the world, like Pakistan and Afghanistan. But, let me stress also, in our societies and here, again, we have to work more on the internal-external dimension of our policies. I am convinced that promoting freedom of religion, freedom of expression must be a key component of the fight against terrorism and a visible part of it. There can be no security, no stability without human rights and I think we have to remind not only ourselves but also our partners every single day. Over the last few months we have condemned in the strongest possible terms the massive abuses of human rights perpetrated by Daesh and sow alliances to counter these terrorists.  Furthermore, the European Union and its Member States are spearheading the international response to the humanitarian crisis in Syria and we are strongly engaged in Iraq. The EU humanitarian policy in this year will focus aid on hard-to-reach areas where there are unmet needs and particularly vulnerable groups. In Syria, in areas of reduced violence, we are exploring targeted programmes for minorities in order to ensure the safety of all ethnic and religious communities; facilitate an inclusive transition, meet special needs and support the reintegration of vulnerable groups in society. We also support efforts by actors working on the ground to ensure that human rights abuses and violations are being documented for future accountability.  I am very grateful for the many and valuable suggestions and recommendations that I found in your report and I count on your support in finding ways of implementing them together. I look forward to our debate for even more suggestions and ideas in this respect.

name: Heidi Hautala
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Development. – Mr President, it is always an important day when we discuss the annual human rights report in this House, and it is my pleasure, on behalf of the Committee on Development, to say that Mr Panzeri has fully incorporated development policy and development cooperation into our response to the annual report. I have full faith that the High Representative also sees the development policy as an integral part of our external relations. I am also very proud of the nomination of the Special Representative – Mr Stavros Lambrinidis. I think it was a fortunate decision that was taken by your predecessor, and we see now the result. Congratulations for the work you are doing. I believe that Mr Panzeri has produced a report which shows that, indeed, there are many important human rights issues related to development cooperation and development policy. I am also confident, Madam High Representative, that as a Vice—President of the European Commission, you have a good level of cooperation with DG DEVCO, the Directorate-General for Development. A human rights—based approach to development seems to be so natural to us already that it is not even mentioned in the report, but I trust that the work will be taken on. The priorities that you have just listed correspond very well also to what Parliament and the Committee on Development have perceived, including corporate accountability.

name: Jana Žitňanská
text: Rapporteur for opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality – When you ask the citizens of a European Union country which problems they consider to be most urgent in terms of the status of women, 59% of them name violence against women. As the author of the opinion on the report currently under consideration for the Committee on Women's Rights, let me therefore draw your attention to what I consider to be the most important on the subject of violence. I consider it most important that states work to build an atmosphere of trust, so that when a woman is a victim of violence, she encounters reluctance, underinteering and unprofessionality after surviving trauma. So that no one would even think to start talking to the victim that nothing actually happened. Member States must take careful care to train health professionals, police officers, prosecutors and judges so that they can help victims of violence quickly and professionally. Another, even more challenging task for all of us is to change the mindset of the younger generation in particular. However, no legislative text alone will ensure this change, it is mainly up to us. Many of us are from a country where bruises and slaps are still taboo and perceived as something normal. Please continue to make an intensive effort to give the victims courage and stand firmly behind them.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating the author of the report, Colleague Panzeri. We are at the end of several months of reflection, of negotiations between Parliament's political groups, and I would like to say that, in my view, I am pleased to see that the text we are going to vote on tomorrow rightly reflects the concern that the PPE Group has towards the protection and promotion of human rights and democracy. I insist on this double component: it is also about human rights, and about democracy. There are two different things, but for us they are linked and from here I think we should also start putting this report in context. I believe that Mr Panzeri's report, in the form we have come to, underlines very well the Union's attitude towards human rights and towards democracy. I think we need to be proud of the way we see democracy and human rights, respectively. I say this even after the stormy debate that we had earlier when, unfortunately, one of our colleagues said here in plenary that, from the point of view of democracy, Russia would be better than the Union. I think the report shows very well why a country like Russia is no better than the Union in terms of democracy and, obviously, in terms of human rights. I mean, if the Union promotes human rights and democracy outside its exterior, it must obviously respect these rights within, but this report does not concern the human rights situation within the Union and within the Member States. I say this because I have had various discussions with colleagues in the LIBE Committee who, as a matter of fact, have said that this issue is being dealt with in that committee. The European Union should not suggest to the Member States what decisions to take, for example, on the legalisation of abortions or same-sex marriage. We believe in the principle of subsidiarity, we believe that these issues are everyone's conscience, and I want to thank Mr Panzeri for the openness he has shown in the management of these issues.

name: Elena Valenciano
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, we are discussing an excellent report this afternoon. In my view, this is a report worked rigorously, objectively and in great depth. But unfortunately, there is not so much good news in the field of human rights. Some monsters that we thought we had defeated forever are being reborn: bigotry, bigotry, racism. And human rights are in danger. It's not a phrase. It's a finding. And so this House this afternoon must affirm without nuance its commitment to human rights and to the rule of law, to its defence, and to the primacy of the values of democracy and dignity for all human beings in the world. The fight against terrorism and the economic crisis are helping human rights to reced in some parts of the world. And we have to commit ourselves, therefore, to the rule of law to defend everyone, beyond our priority, which is undoubtedly the safety of all. Commitment of this House and coherence of the European Union. We cannot, as in some cases, condemn with one hand and sign agreements with the other. We cannot continue to maintain the double side — which we sometimes maintain — in terms of the defence of human rights. And to teach lessons to the rest of the world, we have to set an example first. Example. And that is why the chapter on business, business and human rights seems to me to be a fundamental chapter and a fundamental task that we have to carry out: the defence of human rights. And that our European companies in third countries care about this respect for human rights. It is the European Union's responsibility as a power of powers. Why not become the human power that so many people expect, beyond our borders? And leave me a minute to congratulate Mr Lambrinidis on the excellent work he does and for the renewal of his mandate.

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, this report has become a bulky piece of work, which describes a lot of developments. Congratulations to the rapporteur. Some developments are positive. The EU has more and more tools to implement human rights policies. But sometimes the political will still has to be linked to that toolbox. In some regions, such as South America, we are seeing progress. In other regions, the human rights situation is deteriorating. Russia, already discussed at length today, is unfortunately one of those regions. The country has become a strategic challenge.  In this context, I would like to take a look at the reference in the resolution to the worrying situation in Crimea. The Tatars are a small but proud people. Part of their past is shrouded in mist. The other part is a story of deportations and discrimination. Crimea is their homeland. Relations between the Crimean Tatars and ethnic Russians were always peaceful. But unfortunately, that tolerance is gone. International organisations confirm that Crimean Tatars and Ukrainians are systematically discriminated against. Basic civil rights, such as health care and a job, are denied to them if they stick to their Ukrainian passport. The UN Special Human Rights Envoy is no longer allowed to enter Crimea. The world is watching the demise of a people, although we all believe that minorities worldwide should be protected. The resolution rightly condemns the persecutions of religious minorities in the Middle East. But let us not forget Crimea, a year after the annexation!

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to congratulate Mr Panzeri on this report which is an example of an inclusive report. It has managed not only to incorporate civil society organizations, but also to include many concerns that belong to all of us. They have managed to include, in my view, a particularly remarkable consideration of impunity, international criminal justice, respect for freedom of expression, the rights of women, children, LGBTI... but I also wanted to highlight one thing, and in this I have to thank Mr Au-trevi-ius, who cannot be here today: this is the reference to what is our responsibility for the protection of human rights defenders. They come to Parliament, tell us, enlighten us, and then return to their respective places and see that they are in danger because they have exposed themselves. Let me focus and highlight one of the 215 sections, I think, which are in this great report: the one that has to do with access to safe water and sanitation as the essential human right recognized by the United Nations since 2010. It's something we accept but don't comply with. It seems a lie, but we are not talking about the fact that there are 15% of the world's population who do not have access to a toilet; we are talking about 1 billion people who are exposed to open defecation. There is a child who dies every two and a half minutes from diarrhea that is perfectly preventable. There's no shortage of resources. He's unwilling. We can prevent cholera, typhus, hepatitis, polio, worms... Outdoor defecation contributes to decreased physical and cognitive development, and in addition to threatening people's health and development contributes to sexual violence.  Today I humbly want to break the silence and support the campaign of Jan Eliasson, who also support the United Nations, to end open defecation in 2025. It's a human right and we have to support it.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, as every year, we are looking at this report on human rights and democracy around the world. Our rapporteur, Mr Panzeri, has chosen to make a thematic report which avoids the catalogue side and a lot of 'double standards'. I thank him for that.  This report contains some positive points, but the European Union is not free from reproaches in this regard and is increasingly ill-placed to give lessons. Economic and social rights and corporate social responsibility are largely important. But why not support an international, legally binding mechanism to end the impunity of multinationals, which has been postponed to the UN because of the vote of the Member States? Why not denounce the disastrous effect of structural adjustment plans on rights, particularly economic and social rights? How do we understand the "democracy" and "human rights" clauses when we advocate, without nuance, cooperation with third countries, especially on migration, and we encourage, in particular, the Khartoum process with the dictators of the Horn of Africa? Finally, as you know, Mr Panzeri, I have a problem with the annex on human rights defenders. It is necessarily restrictive and therefore endangers all those who are not appointed to it. That is why the GUE/NGL group will abstain from this report.

name: Barbara Lochbihler
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, High Representative Mrs Mogherini, Special Representative for Human Rights Lambrinidis, I would like to thank the Commissioner for Human Rights. This report is a good, comprehensive presentation of the EU's many human rights fields of action and makes a wealth of suggestions for improvement. However, the report also shows in which areas much more effort needs to be made. In conversations with diplomats, with colleagues from other parliaments, we regularly hear the admiration shown in our conditions under the rule of law and human rights guarantees. In the meantime, however, we are also regularly critical of the contradictions of the EU's human rights policy, for example a failed European policy of foreclosure with thousands of refugees a year who are themselves denied life-saving. It is shameful that we have still not found a viable solution here to build legal routes to Europe and that there are no binding commitments from the Member States to take in refugees. In the area of economics and human rights, this report also shows suggestions for improvement. Unfortunately, however, it has not been possible to establish a majority in favour of introducing a regular human rights impact assessment for forthcoming trade and investment agreements. Similarly, the EU should consider what it can do when human rights violations occur in the implementation of EU policies, and what possibility there is for those affected to then turn to the EU institutions. This is a task that we should face up to.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too welcome mr Panzeri's report and the work done by Mr Panzeri, a difficult and voluminous report, a very long report, which deals with a number of very distinct issues. I welcomed the thematic approach to the catalogue of countries which gave rise to further endless discussions and political positions. Surely it is true, as someone observes, something more could have been done: but the starting point is quite good in my opinion.  It is to be welcomed that, at a time when the European Union's external action is increasingly making respect for human rights in the third countries where it operates, we are trying to create a firm point about respect for these rights. It would be desirable for this to be done with really binding clauses and with really effective control instruments, because often and willingly our resolutions do not follow effective action and effective respect for what we say here.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Mr President, this report throws a spotlight on an array of fundamental rights abuses: violence against women and girls; female genital mutilation; violations of the freedoms of speech, press association and religion. Sometimes, however, we think of these abuses as being somewhat foreign or distant. In Northern Ireland on 26th and 27th of this month, the publicly—funded Equality Commission will bring a legal case against Ashers, a Christian—owned family bakery business, for refusing to bake a cake inscribed with a political message supporting same—sex marriage. Such an action, such a challenge to the right to exercise faith is deeply regrettable and a violation of Article 9 of the European Convention on Human Rights.  The challenge therefore for legislators is to find, as Lady Hale, Deputy President of the British Supreme Court, has described it, a reasonable accommodation for those who hold strong religious beliefs. We need freedom of conscience and religion, and I am glad that you have referred to it, High Representative. I urge Members of the European Parliament to join with me in saying so.

name: Andrzej Grzyb (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by A report on human rights in individual years is a very difficult task to formulate in such a way that everyone is happy with it. I would like to thank the author for the effort he has put into preparing this report. 2013 is primarily the beginning of difficult changes in Ukraine, it is the beginning of Euromaidan, it is the first casualties, 2013 is also a significant change after the beginning of the Arab Spring, but also the beginning of dramatic changes in the Middle East, which also cause huge casualties, because this is the beginning of the functioning of the Islamic State, the Islamist militias, which also mark their route of activity with crimes. Murdered Alawici near Salam, attack on the historic Christian city of Malula in Syria, ransacked, burned churches, forced conversions and many other situations.  I would also like to point out the deteriorating situation of Christians in this context on a global scale, but also in other religions. The Middle East, North Korea, many regions, including Africa, are places where, according to estimates, around 100 million Christians are persecuted every year and around 170 000 die every year. The High Representative also spoke about this.  I would also like to point out that the report is shocked at the events that are taking place in the area of human rights violations in the Central African Republic, Mali, Libya, Sudan or Nigeria. And, of course, it is important to emphasise what is positive. 2013 is the start of the European Endowment for Democracy, or the next Sakharov Prize, which shows the important role of human rights.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Panzeri has presented a very ambitious report. It focuses on the content of human rights and, by means of this procedure, avoids the risk of a mere series of cases, which must always remain incomplete and is therefore vulnerable from the outset. With the increasingly important instrument of urgent questions, Parliament has a good opportunity to react quickly and precisely to change. I therefore warmly welcome the report's recommendation to set up a parliamentary working group to systematically deal with the most accurate overview of detained and persecuted human rights defenders. This also helps to minimise the risk of double standards in our human rights policy. It is contrary to the principles of European foreign policy to base our sense of human rights violations on the basis of political expedientity. There are no good and bad human rights cases, no important and unimportant human rights cases. Human rights are a category sui generis. It is an investment in our future. Only a world in which the rule of law, individual freedom and democracy prevail is a safe world. Such a policy must not be super-teacher-like, it must strike the right balance between quiet diplomacy and public criticism. The institution of the EU Special Representative, which is being filled by Stavros Lambrinidis, is such a step in the right direction and it deserves to be further developed.

name: Bas Belder (ECR).
text: Mr President, the Panzeri report very clearly mentions the worldwide persecution of Christians, in accordance with the facts and therefore quite rightly so. This brings me to the question to the Council and the Commission and the High Representative about the opportunity of appointing an EU Special Envoy for Religious Freedom. I look forward to your response. It is already a discussion held by some Member States, as you know In paragraph 132, the report also deals with the EU guidelines for the protection of religious and religious freedom of 24 June 2013. We are now two years on. Council and Commission, I am very interested in the practical implementation of these guidelines. Mr Demesmaeker has already spoken about the political will: is there?
