Evaluation on your part towards Parliament is highly desirable. Will you come with me? That is my question and if so, what time frame can we expect?  Because I'm really looking forward to that.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the respect for human rights is supposed to be a precondition for our relations with countries with which we have contractual relations.  What should the consequences be for those countries which have violated international law and human rights, and which occupy foreign territories? A couple of days ago, the Israeli Prime Minister arrogantly let us know that he does not support the two-state solution. We know what it means. The Minister for Foreign Affairs of Armenia which occupies Nagorno Karabakh stated yesterday in an interview in my country that Armenia’s main strategic partner in economy and in defence is Russia, and he said that a Russian military base in Gyumri represents the warranty for its country’s security. The government of Morocco, also our partner, will soon organise a high-ranking international conference in Dakhla, in the occupied territory of Western Sahara, where Morocco is violating the basic rights of the Saharawi population. Madam Mogherini, are we going to change our policy with regard to these countries?

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, it is true that in the last decade, the position of women in society has experienced a fantastic improvement. Nevertheless, social, political, cultural and economic inequalities between men and women subsist, even within the countries of the EU and between them. I allow myself now to quote some lines written by John Stuart Mill 146 years ago. In his most expressive The Subjection of Women he says: ‘The … benefit to be expected from giving to women the free use of their faculties, by leaving them the free choice of their employments, and opening to them the same field of occupation and the same prizes and encouragements as to other human beings, would be that of doubling the mass of mental faculties available for the higher service of humanity’. One hundred and forty-six years ago; it has still to be done.

name: James Carver (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, in Munich the European Patent Office (EPO), under its current President, Benoît Battistelli, is disciplining SUEPO staff trade union officials for having the temerity to organise industrial action over breaches in human rights. Sick employees have been dismissed on purported trumped—up charges and there are accusations of discrimination against disabled people being refused employment. The Dutch Court of Appeal ruled that EPO had a case to answer over breaches of the human rights of staff, but EPO cited immunity and the Dutch Government intervened to prevent enforcement of the judgment. What is truly shocking is that not only does EPO appear immune to both the ECHR and the Commission, but also to this House, which is handing it judicial authority over patents within the EU under the single European patent.  How can we demand global respect for human rights when we allow such blatant breaches within an organisation shortly to exercise judicial functions on behalf of the EU?

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Panzeri report is a demonstration that the categorical imperative of human rights has become the foreign policy of the European Union.  Our nations have been asked to abandon their diplomacy, which is described as national selfishness. They were asked to abandon the pursuit of their specific interests in favour of nothing but the promotion of an ideology. The European Union is not aiming for power on the international stage. It does not aspire to become a strong pole in a multipolar world. It has only one ambition: to give the whole world moral lessons, to export its culture of death everywhere with the promotion of abortion, with the weakening of the natural framework of civilizations based on the natural family.  The spread of LGBT poison is the central objective of the Panzeri report. And for the poison instilled by the extreme left to be digested by the EPP group, it is diluted in the general denunciation of attacks on human rights, which targets, as a priority, the geopolitical opponents of the United States, namely Russia and China. The sincere defenders of human rights who are on the side of life will not be fooled. They will vote against the Panzeri report.

name: László Tőkés (PPE).
text: – Mr President, in 2012 the Council adopted the EU strategic framework on human rights and democracy to strengthen our engagement with third countries. The EU now has a Special Representative for Human Rights to enhance the effectiveness of our work. One can say that we now have better tools to jointly defend human rights in the world, yet we still struggle to speak out for the defence of human rights because we are divided and we compromise our values. It is shameful for such an important report to be inappropriately and selfishly used by some in this House to stress internal divisions in issues that remain strictly under national competency. This is wrong, and it diminishes our credibility. I oppose all efforts that stop us from genuinely addressing the ongoing human rights violations, including the persecution of Christians, torture, violence against children and women, the situation on migrants and refugees, people with disabilities and others.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D).
text: – Mr President, it is a matter of order, because the interpretation may not be correct, but the Member who intervened before the previous Member referred to gay, lesbian and bisexual people as poison. I believe that this statement should be withdrawn, unless the interpretation has made a mistake. You can't talk about gay people as poison to this society. This House cannot consent to it.

name: Preşedinte. –
text: It's still a slightly disguised blue card, but we're getting over it.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D).
text: – Mr President, as Parliament’s long—standing rapporteur on corporate responsibility, I want to use my speaking time to focus on the aspects of the report that call on the High Representative to make implementation of the UN guiding principles on business and human rights a key priority in the renewed action plan on human rights, and I would also like to thank Mr Lambrinides for his personal support in this policy area. It was Europe which created the idea of governmental national action plans on the guiding principles, now adopted by President Obama, but I hope Ms Mogherini will assist all of our own Member States now to complete theirs. I hope she will initiate a process of peer review by Member States around their plans, and will herself undertake an overall review as Parliament has asked. Following on from the current French proposal, I ask her to consider European requirements or recommendations on how businesses can demonstrate due diligence on human rights in their global supply chains. As I am proud to have championed the Directive on corporate non—financial reporting now agreed, with its specific reporting obligation on human rights, I ask the High Representative to both support implementation of this framework, but also to champion the new sustainable development goal that Ban Ki-moon is supporting to ensure that that is a global, not just a European requirement. I hope that as Vice—President she will work with DG Justice and its Commissioner to ensure better access to justice for victims of corporate human rights abuse worldwide. This is a rich agenda, and many in business now accept their own responsibility to respect human rights; it is our duty to help them to do it.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by This report, which is intended to speak of respect for human rights, itself contains wordings that undermine human rights. For example, in paragraph 165, we have an attack on the will of entire societies, expressed by Slovaks and Croats in a referendum in favour of defending the natural system of the family. Moreover, ladies and gentlemen, this point is attacked by the fact that such a referendum has taken place at all. If we attack today that entire nations have spoken out in a referendum in defence of the rights and natural shape of the family, how much more at risk are individual people being attacked for the same thing. In the name of the so-called fight against homophobia.  At this point, I have a duty to recall one thing – what my motherland said when the Sejm of the Republic of Poland made it clear in its resolution of 23 June 2006 – that, e.g. the Judeo-Christian moral heritage of Europe, 'cannot endorse the introduction into European Union documents of the term 'homophobia'.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as rapporteur for the report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union, I welcome Mr Panzeri's report. The institutional context in which we find ourselves today seems to be particularly favourable and sensitive to fundamental rights, not only because of the specific mandate received from the First Vice-President of the Commission and his role as guarantor of the Charter of Fundamental Rights. I would like to take up what Mr Mogherini said and take this opportunity to reiterate the european Union's due and just attention to the protection of human rights in the world, which must be reflected in positive actions to safeguard the results achieved and to persevere in the pursuit of the objectives of guaranteeing fundamental rights within the Union as well. That is why I personally will be proposing the development of an internal strategy of fundamental rights, which is nevertheless consistent with the strategic framework on human rights and democracy in the field of external relations. In particular, I believe that we must overcome the Copenhagen dilemma by scrupulously monitoring respect for fundamental rights and the rule of law not only before accession to the European Union but also with regard to the Member States that are now members.

name: Udo Voigt (NI).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the There is much talk of the central position of human rights in EU foreign policy. However, it is not just about third countries, we should also look at where human rights are violated in EU countries. I am thinking of Poland and Romania. Couldn't we know that Americans were torturing, tormenting people there? Do we know more about it? Are there other countries where such a thing takes place? How can it be that, sixty years after the conclusion of the State Treaty, people in Austria still face prison sentences of up to 15 years for their opinion? How can it be that 13 000 investigations take place every year in Germany for reasons of opinion, and that more than 1 000 people are in prison for this reason, especially Horst Mahler, who, at the age of 78, is serving 12 and a half years there and is about to be transferred to psychiatry? How can it be that seven Members of Parliament have been detained in Greece for 18 months without being charged?

name: Kinga Gál (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I welcome the fact that children's rights, including the fight against child hunger and malnutrition, have been given particular attention in the annual report. I think it is equally important that, on my proposal, a separate chapter deals with the rights of traditional national minorities, and it has been recognised that their specific situation requires a specific solution in order to have genuinely equal opportunities. Yet I would now like to talk about the most serious human rights situation: Christians in the Middle East, including women and children, who are tortured, murdered and enslaved for their faith. These are the most heinous human rights violations, crimes against humanity, which cannot be justified by anything, contradict the teachings of all religions, and are incompatible with the most fundamental values of human civilization. The martyrs of the 21st century are these Christian victims from the Middle East. We cannot stand by and watch this, which is why I call on the High Representative for Foreign Affairs to use all available means to counter these inhumane crimes and to find allies to do so.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D).
text: – Mr President, on this occasion I congratulate Mr Panzeri on the content of his report, on the balanced and professional way in which he approached the issue. In the context of celebrating International Women's Day, I would like to refer in my intervention to violence against women through the practice of selective abortion and forced child labour, these shameful practices are some of the major human rights violations at present. According to the report published by the French Institute for Demographic Studies, selective abortion for female fetuses is rapidly spreading and affecting countries in the Western Balkans and Central Asia, where the birth imbalance between the number of girls and boys is very high. It is therefore essential to include in the European Union guidelines on violence against women and girls the issue of gender-based selective abortion by creating indicators and methods of collecting data on this phenomenon and including it in the plan for the development and implementation of country strategies on human rights. With regard to the eradication of forced labour among children, I welcome the progress made and stress that it is our role, as Members of the European Parliament, to continue to promote an environment at Union level conducive to the prevention and elimination of this practice.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Mr. President, I support this report in the majority, but as an MP from Croatia I feel obliged to react to point 165 of the report in which the rapporteur regrets the outcome of the Croatian referendum on the definition of marriage from December 2013. I believe that there is no reason to regret, because the constitutional definition of marriage in Croatia has in no way harmed the rights of the LGBT community. Indeed. It served as a catalyst for the adoption of a life partnership law for people of the same sex in July 2014 that placed the same-sex community within the law as besee for a society that cares for all its members.  The desire of the vast majority of Croatian citizens to keep marriage a union between one woman and one man is not an expression of homophobia or discrimination as point 165 of the report imputes. This is a call for the protection of traditional values that have kept our society homogeneous despite the frequent historical adversity that has affected Croatia.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, yesterday we were put to a vote on the report by Mr Tarabella, a Belgian socialist whom our UMP colleague, Mrs Le Grip, thought it appropriate to congratulate on behalf of the EPP Group. Tomorrow is the report of another socialist, Mr Panzeri, that his alleged opponents of the EPP group will probably vote as one man.  For my part, I voted against the Tarabella report and I will vote tomorrow against the Panzeri report, because both are promoting a dangerous ideology: gender ideology and its procession of ultra-minority communitarian demands.  The Panzeri report also confirms that the European Union spends its time teaching human rights lessons to the entire planet while, at the same time, it flouts the basic rules of democracy by not respecting the sovereignty of nations or the will of the peoples.  Thus, Article 165 of the report condemns the free and sovereign choice of the Croatian people to constitutionalize male-female marriage. Yes, it amazes you, it may even scandalize you, but the result of the Croatian referendum in December 2013 has been respected. Yes, that's democracy! It will soon be the tenth anniversary of the rejection of the Lisbon Treaty by the French and the Dutch, I see that you still despise democratic expression so much.

name: Thomas Mann (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the In the European Parliament, Voice of Human Rights, we commemorate the 56th anniversary of the Tibetan uprising of 1959. Yesterday, Tibetan flags were flying on tens of thousands of buildings in towns and cities in the European Union. We call for freedom of expression, fundamental human rights and an end to the massive repression of a peace-loving culture! Our thoughts are with the 136 Tibetans who have sacrificed themselves, as well as with the hundreds of people still in prison. The Tibet interest group is committed to the substantive dialogue between the representatives of his Holiness, the Dalai Lama, and the Chinese Government. The only so-called crime of the Tibetans is to stand up for their own legitimate rights, the preservation of their culture, their language, their spirituality. Let us continue to work with full commitment to ensure that the suffering and humiliation of the Tibetan people finally cease!

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D).
text: – First of all, I would like to congratulate the Commissioner, especially on the work she has been developing, because the European Union is in fact promoting respect for democracy, universal human rights and fundamental freedoms throughout the world, and respect for human dignity.  The European Union's foreign policy is based on these principles, or it should be so. The European Union's trade policy often favours some authoritarian regimes that attack human rights every day. No human right can be circumvented, particularly when human beings are used as weapons of war and there are many women who pass through and have gone through this hell. Women remain the weakest link in human rights. Women have the right to be protected and we have a duty to protect them. The European Union's pressure on external relations with countries which repeatedly disregard the most basic rights of women and all human beings should be much greater. We must ensure that there is greater investment in supporting and protecting those trying to enter Europe, and I want to focus here on the case of the emigration of women, men and children from the Mediterranean. And don't see the constant deaths in the Mediterranean as collateral damage.  Watching, helpless and serest, is much greater damage to European values.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). Mr President, how would you describe an organisation which proclaims with the aim that 'democratic regimes are characterised by respect for the rule of law, freedom of speech, respect for human rights, independent justice and impartial administration', but when they show it that one of its members is in breach of the abovementioned principles, because of political purposes, he is blinded? In this area we had pointed out with evidence the intervention of the then fascist co-government, but also of Prime Minister Samaras himself, in the alleged Greek blind justice for the arrest of the leader as well as deputies and members of Golden Dawn, the third electoral force, and essentially the only opposition in Greece.  We had informed about illegal detention procedures, without the waiver of immunity, and today here, we are talking about respect for human rights, the promotion of justice, transparency, freedom of speech. Let us hope that, even slowly, there will be active interest and pressure on the Greek Government to restore justice and, by extension, democracy, in order to find an immediate solution to the political persecution of Golden Dawn.  I also wanted to suggest that Mrs Mogherini tell her friends if they want to solve their problems by uniting with Greece.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE).
text: - Mr. President, the annual human rights report is an important instrument for guiding the foreign policy and development cooperation policy of the European Union. This report must focus on the human rights situation outside the EU and I therefore hope that in the end sentences on Member States will be deleted from the resolution, as they do not belong here. Likewise, in promoting human rights, we must follow more systematicly the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, which puts the right to life first. This question is often put in the context of ideological struggles or worldviews. But the fact is that the science of the 21st century proves that human life begins long before birth, begins with conception.  According to the principle of subsidiarity, we have left the legal regulation for the protection of human life as well as reproductive health to the Member States. The same principle should apply in relations with non-EU countries – we must not impose solutions on other peoples that are rightly rejected by non-European peoples as an ideology of adhesive and disregard for the fundamental right to life. Human rights are universal, but only when it really comes to the right of man to a dignified life from conception to death - everything else would only be a show of ideological arrogance.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – The policy of double standards and negligence in the face of impunity in the face of notorious human rights violators are stabbed in the external and internal credibility of the European Union. Assessing the relations of the Union and Member States with third countries, in particular strategic partners in the containers for development aid, should go through a visit to those in their prisons. Many of the governments of countries, with whom we say we have special relations, arrest and persecute journalists, bloggers, activists and political opponents, instrumentalizing the judiciary to repress, oppress and steal. Human rights instruments focused, above all, on bilateral dialogues do not allow for real discussion at any level. They are opaque, lack strategy and scrutiny, they therefore have everything to fail and fail. The Council, the Union, Parliament and the Commission need to invest in strategies to free political prisoners and assist human rights activists, considering the impact repression can have on the security and stability of the countries with which we relate. Look at the total failure in a country with the importance of Ethiopia, which is a privileged partner of the Union in the ACP, African Union, etc. An example of a proactive policy would be to demand today that Saudi Arabia release all political and conscience prisoners. For example, I congratulate the Swedish Government for canceling all transfers of military material to Saudi Arabia, precisely on the basis of the human rights situation and, in particular, women's rights.  I end by saying that the Special Representative for Human Rights has worked very well but discreetly too much. It is essential that you talk audibly about the human rights situation in the countries you visit. We want to condemn laws that confuse journalists and human rights activists with terrorists to silence civil society that is fighting exactly for the realization of human rights.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE).
text: – The great Russian humanist and human rights defender Sergei Kovaljov was at one time proposed for the Nobel Peace Prize.  During the first Chechen war, when the Russian army killed civilians in Chechnya by the thousands, Kovaljov said, "Human rights violations cannot be an internal matter of any state." The fact that he did not receive the Nobel Prize signaled the beginning of a gradual increase in the indifference of politicians, governments, and society to the defense of human rights recently.  Defending the rights of man assumes a great inner sense of justice, just as it was inherent to Sergei Kovaljov.There is no doubt that the imperative to defend the weaker is disappearing more and more quickly. The commercial interests of many EU countries are being put above human rights.  The human rights report we are discussing supports Kovaljov's idea. Human rights violations cannot be an internal matter for any state.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the annual report on human rights and democracy in the world, which we are debating today, highlights the importance of this issue to the European Union. Respect for human rights is one of our hallmarks, as is so often said, and must occupy a very relevant place in our foreign policy. Especially now, at a time when principles of the international order are being questioned and alternative models of political organization even emerge. Ours is a complex and changing world in which problems and crises are not lacking. Unfortunately, it is a good example of this, as the High Representative said at first, both eastern and southern. There are many examples, unfortunately, of serious human rights violations there, and we would like, in accordance with Article 8 of the Treaty, that this neighbourhood area should have as one of its foundations precisely our values, among which is, of course, respect for human rights. Neighbourhood policy needs means, medium- and long-term commitment, realism, as I said before, but we cannot forget our values in that policy either. In the face of our neighbourliness, Madam President, and the rest of the world, external action must take human rights into account. I remember the old motto of the beginning of this century: peace and security, development and human rights, which was given to itself by the entire international community in the early 2000s.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE).
text: – On this subject, I would essentially like to focus my attention on two points: the first point is the question of the transition to democracy. Where I think the European Union can play a unique role, a very important role, it is in supporting the countries that have this democratic aspiration and the forces that in these countries have this democratic aspiration, to prepare for these transitions. We have very good examples in southern Europe: the case of Greece, Portugal, or Spain. In Eastern Europe, as it was possible to conduct democratic transitions successfully and make a great improvement, a great increase in the protection of fundamental rights. That would be the first note. And the second, very brief, just to say that we should look at the defense of fundamental rights, not just as an imperative of every moment, but as a progressive process. We need to look at the progress that many countries make. Sometimes, because we are too demanding at some point, we end up interrupting progress processes, processes that, over time, would certainly bring the defence of fundamental rights to levels that are acceptable.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the report addresses different issues of human rights, often focusing on those issues in which more EU action is needed. But I would like to see a stronger EU framework for carrying out such action; a framework with focused, effective actions assisting third countries in the process of democratisation, with the actions not only being named as priorities but also having actual and measurable targets.  In doing so, the EU must be seen to be consistent in upholding these principles. Therefore, coherence between internal and external human rights policies needs to be enhanced. In relation to a specific issue, suppression of the media and of expression creates oppression and serves only those who seize power at the expense of the best interests of their people and their country, thereby leading to instability and humanitarian crises which, in turn, lead also to migration towards – and tragedies on – EU territories. In this regard, focused effective action with third countries is a must.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the person and human dignity are the centrepiece around which all the actions of the European Union are subsumed. Protecting human rights must be the main point on the roadmap of an EU country and beyond. Terrorism in its various forms increased alarmingly in 2013, by 62%, compared to 2012, and the number of countries affected increased from 15 to 24. The recent terrorist attacks in European countries, resulting in human casualties, the frequent threats of Islamic State against the background of religious and interethnic intolerance, especially in the Arab world, as well as the conflict situation in Ukraine, are just a few examples of threats to the security of the citizen. Human rights must further constitute an essential component of the European Union's external action and a true element of its identity in bilateral relations.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the year 2013 was a challenging year, and in our response to breaches of human rights across the world I reiterate that we must stick to our values and our principles. This means that human rights must be at the core of our relations with third countries. Our policy must be visible, coherent and efficient, with particular focus on our accession region and immediate neighbours. We must support democratic development, rule of law and fair, free and competitive elections. These are the key prerequisites for functioning democracies that respect human rights, and we cannot compromise on them. We must insist on them in our enlargement process.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Dear High Representative Mogherini, dear colleague panzeri, I am glad that we have on the agenda today we have a report on the state of human rights and democracy in the world for 2013 and I think it is good that from this debate it is seen that tomorrow adopted, the last version of your report will concern those countries to which we need, namely those countries that are not yet members of the European Union and therefore it is good that paragraphs 165 and 162. in the end they are not adopted as is currently in the draft and on which we all work together, and I especially say this since I come from Croatia. What seems important to me is that this discussion and this report are in the spirit of our discussion at the previous point on the agenda, on the foreign policy of the European Union, where we pointed out that European values are essential in promoting our goals and our values, which are human rights, number 1, and therefore I especially welcome that my colleague Panzeri as chair of the conference of all delegation presidents pointed out that the guidelines for managing our activities and delegations must be guided by the topic of human rights Priority.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE).
text: – Madam President, at the outset, I would like to say that if a Member of this House has used the words ‘poison in society’ when referring to members of the gay and lesbian community, I think that this Parliament should disassociate themselves from that remark and I would like it if you would do something to address that, Madam President. In my notes that I made I wanted to welcome the special attention this report has given to issues such as freedom of religion, freedom of expression and violence against women and young girls and, in particular, the focus that it places on the issues of forced child labour, poverty and malnutrition. All too often we hear horrific stories of rape, torture, and forced marriage, of young women in particular, and we have an obligation to help them. The best policy that we can do is to support them, to engage with them and maybe to educate them as well, which is something we have heard recently in many debates in this Chamber, and to allow them to think and to act for themselves. The report reiterates the importance of mainstreaming human rights and democracy in all EU activities and calls for the commitment of placing human rights at the centre of all EU relations with third countries. We see that what we have to do is more than just words, we have to support people with freedom of religion, freedom of expression and indeed freedom of thought.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the report rightly draws attention to the importance of the free exercise of the right of assembly and association and calls on the Member States to condemn all restrictions on freedom of assembly and association. Just this week, a peaceful protest march was banned in Romania, an EU Member State, because the political organisations in power disagreed with its political aims and the problems raised. The protest would also have taken place in a city with an ethnically mixed population that had violent clashes exactly 25 years ago. Restrictions on the right of assembly are clearly common practice in non-democratic systems. It would be good to remind romania, whose official position is that it has tackled the problem of national minorities in an exemplary manner, of this. This settlement also seems to deprive minorities of the possibility of peaceful, democratic protest. I believe that the occurrence of such cases in the European Union undersages our own credibility when we criticise the relevant practices of third countries.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I thank the rapporteur, Mr Panzeri, for the tremendous job he did with this report on the crucial issue of human rights. I especially appreciate the introduction of a push for the rights of women; for the rights of children; for the rights of religious, racial, ethnic minorities and for the rights of minorities in general. These persons are a part of society that is highly discriminated against in most countries of the world and that needs greater government protection and support.  The European Union must clearly lead the way with a swift approach to the subject. Societies must change from within, and governments can play important roles in education about and respect for freedom. There should be conformity of rights inside our borders so that the people are not forced to change state in order to see their rights respected. I consider this report to be highly strategic, especially when it states that the European Union when dealing with other nations must exert greater pressure on respect for human rights.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Colleague Panzeri has obviously done a lot of work on this report, but we in the Group of European Conservatives and Reformists still have some remarks. We do not agree with the inclusion of development, trade, fiscal policy, climate, refugee policy and asylum.  We also believe that the report crosss borders with its criticism of the Member States of the European Union, such as Lithuania, Croatia and Slovakia, in terms of their internal family policy.  We believe that each country has the right, through its internal referendums, to decide such important issues in relation to its traditions as family matters. Separately, I personally believe that more attention could have been paid to the victims of The Islamic State and to the complicity of the countries that support it, such as Turkey.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, Europe wants to remain a reference on human rights in the world and, in order to achieve this, it needs a unique and braver voice in the most committed conflicts. It is worth being strong with the weakest and looking the other way when you have to draw attention to influential states like Israel, the United States or China. This explains, for example, the warmth that we should banish on matters as clear as those of Palestine or those of Western Sahara, and we must also keep our own house in a state of review. That is why I support the idea of launching an early warning system that warns us against serious violations of the Charter of Fundamental Rights occurring in different European states. On The European Day of Victims of Terrorism, I stress the need to combat it without cutting freedoms. It's memory day, truth and repair. And I encourage that, in Europe, we support it for all victims, including those in Spain, for example, who have been in the ditches, shot and missing for opposing a coup d'eer for decades.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, this tonight's debate is somewhat paradoxical. We are dealing with the situation of human rights and democracy in the Third World and we do not see the problems within the Union itself. On the altar of budgetary stability, democratic legitimacy is sacrificed, since the possibilities of defining policies by the European Parliament and national parliaments are severely limited.  But fundamental rights, especially social rights, are also sacrificed with constant cuts in social spending. If you are really interested in human rights, I would recommend that instead of going too long about what is happening in third countries, we finally implement the European Union's accession to the European Convention on Human Rights and the European Social Charter, thus subjecting the Union's policies to the constant scrutiny of the European Court of Human Rights and the Commission of the European Social Charter. But then the budgetary discipline in here would be trying unpleasant surprises.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – It's a challenging subject, which, of course,... attention to be paid. I'd touch something else all the time that we haven't talked about. Namely, you mentioned, in this document, the fight against terrorism. However, I think that it is in this fight that, sometimes, in this concern for human rights, we also interfere with human rights, especially through these measures, which mean powers to collect data that can interfere with greater control over people. This can also mean encroaching on human rights. And that's why, of course, I would be worried if we adopted some package of the so-called Patriot Act and we fell into that temptation to strengthen the role of Big Brother. I therefore also consider it important to cooperate with the Council of Europe. And it is precisely the Council of Europe that we can work out a longer-term strategy in protecting the human rights that we are fighting for.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to express my thanks to the rapporteur and to all the shadow rapporteurs who have worked hard to adopt this report, which has certainly been very intensive and laborious. In particular, I wanted to refer to a number of paragraphs which are very dear to me, such as Paragraphs 75 and 76, which mention the need to include the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court in the new GSP regulation, given that some candidates, in order to obtain precisely this status – such as Armenia and Pakistan, which have not yet acceded to it – and, on the other hand, also have a common position of the European Union on the subject of the ratification of the Kampala amendments. , since with a friend an Italian senator I had the opportunity to work on a bill aimed precisely at this in my country. And I hope that, both as colleagues together in the European Parliament and the High Representative, we can relaunch this issue with great vigour for all the Member States. Finally, I would also like to mention, in paragraph 77, the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide, as an opportunity for reconciliation, between two communities, with their past in order to build their future peacefully.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, honourable Members, I will be brief. The debate has been rich with comments and suggestions of which we have taken due note. I can assure you that we are going to draw very much on this in this crucial stage of our preparation of our human rights and democracy policies for the next five years. I would just mention one of the many points many of you have raised, because this is not something I included in my opening remarks and I have a strong personal feeling about it, which is the reference to the role of women in society and in leadership and also the issue of violence against women. Two sides of the same coin somehow. This would probably take hours to debate in full but just let me share in what some of you have said about the fact that the role of women and the fight against violence is not only an issue of changing legislation, it is very much an issue of changing culture, starting with the education not only of girls but mainly of boys in our own families and in our own schools. It is an issue not only in our external policies but also very much in our internal policies. I just wanted to share the fact that I have chosen to dedicate our work on 8 March to Afghan women and in particular to the women in Afghanistan that have chosen or are trying to experience leadership roles, be it in politics, be it in institutions, be it in the police or in the judicial system or in journalism and media. I think we need to support them very much. We have launched a programme for having them in the European institutions for a certain amount of time, so that we can keep this channel open and encourage them on their difficult path. Let me also share with you the fact that on 9 March, just last Monday – and I had the pleasure of being in New York on the 8 March – I met the UN Women Executive Director and we discussed our common policies towards empowering women in society, and also countering violence against women, and I had the pleasure of attending – together with our special representative – the opening session of the CSW related to Beijing+20. I would just underline here again the valuable contributions we have made, the excellent work that was done, and two commitments I can take in specific terms. One, is making sure that we coordinate the internal and external work on human rights in all our policies; secondly, that we try to mainstream this across all sectors of our engagement, particularly when we work with third parties around the world, and the commitment to work together in our different institutions: Council, Commission, but very much with the European Parliament. I would like to thank you all very much for the contributions to the debate – the shadow rapporteurs, the rapporteur Antonio Panzeri, for the excellent report that will very much constitute the basis for our future work in these critical times, and also Stavros Lambrinidis. (Applause)

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank everyone for this debate. Congratulations on the extension of the mandate and, above all, thanks to you, High Representative, because I think you have understood very well what is useful and necessary to do. This debate is important: it signals real attention and also a different sensitivity that I respect, and some of them I do not agree with. I just wanted to point out that the preamble to the Charter of Fundamental Rights states that the European Union places the person at the centre of its action and, speaking in person, no abstraction has been mentioned. On the contrary, that word was intended to move away precisely from the abstractions handed down in the term as a subject and individual and intended to give prominence to material life, to the concrete conditions of existence, to the inviolability of the dignity of each and every one. That is why I want to say very strongly that I refer to the sender the phrases I have heard from Mr Chauprade and Mr Bay: I find shameful some of the statements used towards the LGBT community, which in fact only indicate the level of political incivility in which we want to drag such a fundamental issue as that of rights. Their opposition to the report does not surprise me, because it is opposed to tolerance and respect for people. But that is why I am addressing the GUE, Mrs Vergiat, who should reflect on the idea of abstaining from voting on the report, which I also respect. It would be truly paradoxical if, by abstaining, these obscurantist temptations were to prevail in this Parliament. That is why I believe that the work that has been done is important and, I hope, has the support of a large part of the European Parliament.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place on Thursday, 12 March 2015. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. – With regard to this report, I would like to underline that the EU must be a central element in all the UNION's relations with third countries, including strategic partners. I consider it necessary for EU agencies to draw up an annual report on their activities in the field of human rights, including minority rights. Political transition and democratisation must always be linked to respect for human rights, the promotion of justice, transparency, accountability, reconciliation and the rule of law, and support for the establishment of democratic institutions.  I am pleased to see that the report emphasises that national minorities have specific needs, that full and effective equality between persons belonging to national minorities and those belonging to the majority must be promoted in all areas of social, political and cultural life.

name: Lorenzo Cesa (PPE)
text: in writing. The Panzeri report contains many inaccuracies, first of all the reference in paragraph 136, calling on the Member States of the European Union to recognise the right to abortion under legal security conditions. The AFET Committee, of which I am a member and which voted for this report, has no competence over the Member States of the Union, but only over third countries. This paragraph should therefore not even have appeared in the final text of the report.  Furthermore, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, the possibility of abortion is a matter for the Member States and the European Union cannot interfere in the policies of the Member States in this area.  But it's not the only incongruity. In fact, we also read valuable judgments on referendums on same-sex marriage, which took place in 2014 and 2015 in Slovakia, Croatia and Lithuania, references that cannot be taken into account given that the Panzeri report deals with human rights and democracy in the world in 2013.  My impression is that we wanted at all costs to include the issue of abortion and gay marriage even where it had nothing to do with it, in order to create precedents, which, as far as I am concerned, I cannot accept.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. – In today's debate, we are talking about an assessment of the situation in the EU, including Parliament, on the protection of human rights outside the EU and on further measures to promote the universality of human rights. This parliamentary report should focus on cooperation with the EU and third countries and international organisations. In the relationship between immigration policy and the provision of human rights, the importance of international cooperation must be emphasised in order to find a solution to this pressing issue. The European Union has always set an example in enforcing the principles of fundamental human rights, democracy and the rule of law. Thus, the conditions for accession to the Union included the requirement of human rights, including minority rights and democratic state functioning, which encourages the applicant countries to bring their legal order and state system into line with international and EU standards. The rights of persons belonging to national minorities are, of course, part of this report.  It cannot be said enough that national minorities have specific needs, which are influenced by the history of the state or region in which they are based, as well as their economic and social conditions. National minorities should be given equal treatment so that they can live as equal members of society while preserving their identity. In the area of EU minority policy, it would be desirable to balance the requirements that the EU imposes on third and applicant countries and their own Member States.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I regret that, once again, the discussion on human rights in the world leads to the smuggling of content as sensitive as abortion, gay marriage and reproductive and sexual rights into parliamentary resolutions through the back door. It seems that some of my fellow Members forget the division of competences between the European Union and the Member States.  The Polish Constitution clearly defines that marriage is a union between a man and a woman. Putting pressure on Member States to legalise abortion or to change the provisions on such important philosophical issues is a blatant encroachment on their competences, violating the principle of subsidiarity encroachment in EU treaty law.  I would like to remind you that the role of the EU institutions is not to impose philosophical issues, but to respect the established law contained in the Treaties. Mr Panzeri's report undermines the Christian values with which most of my compatriots are equated. As Polish Member of the European Parliament, I am full of my mandate at the will of our citizens, who, for the most part, do not want EU interference in world-view issues.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. Mr President, there is more EU bilingualism on the issue of the protection of human rights in the world, at a time when the troika has, without any consequence, violated human rights in the countries that have been put to a memorandum and especially in Greece. As the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe held that austerity leads to the violation of human rights, mercely austerity, which the European Union serves with religious reverence, leads to a massive and persistent violation of the human rights of the citizens of the Union.  What does the Commission say about all this? He goes on to "business as usual," insisting on austerity. Therefore, before the European Union supposedly decides to save the world, it is better to put its own house in order.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. – This report in some of its parts exceeds the envisaged frameworks for the report on the state of human rights in the world and interferes with the internal affairs of Member States which, according to the principle of subsidiarity, have the competence to decide independently on matters of marriage and family. In paragraph 165, you inadmissiblely call on Croatia to hold a referendum on the constitutional protection of marriage in 2013 and put my country in an inappropriate context. I ask that you delete this from the report because you call on Croatia as a member of the EU to conduct a people's referendum on issues of importance to Croatian citizens. I believe that this report injustices Croatia and you do not recognize the initiative of Croatian citizens to actively participate in their country's political processes and influence decisions that are important to them. I would add that in the same way the report tosses the internal issues of two other Member States, Slovakia and Lithuania in that paragraph, and that in several other paragraphs such as 135,136 and 164, you mention issues of family, health and reproductive policies such as abortion and same-sex marriage, which are also within the full competence of the Member States and therefore I ask that this be omitted from the report.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. – Mr President, the Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy covers very important problems for people facing discrimination. For this reason, we should make every effort to ensure that citizens' rights are respected. The Treaty of Lisbon draws great attention to cultural and linguistic heritage, while supporting the protection of languages and ethnic diversity as one of the fundamental principles of the European Union. This right is granted to citizens of the Union in accordance with Articles 21 and 22 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, which means that attempting to introduce the distinctiveness of a particular language constitutes a restriction and violation of the fundamental values of the Union. By insisting on compliance with these standards in the world, we must first and foremost introduce the principle of non-discrimination on grounds of language and ethnicity throughout the European Union. Unfortunately, there are still countries where the rights of minorities, especially autochtononic ones, are violated. The European Parliament and the Commission should therefore call on all EU Member States to ratify without delay the Council of Europe Framework Convention for the Protection of National Minorities and the European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages. It should also be recalled that the European Parliament adopted a resolution of the July 2013 European Parliament on the european union. resolution on linguistic diversity. Parliament then called on the countries that have not yet signed and ratified this Charter to do so as soon as possible. He also called for condemnation of all actions that discriminate against or impose language, and concealed assimilation hostile to the languages and identities of other communities. There can be no ethnic discrimination in 21st century Europe.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: We will now continue the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy: The unstable situation in Libya and its consequences (2015/2602(RSP)).

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, Libya was the first point I put on the agenda for the foreign ministers meeting last Friday and Saturday in Riga – in the very north and east of our European Union – to show very clearly that just as we are united when we look at the challenges and threats we have to our east, we do the same with the challenges and threats we have to the south of us. Because the threats we are facing from Libya in these weeks are, more so than in all the past months and years, threats not only to the southern countries of our European Union but threats and challenges for the whole of the European Union itself.  Since we discussed the situation in Libya in this Chamber last January this has been, I would say, together with the Ukrainian crisis, the top priority of my personal work. Work that has been difficult, that is still very difficult, made up of creating the network of international and regional support for the efforts to support and to have political dialogue, under the auspices of the UN, in the dialogue that is currently ongoing in Rabat under the work of the UN Secretary—Generalʼs Special Envoy, Bernardino León.  I started to work on this international and regional framework a few weeks ago when in Washington. The European Union has promoted a meeting between the Secretary-General of the United Nations Ban Ki-moon, myself for the European Union, Secretary Kerry and Mr Shoukry, the Foreign Minister of Egypt, to try to build a framework that could keep all relevant actors – there are many others involved as well on a bilateral basis, but the main political actors, main relevant actors – together in full support of the internal dialogue in Libya.  That dialogue has restarted since January. It has restarted now in Rabat. I was in a session at one of these dialogues before, exactly four months ago today, in Tripoli. I was in the same Hotel Corinthia that was then attacked by terrorists at the end of January, together with not only Bernardino León but also Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon, in one of the last sessions of the dialogue before we restarted a couple of days ago.  I can say that the fact that the dialogue has restarted is something on which we would probably not have bet just a few months ago. This is the result of sometimes silent but constant and difficult diplomatic work we have done together with the UN, in an incredible way, in these months. The European Union supports this dialogue not only politically but also financially. There are other tracks of dialogue going on. They do not always make the news headlines but I think it is fair for this Chamber to know and recognise the work that is done on parallel levels. There is currently a dialogue going on in Algeria between political parties.  On Monday – so just a few days ago – there was a meeting in Brussels of more than 40 businessmen from all different parts of Libya which produced a joint statement asking for the political dialogue to bring the result of a national unity government so that they can be put in the situation of restarting the reconstruction of their country and the improvement of the economic and social situation of all the Libyan people, united together.  We will host in the European Union institutions in Brussels in the coming days a dialogue between municipalities and mayors so that grass-roots local level dialogue can accompany the political dialogue that is taking place hopefully in Rabat again in these days. I have talked to Bernardino León today about the state of play of this political dialogue. We were discussing that too with Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon on Monday in New York and this morning again with the Secretary-General of the League of Arab States. I will have a conversation later today with the Egyptian Foreign Minister. This is all to say that we need to make sure that all actors are pushing in the same direction.  I forgot to say, but that was not out of any political intention, that this was also a subject of my meeting with the Turkish Foreign Minister a few days ago in Riga.  We have to make sure that all relevant international, regional and local actors – local level, national level – push in the same direction. We have to make sure that the dialogue continues and we have to make sure that the dialogue brings the result of a national unity government.  Terrorism, confronting the threat of Daesh, uncontrolled migration, regional instability – these are only some of the challenges we have in front of us in Libya and the unity government in Libya is vital to addressing all these issues and many more. Libya is a rich country full of financial natural resources which if put together, if provided with authorities, can perform very well. What we need to do is ensure that there is a restart, a reset somehow, that allows a government to be in place that can work in all the territory and with all the people of Libya.  It will be vital to addressing these challenges, it will be vital first of all to giving all Libyans the security and the living conditions that the country can offer and that they deserve after so many difficult years.  As I have said, these are not only Libyan problems. They concern all of us. The international community must contribute in all possible ways and as a matter of urgency to solve these problems. Here, continued strong cooperation between the UN and the EU is crucial as well as is, as I have said, our cooperation with the countries neighbouring Libya and with the League of Arab States.  We need a unified and effective state authority all over Libya and I think that a national unity government is possible and desperately needed for the country and for the sake of the country. The European Union is ready, with all its willingness and its support, to help this process. We are doing that already. When we have, and I hope it will be soon, a positive outcome from the dialogue we are ready to give support in all possible ways, in coordination with the UN and with the neighbouring countries.  This includes through missions and operations that are being explored at present. We started to discuss this with the Ministers for Foreign Affairs in Riga a couple of days ago. Libya will be one of the main issues on our agenda on Monday at the Foreign Affairs Council, to make sure that the European Union is ready to support any kind of outcome of the dialogue that is currently taking place. We will also work with the ministers on Monday on migration and when talking about Libya it is impossible not to mention this issue. It is impossible first of all because the numbers of people crossing the Mediterranean through Libya – not from Libya, not Libyans, these are people coming from the Horn of Africa, from Syria, escaping from terrible situations in their own countries – are increasing compared to the same months last year and will probably do so even more when spring and summer come.  This is not just an issue of people crossing the Mediterranean, it is also an issue that affects greatly the countries neighbouring Libya: Tunisia, Chad, Algeria, Niger, Sudan and Egypt continue to receive migrants and asylum seekers from Libya. The EU is supporting organisations like the IOM which are trying to carry out voluntary repatriation.  A few days ago, through one of the EU funded programmes, the IOM facilitated the voluntary return of 400 Senegalese from Libya and these are 400 people that will not try to cross the Mediterranean, risking their lives, feeding terrorist networks probably with financial revenues that are, through criminal organisations, most probably also supporting criminal activities. These are most probably 400 people saved. In the same way we are working with the UNHCR and according to them there are around 400 000 internally displaced persons in Libya. This is almost 10% of the country’s population. They are moving along tribal lines, seeking safety in rural areas and the tendency is to remain in Libya, trying to seek refuge in those parts of the country that are not yet touched by the conflict.  For these reasons, on 4 March, exactly one week ago, jointly with Vice—President Timmermans and Commissioner Avramopoulos inside the Commission we have steered the process that will lead to the adoption of a new EU agenda for migration. It was scheduled to come later in the summer, if not later still. I personally asked for this to be advanced to May because we cannot really wait for more months before acting and acting together and efficiently. It will be built on four main objectives – an effective asylum policy, well managed regular migration, the fight against irregular migration and protection of our common external borders. In this framework I have decided, as I told you, to put migration on the agenda of the next Foreign Affairs Council on Monday where Foreign Ministers will have, for the first time, a discussion to complement the ongoing work of the Justice and Home Affairs Council that is taking place at the same time.  Together with Commissioner Avramopoulos, I have written to the Ministers to share some ideas already now on how we could step up our concrete action in the external dimension of our effort on migration in order to avoid tragedies at sea but also at land borders, securing protection for those in need and fighting the criminal networks controlling the trafficking and smuggling. We have also started to exchange views with the UNHCR and with High Commissioner Guterres on the most effective measures and policies to face these challenges together. It has to be a joint effort starting from the very helpful and useful experience that the UNHCR has developed over the years. I proposed to the ministers that we discuss along three strands. Firstly, enhanced cooperation with third countries of origin and transit on the West African migratory route, the East African one and the so-called silk route in order to build capacities to fight smuggling and trafficking networks and protect stranded migrants in distress. Secondly, step up refugee protection both in countries of origin and in neighbouring countries where asylum seekers and refugees have settled, using resettlement and humanitarian admission schemes and regional development and protection programmes in order to assist partner countries to become robust providers of effective protection in accordance with international law, as well as to provide safe alternatives to dangerous journeys. Thirdly, to engage with our partners in third countries of origin on the potential of regular, well-managed migration. We should consider better targeted mobility partnerships as an instrument for economic and social development, accompanied by reflection on the role of remittances in development and on the mutual recognition of educational and professional qualifications.  Because we know very well that when people have regulated and safe ways this works better not only for themselves – we are talking about people first of all, we just finished a debate on human rights, let us remember that – but we are also talking about the development of their countries of origin and also of our own societies in the European Union. Now these are things we need to do both in the short and in the long term when it comes to external action on our commitment to better management of migration, but we all know – and here I go back to Libya, our starting point –we all know that Libya is the immediate key element for facing the dramatic situation of people dying at sea and also to face the security and stability challenge we have very close to our borders.  We all know, and I can guarantee you that all Member States and all Commissioners know – here I am playing my dual role – that Libya is the number one issue we need to face in these weeks if we want to be sure that the European Union can have a stable and secure future and that our region can have a stable and secure future. The impact of this continued situation in Libya on not only our sea and our European Union but also on neighbouring countries that are struggling themselves with difficult transitions could be really explosive. I am looking forward to listening to your views in this respect. I will be happy to report also to the ministers. Let me send from here a strong message in view of what is happening in these days in Rabat. All parties need to be fully aware of the fact that all possible support will come from the European Union, including on a security level, but we need to have them taking the first step and to unite to save the country.

name: Roberta Metsola
text: f'isem group PPE. – Sinjura President, nixtieq nibda billi nirringrazzja flower-collegi kollha li qablu li għandu jkollna dan id-dibattitu daqshekk importanti. Illum, fil-Libja, hemm numru ta' kwistjonijiet li huma marbuta ma' xulxin. Il-fatt li l-fazzjonijiet differenti għadhom ma laħqux ftehim fuq gvern unitarju – u aħna napprezzaw hawk sforz li jkun hemm hawk tip ta' djalogu – ifisser li gaħd hemm nuqqas ta' sigurtà fil-pajjiż. Is-sitwazzjoni qed tagħti lok għall group terrorist, bħall-Istat Iżlamiku, sabiex jikbru fil-pajjiż. Dawn it-terrorist jistgħu jiġu megħluba biss jekk ikun hemm Libja b'saħħitha u magħquda. Fl-istess ħin irid ikun - dak li għadek kif għedt inti Sinjura Vi大i President – il-poplu Libjan innifsu li jfassal id-destin tiegħu. Kif sostna r-Re tal-Ġordan ilbieraħ, ikun żball jekk inqisu l-ġlieda kontra l-ISIS bħala waħda bejn relijonijiet differenti. L-ISIS I tirrappreżentax l-Iżlam; din hija ġlieda kontra l-estremisti li qed jabbużaw minn reliġjon. Is-sitwazzjoni qed tevolvi b'mod mgħaġel. Eluf ta' nies jinsabu f'riskju li jiġu spustati u ser jaħarbu mit-terrur u l-vjolenza b'kull mod possibbli. Il-flussie migratorji ser ikomplu jippersistu. Wara li twaqqa' Gaddafi, l-Unjoni Ewropea, partikolarment Malta u l-Italja, kienu xhieda ta' influss ta' eluf. Irridu nkunu preparati u jkollna l-kuraġġ li nħarsu lejn hawk possibilità li l-Unjoni Ewropea tista' tagħmel użu minnha. Dan jinkludi li fucknsidraw i大-ikeaqliq ta' assi għall-Mediterran biex jiġu salvati l-ħajjiet u tiżdied is-sigurtà jew pereżempju li narsu kif nistgħu nutilizzaw id-Direttiva dwar il-protezzjoni temporanja tal Unjoni Ewropea. U fl-aħħar nett nixtieq nilqa' l-fatt li din il-kwistjoni dalwaqt ser tiġi diskussa fil-Kunsill Ewropew. Irrid ikollna din id-diskussjoni fuq il-prijorità tal-aġenda tagħna.

name: Ana Gomes
text: On behalf of the S&D Group – You are right, Mrs Mogherini, Libya must be the priority issue for the immediate action of European governments. The power vacuum is fuelling the escalation of violence and sectarianism, making Libya almost Somalia at europe's doorland. Political agreement between Libyans is indispensable, and the European Union must mobilize diplomacy, targeted sanctions and other means to support the efforts of United Nations representative Bernardino León to establish a government of national unity, as Ms. Mogherini said. A runaway Libya, delivering people, oil facilities, humanity's historical heritage to the atrocities of criminal gangs such as DAESH or Ansar al-Sharia, poses a direct threat to the European Union. And the scale of the problem cannot be measured by the number of people fleeing conflict and arriving in Europe on the coasts of Libya. The problem of migration influx is not being combated with Fortress Europe, as Ms Mogherini said, but with avenues facilitating legal migration, UNHCR involvement in screening, protection and support for refugees, and more balanced sharing of refugee reception by European Member States. But it is true that terrorism today has a bridge in Libya with easy and fast access to the European continent, and there are environmental and cultural disasters of biblical proportions on the horizon, threatening the entire Mediterranean. Member States must therefore ask for and be ready to contribute substantially to an international mission led by the Security Council to stabilise Libya, help purge it of terrorists. The Security Council must reform and strengthen the mandate of the UNSMIL mission it has on the ground, taking responsibility for helping to empower the country institutionally for governance and national and regional security. And the horizon has to be long-term and the plan has to involve us, the European Union, and the regional partners. We, Europe, need to learn from our mistakes and omissions after the fall of Gaddafi and engage in the security of Libya. This is to assume that it is our responsibility and interest to invest in the reform of the security sector and in the social integration of militias, in the protection of critical infrastructure. Without this, no political strategy can revive democratic governance in Libya. Missions focused on border security will not be used.

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, at our January meeting, the presence of IS in Libya was only just known. The following month we were confronted with the shocking images of the beheading of 21 Egyptian Copts. Since then, IS has strengthened its position and paraded brand new all-terrain vehicles in Mediterranean coastal cities. An adviser to the UN special envoy to Libya, a compatriot of mine, says in a Dutch newspaper that 'Libya has the potential to grow into a crisis many times greater than Syria. From a European perspective, Libya is more important than Syria. Most of the problems with illegal migrants and some problems with Islamist extremism can be traced back to the chaos in Libya.' A consideration that gives to think!  The efforts of the UN envoy, Bernardino Leon, offer the only hope. But unfortunately, the country is a hotbed of militias. It makes it extremely suitable for IS to do area expansion. The Libyan people do not deserve to be harassed again by a minority, which governs with fear and violence. Europe, therefore, in cooperation with the Arab League, must pledge all possible support to the Libyan people. Libya does indeed need this unity government, which can only be achieved if there is an inclusive peace process.

name: Fernando Maura Barandiarán
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Libya is no longer a state to become a confrontation between factions fighting each other. His interests would be smuggling, drug trafficking and human trafficking. They're not interested in ideology. Neither does religion. This is not a civil war, but a fight between rival gangs. A state of things that favors the expansion of ISIS, installed in the country since the middle of last year. Negotiations between the different sides are open. It's a very difficult agreement. But in the meantime, the Islamic State is advancing. It wants to reach Tunisia and Algeria through its porous southern borders, fenced by Salafirists and terrorist groups. He wants to get to where Boko Haram is to partner with this terrorist gang. I am saying that this decomposition of Libya can reach the entire Sahel strip, Tunisia and Algeria. It is a very serious, very serious focus of tension and instability. We must therefore pay the same concern to North Africa as we do in eastern Europe, as the High Representative has said. We must be prepared for the worst, which means moving from words to deeds, to border control, effective control.

name: Barbara Spinelli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the director of Frontex, Leggeri, sown fear on 6 March: one million migrants are about to arrive from Libya and perhaps there would be ISIS jihadists among them. It has mobilised the extreme right in Europe and awakened the will for military intervention in Libya. I would like to ask you, Mr Vice-President, whether you share this alarm; shares Commissioner Avramopoulos' call for more cooperation with dictatorships, i.e. forced returns; if he approves the idea of Bernardino León, who is in favour of an EU naval blockade along the Libyan coast.  Intervention in Libya would look worse than the Soviet and American wars in Afghanistan. We would get our hands on geopolitically chaotic lands, increasing the chaos unleashed by our first intervention. Today the only way, it seems to me, is to create legal humanitarian corridors, coordinated with the UN if possible, as I think you have suggested.  Politically, it is a question of putting an end – as you have also suggested – to wars aimed at exporting democracy. It is not a question of sowing panic without reliable evidence. I would like to ask whether we should not demand the resignation of the director of Frontex if this evidence is not given.

name: Barbara Lochbihler
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, High Representative Mogherini, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Libya is at a crossroads. Either the UN-backed dialogue between the two opposing political camps leads to an agreement or the country continues to descend into chaos. Then we must assume that the radical forces in Libya will continue to gain influence. It is to be feared that jihadist groups in particular will benefit from a continuation of the armed conflict. Faced with this threat, it must be clear that there is no alternative to a negotiated solution that is compatible with the Libyans themselves. However, the international community can support the negotiated process, for example.B by continuing and complying with the UN arms embargo. The EU should also stand out clearly against external military intervention by states in the region. Those states in the region that are seeking dialogue should be supported, in particular Tunisia and Algeria. Finally, I would like to stress that a lasting solution to the conflict in Libya requires the punishment of violations of human rights and international humanitarian law, as we called for in our resolution back in January. The EU should support measures to detect and document the crimes that took place both during and after the fall of the Gaddafi regime. Support should also be given to the creation of a special United Nations commission of inquiry, and adequate resources must be made available in the International Criminal Court to work on Libyan cases referred by the Security Council.  Allow me to use the time remaining to thank you, High Representative, for your constant and intense commitment to this conflict.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a few months ago I called Libya a broken Pandora's box. Today we can perhaps say that the first pieces begin to recompose. The dialogue that has been laboriously supported in recent months is beginning to bear fruit. Perhaps a government of national unity can be seen on the horizon.  It is right now, ladies and gentlemen, that we must be more vigilant and not make missteps. That is why we must in no way fall into the siren call of General Haftar, the new commander-in-chief of the armed forces, who just on Monday called for the lifting of the arms embargo on the country. If that were to happen, the Czech Republic, Serbia and Ukraine would immediately send eight helicopters, six fighters, four fighter-bombers, one hundred and fifty tanks and leave out tens of thousands of rifles and so on. In addition to the real risk that, in transport, they will end up in the hands of Ansar al-Sharia or ISIS, such supplies would in any case inflam the proxy war that has led Libya into this chaos, given that libya dawn sponsors would feel entitled to relaunch. On the other hand, all factions must know that there is no military option and that we will not tolerate any confrontation at the last blood but only a handshake for a government of national unity at all costs.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to speak by displaying the flag of Libya because I have been there. Unlike those who have spoken before, I really went there and came back this morning and I have to say that what I saw in Libya is not what I heard here. For example, the High Representative said that he had spoken to the Turkish Minister: but does the High Representative know that Turkey is one of the financiers of the terrorists who are in Libya? Do you know or don't you know? Do you know that Qatar is also a terrorist financier in Libya? Do you know that Sudan is a terrorist financier in Libya? The Libyans in the Government of Tobruk, where I was – the Tobruk naval base where the parliament is based, where twenty-three female Members sit – have said that they have not seen a Westerner go to see them for almost a year: there is no Western politician going to Libya and here we are discussing Libya without knowing what is going on! They are calling for the embargo to be lifted because otherwise they have their hands tied while the terrorists and the Islamic brothers do what they want. And I remind you that 50% of illegal immigrants arriving are affected by AIDS or Ebola. Remember that they call Italy like a taxi with barges. You have to go to Libya and see. High Representative Mogherini, come with me to Libya! I went there with my money: come with me!

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE).
text: Madam President, Mrs Mogherini, the resolution of the Libyan crisis is clearly a priority, if not an emergency, because we are all directly concerned and that is why we need a strategy that is up to the challenge. First, we must continue to support the UN-brokered negotiation process for a political solution to the conflict. But we must also strengthen diplomatic efforts and find concrete levers that allow us to move towards the union of all parties against the expansion of the Islamic State. With this in mind, a few observations. Let us make sure that all efforts are in the same direction and that the countries of the region also have sufficient leadership.
