Second, perhaps we should think of a Plan B that could also be a lever in the ongoing discussions. What would we do if the talks were not going to work? Let's have the courage to ask this question as well!  Third, I will emphasize the issue of reconciliation. We must reach an agreement at the national level and above all promote reconciliation and union at the local level. Congratulations to the mayors and local elected officials! And I'd like to draw attention to women. The full participation of Libyan women must be ensured so that they contribute to lasting peace and security for generations to come.  And finally, yes, the European Union can make a difference in managing the consequences of the crisis. To face the humanitarian situation, to fully support the countries hosting refugees: this is what we are being asked to do, because at the end of the day we are anticipating, and that is where the European Union can make a difference.

name: Victor Boștinaru (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would say to the Vice—President/High Representative that theatre is not the solution for Libya – definitely not. We should refrain ourselves, and others also, from playing theatre in trying to solve the Libyan crisis. Time passes, and we do not yet have good news from Libya, with the threat of Daesh increasing and attacks conducted on Libyan territory, including the beheadings of 21 Egyptian Christian Copts. The official affiliation of Boko Haram to Daesh is already a fact which heavily increases the danger for the region. Meanwhile, hundreds of thousands of Libyans are crossing the Mediterranean. In Libya institution-building is the key problem and here Europe should play a key role, together with the regional and interregional partners. I am very much encouraged by the fact that the two conflicting sides finally negotiated face to face in Morocco because a government of unity to control the entire country is very necessary; it is the most important step.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR).
text: – Madam President, two months ago this House discussed the crisis in Libya. At that time the peace talks were between the two main factions and were being brokered by the UN in Geneva under the auspices of Bernardino Leon as Special Representative. Since then, ISIS has strengthened its position in Sirte, from where it has launched attacks against the Copts – murdering 21 men by beheading. Most recently, ISIS has destroyed an oil facility in al—Ghani where another eight Libyans were killed and where nine foreign nationals were kidnapped, two of whom are EU citizens. The previous peace talks have broken down now and a fresh round of EU-funded talks, scheduled for Rabat in Morocco, looks set to be delayed at the request of the internationally—recognised government in Tobruk. Allowing Libya to fall into chaos will result in it becoming a failed state and a safe haven for jihadi terrorism very close to our own borders. This will not only jeopardise our security on our continent, but also lead to a massive influx of refugees across the Mediterranean. Member States need to look more seriously and closely now at a UN—mandated restarting of military options and to support our regional allies such as Egypt in containing this terrible problem.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, I would like to focus on the consequences of the situation in Libya in terms of migration policy for the European Union. If I heard the interpretation, what you called the threat to immigration. In 2014, more than 270,000 irregular border crossings were recorded by FRONTEX. This is more than in 2011, and we know that Libya is now one of the main crossing points, if not the main one, to Europe. The question is why? So, yes, because there is no more debate in Libya. But, yes, too, because Europe's borders are less and less permeable, more and more controlled, and those who cross borders are increasingly identified. Yes also, because of the international situation: these men, these women, these children who are fleeing conflict, but also repression. Terrible situations, you said. They are Syrians but also Eritreans, Ethiopians, Somalis, Sudanese. They are potential asylum seekers, and it is with their state, with their dictator, that we want to deal with this irregular immigration upstream and fight against trafficking, of which these states are involved.  So I have only one question: what are you really negotiating with these states as part of the Khartoum process?

name: Judith Sargentini (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, let me pick up where Mrs Vergiat left off. This is the question: what are you actually doing in these negotiations in the Khartoum process, cooperation between European countries and countries in Africa, including a whole number of dictatorships? That question remains complicated. The question is also: what do you expect from your meeting with the Foreign Ministers and the meeting of the Interior and Justice Ministers next week? Your intention is good. We need to see the crisis in Libya lead to more migration, more refugees. But frankly, in 2011, we did not see member states being prepared to step over their shadows and ensure that we resettle more people, for example. I see no signs at all that there would now be unity between the Member States in northern Europe and southern Europe, because the system still remains: 'Italy, catch them, then we will not be affected!'

name: Janice Atkinson (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, Libya has ceased to be a state thanks to the super war that the EU helped to create. People say they want dialogue. But which set of terrorists will they be talking to? The West intervened in Iraq, Afghanistan and Libya – and the result? Migration on an unprecedented scale leading to the most disgusting type of human trade: people trafficking. The EU’s porous borders and unchecked travel in the Schengen area has led to the Calais crisis. Our own Prime Minister offers the French GBP 12 million of British taxpayers’ money to help alleviate the Calais crisis. Yet to do what? I have asked Mr Cameron the question, but I have received no reply to my letter of 17 January. I fear the lack of border controls will be responsible for the next ISIS attack, and on British soil, directly as a result of intervention in Libya, which is now lawless and is a fertile recruitment ground for exporting more terrorism caused by the West. The King of Jordan said in this place yesterday that the Middle East problem is a regional one and I agree with him. Let us hope you all do too.

name: Elmar Brok (PPE).
text: Madam President, High Representative and Vice-President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has This is one of the cases that causes a bit of helplessness in our place. There, as in other places, we now have violent groups that are not ready to negotiate because they consider everything that has a different opinion to be worthy of destruction. That is the drama of the situation. We have to see that those that have also been promoted are being promoted by other states, or in some cases, that the matter is becoming so difficult. I also believe that we should support Egypt a little bit here. I think the reaction in relation to coptic Christians is the right one. We should also see that this has a major impact on the refugee problem. Since 1 January, there have been 9 500 migrants who have tried to flee across the Mediterranean from Libya. That is 70% more than last year. We see the cold-heartedness of the smugglers forcing refugees onto the crumbling boats with Kalashnikovs. I believe that, in these areas, we may also need to move closer to the coast of failed states in order to prevent these smugglers from dealing with people in this way and thus bringing about new deaths. We all know that, of course, the issues of a ceasefire and the monitoring of infrastructure worthy of protection and so on also play a role. However, I believe that we should seek contact here and see that the issues of the wave of refugees and the drama of the survival of these people are at the centre of attention and that we must therefore also move closer to the coast in order to assume our responsibilities, as was done a few years ago. Perhaps we should remember to do so in order to protect refugees.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in the light of recent developments in Libya, opportunities to resolve the crisis peacefully can lead to positive developments, and that is why the ongoing political dialogue is important. Without a political agreement, it is difficult to imagine an effective response to the terrorist threat, which today is not only an imminent danger to the Libyan people, to the stability and unity of Libya itself, but has become a threat to the whole region. I would also like to remind the new strategist Buonanno that lifting the arms embargo would only help to intensify hostilities and not necessarily secure a military victory. Political dialogue remains the only possible solution and, indeed, it is important to assure the parties that the only genuine interest of the international community is to assist Libya in forming an independent and technocratic government of national unity, which is the only solution to the Libyan crisis and the institutional premise necessary for an effective response to terrorism and also to the issue of immigration.

name: Amjad Bashir (ECR).
text: – Madam President, Libya used to be one of the Arab world’s wealthiest countries. Nearly four years after the fall of the Gadaffi regime, the nation lies in ruins. A power struggle has torn the country apart, as rival groups viciously fight to gain control of Libya’s vast resources. The energy industry, which was supposed to be the cornerstone of Libya’s recovery and a success story of the Arab Spring, is on the brink of collapse. Oil revenue levels are critically low and could bankrupt the government. There are reports that up to 1 million migrants are ready to head towards Europe. This could cause a humanitarian disaster of unprecedented proportions. UN-brokered discussions surrounding a unity government is good news. Nevertheless, a lasting outcome will require concessions, patience and, most significantly, Libyan solutions to Libyan problems.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: – Last week, a group of Asian and European workers was kidnapped in Libya by terrorists, presumably from the Islamic State. They were guilty, above all, of working in this country. Moreover, two of them, Austrian and Czech, were guilty only of being members of Western civilization. Today we are faced with the abduction and murder of civilians not only in Libya. It is the result of the brutal bombing in 2011 that destroyed the brutal regime but also destroyed the state. Instead of effectively helping the Libyans to stability, peace, and rebuild, Western powers have used only brute force.  The result is chaos, growing social instability and a wave of refugees heading across the sea to the EU. Thus, abducted EU citizens reap the consequences for politicians who can think of nothing but smashing, destroying and killing. They lack any ability to bring stability and sustainable development to the country. Libya, Syria to Afghanistan, that's your calling card. I strongly urge you: instead of idle talk, let us finally do something here. While we're all talking, people are dying on the other side of the sea.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, to call the situation in Libya unstable is an understatement to say the least! The situation is complete and utter chaos with no foreseeable solutions and only dire consequences. Colonel Gaddafi richly deserved his fate, but the intervention of Britain and France was done without thought for the consequences. The West started out by supporting Gaddafi’s opponents, only to find that what replaced him is even more savage and barbaric. The moral of the story is that Britain should not get involved in military adventures unless it is clearly in our national interest, has a clearly identified military objective and there is some idea of what the outcome and the unforeseen consequences might be. Instead, we allowed ourselves to get sucked into a piece of EU foreign policy vanity that has unleashed a vision of hell in the shape of armed and unrestrained Islamic extremists who know no moral or humanitarian restraints.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, High Representative, although three years have passed since the fall of Gaddafi, Libya is a long way from stability: two opposing governments, dozens of rival tribes, militias and armed gangs. Total anarchy in a fratricidal struggle whose fate is difficult to predict. What makes this scenario more disturbing is the recent advance by ISIS, which is becoming the perpetrator of crimes against humanity that we have already witnessed in Syria and Iraq. Uncertainty on the part of the international community, poised between awareness and fear of action, is paradoxically fuelling extremists in the Mediterranean.  If the Government of Tobruk does not quickly find a compromise with the Tripoli government and if the West finds it difficult to provide a reliable response in a short time, we will end up handing over control of human trafficking to ISIS, and then we will be faced with the fusion of two phenomena that were once distinct: that of immigration and that of Islamism; an unacceptable explosive mixture that could endanger the safety of our citizens. We are meeting here to try to understand where Europe intends to be in this scenario and what role it intends to play in restoring a situation in Libya that is in line with the rule of law, and I ask you, Mr Solana, that the time has come to demonstrate the incisiveness of European diplomacy: we want to hear from you concrete measures and not a dialogue that remains an end in itself in this House. Please: concrete measures.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her There were times when you could perhaps say, what are conflicts that happen to me far from my homeland? This finding, which has always been inaccurate, is now more unnecessary than ever. The situation in Libya in particular shows this. It was only at the weekend that Daesh terrorists kidnapped assembly workers in the al-Ghanie oil field, including the Upper Austrian Dalibor S. His fate is uncertain. The people in my country are dismayed, as many people are doing at the moment, all over Europe. Stopping the terrorists requires all the effort of all of us. We can only defeat Daesh if we take uncompromising action against them, in Europe and in the countries where areas are under their control. That is why we must do everything we can to restore statehood in Libya, and we must not waste any time in doing so.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra (PPE).
text: – Madam President, we are in the presence of a failed State, of land conducive to the Daesh; that is why I support the efforts of my compatriot Bernardino León and Mrs Mogherini, which is why I support the achieve of a government of national unity. We have seen how the barbarity of the evil called Islamic State produces deaths, kidnappings, destruction of cultural heritage, mass displacement of population, flight from territories of danger. The Mediterranean. We will not be able to prevent them from leaving, Mrs Mogherini, what do you intend to do in the face of this eventuality? We need to provide a political, solidarity and joint solution; we must work with third States on development cooperation, humanitarian aid, migration and security policy.  We need to facilitate legal escape routes for those who need to save their lives. I am betting on a Community and solidarity resettlement, for a single area of asylum in Europe, in which we involve all the Member States in the same way and, above all, I hope that we will fight with determination against those who, using these criminal practices, do business with human life. I bet on the improvement of Europol, Eurojust, Frontex and EASO. For the implementation of its competences and budgets and for greater coordination throughout the territory of the Union.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE).
text: – Madam President, for almost a decade the Central Mediterranean has been one of the main routes of illegal entry of immigrants into the European Union and every year we see this number increasing for 2015.  It is also predicted that perhaps as many as half a million refugees, mainly from Libya, will arrive. Unfortunately, many of them could lose their lives as we saw it happen. Funding for rescue operations at sea is limited. Frontex has announced that it will not have enough financial and human capacity to deal with the situation. Therefore, you really need to focus on this problem and especially on the source of the problem.  Libya was torn today between the two centres, in Tripoli and Tobruk and with ISIL threatening to use the country as a training ground for attacks on Europe. Therefore, we need a political solution and for the EU to engage more and support the UN-led dialogue.  In this regard, I welcome the priorities presented here by the High Representative, but we also need to think now about a longer-term development solution that can only ensure long-term peace because poverty is a breeding ground for radicalism. And through development aid programmes, we need to ensure that institutions are building in Libya. That's the key. Unfortunately, the opportunity to do so immediately after Gaddafi's ousting from power was missed. But now we must not escape this responsibility of ours for the safety of Europe.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D).
text: – Irridu ntemmu l-instabilità li teżisti fil-Libja għaliex b'dan il-mod biss nistgħu nassiguraw stabilità fir-rejun tal-Mediterran u fl-Unjoni Ewropea kollha kemm hi. Għandna ntemmu din l-instabilità anke għal miljuni ta' persuni inno大enti fil-Libja li emmnu onestament li kien se jkollhom bidu ġdid tliet snin. Kif inhi s-sitwazzjoni bħalissa qed twassal biex ħafna persuni qed jippruvaw jaqsmu l-Mediterran u jekk il-pajjiżi li jħabbtu wi大大hom mal-problema tal-immigrazzjoni se jibqgħu jiġu injorati, il-Mediterran u l-Ewropa kollha kemm hi se jbatu riperkussjonijiet serji. Hawnhekk nipproponi t-twaqqif ta' task force diplomatika Ewropea li tikkunsidra kwalunkwe soluzzjoni possibbli, kwalunkwe sitwazzjoni potenzjali, filwaqt li tfassal pjan li jindirizza xenarji possibbli. Din it-task force għandha twieġeb lilek, Viikei President Federica Mogherini. Għandu jkollna miżuri preventivi li ja大大ertaw li s-sitwazzjoni kurrenti i tmurx għall-agħar, anzi tistabilizza ruħha bi ppjanar u impennna serju. Għandna ngħinu u nħeġġu biex fil-Libja jkun hemm gvern ta' unità nazzjonali. Is-sitwazzjoni fil-Libja u fil-Mediterran i tistax tibqa' tiġi injorata għal aktar żmien.

name: Monika Hohlmeier (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Thank you very much for allowing me to speak. At the moment, we cannot assess the situation in Libya and in terms of what awaits us from when the winter storms on the Mediterranean are over. Many people do not voluntarily travel to us in broken boats, but are now sometimes forced to board these boats. That is why I am asking the very specific question: what specific measures do you envision to prevent thousands of people from being killed from spring onwards because they will not reach the coasts of the European Union? How can we prevent the boats from departing and trying to reach an agreement to take orderly measures, including repatriation measures, and, where possible, to launch a range of measures to prevent mass deaths?

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the situation in Libya must lead us all to the conclusion that armed interventions by foreign forces in third countries usually lead to chaos. Libya has already been dismantled in practice. Various forces and tribes collide with the aim of their prevalence. Arms and people smuggling is on the ups and downs. At the same time, the jihadists are advancing in order to join Boko Haram.  The state of chaos in Libya has caused huge waves of refugees to the European Union. The challenges now for the European Union are enormous and can only be addressed in a peaceful way. That is why we must support the negotiations in the region in order to resolve the acute problems peacefully.  What is the role of Turkey and Qatar in Libya? Do they fund the jihadists, yes or no? And what measures is the European Union going to take against these countries? Because once again, as in Syria, relations between Turkey and the jihadists are particularly close.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: Madam President, Dear Madam Commissioner, I am not a man who is apocalyptic and pessimistic. I'm very optimistic by nature. But in this particular case, it's like time's up. I'm afraid that these three years when we all hoped, after what happened three years ago and the revolution, that the Libyan people would take their rich country into their own hands and create a prosperous country. Today it really is all, clearly, missed.  Therefore, I support your especially ambition to create a government of national unity because obviously this is the only solution so that these criminals who ravage and kill people, innocent people and innocent victims can became violent and create great problems in all the countries in which they perform. I particularly underline your ambition to speak to local and regional authorities. Some experience I have on this issue and I think it's also a good part of your strategy.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D).
text: – Madam President, can I start by thanking our High Representative, Federica Mogherini, for the excellent work that she is doing. I think it is important for us to understand that the European Union does have a critical role to play on the world stage and it is good to see that, under her leadership, we are getting better and better at this.  A number of my colleagues have touched on the difficulties that we are facing in Libya and the dangers that we expose ourselves to in this. We need to make sure that we do actually work towards finding a resolution. I know that a lot of good points have been covered and I just want to say three things that we need to be looking at. The first is that, with the breakdown of the state government in Libya, there are ordinary civilian people who are actually suffering; there is a shortage of food, shortage of medicines, etc., so we need to help them on that front. We also need to work on the idea of non-interference from other states, and we need to work for reconciliation and for a national unity government.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: VPC/HR. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, allow me to reply in Italian. I have to say that I agree with what one of you said: using the term 'unstable situation' for Libya is an understatement. Just as it is an understatement to refer to a failed state: we are simply not dealing with a state. And that is the main problem we face. In addition, there is the crux of the complexity of the problems that are intertwined on the Libyan stage, they really do, probably, as many of you have said and as I said at the beginning, one of the crises if not the most potentially dangerous and dramatic crisis that we have around us. There are many problems and levels of problems and complexities that are intertwined: on the one hand, those relating to security, not only of Libyan territory, where we see not only a greater presence of terrorist organisations and groups, but also a real use of Daesh franchising on organizations or groups or militias that previously exist, but also a link with other crises, those to the south, for example with Boko Haram, which has been mentioned, but also with the crisis in Syria and Iraq and the return or arrival on Libyan territory of foreign fighters from other scenarios of conflict, with potentially devastating consequences for neighbouring countries: think of Tunisia, one of the countries that we call , quite rightly, a success story of democratic transitions in the region, which must be subjected to terrifying pressure at its borders, both in terms of security and immigration. So problems in terms of security, in terms of immigration and trafficking in human beings, in terms of controlling both the energy and financial resources of a potentially rich country, which would not need, as it did not need in the past, to count on international support, but clearly under these conditions the population extremely affected by a very dramatic humanitarian situation – and here too the European Union is doing a great deal and is ready to do more – and the further level of consequences for neighbouring countries, From Tunisia, but also Egypt, Algeria and the European Union itself, as well as the neighbouring countries to the south – think of the whole of the south Saharan area – consequences not only in terms of security and immigration but also consequences in terms of regional political dynamics , because we know very well that one of the main problems we face is not only the total collapse of Libya, not only a potential division of the country, but also the risk of a proxy war over Libya and Libya, by other regional powers or, so to speak, the enlarged region. That is why it is very clear to all Libyans – and I hope it is clear to all of us – that there is no military option to deal with what is happening in Libya and anyone who can be tempted by the 'There is a crisis, let us intervene' approach would not come to terms with the complexity I have just mentioned, with very large territory and with a very complex social structure, as well as with the absence of state structures. Such a complex problem is not answered with the illusion of magical answers: there is no magic wand for this crisis, just as there is unfortunately no magic wand for many crises, but for this one even less than others: there is no military option – the Libyans know this very well and I believe that we should know very well too. This does not mean that the European Union is not interested or that it does not also have the main responsibility for preparing concrete actions, which have been asked of me – I am sorry that the member who made the request to me today is no longer here at the moment; I hope that my words can be reported to you, but you obviously did not listen to what I said at the beginning: well, the European Union is doing concrete actions, indeed I have to say that we are among the main supporters, not only supporters but builders of the concrete actions that are on the ground today for Libya: for example, dialogue. In relation to the political process under way in Rabat, it is true that there are setbacks, but in such a difficult process we cannot give in to setbacks: we must insist on the need to move forward. The dialogue in Tripoli, the dialogue in Morocco, the dialogue between Tobruk and Tripoli and Misurata – and I can confirm to Mr Bonanno that I was in Tripoli exactly four months ago and some of those parliamentarians from Tobruk I met them in Tripoli engaged in dialogue, just as there were parliamentary women on the other side too: it is a dimension that some people asked to strengthen that I think is useful. On the other hand, it was the women of Misurata who encouraged their men to sit at the table of dialogue, because they were tired of a conflict that is depriving them of resources and human lives. Dialogue with the Libyans, therefore, dialogue with the UN – two or three days ago with Ban Ki-moon we talked about the situation in Libya – dialogue with the Arab League and with the regional players: I recalled that we discussed this with the Secretary-General of the League last time this morning and we will talk to the Egyptian Foreign Minister as soon as we finish this long plenary session. But building European actions also means working on options that can be ready at the right time, right actions to be carried out at the right time. Getting things wrong in this crisis can be fatal, as I believe has been demonstrated in recent months and years very clearly. This means preparing, for example, not only border control, but also preparing for the rational and human rights-respecting management of migratory flows and asylum seekers, together with the UNHCR; it also means starting to prepare measures for the protection of the country's basic infrastructure, starting with the buildings of a future government but also the communication and road link infrastructure to airports; it means working on measures to monitor a ceasefire when it is in place. Libyans are well aware that the European Union is working constantly these days and weeks, not only on the channel of dialogue, but also on the concrete instruments that we will make available to a future government of national unity to ensure that that government of national unity – and not external military intervention – has the means to meet the security challenges , the reconstruction of the country and the management of the migratory flows that Libya will have to face. The other challenge, which some have mentioned, is not only to put these options into practice, not only to implement them so that they are ready to use at the right time, but also to achieve them in the unity between our 28 Member States that any decision in this regard requires and will require.  So, of course, this is not an easy process, but I believe that the seriousness and drama of the situation puts us – and all our 28 Member States – in front of us with a responsibility and an urgency from which we can hardly escape. This means being ready together, at 28, to take these decisions if and when they are necessary and also to develop together, at 28, greater solidarity in reception. This is one of the issues that we have begun to address, as I said, with the Commission, which the Interior Ministers are currently addressing in the Council and which the Foreign Ministers will address on the issues for which they are responsible next Monday. I was asked what we are actually doing about the Khartoum process: the Khartoum process was only initiated at the end of November by the Italian Presidency in Rome – I was present at that meeting – and it is a process that can give us many instruments: three months is not enough to ask for an account of what has been done today, but what is on the table is basically greater cooperation with the countries of the Khartoum process. , not only in the management of borders, but also in the rational and respectful management of human rights – I repeat – of migratory flows and joint work to develop the capacities of these countries to face what is a challenge first and foremost for them. I think I have answered most of the questions that have been raised. I will end with a comment: at the moment, we are rightly focusing on the urgent need to meet a challenge in terms of security and human rights and the risk of implosion in a large and important country close to the European Union. We would be mistaken if, among the concrete actions that we are preparing these days, we did not also include the strength of any element of European Union support for any of our partners, namely institution building. Here we are faced with the absence of a successful process of setting up the institutions; this is what has been lacking in recent years and this must be the european Union's first strong engagement point in a partnership with the Libyan authorities in the future.  The key point will be this: Libya is not weak economically; Libya has enormous capabilities: what the European Union can do, over and above its commitments to security and the management of migratory flows, over and above the commitment to border control, over and above the commitment to a constructive and non-destructive regional dynamic, is support for institution building. We will never, in the long term, overcome libya's challenge if we do not work on building democratic institutions, responsible for the whole of Libyan territory and responsible for managing the lives of all Libyans, in regardless of whether they are from Tobruk, Tripoli, Misurata or elsewhere.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The debate is over. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. In Libya, chaos reigns. Christians are being massacred by the local ISIS affiliate, four Filipino nurses have recently been kidnapped and the sending of coalition soldiers to the field is under consideration. These tragic events demonstrate once again that the overthrow of Colonel Gaddafi, far from bringing democratic values and respect for human rights to Libya, has in fact plunged the country into a real civil and tribal war that fuels the desires of jihadist Islamists. That is why the West must learn all the lessons and re-establish diplomatic relations with Bashar al-Assad to prevent Libyan chaos from being exported to Syria.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. – A few thousand km from the Italian coast we are facing a situation, the Libyan situation that is completely out of control and that seriously threatens the entire north shore of the Mediterranean due to the advance of ISIS. I insist that libya's establishment be seen as a European priority and that the entire international community should at the moment strengthen its commitment to an immediate solution.  Further delays will have no further consequences other than to put international security at serious risk. I encourage the High Representative to call for and coordinate joint action by the 28 Member States with the aim of strengthening common defence and security, and by recognising the legitimacy of the Government of Tobruk, acting to achieve the unity of the Libyan factions currently fighting.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. With the fall of Colonel Khadafi in 2011, Libya seemed to be reborn from the ashes. For the first time, free elections were held and the people would be able to express themselves freely. But this was without counting on the legacy left by the country's tribal organization, wanted and established by Khadafi, since his coup d'état of September 1969.  Today, the country is mired in total government instability. Tripoli in the north and Tobrouck in the east are vying for power. If Tripoli is under the influence of the Muslim Brotherhood, Tobrouck is a moderate city. Beyond the clash between religious and secularists, Libya is torn between the new elites who recognize themselves in the power of Tobrouck and the elders who swear by a power emanating from Tripoli.  Libya's geographical location is unique. Tripoli is much closer to Rome than Cairo. A question then arises: don't jihadists take advantage of these nut shells to install bridgeheads on the island of Lampedusa? I call on the European Commission here to finally have an official European position on Libyan news and remind us that, behind our European fears, there is also and above all a distress of the Libyan inhabitants.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: We will now continue the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy: The Mali Peace Agreement (2015/2593(RSP)).

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, on behalf of the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy/Vice-President of the Commission, I am very glad that Parliament still has a keen interest in the situation in Mali, as the European Union has deployed considerable efforts in support of peace, democracy and development in the country over the years. We are all saddened by the recent attack in Bamako on 7 March which cost the lives of several people, including a Belgian security officer in the EU Delegation. There is a real risk that increased terrorist activity will derail the political process which is currently at a turning point. All should join efforts to make sure that this will not happen. The United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (MINUSMA) in particular should be given the appropriate means to accomplish its mandate. The EU condemns the continuous attacks against the UN forces, such as recently in Kidal on 8 March. As you know, the EU contributed to reaching a peace agreement in Algiers on 1 March. It acted as co-mediator together with the United Nations, the African Union, the Organization of the Islamic Conference, the Economic Community of West African States and five neighbouring countries.  The European Union Special Representative was personally involved in the talks. It required substantial efforts to reach a compromise between the parties, respecting the unity and integrity of Mali.  The Accord foresees further devolution of economic competencies and resources to local authorities and the creation of local police forces. Regions should be better represented in the central institutions. The Malian army will be reformed to integrate ex-rebels in its ranks and will then be progressively redeployed over all the territory under UN MINUSMA supervision.  The immediate challenge for us is to obtain endorsement of the agreement by the Coordination. The Eureopan External Action Service is currently taking part in a joint mission on the ground to support this process and to convince the different stakeholders that there is no other credible alternative.  It is now important for the Government to demonstrate its commitment to the agreement by taking swiftly some of the actions it has undertaken to deliver. The EU will play its role in making sure progress is indeed achieved. Beyond this immediate action of the mediation, resources will have to be mobilised to accompany the process through reconciliation and a re-foundation of Mali. Our 11th European Development Fund National Indicative Programme has just been signed on 6 March in Brussels and would contribute significantly to this endeavour, but implementation will depend partly on the speed with which the government meets its obligations.  Other tools within the comprehensive approach and in synergy with Member States and other international actors could also be mobilised as well. But of course, security remains a pre-condition for any humanitarian or development action. The UN mission – MINUSMA – as already mentioned, has a crucial role to play. The EU should support it in its efforts and make sure it is given proper means to accomplish its mandate. To this end, the EU will have to assess how the EU Training Mission and European Union CSDP Mission in Sahel Mali, can work with MINUSMA on the disarmament, demobilisation, and reintegration and security sector reform processes of security forces, both civilian and military, as foreseen in the agreement.  These EU missions are already providing advice and training contributing to the reform of the security sector. In the longer run, efforts have to be pursued in the regional context through the implementation of the EU Sahel Strategy for security which was adopted in 2011. The adoption still this week of a Sahel Regional Action Plan will indicate additional actions to support the strategy in the years ahead. I thank you very much and look forward to a fruitful debate.

name: Davor Ivo Stier
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. – Madam President, at the outset I would like to express my condolences to the family of the fallen employee of the European Union Delegation in Mali, Ronnyi Piens from Belgium, the victim of a terrorist attack in Bamako. Continuous violence in the northern part of Mali has become a brake on the development of the entire country, but also a threat to the security of development of the wider Sahel region.  This recent act of violence in Mali, including the death of European Union nationals, is unfortunately just one of many examples of violence and human rights violations. All parties to the conflict have committed serious human rights violations, including violations of the right to life, enforced disappearances, torture, sexual violence, arrests.  Recently in Brussels we met a delegation from Mali who told us that there is no peace without development or development without peace, and that is why I join the call of the High Representative and Commissioner Mimica to all parties to the conflict to start a constructive dialogue and to sign a peace agreement in Algeria as soon as possible and to embark on a path of reconciliation, reconstruction and development.  A peace agreement is a fundamental precondition, but long-term stability and growth can only be achieved through reconciliation and eradication of extreme poverty. The people of Mali really need EU solidarity to ensure a dignified life through sustainable development.  Development cooperation between Mali and the EU was renewed in 2013 after the government showed a willingness for political dialogue, and it is now important that all sides show seriousness in reaching a peace agreement and that Mali returns to the path of stability and sustainable development.

name: Ana Gomes
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, the peace agreement is essential to ensure control of the entire territory of Mali and to prevent the expansion of the terrorist threat in the north of the country, which feeds and feeds into the conflict between rebel forces and those loyal to Bamako. The terrorist threat that, in recent days, has struck miserably, claiming the lives of children, civilians, MINUSMA peacekeepers and a security official of the European delegation.  It is necessary that all the parties are represented in this peace agreement, including the Tureg community, and it is positive that the agreement organizes the transfer of autonomy to the north of the country and the strengthening of the representation of the northern communities in national institutions.  The political solution to ending the armed conflict in Mali must be based on an inclusive plan, representative of the diversity of society, so that it is sustainable and restores peace to the country. Mali's security is essential for the pacification of the entire Sahel and for the eradication of the terrorist threat in the region, where it finds fertile ground for the violent insuprising and proliferation of organized crime that gives it financial support, such as arms and drug trafficking.  Nothing will work if the peace plan and European action in Mali do not integrate a regional perspective, taking into account the links to crises in the Central African Republic, Libya and Nigeria. And finally, nothing will work without European support for good governance and institutional capacity building and development in Mali.

name: Michèle Rivasi
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, what I wanted to tell you is that, within the framework of the ACP, we received a Malian delegation of imams a fortnight ago. And their cry of alarm was: "Help us, because there are more and more jihadists with Kalashnikovs coming into mosques". Therefore, it is true that their first concern is safety. But not only that. It is also the development of their country and, in particular, of all this part called the Sawâd. This peace and reconciliation agreement is an opportunity for us that we strongly support. But you have seen that there are a whole series of associations that first ask for public consultation before it is ratified. This means that the European Union, as you said, must really support Minusma, but at the same time we need an action plan to give this population a future. There is no more public service. There is nothing left in those areas. If the European Union does not devote all its energy and financial resources to public services, I do not see how the population can accept the fact that there are still movements with Kalashnikovs that threaten the population. It is therefore urgent that the European Union becomes more involved.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – I have listened with interest to the EU's efforts to support the peace process in Mali. In my opinion, this is extremely important, it has already been said here.  It is possible to stabilize the country's circumstances if the cessation of hostilities agreement between the Malian government and the Tuaregs moves further into a more stable peace agreement. It is the EU that can help, both by pressusing the Tuaregs and by pressuding the Malian government. We have seen in recent years that there has always been an attempt to conclude a kind of ceasefire agreement, and that attempt has failed. He also failed because the government in Mali was unwilling to respect a certain degree of autonomy or self-government for the Tuaregs.  Only this stable agreement can lead to Islamic fundamentalism and the attacks we condemn being suppressed and Islamists in Mali not increasing. I consider this to be extremely important, and I also condemn the attacks, where, unfortunately, EU citizens were also victims.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I greatly deplore the violent terrorist attacks last weekend that should not disrupt the efforts for peace in Mali.  The peace agreement between the government of Bamako and the Tuareg rebels in Mali could effectively revive an area that has been devastated by civil war. This agreement presents a concept of decentralisation of powers that has proven effective. Greater autonomy is the key to reducing tensions in the region. The clauses in the prospective agreements, such as the one that transfers 30% of Bamako administration revenues to local entities, are much needed elements in the peace agreement and need to be encouraged. The proposal of creating powerful elected regional assemblies led by a directly elected president should be fast implemented, and the request for a greater representation of the northern populations in national institutions has to be fulfilled. I truly believe that this agreement is a crucial step for the stability of Mali; a victory for reconstruction and the reconciliation of the area. As stated by the agreement, the reconciliation of Mali must: ‘respect its territorial integrity and take account of its ethnic and cultural diversity’. I also believe that this demonstrates the possibilities for success by European diplomacy, and could become a model for the other conflicts in the region. Algerian leadership in these negotiations has to be praised as well. I encourage all stakeholders to sign it. The people of Mali have been troubled enough. They deserve peace.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the news of a peace agreement for the people of Mali is certainly good news, but we must admit that there are aspects that continue to concern us and that do not allow us to call it a full success. First of all, the agreement has not yet been signed by the rebels in the North and then the rebels in the negotiations do not represent all the people in the regions concerned. Not all northerners feel represented by Tuareg separatists. Young Malians have expressed their frustration with groups that persist in speaking on behalf of the entire population but from which they do not feel represented. The viral campaign they launched on social media garnered thousands of endorsements but it seems their voice has not been heard. Last weekend's terrorist attacks testify to ISIS' presence in the territory. It is therefore all very well to rejoice today, but with the knowledge that peace and reconciliation are still a long way off.

name: Boris Zala (S&D).
text: – Madam President, this agreement is of crucial importance, not only for the future of Mali, but also for European security and our counter—terrorism efforts in Western Africa. It is still unclear whether the preliminary agreement between the central government and the Tuareg rebels will translate into a lasting political settlement. A durable peace agreement is absolutely vital and the EU must do its utmost to assist Algeria and other international mediators to secure it. France was right, in 2012, to send in the military to drive the Islamists out of northern Mali. The EU is also doing commendable work through its training mission in the country. Let us hope that Mali will be a positive example in this regard.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the signing of the preliminary agreement to end the conflict with the rebels in Mali is an important development. Indeed, the provision for the creation of regional assemblies elected by direct universal suffrage with significant powers will undoubtedly contribute to democratisation in Mali and to reducing tensions.  But Mali cannot solve its financial problems while it is overcharging foreign lenders. That is why this country's debt to foreign lenders should be written off. At the same time, all war crimes, such as genocide and human rights violations during the conflict, should be considered.  Finally, the European Union must provide the necessary assistance to support the development of Mali, because that is the only way to limit the action and influence of jihadists in the region and terrorist attacks.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, just today in Kidal, a large assembly of Tuareg armed groups in the north began to assess the proposed peace agreement supported by the Malian Government, its neighbours and the international community, including us as the European Union. Among the points raised by the agreement is the Regional Assembly, as has been mentioned by some of my fellow Members, with concrete powers, decentralisation to local self-government and the granting of a large part of the powers to communities.  Nor should we delude ourselves, not least because a large part of civil society is still excluded from this process, including the younger Malian generations. We must use our influence to ensure that they too are part of an agreement that must be everyone's agreement.  We cannot afford another deflagration if we do not want Mali to become another Syria, yet another unsolvable crisis and a breeding ground for the ambitions of extremist groups.

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, this debate has again demonstrated that security and development must go hand in hand. There is no one result without the other. The EU, together with the international community, is determined to pursue joined-up thinking to translate into reality the peace agreement and monitor its implementation. It is the best text possible that could be adapted in the current context and there is no alternative.  We will work towards full confluence and complementarity of our actions, including CSDP instruments as part of our comprehensive approach. In fact, the EU has real added value in this process and is trusted by all sides. However, expectations are extremely high and the EU should not disappoint knowing that all remains to be done and depends first of all on the Malians themselves in a complex regional environment. I would also like to underline that the EU has already developed a number of projects for the return of the administration in the northern regions through the instrument contributing to stability. Construction and planning of infrastructures, for example the road to Timbuktu and Bourem—Kidal for the North-South axis has already begun and it is only a matter of time for resuming work.  Finally the EU will make available to the government already this year a substantial amount of budget support through a new state building contract. I would like to thank you for this debate and we hope and count on the continued support of the European Parliament for our policy in the Sahel.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. – I welcome the initialling of the Mali Peace Agreement, which ended months of negotiations with crucial mediation between Algeria and other international actors and organisations, the European Union, the United Nations, the African Union, and the Economic Community of West African countries and several neighbouring countries. The agreement reached is a significant step towards establishing lasting peace in Mali while respecting its unity, integrity and territorial sovereignty. I believe that all parties to the proceedings will seek to respect the compromise solution reached for the benefit of the people of Mali and to reach a lasting solution to the conflict. It is important that the European Union, in cooperation with other international actors, monitors the process of implementing the agreed agreement, as security and peace in Mali poses a strategic challenge for Africa and Europe. The EUCAP Sahel Mali civilian mission launched in January this year plays an important role in the European Union's regional approach to the security and development of the Sahel. In the context of security breaches, as evidenced by the latest assassination in Bamako, which also killed several European citizens, it is important to assist Mali's institutions in implementing the necessary reforms in the internal security segment. Security is an indispensable precondition for all other activities that the international community wants to launch in the domain of reconstruction and development of Mali.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on relations between the EU and the League of Arab States and cooperation in countering terrorism.

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council, Vice—President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I am speaking again on behalf of the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. I am very glad to address the European Parliament on the relations between the European Union and the League of Arab States (LAS) including cooperation in countering terrorism. Since the upheavals started in 2011, the Arab world has gone through a wave of political changes, some of which have resulted in democratic processes, and a number of which have, for the time being at least, led to outright conflict. Still others have seen revolution overturned and some have seen no change. This has transformed the geopolitical landscape.  Today, on its south-eastern and southern flanks, the EU is facing an arc of conflicts and crises – from Iraq, Syria and an unresolved Middle East conflict, to Libya and the Sahel, with spillover effects throughout the region. Co—operation with our partners in the Arab world is essential if we are to address the regional challenges and threats which they and we face. Security threats, of course, include jihadist terrorism and transnational crime.  There are humanitarian challenges, including the catastrophe of millions of refugees and displaced persons on our doorstep, and social and economic development challenges need to be addressed – especially the lack of employment and opportunities for youth.  We are ready to assist with the effort in meeting these challenges both bilaterally and at a regional level. In this demanding context, the League of Arab States is a vital partner for the EU. It has legitimacy as the only pan-regional organisation bringing together all Arab countries. If its crisis management capabilities are properly reinforced – and with the political willingness of its Member States – it will contribute to tackling the challenges that were just mentioned.  It reinforces Arab co-ownership therefore facilitating the implementation of EU policies in the region. I firmly believe that there is untapped potential in our relationship with the League, which is in our interest to reinforce.  So it is clear ‘why’ we engage.  Now let me give an overview of ‘how’ we engage. The EU and the League of Arab States have indeed strengthened our relationship recently. Less than two months ago, the Secretary—General of the League of Arab States, Dr Nabil Elaraby, visited Brussels and we co-signed a memorandum of understanding on co-operation between our organisations. Dr Elaraby also addressed EU Foreign Ministers and this Parliament. In all these meetings, he stressed the need for stronger Euro-Arab co—operation and made clear his support in the fight against terrorism.  In June last year, a successful EU-LAS Foreign Affairs ministerial meeting was held in Athens. Almost 50 Foreign Ministers agreed to launch an unprecedented Strategic Dialogue as a platform for exchange on political and security matters (including crisis management, humanitarian assistance, counter-terrorism, the fight against organised crime and weapons of mass destruction).  Beyond dialogue, the aim is to tackle these various issues through operational engagement with both the League Secretariat and LAS Member States. Counter-terrorism is a particular priority for the EU at the present time. The Council conclusions adopted last month gave us a mandate to tackle terrorism at regional level, engaging with organisations such as the LAS. As I said before, the League is also committed to addressing this threat. The Arab Foreign Ministers have in fact been discussing terrorism this week.  In this context, we are exploring some concrete initiatives in the counter-terrorism field. A project on countering radicalisation and foreign fighters will be launched soon for the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region. We would also like to work on capacity-building measures in the fields of law enforcement, criminal justice, security sector reform, paying due regard to international human rights standards, in close co—operation with Europol, Eurojust, Frontex and CEPOL, and to address the ‘foreign fighters’ phenomenon, as agreed at the Athens meeting.  A concrete, positive example of how we can engage to jointly tackle common threats is the EU-funded crisis room in the League’s headquarters. This is an ongoing project which aims to build up a pan-Arab early warning mechanism to deal with catastrophes and crises. Our co-operation is not limited to political and security matters. Since 2012 we have a joint work program of co-operation in various fields, from human rights to energy, and other activities are being planned.  I would like to focus now on how the EU and the LAS work together on human rights. Since 2012, the EU and the LAS have identified common priorities, developed a number of initiatives, and engaged regularly including with the Arab Human Rights Charter Committee and the Arab National Human Rights Institutions. The Council of Europe has also been involved in some of this work. Key topics have included women’s empowerment, promotion and protection of human rights in line with international standards, engagement with civil society and co-operation on election observation. The EU is committed to ensuring that human rights are mainstreamed in our activities across the board. It is particularly important that we do so in the context of counter-terrorism. It is also important that we engage in cultural dialogue. Last April, for example, we organised a dialogue in Cairo on ‘co—existence and acceptance of the other’ and next month we will have a dialogue in Brussels on ‘freedom of expression and freedom of association and assembly’.

name: Tunne Kelam
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, may I welcome on behalf of the PPE Group the perspective of possible EU-Arab cooperation in the fight against terrorism. The Memorandum of Understanding signed in January may look like a modest start, but has immense positive potential. It could well become the start of the EU-League of Arab States strategic dialogue.  It is clear that to defeat ISIS it is mandatory to have all countries of the region on board, each making an active contribution. It is necessary to jointly identify challenges, shared goals and possibilities for common actions to counter the terrorist expansion. King Abdullah expressed it very well yesterday, that this fight has to be carried out by Muslim countries first and foremost. It is crucial to take jointly and exchange information on sources and means of terrorist financing. Also a joint mechanism to control the illegal arms trade and cut the roots of jihadist volunteers will have significant practical value.  It is clear that in fighting terrorism the fundamental rights of people have to be safeguarded. Better protection of human rights by our Arab partners would help to develop the culture of tolerance and inclusion in the region. Arab-EU cooperation should be used to better protect terrorist-targeted religious and cultural minorities of the Middle East and will certainly help to implement King Abdullahʼs declaration that Christians form an integral part of the Arab past, as well as its future.

name: Knut Fleckenstein
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, Minister, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Yesterday, in his impressive speech, the Jordanian King reminded us that the fight against terrorism in the name of Islam is primarily the task of the Muslim states. But since terrorism is a global problem, it can only be solved globally, that is, with each other. And it is only with shared strength that we can really achieve this. In order to develop precisely this strength, the Memorandum of Understanding for enhanced cooperation between the Arab League and the European Union has been concluded. We very much welcome improved cooperation between the Arab League and us, not only but also in terms of counter-terrorism measures. There are many areas in which we can only achieve something together. We need to cooperate better, especially on early warning systems and crisis prevention. The Internet, and especially social networks, facilitate cross-border contacts and enable the dissemination of propaganda without a physical basis. This challenge can only be answered internationally. The phenomenon of foreign fighters or travelling fighters can only be tackled together with the states that are targets for these fighters. This is both about the fight against terror and about strategies for helping dropouts and reintegrating them into society. We welcome the fact that there are already many, very different initiatives across Europe that stand up against extremism and tolerance. Terrorism in the name of Islam is a serious threat, in the EU and in the Arab states. We can only successfully combat this threat together with Muslim communities in the EU and Muslim states outside the EU. This common ground is also needed to ensure that the fight against terrorism is not misused to incite Islam. Each side has its own tasks to consider at home. For us, it also means how important it is that we do not use it in the prosecution of criminals, but that we avoid radicalisation in the first place. For the Arab states, this means, much better than before, to prevent the supply of arms to terrorist organisations and the financing of terrorism from these countries themselves. It also means guaranteeing human rights.

name: Charles Tannock
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, with the rise of ISIS in Syria and Iraq, and Islamist terrorist attacks occurring in Europe, cooperation with our allies in the Gulf and the wider Arab world is more important today than ever in combating international terrorism. The Arab League can do much to stem the causes of jihadi terrorism at the roots. A more proactive approach in restricting the funding activities of certain religious charities that are in fact financing terrorism, restricting the travel of known terrorists, and ceasing the promotion of Wahhabi Salafism across the globe are just three examples.  This House was addressed yesterday by the King of Jordan discussing the key role that his country is playing in the air campaign against ISIS. Along with countries such as Egypt, Jordan is a great example in the region of what genuine military cooperation can look like. Tunisia is also a good example and success story of what democracy can mean for the Arab Spring. Finally, more also must be done to pressure those GCC states, notably Qatar, that are funding and equipping directly or indirectly international jihadi terrorism.

name: Marietje Schaake
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, to counter the horrific terrorist acts by ISIS and others, it is key that countries that see high numbers of victims of terrorism, as well as large numbers of perpetrators, are actively engaged in fighting back. As the King of Jordan said yesterday, the fight that is witnessed between terrorists and those who want to defend pluralism is a fight within Islam. It is important that countries of the Arab region take responsibility. Cooperation between the EU and Arab League states on counter-terrorism is welcome, yet clarification is needed. We call on the publication of the Memorandum of Understanding so that there is full transparency and we can see what is agreed. It is unfortunate that the press release by the External Action Service did not mention the importance of respecting human rights while cooperating on fighting terrorism; because in this House we have repeatedly been asked and forced to call for the respect for human rights, notably after the Arab uprisings, as they are often violated, precisely in the member states of the Arab League, severely and systematically. This kind of repression is too often legitimised by arguments of national security or by invoking counter-terrorism and the EU cannot and should not, directly or indirectly, be a part of legitimising repression in the name of counter-terrorism – not the repression of those that act entirely in line with their universal human rights. Sadly, from Bahrain to Egypt, from Saudi Arabia to Turkey, from Qatar to Sudan, we see this kind of repression. I think that we should take the lead in ensuring that security and freedom are integrally related and the EU must not be tempted by any short-term perspectives on interests while forgetting about the fundamental values upon which we base ourselves.

name: Cornelia Ernst
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her So this is about security cooperation. That as such is not a bad thing. With the Arab League, which – and here we are faced with the problem – includes relevant states in which state terrorism and human rights violations are, in a sense, the daily bread. Let me tell you quite frankly: security cooperation, which is ultimately negotiated with such undemocratic despots, does not belong. And do you really believe that, because of a few lacklustre and almost naive points on human rights in the resolution, even an Egyptian policeman will stop flouting human rights? Are our security partners really states like Bahrain, where internet activists are sent to prison for a single tweet? Is Saudi Arabia our confidant, even though people there are being publicly whipped and beheaded? And then this memorandum is not even really public. So, I have to tell you quite honestly that this is not security cooperation, but complicity. After all, we also sell weapons and surveillance instruments to our partners. And human rights are a side issue here. What is really at stake is state resonance according to the motto "Whoever wears uniform, you can trust a priori".

name: Alyn Smith
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I think the Chamber has genuinely done a good piece of work on this resolution. I would explicitly praise Mrs Schaake for the work she has done in coordinating the different groups in its production, because this is a solid resolution that we have before us, where it could have been the blankest of blank cheques and the most mixed of mixed signals, because there were enough people trying to make it so. The subject is too serious for petty politics. The fight against terrorism and the cooperation of the EU with the League of Arab States, as outlined in the Memorandum of Understanding, is a serious subject that deserves to be taken as seriously as indeed we have done, except that the Memorandum has not been published. This surely sends the worst possible signal to our partner countries within the region. Within the resolution, in Recital D, we highlight that fact and in point 3 we explicitly call for its publication. There is cross-party support for that. I would be grateful for an explicit reaction to that call this evening. More widely, it is not a toothless resolution either. In Recital I, we refuse to turn a blind eye to the shortcomings of our partners in that there are serious and systematic violations of human rights in member countries of the Arab League states, because we cannot turn a blind eye to their failings. We also, in point 5, state that the solution to radicalisation is not simply military. The roots are far more complex than that, and any solution must be multifaceted and much more sophisticated in nature. In point 9 we explicitly say that counter-terrorism measures may never be abused to repress legitimate dissent. That again is a nod to the practices of some of our partner countries. In point 11 we stress the importance of cooperation between the EU and the League in the field of human rights because there are things to build on. We must do that by example. The regimes in charge of the Middle East and North Africa are indeed important partners and we do indeed need to deal with them. We do have a common aim. As we say in point 2 of the resolution, terrorism poses a direct threat to all countries and all people, regardless of their ethnic background, but our duty is to our values and to the people of the region, not necessarily the regimes in charge.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this memorandum is undoubtedly an important first step, as we have rightly emphasised with my fellow Members in the resolution, whom I would also like to thank for their excellent work. Unfortunately, many points are still entirely programmatic, with practical consequences still to be evaluated. There is very little legally binding, despite the enormous challenges to be faced, not only against terrorist groups but against the now genuine franchises of terrorism. I repeat our firm rejection of the rhetoric of the clash of civilisations and, even more so, of religion. We need the help of all the Muslim communities in Europe to isolate extremism and to avoid – and in this respect the role of arab states can and must be fundamental, as the King of Jordan told us yesterday – that we end up with this kind of argument, with political but also cultural instruments. However, we also need a total and concrete commitment on the part of all the Member States of the Arab League not only to refrain from all forms of proxy war, but also to actively pursue those who, even as a private citizen, help to finance directly or indirectly the geopolitical conflict between the Sunni world and the Shiite world with various proxy wars.  No fear of naming names or harshly penalising those who play with the fate of millions of people: if there is no sincerity, this memorandum will remain only a fine declaration of intent and that is precisely why we cannot forget, because cooperation does not mean forgetting.  That is why I will continue – and with me, I hope, many other colleagues together, I am sure – to relaunch the protection of human rights and the need to abolish the death penalty: always vigilant, accomplices never.

name: Mario Borghezio (NI).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the debate has rightly emphasised that the most important issue – even though High Representative Mogherini has focused mainly on the issue of human rights – is the most serious and urgent effective cooperation in the fight against terrorism. It seems clear to me that the adoption of the memorandum of 19 January and also the events that have followed do not give us any hope of concrete results, because the position of two contractors – on the one hand the Arab League and on the other that of the European Union – is that of two entities that make words and not deeds. As far as the European Union is concerned, tell me what it has done in practice on the issue of foreign fighters, on the issue of external border control or internal counter-terrorism controls. Yes, measures have been taken which affect the European Parliament, over and above our security, there is very little. Nothing has changed at airports, in controls, etc., and even the Declarations of Intent of the Arab League have not gone any further because there is no system of services, so it has not been possible to identify common objectives in terms of intelligence and coordination of both civil, political, intelligence and military interventions. Nothing done.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Madam Minister, I would like to congratulate you on the timely signing of the above-mentioned Memorandum of Understanding. Moreover, this strengthening of cooperation and strategic dialogue, embodied in the sharing of experiences, information and best practices, will of course result in the creation of institutional contact points to coordinate joint action in the desired intensification of mutual consultations, as well as in the establishment of joint working groups.  I also believe that, with this signature, an important step has been taken in the implementation of the UN global strategy in the fight against terrorism, which I would like to stress, because it is precisely through the creation of partnerships on an increasingly global scale and increasingly involving existing regional organisations that can be moved towards the effective implementation of this global strategy , which intends to act on an extremely complex reality, constantly changing, and increasingly well equipped in financial, logistical and technological terms.  I believe, in particular, that, within the framework of the European strategy to combat terrorism, greater coordination between Member States, EUROJUST, EUROPOL, and especially in operational terms should also be promoted.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I fully support this agreement, but when the High Representative tells the United Nations that we can both fight terrorism and respect human rights, the agreement represents a true test of those words. Will it lead to a review of anti-terrorist laws in the Arab countries so that they stop being used against legitimate journalists and human rights activists? How will our cooperation with security forces avoid complicity in human rights abuses in countries where there is use of the death penalty and credible evidence of the use of torture, and how will our cooperation seek to eradicate these practices? What will this cooperation achieve in ending the direct funding of terrorism by some of the states themselves, and will our dialogue have an equal emphasis on tackling root causes which allow terrorism to breed, to combat radicalisation abroad as well as at home, to recognise that repression aggravates terrorism, rather than preventing it? The terrorist threat is real and we want cooperation with the Arab States, but it is the terrorists who challenge the rule of law, and it is us who must always uphold it.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ECR).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for This memorandum of understanding was negotiated by officials and diplomats. Not one parliamentarian was involved. And this evening, at 10 p.m., we are talking and discussing this matter with 20 colleagues and 100 interpreters. The ECR Group has tabled an excellent motion for a resolution, and we are the only ones who have called for a balance between freedom and security in response to the terrorist threat. For a society must not give up its own freedom, it must not deprive itself of its freedom. Otherwise, the terrorists have already won. We should learn from the mistakes made in the United States. And the fact that the Greens, of all people, have tabled motions for deletion on this point shows once again that they are teletubbies on YouTube, but less so as pillars of a liberal social order. I wish you good luck in the implementation of this memorandum of understanding.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE).
text: – Today, terrorism is the greatest threat to the world. Under his ugliness are all citizens, regardless of their ethnicity and religious affiliation. I welcome the initiated diplomatic efforts with the League of Arab States to act in a comprehensive and coordinated manner against the threat of terrorism and extremist violence.  Madam Minister, the fight against terrorism must ensure full respect for international human rights standards. Sharing intelligence with third parties and creating tools to limit the financing of terrorist organisations are essential. I find the initiated proposal to establish the security atachet post of the European Union delegations as an opportunity for better coordination. Another instrument is to strengthen security cooperation in the renewed European Neighbourhood Policy.  In addition to establishing a European strategy to combat international terrorism, we need to deepen intercultural and inter-ethnic dialogue among all countries. This dialogue must take place both within and outside the European Union. I deeply believe that freedom is the backbone of security, and colorfulness and diversity are the foundation of every single freedom.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I have always spoken of the need to work with regional and local actors for conflict resolution — the threat of jihadist terrorism is no exception — but as long as these actors share our same objectives with facts without rhetoric. This memorandum is full of good purposes, but we must ask ourselves whether the League of Arab States sincerely shares our objectives. It could be that if it strongly condemns state terrorism and the pursuit of human rights; it could be that if it recognizes Syria as an interlocutor, because the destabilization of the West and this League of Arab States has been catastrophic for our security; it could be that if it requires Saudi Arabia to stop destabilizing neighbors or spreading Salafism and Wahhabism, apart from s stop funding terrorism; and it could be that if its members didn't arm terrorist organizations like the Islamic State. Are we sure about all this?

name: Judith Sargentini (Verts/ALE).
