text: Mr President, I have serious doubts about a treaty with the Arab League. A first reason is that Arab countries have the same barbaric practices, such as chopping off hands and giving canes, as Daesh. Reason two is that a lot of funding from extremists comes from Arab countries. And reason three is that countries like Saudi Arabia, but also think of Egypt, through the arbitrariness with which they treat their citizens and the regime of oppression they carry out, are promoting extremism.  I wonder for these three reasons how we can effectively pursue an anti-terrorism policy with the Arab League. As long as the text of this treaty is not known, I am not reassured.

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for My goal is to build a safe Europe. We must be able to live together in security and peace. Unfortunately, the majority of EU Member States do not act early enough on the radicalisation of young Muslims, but only act when the returning jihadist has already carried out his attack, promising to do everything possible to prevent terror from striking again. Madrid, London, Brussels, Paris, Copenhagen – what will be the next city? None if I may choose. Working with the Arab states, exchanging information and finding common security solutions is a good thing. Cutting off the supply of capital and weapons to ISIS-controlled areas is seen as a prerequisite for ending the merciless violence of jihadists. I do not believe, however, that we in the European Parliament can resolve the conflicts that exist between different interpretations of Islam. The reform of Islam must come from within. I believe in increased border protection, in PNR, in increased internal security and in a functioning legal society that arrests and condemns all those who wish to participate in terrorist acts, wars and attacks.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The Union now wants to fight IS terrorists together with the Arab League. That sounds good. But what does this Arab League stand for? Skepticism is warranted, because over the past 15 years, the league has shown a thoroughly inhomogeneous picture. The Assad family was dropped in 2011, Qatar emerged as a great friend of the Muslim Brotherhood in 2013, and Saudi Arabia, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates remain key sources of funding for ISIS, according to the Center for Arab World Research at the University of Mainz. The Washington Institute for Middle East Policy is also hearing similar things. However, the Jordanian king's visit to this house left a glimmer of hope with me. He spoke clearly and said that the basis of a successful fight against IS must be social justice and respect for other religions. However, whether this can work with Salafist Muslims in Saudi Arabia or anywhere else in the Emirates, who all play a double game, is quite questionable to me.

name: Victor Boștinaru (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to reaffirm to the Minister the importance of the cooperation between the EU and the League of Arab States in countering terrorism and to stress its utmost importance today when facing a series of highly disruptive terrorist activities all around the globe, which I strongly condemn.  I specifically call for the development of dedicated channels of communication and specific procedures for the periodic exchange of good practice in countering terrorism, and for timely appropriate information sharing. Furthermore, I strongly encourage an enhanced and comprehensive dialogue with moderate religious leaders, elites in the Arab countries, who should be promoted as a key actor in the stabilisation process of their societies.  Regarding the framework established through the Memorandum of Understanding, I would like to emphasise the need for closer co—operation in monitoring and cutting financing mechanisms dedicated to terrorist activities, in dismantling armed traffic networks and in adapting transparent guidelines and common standards for the transfer and exploitation of dual-use devices equipment.

name: David Campbell Bannerman (ECR).
text: – Madam President, the clear and present danger posed by returning European jihadist fighters is a real one and likely to persist for many years to come. The returning wave of extremist, Islamic fighters sends an undeniable message that counter-terrorism efforts have urgently to be reinforced across all Member States and in cooperation with the League of Arab States, particularly on security services – and that is a most helpful area. Further to this, I encourage all Member States to confront extremism by blocking hate preachers coming to their shores and by removing thousands of items from the internet that encourage or glorify terrorism. This is what the UK Government is striving to do. In my capacity as Chairman of the Delegation for relations with Iraq, I also welcome the words of King Abdullah of Jordan yesterday, as any counter—terrorism strategy to combat the evil of ISIL and other jihadist terrorist groups does need the full cooperation of Islamic nations through the League of Arab States. Without this support our Member States efforts to tackle Islamic extremism are greatly undermined.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD).
text: –  Madam President, King Abdullah said here yesterday that the crisis with Islamic State is an ideological battle that must be fought and won within Islam. He compared the IS threat to the Second World War, and described theirs as an expansionist ideology. He is quite right that it is not just a physical struggle, but an ideological war that can only be resolved in the Islamic world by the moderate Muslims defeating the extremists.  It is a fact, however, that a number of Islamic states fund IS and other extremist groups around the world. It is estimated that more than half the mosques and imams in the UK are funded by Saudi Arabia and Pakistan and these countries export their extremists to us. Christendom needs to recognise the threat to its culture and way of life and tackle it head on in our own lands. We cannot rely on the Arab League to do it for us.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). Madam President, the serious threat posed to the European Union by the war activities of ISIS jihadists and the crimes they commit not only in Middle Eastern countries, but also in European countries, require us to cooperate directly and closely with the countries of the Arab League trying to tackle terrorism. We must at all costs prevent terrorists from arriving in Europe. Italy, mainly because of its proximity to Libya, but also Greece and Spain, are ideal destinations for terrorists.  As you know, a large number of illegal immigrants arrive every day. So their traffic routes and landing coasts are known to illegal traffickers and can comfortably be exploited. Usually terrorists arrive in small groups, encounter cores that have already arrived in these countries, coordinate, and can cause chaos by attacking various targets.  I end by saying the characteristic statement of Gaddafi's cousin, who in a British blog said that among a thousand illegal immigrants 10 to 50 are terrorists. "In one to two years you will have a new 9/11."

name: Ελένη Θεοχάρους (
text: PPE). Madam President, the European Union's Memorandum of Cooperation with the Arab World is important and timely. Its implementation and the coordination of Member States in the fight against the nightmare of terrorism are crucial factors. Arab countries are at the forefront of terrorism, but they are also its first victims. That is why close cooperation and support is needed for those forces in the Arab world that are moderate and fight all forms of extremism.  I come from a small country that is in the crosshairs of ISIS, because it provides military facilities to those who fight terrorism and because the occupied part of Cyprus is a man of fanatical Islamists. We know very well what terrorism means and especially state terrorism, of which we are victims. Cyprus works closely with some Arab countries in the fight against terrorism and can be an advanced outpost of the European Union in the Middle East. But, as a central pillar of our policy in the war on terror, we must have the democratisation of the regimes of the Arab countries.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, cooperation with Arab countries is essential to help the partners concerned in the southern Mediterranean in formulating and strategies for counter-terrorism. We are able to offer our Arab partners our technical and operational expertise in order to develop the necessary monitoring and surveillance mechanism to have safer borders. I believe, however, that the European Union must also improve its relationship with regional Arab organisations, as well as the League of Arab States, and also with influential sub-regional forums. This applies in particular to the European Union's collective commitment to countries in serious internal conflict – I am thinking of Syria, Iran and Libya – and we are talking about related European collective policies that must be carefully coordinated with the general policy lines of the League of Arab States, underlining the need to maintain the security and territorial integrity of these countries. For all this, I believe that cooperation between the European Union and the League of Arab States is absolutely essential.

name: Dawid Bohdan Jackiewicz (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab "Naivety is the dumbest side of stupidity," once said a prominent Polish poet. I would like to ask you today why, in the face of such a great threat of international Islamic terrorism, today the European Parliament is itself a witness of extreme naivety? The European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the Union's relations with the League of Arab States in the field of counter-terrorism cooperation states, and I quote, 'the European Parliament welcomes the Memorandum of Understanding between the Union and the League of Arab States, which gives this dialogue and this cooperation a multilateral character'. Beautiful, but unfortunately empty words. In fact, this whole document consists of these terms: Parliament welcomes, stresses the importance, calls for cooperation, reiterates its importance, strongly condemns, calls. This is the whole content of the document that we are talking about today, which we are creating ourselves. Is this supposed to be our voice in the fight for Europe's security? It is, after all, an extremely naïve voice. What is our idea for an EU and European security policy? In the roar of successive exploding bombs, we try to find a quiet and calm angle, where we can calmly deepen our understanding of the problem.  Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur Is this really all we can afford in terms of the security of our continent?

name: Ramona Nicole Mănescu (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the key to defeating terrorism is a coordinated effort between all parties who are committed to peace and democracy. I am encouraged by the Memorandum of Understanding between the EU and the League of Arab States. I believe we must also work closely with the African Union and the Gulf Cooperation Council as well as the UN Counter-Terrorism Committee. But cooperation itself is not enough. It is essential that we cooperate effectively and intelligently with all our partners, sharing information about firearms trafficking and terrorist financing and learning from our previous mistakes. We must also see our counter-terrorist strategy as part of a bigger picture, fully integrated into our foreign and development policies, because to defeat terrorism we must also understand its underlying causes such as poverty, hopelessness and a lack of governance, which is essential to resolve these problems. We will defeat terrorism when we unite with our allies to offer a better future to the young men and women who are drawn to extremist groups, by drawing on our own European values and economic strengths.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her There is no other issue in this House that there is more agreement than that Daesh is an existential threat to our freedom and must be combated by all means. That is why it is also important to find allies, and the Arab League, whose states are still under much immediate threat, is arguably a very important partner in this. This memorandum is therefore to be welcomed. In the coming months, however, care must also be taken to ensure that the words are followed by appropriate action. Nor must we refrain from demanding that our partners respect democracy and human rights. This was also the case yesterday by Swedish Foreign Minister Margot Wallström at the Arab League meeting in Cairo. She was not allowed to give her speech at the intervention of Saudi Arabia. It would have said nothing more than that democracy, security and development are linked. It would have been good if her Arab colleagues had heard that too.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I welcome the Memorandum of Understanding signed by our foreign service with the General Secretariat of the Arab League.  Political dialogue and cooperation on security issues between Europe and the Arab League are key instruments in the fight against extremism and terrorism. As a member of the Development Committee, I would also like to highlight this dimension in this debate. The comprehensive European strategy against terrorism must make full use of the instruments of development cooperation, not only in the form of classic anti-poverty and inequality programmes, but also in more innovative initiatives to fight corruption and promote the rule of law and inclusive institutions.  In this way, our development policy will also contribute to a general effort to narrow the space for extremists who often try to legitimize their radical policies by impersonating fighters against corrupt regimes in the Arab world.  The current imperative to fight terrorism must not lead us to give in to respect for human rights and the rule of law in the countries with which we want to build a partnership against terrorism.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D).
text: – Madam President, terrorism is a global threat and only global cooperation can defeat the terrorist agenda and all those that support it. Calling for an alliance between Europe and the Arab States in a fight against terrorism is, therefore, vital. I welcome the recently signed Memorandum.  There are many Arab countries with good strategies for countering radicalisation and extremism and stopping terrorist funding. The UAE, for example established the Hedayah centre in Abu Dhabi. We do not have to reinvent the wheel; we can learn from their experiences. It is vital, however, that the cooperation avoids the mistakes of the past. The global war on terror after 9/11 involved measures that violated fundamental rights and international law. Respect for human rights and the rule of law must not fall victim to combating terrorism; these must be the bedrock of it. Many regimes have used repressive methods and emergency legislation to crush dissent. Repression re-provokes discontent and radicalisation, setting off a cycle of violence. Europe and the Arab League states must pursue a comprehensive counter-terrorism strategy that tackles the root cause of radicalisation, with particular focus on the economic and social situation of the younger generation in many of these countries. Young people must be inspired by values of mutual respect and inclusive society so that we stop the vicious cycle of violence. We need to work together as we are all facing the same threat.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE).
text: – Madam President, we have an expression in the Irish language – ‘ní neart go cur le chéile’ – which means ‘together we are much stronger’, and it is together, working with the League of Arab States, that we can defeat those who are intent on attacking our own way of life here in Europe. When it comes to the situation in Libya, to the Middle East peace process and to Syria and Iraq, we share a common interest in looking for long-lasting solutions to ensure regional peace and stability. It is together, working with the League of Arab States, that we can counter the threat that groups like ISIS pose to both the Middle East and the rest of the world. The rising threat posed by Islamic fundamentalists to our young people in Europe is a concern. Together with the Arab world, we are fully aware that this is not only a military fight but also a political and a cultural one. The question of how to de-radicalise and integrate the disaffected person is one of the key points on which our strategy focuses, and a primary point of focus for Parliament and the Commission is the fact that, of the approximately 10 000 foreign fighters in crisis regions, more than 3 000 radical Islamists are from Europe. Most of them are young men and they are travelling to fight in countries like Syria. The rise of ISIS makes it clear that there is no room for complacency among the international community when it comes to the growth of extremism among our young people. We must cooperate on security, intelligence, early warning protocols and counter—terrorism measures.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I am intending in catch—the—eye to make the point that the threat of the spread of terrorism is on the rise, and I would like to make the point of the conformity of every policy that is at stake with human rights and engagement of the European Union within the international community and the values which it stands for, the diplomacy when it comes to political dialogue, to setting a point on the accomplishment of compromises and engagement on international law, and the statements and resolutions that have been adopted by the United Nations. But the point I wanted to make is that we tend to overlook the threat against the Arab States themselves when it comes to international terrorism. It is a major threat and Iraq, Libya, Syria, every single state, has to be taken into account for their own efforts, when it comes to deploying diplomacy to the European Union.  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to express my satisfaction at the High Representative’s new approach to counter-terrorism cooperation between the European Union and the Arab states. It is clear that, terrorism being a global threat, it has to be faced together globally. This alliance of civilisations is a revolutionary means of establishing a common, strong position on open conflicts and ongoing crises. It could prevent the creation of bad new situations, for example in failed states where there is an increased danger of terrorism spreading. I believe it is important to support the moderate sections of Arab societies – those that are willing to be our allies in the fight against terrorism and that have the capacity to do the groundwork for the establishment of peace and security in the Arab countries. I truly hope that the dialogue with the Muslim communities in Europe, as well as in the rest of the world, can become the most powerful weapon for making the world a safer place for all.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, as jihadists strengthen their forces and become more aggressive and dangerous, the European Union's cooperation with the Arab League can help to reduce terrorism. But cooperation must not be left alone in security matters. It must be extended to the field of politics, the economy and society in the Arab states.  Cooperation between the European Union and the Arab League in the field of human rights will contribute to the democratisation of Arab states. In this context, the Council of Europe can also play a decisive role. Upgrading the position of women, protecting religious minorities and especially Christian communities, upgrading the role of civil society, reducing poverty and social exclusion will help to strike at the social causes that are throwing fertilizer at the development of jihadists. Finally, I repeat that Qatar and Turkey should be put before their responsibilities for their relations with the jihadists.  (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Colleague, do you really think that Arab states can be democratised easily? Do you really think that if we Europeans tell someone what democracy should look like, they will simply accept it?

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), "blue card" answer. – I do not argue that the European Union should be invasive in formulating standards in terms of democratisation and/or social behaviour and imposing them on the Arab states. It is certain, however, that with the osmosis that is being done there will be an expansion of democracy in the Arab states and this is very important.  Closing our eyes to violations of fundamental rights in arab states is wrong and that is something we must point out. However, our interventions should have the element of cooperation, not intervention.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Poverty and lack of prospects lead to terrorism, we have noted. The EU stands for values, for standards. But confidential cooperation with the Arab League is highly doubtful. The last 70 years, indeed the last 500 years, have actually been opposed. I think, however, that as far as human rights are concerned, we can play a pioneering role, we can be a role model. We still have, after 60-70 years, refugee camps in Jordan and Syria, where hundreds of children have just died of starvation in Syria last year. I think there is a need for action here, and we in the EU, through the UN, are primarily responsible here. It is funny, or indeed disgraceful, that we are constantly upset about others and demand respect for human rights and that we do not actually respect human rights at all.

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, together the European Union and the League of Arab States represent a quarter of the states in the international community. I will not hide the fact that multilateral engagement of this magnitude is a challenge. However, I do believe we have no choice. As friends, partners and neighbours, with a series of common threats before us, we need to seek overlapping areas of consensus and to forge stronger links between the European Union and the Arab world. I welcome your initiative in holding a discussion on the relations between the European Union and the League of Arab States. In a context of evident regional instability, it is essential to maintain the political visibility of relations between the European Union and the League of Arab States in exchanges like this one. I would also like to thank Members of the European Parliament for their constructive approach to the challenges faced in our region and in the Arab world. I understand that a Committee on Foreign Affairs report, prepared by rapporteur Mr Peillon, on security challenges in the Middle East and North Africa is in the making. This is very much in line with our commitment to closer cooperation with the League. Let me also mention that the European Union engages with the League of Arab States not only on security but also in numerous other fields. Since 2012, the European Union and the League of Arab States have shared a joint work programme on cooperation in many sectors. Let me mention just some of them: for example, women’s empowerment, where we engage in a programme jointly with the UN; and human rights, involving also the Council of Europe in streamlining human rights within the activities of the League of Arab States. In addition, the European Union and the League of Arab States are cooperating on election co-observation, focusing on consistent information-sharing regarding the selection of priorities, as well as capacity-building support to the League of Arab States election unit and enhanced cooperation among the respective missions deployed to observe elections in the region. We also engage in other fields, such as civil society and culture. So we can hardly say that relations between the European Union and the League of Arab States are too much security-driven. Several of you referred to the need to address root causes and to counter radicalisation. I would like to draw your attention to the very substantial Council conclusions adopted only last month, which include a clear reference to the underlying factors of radicalisation and the need to support initiatives in the areas of youth provision, education and vocational training, as well as the importance of facilitating interface and civil society dialogues. Several of you also spoke about the Memorandum of Understanding (MoU). Let me emphasise that the Memorandum of Understanding has been shared with the European Parliament and those in this House who have requested it. The MoU builds on the Athens Declaration. It is not the bedrock of relations between the European Union and the League of Arab States but rather a complementary instrument to ensure that the European External Action Service and the secretariat of the League of Arab States contribute to the successful development of EU—League of Arab States relations. The MoU will be made public, as requested by this House. To conclude, allow me to quote the wise words pronounced by His Majesty the King of Jordan in this Chamber when referring to the challenge posed by terrorism. He said: ‘Our victory now depends on our unity […] Only by co—operation can our regions shut down the sources of terrorist support and defeat their purposes.’

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. Strengthening military and security cooperation between the European Union and the League of Arab States is essential if we are to effectively combat the global terrorist threat and extinguish the hotbeds of jihadism. We must stand together if we are to block foreign fighters, dry up the sources of terrorist financing, stop arms trafficking and defeat the Islamic State group. We must also strengthen our political and cultural cooperation in order to curb jihadist propaganda and stop the recruitment of local and foreign fighters, but also to defend human rights and religious minorities in these regions. The signing of a Memorandum of Understanding between the European External Action Service and the League of Arab States and the announcement of the strengthening of the strategic dialogue between the Union and the League States on 19 January mark an important step in our commitment and our fight against terrorism.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on the rise of anti-semitism, islamophobia and violent extremism in the EU (2015/2595(RSP)).

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, our debate this evening is very timely. We all know that discrimination is one of the scourges of our society. We are shocked when extreme violence hits our front pages and television screens. But we all know that the problem is far more widespread. Ethnic and religious minorities, Jews and Muslims most obviously, are facing discrimination, harassment and violence and there are many reasons to believe this is getting worse.  A 2013 study by the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights showed that an overwhelming majority of Jewish respondents felt that anti-Semitism has increased over the past five years. Countries like Belgium, France and Hungary were mentioned in particular. There is more than anecdotal evidence to suggest that European Jews consider emigrating due to security concerns. This is wholly unacceptable. There is also growing evidence of discrimination and stigmatisation of Muslims as well as an increase in the number of Islamophobic incidents. In France a 53 % increase in individual attacks against Muslims was registered in 2014 compared to 2012. Since the Paris attacks a further spike in incidents has been observed. Violence seems more and more part of this extremism. In just a few years, we have seen fatal terrorist attacks in Toulouse, Brussels, Paris and Copenhagen. Such trends are fundamentally contrary to the traditions and values which have made Europe the society it is today. When negative stereotypes are fuelled in the media, in political rhetoric, in public rallies, those responsible are directly challenging the traditions of pluralism, inclusion and tolerance that lie at the heart of Europe, and of the European project. The fundamental values of freedom, diversity and respect for the equal dignity of all individuals cannot be compromised. So how can the EU itself help? Of course, our direct remit is limited, but we certainly need leadership and a clear message from its institutions. This Parliament, the European Council and the Commission all gave a full and unconditional defence of our values in the wake of the Paris attacks. But we must stay vigilant. We must show that we are for solidarity, to protect communities under pressure and to avoid stigmatisation. Stepping up actions aimed at preventing and combating extreme forms of racism, prejudice and intolerance should be a priority. The EU has specific legislation on combating racism and xenophobia by means of criminal law. The Commission acquired enforcement powers for this legislation in December last year. We have also adopted a Directive to support the victims of crime, including all victims of hate crime, which will enter into effect as of November this year. The Commission will prioritise the effective enforcement of both instruments. Phenomena such as hate speech online will also be examined in this context. In order to prevent violence, extremism and radicalised behaviours we also need to strengthen measures promoting social inclusion and cohesion. A priority in this context is to fill existing gaps in EU law on protection from discrimination. In 2008, the Commission proposed a directive on equal treatment, prohibiting discrimination outside the labour market, irrespective of disability, age, sexual orientation and religion or belief. It would extend this protection beyond employment, where EU legislation is already in force, to the areas of social protection, education and access to goods and services. This must now be taken forward into law. We must make the most of the programmes we have to help Member States to address the root causes. For example, the Europe for Citizens programme brings together both the critical memory of the past and civic engagement firmly rooted in shared values as a defining feature of vibrant democracy in European Union. Particularly important is our work to address radicalisation. We need to better understand why some people are drawn down a path so much at odds not only with European values, but with the beliefs of their own communities. That takes time and effort, but there are grass-roots actions in schools, prisons and community centres across the European Union, which are working to exactly this end.  The Commission offers support to such projects and helps others to learn from them. Within the Radicalisation Awareness Network local actors can exchange their experience and knowhow. Over 1 000 practitioners have now been involved over the last three years, resulting in concrete recommendations and hands-on support.  Promoting better interfaith and intercultural understanding also plays a crucial role. In May and June this year the Commission will organise high-level meetings with religious leaders and non-confessional organisations to discuss the issue of tolerance, respect and living together.  Finally, the Commission decided to devote its first ever Annual Colloquium on Fundamental Rights, scheduled for this October, to fostering tolerance and respect, with a focus on preventing and combating anti-Semitic and anti-Muslim hatred. Rising anti-Semitism, Islamophobia and extremism challenge the common values on which the European Union is founded. We must stand up to safeguard these values. As policymakers, political leaders, community and religious leaders, as well as citizens, we must make sure that all our communities can feel at home together and share the hope of a future in Europe, in order to give Europe a future.

name: Esteban González Pons
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, 'if Auschwitz could have existed for five years, then everything perverse is possible in this world'. These words were uttered on 27 January this year by former Polish imprisoner Alina Birenbaum in an act of tribute and remembrance of the victims of Auschwitz. The paris and Copenhagen attacks, the attack on the Jewish museum in Brussels, or the desecration of a Jewish cemetery in the east of France, are an example that something we are doing wrong, because those who commit these crimes do not come from outside, are born here and have been educated in our schools. It is not a problem of Palestinians and Jews: it is a problem, again, of Europeans and Jews. That is, of Europeans and Europeans who are Jews. If we do not act decisively, if we do not raise our voices, we run the risk that this 21st-century Europe will look like 20th-century Europe again. Those who attack a person for being Hebrew will attack us tomorrow for being Christians or being atheists. If we let the seed of intolerance germinate in our streets, whether we allow us to believe in God or not to believe in any god to be a reason for revenge, if we allow the preachers of hatred and heartbreak to become strong, then this Europe is doomed to suicide like that of the 1930s.  We need to educate future generations to understand what happened. We have to teach tolerance. We have to show that we learned from mistakes. We have to prove that the victims were not in vain. But in the meantime, if someone is going to want to mark the citizens again because they are Hebrews, then we must step forward and ask that the first ones we are marked be Members, because, as the Talmud says, "it is better to be among the persecuted than among the persecutors".

name: Claude Moraes
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I would first like to say that the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs will hold a hearing shortly on anti-Semitism, Islamophobia and hate speech in Europe. I hope that hearing will take place during the day, at a time when people will be present, and not at this intolerably late hour. I have spoken about this with my colleagues Ms Hohlmeier and Ms Wikström, and I am sure other colleagues from other political groups will find it quite extraordinary – and that, with all respect to you, Madam President, you will communicate with other colleagues about it – that the issue of the moment, anti-radicalisation, should be discussed, and our Commissioner, for whom I have the greatest respect, should deliver a communication on it and hear reactions, with virtually no one listening, and that it will be reported tomorrow to very few people. This is not tolerable. Why is it not tolerable? Because the issues we are discussing are so complex. We are discussing anti-Semitism, Islamophobia and an issue which really has not been discussed enough, anti—radicalisation. We all know that anti-Semitism and Islamophobia are issues of the deepest complexity. Jews and Muslims have existed for generations in Europe and the millions of Jews and Muslims in Europe, who now have to face the intolerable attacks which my colleague has described, are going about their daily lives and facing these issues because of a tiny minority. We know these issues are complex, but the job we have to do in the European Union is to see what competences we have to make lives better. We understand that, with the Race Equality Directive, the Council framework decision on racism and xenophobia and all these other tools, we have a job to do and we will do that job. However, anti-radicalisation is an issue which we are just beginning to understand. The European Union will have a role to play in this, and so will Member States. It is a deeply complex issue and, when we find out what it is all about, it will have to be discussed, not at the last minute – 11 o’clock – but among all of us, and not just in one committee but right across this House. When we have this discussion, it will cut across economy, culture and politics, and it will not be confined to one political group. This must be discussed right across the political spectrum, because Jews and Muslims will continue to live in the European Union together – that is how it will always be, whatever else will be said in this debate tonight – in unity. I hope that we will treat this issue much more seriously than we are doing tonight, and I am sure all my colleagues will agree. (Applause)

name: Jussi Halla-aho
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, interethnic and intercultural prejudice and violence are a serious and growing problem in Europe. If we wish to fight that problem effectively, we must avoid politically correct but inaccurate stereotypes. There is a tendency to lump together Jews and Muslims, as well as sexual minorities, as the victims. However, anti-Semitic violence, in particular, is most often perpetrated by Muslims in Western Europe, rather than by neo-Nazis. This is hardly surprising, given that hate speech and intolerance are quite common phenomena in many of the most popular mosques and other Muslim institutions in Europe. There is also Islamophobia in Europe, in the most literal meaning of the word: fear of Islam and Muslims. That fear is caused not only by terrorism but also by the generally poor integration of many immigrant Muslims in terms of European basic values and way of life.

name: Cecilia Wikström
text: On the other: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Like my colleague Claude Moraes, I regret that this debate takes place when this House is empty, when journalists have gone home to sleep or eat, listen to music or read a book. I regret that this important statement by the Commission, perhaps the most important thing that the Commission has made in a very long time, is not met with the attention it deserves. The recent anti-Semitic attacks in Paris and Copenhagen bear witness and speak for themselves. In my own country, Sweden, where we have a fairly good reputation internationally for the protection of minorities, Jews do not feel safe today. The media and opinion leaders are helping to strengthen the climate that prevails against Jews and many are not taken seriously when they express concern. A Swedish journalist recently asked a police officer in Malmö what the police are doing to combat the attacks on Jews, for example against the rabbi in Malmö, who has been repeatedly beaten and subjected to physical violence. The police then responded that the rabbi is so self-deprecent, referring to the rabbi wearing kippa and star of David and Jewish symbols. It has gone very, very far in Europe when the very police force that is supposed to defend every person's right to be who you are, sees it as something problematic that someone is Jewish. Many Jews in Sweden and other European countries are afraid today. They want to leave Europe. Then it is no longer the same Europe in which we live. They have been met with incomprehension and accusations. We have all failed to create security and safeguard freedom of religion, and we must recognise that today. It's happening right in front of our eyes. We must stop turning a blind eye to the reality faced by our religious minorities today.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, antisemitism, Islamophobia and violent extremism are particular forms of racist culture and behaviour that result, in their most extreme consequence, in denial of the very human status of the targets of hatred. All the political forces in this Chamber must condemn in the strongest possible way these abhorrent phenomena and all their manifestations in the present and in the past, such as the holocaust of the Jews by Nazi criminals in the second world war.  Public condemnation and criminal punishment of racism is a prerequisite for Europe not to relive similar dramas in the future. I must point out, however, that racism has many manifestations and that some of them begin in a somewhat covert way. One example is the targeting of the Greek people in recent weeks by the German newspaper Bildzeitung, with unacceptable designations such as for "greedy" Greeks and the like. The cultivation of hatred between peoples begins with small seeds, and in order to eradicate them, we need to condemn, unseizablely, all the perpetrators of the sowing of the havoc.

name: Ska Keller
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, anti-Semitism, Islamophobia and racism are no new phenomena in Europe, and they are an internal problem – not something brought to us from the outside. This is a problem that we have to deal with inside the European Union and, sadly, these attacks on people are on the rise. Jews are being attacked, and even schools cannot operate without police or army protection. Certainly, this sort of protection is nothing that generates a feeling of security among people. Quite the opposite: it shows how much insecurity there is. We see in Europe that parties are being founded on the basis of Islamophobia and of racism. It is appalling to see that parties and politicians are able to gain votes with those ideas, and equally appalling to see that there are politicians trying to do exactly that. I believe we all have to stand together against anti-Semitism, against Islamophobia, against racism and against xenophobia, and we have to do so very clearly, and be prepared to do so at every moment, in order not to accept any form of mistreatment of human beings. It is therefore important that we do not legitimise the arguments of the extreme right or give them any space to manoeuvre, because in Europe we have a lot of space for different religions and we have a lot of space for people from different origins. Europe is built on the idea that we live together, that we progress together and that we are all working together for human rights, peace and understanding. Europe has no space for anti—Semitism, Islamophobia, or racism – and we all need to make sure that it stays that way.

name: James Carver
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, as the grandson of a Polish Jew who fled his home town of Oświęcim, latterly infamously known as Auschwitz, at the beginning of the last century, I say that the time has come to face up to the reality of anti-Semitism today. With Western European Jews being shot in schools, museums and places of worship, we need to be honest with ourselves about the root cause of this cancer. Since the despicable murders in Paris, attacks on British Jews have risen threefold. Political correctness and multiculturalism have failed. With thousands of Jews now fleeing Europe, what does this say for our liberal and tolerant values? They said 75 years ago that enough is enough. I am now saying that it is unacceptable that synagogues are increasingly looking like Fort Knox. As Edmund Burke once wrote, ‘For evil to happen, good men must do nothing.’ Enough is enough.

name: Hans Jansen (NI).
text: – Mr President, Islam teaches that the Koran is the literal word of God. The Koran now orders us to fear Islam. In Koran 8, verse 60, Muslims are called upon to do everything possible to scare people who are not Muslim. But what do we hear now from the Organization of Islamic Cooperation and the like? That organization is running a campaign that wants us to feel guilty about our legitimate fear of murderers like those at Charlie Hebdo. If we do what the Koran says, we fear Islam, then it is also not good.  The Islamophobia campaign is part of a psychological warfare against all and everyone who is not yet a Muslim. Members of the European Parliament, members of the European Commission, do not be fooled. The Koran commands us to fear Islam. Islamophobia is simply an order of the Koran.

name: Monika Hohlmeier (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has First of all, I would like to join In his protest against a decision by the Bureau to put key issues such as anti-Semitism, Islamophobia and the fight against extreme violence and intolerance in our society on the agenda at eleven o'clock at night. We really wanted to send a common, bipartisan signal against intolerance in our society, which the public should see, because we actually agree with each other and do not need to tell ourselves at eleven o'clock at night. Now, at eleven o'clock at night, there is not a single journalist left. I would ask that this really be taken into account in future in the Bureau's decisions. Because we will stop meeting tomorrow at 11 a.m. I therefore wonder whether it makes a great deal of sense to discuss this issue today from 11 a.m. to 12 p.m. On the point itself: prejudices against Jews, hate speeches by imams calling for the death of non-believers and the perpetuated sexual availability of women for men, people who flatly denigrate Muslims, radicalisation of people from many backgrounds and for many reasons – we have a wave of intolerance moving through Europe, we have a wave of radicalisation moving through Europe. We must take consistent steps together towards positive integration, a strategy for understanding each other, a strategy of dialogue between religions and tolerance among believers, of accepting one another in a society. I call for us, in all our various measures that we are taking, to take concrete steps to promote a genuine tolerance of a genuine nature within our societies and Member States and to hold to account those who are trying to do the opposite.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D).
text: Madam President, today we are making a very difficult observation, that of the rise of anti-Semitism, of Islamophobia, of violent extremism.  If history reminds us how the various forms of racism and discrimination persist through the centuries, the racism that is developing today is devious. In addition to violence and other attacks, it is also the scope of racist discourse that we must point the finger at. The barely hushed allusions, the small sentences and other insidious forms of expression are more and more trivializing an uninhibited racist word, than it is expressed in the street, in political debate, in the media or on the internet and social networks. Uninhibited discourse has thus entered the public debate. It drags in its wake a lot of fears and simplistic recipes that twist reality in the service of an ideology.  In this context, political leaders have, of course, a special responsibility. While they must, of course, provide answers to overcome the economic and social crisis, prejudices and marginalization, they are more than ever responsible for condemning racist remarks and promoting constructive intercultural dialogue.  In this public speech, the media also have a role to play, essential in promoting mutual understanding between different religious, cultural and traditional communities. The media must resist stereotypes and shortcuts that are as false as they are dangerous.  The European Union has introduced and initiated a wide range of measures to combat the various forms and manifestations of racism and xenophobia, but is this sufficient to counter racist hate speech? What are the means available today to combat the growing phenomenon of verbal violence on the internet? More broadly, as it did in 2011 to promote the development of national Roma integration strategies, is the Commission considering proposing a framework for national strategies to comprehensively combat the different forms of racism and discrimination affecting a particular community?

name: Bas Belder (ECR).
text: Mr President, we must recognise honestly the evils of anti-Semitism in Europe and fight it together vigorously. For this, I think the appointment of an EU special envoy is urgently needed. Council and Commission - and I see Commissioner Hahn in person here - I ask you to seriously consider this proposal. It goes without saying that jewish communities need to be continuously and actively involved in the fight against anti-Semitism across Europe. Equally self-evident, I believe that fellow citizens of Jewish descent can live a life without fear in all EU Member States. That is our current personal and collective task, regardless of the timing of this debate. It is absolutely not a matter of Jewish communities having to carry their safety at their own expense. Their well-being, literally and figuratively speaking, is really too precious.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE).
text: Madam President, in Brussels, in Paris, in Copenhagen in museums, in hypermarkets, in synagogues, in the streets, in stadiums, in the four corners of Europe, we despise, hate, we assault, we kill Jews because they are Jews. Racism is abhorrent, all racism is reprehensible, make no mistake, but in Europe today, Jews are the only Europeans to die for what they are. Anti-Semitism is not the problem of the Jewish community, it is a cancer of our society as a whole, a cancer with multiple causes that it would be naïve or even perverse to reduce to the only conflict of the Middle East, to Israel: who can think for a second that a solution there would erase in us a thousand-year-old hatred?  The anti-Semitism of the Islamofascists has been shared by all the fascisms of history; the difference is that today, speeches and images have an effect multiplied and globalized by the power of the internet. It is this reality that we must combat by education, again and again, by raising awareness of the major players on the web and also by strengthening our laws.  The 28 do not all condemn anti-Semitic and racist acts, speeches and parties; there are elected Nazis in our Parliament, and I think we could start there.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, yes, for several years a climate of hatred and violence has been rising in the European Union. The rejection of the other is an easy worst-case in times of economic, social and political crisis. Racism must all be fought together, without hierarchy, at the risk of seeing them exploited against each other. They each have their own story, but are all fueled by the same fantasies and many stereotypes, and often go hand in hand. Anti-Semitism and Islamophobia feed on each other.  Since the attacks in New York, Muslims have become increasingly stigmatized and, with them, all those who do not have the right skin color, whether they are believers or not. Women are particularly affected. The majority of them and of them are European citizens and have lived in our territories for a long time in peace. The issue of migrants is being confused. We're trying to make people believe in the clash of civilizations. We see behind each of them a fundamentalist, even a terrorist, as if Islam was in itself a carrier of radicalism. They are being asked to dissociate themselves from acts of terrorism committed in the name of their faith, even though it is being hijacked, as King Abdullah II said so well yesterday. They are the new dangerous classes and, unfortunately, many governments are participating in this stigma.  I am an atheist, I defend freedom of conscience and therefore the freedom to believe or not to believe, the separation of religion and politics, but also the right to freely criticize religions, whatever they may be, as any opinion. These values are the key to "living together."

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE).
text: – Madam President, when a Jew is beaten, humanity falls to the ground. In Paris we hear, once again, the infamous cry of "Death to the Jews!". Cartoonists have been killed for drawing, cops for being cops and Jews simply for shopping and being Jewish. In 2012, three Jewish schoolgirls and a rabbi were shot dead in Toulouse. Also, at the Jewish Museum in Brussels, a jihadist attacked and killed three people and seriously wounded another. Verbal attacks, fire bombs, desecration of cemeteries, children afraid to go to school: hostility towards Jews is growing like never before. For religious prejudices, also racial, ethnic and cultural. Anti-Semitism is one of the oldest forms of prejudice known to humanity. We are facing a threat which will last in the short and long term, and which will not even overcome the most eloquent speeches we make in this Parliament or the most symbolic acts. I have attended many acts related to the Holocaust, in which we have wept for the dead and murdered Jews, to which, unfortunately, we cannot bring life back. We have built in Europe and we are the benchmark of democracy, pluralism, tolerance and dignity. Let us give up the voice, then, to defend these noble values. We have a responsibility that is individual, but it is also collective. I call on the Commissioner, and also the Commission and this Parliament, to make policies more proactive. Europe and its values are being attacked. The European Union should discuss and approve a special plan, a comprehensive action plan, which was monitored and recorded. And also, appoint a responsible person, identify someone to follow up. It's not just an attack on Jews or Muslims. It is a full-rule onslaught of Europe and its values. Let us never mix anti-Semitism with the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. It's a crude excuse. It's up to us to take the floor and act.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the rise and rise of anti-Semitism in Europe must be taken very seriously and must be singled out as an object of debate by this European Parliament. Undoubtedly, the abject management of the crisis and the exasperation of inequalities have something to do with the resurgence of this trend, of this European querence, of seeking old demons and scapegoats.  But there is a certainly worrying combination of at least three elements that are explaining this rise of anti-Semitism. First, the entrenched old prejudice of far-right sectors and the more conservative and nationalistic thinking that Jews are guilty.  Secondly, without a doubt, the increase in this jihadism, of this Islamist radicalization, which, once again, once again demonizes anti-Semitic prejudice.  And thirdly, the feeling of impunity with which some are cowardly covered up on social media and on the internet to download hate speech.  We are facing a very worrying situation which has made police surveillance again in synagogues, that there is a sense of concern and in Jewish schools in kosher supermarkets or Jewish schools, and that many European Jews and Hebrews are thinking again, as at the worst times of the 20th century, of having to leave the European continent and seek refuge somewhere else.  This threat must therefore be taken very seriously: the first alert has been expressed by the European Agency for Fundamental Rights, which has pointed out that this evil cannot be trivialized and that it must be taken very seriously. It has warned of the increase in anti-Semitic sentiment throughout Europe and therefore has to be identified as a phenomenon in an honest and objective way, which must also be objectively objective. A relevant legal definition must be found in European law that anti-Semitism consists of; but, on the other hand, it has to be prioritized by this European Parliament.  It has to be identified as a problem for Europe for Jews to be invited to emigrate from the European Parliament again; a European task force on this problem of anti-Semitism must be formed; and it has to be revealed that we cannot allow the loss of historical memory to make... (The Chairperson interrupts the speaker)

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, today is European Day for victims of terrorism. It coincides with the anniversary of the train attacks in Madrid eleven years ago. Well, today, in France, the military protection of Jewish shops and kosher food continues. When everyday gestures must be protected, the situation is really serious. We are obliged to seek security, but we must also combat hate speech, which leads to anti-Semitism, Islamophobia or violent terrorist fanaticism. The essence of fanaticism is in the will to force others to change. Fanaticism is older than great religions or ideologies, as The Israeli writer Amos Oz pointed out. In the 21st century, these are some of the faces of evil. But we cannot let speeches that generate group identity from hatred continue to grow in Europe to those who think or live differently. And the viralisation of fanatical identity must be fought specifically in the children and young people of the European Union. That's as important as police or military protection. And the viralization of democratic identity must also be provided by educational curriculums. Commissioner, we are talking about European citizenship in this Parliament, but we must act essentially to protect it.

name: Cornelia Ernst (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In my home town of Dresden a few years ago, an Egyptian Muslim woman was stabbed 17, in the middle of a courtroom. The Dresden Synagogue must be protected from smears every day by the police. Anti-Semitism and Islamophobia are unfortunately everyday forms of racism. And they must also be combated in the knowledge that they are. As we all know, this is not primarily about religion, but about the stigmatisation of people, their group-based exclusion, degradation, degrading, degrading, which practically erases their individuality, even the individual. The most perverse form was Auschwitz. The lesson of Auschwitz is to ensure that the exclusion of all people is combated and that the human rights of every human being are truly fought for and defended. Let us finally begin to eliminate the social and economic causes of racism. Social cohesion must once again be taken seriously in the EU. Finally, as long as right-wing extremists and right-wing populists incite resentment and racism in this House, the call for an effective fight against anti-Semitism and anti-Islamism remains an empty word. We must therefore clean up here in this House too!

name: Heinz K. Becker (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to begin by saying that it is extremely regrettable that, in view of the dramatic increase in anti-Semitic incidents in Europe, no specific resolution can be discussed today, because our colleagues from the Socialists and Greens have prevented this. I find that very regrettable! Let us remember that the number of anti-Semitic incidents doubled in 2014, that Jewish Europeans fear physical attacks, that Jewish events are shunned, because visitors do not feel that Jews in Europe, for fear of discrimination, do not indicate that more and more of these Europeans are leaving Europe because they see their lives threatened. I call on the European Commission to take infringement proceedings against those EU Member States that have still not fully implemented the 2008 Framework Decision. I call for EU laws against hate speech and hate speech to be amended and tightened up. For what many imams give of themselves must be stopped! I call for a massively stepped-up dialogue between cultures and religions to launch an offensive and financial resources from the Commission and the Member States in order to remove both right-wing and leftist radicals and, of course, radical Islamists. That is why I am calling specifically for an EU action plan against anti-Semitism and extremism in Europe, because that is the only way we will protect European values of freedom and respect.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D).
text: – Madam President, my fellow Members have repeatedly referred to the spread of anti-Semitism. But let me ask you today, World Victims of Terrorism Day, do we still remember the victims? Remember the three little kids who lost their lives in Toulouse? Remember the paris victims? Remember the victims outside the Jewish museum in Brussels? Not really, I'm afraid. I'm afraid we're going to forget about these murderous assassinations very quickly. Today we are at the heart of the fear of our Fellow Jews in Europe in their daily lives because they are subjected to physical and verbal atrocities. You, Commissioner, have alluded to the dramatic increase in anti-Semitic expressions against Jews in France, England and, I might say, in many European countries. And when we look for reasons, we point both to Islamic fundamentalism and to another subject that we do not like to talk about, and that is far-right ideology. We do not like to talk about the fact that today in Europe there are governments that claim to be democratic and are willing to join forces with far-right forces in order to retain power. In my country, Hungary, such a government is in power right now. I think that we now need to realise that anti-Semitism is not only the ideology of the far right, but also appears in the middle of society. Anti-Semitic authors are included in school textbooks, and people in their daily lives are increasingly willing to accept that we must behave differently to Jews than to our fellow citizens. And we are the reason for this, because we refuse to face with ruthless sincerity what we should face: that we are not always in solidarity enough, that we do not stand up for others, that we do not speak up, that we turn our eyes to each time, but that we do not face atrocities against our Fellow Jews. I join all those who say that the European Parliament must take a much stronger step and establish a 'task force' to resist anti-Semitism.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I would like to take this speech to denounce the ons of Islamophobic speeches in this Parliament, which are still xenophobic discourses. An example: on 15 January, Front National Meps Aymeric Chauprade made statements here in the European Parliament, speaking of a supposed Islamisation of France and Europe and linking Islam and terrorism. His main thesis is that democracy is not compatible with Islam.  It is a hate speech, whose sole purpose is to fuel intolerance and violence. These are statements made in this Parliament, using audiovisual resources of the Eurochamber. From the United Left we asked President Schulz to impose the appropriate sanctions, but unfortunately it was not done. By not sanctioning such xenophobic behaviour, this Parliament is giving wings to the far right and intolerance.

name: Michał Boni (PPE).
text: – Madam President, after the holocaust experience, what is the background of modern anti-Semitism and the new phenomenon of Islamophobia? Very often it is detached from reality. There is only a small real Jewish community in Poland now, but there are many examples of using negative attitudes oriented at people defined as hostile. The symbol of those negative emotions is related to the expression ‘Jews’. But in many places in Europe, the real Jews are attacked. What is wrong with our culture that Jews, and, in the near future, Muslims can become the stereotype of personalised evil? The Internet disseminates hate speech of all kinds; the texted and tweeted words are very often devoid of responsibility and identity. What do we need to do? Firstly, we should react. The most dangerous response is social and political neutrality. Secondly, we should be active witnesses of the incidents that occur and talk about them publicly. Thirdly, with respect to freedom of expression, we should act using legal tools. Fourthly, we need some campaigns, such as no hate speech. Fifthly, we need educational programmes which will build freedom, respect and openness vis-à-vis the imposed spiral of violence. The danger is that when words turn into hate speech they begin to burn because of somebody’s idea of religion, race and ethnic origin or only because of personal background. We have to stop it. If we do not, let me use the metaphor: those hate words will burn people, as was the case in our history.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, I fear that every day we will bring a little more great rifts in our societies because, you see, it is a diabolical mechanism that is being put in place. It is dividing our societies, and this trap that is closing in on our democracies, we must at all costs thwart it. The safest way to thwart it is to stand with our values, to fight with the utmost firmness against all racisms and to fight with the same vigour the religious fanatics and fascists who, we know, commonly thrive. Then, as Commissioner Hahn said, it is also about making culture prevail over ignorance.  The bottom of the air in Europe is now irrespirable, and we know all too well what it announces. It heralds the worst because, in this European continent, we know how monsters form and can be reborn, but we also know how to fight them. This is the fight we are called to today.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Personally, I am very concerned about the growing attacks against the Jewish population in the EU.  In Belgium, the number of attacks has increased by 40% in the past year and even doubled in France. I do not want anyone to be afraid to live in the EU. I don't want Jews leaving the EU out of fear. Their exit from Europe would be a loss for all of us. Ladies and gentlemen, an attack on the Jews is an attack on ourselves. Just like any attack on anyone who is Muslim.  We must do our utmost to ensure the protection and security of Jews in Europe. As the King of Jordan said in this hall, "Islam is a religion of peace." So did Christianity, Buddhistism and other religions. I would therefore like to call on all Muslims living inside and outside the EU to do their best to ensure that there is a peaceful coexistence with all the populations in Europe and in the world.  In the first letter of St. John, in the 14th chapter of the eighth verse, it is said, "He who does not love does not know God, because God is love." Ladies and gentlemen, religion is about love, religion is about coexistence, religion is about fighting hate. He who says otherwise is not telling the truth.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, Jews, Muslims, Christians and atheists. Immigrants and natives. All of them, very little useful labels to explain reality and, therefore, to improve it. Today, millions of people are suffering from a social, economic and vital emergency in Europe. An emergency that is also avoidable. And that it is clear responsibility of 1% of the privileged who have decided that their narrow interests must take precedence over the dignity and safety of the other 99% of the humble people, of ordinary people. These are the labels that explain the disaster and indicate possible solutions: oligarchy and village, those above and below, 1% and 99%. When some irresponsiblely use other labels that explain nothing and point to the latter as to blame for the penultimate's ills, let us think of who benefits from hatred and smokescreen.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE).
text: Madam President, three years ago, almost to the day, in Toulouse, French children were killed outside the Ozar Hatorah school because they were Jewish.  There was the Jewish Museum in Brussels, there was the synagogue in Copenhagen, there was the double murder of a French couple who lived in Créteil, in the Paris region, there was of course, of course, and it moved all of Europe and beyond the world, the horrific and cowardly attacks in Paris and the tragedy of the Jews killed in the kosher supermarket.  Of course, we must strongly denounce the rise of anti-Semitism, of violence directed against the Jews who live in our territories. We must call for the awakening of consciences, we must work to strengthen our arsenal of protection of our humanist and European values, which we believe to be universal values. We must work to coordinate our efforts to combat and affirm our solidarity, compassion and sympathy for all the Jews of Europe, who are currently, on the territory of the Union, the most persecuted community, most exposed to murder, discrimination and stigma because of its religion.  But let us not underestimate the seriousness of the rise of Islamophobia, all forms of racial hatred and religious hatred. It is really about hatred and human stupidity, and there are weapons, of course, and a repressive arsenal that we need to put together and strengthen, but above all, I believe, there is education and the duty of remembrance. There is filthy ignorance and guilty ignorance of what the history of Europe has been, of a number of facts that have upset our continent and marked our consciences.  We need to develop education, memory must be awakened. Tolerance education, of course, education to the acceptance of the other. Education is one of the levers to fight stupidity and hatred.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE).
text: – At the end of January, we marked the 70th anniversary of the liberation of concentration camps.  The greatest tribute to the six million victims of the Second World War Holocaust would be understanding and peaceful coexistence. Instead, today we are once again seeing an increase in anti-Semitism in Europe. The rise of extremist ideologies poses the greatest threat to democracy, it is a threat to the people of the European Union, to our way of life, to the values and freedoms on which the European Union has arose and is based today.  That's why it's important that we do everything we can to keep it in the bud. Each of us is responsible for the fight against intolerance, xenophobia and anti-Semitism. The pursuit of more tolerance and participation in society is a must-take for both political actors and civil society, but this is the only real and possible path. I believe we will succeed.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D).
text: – Mr President, we have seen an increase in anti-Semitism, Islamophobia and violent extremism. These worrying trends must be equally addressed by the EU. Anti-Semitism is not new in Europe and unfortunately it is still a reality for many European Jews. Similarly, Muslims are experiencing hate harassment, violence and discrimination. There is a need for EU legislation. Preventive legislation must be put in place through passing tougher laws. The Commission should propose a framework for national strategies to combat discrimination in a comprehensive way and to promote full inclusion.  There is a crucial need for interfaith dialogue and cooperation. I have seen the success of this work in my own home town, Manchester, where Jewish and Muslim communities are working together to combat hatred and discrimination. Anti-Semitism and Islamophobia cannot be seen as a Jewish-Muslim problem, but rather a European issue jeopardising the democratic fundamental rights and the values of all EU citizens. Embracing diversity is the only way forward if we are to find hope.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR).
text: Madam President, Commissioner Hahn, I would like to thank commissioner for his excellent work and for her excellent work. Let us speak of facts and figures! ISIS has threatened, killed, burned scriptures, destroyed historical monuments. Boko Haram has threatened Christians and even kidnapped children. I think it is difficult to talk about individual perpetrators. We had choirs of screaming women in front of our Parliament in Brussels, shortly after Jews were shot dead in Brussels. In this respect, one simply has to let figures speak for themselves. Of course, the number of terrorist attacks has increased. Unfortunately, 99% of terrorist attacks are perdide. To say now that anti-Semitism can in any way be equated with Islamophobic acts and violent extremism is out of all proportion. We should not be in a false tolerance and we should not talk about the facts, because here in Parliament, far too often, perpetrators are victims and ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, the fact that few want to recognise is that the rise in anti-Semitism is in direct relation to the rise in fundamentalist Islam. There are many verses in the Koran calling on Muslims to make war on unbelievers. Egypt’s Minister of Religious Endowments reportedly said in March 2014 quoting from the Hadith ‘We hope that the words of the Prophet Muhammad will be fulfilled: ‘Judgment Day will not come before the Muslims fight the Jews, and the Jews will hide behind the rocks and the trees, but the rocks and the trees will say: O Muslim, O servant of Allah, there is a Jew behind me, come and kill him’.  If you want to understand the rise in anti-Semitism, that is a good place to start. There is some hate speech for you. Now regarding Islamophobia, a phobia is defined as an irrational fear. Many people have a perfectly rational fear of fundamentalist Islam. Would you deny them the fear that leads to self-preservation?

name: Franz Obermayr (NI).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Phobia: so almost morbid fear of Islam! I have believed that the days when people who are concerned about human rights violations, who are concerned about religious intolerance, have been called sick are over. When someone criticises calling him sick, it reminds me of the knitting patterns and mechanisms of Nazi era and communism. We should not be hypocritical here, should openly mention the problems that exist with Islamism in Europe. We should also work with moderate Muslims and listen to them as partners. I know many committed, tolerant Muslims and appreciate their courage. Some of these intellectuals are threatened with death by their brothers in faith by fatwa. We should also be concerned about this. We should stand by these courageous fellow citizens and openly call things by their names!

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for this interesting debate. Unfortunately, as has been said by many of you, it is at a very late hour on an issue which goes to the very heart of our Union. Extremism – whether political or religious – requires a robust response from all those who believe in a free, open, tolerant and diverse democracy. The Irish statesman, Edmund Burke once said that ‘the triumph of evil is dependent on good people being silent’. We all – as authorities, as individuals – have a responsibility to ensure that all Europeans, whatever their background, whatever their religion, feel at home in Europe. As the guardian of the treaties which enshrine our fundamental values and principles – human dignity, tolerance, the rule of law, equality and fundamental rights – the Commission will do all it can within its powers and together with Member States to combat the scourges of racism and xenophobia. We all know that laws are only as good as the extent to which they are enforced and implemented in practice. This has prompted the Commission to prioritise actions aimed at ensuring that Member States not only introduce legislation to counter terrorism, racism, xenophobia and hate crimes, but also actively and effectively ensure its enforcement on the ground. Parliament will remain a key partner for the Commission in taking these actions forward, so we count on your support and I hope there will be another opportunity to discuss this issue at a more appropriate and visible time. (Applause)

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. – History shows us that the road to tolerance in Europe has been long and tortuous, of sensitive balances and small advances. The lack of religious tolerance in particular fills much of the darkest pages in our history. Today, fortunately, 28 peoples united in diversity embody a territory that is founded on tolerance and that does not tolerate aggression to this freedom. Recently, the attacks in Paris were intended to threaten another pillar of our community: freedom of expression. They were not attacks in the name of faith, carried out by Muslims or Jews, were criminal acts perpetrated by radicals. We cannot therefore allow these acts to poison our most fundamental values. As the King of Jordan reminded us, the future is based on unity and respect, not on division and stereotypes. The Union and its political actors, but also the Member States and their leaders, have special responsibilities. The discourse must be one of respect and tolerance for minorities, and concrete action: in awareness, education, prevention and sanctioning. We should not take anything for granted, but on the contrary, have the notion that the preservation of our values requires permanent work.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. Anti-Semitism and Islamophobia go hand in hand. Far-right groups have gradually replaced the former, the second. Today, the main perpetrators of anti-Semitic and terrorist violence attacks are no longer right-wing extremists, but radicalised elements in Muslim communities in Europe: Muslim anti-Semitism. It is a result of the social exclusion suffered by Muslims and international politics. In this sense, ISIS only offers an identity to those who have always been marginalized and discriminated against. The proposals put forward by the Jewish community (the european-whole ban on wearing the full veil) are not long-term and constructive solutions. We need interreligious dialogue, joint civic initiatives, integrated schooling and more inclusive governance structures. Muslim leaders must fight an anti-Jewish mentality as actively as European Jews must help dispel the falsehoods that fuel Islamophobia: this is the way to beat the twin threats of anti-Semitism and Islamophobia.  Europe can and must play a key role in this dialogue and the creation of mutual tolerance and the promotion of a civic culture. Let us think in this direction.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. – Extreme liberalism and illegal migration have allowed a clash of civilizations in the centre of Europe. On the one hand, the European Christian civilization, and on the other, determined to impose their order and rules of the Saafites. The increase in extremist attacks and increasing anti-Semitism are a direct result of the spread and preaching of radical Salaphitic Islam. The best example of this is the attacks in Paris, where radical Islamists born and raised in France shot dead 17 people, four of them Jews. Today, there is no Islamophobia in Europe, but different opinions and freedom of expression. Movements such as PEGIDA are europeans' response to attempts to change the image and spirit of Europe. Europe is founded and built on Christian values and only by preserving them can it survive.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. – The attacks in France and Denmark are an attack on European fundamental values, especially the fundamental ones: that of life and freedom. At the base of these attacks we find hatred of the other. Again, the Jewish population is among those who are subjected to such attacks and hatred. Unfortunately, in Europe we know better than anyone how far anti-Semitism can lead. That is why we have a special responsibility and commitment to our Jewish citizens, who must enjoy the highest protection on the part of states. Jihadism is a very real threat to them, but also to the Muslim population itself, which is not only the victim of attacks but also sees a daunting persons shed a distorted image of the faith they profess. Let's not fall for the mistake of taking the part at all. We combat terrorism and violent extremism and foster the coexistence of all those who want to live in peace and in accordance with European values to which we are unwilling to renounce.

name: Alyn Smith (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – Europe is facing an enormous challenge of reacting to racial tensions as we witness the rise of both anti-Semitism and Islamophobia. At a time when tensions are running high, our duty is to stand up to closed-minded prejudices, and we must remember not to lose ourselves in statistics but to tackle the real causes of these problems. While attitudes towards Muslims are negative across Europe, we’ve also seen anti-Jewish sentiment growing steadily and it has to be addressed. We need to be vigilant within our communities and not allow for anti-Jewish sentiments to develop just as much as we need to protect Muslims from damaging anti-Islam discourse. It should also be noted that the European Network Against Racism has called on the European Parliament to create a database to assess the rise of Islamophobia as we lack statistics on this, while legal tools have been created in various Member States to fight against anti-Semitism. We must collate all evidence of all hate crime on the same basis if we are to tackle all such prejudice effectively.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. – The European Union was not based on the values of anti-Semitism, Islamophobia or violent extremism. Yet in recent months, in the heart of the EU, we are facing precisely these challenges. In the case of phenomena that we strongly reject and condemn, the zero tolerance rule should apply, as they are incompatible with the values of respect for human dignity, rights, freedom, equality and non-discrimination. The wave of anti-Semitism is a pan-European problem that needs to be addressed in a coordinated manner. I therefore welcome the High Representative's support for the idea of the European Jewish Congress on the establishment of an EU working group to combat anti-Semitism, which should be composed of both MEPs, members of the European Commission and representatives of civil society. In recent years, intercultural dialogue has become an important element of THE EU's action and is one of the key weapons in tackling extremism. Although the European Union has quite a few levers to combat anti-Semitism and violent extremism, particularly through legislation, financial support and dialogue, we should be much more bold in tackling these problems. Last but not least, let us not forget education, which is a key preventive approach in the fight against anti-Semitism. Member States should strengthen citizenship education in schools, which would also include education on religions, thus eliminating ignorance. Perhaps this could have prevented the horrific events we have witnessed in recent months.
